author: Patricia M.

description: Heard this was a total tourist joint in the Fairmont on Nob Hill but what a fun place!  Ha!  Love the tacky colorful Polynesian interior, the fake thunder and rain, the floating mobile stage in the middle of the pool, the lounge band and of course ... the Tiki Bar!  Pretty good tropical drinks, which I hear, have gotten better through the years.  They also come in cute coconut ceramic cups and of course mini drink umbrellas!  There's a dining room that serves food but coming for drinks and hanging out at the Tiki Bar is the most fun.  This place can get pretty crowded with a lot of young folks who end up dancing to the music after a few too many drinks.  But if you know what to expect when coming here, this is a great place for just a really fun time.
author: Kelly P.

description: The review is solely for cocktails in Tonga room. Short tip to everyone :don't drink cocktails In Tonga. The alcohol quality is really bad and you just can feel it after one cocktail. T
author: Jas A.

description:
From my previous Aug 23 2015 review:
Located at The Fairmont San Francisco, Tonga Room & Hurricane Bar has delighted guests with its tropical décor, decadent libations and Asian cuisine since 1945.  After watching Anthony Bourdain have a meal here during his show The Layover, I knew I had to come.  I  highly recommend making a reservation as the lines are long, but worth it for the drinks, food, and indoor rain.  The ambiance is amazing and made us feel like we were living in Oahu again.
author: David K.

description: Pathetic food...worst Korean ribs and never ever order the shrimp main course. This place is a good hangout for drinks and few drinks. They charged $15 for some band singing in there. If the restaurant cannot pay for the band why invite them first place... Why beg for money from the customers. This dinner is a rip off for the quality of food, I would suggest if you are here for the ambience just walk in a take some pics... don't even bother to buy a drink... Shame on Anthony Bourdain for reviewing this restaurant in his show..this is my first ever yelp review.. imagine the disappointment after having the food that made me write this.
author: Pradeep T.

description:
It was a special night for us as I took my family to a place in which my Grandparents had their honeymoon in the 1940's. My kids loved the ambiance and it was fun to us to imagine what it was like long ago. 

The staff at Tonga are the real story - to have a person like Addison there who is a leader who believes in ensuring the customer has an incredible experience makes all the difference in the world. Our server was fantastic and the front of house made us feel at home.

Go to Tonga Room. Go back in time.
author: Tom L.

description: This place is a total tourist trap, with its high prices and location. The drinks were expensive and the place was crowded. It's cool to do once, but i do not see myself going there again. The drinks averaged about $17. It was a pretty underwhelming experience. There are plenty of places in the city to grab a good mai tai or other sorts of cocktails for under $15 easily.
author: Cecilia V.

description: Well established restaurant in Nob Hill - live music. Looks like the inside of a pirate ship. Band floats on the water. There is also a waterfall. Order the tenderloin!!!! You won't be disappointed.
author: Alisa I.

description: Horrible hostess. We wanted to have Father day dinner there for my husband first. We got there at 6pm and was told it would take 1hr to be seated. Hostess asked for name and number. 1hr later got a texted saying they were ready for us. When we got there the hostess stated that they didn't have our name or number on their iPad. I showed her the text as proof. All she said I'm sorry there might of been a glitch but I can add you on the list again. We didn't want to waste anymore time waiting but they pretty much wasted our time on my husband. first Father day. Thanks
author: Melanie S.

description: Arrived at the Fairmont at 4:15 and went downstairs at 4:30.  The line just started to grow behind us.  By 5:00 there were about 30 people behind us.  Bar tables were full within  15 minutes.  We had an absolutely awsome time.   Our waitress, Perla, was attentive and took great care of us.  If you can come Wed thru  Friday 5 to 7 the drinks are considerably less expensive but the experience is worth the expense.
author: Tim L.

description:
I am giving the Tonga Room ALL THE POINTS for the fun I had - but I wish I could rate them separately on a few other factors... 

You will wait a long time to get in (even if you're just going to the bar).
You will wonder, "Can it really be that good? It is situated in the bottom of a hotel, after all."
You will pay way too much for a single, small cocktail.
You will wish there were a coat hook or rack, or somewhere to put your stuff in the bar area.

But...

You will share a bowl of something delicious, with multiple straws.
You will dance.
You will dance in the "rain."
You will dance on a pirate ship.
You will have the time of your life.

If you at all enjoy tiki bars, or anything fun - you will enjoy The Tonga Room. The wait - and the $$$ - are worth it. In fact, I am conflicted about writing this review, since I know I will probably wind up waiting longer the next time I am there!
author: Catie F.

description:
Don't waste your time and money and definitely do not host a private event here! The staff failed to keep our event private and outsiders were drinking on our tab (we rented out the bar at a $2,000 fee), they were unable to clarify how they calculated our group size yet charged us the maximum our contract would allow, the food and service was horrific, the were completely inflexible with start time - our dinner reception ended early and we were hoping to come over earlier and even though the bar and restaurant were empty they were not accommodating. 

We selected this bar because of its history and we had international guests. We knew the food here was terrible and drinks were overpriced, however, I wish we went elsewhere. It was not worth the headache. 

Though the Fairmont is listed as a 4-5 star hotel, the service you'll receive in the Tonga Room is as though you're staying at a motel.
author: Jenna L.

description:
Tonga! Tonga! Tonga!
I had heard so much about this place and how much fun it was, I was thrilled to see I was staying just blocks away.
Make sure to call ahead & make sure they are not closed to private parties, seems that is common.
This place has such a fun atmosphere! Get ready for fun fruity drinks, lots of music & dancing and memories to last a lifetime!
I recommend the lava bowls. It may not be the most practical option for a drink but who doesn't want to drink their drink out of a huge bowl?!? YOLO right? 
It's tacky tiki fiesta at it's finest! Enjoy the tropical decor & try to get a table with a view.
Happy hour is Wed - Fri from 5-7p and it's a $15 per person fee w/ a 1 drink minimum. 
You can also enjoy dinner but I think this place is better for drinks & fun.
author: Phylicia K.

description:
Here's how you do the Tonga Room: 

- Get here by 6pm, for happy hour
- Order a couple drinks or a punch bowl
- Do not stay for dinner
- Leave as soon as there's a cover. 

It's an awesome kitschy spot, I actually don't like the drinks that much, they are way too sweet, and the food is mediocre at best, but we keep coming back just to enjoy the tiki vibe. Remember, as soon as you've soaked some of the tiki craziness up, there are literally thousands of more delicious and cheaper restaurants within 10 minutes walk.
author: Tasha D.

description: I went and had a great time! My drink, although $17, was delicious. I would recommend their Fog Cutter. The ambiance is great. I love that they have fake thunder that will make it "rain" on the pool they have in the middle of the place. The staff was friendly and efficient. Would go again. Only four stars Because drinks are pricey and don't have much alcohol in them. I do like that they have a standing area by the pool.
author: Sidney G.

description: Terrible experience. Pretentious. Should have listened to the people walking out stating "this place is overrated". Service was terrible. Server acted as if everything we ordered was only appetizer worthy. Won't be back.
author: Kivani R.

description: Nope. Very busy with a young liberal crowd during happy hour. Couldn't get a table, nor a drink/service after 10 min, and a bathroom trip is just short of walking through a corn maze into the hotel. Left there and went to Irish Bank for a more laid back feel.
author: Patrick M.

description: This place was a blast. Here for girls trip. Music was good! Appetizers a little pricey, but we had a blast! Definitely make reservations or u will be waiting in line.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Just so you know, this place is all island kitsch, from the decor to the entertainment. We had reservations at 8pm on a Saturday night to celebrate a friend's birthday. We were seated promptly. 

Our table service was odd, it seemed like we had three different waiters and it felt like we were the table that kept getting delayed service. A table that was seated 15-20 minutes after us got their drinks and food way before ours. Granted there were a few bigger tables but c'mon, you can't ignore one just because of the big tables. Anyhoo, we had a mixed appetizer of ribs, egg rolls, chicken, and crab won tons. It was decent but maybe skip the crab won tons. Those did not taste like there was fresh crab in it at all. 

The atmosphere was lively and perfect for sharing a bowl of an alcoholic mixed drink with tons of rum. The drinks were all "islandy" and of course expensive. I ordered the scallops which did not taste fresh but my dinnermates' dinners all seemed okay. Desserts were just okay as well. The highlight of the place is the music, the band played in a half-boat which floated in the middle of the rectangular pool. They played covers from the 40's to the 00's and did celebration shout-outs to the diners. Seems like erryone had a birthday that night. They were awesome. 

If you want the full experience, make reservations. If you just want to hang out and listen to music, hit up the bar and stick to the appetizers because the regular food isn't that great. There is usually a line for bar seating in the evening (sometimes more than an hour wait) so get there early.
author: Prim P.

description:
Drinks 8/10
Food 7/10 
Service 2/10 

Nice drinks, good ambience, food tastes good as well but service is horribly awful. It takes 35 min between every course we ordered to be served and server was neither polite nor welcoming. 
Suggested  for bar hoppers but better off grabbing a bit some where else
author: Chirag N.

description: Knowing that they don't take reservations for dinner if you don't stay in the hotel, we went in with the expectation of a wait. My family of five waited 1 hour & 45 minutes and the hostess seated us at a small round table for in the bar area that could barely fit two. Shocked, we asked "we waited almost 2 hours for you to give us a bar table when there are multiple empty dinner tables in the dining area?" to which the hostess responded "yes". We immediately got up and left. Extremely disappointed.
author: Emily R.

description:
Food is not as good as it use to be.

Bartender had no suggestion when someone just asked for fruit juice and rum.  Wanted to stay complicated!
author: Chris J.

description:
We made dinner reservations here while staying at the Fairmont for one night for our anniversary. Both the Tonga Room and hotel were quite a special treat and after paying for the hotel, the $135 dinner/drinks tab didn't feel too expensive! 

We love tiki bars and this one is really special. The pool, rain, thunderstorm effects are really fun and the band started playing midway through our dinner. They were a good band, music was great, but choice of pop music was a bit surprising! No complaints though. 

We had Mai Tai and Konga Tong for drinks and they were tasty with plenty of kick, reasonably priced at $15. Also had some wine later in the evening. Kalua pork was delicious and we could have shared that for our meal. Also had Mongolian Beef which was amazingly tender. 

Our waiter, Bash, was wonderful. Very attentive and a nice guy all around. He comped us a dessert, which was a sweet surprise! We never felt rushed, which we really appreciated. 

Can't wait to go back!!!
author: Jan H.

description:
Can't believe I haven't reviewed this place - I make sure to go every time I visit here with my son, who pretty much considers this what a grown-up restaurant should be.

The food is asian-influenced pacific island style (as you'd expect) - so think spam fried rice, coconut shrimp, poke, etc. I can't say it particularly ever blew me away but I never had a bad deal here. 

Of course what's not to love about giant tiki drinks or listening to lounge music being played from a small "boat" during an indoor "thunderstorm". Come here for the experience, because they don't make places like this anymore, and I'm betting soon enough this will close down to be replaced with a "could be anywhere" new-American cuisine/hipster spot.
author: Joshua B.

description: I was just there for dinner.  I can't express how unsatisfied I was with the service and even more with the food.  sometimes I can ignore the service as long as the food is good ... You can definitely have a good drink here and that's all this place is good for. The hostess are horrible, I do not waste my time writing a review it doesn't matter if it's good or bad  but this place was really horrible and I'm so disappointed that I Really had to waste 5 minutes of my time to let you know how bad this place is, it's overrated and it's expensive, not worth it.   please do not waste your time and money at this place...  I cannot find other words to describe the disappointment at this place....
author: Evelyn Z.

description:
Stopped in here for a drink and appetizers after a disappointing and dull magic and illusionist show in the Terrace Room at the Fairmont--clearly the Tonga Room has now become merely a showpiece for the San Francisco tourists. While the celebrated Mai Tai was slightly better than satisfactory, the appetizers were truly awful and tasted like Lean Cuisine frozen leftovers reheated for the second or third time. 

Only come here for drinks and the ambiance and avoid getting stuck with a bar tab in excess of $95.00 for one Mai Tai, one Ginger Ale, two appetizer plates I wouldn't even serve my own dog, and a $14 cover charge. At least the music was lively and pleasant.
author: Kenneth P.

description: This place was great! The only problem I had was there was a long 2 hour wait. Once we finally got into the restaurant it was worth the wait. The drinks were strong, the food was delicious, and the music was just right creating a vibrant environment. I would definitely recommend checking this place out at least once and go after 8 when the band begins. I do not think you will be disappointed.
author: Benita J.

description:
This place has an awesome atmosphere you can't find at many other tiki bars in the city! Located underneath the Fairmont, I wouldn't have expected to stumble upon this sort of bar with a fun, laid-back environment.

I've been here twice now with my boyfriend and we've always had a good time here. First time we got their scorpion bowl, smuggler's golden punch bowl and their pineapple royale cocktail. How did we drink all that? To this day.. we don't even know haha. All we remember is having a great time on the dance floor that's looks like a ship and enjoying the live music out on the water. Oh and the indoor rain! 

 We came back recently to try a couple of appetizers with their scorpion bowl and we couldn't even finish it. Their appetizers are pretty good though! We got their calamari and egg rolls and got to sit by a table next to the dance floor which was a good people-watching spot. On fridays and saturdays they have a $10 cover charge/person for the live music so I would recommend coming here on a weekday if you can!
author: Kathleen S.

description: The Tonga Room is as old school tiki as it gets! Thank goodness it still exists! It's not exactly a cool crowd and entertainment is super cheesy but everyone's having fun and drinks are well made with top notch ingredients. They take their time making them so there is a bit of a wait at the bar. One odd thing is they make it super difficult to eat here. Half of the restaurant was empty but they said there were no openings. I'm glad they are doing so well they can turn business away! Seriously, I'm glad because this place can never go away! Decor is unbelievable! A must see for Tiki fanatics.
author: Ari R.

description:
Whoa mama, we're deep in kitsch flavor country now!

The band boat floats serenely by as fake rain falls over the outer edge of an indoor pool in the center of the thatched-roof restaurant. This is your faux dream tropical vacation, complete with pricy luau foods and hilariously big communal drinks. Scorpion bowl ahoy!

They make a surprisingly good piña colada, opting to put in just pineapple juice, coconut milk and rum, no half-gallon of simple syrup! 

The Tonga room was well worth the trip to the Fairmont based on their colada game, but baby, if you're going, go big. Get the Royal Pupu platter because everything on it is phenomenal! The ribs and wings are tender and covered in wondersauce with sesame seeds. The crab rangoons have tasty actual dungeoness crab in them, but oh man, those shiitake spring rolls are UNREAL. Crisp, savory, succulent, they don't need sauce but you'll get territorial over these dainty nibbles and want to experiment. Give in, it's worth it.
author: Emily H.

description: I love Tonga Room for the atmosphere, including the cheesy cover-charge-required band. The drinks are tasty and strong but expensive. The food is fine but expensive - eat elsewhere if price matters. Service is always friendly. Knocked off a star for general pricey-ness.
author: Kayla M.

description:
Be prepared to get your cheesy on and enjoy the atmosphere at the Tonga Room.  That is if you are lucky enough to get in.

A top the Hill, the Fairmont has succeeded in turning a lemon into lemonade.  Yes the Tonga Room used to be their indoor pool.  Genius use of space as they converted it to a restaurant/bar complete with a band playing on a boat in the middle of the water.

We stopped by here for a drink after dinner.  What a great place to escape from San Fran's hip norm.  

Loved the music and decor.  Everyone in a great mood. Get your dancing feet moving  and forget how cool you are.
author: Susan C.

description:
There has been an increase in popularity of the Tiki Bar concept lately in San Francisco and Tonga Room is one of the most visited one by locals and tourists. Located inside the famous Fairmont hotel, this bar is very authentic and appealing in it's ambience. The well designed shacks and the artificial rain effect indeed gives you a feeling of being on the Hawaiian islands. Since they don't take reservations anyone, they have started to charge $10 for entry after 8 pm and because of that reason, usually people just are standing in the bar area and all their tables are empty. I would say it looks a little too big for a bar!! I would have loved it more if it was a little smaller and cozy. But yes, it has Live Music and that does make it more attractive. It is a group hangout place for sure. 
Coming to the drinks...  Hell yeah, PRICY....they are strong, but a little sugary too!! Still we really loved them the way they were blended. The overall experience is great and enjoyable more because of the ambience and live music.
author: Foram C.

description: The food was below average and the service was shockingly poor. It takes for ever to get your food and drinks even though the place is half empty. Also made us wait 110min when the place was half empty. Hidden cover charges for mediocre entertainment. Utter disappointment, will not return again.
author: Zhe H.

description: They charge cover charges when you are there actually before the band starts. The hostess is so arrogant and cheeky .... they take forever to serve you and make you wait an hour and 50 minutes when there are zero people inside.. the food and the drinks are below average
author: Priscilla R.

description: I do not understand what all the fuss is about.  They're supposed to specialize in rum-based cocktails, but almost every drink my party ordered was pretty gross, and not cheap.  The service was terrible- our server was downright RUDE to our party, for no good reason!  The appetizers we ordered were decent, but not worth the price.  Unless you're coming just to see a waterfall in the middle of a restaurant, skip it.  Oh, and make a reservation WELL in advance.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Anthony Bourdain has been here so being in SF it made sense to follow in his tracks. Walking in I was amazed that this bar is even is one of the fanciest hotels in the city. Sat at the bar and ordered first the Mai Tai and Piña Colada. Both were great and the bartender didn't have a light hand! Our last drink was the Smugglers bowl to share and that too was great. The drinks here taste very fresh and I could tell sitting at the bar that these are actual bartenders who know their business. 

Atmosphere is totally fun. The pool in the middle of the room with the "boat" the band plays on is great. I loved the "rain showers" too with the accompanying thunder. 

Overall this is a fun bar to grab a tropical drink and chill. If back in SF I will return!
author: Allison O.

description:
Wonderful Entertainment!!!

I love the fact that the band is in the middle of the restaurant and that they are on a mini boat that goes back and forth on the water. 

I did notice that the menu online and inside the restaurant are different. They do not have the same items on there. Also, it is quite expensive. I did not like that they do not have a lot of choices to choose from. 

The egg rolls are a must to try, 

You also have to pay an entrance fee its not expensive, i did not mind that because pretty much we are paying for the entertainment. 

Parking WILL BE  a hassle. Its preferably to take a taxi or Uber. MAKE RESERVATIONS because it does get packed inside. 

One more thing. They have a dance floor in front of the bar which gets really nice.
author: Jannie M.

description: So much fun dancing here! The band plays in the middle of the pool and it rains every 30 mins or so. Really great Hawaiian vibe but the music was all American hits, great set list performed by a very talented band. Highly recommend for a fun night out with the girls.
author: D M.

description: Expensive but shitty food. Crab legs were good but othe than that there's nothing to eat here.
author: Reina Y.

description:
The Tonga Room is such a fun little place to hang out and get a drink with friends. We came on a Friday night and it was absolutely packed. The entire restaurant is adorably decorated with straw huts everywhere, and a large lake in the middle of a restaurant where the live band floats around on a boat

There is a tiny little dance floor that fills up fast and is full of fun good natured people looking for a fun time. A+ for the super chill crowd! The music is a little repetitive though, I wish they mixed up the genres a little.

Overall, the Tonga bar is definitely a little gimmicky and expensive, but its one of the rare places that you can enjoy the fun Tiki atmosphere AND dance to a live band. So definitely give it a shot.
author: Sarah T.

description: You're going to the Tonga Room for the vibe and music. The food is crap, and the drinks are mediocre. You're paying for an experience, and you know what that's fine! I drank with my friends and had dinner. We had a blast! It's the company you have with where you're at! ENJOY!
author: Darlene Y.

description:
Just as kitchy as everyone says!!! Veggie potstickers were good. 

The hostess was rude, very rude and unapologetic. Our waitress was short and refused to give me virgin versions of any of the punches or specialty drinks. Only after i begged her to give me anything but a Shirley temple did she explain that the alcoholic drinks are all pre mixed :O . She served everything with a frown on her face :( 

The band was better than expected and kind of saved the night after the staff was so inhospitable.
author: Sara Emily S.

description: Fun, quirky, unique. This place was really neat. We ordered the hot pot and the side of forbidden rice. Had the baby back ribs as the appetizer. Service was quick. Just be aware that if you go on a Friday or Saturday night, they have a live band and if you stay to listen to them they'll add a per person $ cover price to your bill. We were there long enough to hear about 4 songs and didn't get charged. So it was cool. Definite thumbs up.
author: sergio h.

description: Awesome atmosphere and music! This is a good place for drinks and maybe an appetizer. I definitely would not recommend the food as I find it very subpar for the cost. The staff definitely goes above and beyond!
author: Amber L.

description: Anyone who has been to the tiki bar at The Disneyland Hotel knows exactly what the Tonga Room looks and feels like. It is like the tiki bar, it's a bar which at times requires reservations, and they have special drinks in which they entertain the guests with hurricane effects and squirts water at you! It's below the hotel and you can walk down the stairs when entering the Laurel Court Restaurant! There is a fee to get in for the band probably. They perform on water or they get wet, it's all odd!
author: Steven W.

description: Really disappointing that they no longer take dinner reservations. It's always an enjoyable venue, but making people wait in line for an hour just to get a table won't be an option for us. Waiting to hear if they change this policy in the future. I sure hope so.
author: Kiely W.

description: How else can I say.. TOURIST TRAP. My goodness my boyfriend and I came here for New Years and we left with a sore wallet & upset stomach. The drinks were terrible. I sent mine back just to get one that tasted almost identical. The food is "buffet style" so you go wait in line for 30-40 minutes fighting all coughing people around you. It's great. The drinks are NOT included in the exuberant price you just already paid, so don't get excited. When the bill arrived we also found out you pay around $80 in "SVC charges" and taxes. I would not recommend it, nor will I be back.
author: Kay M.

description: Tonga is a must when in San Francisco! Great atmosphere, drinks are awesome, food is AMAZING! The live music is perfect, a mixture of oldies and current. Definitely loud but enjoyable with family and friends. Expect to dance in your dinner seat! The waiters are very friendly and consistent with filling your cups and food came out quickly.
author: Brandie A.

description:
BUZZ KILL!!

This place has all the cosmetic ingredients for a fantastic time. The staff on the other hand are doing everything they can to ruin that. Starting with the jerk at the door to tired worn out table staff all the way down to the most uninspired bartender we have ever seen. We were all in from out of town in for a work event and could not be more primed to have a great time. This place manage to mess that up in no time. Only because we were staying at Fairmont we thought we would give it another chance on the next night, GIANT FAIL!

Next year we're going to stay at another hotel. It should be noted the Fairmont it great. We just did not want to Uber away for a good time after work.
author: Surfer D.

description:
OMG we had the worst experience here, you guys.  We had an 8PM reservation, weren't seated until 9PM and our food didn't arrive until 10PM.  No apologies, no service above and beyond to recognize the inconvenience.  We had three kids with us and two fell asleep at the table before our food even arrived.  We saw our waiter once during our time - he took our order then came back again to scoff that our food wasn't out. 

The food was also disgusting.  My husband ordered Korean Beef and it was soupy and looked like dog food.  Legit, looked like dog food.  My son ordered kids ramen noodles which were actually low mein (hello, there's a diff between ramen and lo mein) with meat he wouldn't touch (and this kid eats everything).  I ordered Kahlua Pork which was cold.  Yummy.  Cold pork.  

To top it off, there was a woman who arrived earlier in the evening - she was super drunk and her friends left her at the front entry way.  About an hour later she got sick ALL OVER herself, the bench and floor....right where you check in/walk into the restaurant.  Hello.  Even my 8 year old knew she looked like she might barf but the restaurant let her stay?  

My husband, who gets very quiet when he's angry, had a nice convo with the Manager who comp'd the meal we didn't eat.  He offered another reservation for the next night and my hubs was like, WTH would we come back.  

If you are DYING to see what it's like, go for one drink b/c the atmosphere is fun but DON'T order food and don't trust anyone who says the food is good - even if it's like your bestie.  Find a new bestie.  Seriously.
author: Jenn V.

description:
We arrived at the Fairmont in the late weekday afternoon and decided to try the Tonga Room for drinks and a small bite.  We ended up getting in at the tail end of happy hour around 6:30.  We liked the drinks and food we got and our waitress was very attentive and helpful.  We were amused by the "rainforest" effect and the numbers of people who had to have their picture taken with it.  (Somewhat reminiscent of the Rainforest Cafe chain but without all the sound effects and animatronics.)

After spending a full next day at Fisherman's Wharf, we decided to come back to the Tonga Room shortly after 5:00 and were seated promptly.  They had a large section of the bar area condoned off for a private party that made the rest of the bar really crowded.  We had the same waitress we had the night before, but the service wasn't as good.  The drinks and food were good.

So ffter two nights at the same place, we decided we would try someplace else for our final night in SF.
author: Wil C.

description: This is like "Disney for adults," per my boyfriend's family. We hit up this spot whenever we're in town, half for the spectacle (the indoor pool, tiki vibe, etc.) and half for the yummy (albeit pricey) tropical drinks. Recommend going at least once, especially if visiting or when you have visitors!
author: Ana M.

description:
Came here on Friday night around 10pm. It was starting to get crowded as we walked in. No need to pay if you elect to stand but they will charge you $10/person if you want a table. Drinks were great. We had Mai Thai and sort of like pina colata. They also had live music performance. Not sure if it was only that night, but a lot of Hawaiian shirts were seen.

Live music performance played classic hits like 500 miles, sweet Caroline, I wanna dance with somebody and have you ever seen the rain. Great looking people everywhere and dance floor was a hit. You can choose to just watch the show too if you don't want to dance. Overall, very friendly and fun ambience.

I'd definitely come back here again.
author: Kevin C.

description: Great place to meet for a drink or have dinner. Always crowded but fun atmosphere. Cool ambience with tiki bar theme.
author: Karen S.

description: What a heartbreaking disappointment!! We have celebrated a Xmas weekend here for 5 yrs but this year with new no reservations policy , our experience was horrific.  In line early to wait 1 1/2 hrs for dinner but given a bar table. No room for food . Assured that same menu as "dinner", but not at all. Unable to accommodate kids needs , unlike previous years. Food late/ had to cancel dishes. And we watched 5 tables sit empty for 2 + hours. Family tradition over. What a downright disaster of an evening!
author: Vince W.

description: Very crowded. The drinks were good but tough to get service, just too many people. Atmosphere was cool, very retro south seas. The menu is somewhat limited, the pupu platter (sp?) was very good, but the waitress suggested a $50 fried whole crab that was not good. The main crab shell is empty, so it's for show. There were 4 clusters that were so glopped up with sauce that it was impossible to eat, and we got maybe 5 ounces of actual crab and double that breading and sauce. I've washed my hands 3 times and still smell the sauce. Get a drink, get the appetizer plate but skip the whole crab.
author: Fred M.

description: Absolutely love the vibe of this place! We visited the Tonga Room during happy hour to enjoy some good deals. If you've ever been to Trader Sam's at the Disneyland Hotel, the Tonga Room feels like a bigger version. They have rain that comes down from the ceiling every 20 minutes or so. The drinks were tasty and strong. My favorite was the Spice Killer! I would definitely order it again. We didn't order any of the food options, but they sounded good. Prices definitely would have been quite steep if we didn't come during happy hour (drinks for $10 each versus the usual $17 or so). They also have a live band that plays out on the water (cover charge of $15 per person if you're seated at a table). Would definitely return; we had a blast.
author: Kelley A.

description: My sister and I visited the Tonga room & hurricane bar for the first time. I bought her a Tonga Kong, a creamy coconut concoction that was sweet and strong. The Tonga room is located in the Fairmont Hotel. Island theme, fairly large room, and in the middle of the room is a pool of water and a boat for the entertainers. We saw rain and lightning before the band played jams from my sister's time. The restaurant/bar seems to be designed like you are on a ship. Wouldn't mind coming back.
author: Jay M.

description: The happy hour there is awesome you pay for a plate and you can have cocktails and small bites and fruits about the place the atmosphere is very nice, I will say is a rain forest cafe for adults. We didn't wait for dinner though.
author: carla a.

description:
I am a San Francisco native, and I have been to the Tonga Room quite a few times in the decades of my life.  (I've even been there for High School Prom events.) I wish I could be more excited about this review, but in all honesty, and at present, I am very disappointed, AND I will avoid going there unless I have lots of money I want to spend for dinner.  I say this because I know the food on the dinner menu to be quite good.  It is very representative of food one might have in a number of Pacific islands, and  I have been delighted with many items I have ordered.

What I am reviewing at this moment is what used to be an incredible Happy Hour experience. I understand that drinks and appetizers have increased in price over the years, and I willingly accept that.  What I am most disappointed with is the the offering of free food that is provided during the acclaimed happy hour.  In the past there was shrimp, ribs, meat egg rolls, very tasty noodle dishes, incredible salad combinations, and even things like shu mai , and tasty pieces of chicken on skewers.  
These days, it seems that there is nothing even resembling actual protein on the appetizer table.  The options are mostly carbs; vege eggs rolls, bland chow mein, and a few other things I don't know how to describe.
The Tonga Room is a fabulous atmosphere, and the rain pool is one of the most magnificent elements of any night club/ restaurant in San Francisco.  Tonga Room management, charge enough to make the food better, and many of your local patrons will return.  Please.
author: janice s.

description: I had been looking forward to trying this place for a LONG time, but sadly I was disappointed. After an hour and a half wait we were seated next to the bar area which was not that great. Their drinks are pretty funky, so with the waitresses help I chose one .... it was disgusting! It was super bitter and tasted like curry powder. I didn't drink it and the waitress didn't even ask once if I liked it. Complete waste of $15! Service was very lacking and very slow. We kept looking around for our waitress to order more food but she was no where to be found. The key lime cake for dessert was really good, but thats about it. Overall I expected more. I thought the drinks would be good and the service would be better. Don't think we will be back, our money is much better spent elsewhere.
author: stacy a.

description: Very cool tiki bar.  They had a band on a floating barge  inside.  Great drinks. Great decor.  It's located in the basement of the Filmore hotel.  This is a must visit for any tiki bar fan.
author: Mike G.

description: Usually gets crowded during the later parts of the evening but if you're looking for a a quick beer and some good live music, it's the spot for you. The hostess Veronica was very helpful and knowledgeable when helping out our group.
author: Joshua B.

description:
My wife was dying to go to the Tonga Room. I tried booking a reservation through Opentable, but no room at the inn. You can't even call to make a reservation. On our first evening in San Francisco, we decided to take a chance on a Friday night and just go to the Tonga Room and see if we could get in.

When we arrived, the joint was jumping and it was even before the music started. I asked the hostess if there was room for 3 and she said, "For appetizers and drinks?" Naturally, I said yes and we were seated. If the Tiki Room and Pirates of the Caribbean had a baby, it would be the Tonga Room. 

Around 8ish, the music started. The band is set up on a barge in the middle of the lagoon(Yes, the hotel turned their pool into a restaurant). I was wondering what kind of music they were going to play considering the clientele, which was a mix of everyone. And yes, there were hipster and man buns. I mean, it is San Francisco, right? The band played music that crossed all the age groups in the room. People were dancing including the cougars and kids.

The appetizer menu has something for everyone. It is, of course, Tiki themed. They also have a large tropical drink menu. My wife started with a Chi Chi. My daughter had Pineapple juice on the rocks. I had my usual Maker's Mark Manhattan. As for the food, we tried several things. Calamari being one of them. 

I am always concerned when I go to places like this because I always think the service is going to be horrible. I don't like to be rushed, etc. Romy was our server and did an incredible job and even treated my 9 year old with respect, which a lot of servers don't do. So if you go to the Tonga Room, ask for Romy.

After all was said and done, we ended up spending 4 hours and about $200.00, but I would do it again. I don't go to San Francisco very often, but the Tonga Room is on my list of "go to" places and it should be on your list also.
author: Bill S.

description:
You feel like you should hit the obligatory gift shop on the way out. It is quite Disneyesque and for good reason. It was designed by Mel Melvin, a 1940's set designer for MGM studios. It looks great. But it definitely staged.

My first Mai Tai was meh...

We got some pupus... They were decent for bar food. The vegetable dumplings were actually quite nice. The spicy poke wasn't too spicy. My other half wasn't crazy about the pork sliders, they were a bit tough. 

We ordered a Lava Flow for 2.

We ordered some dinner. We got Sichuan green beans. They weren't too spicy. A scallion pancake, it was quite dry. And the Hawai'ian fried rice. It was a tad salty, but flavorful. 

I ordered a second Mai Tai from our server P.J. She brought me an absolute panty dropper. I admit it. I couldn't finish it, and I'm a pro drinker. Wow!

In truth, the food is meh. The service is top notch!
author: Lea S.

description:
I felt a little out of place at this tourist hangout but Tonga Room turned out to be surprisingly fun. There was a live band on the boat in the middle of the "pond" playing great music. People of all ages were enjoying their evening on the dance floor. Even though the artificial rain is cheesy, I still loved it. The thunder and lightning were a nice touch as well.

We didn't try the food and only had drinks. Since this is a tiki bar, I decided to go with the pina colada. It felt so tropical with a slice of pineapple and a paper umbrella. I had a wonderful time on a weeknight evening.
author: Yi Z.

description:
For a place like this ratings cannot be based on food alone.
Drinks 5 stars
Atmosphere 6 stars
Service 4 stars
Food 3 stars

They're drinks are delicious and you have the option to upgrade to drinking out of a Pineapple or adding a 151 floater!

Walking into Tonga Room gives all the feels of waking into a themey restaurant in Las Vegas or Myrtle Beach, but it just feels right! 

The swimming pool had a floating "boat" in it with a live band. Such a trip!

The food is fine. Get some appetizers and a PooPooPlatter, skip the entrees.  

Even if you never go back, it WORTH a first visit. Make a reservation because there was a line out the door when we got there.
author: Lindsay D.

description:
Hurricane and rain very lame and way over priced. Not sure what the hype was all about. 
Food was not even that good. Way more choices in town that are way better.
author: Joseph F.

description:
I was so excited to finally have an excuse to come here and get in for a few drinks! A had family visiting from out of town and we had the idea to come here after wandering around SF for a few hours. We got here around 4:45pm (they open at 5) and were the first in line. We have tried to get in for Happy Hour before and the line has been down the hall before opening. Since they don't have Happy Hour on the weekends, it only started to fill up about 5 minutes before opening. We were sat promptly at 5 in the bar area on the pirate ship at the corner of the lake in the middle.

Let's just get out of the way that Tonga Room's decorations are tacky AF. This is normal for Tiki Bars and adds to the fun. They have a thunderstorm every 10-15 minutes where it rains in the middle of the pool. It's pretty wild. Anyways, the 5 of us each ordered our own individual drink. I ordered a Spice Killer ($15) and A got a Zombie ($18). 2 others at our table got these drinks and the 5th person got a Tonga Kong ($15). The menu specifies how strong/sweet these drinks are on a scale of skulls (for alcohol) and sticks (for sweetness). The Spice Killers were the most alcoholic/least sweet and the Tonga Kong and Zombies were more sweet/less alcoholic. We had dinner reservations after so we didn't order food but what the table next to us ordered smelled surprisingly delicious. 

Our drinks arrived in 15 minutes and they were HUGE. I didn't try the Tonga Kong but the Zombie tasted much more alcoholic than my Spice Killer though I definitely preferred the taste of mine to A's. That being said, these drinks were sneakily strong. I was DEFINITELY feeling a bit jolly halfway through my drink. By the time we had finished our drinks, we were a fun bunch. Since we had time before our reservation, we decided to split the 4-person Rainmaker ($60) between the 5 of us. Keep in mind this had the same alcohol/sweetness rating as my beloved Spice Killer. This drink was great and a lot of fun to share but there was a lot of ice in it so we finished it much sooner than anticipated. Determined to make it to dinner, be able to joy it and maintain some fine dining table manners, we asked for the check. While it was ~$30pp, I will say that I did not feel ripped off by these drinks based on how strong and large they were. 

I took off a star for the music since they were playing top-40 which was a bit...bizarre. Also, you can take kids here so there definitely are a fair amount of parents getting silly while their 6-year-old is in awe over the pirate ship. This makes a bit of an odd atmosphere but it IS in the middle of a hotel. Is it a tourist spot? Sure but, like House of Prime Rib, this place deserves to be one. I don;t think A and I will be back by ourselves but next time we have visitors, you can bet we are going to make an effort to come here.
author: Carrie W.

description: This place is a hot mess, but a pretty fun and amusing hot mess that a lot of people (including myself) choose to subject themselves to on occasion. It's located inside the classy Fairmont Hotel, which is already thematically pretty disjointed and foreshadows the randomness to come. There's a random body of water with a floating stage that plays host to random live performances. The decor is tacky and tropical (?) themed. The drinks are strong and pricey. The food is decent - but I think most people come here for the bustling atmosphere, commitment to kitsch, and the aura of being able to get weirdly drunk and no one will mind since you're already surrounded by weirdness. In that sense, the Tonga Room's weaknesses are also its strengths. It's one of those places you have to come to at least once in your life, whether it's to embrace it or make fun of it.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Loved it, loved it and loved it! 
Unique and amazing interiors and experience. Live music. Casual and loud - so me! 

Loved the cocktails especially my Zombie! 
You HAVE TO reserve way early. It's always full. 
They don't take reservations before 7 though. You can walk in; although there is usually a 1/2hr wait.
author: Sowmya S.

description: Anthony Bourdain made me want to come here (and my daughter really wanted to go).  I must say, I had a blast.  Our waiter- Bash- was amazing!!!! Shout out to the best waiter ever!  We have a serious allergy, and he made sure everything was safe for us.  Thank you!  We had the drink for two- A Monk Walks Into a Luau- and it was good.  We also tried the Mai Tai, also good, and the planter's punch- not to my taste.  To eat, we had the cabbage and papaya salad and the glass noodle salad- both were delicious!!!  We got great pictures, and had great food and enjoyed our drinks.  What more could I ask of an evening?  Seriously, though, the service is what kicked this up to 5 stars- I don't think I've ever had a better waiter.  Our bill was very reasonable for this kind of crazy place- even with all the drinks and the VERY large salads- plenty for 2- our bill was only 90 with tax!  It was a Weds- so there was no band.  Might be fun to see that.  It's dark in here, and I'm not sure about the happy hour- people seemed kind of grumpy over there.  You get the premium waterside tables (like we had!) by making reservations.  I made mine over a month in advance.  The bathrooms are quite a hike, but nice- if crowded.  We caught a cab down to Powell street Bart and it was 8 dollars (7.60).
author: Alex M.

description:
This place is a blast. Try the following mindset prior to entering:

"I'm in San Francisco, a modern city filled with amazing musicians and artists alike. Now I am entering some sort of  Disney - Hawaii vacation-like alternate universe." 

It's fun. The drinks are tasty. The live music is free! and great. There's a dance floor. Where else can this be found in SF?! No where I tell you!!!

1 - 1.5 hours is probably enough time to spend having a drink and getting your dance on before heading home or going to the next spot for the evening.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
My boyfriend surprised me here on one of our dinner dates.
This place is located inside the beautiful upscale and classy Fairmont Hotel. Everything from the architecture to the bathrooms in this hotel is elegant. 

--Okay so moving on to the actual restaurant bar itself...Love love love the atmosphere here! The live band was playing great oldies music and the coolest part was that they were floating on the water! Every few minutes a "rainstorm" effect would come on. The vibes definitely made me feel like I was somewhere tropical. The crowd seems to be in the mid 30s+ considering we were probably the youngest couple there aside from the families.

Food and drinks are "Hawaiian/asian" themed. Not much to choose from and sorta pricey. Can't complain, you're inside a pricey historic hotel. 

Would definitely come back here for the vibes to dance and drink ;)
author: Hayle C.

description: Awesome food and service.  Great place for an office party.
author: Matt T.

description: Very nice bar with cool decor and setups. We tried the A Monk Walks Into a Luau for 4 people and we definitely got our money's worth considering how strong the drink was. We also tried the fried calamari and that was amazing, one of the better calamaris I've had. Although everything is indeed expensive, being a tourist attraction and in a hotel, it's worth a visit if you're in San Fran.
author: Judy M.

description: Vegan friendly and a lot of fun . The place is Polynesian with Polynesian flare , band in water and wonderful decor . Kinda pricey but worth it .
author: Robin M.

description: Cool looking place and it draws a big crowd for happy hour with its strong drinks. I don't know about the food.
author: Terri F.

description:
For starters I have been a fan of the TONGA room at the Fairmont hotel for years WELL that was then and this unfortunately is NOW!!!!!  The TONGA room is totally IMO living on most of its past fame and reputation, unfortunately as I sooooooo wanted to give a rave review but I can not rightly justify anything more than 1 star this time around.  I have been coming to the Fairmont since the 70s and NOW,  The good here is super friendly service (hey the drinks are $20) and some are $10 at happy hour (more about HH later).  Also the live band that plays in the middle of the pool and the rainfall inside are still FANTASTIC, but everything else and I do MEAN everything else is way  way below PAR,  To start their happy hour is posted  as wed-fri from 5-7 pm and sundays 8pm-close http://tongaroom.com/Userfiles/TongaRoom/Images/Footer/newdrink.jpg
The staff needs to be aware of this and THEY NO GD Clue as we were told last Sunday (8/13/17) that there was no HH because of the live BAND (WTF!!!!!-we waited specifically until 8pm to visit just to order some HH appetizers ALAS but to no avail!!!)  apparently the band starts at 8pm on sunday and 7pm during the week.  Please take the info that you have food available for HH WHEN YOU DONT  off the site so people can plan accordingly,  The drinks (MAI TAI was a hUGE disappointment they used to be great see above about living in the past!!)  This version was not worthy at all.  I was really disappointed that I had to argue with the hostess for a few seconds that happy hour should at least be available in the bar, which it was but not until I complained,  Also remember no food served at the bar(as one employee mentioned to me it is not cost effective because it takes me 20-30 seconds to make a $20 drink but I have to stop and go all the way to the kitchen if someone orders food.  This all a shock to me as I was here a couple of months ago and was able to order the food at HH prices (on a Sun night-but I think the band had stopped playing????  I don't know there are other places that value my participation and money more than the Fairmont OH BY THE WAY if you stay here (HOTEL charges its guests $72 to park- but it is in and out privileges in SAN Francisco you do not need a car; ever heard of UBER;cabs, walking, cable cars or bikes????)  on the downhill path so I hope that somebody that matters at FAIRMONT sees this review, I know it is not very complimentary but hey it is hones and truthful
author: Tim R.

description:
If you want a change of scenery, the Tonga Room will take you to another world. 
Right when you walk through the door, you are transported to a tropical paradise. Tikis and huts surround a blue lagoon, and your ears are filled with live music. The environment is truly unique, and FYI the Tonga room is a historical nightlife spot to visit in San Fran.

In regards to dinner, their menu is Asian infused, and not very unique in flavor. Overall, the menu is satisfactory, but hard to compete with the food available down the street in China town. My favorite thing on the menu were the vegetarian eggrolls made with Shitake mushrooms. 

I still recommend you go to the Tonga room for cocktails and the environment. And beware, there is always a tropical storm ahead. :)
author: Isaias S.

description:
Once in a lifetime experience. Tonga is place you must visit if you're in San Francisco. Drinks are good too pricey but good. The band was excellent. We order appetizers and they where good. For main plates we order the pork and it was dry, the chicken was good and the chow mein honestly you can get better chow mein anywhere else. 
Overall we had a great time will recommend going for drinks and appetizers only.
author: Maria B.

description:
Super cheeky fun!  It's not the cheapest place on the planet, since it's in the Fairmont Hotel. 
 But the drinks are potent and well crafted.  The atmosphere is impressive and over the top, while still somewhat cool and mellow.  Will definitely go back to try the food.
author: Sunny C.

description: Food is really good, but the mixed drinks were so bad they gave me a stomach ache. Either too much sugar or too much acid. Yuck.
author: Mathias A.

description: Tonga Room is a bit pricier than other tiki bars in the city, with a way more insane wait to get in for bar seating. I'm a fan, but really only when Pagan Idol isn't open.
author: Iris H.

description: We had dinner reservations here and were told when we arrive it was $15 extra per person to sit at a table because they had entertainment that night. We had a group of four so we didn't want to pay $60 on top of our meal and drinks so we went to the bar for a drink and enjoyed the same entertainment for free.
author: Joanna L.

description: Nice themed bar...one of a kind. Me and my friends went here for happy hour yesterday to celebrate my friend's birthday. You will feel excited once you enter the room. The buffet is nicely presented however was a bit disappointed with the quality of food. Won't go back for Happy Hour but will try the dinner next time. Drinks are too strong...just a warning!
author: mel m.

description:
My fiancé and I were staying at the Fairmont and decided to check out the hotel bar - to our pleasant surprise we discovered the Tonga Room on the lower level! 

This spot is pretty unique - a rectangle pool is at the enter of the room where rain falls and tables surround the perimeter. 

We arrived Saturday night to a large line - I believe hotel guests do not have to pay cover for live music on weekend . 

Pros:
 - ambience, ambience, ambience! 
- signature drinks / fish bowls are strong 
- variety on menu

Cons: 
- food was just ok, we enjoyed out dishes but nothing blew us away. 
- somewhat pricey ($10-15 drinks) but considering the experience it's totally worth it.
author: Sierra A.

description: If I could give zero stars I would. Went there for happy hour and the drinks were amazing...at the bar. Wanted to eat and got seated at a shared table,..no problem right? Wrong. Ordered two appetizers from the happy hour menu. Waited 45minutes(33 minutes according to the server). Showed proof that we had been waiting quite a bit of time and he PICKED UP OUR FOOD AND TOOK IT AWAY!  Management said he felt "threatened" and she stood behind him. Ummm we ordered shrimp tempura and spring rolls...both were disgusting. But to have a server be so combative is beyond ridiculous. I'd save the money for over priced appies and a headache as far as the service goes. Clearly they don't understand that being in the service industry entails.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
I will say that parking for this place on a rainy Friday was an absolute nightmare. We ended up parking on Vallejo on the other side of Chinatown and just walked it. This has nothing to do with the Tonga Room itself and won't affect it's star rating.

You walk into this beautiful hotel from the California Street side to get to Tonga, (though I highly encourage you to look at the lobby before heading home if you just came here for the Tonga Room, photo attached). If you REALLY want to enjoy the Tonga Room, MAKE A RESERVATION! So many of the low ratings on here are because people have had to stand in line just to stand at the bar.

I made my reservation a week prior on Open Table and requested a spot by the water. When we arrived, we bypassed the line, and were immediately seated by the water.  This may have just been the next open table, but I'm an optimist and will just assume they read my request.  Also, on Friday and Saturday there is an additional $7 entertainment fee.

The wait staff is amazing. Our waiter was quick and polite.  The manager even stopped by our table to give the history of the bar. We ordered our food and drinks and they were served promptly.

As a vegetarian, I didn't try much of the food, but my husband was IN LOVE with his food.  The complimentary edamame was good for me. Drinks were strong and tasty and come in mugs that are fun to take pictures of.

Our bill for the Pupu Platter and two drinks each was about $84.  Our reservation was at 6:15pm and we left before the band started so we didn't have to pay the entertainment fee.
author: Cori G.

description:
Yelp's 365 Review Challenge 2014 #368 - #365

Been here since 1945. There's no other place I know of in San Francisco that has a full Hawaiian theme lounge and bar. This place was highly recommended from my sister who lives in San Francisco. It's located inside the Fairmont Hotel below the lobby. The staff who assisted us on the hotel were more than friendly in getting to the Tonga Lounge. Talk about 5 star service in a 5 star hotel. 

Inside of the Tonga Lounge includes a large lounge decorated with bamboo, a dance floor and a lagoon. Talk about an island theme! One of the band members mentioned that the room use to be the hotel's indoor swimming pool, very interesting.

I ordered the Hurricane $17 and that was strong and we ordered some appetizers calamari and soybeans, both were ok. The soybeans had some spicy salt on top and the calamari was very breaded. They have a live band playing in the background with an artificial thunderstorm with some thunder. Our waiter was very courteous with our order. The place seems to be popular because there was a long line for people to get in without reservation. It was a good experience and relaxing indeed. I hold this as one of my lounge spots whenever I return to San Francisco.
author: Paul B.

description:
I had trouble with my Christmas Day reservations even though I made it 2 months in advance.  We wanted to be seated next to the pool area to watch the band.  We were told over the phone 3x it shouldn't be a problem.  The 4th time we were actually having drinks at the bar during Happy Hour a couple of hours earlier and talked to the hostesses.  Again, it shouldn't be a problem.  We went to the room, got cleaned up and went back down for dinner.  

When we got there...sorry, no table by the pool.  I was livid. I told one of the hostesses that I talked to people 4 different times and she was the only one who says that it is a problem.  She just walked away, probably to not blow up in my face.  We were appeased by Natalie who put us in a bigger table with a decent view.  But still, why could we not get what we wanted? Last year we had dinner there and asked if we could sit at the poolside tables which were empty at the time.  We were told they were reserved.  So this year, why could they not have done the same thing and not seat people there when we reserved and requested a poolside table?  

Earlier, at Happy Hour, my husband ordered 2 glasses of wine at the bar.  When he tasted it, he said he wanted to buy the bottle.  The bartender, Matthew, said he only poured one of the glasses out of the new bottle, so he wanted to charge us for the bottle and a glass.  He was also rude about it.  We complained to the manager about his behavior.

Finally, during dinner we ordered the deep fried Red Snapper, sort of an Asian version of a Mexican Majares Fritas.  $44.  When it came to the table it looked great.  Whole fish displayed on a huge platter.  It was almost embarrassing, but looked delicious too.  The seasoning was great, but the meat very dry.  Very disappointing.  We were beaten down by that time and decided to just go with the flow, enjoy Christmas Day and the music.
author: Gail K.

description:
The drinks were nice...

The service (not bar tenders) does not exist...

The only thing worse than the service was the food...

If you are telling people you are a premier establishment in the city this type of environment is unacceptable.

Plates and dishes piled up on chairs because nobody cares...

I don't care if it's Saturday night and you're busy.

That's what employees are for.

It's sad that owners of this landmark just don't care...

Jus sayin
author: Goofy N.

description:
Don't get me wrong - the atmosphere for this place is pretty cool. And, I'll be the first to admit, my friend and I wanted to go here because it looked rad on Instagram. However, I would never eat at this place.

We went at 5pm and they were only doing happy hour. If you wanted to get a table, you had to stand in a line (where they could see you, vs. putting your name down) and wait until they let you into the dining area). We were told that you can either pay $15 for their happy hour buffet (about 6-7 different options ranging from noodles to eggrolls) or stick to buying drinks at the bar. Because we planned on going to dinner after this, we stuck to the drinks.

I got the mai-tai, which wasn't very adventurous of me honestly. I was overwhelmed by the drink options and stuck to what I knew - very boring. It was alright.. but as the two star rating on Yelp states, "Meh. I've experienced better." There was so much ice in my glass that I honestly feel that the drink only filled up half of the glass total before the ice pushed it to the top. My friend got the drink which had coffee in it and returned it because it tasted so strongly of milk, which she said didn't mix well with the alcohol.

Once you get your drinks you can either sit at the bar (which is packed), or find space to stand in the small area where the buffet is - but majority of the room is dining tables which are completely empty.

The couple next to where I was standing paid for the buffet, and were complaining about how bland the food was. I looked at the Yelp reviews again and it pretty much confirmed my thoughts of this place.

Don't go for the food or service - go for the pretty drinks and pool area that you can Instagram...
author: Richa A.

description:
This is less of 2 star review and more of a 1.3 star review.

Also this review is exclusively for how Fairmont's Tonga Room handled my employer's holiday company party.

Here are the lowlights:

1. HUUUGE SLOW INEFFICIENT lines
2. Running out of food. 
3. Some of the bars ran out of some of the beers (anything other than bud or bud light)
4. Cash only - wont accept credit cards
5. Prices - i think the cheapest thing was 11$ and that was something horrible like budlight.
6. Honestly - the space is just not big enough to accomdate over 600 people.
7. Band too loud
8. Foods OK at best but - stale pita != pita chips
9. Ran out of room in the coat check - clearly they accepted a booking they were not prepared to handle.

Other that - the event was wonderful, and I have no strong feelings about this particular establishment.
author: Oleg H.

description:
This is review on a recent company party we had at this location.  The venue obviously oversold our company on what they could deliver.  Here is a recap of my experience - stand in line for a drink for 30 minutes, stand in line for an appetizer for 30 minutes, stand in another line for food, stand in line again for a drink.  One co-worker made the perfect comment of "oh look! a line!"  A couple key notes -

- We were supposed to have appetizers (400 of each) yet they somehow ran out in 10 minutes.  I was there at the very beginning and never saw anything.  They had the venue throughout three rooms but I later found out that the appetizers never left the first room and the people walking around never made it to the actual tonga room

- The bar did not take cards.  SERIOUSLY?  And I know that if they had told our team putting this together before hand, they would have got the message out to everyone to bring cash so they obviously didn't.  How does a bar not take cards?

- The bartenders except one lady were incredibly slow.  Someone said it best, they were like bartenders you have in a hotel lobby - not a bar.  The old man actually snapped at the coworker I was with and she hadn't even said anything to him yet.  Incredibly rude.  Another bartender when asked if there was anything to drink for pregnant ladies, literally yelled back "WATER!" How is this a way to treat guests?  The guests weren't even being disrespectful.  And then they tried to charge for water!  The free stuff that comes out of a tap! 

- The food was not set up in a good situation to refill easily and food ran out everywhere.

Like I said previously, the Tonga room definitely over sold us and were in no way ready and able to accommodate what they said they could.
author: Amanda K.

description: We came here for drinks, and I admit I was surprised and a bit tickled by the all-in tiki decor. I wasn't loving the mai tai, which I had to be convinced was not a mojito. Purists be damned, I want my pineapple! I'd still come back for the ambience, and give another drink a shot.
author: John M.

description: Good music experience.Expensive food and high coverage charges.Nice ambience.1.5 hr wait on Fridays
author: Navami V.

description: I haven't eaten here but the happy hour is definitely worth stopping by! The drinks are a bit pricey but delicious and fun themes. The atmosphere totally makes it worth it, if you're in the area it's awesome for maybe pre dinner drinks.
author: Krista H.

description: This place is pretty pricey. So something to consider is that you're pretty much paying for the ambiance. The live rain forest environment  was pretty cool but nothing really stands out about their drinks. I recommend getting here during their happy hour. I'd also recommend driving here as that the area is pretty hilly and steep. So if your plan to walk, be sure to where comfortable shoes.
author: Mikki M.

description:
The food selection is small. They run out of items. It taste just "ok". 
The atmosphere was fun!

Reservations are a pain over the phone, especially since the place looked half empty when we arrived. And the hey accept walk ins. 

It's fine for families. My 2 year old and 5 month old were with us and the 2 year old was happy dancing. Great place to take your parents for some clean SF entertainment.  The singer was was friendly and had a nice voice. Great show. 

I wish they had better food, or just other options.
author: Mel A.

description:
OMG this is a once in a lifetime experience that you should not miss!

A tinny band complete with "Wedding singeresque" vocals and a cranky server. Mix this with gigantic quantities of rum and BAM you are in a tropical paradise deep inside the Fairmont SF! Plus it rains in between sets complete with thunder while the band sails away on a retractable stage!

If you've been here before then you need to bring those that haven't. If you have not been here before then throw on your leadership boots and lead the way!

Woooooooo Cheers!
author: Jim P.

description:
I think I have to return here again in the future. Although quite the fun and kitschy place to bring a friend or loved one for the entertainment. I do question is there more to happen here expect for a slight storm show every hour? But I digress, if you love your tiki bars, and who doesn't? And if you don't paying a little more for the ambience in one of San Francisco's most famous bars in one of the city's most luxurious hotels. 

My friend and I, after a little bar hoping in places closer to Union Square, we always wanted to try this legendary place so up we went. It was a long walk from Stockton Street and once we made it we found the place slightly uninhabited for an earlier Saturday evening. 

The place picked up after a while, our server who was perhaps one of the more grizzled servers of this historical place suggested we get the Chi Chi's and Some Shrimp and Cilantro Rolls to eat. We agreed and of course got some Crispy Calamari (i.e. Muhe'e). 

The dishes tasted solid but the drinks were the highlight, fun and fresh they should be considering how few and far Happy Hour is at this place. But then again if the out-of-towners are coming in by the truckload then why should they expand the days and hours of H.H.? I would come back here just to get the feel of the place it is so huge and with the hourly storm and light show with some unique bar bites and tropi"cale" drinks? What's not to love?

I just hope this San Francisco institution isn't going anywhere anytime soon.
author: Jason F.

description: Hella expensive drinks didn't even know how to make a old fashioned but the bartender still charged  me 17.00 dollars for it ... then I order the porterhouse steak med rare comes out well done I would have taken it back for the 45 dollars I paid but have you seen the movie "Waiting"???  Plus it's really uncomfortable eating a steak you sent back for being over done ... Fuck this place will never go back don't recommend it it's a novelty place for tourists.
author: Robert P.

description: This place would get five stars if they would TURN THE F*ING MUSIC DOWN.  It is LITERALLY IMPOSSIBLE to hold a conversation on a Saturday with loud live music.
author: Jake B.

description: Great place to hang out with friends if you love a crowded room, then this is the place . Live music, drinks & food are amazing but Dessert was stale both times we went.
author: nazmena j.

description:
We were here in May of 2015. Wonderful
Hidden gem, really takes you back to a different time. Make sure to get a seat by the water to watch the band and order as many fruity cocktails as possible. Not a very lot of vegan options, some
Rice and veggies which were seasoned well. Make a reservation, they do get packed.
author: Rachel J.

description:
Kitschy old-school tiki bar in the basement of the Fairmont Hotel, complete with an island-themed band that plays out of a pagoda floating atop a pool in the middle of the room, and a simulated rain show every now and then.

The food isn't so much the focus as it is the retro atmosphere and the chi-chi cocktails, which are generously sized, well-presented, and feature all sorts of fruity ingredients. I enjoyed the hurricane, a "tropical cocktail" with rum, lemon juice, passion fruit syrup, and pomegranate, as well as the pineapple royale, which came in a ceramic pineapple-shaped container and featured rum, brandy, Cointreau, and pineapple juice. The bartenders are also friendly and on top of their game. 

While I wouldn't go at peak periods (weekend nights), this might be a good venue for some pre- or post-gaming if you're heading to the Masonic Theatre down the street or if you're having dinner in the vicinity.
author: Vincent L.

description:
We stopped here after seeing an episode of the Layover in San Francisco and were intrigued by the ambiance and, well, if Anthony Bourdain goes somewhere it probably isn't bad. 

The bad:

Frankly, the food is over priced for what it is. It's not bad by any means, but it isn't good enough for the price tag. I enjoyed it, but the money is better spent elsewhere. Maybe it was just the dish that I had. 

The meh:

The drinks were really good! Like totally good. But again I think they fall victim to the same issue as above, they're just too expensive for what they are, even though they were pretty stiff.

The good: 

The ambiance. 10/10. The entire setting of the restaurant is fun, beautiful, and entertaining. It really does a good job of giving off that tropical feel and looking around the place it was full of life and people having a great time. 

Overall:

I think the Tonga Room is definitely worth a visit. The price is likely jacked up because the venue itself is really just that great, and it is going to be a tad bit touristy, but even then it's worth the price when you take everything into account for at least one visit or to take somebody out for a special occasion.
author: Eric M.

description: We were just here for drinks and got there at 5 pm when it opened and it was already crowded. The folks at the hostess stand were friendly and the bartenders were efficient. The bar has no stools. We were told they take up too much room. The drinks were almost undrinkably syrupy. It was crowded and we wanted to sit down but couldn't. It's a cool touristy bar and I'm glad we poked our head in and tried a drink but all in all, I'm "one and done." I came, I saw, I left. We went up to the lobby bar, had amazing manhattans and much better time.
author: Brian B.

description:
I went to this place on a first date, which was probably not the best idea lol...but anyways -- I really wanted to check out this place because of the decor/ambiance.  We had tried the week before, but had failed to realize its NOT open on Tuesdays...so we came the next week on a Wednesday!  We didn't make a reservation, but still got seated anyways -- there were plenty of open tables.  So I wouldn't worry too much about making one on a weekday.  

Back to the date thing --- too loud for a first date lol.  Between the rain showers over the pool, the fake thunder, and the live music...haha not good for getting to know someone.

Also note, on some nights -- they have live music, and charge you an extra $7 as cover (but it's just added onto your bill.

I got the Pineapple Royale as my drink, and it was good (smaller than expected), but good.  We also ordered the Pu Pu Platter for two, crab tacos, and pork dumplings.  Honestly, everything was okay -- like nothing life changing. 

I think this place is worth coming and having a drink for fun and mostly for the decor/ambiance -- but just keep in mind it's for tourists, foodies will not be impressed.
author: Michelle S.

description:
My 28th birthday surprise dinner on January 29th 2015 was here with my boyfriend. 

After wandering the block to "throw me off the scent" we talked into the Fairmont Hotel and found out way to the entrance of the Tonga Room. 

I was super excited and a little in awe as we entered the elaborately decorated restaurant. It is like walking into a giant wooden ship, with beautiful wood and tiki accents, thatch hanging "roofs" and a pool right in the middle of the place! 

Seated near the pool our drink orders were taken and we scanned the menu for some food fare. A small but solid collection offered a big variety of things to try. 

We ordered:
Appetizer of Calamari: Fried, Tender Calamari, one of the BIGGEST portions I had ever seen... Not what we were expecting portion wise, but we were pleasantly surprised with how tender this item was.

While munching on the mass of calamari I was pleasantly surprised by the "rain" in the pool and then a boat moving! Wait... what? There is a BOAT! How neat. And a live band playing awesome music on this boat, in a pool, in a restaurant, in a hotel in San Francisco! Mind.. Blown... 

For dinner I had a BEAUTIFUL piece of of fish with a bright, lemon sauce that just popped on your tongue along with plantains and macadamia nuts. 

My boyfriend had a giant portion of Kalua Pork with an egg and rice. Overwhelmed by the portions we talked, drank, laughed and nibbled while listening to music until we literally burst. 

Dessert brought a beautiful Pineapple Rum Cake with a candle and Happy Birthday sung to me by a super polite waiter. 

Such an amazing experiance right here in our city.. If you are missing the islands, come here for a fun night out!
author: Meghan L.

description: To make a long story short... we had to wait in line to go to the  bar... fine... but we had not eaten dinner and I was looking forward to eating here as well but that would cost an additional $15 per person. So we went in and had a few drinks but we were all still hungry, I decided we must have misunderstood. I went back to the hostess and asked if we could get sat and eat. She told us bc there was entertainment we would be charged $15 per person. So... all the people standing up drink every where got in free but we want to purchase food and you change $15 extra per person??? Most backwards concept I've ever heard except for a place that is just looking to make money off liquor sales. Which also brings in underage people. Very disappointed
author: Catherine C.

description: This bar was so fun! Visited SF for first time and very glad I put this on itinerary. Dim lighting, tasteful tiki decor complete with rain and thunder effects. Romantic ambiance. The drinks were delicious and soooo strong. Highly recommend this place for happy hour (5-7). The prices are too high beyond that. I like slightly sweeter drinks. I had the tonga kong (highly recommend) and then the monk walks into luau (shared that with boyfriend). Had the calamari and tostadas. Good value happy hour food to go w the drinks.
author: Mimi N.

description:
Horrible don't go here! We checked in with the host mentioned we were only getting drinks so she sat us at a table by the bar. Once we got the check we found a $60 charge for the table, which the hostess never mentioned on top of the drinks we ordered. We tried asking the hostess about the charge and she was incredibly rude and lied about not telling us. 

We honestly didn't mind paying the charge since there were four of us but the way the hostess treated us was horrible and this we would never go back. 

The place is cool but overall really unpleasant that they trick you into paying way more and the customer service is horrible.
author: Ana M.

description:
I loved the Tonga Room when I went but be prepared for cheesy. The band is AMAZING - at one point I thought it was a Bruno Mars recording not the band playing - and their recorded music is on point too (hello cheesy 80s). I didn't get a chance to try their food but it's the Fairmont, how bad could it be? We ended up drinking the pineapple punch bowl, the better of the two. The other punch bowl is very strong, which wouldn't be bad if you liked rum a lot! The staff is so nice and when we didn't like the rum punch bowl they swapped it for the other at no cost!
The only downsides are the line for the bar gets crazy long (over an hour) and as of September they are no longer taking reservations. I would say if you showed up for dinner around 9 on a Friday or Saturday you could probably get seated quickly and get drinks at your table. Keep in mind the kitchen closes at 10.
The "rain" in there isn't as cool as others make it sound too, it's just raining around the perimeter of the lake where the band plays, but they really didn't cut any corners when sticking to theme. 

Although cheesy, it's definitely a fun must do in sf if you're a local, or a tourist!
author: Shannon H.

description:
This place was fun. When my friend and I showed up for dinner, we were able to get a drink pretty quickly and stood by the pool in the middle. People did mention there was some water show, but we didn't experience it (I kind of wish I did).
