We ended up ordering a Singapore Sling and the Hurricane. I really enjoyed my Singapore Sling. Fruity and not super alcoholic. My friend's hurricane was about too much for me, but it was still good. 

Protip: go to the tonga room and get a drink!!
author: Nina Y.

description:
Went for dinner on a Thursday night. 

Pros: great show and live band. Fun dancing and cool rain effects in the restaurant. Great Sevice and the drinks were made perfectly- not too weak, not too strong. 

Cons: had to wait 15 minutes for a table even though they had tons of empty tables all night. They charge extra for the show even though we just came for dinner. But the band was good, so I didn't protest. Pretty loud, not the best place for an intimate dinner.
author: Jon B.

description:
Did I go to Tonga when I went to the Tonga room? Heck no! Nor did I feel like I did. I had mixed emotions. Is this rather cheesy and off the wall spot really in the Fairmont hotel? Yes. Yet the simple fact of the matter is...It was fun.

The venue is creative and entertaining. You aren't in the stuffy feel of the Fairmont (please read that with a tone) and the craziness of the city life. You are in this cheesy fun spot that has a live band playing while you enjoy some colorful cocktails. By the way...share the cocktails, or you will all be stumbling out at the end of the night. 

Service was ok. You can never be quick enough when you want a cocktail, but the staff kept up with the pace. While I can't speak for dinner service, the post hours certainly was fun and entertaining.

For something different than the normal city activities, check it out. It was a cool laid back spot that was worth the small cover charge!
author: Chad Y.

description:
My daughter's classmate had a Bat Mitzvah here, shut down the entire block surrounding the Fairmont.  They went all out, anything you can think of, they paid for.  It was like the movie "Bridesmaids", where you leave with a cute puppy as a party favor, but at this party, you leave with live gold fishies at a 12-year-old girl's party.  I literally thought President Obama was in town (again).  The best party ever that night in Nob Hill, had the time of their lives!!!

Obviously I'm not Jewish, but always wanted to try the Tonga Room as a local.  This place is overly pricey and touristy; although, I can totally see why the out-of-towners love it.  Our experience here was dull, besides the band on the water.  I couldn't really see them with all the people shaking their tail feather in front of our faces.  They kept the place lively, as the recurring rainstorm was not entertaining at all - it gets old. 

I specifically asked for the kalua pork to be less salty.  Guess what?  It was still salty.  Kalua pork and rice, don't expect to see much rice.  Our server was an Asian lady who didn't crack a smile, she was so done for the evening.  The drinks were skimpy, definitely not worth paying full price, maybe during HH.  The cover charge was unnecessary, just another cost they can tack on like the SF restaurant healthcare surcharge.  If I want a tropical vibe, I will be patronizing Natoma Cabana next time and know that my drinks are made with love.
author: Christine R.

description:
I have great and long-standing affection for the Tonga Room, and know to expect the drinks to be overpriced ($16 and $18!). They just weren't very good this time. The Mai Tai had odd , tar-y note to the flavor, and the other drink I tried wasn't very good either. We finished them, but more discriminating or assertive drinkers might have made an issue of it. It is a great room (in a kitschy way, of course)--still kind of a treasure, but they need different drink recipes. If it keeps on like this, I'll stop feeling lucky that it avoided being closed a few years back, when the hotel was gonna axe it.

It would nice if they had svelte Polynesian women as servers, but I think that about every place.
author: John H.

description:
My first visit to the Tonga Room when I was at the tender age of 12.

Yep, my mom started me young.

Not romancing the bottle (that was my own doing) but she instilled in me the value of a dollar. Well, she tried to at least because I'm doing a piss poor job of it as an adult. 

As a kid, my mom would bring me to the Tonga Room for the then $2 buffet with one drink minimum (now $10 on Wednesdays - Fridays 5-7pm). The food was like PF Chang's but hey, I was young and had no standards. Potstickers and egg rolls--FTW!

Pass forward eons later, Tonga Room has become a hot spot for tourists thanks to Anthony Bourdain. I haven't been back in years so when my friend suggested we come here for after dinner drinks, I was game.

We arrived a little before 10 pm on Saturday to a line with about 30 people deep. We didn't make reservations but the wait for a table wasn't too bad (25 minutes). Cover on the weekend is $7 ($5 Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Sundays). Do NOT even attempt to drive here. Street parking is impossible and valet is $56!?! Uber it.

Walking into the Tonga Room, it was as tacky as I remembered it: Rain Forest Cafe meets Mama's Family in Hawaii. All I was missing was my muumuu.

I usually don't order foo foo, fruity cocktails but when in Rome right? We decided to share the Scorpion Bowl ($32) and Smuggler's Golden Punch Bowl ($22): http://bit.ly/1ltQsvk. My friend also ordered a pina colada. Considering how busy they were, our drinks surprisingly arrived in just 7 minutes...from the kitchen.

With the first sip of the Smuggler's Punch (white rum), we looked at each other and we all had DAT face...like we just sucked sour toes. Maybe the Scorpion Bowl (dark rum) tasted better? Nope, it tasted like ass with butane. They were the WORST drinks we've ever had. Bar none. A hot mess of cheap wells charged at top shelf prices thrown together by someone who has no business mixing drinks. The Bon Vivants would be horrified. 

My friend's piña colada was merely commercial piña colada mix over crushed ice. For a $12 drink, you would think they would take the 30 seconds to blend it! Nope. My friends and I were saying that we wouldn't be surprised if the drinks were pre-made and kept in huge tubs; where the waiters would ladle into a bowl with ice when an order is up.

Even though we just had dinner, we thought ordering something salty would help the drinks go down better BUT $14 for four cha siu baos (bbq pork buns)?! WTF, I could uber it to Chinatown and back, and get half a dozen for that price. I'm sure it would taste better too. Instead, we opted to get $6 bottled beers to chase down our awful drinks that we never finished.

For legit tiki cocktails at half the price, hit up Smuggler's Cove (Hayes Valley), Tiki Haven (Sunset) or Trad'r Sam's (Richmond).

Now for the service. For a "world renowned" hotel, I expected the service to match. Instead, service was that of a stereotypical Chinese restaurant. Sh*tty. Before I can even put my purse down as we were seated, our waiter curtly asked, "ready to order"? Slow your roll, homie. Once we ordered our drinks, he just plopped it on the table and went MIA. The staff clearly have been working there for decades and have lost every incentive to provide good customer service. Yay, unions!

So why three stars?

Tonga Rooms is one of those place you have to experience once in your life. It's hella cheesy and hella overpriced, but hella entertaining. The floating live band and the crowd were Tonga Room's saving grace. The upbeat band did an awesome job singing renditions of top hits from Prince, Stevie Wonder, Michael Jackson, Pharrell, and Bruno Mars. 

The older crowd was eclectic and very fun. The table next to us was celebrating a 40th birthday and birthday boy was on a mission...OPERATION: GET SMASHED. He put several straws together and managed to drink from our punch bowl: http://bit.ly/1tFBQZY. He then went around to other tables and did the same. Total beast.  

Mad props to the older Asian ladies who were getting down on the dance floor. There was one in a tight white dress flossing "Hollywood" stunna shades from the 80's movie Mannequin: http://yhoo.it/1pCyeYp. When I grow up, I wanna be just like her....twerking up on a 20 somethang year old. GO MAAAAMIIII!
author: Cherylynn N.

description: A must visit cool bar in SF, very stylish with interesting decorations. Wonderful live music performance during the night.
author: Maruko X.

description:
"Every American needs this," Anthony Bourdain said in reference to the Tonga Room. "Because if you've got no love in your heart for this place, you are a sick, twisted, lonely f*ck with too many cats."

Anthony also said "It's the greatest place on earth." I'm not certain about that, but the Tonga room is pretty freaking cool! Definitely unique! Located inside an unassuming Fairmont Hotel in downtown, you walk in and are transported to Gilligan's Island meets hyped up Techno club! 

The scenery is the bomb - from people watching, to all of the palm trees, flaming tiki torches, the cool "lake" in the center that houses the floating stage the band plays cheesy cover songs from - complete with the occasional rain shower and thunder that you would expect in the tropics! Don't worry, you won't get wet...it only rains over the lake...well, I guess unless you fall in! People seem to really like the specialty libations offered and are not shy at all about getting their groove on and letting loose island style! 

Our small group landed a table for 4 located in prime real estate. Wait staff is amazingly attentive! Had to try the Lava concoction for 2. Not sure exactly what was in it, but I'm sure it included some kind of rum...aka love punch. Also ordered the Royale Pupu Platter. Good eats. So much better than expected.! 

Overall: Yeah, the prices are high, but you pay for the adult amusement park factor! One of a kind! Totally worth a visit!
author: Dawn H.

description:
Tonga Room is very cool ...but not exactly what I was looking for

ATMOSPHERE

Hands down, Tonga Room is the most unique bar/restaurant I have ever been to! The repurposed pool into a lake with floating live band? Genius. Too bad the band left not 10 minutes after we got there.

It is VERY loud and quite bustling. I would say Tonga is the perfect place for a family or friend celebration. There's a little dance floor to see all the silly or crazy moves people are willing to do in public.

There's also a decent standing table area by the bar for those who are only drinking and not eating (where we managed to grab a table).

SERVICE

This ain't the club but holy cheesus I could NOT manage to get the bartender's attention. To be honest, I was hoping for a quiet night with a few drinks so I was a little overwhelmed and people were just so pushy at the bar that I couldn't find the courage to speak up. I just let my friends handle it. Bartenders are a little slow. Maybe they should put more on shift. Staff were not that friendly but were not horrible but the chaos of the room felt like it needed a little more control...Unless that's what they were going for? I was hopelessly lost half the time.

DRINKS

The drinks were, unsurprisingly, fruity and sweet. The balance of flavors wasn't too bad. Besides a few cocktails we shared a large bowl thing, which seems quite unsanitary to me (backwash alert). The drinks could have been stronger. Price is alright.
author: Pim Y.

description: First timers...Great atmosphere! Strong drinks!  Bartenders could have been a bit more friendly with the amount of money rolling in but it was still a great time!
author: Allie L.

description: I know this place is supposed to be fun but it really was not.  They open the door at 5pm.  We got there a bit early and had to wait in line.  By the time we got to the front, there was no bar seating left so we had to stand around.  We did get a drink right away.  I had some run concoction.  It was good but pricy.  The floor was sticky and wet near the bar.  We did not stay for the show later but I definitely don't need to go back after this experience.
author: Karen C.

description:
The Tonga Room is a pretty fun place to visit. You've got strong tropical drinks for two (or four), a machine that can make it rain on demand, a dance floor, an owner who will personally come to your table to see how you're doing, and fancy dishes galore.

They do go with the whole "less is more" principle here, but everything is surprisingly filling. Just be sure to swing by the bank before coming -- this place isn't cheap.
author: Casey S.

description: Anthony Bordaine might of had a good time here but I didn't. Tonga is all about the decor and forgot about the bar. We went for happy hour and were arrogantly told there was a hour and a half wait for a table but we could get a drink at the bar. Ok, fair enough. The bored and indifferent bartender took my order but explained that there was no appetizers unless you had a seat.  I looked around and saw open tables,not just in the restaurant, but in the bar as well. With open tables the place was crowded, the two managers diligently guarding the reserved tables. We left before the Olsen twins arrived.
author: Art H.

description:
Did not have high expectations to start with based off the Yelp reviews and pictures. BUT this has been a place my boyfriend mentioned he wanted to try since it was a San Francisco staple. Made reservations a few weeks ahead and were seated on time. Prior to sitting we agreed not to even try their main entrees and just go for drinks and appetizers. 

-The ambiance screams cheesy-Disneyland-tropical, which I actually kind of enjoyed since it was different than the modern contemporary decor many SF restaurants are going for. 
-COVER! Yes there is a cover that I was only made aware of as we were sitting...$7/person for the cheesy band (to be fair I say cheesy because they were old school dudes doing covers to songs from the 70's...I'm sure my parents would've loved them lol) 
-Cocktails...nothing worse than sugary overpriced cocktails in my opinion.
-Food=thumbs down, as expected. We had only tried the calamari because nothing else on the menu sounded interesting enough to try. AND how bad can you mess up fried calamari? Well for $15, this bowl of calamari was hard, chewy, and overcooked. 

On the bright side, our server was really nice and accommodating of my lactose free diet! Overall, not a good place for young couples or "foodies" but would highly recommend for tourists seeking a fun night in SF.
author: Kimberly C.

description: Came here with friends for drinks but we ended up sitting for food too (they would have charged us $15 per person to sit and order food if my friends hadn't been staying at the Fairmont hotel - they did charge us this at first and we had to ask them to fix it).  Wine not cheap.. $11-20 per glass, and hardly any vegan food options.  We got veggie pot-stickers and veggie spring rolls, which I HOPE were vegan but in a dark, loud restaurant with a slight language barrier with the waiter it was hard to find out.  My friend ordered us the fried rice, and asked them to leave out all egg and meat, and it arrived full of egg.  I told them just to leave it and I would try to eat around the egg, and later I also thought of the fact that it might have been cooked in butter instead of oil.  The waiter brought a surprise salad covered in non-vegan creamy dressing to try to make up for it.  I gave that to my friends since I couldn't eat it.  We also ordered edamame which came covered in some kind of mayonnaise (mayo is full of egg), and I didn't remember seeing this specified on the menu.  So overall, it's not very vegan-friendly.  They tried, sort of, but the staff needs to be better educated on being sensitive and aware of dietary needs because I'm not a fan of purchasing food I can't eat.  Otherwise, the decor is cool, and it's a neat, unique place for a drink if you don't mind standing.  If you are vegan, I would recommend eating elsewhere.
author: Reba W.

description: The bartender took awhile to get to my group, but once he did, he was super fast! Drinks are on the pricy side, but they're strong. Tonga could use more standing tables for people to gather around as well. The place can be a little hard to find, but everyone at Fairmont was kind in directing us where to go. Would definitely go again!
author: Emily S.

description:
Here for cocktails with my band. It's pretty dark in here but that's mood lighting. Every once in a while it starts "raining" and has lightening in the middle of the plane. Pretty cool. Like rainforest cafe but fancier without all the gorillas and smelly children.

I opted for the buffet which was minimal but is $10 and totally worth it. 

The pinch bowls to share are not worth it. They're pretty small. Just get your own drink. All in all I liked it. Our waitress is bomb!
author: Samantha W.

description: Great fun atmosphere! Beware the strong drinks, I would give this place a 5 but knocking it down to 4 because the drinks have a balance problem. They TASTE strong which isn't totally appealing. Two drinks and I'm done for the night, and I am no lightweight. That being said, if you pace yourself you will enjoy it! We had a pupu platter (ie, an appetizer sampler) and the appetizers are amazing. And I can't emphasize enough how fun the atmosphere is. Worth a stop for sure, and the super-strong drinks are only $10 each during happy hour, which I think is 5-7.
author: Katie W.

description: I showed up about an hour before closing on Sunday just to check out the Tonga room. My husband and I shared a tiki drink ($24 after tax and tip -- damn!) and checked out this Anthony Bourdain's heavily endorsed tiki joint. The drink is a bit on the sweet side for me so I only had two sips. There is usually a $7 entertainment fee per person, but I guess we didn't have to pay it because we showed up 1 hour before closing. The band was pretty good and it's cute how they played on the moving float. The decor is fun pictures too! Great touristy place to snaps some photos and enjoy the fun tropical party atmosphere.
author: Lina W.

description: Even with the renovations, the Tonga Room still makes you feel like you stepped into an old-time San Francisco classic. The tiki decorations are a little tacky, and the rain and thunder still come pouring down, which, after hearing a live island-inspired rendition of Creedence Clearwater's "Have You Ever Seen the Rain?", you feel just a bit happier. Drinks are strong, and bowls are large, so prepare to drink. Whether you're sipping on classic Mai Tai, Singapore Sling, or Planter's Punch, be prepared for a large dose of rum and sugar. You can't go wrong. Food-wise, you're not really here for that, so maybe you just want a Pu Pu Platter to share while you dance and listen to the thunder.
author: Danny C.

description:
I'm a native San Franciscan. I've been coming to the tonga room for years, even as a child with my parents. Great place. However, tonight, I did not have the best time. 

It was a Saturday night around 9pm (precisely 4/2917 at 9:05:57 pm - according to my receipt. Check: 6789)  I was waiting at the bar with my dad, ready to order drinks. It wasn't too busy when I got there. The bartender (the only Asian bartender, couldn't see his name on tag) then came up to our side of the bar and I began to order. Immediately he threw his hand in the air gave me the worst attitude and said, "Excuse me! I'm taking their order first," in a completely condescending tone. He then proceeded to ignore me and take the order of a group of blonde women to my right (who btw, arrived AFTER me). First of all, I was there first. I was in no way trying to grab his attention in a rudely manner. I only spoke up and ordered because I knew it was my turn and everyone else at the bar knew I was next in line as well. Even the group of blondes he served instead apologized to me for the rude bartender's attitude. It wasn't even that busy to begin with! How can you not know who comes next?? Finally another bartender, Matthew E, came over and asked for our order. He literally saved this review from being a one star rating. He got our order correctly and even threw in an iced coffee. Thank you, Matthew E for the great service! Asian bartender, please learn some manners and know how to talk to patrons like adults and not talk to them like they're children.

NOT going back to the Tonga Room anytime soon, nor will I be recommending this place to other people. You just lost a long time customer!
author: Katrina D.

description: What a busy place! We were lucky to get a seat so make sure you make a reservation. Happy hour was just ending so maybe that's why it was so packed. The drinks were ok.
author: Rebecca S.

description: This bar is at the Fairmont Hotel.  You can enter through the side entrance and there will be a cover charge for $10 that we thankfully were able to avoid especially since the drinks are about $15+.  Like Anthony Bourdain said you'll find your girly umbrella drinks here and they have got a punch!  Fun environment for various ages.
author: Cynthia A.

description: The lines for this tourist destination are absolutely ridiculous! Got here at 10pm on a Saturday night and we waited over 1.5 hours in line to get inside :/ I even asked the employee at the door how long the wait would be and they told me only 30 minutes. I'd highly recommend just paying their table fee of 7$ per person and getting a table if you want to check out this place. The drinks are wonderful and the scorpion and lava bowl are perfect for sharing with friends! We devoured two of them within 30 minutes and then headed out to the dance floor for some cheesy dancing with the older couples. The live band was fantastic and the music was great but they were incredibly rude and wouldn't take any of our requests. Despite the good drinks, the long wait and staff is just not worth it.
author: Lisa H.

description:
Had to check out the Tonga room. Third trip to SF and first with the "kid". (16). He thoroughly enjoyed the atmosphere and the food. While I also enjoyed those things,couldn't give more stars due to service issues. 
Complimentary edamame was presented when we sat down --but the bowl was full of EMPTY shells how could the waiter not have known that these shells were empty?? Just gross to be served! 
Service was slow- which was weird because there were 2 "assistants" helping with water and clearing. Couldn't one be trained to help take drink orders to keep things moving??  Overall enjoyed the evening. Lots of fun folks enjoying the retro vibe and our food was very good.
author: Kay K.

description:
Tonga Room is beautiful indeed. The indoor pool with a center gazebo along with the band is pretty darn cool. They even have artificial rain that comes down every so often, giving the place a tropical feel.

The website says that we had to pay a cover to get in but we went on a weekday and since it was quiet, we walked right in. We only went to the bar area for drinks.

The drinks are very expensive for their small sizes. I tried 3 different drinks and didn't quite care for any of them. The bartenders are very nice though and the service was fairly prompt.

I probably wouldn't come back here again on my next visit but if you haven't been, the decor of the restaurant is great for a photo op with your friends.
author: Natalie K.

description:
The drinks are bad. The food is bad.

IT RAINS EVERY 30 MINUTES, THE BAND PLAYS ON AN ISLAND, THE DANCE FLOOR IS A PIRATE SHIP. THAT IS SO COOL IT ALMOST MAKES IT 5 STARS ALONE...but...

...this is a place where their fruit juices (likely) come from a can. It's in the Fairmont, which is beautiful, and I have never had a bad time here. Bring a group, grab an over-priced, poorly mixed Scorpion and dance to the band. It'll be great.

 For a true, mid-century Tiki experience, though, probably not your best bet, especially not in the Bay Area which boasts treasures like Forbidden Island and Smuggler's Cove. Even the drinks at Trad'r Sams is better.
author: Scott B.

description: I love the Tonga Room!!! Literally my favorite restaurant ever! Last night we were lucky enough to get a table with no reservation, no easy feat considering you usually have to make one several weeks in advance. I have the best husband  thank you to handsome "host" who gave us the table & our awesome waitress who really took care of us and encouraged me to order the mahi-mahi which was one of the best dishes I have ever had!!! Cooked perfectly in a mouth watering, light delicious, delicate sauce. I don't ever want to order fish again because I know it won't compare with the one I had last night..... for appetizers we had the pu pu platter and each little morsel was more yummy than the next. Our drinks were on point too, mai tai's and a scorpion bowl in fun Hawaiian  glassware. Now let's talk atmosphere & music, you feel like you are at a luau in Hawaii at a fancy hotel (maybe because you really are in a fancy hotel) you don't feel like you are in the Bay Area at all. It rains while you are dining looking out over the pool, listening to your favorite band sing Santana songs. I love the band! It's worth the extra money you pay to listen to them. Thank you Tonga Room for always giving me the best date night EVER!!!!!
author: Tigerlily S.

description: The ambiance is awesome.  The room looks great and the rain storm every 30 minutes is cool.  The drinks are pretty good too.  If you're in San Francisco you really should check it out.  That said when we went the food was mediocre and the service was fair.  It seemed like our server was unhappy about something.  We got there right when they opened during the week and there was a line, but we were able to get a table right away.  It is definitely a fun place to check out, hopefully the server we had was just having a bad day.
author: Brian R.

description: I like this place, was coming  there with friends three times. Every time we saw musicians in the boat, ones they played a special song for my friend's b-day - very nice!)) It's a great place for having good time, listen live music and dance maybe. I like the restful atmosphere of this place. But I did not try a food there yet. Every time we came for the cocktails only. For sitting on the table you would pay 10$ per person but you can stand on the "deck" or sit on the bar for free.
author: Podvysotska A.

description: This place was pretty happening, nice strong drinks and island cusine. Who knew right under my nose is a slice of island life.
author: Calvin L.

description:
Best fun we have 
Food was good service is fast 
Drinks are on the strong side 
Will love to go again
author: SHARON T.

description:
I don't know how this place only has 3.5 stars!!!!  We made reservations ahead of time and was seated as soon as we arrived.  The hostess was nice and polite and set high expectations for the rest of the night.

We got seated and our server (I think his name is Bash) came over asking us if we wanted water and something to drink.  He was very attentive throughout the night and make sure we were happy, watered, and satisfied.  He was fun to have around and passionate about what he does!  We need more people like him in the service industry!

Our drinks were definitely the highlight!  I got the Royale Royale and my husband got the Hurricane and then the .  Both very sweet drinks but delicious and FUN!  Mine came in a freshly cut pineapple with sunbrellas! 

The food was consistent and good, I loved the Tonga Platter for appetizer with crab ragoons, wings, spring rolls and tender, delicious ribs!  We got the Tongan fried rice and Kahlua Pork for the entree.  Both very consistent dishes that I would not mind having again!

The atmosphere was super cool!  We came right before Halloween so all the decors were up and you can tell they splurged on it!  The fake indoor rain came on once in a while and the bar was popping!  I can't wait to take my parents here when they visit!
author: Gwingie L.

description: I went in with my expectations perhaps a bit too high. We were seated towards the front and away from the water so I felt I didn't have the full experience. Also the band wasn't playing at the time and it was early evening on a Sunday so perhaps the ambience would be better later in the night. I ordered the zombie, which is definitely strong but almost tastes like NyQuil. The Mai Tai tasted much better and one was enough to get me decently buzzed. Their drinks are expensive but I feel you're paying for the atmosphere.
author: Rohini B.

description:
The only reason why this place is getting 2 stars is because of the service which was at times questionable, i.e. clearing plates that someone was still eating..

In short this place is over priced and more geared to individuals in their late 50's. They charge a $10 cover charge for a band that plays oldies. Our party of 9 decided to do pre fixe menu and the food was nothing short of crap which was bland, and over cooked. 

They even messed up on the dessert which was without a doubt pretty but too tart for anyone's liking.

Lose your money else where folks.
author: Jody B.

description: Finally was able to visit the Tonga Room after wanting to for a long time.  Unfortunately the experience left a lot to be desired as the staff let a private next to is completely over run our table.  Constant pushing and bumping into us followed by being told I was the one being rude for complaining to the people attending the party.  After several members of our party complaining all the manager did was comp our drinks and cover instead of the whole meal.  I'd be willing to give it another chance but the first impression is one of poor management and utter lack of respect for their regular customers.
author: Spencer D.

description:
Disaster of a bar in the classiest of hotels. My friend described it as an adult Rainforest Cafe. I wish it was that! We waited in a line (with a $7 cover?!) to enter a creepy, mostly empty restaurant/bar. In the middle of the hideous painted brown dark wood decor is a very large, old tiled swimming pool. In the middle of the pool floats a large boat/raft where a band plays. The boat teeters in the middle of the pool and gets pulled back and forth across the place. Think of this taking place in the lamest possible way. I don't think the decor has been updated in decades. 

After waiting in line for way too long, the bad music was too loud and the ambience left more than a little to be desired. We wanted to chill at a bar and have a drink, but they insisted we go to a table and were very strict about who was with us. We were seated and finally brought menus. They serve sugar and (mostly) rum drinks that are made for 2 or 4 people. There was nothing craft or alluring about any of them. The waiter informed me the least sweet drink on the menu was a Mai Tai. No. 

My friend ordered a lava bowl for 2. The $20 spent on this was one of the worst I've ever spent. The bowl was small and terrible - syrup and rum. Others at the table more wisely opted for a beer, of which Tonga's selection was not impressive. 

Skip Tonga. It's outdated, unfriendly, icky, and not tasty. Maybe this place is better with beer goggles?
author: Kara T.

description:
Ambience is pretty nice. Crowd is definitely on the older side.
Drinks are good but seem very overpriced.
author: Nitesh D.

description:
You have got to be kidding me. I walked in on a Friday night and the band was playing "Achy Breaky Heart" to people line dancing. This was followed by something I couldn't identify, but it started a conga line by some people wearing leis. I felt like I was at a bad Mexican resort, frequented by Americans who had never left the country. 

Doesn't matter how good the drinks are if you can't stand being there.
author: Mariko F.

description: They are a little pricey and food is just alright but the atmosphere is amazing! And there drinks are also really good. Definitely worth going.
author: Nelly J.

description: What a fun spot service is a little spotty but after a long walk in San Francisco being proper tourist it was a sweet spot to sit drink and have some laughs.
author: Leslie H.

description:
I have never given a restaurant a one star but here you go - I give Tonga the honors.

1) We arrive at Tong and there is a very long line on a Friday night. A long line like we are at a club. I am supposed to be taking my fiance on a date so we were relaxed and willing to wait. I walk up to the doorman and ask him what the line is for. He said that if we had reservations to see the hostess, if we did not have reservations step in line. So we stepped in line

2) We painfully watched the doorman awkwardly tell people "no you cannot meet your party inside unless we can prove you are a part of their party" - "no you cannot come in unless you have a reservation, please stand in line" - "no no no no no"  for about 40 minutes

3) At the 40 minute mark the woman asks "who would like to sit in the bar area at a table for two and we said "yes!" She takes us to a sticky table next to the busy bar area and the server hands us two bar menus. We had been looking over the full menu in line and asked if we could order from that menu. The server told us no, that the bar area had a bar menu with plenty of good options.

4) I walk back to the hostess and told her that when we were seated, she did not explain that we would not get the full menu. She said "this line is for the bar - if you want to sit at the bar, that is the only menu available" wait - what? I explained to her that the doorman told us that this line was for people who did not have a reservation - not specifically the bar. She said "no one in line will be seated at a table because we have a lot of reservations - this is only for the bar" I WISH you all would have explained that one hour ago.

On top of that there was an extra $10-$20 (i cant remember) to be in the band's presence while we ate. No thanks - I will NEVER be back to this poorly ran establishment.

Oh - and we left - we didn't eat there and never will so no comment on food
author: Jazmyn W.

description:
What a magical place, in such a bizarre way. Why does a beautiful historic hotel at the top of an SF hill have a basement tiki bar? Because someone there was/is a genius I guess. They took the hotel pool in the basement and put a floating stage on it, and made it rain around the edges (literally) and filled the surrounding room with palm trees and put a bar in and a bunch of tables and high tops.... and Tadah! Tonga! I'm not sure I would ever dine there, it's a little damp and basementy, but it's so freaking fun and over the top to go for drinks. Walk into the glorious art deco hotel lobby, find your way downstairs and to the right and follow the signs for the Tonga room and then boom, basement theme bar. Everybody Tonga.

(I actually started out at 3 stars for this one, but then I remembered how freaking amazing the band doing covers on a floating stage on the pool was in the rain and I bumped it up just for them. They are everything.)
author: Risa D.

description: Five stars for the experience, 4 stars for the food. The restaurant has an in-door tiki bar surrounded by water... how cool is that? You'll need reservations for dinner. We did a walk-in around 5pm on Sunday (there was already a line) and sat in the bar section. The "bar bites" were pretty good. I'd go back for the experience with friends. If you're visiting San Francisco for the first time, definitely check this place out.
author: Brooks A.

description:
The Tonga Room is a San Francisco institution. You gotta go in when the band is playing, just to watch the indoor rain fall with lightning and thunder effects, and the band floating in the middle of the water. Definitely a fun place to drink, dance and have some eats if you're hungry.

We ordered the beef jerky, which actually was very good! It was more like thin slices of beef pan fried and charred, rather than dehydrated. It had a nice sweet chili dipping sauce. A nice flavor of saltiness to compliment the drinks!
author: Joselito L.

description: Gave them 4-stars back in 2011. Every staff was friendly and the food wasn't bad. The highlight was the band & the rain & thunderstorm effects. However, they had a fire incident and after it cleared, the hostess announced they will be serving drinks ONLY but NOT dinner. I clarified this with her as we had reservations so we left as we were very hungry. She was not even apologetic and was SMUG about it. Then they reported us as "no show" with Opentable. Given they cannot serve dinner which requires reservations, it's not common sense for people who wants to eat to leave. D-UH!
author: Maryanne Rachel C.

description:
What a weird place.  It's like something from Disneyland broke loose and barricaded itself in the basement of the Fairmont Hotel.

Walk inside and you're transported to a faux tropical environment with tiki huts and fake thunderstorms falling into an indoor pool.  It's tacky-amusing.

We arrived during Happy Hour when they told us they'd sold out for their buffet, but we could have a drink at the bar.

We paid $15 to share a "lava bowl" - Two different rums, lemon, lime and a candied orange peel.  Their bowls are supposed to be for two people, but even for two, it wasn't that much booze.  Still, the drink packed a punch.

I can't speak to the quality of the food, but this place is so bizarre, you kinda have to make a stop here just for the experience.
author: Ben B.

description: I have called 3 times and left a message for the lady that takes reservation. I wanted to celebrate my parents 50th anniversary there. This place lost our business.
author: Lula J.

description: Drinks are expensive. Environment is fun and super unique. You have to pay $15 to get a seat if you're not a hotel guest.
author: Sean M.

description: Let's start with the positives: we had reservations, they honored them, they sat us down on time but  then it took another 20 minutes for a human being to walk by notice we were alive. Then it took another 40 minutes for the food to arrive. Mind you, the portions were small and the food was less than impressive. The Mai Tai took the edge off but I definitely lost my buzz once our waitress, Grace, returned with the bill. She had penned  in her OWN gratuity amount in the gratuity line! Wait, what?!?!  I thought that was my decision. She gave herself a 40% tip!!! I don't know if she thought we were buzzed or stupid. The only reason I didn't get upset is because it was Christmas Eve and I thought it would be best to let it go. My advice? Go for the drinks, music & dancing...skip dinner!!
author: Sharen E.

description: Really enjoyed the atmosphere here! What a fun tiki bar/restaurant with a unique experience that once was the indoor pool back in the 30s for the hotel. Now what was once the pool in the center of this restaurant/bar is where a boat hangs out on the center of the water for the band to play and it rains over the pool (not on you) throughout the evening for a fun experience. We didn't have dinner but instead enjoyed the lounge area with a tasty Mai Tai and a Fog Cutter - both very good and nicely served! We also ordered the calamari which came with quite a large portion, almost too much for two for an app, but it was good. Would love to come back when we're back in the city!
author: Mindy N.

description:
I love Tiki Bars, so much so that I search them out when traveling, this one is on par with most in the decor department except for one thing. They have tiki heads and palm fronds however they take it one step further. A lagoon fills the center of the room that features a monsoon with a floating stage. 

Big drinks is the name of the game and I love me a big drink. Like a lot. These were not too great however. Lower end booze and syrupy juices are what made mine unpleasant. Sure it got me drunk but it wasn't a fun experience. The food was fine, expensive but fine. I don't know if I'll return since there are far better cheesy tiki bars; but if you're in the area and want a faux island experience, it might be worth the stop.
author: Justin C.

description:
Such a fun night!

My dad made reservations at the Tonga Room way in advance because he really wanted to make sure we didn't have to wait in that horrendous line! So at 6:30 we walked right up to the hostess and were seated at a beautiful table near the water. 

We ordered the Pu Pu Platter to start and it was excellent! The chicken legs were tasty and had a bit of a bite to them so they were definitely one of my favorites. The ribs were a bit on the salty side but quite meaty, egg rolls were solid (filled with portabellas), and the crab rangoons were actually quite tasty considering I'm usually not a fan of those. I LOVED the three sauces they served on the side: plum sauce, chili sauce, and hot mustard. They were super yummy!

For dinner we ordered the Huli Huli Chicken, the Kalua Pork, Forbidden Rice blend, and the grilled asparagus. Everything was tasty but the portions were huge so watch out! I enjoyed the chicken the most because the meat was tender and it had a nice mix of veggies in a sweet, tangy sauce. The Kalua pork was pretty good but it tasted better with the addition of some of the side sauces because the meat was a tiny bit on the dry side. The asparagus was perfectly cooked and the Forbidden rice blend was excellent; a nice change from the usual plain white rice. 

I was super full and didn't want dessert but my parents wanted to try something so they ordered the banana split (which is supposed to be for 4-6 people). IT WAS MASSIVE. There was no way we could finish but we did our best; all the ice creams/sorbets were delicious, but I enjoyed the mango the best. We also asked for the sauces on the side (chocolate, strawberry, caramel) which was perfect because it kept the ice creams safe and each person could add as much as they wanted. 

Service was great, and it was a lot of fun to listen to the band which started playing at 8 PM. This was a great experience and I'd definitely recommend visiting!
author: Sam F.

description:
Ok they don't open till 5:00!
So no NOONER... Shoot ..and dark Monday
Go in grab a drink , not a place for kids, big kids work great as long as " drinks well with others"..
Try a MaiTai so smooth really refreshing!
No seating in dining area till 6:00..will cost u 
$5.00 to just look around.. But, buy a drink then you can take a tour for free!!
Didn't stay for dinner service was good not over the top doting
author: Lisa T.

description: The service was slow and the mai tai was gross. Wouldn't suggest it. $10 cover charge. Would not suggest going
author: Andrea C.

description: We had dinner at Tonga Room last Saturday and our bill was over $200 just for three of us and on top of it they charged us a cover charge of $45/- which is TOTALLY UNFAIR.I understand charging a cover charge if you are not having dinner and only going to hang out but to charge diners a cover charge that is a TOTAL RIPOFF. Plus, if that is the case the band should not stop for breaks either as diners pay the cover charge to listen to entertainment and the cover charge should be prorated each time the band takes a break.The band was great but overall I don't think a diner who is spending over $200/- in F&B should be charged a cover charge on top of their F&B.
author: S W.

description: The atmosphere is super fun, I loved the live music and indoor rain into the pool (even though they charge $15 per person entertainment fee). Our waiter David was great but the food was pretty much terrible and over priced. The calamari soggy, the pineapple fried rice bland and the beef dish was meh.  The drinks were strong but also not very tasty.  Do not waste your money on dinner here!
author: Jennifer L.

description: This place is in Fairmont Hotel. I love the place, the food, it is fun and you can dance while the band plays the music in the middle of the lagoon that shows a Polynesian culture, it was nice. I would recommend this place.
author: Sam A.

description: Overpriced! Food wasn't great at all. The place looks aged and run down. Made a reservation for Saturday at 615. Service seem good. Wait staff was friendly. There was no live band as I would have thought but was told rather sternly that if I was still seated for dinner after 8 I would automatically be charged $15 person for the live entertainment. I wonder if they do this to those that have a reservation at 7. Overrall just wasn't very impressed with this restaurant.
author: Melvin J.

description: Great Atmosphere, Fun Drinks, Overly Priced Large Plate Food, Great Customer Service, A Fun Tourist Trap, the Disneyland of Dining.
author: Adam V.

description: Made reservations a week in advance for dinner tonight at five, paid a 20 dollar uber to get there walk in and are rudely told it is closed for a private event and that we could come back tomorrow at 5 and I had said well I have my confirmation email for reservations tonight and was then told doesn't matter you will not be allowed in tonight. The man was very rude and showed no concern for what had happened. Will definitely not be coming back.
author: Kate M.

description: Stopped in for a tiki drink early in the evening of New Years Eve. The bar was empty. They were charging a $10 cover charge for no reason except that it was NYE. Booooooo !
author: John B.

description: Great atmosphere! Super yummy drinks & such a good vibe. I love tiki bars! It was super crowded but it didn't bother me like I thought it would!
author: Juls B.

description: This bad review is for management. I made a reservation over a month ago and OpenTable, the service they use to schedule their reservation messed up my reservation. They emailed the manager at Tonga Room letting them know they made an error and to see if they could acomódate us still and Tonga Room never got back to me. Despite the message they received and me leaving several voicemails with the manager Addison Jolly. I was really disappointed, a phone call even to say no would have been nice.
author: Yaneira T.

description: What a cool and unexpected place sitting in the basement of the Fairmont Hotel!  I attended a party in a section of the Tonga Room and absolutely loved it!  The atmosphere is second to none, the service was great, the pina colada was refreshing and expertly made and the food was quite tasty too.  I will definitely be back on my next visit to San Francisco as this gem is too good to go to just once!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
We came here on the weekend and although it was a great atmosphere, it was a little to busy for me and too many people. 

We had to sit in some very  uncomfortable chairs, due to ow busy it was. The food was OK, and nothing special. Although the chicken wings were great. 

I can see this being a great place for friends to grab a drink, but more inconvienent for a family coming to town to visit, unless you book a reservation far ahead.
author: Brandon M.

description: Food great. Drinks are disgusting. I'm so sad. I wanted the drinks to be better. The share drinks are soooo nasty. NASTY!!!!!
author: CW K.

description:
What a fun place!!! There is a reason that this is a must visit on the trip of the bay area. The food - the Kalua pork is awesome.... I could eat unlimited amounts of this perfectly done swine. The drinks - the Mai Tai is a thing of beauty - I quickly lost count of how many I had: isn't that the point! The entertainment - okay, kitschy,  but isn't that part of the fun of the whole place? 

Don't go here because you are expecting a super classy dining experience, it is a theme restaurant and bar and lives by that Hawaiian tropical theme. Do go here for fruity drinks with umbrellas and lots of tiki vibe.
author: Greg F.

description: We came for drinks and pupus and weren't disappointed with any of it. We loved the atmosphere. We really enjoyed our experience.
author: Maureen M.

description:
I give this place 5 stars because it is by far the best deal in town. Caveat, only if you go during happy hour from 5 to 7. 

Head up to the top of Nob Hill for 5pm and enjoy a $10 all-you-can eat buffet and (I recommend) a Mai Thai. Sip it!  Trust me. It's strong!

Get there for opening at 5pm and enjoy a little quiet time over the pool while you get your drink and food before others arrive. By 6pm it's busy and you will wait for a table. 

The ambiance and atmosphere is really cool, and the rain and thunder is neat too. 

You don't have to order the buffet, you can order off the bar menu of apps. If you order the buffet you must have at least 1 drink, if you order of the menu, you don't have to order a drink. 

Recommended!
author: Aaron P.

description:
I don't care what you think, this place is awesome. 

It's definitely for an occasion. If you have some friends in town, grab them, play catch-up while you wait in line for a good while, then have your camera ready for when their eyes pop out of their head when they first walk into this place.

As a swimmer, I usually scoff at a place that has a pool (or a fountain big enough) that's not used for swimming. Pff. This is definitely the best alternative. Take your old pool. Throw a barge in it. Toss a band on top of that. BAM. Surround w/ fancy drinks in totem-cups. Top off with a little paper umbrella. 

Congratulations, you've just served up some memories for your guests that they will take with them forever...that is unless they had one too many flaming cocktails.
author: Carol M.

description: I got tipsy when i was here because the drinks was good especially the coconut cocktails. They have awesome deal with $10 per person buffet.  There were eggrolls, salad, fruits, Fried rice noodles, and two kinds of chicken wings. Except noodles and rice, I like everything else. Good place for happy hour. But line was long if for seats, you can directly go inside to get food and drinks if you want to stand the whole time,  very crowded after 5:30pm. We had our seats around 5:45pm but had to wait about 40 minutes.
author: Meichelle L.

description:
The place is pretty touristy but I expected that before I went. Inside, the decor is very chill and the indoor pool is a nice touch for the atmosphere. Just a warning as the drinks are a bit pricey, but they make up for it with potency.

For food, we go the ribs. They were pretty good, but know they are Asian style and braised rather than smoked. They are covered in a heavy, sweeter sauce that's very similar to Chinese style.
author: Arthur K.

description: SUCH A TREASURE! This place was awesome! The drink was strong and delicious and the ambience was super memorable. I've been telling all of my friends about it. If you're near Nob Hill you so must check out the Tonga Room and allow time to soak in the history of the Fairmont hotel. It was all good.
author: Jayne I.

description: Step back in in tiki elegant time.  This bar was beautiful, there was live music and minimal millennial guests.  Great place for a drink and some dancing.  Loved it.
author: Grace G.

description:
Ok I am in love with the Tonga room and this girl Natalie but that's not why I'm writing this review today.  Other than running out of pineapples on a Sunday at 10:30... Flawless!!!

Great show, amazing chicken wings, cold beer, coffee served in a carafe.

And let's not forget the atmosphere!! It's like you are in Hawaii and it has fake thunder!!! Boba! It's exciting fun and romantic!

I highly recommend it, it's my go to in SF now. I may call ahead or bring my own pineapple. Oooo and the giant banana split! Get it!!! I know $20 but it feeds 4-6... Really 10-12'n

Special thanks to PJ! You made our last night in SF perfect, I think she has great dessert skills too!
author: Mario G.

description:
Atmosphere is great! Band was amazing. Stick to the beers. Mixed drinks are not good and wine is either old or cheap.
Worst Mai Tai ever, pina colada was not frozen was more like on the rocks.
author: Michelle S.

description: Very disappointed. Waited over 2 hours to be seated despite being informed it would only take 45 mins. After being seated it took over an hour and a half to get our food. The food itself was ok and the service was terrible. Will not return or recommend this place.
author: Maria L.

description: A friend recommended this place because it looked like fun. We didn't have reservations and we waited about an hour to get seated.  During that time we saw other people being seated without reservations.  There were empty tables everywhere.  Im from l.a. so i know good food,  the food was terrible and overpriced.  The waiter was at least honest about what dishes not to order. We were also charged an extra fee for the live entertainment  for not being guests at the hotel.  The music was so old fashion. Their cocktail drinks were not good either.  The place itself was cute, reminds me of rainforest cafe vs pirates of the Caribbean.  Won't be going back.
author: xinia q.

description:
This will be my first and last time here.

1) Food was subpar. Not worth mentioning.

2) Delicious cocktails concoction, but overpriced.

3) Extremely slow service

This place was not my cup of tea. I liked the ambiance, live music, and decor but nothing made this place worth coming back. I blamed Anthony Bourdain for making this place seem so magically amazing...
author: Owie N.

description: This place is a gloriously tacky delight that whisks you away with their stiff kitschy drinks, swift and attentive service, and whimsical rain storms! It seems to be a fun hidden secret that only the hippest catch wind of. Enjoy
author: Kelly D.

description:
I don't think any number of customer reviews will affect this place's business by now, but nonetheless this place leaves something to be desired for the customer.

We loved the drinks and the music, which is clearly what most people frequent the Tonga room for. The band really catered to the crowd and was very friendly. The drinks are super strong, not to mention expensive, but what can you really expect at a spot like this?

The food was definitely the worst part of the whole experience, but I wasn't super disappointed since my expectations were pretty low to begin with. 

I would definitely come back for a fun event or celebration just for the drinks and atmosphere!
author: Erica V.

description:
Zero stars. 
Worst service ever. 

We spent time in the line to have drinks at the bar, came in and met some friends who had gotten there earlier but we got kicked off two tables, after having bought 10+ drinks ...the manager saying we needed a reservation (because we were a group of women ...meanwhile the EXACT same thing happened right in front of our eyes to a table of guys but they were not forced to move)
And yet there were several open tables just sitting empty...it was almost comical what a shit show their system is. 
As if they've devised the perfect way to mistreat people just looking to have a couple drinks in a kitschy place. 

Drinks are weak, overpriced, the servers are so rude and neglectful and the management  is just ridiculous. 
They get so much tourist traffic that they don't give a crap how badly they are treating the locals. 

I'm not even sure why we went there other than trying to be nostalgic ...but we will NOT be back. Ever. 

Just skip this place. Sucks.
author: Nilu r.

description: I give this place 5 stars for sure. I had great service each time I been here and the food plus drinks tast phenomenal. It's a fun experience I recommend going here w a friend or in a group or with your family. They have fake rainstorms in the middle of the restaurant and a dance floor so cool  I recommend trying their tacos and chicken. And their delish vergin or Mom vergin pina coladaaaasss
author: Sophia H.

description: The best place in the world  my heart hurts when I'm away can't wait the wonderful atmosphere and staff make this the easiest escape to a Polynesian Island .
author: Man P.

description: Great place to hangout with friends, a date, or people coming out of town. A little touristy and drinks a little pricey, but great fun place to have a couple of drinks and listen to live music that is being played in a small ship/boat in the water. Cool place to get down and dance freely with live music in a small dance floor after dinner!
author: Emmanuel A.

description:
Staying at the Fairmont in San Francisco? Like Eisenhower Era drinks? Ever wonder what a Polynesian bar in a fancy hotel would look like? Go no further. Come here, get World War II wasted. Have the bowl for 4 people by yourself. Then have a Zombie. THEN drink every sugary drink on the menu. It's well worth $187.19. Total benefit: enough paper umbrellas to guard against an afternoon sun shower. This is the most
fruit I've eaten in months.
author: Felix M.

description: Sorry, not impressed. Actually disappointed. Way over rated. Had reservations for 7:30 pm and were told we would incur an additional $15 per guest at out table if we were still seated a 8pm. Are you kidding? The manager came to our table and said not to worry. Half and hour to order dinner and consume it. We were staying across the street at the Mark Hopkins International hotel and thought it would be fun as we could walk across the street. This is the kind of place I would hang out when I was in the military in South East Asia. It was a blast then. But, for me it is a been there done that experience. To finalize, the food was mediocre.
author: Michael K.

description:
Nothing can be written about this place that hasn't already been written. It's tacky, it's tiki, it's silly, it's wonderful, it's a freaking must for tourists. It always seems to be packed, and who among us wouldn't want to dance on the deck of a pirate ship? Yes, there is a slew of your favorite fruity rum tiki drinks in theme glassware. The live band plays lots of your favorite silly songs from the deck of their floating barge, covering the "wide" range from disco to...Lionel Richie. If it doesn't make you smile out of fun, campiness, horror or embarrassment, you're dead.

Important news: As a longtime fan, I can attest that they have recently improved the caliber of the drinks. That is a long overdue blessing. It might have something to do with customer service or a new GM. Or it could have something to do with the influence of nearby Smuggler's Cove (which has perhaps the best tiki drinks--no, make that the best drinks of any kind--on the west coast). I give Tonga Room 4 stars. Smuggler's Cove? More like 10!
author: Tom M.

description: I felt like I was in Fiji! These place is a blast. Some local friends wanted to take us and had us at "floating stage for band" and "real pirate ship". They have amazing attention to detail here! I had a tropical drink (which are about $15) and a beer. Both were delicious. They charge $7/person to sit at a table if you are not ordering food so we hung out at the bar area. The band was great and covered many great 80s songs and quite a few people were dancing. Oh and it also starts raining here about the pool area - it is so fun!
author: Jessie V.

description:
Came here last Saturday at around 8:00pm. The line was getting longer and longer as we were waiting. After about 20 minutes we managed to get in. We were in the standing are of the bar, if we wanted a table the wait was an hour. 

The place looks cool, like a Pirates of the Caribbean set. There was live music, with a $ 7 surcharge for the entertainment ( we didn't have to pay it though because we were standing I guess... not sure why)

The music was loud, the drinks were good and the atmosphere was fun! We ended up having a real good time.

I wouldn't call it my regular place but I would come here every once in a while for some tropical drinks and fun music.
author: Tamara S.

description: Stopped in last night with my family (kid friendly too), super fun and unique retro tiki bar/restaurant! A pool with a live band in a floating hut/boat in it, it even rains with lighting in the pool area! Good drinks & live music playing top 40 hits, cheesy but super fun of you don't take yourself too seriously! The only downfall is they charge a $10 cover per person if you want a table. It's free if you don't mind standing around the bar/dance floor.
author: She-Ra X.

description: This is everything I wanted it to be. A 70 year old tiki bar in the bottom of a fancy hotel (that has a beautiful lobby and great piano player). We just wanted a drink since we knew they were expensive. The bartenders were nice and I got the pineapple royale and the hubs got a hurricane. The drinks were strong so at least for a lot of money it was worth it and mine came in a pineapple glass. The band played all the lounge songs you imagine like margaritaville, more than woman, bailamos. Then it rained over the pool and that was cool. Got what we came for. Mahalo.
author: Brigid P.

description: Server, Ken, was great! Fun atmosphere w/Band & rain storm. But food was not good. Short ribs were half fat. Potstickers not flavorful. Fried rice was best.
author: Debbie A.

description: As much as I give credit for the concept, the combination of poor service, mediocre food, and an overpriced menu is not worth it.
author: Zorayr K.

description:
Total tourist must try spot in San Fran.

I have been wanting to go to Tonga Room after seeing it on Anthony Bourdain's drunk travels around SF in one of his shows.  My boyfriend's parents were staying at the Fairmont and looking for a pre-dinner drink when we decided to head downstairs to the Tonga Room. Walking in this place is pretty cool, yes, cheesy, but the fact that you are literally underground in what used to be the pool for the hotel they have done a good job of renovating it into a tiki bar/pirate ship.  I actually prefer this spot to Smugglers Cove as there is was more seating and a nicer space. Slightly reminiscent to my childhood days at Walt Disney World and the Pirate ship attraction... but with booze!
We were able to grab some seats by the pool and shared the Smuggles Golden Punch Bowl for Two ($22).  It was not overly sweet and ginger/yellow chartreuse were a nice balance with the rum.  The server was a bit busy and neglectful, but it seemed that she was the only one working in a pretty full bar/restaurant area so that was understandable.  This is not the kind of place where I would go on the reg, but bringing out of town guests (who are paying) is a different story! I would choose this over Smugglers Cove for the better seating and overall experience
author: Kelsey B.

description: Ya gotta come to the Tonga room at least once in your life!  Old World Historic Fairmont Hotel, and the historic Tonga room. Check out all the pictures of days past while you are there. It's an experience... that's all I have to say. Drinks are pricey of course, but strong and well made.
author: Greg S.

description:
This place is really neat. I love the decor and the history behind it. The house band was great. We came here because several of my friends had suggested it, as I had never been to San Francisco before. 

My only issue, Is that after spending $40 for two drinks, you aren't allowed to sit down unless you spend an additional $20. Due to this, half of the seats were open and there were far too many people standing in one concentrated area. I will return next time I visit San Francisco, but I hope that they stop charging people for wanting to sit down. I have no problem with cover charges, but they should be done at the door.
author: Brittany C.

description:
We only came here to have drinks so I am solely rating the drinks and atmosphere. 

The atmosphere was so much fun!! I couldn't get past the awesome tiki room decorations and the fact there was a pool in the middle of a restaurant. The drinks were pricey (which was expected) but delicious. 

If you have a group of friends who aren't strapped for cash and want to just go out, drink, dance, and have a good time- this is your place!
author: Gauravi P.

description:
This place has an amazing ambience!
Unfortunately, the compliments end here. The food is expensive and nothing to brag about and so are the drinks. 
Just so you know, if there is live music there is a charge of 7 bucks per head. 

Good for once,I say!
author: Neil S.

description:
Texture: 4/5
Bathrooms: 0/0
Diversity: 27/100
Straws: 15/5
Love: 3/5
Tikis: 5/5
Pool: 1.4/7
Death
Boats: Yes/Plz
Drinks: 4/5
Falsetto: 90/105
Scent: Pleasant


Overall: Chipotle
author: Alexis Lynn E.

description:
Contrary to many reviews, the service during my visit was great. The hostess gave us a reservation no problem and both our servers were very helpful, giving us their recommendations and even letting us try the soup before ordering. 

Come here for the drinks and atmosphere. The food is over-priced for the quality, but the Mongolian beef and chow mien were both really tasty. The strong, fresh drinks are enough to have me come back.
author: Evan R.

description: Had a incredible food and a fun and inviting atmosphere. So surprised by the lightning and rain storm inside and love that the band was on a moving boat in the middle of the restaurant. Everyone was dancing and singing along, One of the best experiences I've ever had on a vacation
author: Micaela C.

description: We have been going here fore quite a few years but had been for a year.   We loved going for Happy Hour and getting the buffet in the bar.  We hadn't gone in awhile and decided to call to make sure they still had it. I called at 3 but the Tonga Room doesn't open till 5 so I was kicked back to the hotel operator or front desk.  I told them we wanted to come out to the Tonga Room and did they still the buffet during happy hour in the bar.  Yes I was assured it was still going on.  Well after an hour BARt ride and Uber ride up the hill,  we arrived to find a hostess telling us it was no longer offered and handed us a little happy hour menu that was served instead..  she then ran inside the restaurant locking the door behind her and never returning.  There has always been a Hostess there 30 minutes before they opened and I knocked on the door as I had questions about the menu.  The rude hostess saw me and refused to come to the door.  I was so upset we left.  Very rude and disappointed that I made a trip to SF for nothing.
author: Dawn B.

description:
So I am a big tiki drink culture fan. For about a year, we were even lucky enough to have a tiki bar in Charlotte; Tiki Hideaway. Unfortunately, I think it was a bit too hidden away and alas, it is no more. So, last weekend while in San Francisco, I hit up three tiki bars, Tonga being one of them. It was on my radar for awhile so me, my husband and brother and sister in law hit it up on Friday night over Labor Day weekend. This place gets crazy busy! Loved it. Its what you might expect that it is in the basement of the gorgeous Fairmont Hotel. When you get to the bar, you see the water features, are greeted by a large tiki god and the bar has all the fresh citrus and frills you want. We stood at the surfboard shaped table since there wasn't much seating (that was not a table) ad enjoyed 2 drinks each. The 2nd round consisted of a mai tai which was very nice and easy to drink, a hurricane, which is not a tiki drink in my opinion but the best drink of the night, and two smuggler's, which is a recipe from my all time favorite tiki bar Smuggler's Cove (also in San Francisco). We also shared a communal punch that hit the spot too. 
How can you go wrong with tiki!? It just makes you happy and possibly a bit giggly. Now go already!
author: Emily P.

description:
Had heard about this place on the Travel Channel's - 'Anthony Bourdain's-'The Layover-San Francisco' and hiked up Powell Street from Union Square to the posh Nob Hill neighborhood to check out this historic hotel, and home to the infamous Tonga Room: Hawaiian Restaurant and Bar. 
To give just a little backstory on the history of this amazing building I was interested in its original owners the Fair sisters, who have a Rhode Island connection where I live. (See this info later in the review.)
The Tonga Room is located in the hotel's basement, or what they call the 'Terrace Level.' The 75-foot pool was added in 1929 and dubbed the Fairmont Terrace Plunge. In 1945 the hotel hired well-known Metro Goldwyn Mayer's set designer Mel Melvin to create a tiki-style themed experience. It does not disappoint. The pool is surrounded by bamboo railings and Tiki tables and kitschy art work and accents. You feel like you're in a 1950's Hawaiian bar....  or quite possibly on the set of Gilligan's Island. Riggings on the perimeter of the dance floor create the feeling of being on a schooner, and apparently the dance floor was constructed of wood from the S.S. Forester, a schooner that once sailed back and forth between San Francisco and Hawaii. Every half hour or so rain falls from the ceiling creating a humid air reminiscent of the South Pacific.  Thunder erupts from somewhere in the corner of the room. It's just plain fun!
The band, the Island Groove Band that I saw on Friday night are really entertaining. They perform on a slowly floating barge in the middle of the pool. Playing everything from 1970's Creedence Clearwater Revival's 'Lookin' Out my Back Door,' to 1985's hit 'Kyrie, 'Lionel Richie's classic 'All Night Long' to the more contemporary Michael Buble's 'Sway.'Giving waves and shout outs to the many tourists and locals alike throughout the sets, they're the perfect band for this setting.
A fruity Scorpian or Lava bowl is a must if you're going to really take the plunge. Not cheap, but well worth the experience. The glass wear is of course voodoo themed & coconut shaped and 1950's style glasswear, just classic! We did not eat here, but there was a wait for dining and there seemed to be numerous couples, and larger parties dining there. One was a large group with a couple celebrating their 50th anniversary. Though they had mentioned a $10 dollar cover we decided to wait for a table at no charge and then somehow they said just told us to head into the bar at no cost. Dress code seems to be dressy casual. After all, this is the Fairmont. The Venetian Room right upstairs is most famous as the place in which Tony Bennett first sang 'I Left My Heart in San Francisco.'
Speaking of the Fairmont, let's get back to the history of this amazing property. Built in 1902 by female architect Julia Morgan, the first female graduate of Paris's  E'Cole Des Beaux Arts the lobby of this property is on par with architecture in Europe.  According to the Fairmont's web site. ...'It was already completed, and the interior furnishings had been delivered and were awaiting their various places in this Palace on Nob Hill. The hotel had just been sold on April 6th, less than two weeks before the conflagration that was to all but level the City. The story however, goes back earlier than that. Tessie and Virginia Fair were the daughters of James Graham Fair, one of San Francisco's wealthiest citizens. 'Bonanza Jim' had struck it rich in a Nevada Silver mine, and his daughters were determined to construct a grand monument to their father, who had passed away in 1894. In 1902, construction began on The Fairmont Hotel, but by 1906, it had become too much of a burden for the Fair sisters, and they sold it to the Law brothers, Herbert and Hartland, in exchange for two existing office buildings at Mission and New Montgomery streets. How could anyone know that the 'great San Francisco fire,' as locals referred to the disaster of the earthquake and what followed, was just days away.' While the Fairmont was shaken by the great quake, it faired better than much of SF that was devastated by fire. The sisters not only honored their father with the flagship for the Fairmont properties 'FairMont' atop this most scenic hill in SF, they also took some of his fortune and built Rosecliff Mansion built by McKim, Mead and White on Bellevue Avenue in Newport, RI.  Both were prominent society members on Bellevue Avenue. They both married well to New York society members Hermann Oelrich's,  and William Vanderbilt III. Oelrich of steamship fortune, and Vanderbilt heir to Steamship and Railroad fortunes.
If you like history and Scorpion bowls in an interesting setting, don't miss the Tonga Room!
History pulled from of the Fairmont Hotel web site & Wikipedia.
author: M D.

description: $10 cover each for music when you're already eating there and spending $200? Stingy! By reading other reviews, I'm surprised they are still ripping people off with that stunt. Why haven't they just worked that into the price of the food and drinks. Music started at 8:30, our reservation was at 7:30, basically paid $20 for 20 minutes of music before we were done. Drinks and food tasted great but was overpriced. Only positive was the great waiter we had and atmosphere was fun but was overall turned off by the music charge. Not the way I was looking to end my bday, feeling ripped off. Nice to go there once to check off a list but will not return and would not recommend to locals or tourist. Much better spots for the value of your money and quality of food. PS, parking cost us $75 at the hotel for dinner, nearly had a heart attack!!!!
author: Ranee W.

description:
1) the ambiance and decorating is amazing - there's a pool in the middle of the room where it rains (only place in california it rains apparently), with a little boat in the middle of the pool that the band plays on.  It's a wonderful atmosphere and the theme is carried through the entire place

2) We ordered 3 drinks which were great - lychee martini, pineapple royale and zombie - wonderfully crafted and too tasty, it would have been easy to drink there's all night 

3) our waited Bash was amazing - tentative to each of our needs, told us about his favorites, what he thought we would like when we described our likes.  Great!

4) the food was okay - I can't imagine anyone comes here for the food.  We got cold edamame, complimentary but none of us prefers cold edamame over warm.  Our appetizer was calamari, good and typical as it is at most places.  Ordered Kalua pork, seafood steam pot and the mahi mahi.  While the food was good, it's nothing that would want us to return.  

Overall, the price is not with the food - going here is a fun experience because of the theme and cool thing to do due to the history but I don't foresee myself going back.
author: A. Christina S.

description:
More of a 3.5 stars lounge. 
Super cute touristy lounge. There's an occasional fake tropical rain storm. The ambiance is obviously fun. 
Negative points for not answering the phone, tried to make reservations a week in advance (called twice).
Long line on Friday/Saturday nights, could take 1+ hr waiting for a table, go for standing bar...

Do share a "fish bowl" with your group! 
Lava bowl - super strong, non girly
Smuggler's Golden Punch bowl - easy to sip, watch out it can creep! 
Scorpion Bowl - my second choice after smugglers...
author: Christina T.

description: I saw this place on the Travel Channel and convinced my friend to go check this place out with me. I'll admit that the theme in deck or inside is pretty cool. And the staff is very friendly. The drinks on the other hand are so so so strong that I can literally smell the alcohol while he was making it. After about two drinks you Tonga room started spinning and I knew it was time to go. I never got a chance to taste the food so I'm not going to judge them on that. If you're in the mood for a strong ass drink like you were in college then I would recommend going here.
author: Marcus S.

description:
I'm a tiki bar fan and love the atmosphere of the Polynesian themed Tonga Room and Hurricane Bar.  The room is definitely bigger and not as cozy as my favorite Tiki Ti on Sunset Blvd in Hollywood but I really shouldn't compare them.  What you get is a very cool departure from the elegant lobby and grounds of the Fairmont Hotel.  

Located in the lower level, the room used to be the old hotel swimming pool and it still is one of the best features of the restaurant serving as the focal point for the floating band and the thunderstorm rain that showers over the pool periodically. 

We had drinks with our party and I can tell you the bar does not skimp on the alcohol.  Maybe I'm just getting old but I got faded on the Smuggler Bowl.  It is pricey compared to other bars but remember you are in the freaking Fairmont and in one of the highest real estate markets in the city. 

The bar food is ok - they continue the south pacific theme on the bar food menu but nothing spectacular to report.  Stick to the drinks like the Zombie or the Smuggler Bowl. 

Get there early or you will need to wait in a line outside the room. They also charge a $7 cover in the evening.
author: Peter H.

description: Bad food, the worst service and complete disaster of a restaurant. We first waited for over 30 minutes for a reserved table then we waited over 1 hour for our food to come out. After we finished eating the server gave us the bill and told us that we need to tip her over and above the Normal price. The food was cold and the server gave us an attitude. I recommend only to go for the music and stand at the bar ... don't get near the restaurant part.
author: Amir I.

description:
SCAM! They charge a $10 per person fee for a table if the band starts playing (at 8pm) while you are seated even if you are seated before 8pm and the dinner service is slow. It will be added to your bill without you knowing beforehand. And they call it a cover charge even though they don't take it at the door and charge you after for it!

This is for Friday and Saturday nights.
author: Tracy C.

description: Wat a fun filled day. We had so much fun because of the seatings next to the band and the band was amazing...the only disappointment was the food and drinks...this place is just to have fun and dance. Defently not to eat. Will not come here...food is very expensive and not upto the mark.
author: Sweet G.

description:
Great place for drinks and dancing. Food was just ok. Great atmosphere here. We had a great time. 

I had the Huli Huli chicken. It lacked flavor. I picked at it and mostly ate the veggies from the plate. 
The walu fish was moist but bland. 
Drinks were delicious yet strong. The presentation was good.
author: Priti P.

description:
When you head downstairs you get the feeling you've traveled back in time! Seriously, there is a floating band in the middle that used to be the hotel swimming pool. 

He drinks are good and strong, but dangerous! We got the big punch bowl that I think was called the volcano. Good thing we can just walk home!
author: Thomas R.

description:
The Tonga Room is the tiki bar to beat all tiki bars. So much fun with the periodic thunderstorm complete with showers, bamboo furniture, hanging lanterns and thatched roofs all over the place. 

In the center of the room is a pool, where sometimes a live band floats as it plays island favorites. (Note: the Tonga Room used to be an indoor pool for hotel guests.)

We were here for pre-dinner drinks and were not disappointed. With the pineapple, umbrellas and coconut ceramic glasses I almost expected to hear the slack-key guitar and ukulele to start playing and lovely lei-adorned, brown-skinned dancers pulling reluctant diners out on the floor to do the hula. 

After a couple of Scorpions (for two, accompanied by 18-inch straws), I might have volunteered to embarrass myself. My! Those drinks were strong - but the sweetness of those tropical drinks masked the alcohol content. The drinks were excellent!
