It's been many years since I was here last. During that time, they almost shut down the iconic restaurant located in the posh Fairmont Hotel. At that time, the menu was Chinese but the reincarnated Tonga Room has returned to its roots and installed a more Hawaiian-themed menu that includes the loco moko, kahlua pork  and other dishes familiar with island fare that borrows from the Asian cultures that make the Pacific paradise unique. I vowed to myself to return for the food.

I'm so happy the Fairmont decided to keep the Tonga Room. Its a San Francisco institution. I won't wait so long until my next visit.
author: Ed D.

description: Fun place, great ambiance. The food came out pretty good as well. We ordered the calamari, Mongolian beef and chicken chow mein. Yes I know we didn't get none of the traditional plates. But we enjoyed our food. The service was on point. The band did a wonderful job! Wish they could of went a bit longer for valentine's but it's ok, we're  Coming back. Thank you to our waiter Ken. Your were awesome my man! Cheers! Stay blessed.
author: Roneel P.

description:
5 stars for the bar and ambiance. This place is arguably my favorite bar in the city. Really cool vibe and almost always packed with a huge line to get into the bar area. They have a live band (and a cover charge) on Fri/sat nights starting at 8pm. 

3 stars for the food. Menu is a bit limited and mediocre for the upscale prices. The entrees were pretty underwhelming while the appetizers were better. I definitely recommend the Tuna Poke and Curried Crab wonton tacos. 

Drinks are pretty creative and can be strong or weak depending on what you get. They all taste great though. 

This is a perfect spot for a date, birthday or special event celebration. Overall I definitely recommend this spot. It's always fun!
author: Nik R.

description:
You know, I was really looking forward to this place.

Shit man, I hoofed it up Powell in a tight black dress - THAT's fucking effort.

And when we got there, I didn't even mind the 20-50 minute wait, because I was so exhausted from the trek, I could use the down time.  
However, when we got in (after 20 minutes because we opted for hanging at the bar and not a table) I was just not that impressed.  

Don't get me wrong, the decor is amazing!  There's rain, a boat with a band, and damn good drinks in kitschy glassware.  But I didn't want to stay and order a second drink.  

Maybe my expectations were too high.
author: Libby R.

description: Surprised my husband in November for his bday by taking him to the Tonga room, I had heard about it from a friend and wanted to try it out. I read the yelp reviews first which made me question if we should go but I felt like most of the complaints weren't good enough reasons for me to not try something new and I'm glad I followed my intuition. The ambiance was amazing, the food was great and the band was the best part! We danced the night away at our table after we ate and met some really cool people. The only reason I'm not giving them 5 stars is because they only accept reservations if you're staying at the Fairmont or have a party of 10+. I went ahead and splurged on a room just to be able to get guaranteed reservations, without them, we would've been waiting for an hour and a half - no thanks! The band starts at 8 pm, our reservations were at 7:45, got seated immediately and had a great waiter!
author: Kristy M.

description: I came here with a group of friends. It has a novel appeal, but the selection of drinks wasn't very good. The food we got was just overpriced Panda Express. The place screams fake, with the theming and the dad feel good bands. And on top of it all, there's a $10 cover charge. There are a lot better places where you can go to drink and eat close by, unless you're looking for a glorified Margaritaville. Might be worth coming by if you're already toasted and want to keep your buzz.
author: Nick C.

description:
Great place to take visiting family/friends or for a date night. It's a tiki-themed restaurant with a bar and dance floor. There's a pool in the middle with a gondola for a live band.

Reservations are highly recommended. You can wait, and the line moves at a moderate pace. There's a cover fee of $7/person for the music if the live band is playing (Friday and Saturday nights).

The appetizers are average, but the drinks are delicious. I got the Mai tai and it was yummy. Next time I come with a group, I'm going to try those bowls (scorpion bowl and pineapple I think). The music gets loud and makes it difficult to have a conversation with your friends. 

Cute place!
author: Ruby K.

description:
Loved this place because of the live music, food, and drinks.

Came on a Sunday with the boyfriend for a late night dinner (like 9:30 pm). We shared a bowl and shared two plates.  If I remember correctly it was one pork dish and something else but to be very honest all of the dishes sounded delicious. We also got dessert and they were amazing. 

The meal was pricyyyyy and worth the amount we paid for but not really worth it. I don't know how down I'd be to go again and drop that much money when we could probably get the same Hawaiian food for half the price. It was definitely an experience that was fun.
author: Lydia K.

description:
I can't believe that I have been living here for 5 years and this was my first visit to this historic bar! I absolutely love tiki bars and this one did not disapoint. We were surprised that there wasn't an external entrance. We wandered around the the normal looking hotel until we saw the big red sign. Once you walk in, the mood totally changes. There is a big pool in the center of the room and everything around it is made to look like a ship. There are flickering lights everywhere. Every so often there is "thunder and lightening" and it "rains" on the pool. The band plays on a floating stage on the pool.

We enjoyed the appetizer platter so that we could get a sampling of everything. We also got the sweet potato tater tots. They weren't my favorite, but the sampler was really good. My favorite drinks of the night were the zombie and the mai tai. Very well done classics!
author: Kari G.

description: Everything you've heard is true. Its the most interesting concept I've ever been in, and one of the most expensive. You will hate that it is shoulder to shoulder on a Saturday night and love the fact that the band plays in a boat on the water. The drinks seemed to be just ok, and nothing under $15. So make sure your credit is up to speed!
author: Darren T.

description: My best friend and I just came here for the drinks and atmosphere. We had 3 different drinks a piece, I couldn't remember for the life of me what they were because by the end of the 3rd drink I was well toasted and needed to be put to bed! Cool place and vibe! The hotel was really neat too! Will be back.
author: Brittney F.

description: The last stop on our Anthony-Bourdain-trail, this place turned out to be quite charming. Nestled inside a hotel, you have to look around a bit to find the entrance. We got some good strong cocktails and listened to the band for some time. We felt we could have dressed a bit better, but no one made us feel unwelcome. Great ambience! We had to rush to catch the last Bart out of the city, but would definitely like to come back.
author: Sid W.

description:
Totally touristy, kitschy and fun.  Pity about the overpriced, AWFUL food.

$30 for a dish that had the flavor of a reheated frozen entree. ICK.

If you simply HAVE to go here for the San Francisco experience, be sure you go when the band is playing.  That's where the value is.
author: Brian C.

description:
First time going to the Tonga room which is located in the fairmont hotel was a nice experience. 

My friend and I got there with a bit of a line from the podium, so we just walked in and I took in the mellow atmosphere along with the Polynesian vibe. We went straight to the bar and glanced at the menu. There were plenty of drinks to choose from and also shareable drinks as well. 

I don't exactly remember which one I got, but the pina colda was a great drink. You do get a bang for your buck, so prepared to drink down a few with some good company.. 

Ps.. Next time making a reservation would be smart.
author: Lisa K.

description:
This place is a pretty decent place to get drinks and eat. I think because of their tiki themed setting, it makes it feel like you are in the Polynesian Islands. Their drinks are not bad, but I think you paying for the environment than the drinks themselves. It does get a packed quite quickly so I HIGHLY recommend getting their early if you do not have a reservation. When I went, we had their buffet. I would say for a buffet I would give it a 5/10. For the price and what they are giving you, I thought it was ok. It wasn't anything great or special. Sadly, one of the good dishes, I believe it was the pork belly, was rarely refilled, which was quite disappointing. They would refill it once in a while, so they really limited you on what you could get. One complaint is that if this is a buffet and they are advertising it that way, they shouldn't be so skimpy on the food that they are providing for buffet and limiting patrons on getting "cheaper" food. 

Also, be aware of their "cover charge". They have live musician play and out of the blue they will charge you a cover charge on top of your meal. That was also another thing that I wasn't to please about was how they sabotaged you into paying cover charge for their musicians. It forced us, at least, to eat faster and get out of there, so that we would have to pay to cover charge. We really weren't able to enjoy our time there. 

If I remember correctly the cover charge is like $10 per person on top of all the food and drinks you purchased. Kind of ridiculous! 

Other than that, I think this is a good one time experience and I do not plan to come here again.
author: Rob F.

description: limited experience... only one trip and that was @ 11PM on a Friday night, so take in stride... I was reminded of a dive bar and not the cute kind.... the basement-pool of the elegant Fairmont is repurposed as a kitschy tiki-bar.... glad no one jumped into the pool.... at $20 per Fog Cutter/Singapore Sling and 3-deep at the bar it is quite a crowded and expensive place to enjoy a drink or two... the lobby bar 2-floors up looked more inviting and comforatble to my eye...maybe dinner hours between 5 and 10 offer a different experience.... caveat emptor....
author: J M.

description:
Poor service. Poor customer service-charged us cover charge-with no prior notice- we were from out of town, had confirmed reservation on phone with a representative who did not mention anything about a cover charge. Just ok live music.
The whole "rain" experience -total let down
 Totally not a memorable experience
author: Sanju S.

description: One of my favorite places to visit. The history behind this place is amazing.  For tourists this place is a must, as well as for locals. Make a reservation!!! The deinks are really good. For food, I ate the platter and something with chicken cor the entrée. Spend a extra 10 dollars for the seasoned rice with coconut.  Look for street parking, local garages are expensive ($30 for 3 hours!?).  The water fountain in the Nobhill park is great for photos.
author: Francisco F.

description:
Inside the bar looks really nice and the drinks are awesome. A lot of rum. I was a pirate that night, "where is my rum!!!". 
Be aware that you have to pay $5 on some nights. The band was awesome! Had fun.
author: Mark T.

description:
This is an interesting place for sure. The concept is Hawaiian. Not performed well, but Hawaiian. If you saw the Anthony Bourdain episode where he states "You know Singapore Slings aren't served in Singapore", this pretty much wraps up this place. I think this was as much as the editors would allow on tape. 
Later on it plays classic disco music (Gloria Gayner and even Queen). Kitschy is an understatement.   But, kitschy in a good way 
The (lead) bartender is the saving grace. Ask him for a rum drink off menu and he will make a great drink. He does know his rum. 
I didn't order any 'Hawaiian' food as is was overpriced and doubtful for being authentic. I ordered the Brussels - these were good.
The bar crowd was fun and friendly.  Locals I met bought me a few rounds (maybe one too many!). 
Overall, this was a nice place to go.
author: George S.

description: Expensive but excellent! Food was wonderful, ambiance  refreshing, service  excellent. MaiTais are still the best.  Since 1945, they remain an icon in San Francisco!
author: Stephanie E.

description:
Had no idea this mind-blowing experience existed in SF, within the bowels of The Fairmont, no less.

Expect all kinds of silly-happy-cheesy. If older couples (and some hesitant younger couples) merrily dancing to the cover band's rendition of "September" (Earth, Wind, & Fire) or "All Night Long" (Lionel Richie) doesn't warm your heart, you're a fucking vampire, begone upside down to your coffin.

Decent margarita.
author: Inigo M.

description:
The drinks there were awesome, loved the lynchee martini. 

The Service was wonderful and the entertainment was nice (live band).

I m giving this a 3 star because of the food and price. The food was not authentic and was just mediocre coupled with the high $$$$, made it hard to give it a 4 star.  The potstickers were soggy and tasted store bought from Costco (Ling Ling brand).
author: BT B.

description:
Worst service ever from the reception staff to manager Kristen Carter!!!

Attempted to get a reservation over the phone, but they were full and told us they only take walk ins. Ok, sounds fair. When arrived, placed my name on waitlist  with hostess(blond hair) and was told I will received a text and wait is about an hour. No problem, so we walked around for approximately an hour and waiting for the text. 
Went back approximately an hour and the time was 9:45pm. The hostess was no where to be found,waited 5 more mins and the hostess came back. We told her we were placed on the wait list and she looked and was like,oh, I can seat you guys now. (She totally forgot to call us!) 
After we sat down, it was slightly pass 10p and I also have been here I've before and knew we were sat at the appetizer table and no entrees are served there. I walked up to the hostess and asked her if we can get the food menu. Her response was,we stop serving food at 10. I was appalled this lady didn't in any way let us be aware of such important policy that no entree is served after 10! That's the whole idea of our reservation,is to enjoy the food and entertainment,and not pay $15 cover fee to sit and have appetizer. She immediately saw how pissed I was and offered me to speak with the manager Kristen Carter. She was young and experienced and basically said the same thing her hostess said,"we stop serving food at 10." I asked her if you trained your staff to tell your "customers" that when we placed our name to let them know entrees stops serving at 10? Her response was yes, so why am I just being told? She replied with the same answer, we stop serving food at 10 and that's our policy. 

I was not only hungry and upset,but we had visitors coming from overseas Europe and was disappointed at the way we were treated. We stopped by to get some Korean BBQ afterwards thank god and was served much better.

I hope the management team at the Fairmont Hotel is aware of how horrible the food service department is,in particular, the manager Kristen Carter. Her and the hostess seem to be really good friends and found this incident entertaining for them, but was a horrible and upsetting experience for us. We will likely never to go back again.
author: Kelvin L.

description:
YELP CENSORED ME, THEY TOOK DOWN A PHOTOGRAPH OF THE MENU. How is the menu not representative of the business?????

  YELP SAID:: "We're writing to let you know that we elected to remove one or more of your photos of Tonga Room & Hurricane Bar from Yelp because the content didn't appear to be broadly representative of the business"

F***K YOU YELP!
author: JL B.

description: I would have liked to give this fun restaurant 4 stars, but the ambience was ruined by the live band which we were forced to pay $7/person extra to endure listening to while we dined. The room is fun, reminiscent of tiki rooms from eras gone by. The food was quite good, not great, but very good, and the service was excellent. But the live band -- that was *not good*. They sang off tune, didn't balance the sound mixer - resulting in the vocals being just a blur while the guitar blared, and they played so loudly that my table companions and I could not even carry on a conversation by screaming. Call first, and if they have a band playing -- don't go.
author: Cary R.

description: This is located inside Fairmont hotel. It's pretty awesome that they make this place look like you're on a ship. There's a pool in the middle and they can make it rain according to the music they're playing. They don't have a DJ but they have a live band performing. They also serve food and it's Chinese American fusion. They have a variety of cocktails. We got the bowl for 2 and it's actually not bad but a bit small. If you're going to order the bowl and you have 2 people, I suggest that you order the bowl for 4. If you're ordering cocktails, make sure to ask for napkins or whatever you need when they bring you your drink since the servers are not too attentive.
author: Cindy W.

description: This place is a little pricey for what you get but it is pretty good! The kids menu is the same as some of the adult items just a different name. The service was great our server was great with my son and he really enjoyed the rain storms! The busses however was not very friendly-- he kept trying to take our plates as we were eating off of them and I picked up my son for a second and he came over to our table pushing the high chair out of the way to clean even after I told him my son was not finished and it wasn't necessary! The drinks were great strong and good quality! The banana split we shared amongst 4 people and it was good and plenty!
author: Heidi Y.

description: Crowded and expensive.  If you stay at the Fairmont, it would be a must do.  If you aren't a Fairmont, then non-weekend dates would work.  Went on a Saturday night and thankfully a large party cancelled so we got seated but for the 1/2 hour we had to wait there isn't anywhere in the bar to sit. You have to be crowded up w/many more people - not fun.  Food was more quantity than quality so order a few dishes for sharing but don't over order.
author: CA D.

description:
This was supposed to be written in 2013. I took my boyfriend to Tonga to celebrate his birthday.
Good: Ambiance, the environment, live band music, the drinks, and the server.
Bad: Food was definitely mediocre. It could have been better. The snapper fish was such a disappointment. I was like, this does not have salt. It wasn't great. 

I will give this place another chance. Hopefully the food this time around would be better.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Went for my birthday. Cool Atmosphere and enjoyed dancing. The service was good, just good. The food however was awful. There were 6 of us and only 2 of the entrees were edible. The papaya salad was terrible, unripe papaya that was coated in mayonnaise . Hot and sour soup was way too salty. Desserts marginal at best and espresso arrived cold. Go for drinks and appetizers only. Much touted mai tai was so-so, would not order again. Band starts at 815pm. Would never return for dinner, that would be a waste of $$$!!
author: Lauraine E.

description: Been here twice and really like it. The atmosphere is amazing and makes you feel like you're not in SF anymore. Great place to chill and relax while having a nice dinner. Also, the drinks and food are decent. My friend and I got a Rainmaker and a Pupu platter to share. The rainmaker was nice and strong, just how I like it. The food is mainly Asian fusion and has some very interesting tastes, so be ready for that. My only issue with the place is that it is very pricey.
author: Kevin L.

description:
You know, I really like this place. I think its super fun and the drinks are solid and the bar food is tasty. Live music and pacific islander theme - what's not to love!

However, once you've gone a couple times - I don't think theres any reason to come back. The drinks are good- but I've had better Mai Tais at Liho Liho's... hell I think I prefer Li Po's!

I've never sat down for a proper dinner there but the bar food is solid.

The live band always plays classic cover songs that make me smile and I always look forward to when it "rains" in there.

But I have to say, I feel there is somewhat of a douche-y crowd. Either a corporate jerk who talks poorly to the bartender, or just a group of people that don't have anything positive to say about life.

Anyway, now I'm getting off topic.

I would recommend checking this place out once or twice and making the decision for yourself.
author: Mayra M.

description:
I LOVE this place and feel so lucky to have stayed in The Fairmont Hotel and to have this tiki bar downstairs. 

The environment is cheesy but so much fun. The house band is incredible and played covers that kept the dance floor bumping (yes, I just said bumping).

Although they have beer and liquor, you've got to order a signature fruity drink. I went with the piña colada with the umbrella straw and the hubs went with the Singapore slinger. 

Def worth checking it out.
author: Kelleigh M.

description: Tonga Room was so fun, and for a second it felt like we weren't in San Francisco.  We came for a Bachelorette Party, and the staff was very accommodating.  The Pina Colada was really yummy!  Roberto was our waiter and he was the best.  We hope to come again soon :)
author: Lauren W.

description: Was visiting SF for a week with my boyfriend. A worker at Amoeba Music recommended we head to Tonga Room for drinks one night. He described it as "everyone from middle aged tourists to newly 21 year old kids dancing to live music played on an island in the middle of a pool" which is spot on. We didn't eat and only got beers so can't rate the food - but the atmosphere was pretty great. Mixed drinks were island themed but overpriced. However, was worth checking out for the music and fun night of dancing.
author: Jessica M.

description: By far my favorite spot in SF. The live music on the barge is incredible. The drinks are pleasantly stiff. Overall the atmosphere is jubilant and somewhat electric.
author: Enrique F.

description:
A logistical nightmare stemming from an illogical decision by the manager put a damper on what should have been an enjoyable evening.  We arrived in a large party of about 25 and were told we would have to wait while they "prepared" for us.  We stood in line for 30 minutes before they let half of our group in and kept the rest at the door for another 15 minutes.  All the while, many smaller groups of singles, couples, and even parties of 5-6 were allowed to skip the line and waltz in ahead of us.  Why a bar would treat a group of 25 differently than 25 individual people is beyond me.

One of the bar tenders was rude and appeared to be quite frustrated by the large crowd on this evening, something that, to me, seems like an obvious and regular element of tending bar.  I would liken him to an author that hates writing, or a gardner who hates flowers.  Perhaps a career change would alleviate his annoyance.

They serve what must be some of the most expensive drinks in the city.
author: Joey C.

description: This bar/restaurant has lost every ounce of charm it once had. You can't even sit down at the bar at 5:00 in the afternoon without a reservation. Add a cover charge of $15.00 per person and you have an establishment whose best days are far behind. There are plenty of places with tiki drinks that won't treat the large majority of their patrons like second class citizens. Please go there and let this sad place die out.
author: Jeff S.

description: After seven years of living in SF, I finally made my way to the famous Tonga Room. The entrance is not what you expect, because it resides in the fairmont hotel. I could only guide myself by seeing the lit up sign at the hotel's entrance. After making a right, then a left through the hotel lobby, I find myself inside the Tonga Room. The tiki atmosphere doesn't feel tropical but more like 1950's baby boomer tropical. Everything is plastic, and colorful, giving the illusion of escaping your urban environment in exchange for something more exotic. I had a table by the pool area where occasionally 'rain' would fall, and a live band would play popular cover tunes that we all know and love. I ordered myself a Mai Tai, and Zombie. Both were delicious but is best take slow, very intoxicating. For my entree I ordered a coriander crusted tenderloin, and it was delicious. The meet was nice and juicy. I hope to return in the future, and try more the drink specials.
author: Joel G.

description: My husband and I had a wonderful time here celebrating our anniversary. We had made a reservation for dinner on a Friday night and were seated immediately. I absolutely love the atmosphere here. I was telling my husband how this was so reminiscent our of time in Hawaii (where we got married) and we loved it! I got the wagyu beef and he got the mongolian beef- which were both amazing. That was his first time trying wagyu beef and he loved it. I enjoyed the pina coladas here-very well made. I had wanted to try all of the other amazing looking alcohol drinks, but my husband was in the mood for a round of shots instead. Will definitely be back!
author: Kristy C.

description: The Tonga Room was great as far as the live music was concerned! The band was great and I liked mainly all the songs they played. The food was low quality for the price would not recommend for dinner. Great choice for a night out drinking and dancing! Make reservations!
author: Rae T.

description:
As a bar patron only (didn't order any food or even glance at the food menu) I have to admit, I love this bar! The drinks are really well mixed, the live music is awesome, and all the patrons seem to have a great time on the dance floor.

We ordered the following drinks: Piña Colada, Mai Tai, Zombie, Singapore Sling, and Pineapple Royal. All were delicious. We agreed the Mai Tai was the strongest (not sure if that's because of who mixed it or if it's always the strongest) but all were mixed perfectly and super yummy.  

We arrived around 9 PM on a Saturday and there was a line out the door. Originally we said we would do standing room only to bypass the line, but quickly changed our minds when we got to the bar. Super crowded and difficult to get drinks if you aren't aggressive, which we aren't. We ended up getting back in line and got a table after probably 20 minutes of waiting. 

The live band is awesome and plays a variety of songs. The crowd gets pretty in to it too and the dance floor is full most of the night. I even joined a conga line at one point.
author: Rachel F.

description:
LOVE.

We're tiki aficionados, so this place was a must stop.  We made it our Friday night Happy Hour destination.  Pretty cool that they have daily HH!

Arrived a little too late and ended up SRO at the bar.  Which was fine with us, though the hostess said we could not get the HH buffet there.  Went and got good standing spots at the bar and ordered a couple of Tiki drinks, and later asked the bartender if we could get the buffet and he said sure ... We could just pay him.  Score!

I have to say we really enjoyed it.  We will definitely go back, maybe a little earlier next time to try getting a table.  Although I think possibly some of the charm of the evening was being elbow-to-elbow with people and sharing commentary about our drinks.  The buffet food was tasty ($15 each) although they ran out of tasty potstickers/dumplings early and did not keep them refilled.  The noodles and the chicken wings were the other stars.  

We ventured off of the HH menu for one of our drinks each as well.  The tiki drinks get some pretty dang good praise from us as self-proclaimed Tiki-heads.  They were "proper".  The Mai Tai was solid but my favorite was my Three Dots and a Dash.  

Go.  It's fun, kitschy, with a solid offering of drinks and a fun little HH buffet to prepare you for a night on the town in SF!  Let's keep this place going!
author: Ann A.

description: Came here with some friends for a late night drink. I wanted to come here after seeing an episode of The Layover with Anthony Bourdain. The drinks were pretty good but a little pricey.  The bartenders were really friendly and able to make suggestions.  Definitely worth visiting at least once if you're in San Fran and wanting to do the tourist thing.
author: Jessie A.

description:
Matt is awesome! First off, he served me the cocktail 3-dots-and-a-dash, classic tiki cocktail, not on their menu. I told him I would look up the rest. But before my Internet allowed though the drink was in Front of me! 

When I left I went for the ladies room.  A mother and her suck boy came in and he was so sick I thought he was going to throw up his innards. I promise I would bring a bottle of water at least to make things easier. Bring kids back to the bar and told Matt the situation. I was totally willing to pay for a bottle of water if need be. But obviously being the great customer service man that he is just gave it to me and I ran it to them. I don't know what water will make him feel better, but I tried and found it I hope that little boy better Matt made a damn good cocktail for me.

Thanks and cheers Tonga!
author: Nicole S.

description: I had pretty low expectations of the food going in but it was actually pretty good but not amazing good! The ambiance is still the biggest reason to go here, the converted pool is really cool and the floating boat band is realllllly cool. The service was good and the food while not the best was satisfactory. This place could be a must go if they just rejuvenated their menu.
author: Adrienne M.

description: This place could use some love. Its very fun with pirate/tiki bar thene, and in a stunning hotel. The drinks were good. The food just ok, a mix of hawaiian/chinese, but not refined or quite tasty enough. There is an old pool that is made to look like a lagoon, and a boat that is a stage. The background music should have been tiki, it wasalternative pandora radio, which The just felt off. If a chunk of money and a bit if creative design was put into this place it would be great. Have a drink at the Pagan Idol on Bush, now that is an amazing tiki place!!!! And Tonga room should take notes!!!
author: Duane R.

description: Tropical drinks, live cover band, and cute grandparents dancing.. who wouldn't love this place?
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Tourist trap! Poor quality drinks overpriced.
Kids running around everywhere. Next place please. Bad cover band playing as well.
author: John K.

description: Went here for a friend's going away get-together. It's a fun atmosphere with a live band playing on certain nights (with a $10 cover charge). Mai Tais and Pina Coladas were ordered around the table. The drinks are strong, which is good for those who can hold their alcohol. We also ordered some desserts, including a banana split and a coconut chocolate cake. The banana split had a weird combination of ice cream (including sorbets) which did not go well together. It was not very good. The coconut chocolate cake was the smallest piece of chocolate cake I have ever seen. It was maybe a quarter inch thick and 3"x3". And it was over $10. I suppose it's a fun place for tourists, but not somewhere I plan on going again.
author: Annie L.

description: I am giving this three stars based on the service. Food was not Polynesian, it was overpriced Chinese. Can't comment on the fruity drinks, but those must be the only reason this place has a high rating.
author: Joe H.

description: The staff and experience at the Tonga Room this past weekend was outstanding! I planned a Bachelorette Party here for my best friend. I was able to easily communicate with the restaurant ahead of time to coordinate details. They also allowed me to set up the table ahead of time before guests arrived. I was immediately brought to the table. The server and manager greeted me promptly and introduced themselves. The server was super attentive and friendly. We were never in need of anything. The server and staff were on it! I was so thankful to have an effortlessly fun party for my friend. I would definitely come back and highly recommend it for anyone celebrating or wanting a fun night out.
author: Gina R.

description: I was there last night and the food is okay but the drinks were good. The place is pretty cool with the water in the middle with the boat that the band plays on. The band was great and we really enjoyed the music. The only reason why I'm giving 2 stars is because we came early and they told us it was a 45 minute wait. So we gave them our phone number to text and went upstairs to our room. Came down in 30 minutes and the host told us she had contacted us 9 time. We never received any text messages. So we gave her another phone number so she can try to text again and it didn't work. She finally told us that their text service doesn't work for ATT. She should have asked us what phone provider we had before she asked for our number knowing ATT doesn't work. So we had to wait another hour until we were finally seated. So pretty much if you have ATT sit in the lobby until a table opens up because if not you're not getting a table. Pretty much killed our mood because we were excited to go there to celebrate a friends birthday.
author: Bao N.

description: If you like piña coladas and getting lost in the rain, don't come to the tonga room. After all the hype and Anthony bourdain buildup, we found the experience more underwhelming than a rainforest cafe in Las Vegas. Sure, it rained into a strange centrally located pool surrounded by empty tables the happy hour patrons are not allowed to sit in, and sure our appealing sounding and wretched tasting tropical cocktails were garnished by core-containing pineapple wedges, but if I'm going to spend that much on a drink and and "tropical" experience, I'll chip in a few extra bucks fly myself to Hawaii.
author: Alisa W.

description:
Try Tonga Room at least once in your life but keep in mind that it's wildly overpriced and the food and drinks are really just so-so. It's a historical institution when it comes to tiki bar history and I'm glad they continue to exist for that reason (there was a time when Tonga Room's continued existence was in doubt). 

But like I said, overpriced. You're basically paying up the wazoo to have the experience of being there. At the same time, it's a genuinely "only in San Francisco" experience. A tiki-themed restaurant/bar with a swimming pool in the center, with faux thunder/rain storms at regular intervals? 

Yup, that's Tonga Room in a nutshell.

Check it off your tiki bar bucket list if you must, but keep in mind that San Francisco has two other tiki bars that are vastly superior to Tonga Room: Pagan Idol and Smuggler's Cove. No, they don't have the historical cachet of Tonga but their drinks, pricing and overall experience are much better than what Tonga has to offer. And I daresay, they are also both legitimate "only in San Francisco" experiences. 

My most recent visit to Tonga Room was a couple of days ago. My mom was in town for a quick vacation; she'd heard about Tonga from her SF-transplant buddies and insisted that we go. We ended up doing a mini tiki bar crawl since her time in SF was limited and we were on foot. Since Pagan Idol is nearby and opens an hour earlier, we started there and then headed off to Tonga. 

I wish there was a way we could have reversed the order because Pagan Idol is much better, but it opens an hour earlier and fills up fast. Tonga was a letdown for both of us after visiting Pagan Idol (one I knew would happen because I've been to both places before). We're saving Smuggler's Cove (which I've also visited multiple times) for her next visit.

We both ordered daiquiris, a tiki bar standard, but an off-menu item at Tonga. They were priced at $15 each and were mediocre. Pagan Idol's daiquiri is currently $10  but it is *so* good that it sets the benchmark for me for daiquiris and I've yet to try a better one. I like ordering classic daiquiris when I can because they're a good test of a bartender's skill set and whether or not a bar is using quality ingredients. 

Though a simple drink on paper (a classic daiquiri is just rum, lime and simple syrup), you can end up with something sublime (good rum, fresh lime juice and properly balanced flavors can make a daiquiri one of the best and smoothest cocktails ever) or you can end up with something that makes it clear that they're just "phoning it in" so to speak (bad rum, lime juice from a bottle, and poor flavor balance). Tonga Room's daiquiris fell into the latter category. They were drinkable but that's about it. They tasted "strong", but not in a good way. More like in they were using poor-quality ingredients and it showed. 

As for the food (we were in the bar area and not the restaurant proper, BTW), we only ordered one thing, the fried shrimp and cilantro rolls (both of us were too stuffed from eating so much great food all week to eat anything else). They were tasty enough but not memorable at all and like the drinks, overpriced. We enjoyed them well enough in the moment, though. 

I'll continue to indulge out of town guests who want to visit Tonga Room but I'll tell them there are better spots that are more worthy of their time and money (and I won't return on my own). However, like I said earlier, I'm glad Tonga continues to exist. It would be a huge loss if they closed down, both for SF and for tiki bar history in general. 

I do think they're resting on their laurels a bit since they're far more well known by out of town visitors. And maybe that's a good thing. Pagan Idol and Smuggler's Cove fill up too quickly as it is. That said, if Tonga Room has any interest in being a proper stop in a tiki bar crawl, they should consider opening their doors at 3pm. The experience will only build up from there and I think they would be looked back upon more fondly if considered in a historical context.
author: Maya B.

description:
It was as campy and extravagant as I imagined. I was trying to coordinate a large group on a Saturday so I was worried we would be turned away. We lucked out and got there before the large crowds, around 8pm, when the band started, and we were able to stand around the bar just fine. Drinks are expensive but well-mixed and strong. 

Some helpful tips: 
- Band starts at 8pm. If you just want to stand by the bar, there's no cover. If you want a table, there's a $10 cover after 8pm. 
- Sharing a scorpion bowl,or any bowl, is more cost effective with one other person, if you're planning on drinking several. 
-My coworkers were able to find parking, but it is not easy. There's basically no easy way to get up the giant hill ,except the trolley. It's overpriced, but a nice tourist attraction. If you're taking public transit, be prepared to use those calf muscles and stop after each block to catch your breath. 

I'd like to come back here with my grandparents and try some of the food. I think it's a pretty fun environment for most ages, since it's such a novelty spot.
author: Katie D.

description:
For an almost $400 people for 4 people, yes, I have experience better.  Far, far better!!!

Everything is over priced.  Some items were too salty.  The waiter was attentive and the indoor rain and band made it enjoyable.

Since they their drinks are so expensive, try ordering with little to no ice.  They fill the entire glass with ice to cut down on the alcohol.
author: Amanda H.

description:
I had my first experience at Tonga last night and I had a lot of fun. Though it is a little bit cheesy, I totally loved it. They really tried to recreate Hawaii in a restaurant, from the drinks, to the food, to the hourly "tropical rain". 

Tonga has a happy hour, daily, from 5-7PM, where they have reduced prices on drinks and appetizers. Thursdays there is also a band that plays, out on the water - pretty cool to see. Tonga is certainly a fun place to go for a birthday or a date as there is lots to see and talk about. Definitely worth a visit once while you are in San Francisco.
author: Aletta B.

description: Amazing restaurant! The Tonga Room is definitely a restaurant that everyone should experience. The service is outstanding the food is very delicious. And the drinks taste great and will definitely get you a little tipsy. The bands were great and played music that just makes you feel good. I honestly felt like I was on a vacation when I dined here. This place is Perfection. Will be returning in the future. Thank you Tonga Room for a great experience you deserve this 5 star review
author: Cody C.

description:
This is a cool and cliche tiki bar in the heart of SF, and we went there with local friends in the service industry.  The drinks were tiki perfect, and the pupus were pretty good. We enjoyed the periodic simulated tropical rain showers in the center of the bar.  

The only real downer to this place was that it is tucked away in the basement of a rather high end hotel (the Fairmont) which added a pretty notable percentage on all the normal prices.  They had a happy hour special on a buffet, but it was too dark, too shady, and not well stocked.

A uhi ho!!
author: B C.

description:
If you're looking for crap drinks and employees who don't wash their hands after destroying the men's room then Tonga is the place for you. 
The magic starts when you get to the hostess station and you're greeted by two surly hostesses who roll their eyes when you have the audacity to ask for a table. Once you're inside standing at the bar a server will come by which is nice. Do not order the pina colada! I'm not entirely sure how they make theirs but it tastes very chemically. I think it may be the low grade mix they use. As a reference, the blended coladas in Las Vegas that are served in those tacky glasses are miles better than these. So before my drink came I went to the men's room. When I walked in I was blown away by the odor. I won't provide more details than that. While I was drying my hands the toilet flushes and the guy came out who was an obvious employee there due to the uniform. Made a B line past the sink and went out the door. WTF???? When I came back I had my drink ready which I sent back after other people tried it. They were also shocked at the drinks chemically taste. Got a mai tai instead. Not too bad. My suggestion: set expectations lowwwww. Go. See the waterfall. Don't order food. Have a mai tai and then go somewhere else.
author: Kevin M.

description: I remember visiting the Tonga Room vaguely as a child, so when I returned recently I didn't know what to expect. The staff was welcoming, informative, and attentive. Two staff members who really stood out were our waiter David and his helper Bash. These two took the time to make sure we were happy with the food/ enjoying ourselves and explained different menu options all with smiles on their faces each and everytime. The live band was pretty amazing as well. They played great music, had us dancing in our seats, and had many people dancing on the dance floor! Really fun environment, great food, and wonderful staff.
author: Heather C.

description:
Obviously had to come here because the Bachelor made it look so awesome!  Plus it's located in the Fairmont!  How could you not at least drop by???

We ordered the HUGE punch bowl and shared it among the three of us.  Man that is a lot of liquor for one person.

I really want to come and try the one in the pineapple next time!
author: Michelle T.

description:
Awesome tiki drinks in a crazy setting. All the drinks are good - try many. Authentic spot from the tiki craze. The band on the boat in the "lagoon" combined with the rain and thunder is great.

You have to experience the Tonga Room at least once. So cheesy but so awesome. Best done as a late night stop after dinner or bars.Great for strong beverages and good laughs. A must if you're visiting San Francisco.

Get the pineapple royale, it's the only drink served in a giant pineapple. Expensive strong drinks in the swanky Fairmont Hotel.
author: Rachel G.

description: terrible service, terrible food, awful sugary cocktails and mainly super overpriced. very expensive for nothing. band is cute and vibe is kind of fun but not worthy the trip.
author: Myrto K.

description: Overly priced ($16 for a tiny mai tai!!!!), kinda gimmicky (maybe the rain would be cooler with less people or more rain), and in a hotel which means the crowd is a weird mix somewhere between bachelor party and weekend work conference. Not sure about the food because we couldn't stick it out long enough to snag a table.
author: Liz H.

description:
Who doesn't enjoy a tiki bar once in a while? Tacky fun with a hangover almost given! Tonga Room is one of the longstanding tiki bars in the city, located within the Fairmont and very popular with tourists. There's a cover charge of $7 on Friday and Saturdays for live entertainment.

How does it compare to other tiki bars in the city? It's very spacious, plenty of table seating, and setup to host events as the space was converted from a swimming pool in 1945. The live band stage in the middle of the water moves back and forth during a performance which is pretty cool. Just be careful not to get too tipsy near the edge of the dance floor and fall in, they'll tell the bar to stop serving alcohol until whomever is kicked out.

Besides being spacious, there's only ONE bar located near the entrance that has two overwhelmed bartenders working hard to keep up with demand. The midsize bar itself is open seating but the bar tables adjacent are all reserved even though no one ever came during the last hour the bar was open, but the servers would gladly remind you to keep off if you try.

Ambiance isn't as tacky compared to smaller tiki bars in the city (ie: Bamboo Hut) but it's also not as charming compared to a medium size tiki bar like Smuggler's Cove.

Drinks: You can expect the usual selection for a tiki bar, think rum. The highlights of course being the three punch bowls available, served in either two or four person sizes. It's $20-22 a punch bowl for two people, or $32-34 for the four person size. The standard scorpion bowl and volcano owl are offered which are good choices. I also tried the unique Smuggler's bowl which tasted a bit like sweet and sour, not a fan. Top shelf cocktails are $13.

Happy hour buffet & drink deal for $10 sounds pretty sweet, maybe worth another visit on Wed-Friday.

All around touristy spot and it closes early on weekends at 12:30, so if you're looking to continue the tiki bar partying, make sure you know the alternatives!
author: Steven C.

description:
The reservation staff at the Tonga Room is utterly incompetent. Let me tell you my story.

I called them on Sept. 22 and left a voice message asking for them to call me back to set up a large reservation for a birthday party. Danielle called back the next day. It was a 5 minute call where we set up the details (20 people on Friday, October 9). Never once did she mention a set group menu with a minimum cost. Danielle said to expect a contract in my email, I said okay.

The next day, 9/24, I still hadn't gotten the email, so I called and left a voice message. I then called again FIVE MORE TIMES, leaving voice messages every time. I called on 9/30, 10/1, 10/2, and 10/5. Each time I left my phone number and email address.

Finally, on Tuesday, 10/6, three days before the party, she emailed me. This is when she told me about the fixed menu and the price minimum. She called me the next day, and I told her it was too high ($70/person, not including alcohol), and she said she'd talk to the chefs to negotiate something lower. This apparently wasn't possible. It wasn't possible to get a cheaper menu, or for 2 people to share a plate. She is telling me TWO DAYS before an event I reserved nearly THREE WEEKS IN ADVANCE, that it is $70/head, not including alcohol, non-negotiable. Oh, and we can only have the table for 1.5 hours.

From this experience, I can say that the reservation staff (Danielle & co.) at the Tonga Room are incompetent (can't write down a phone number or spell an email address correctly), provide horrible customer service (don't call back, unwilling to compromise for large groups), are disrespectful (see above), and are an embarrassment to Fairmont Hotels.

Needless to say, I cancelled the reservation. Thanks for ruining my birthday. :)
author: Aly H.

description: Not all that I thought it would be but wasn't too bad. Maybe because it was like a Wednesday night when I went.
author: Carmelo W.

description: Great atmosphere, the drinks went beyond my expectations of typical tropical concoctions.   The place was packed with a line of people waiting to get in!  We came here be because we saw the Anthony Bourdain show and it did not disappoint!
author: Aymi C.

description:
I went with a big group from work to celebrate a co-worker's birthday, and we had such a great time! PJ was our waitress, and she rocked!!! The service was attentive, drinks and food were delivered quickly after they were ordered. She kept the party going!
The food won't win any prizes, but it's perfect bar fare. The drinks, oh my, the delicious tropically inspired cocktails were super tasty and strong. My favorite combination!
author: Tim G.

description:
Oh the TONGA ROOM. Where do I even begin with you? You're so unsuspecting... living inside the gorgeous, iconic Fairmont Hotel. You wouldn't think kitschy, tiki bar would be inside the Fairmont.. but oh, it is. It's like you're transformed to a tropical paradise with a pool and a boat floating around. Sometime, the boat will move around. Sometimes, there will be live music on the boat. WHAT? I know, it's crazy. Then, every hour or so, you'll hear lightning, thunder, and rain. Not actual rain, but just water coming from the top into the pool. (I'm trying my best to describe it here..).

Anyway, it's a nice tourist spot to visit.. but definitely not a place for me to go on the regular. Not only is it not close to BART and up a huge hill, but also the drinks are also expensive... too expensive. I can get my piña coladas a lot cheaper elsewhere. Also, get ready to wait if you want to sit a table. They were able to let us in if we stood, but I hear sometimes there's even a line for that too!  

(19/100)
author: Cassy H.

description: Don't wait in that big, dumb line unless you have to have a table. People loooooooove to stand in line. Just walk in, go to the bar, order your tiki drinks like a boss and hover like a drunk vulture until someone leaves. Try to go during their happy hour, super good, greasy coat-your-stomach Polynesian food. It's a ten dollar buffet and there's drink specials, too. It rules. We had a puu puu platter, really good, and the bartender, Jake, was great. Love this place. PS? It rains and thunders.
author: Amber W.

description:
Why do bartenders in the city hate serving drinks so much?

Seriously- The bartenders look annoyed, even when you're polite. It's nearly impossible to order at all, let alone the second one. Even when four of us were sitting directly at the bar, they avoid eye contact and don't even see your money out and ready.

The drinks are pretty, exactly what you'd expect. So is the atmosphere.

Being with a great group of friends really improved our experience. We were all just so thirsty trying to get our cocktails.
author: Steph F.

description: Hilariously fun place to have cocktails with friends (watch it "rain," and see the "boat" move with the band playing on it). If you spend just enough time here your wallet will thank you (1 round...)
author: Kerry G.

description:
The Tonga Room.  Inside the iconic Fairmont hotel.  A must for nob hill.

The floating band, the rainstorm, the sheer tiki-ness of it all.  The theme from Hawaii Five O.  What is not to love?  

Fact: My date brought me here for our senior prom.  

The drinks are tiki heaven.  I love the chi chi.  It's a piña colada that's vodka based instead of rum based.

They do an impressive buffet for ten bucks.  Most recently I went & it happened to be happy hour; but that does not include the buffet.  

Don't go on a Friday or a Saturday night.  There's a line.  Serious.  

Dinner is maybe a tad lackluster, but that's never been Tonga's thing, really.  Tonga is a true classic in an equally classic location.  An SF tradition.
author: Veronica M.

description: Come and ask for Ken who is an amazing attendant.  The mixed drinks with fresh juice are the best...food is ok.
author: Chet M.

description:
Tonga Room is the perfect one or two drink tiki bar experience for tourists and locals alike.  Aside from getting to wander around the halls of the vaunted Fairmont, unless you're smart and take the side lower-level entrance on California, you get to step into one of the largest and most interesting spaces in the city that I can think of.

Ask any bartender, pending their workload, about the history of the place and you'll get some crazy stories.  The place hasn't changed much since it was originally converted from the hotel's pool to a restaurant, exception for the addition of the rainstorms.  Man, Rainforest Cafe really stole then broadly commercialized that touch, huh?

The only thing I've had at Tonga has been the drinks, so we can start there.  My absolute favorite, as an eternal fan of cherry flavor and gin, is the Singapore Sling.  I could list the ingredients, but anyone coming here expecting anything but tropical drinks is sorely misguided, so we can leave the description at "fruity but definitely alcoholic".  The Mai Tai, obviously, is also a draw, and the punchbowls are more than enough to share with someone else.  The bartenders are quite knowledgeable across the board and I've had some good conversations with them about the differences in their rums, which I don't drink very often.  Really, you can't go wrong with their drinks.

I've not had any food here, but I have seen a buffet set up by the pool on more than one occasion, and it certainly smelled good if that counts for anything.  I believe it's mostly asian-based cuisine, which would fit in with the tiki style.

There are plenty of things Tonga can improve upon, but I think this is a case of "why mess with a classic?" in many regards.  Best time to come is right at opening (5 pm) on a weekday to avoid too big of a crowd, but don't get dismayed if you have to wait a bit for a table or a drink.  You'll appreciate it once that Singapore Sling (seriously, just get it) hits your palate.
author: Frank R.

description: Great restaurant. I have been coming here for years and it never disappoints. Great food, great service and great atmosphere! A true San Francisco institution!
author: Janet M.

description:
Came here on the first night of my high school reunion for happy hour. Place was insane! We got there early -- thank god -- and got a nice corner area for our group. Buy a cocktail and for $10 you can help yourself to the buffet. Okay, the buffet isn't anything to write home about but there are noodles, fried rice, chicken wings, edamame, spring rolls, a pasta salad, and fruit.

The fun part of it all were the "bowl cocktails" -- I think one was called lava bowl and meant to be shared with others. My group got quite a few of these huge concoctions for the table.

During certain moments, thunder and lighting starts up followed by a rain shower. Extremely cheesy but pretty fun if you're in a group. I don't think I would have found it AS charming had I been there on my own.

I thought the place was a little misplaced for being inside The Fairmont hotel, but I guess it's been here forever.

Would I ever come back? Not on my own, but if a group wanted to meet up, I won't say no.
author: Anita L.

description: Came here on a Wednesday night, they had a band. The band was pretty amazing!! I wish I caught their name, they were a cover band. But great band and a great set! Now to the food, I had the PuaPua Platter, which consists of ribs, chicken wings, egg rolls and crab. The flavours of the ribs and the chicken wings were great! As for the drinks were also on point. They have a selection of bowls which are meant for sharing we had one of each, they were all great. All and all this place was a blast, great food and great drinks and great service! And the band was amazing!
author: Matt P.

description:
You wouldn't think that a Polynesian themed bar would be located under the Fairmont Hotel, but this gem is a wonderful restaurant/bar that is worth visiting!  We visited on a Saturday night in November but since we weren't guests at the hotel, we had to pay $7 cover.

Prepare to be wow'd upon walking in!  The decor of this place is truly breathtaking, with a pool in the middle of the restaurant to top it off. In the middle of the pool is a band that plays covers all night long.  And I believe there's a fake rain shower every half hour or so.  There's also a small dancefloor so people can dance along with the band.

We came here with another couple just for drinks before heading out for the night.  We were seated immediately because we had a reservation. They offered two huuuge punch bowls on their drink menu so we ordered both of them.  But they were so huge that the 4 of us could easily share the two. 

Seems like a very chill place for dinner and drinks.  Food seems a bit pricey though but I guess that is expected when you come to a nice place like this.  Although we were here only for an hour for drinks, we'd likely consider coming back for a meal.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Don't come here expecting fine dining. This place is definitely a little pricey for what it is, and it is located inside the Fairmont, and it is  on Nob Hill. However, the atmosphere more than makes up for the lackluster touristy food. 

You have to love this place for what it is - a tourist stop in fancy hotel. I love it because the place looks like a Polynesian tiki room with a giant pool in the middle. Depending on when you come - I suggest at 8 - a floating barge will come out to the middle of the pool and a band will play 80's and 90's cover songs. In addition, every ten minutes it rains into the pool. 

I have a place close by and really love coming here. It's touristy and overpriced but there isn't a place like it anywhere in SF. It's uniquely kitschy and certainly out of place in an old hotel, but eating here is very entertaining. The food is a mix of Thai and Chinese and some other fusion. I don't really care as they have Chivas (yeay!) and they make very strong drinks. I'm not a lightweight but after having a scotch and a Mai Tai I was pretty toasted.

The band and the decor and the rain from the ceiling really make this place. The bar area is lively and there's a small dancing area. When the 40 something tourists get nice and drunk you get the added entertainment of watching them break out their dance moves. 

A lot of previous reviews are negative but i think people really miss the point of this place. People who don't like it expect it to be fine dining because it's inside the Fairmont, but if you can appreciate it for the delight that it is, you will have a fantastic time. Even Anthony Bourdain said that "It's the greatest place on earth".
author: Sam W.

description:
I was so excited to finally come here because it's been on my Yelp bookmarks for quite some time now. Went there 30 minutes early to grab a drink at happy hour and then go to our reservations. The host pointed us to the bar and we were off! We took a seat and NO ONE approached us for 10 minutes. 

I tried to flag down a young lady server with glasses and she ignored me and went about her business. I finally asked her if she can take our order and rudely said "You have to be seated here by someone in order to eat here" and walked away. 

We got up and went to a standing table and saw a vacant table that needed to be cleaned. We waited for someone to clean it and another server, ruder than the other lady, said "You can't sit here" and went about her job. 

I wanted to leave at that point. Every person we encountered were very rude. My boyfriend said we've been waiting to eat her and to just give it a chance. He went to the bar and they bartender said he would be right with him but it took awhile. It wasn't too packed so I was confused why it took so long. Maybe he forgot. 

25 minutes later, the host calls us to our table. We got seated, ordered, and had an awesome time. Our server was on point and it was a great time in the dining area! They gave a complimentary dessert too due to our anniversary. 

We were done and wanted to take a picture at the dance floor so we asked the older gentlemen host, whom I did not know he was a host and said "Sorry, I'm busy right now seating someone" and smiled to the people who was being seated. I was not aware he was a host seating someone, but be polite and say give me one minute or let me find someone to take it for you. 

I felt as if since we were not in the older crowd, they were very rude except for my server in the dining area. 

I myself have worked at a restaurant for five years and know how the system works. just horrible to be so excited and have high hopes for a restaurant and it just totally let's you down. 

The food was awesome, but it doesn't even make me want to come back because of the service. bIggest letdown
author: Clarice C.

description:
Awesome atmosphere and good service, but drinks are only mediocre and expensive.  This is a fun place to come to for an occasion with a small group of friends.  We ordered a pina colada and a daiquiri and they weren't overly sweet considering, but also not very tasty like one would hope.  Perhaps it's a better idea to order well drinks.  

We came on a Saturday, so there was a cover for the live band, but it was worth it because we came early enough to get a table.
author: Kelly S.

description:
I had heard a lot bat this place from my friends. Last week i finally got a chance to go there and i must say it was a very different experience. Their band which plays on the boat was great and the food was good too. It is little on the pricier side but not that expensive. 

I would say go there once to get an experience but it is not my go to place.
author: Sub N.

description: If I could give negative two stars for Roberto & his service at the tonga room, I would. We waited for an hour for our food (pot stickers and fried rice). People were served around us, and when we finally asked officially about it, he came by with our food and said, "I heard you want to cancel." We said, "no, please serve it," and he responded, "okay, it's canceled," and carted away our food.
author: Laura D.

description: Four stars for tiki drinks, appetizers + nostalgic environment. Singapore Slings were our favorite and assorted spring rolls. Short rib sliders could use a bit more meat for the price. Loved the crab Rangoon but they now charge per piece $3.50, which adds up! Overall, it's fun for occasional celebration, and I'm glad it's still around. If you hop on the Powell St cable car afterwards, hold on! The cocktails sneak up on you.
author: Sue D.

description: Long and the short of it: as far as tiki bars go, the ambience is unmatched - but the food leaves a lot to be desired. The Tonga Room feels authentically inauthentic in the best way - if you told me the interior hasn't changed since the opening in 1945, I'd believe you. The rain, the floating bandstand, the ship rigging and assortment of tiki artifacts - this is mecca for kitsch fans. My friends and I all got drinks, and although very pricy, I was impressed (they are quite strong). But the (very expensive) food ranged from bland to salty and unappealing. I get you're paying for the experience, but $30 for a mound of passable pork isn't a great value. Go for the atmosphere, maybe grab an appetizer and a drink - but go somewhere else for the full meal.
author: Jason C.

description: Love this place!! Love the ambiance, Mongolian beef, kung poa prawn and their drinks! This place is a great place to go for a special occasion!
author: G A.

description: This place was really fun! The drink prices are definitely a little high, but you're paying for a great atmosphere, and some live music. I'd go back for sure!
author: Tim R.

description: I've only been here once, so take what I say with a grain of salt. I'm also not that familiar with San Francisco's hot spots. But I found this place delightful. The live entertainment (The Island Groove) were in fine form, the occasional rains pouring from the ceiling had the same cheering quality as a crackling fire, the service was attentive and thorough, the bartender's pours were heavy, and the food was delectable. I had the whole deep-fried red snapper and it was cooked to a turn. The ribs were something else, too, and I can't say enough about the crab rangoons. Apart from having to book reservations six weeks in advance, this place is solid gold. One of the waiters even took care to duck out of the way when my friends and I were taking selfies (such consideration!).
author: Andy P.

description:
Tiki Bar - check
70 year old bar - check
SF tourist destination - check
Big sharable drinks - check
Lagoon (and rain) inside - check
Happy Hour - check
Been featured on TV - check

So if you're a tourist visiting SF around Happy Hour,  it's a must stop.  If I was a local, I would probably only go to bring visitors from out of town.  Glad we went.  Probably never go back.
author: Rex L.

description:
Share some drinks and snacks with your friends. This big tiki, buried in the bottom of the Fairmont should be experienced, enjoyed, taken in then let go. It's fun and cool but not place you keep visiting. 

You're going to want to drink to take this place in and sure, you can order up a classic like the Mai Tai or a Hurricane but the Tonga room is made for friends to come together so share a Scorpion Bowl or Lava Bowl for two. While you're at it, place an order for a PuPu platter to take you back to nights out with your parents. The Shiitake Egg Rolls and Edamame are also good fare to share. Are you getting the picture? With Happy Hour from 5:00-7:00, Wednesday through Friday, you can come and enjoy this funky place and save a buck too. But what do you get during the happiest of hours? Well, for only $10 an All You Can Eat buffet. That's what! The fine print does require a one drink minimum but you've already got that covered. Speaking of cover, there is a cover charge when the bands on but it's cheap at $5 on the weekdays and $7 on the weekends. That's a good deal, friends. 

If it's the weekend or a holiday, this place can get packed so show up at 5 and be ready to get your drink on and your snack on as it's raining up in here. No, it really is. Rain, thunder and lightning will seem to come out of nowhere as if falls over the lagoon.

Enjoy this fun and funky piece of San Francisco history.
author: Mark F.

description: Haven't been here I. 15 years and it definitely hasn't changed! Super cheesy, way too loud music, extremely sugary drinks! It was a good time though and they pour the drinks with lots of alcohol to get you up and dancing! Good time was had!
author: Melanie N.

description: Fun place to hang out at night. Long line at 10p, Saturday night. Around 20 people in front of us. Waited almost an hour for standing room. If you want to be seated, its $10/per person. Bar service can take long. They are busy. I didnt try food. Live music was good. Wish the hourly "storm" was louder with the room dimmed. But it not, just some water coming down and a few flashes of strobe light. Area to dance. Alot of seating areas, which most were empty because people didnt want to pay. The line was about 3p people when we left around 11p
author: T H.

description: Definitely a must see when in the area! It's not often that you see a band on a floating boat in the middle of the restaurant. Awesome tropical theme, fun ambiance, LIVE MUSIC, and super strong yet delicious drinks! Only came for nightlife, no cover charge and a decent sized dance floor.  I can't really say much about dining experience- but I will for sure take my family here for a special occasion.  I know my mom will definitely love to take photos of almost everythere in there! (Asians love to Facebook post about everything lol)
author: Rachelle C.

description: Love this place! Delicious drinks and friendly bar staff! Good music and cool rainfall, feel like I'm in Vegas whenever I'm here--pirates of the Caribbean!
author: Natasha K.

description: Go for the atmosphere. It's like stepping into the pacific islands. Their known for the great tiki drinks. We got the chi chi and listened to the live music and enjoyed the "rain" - plus, the Fairmont hotel is gorgeous and is worth checking out!
author: Chelsea C.

description: I was so exited to celebrate my husband bday at Tonga Room. We seat at the bar tables, the server was so unpleasant, food was cold I asked her to warm it up for me and by the time  she came back with my food my husband had already finish his. The environment was fun, just not the service.
author: Alma L.

description:
Total sell-out!  This place is definitely, definitely not worth the hype.

Like a million other people, we saw this place on "The Layover" so gave it a shot.  There was a 45 minute wait shortly after it opened at 5pm, and they charge a $7 "entertainment fee" just to sit down.  We stood at the bar and ordered one of the big bowls for fun.  These kind of drinks are always sweet, but this one was over the top and seemed to be made with the cheapest alcohol they could find (despite costing something like $50).  And they don't light drinks on fire, despite what you might see on TV.

We ended up chatting with quite a few people who were all there basically for the same reason as us.  All were disappointed.
author: Bob C.

description:
My three friends and I snagged a last minute reservation for 8:45 on Sunday night. When we arrived the Tonga Room was about 75% full and we were seated right away in a great seat right next to the pool/floating stage. Our server Dave was very attentive and helped with substitutions on the Ohana menu (substituting two pork dishes with chicken and beef). The food was surprisingly good and the portions are very generous. I a lot of people were leaving with similar take home bags as us. 

Tonga Room is definitely pricey. The four of us ordered the $70/per person family meal and a Lava Bowl (for four) to share. After tax, tip and the $5/per person entertainment fee it came out to be $400. 

Pricey but worth it! It's definitely a fun, kind of cheesy in a good way experience. The music is good and there's always people dancing on "the deck." It's always nice to feel like a little kid again.

If you're a local, you can sign up for the free 1907 Club that incentives SF locals to visit/eat at the Fairmont. You get 15% off dinner and the entertainment fee is waived at the Tonga Room. There are other perks:

- Laurel Court Restaurant & Bar: 20% discount off Lunch and 15% discount off Dinner
- Tonga Room & Hurricane Bar : 15% discount off Dinner & Entertainment Cover Fee Waived
- Caffé Cento: 15% off any purchase and a free medium cup of coffee with food purchase
- Corkage Fee Waived for 1st bottle ($10 for 2nd; $15 for each additional) in the hotel's restaurants
- Complimentary 2-Hour Parking (validated when dining at the hotel)

There's an article on hauteliving.com if you search for Fairmont 1907 club
author: Angella A.

description:
The Tonga Room is alternately a little slice of heaven and an alternate dimension. It seems to me that the default mode of appreciating this place should be the ironic one: it's often loaded with tons of upper/ middle class white tourists and bro-ish types, all of which (if they have any humanity in them) enter the place gawkingly, astounded (as they should be) by the utter bizarre beauty of this secret(ish) Tikitopia; the band plays on its boat a wide range of songs from a sort of Santana-ish position- and they're solid. They're really good. Because of them my partner and I's new song is Toto's "Africa," specifically the Tongo Room's house band's version of it; the dance floor is an exact replica of some fabulous pirate ship deck, and on it there is to be found a high rate of spontaneous line dancing to a large number of very non-country sounding songs- this last time I visited said line dances were sort of defacto lead by this ancient Chinese man who could out dance just about everybody there. But I don't believe that this place can only be appreciated as such (in the ironic mode): my partner and I have been returning to this place on an almost monthly basis, and that's because it is simply a place to earnestly have fun: to dance, chat with tourists who are only in town for 15 minutes, taste the rainbow, etc.

So: I don't care about comparing the quality of juice-based cocktails sucked through a five-foot straw out of an actual flaming pineapple because let's face it: you're sucking a juice-based cocktail through a five-foot straw out of an actual flaming pineapple and that's amazing. 

On a serious note, I really really want to commend both the head waiter who attended to my partner and I's party of fourteen at the very back of the club during this last visit: he was communicative, attentive, polite, and helped wade through the chaos of splitting a check 30 ways at the end of the night. Similarly the two hostesses that assisted us were really very helpful and amazing: they helped me welcome and escort our trickling guests in to the table, and they helped us find a dance club that was open later as we left at the end of the night. 

All said: this place is amazing. If you've never gone, you should, at least once in your miserable too-cool-for-tiki-bars-life, and if you have gone, you should go back and tip your servers as much as humanly possible. xoxoxoxoxoxoxoxoxo

PS I would totally recommend reserving a table- the bar can get really bogged down and chaotic, and there's not many places to sit if you don't have one. xoxo
author: Joshua A.

description: Wasn't good. The mai tais were blow you out of the water strong. Burnt strong. Service was very poor. We didn't see our waitress for almost an hour and it was a Sunday even though there were a million open tables. Menu was quite poor. We thought this was going to be fun but it was bad all the way around
author: Christina V.

description:
Wow, every bit the tiki room feel you'd hope for. Bored with the button-up vibe upstairs? Head down to the Tonga Room for a kicked-back good time. Simple Hawaiian-inspired drink and food menu. Sometimes they have live music, as they did on Sunday night. Great decor. And I don't mean ad hoc, improvised minimal decor...it's a treat for the senses. Love the water feature, but I'm not going to over-explain it and take away your fun. ;) 

The Tonga Room's rep as an SF institution is well-deserved. A must-do!
author: Karen Z.

description: This place is unorganized and does not have any structure! On top of that I ordered a Red Bull vodka super simple and all I got was Red Bull and I said Red Bull vodka to the bar tender and he said yupp! After waiting over 45 minutes for a table we got sat and they told us the kitchen is closed! Never coming back!
author: Sharif A.

description: Not even close to the hype. We made reservations for Thanksgiving told only 6:30pm was available but tons of open tables the whole time we were there. My wife ordered a drink with pineapple juice and they used pineapple soda then swore up and down it was fresh, she is allergic to carbonation. Mongolian Beef was dry and had no flavor, sent that back. Kung Pow was good but have had better at $10 a plate corner places. All in all, don't waist your money, to many other places in SF that have better food and ambiance.
author: Dan L.

description:
So kitchy, and you should definitely skip on the food (especially the happy hour buffet), but the drinks were easily down-able and delicious. The atmosphere is definitely interesting (even the meandering hallway to get to the Tonga room was unexpected). 

But definitely worth a visit if you're in the city, even just for a cocktail.
author: Angelica K.

description: I went for the history, the strong drinks, and cause it's a tiki bar duh and was not disappointed on any front! I am a huge Bourdain fan so the Tonga room has been on my list for a while. I have heard very mixed reviews of the place from many different people but I have nothing but good things to say about it! I arrived a wee bit to early on a Wednesday afternoon (around 3:45pm) and my date and I went and checked out the giant gingerbread house in the lobby of the Fairmont then just sat on the bench outside the tonga room for about an hour and talked. It was a first date and a perfect way to start it off. In hindsight I am glad we were there so early because by the time the joint opened there was a decent sized line of people waiting to get in and within 30 minutes of opening the joint was packed! Inside is everything I had hoped for of a grand tiki bar and the drinks were definitely high octane if you catch my drift, which is nice cause usually drinks in a tiki bar are too sweet for my liking. Anyway I am glad I finally got to check this place out and would without a doubt recommended it for anyone in the area to come and check out. Such a cool place with such a cool history!
author: Shaun M.

description:
Definitely a tourist attraction so just keep that in mind when you go. Gotta wait in line for a table or go in and attempt to crowd around the bar space. 

The buffet food is mediocre but helps soak up all the alcohol from their drinks. Cocktails are pretty strong and consistent. Everything tastes delicious and boozy! Not to mention some are served in tiki glasses which makes the experience way more fun. Highly recommend sharing the punch bowls if you're going with a group. Get em all! 

Perfect for hanging out with friends, though not the best place to catch up as it gets pretty loud with the live band. They also charge cover when the band is playing and they mostly play covers of recent pop songs.
author: Maryann S.

description:
I liked this place. Kitschy and fun. Do not expect fine dining, although our dinner was surprisingly good. 

We walked in though the lobby and were blown away by the Fairmont (I wanted to switch hotels right then, but thats a different review) and made out way downstairs to the Tonga!! Great vibe. I used to be the hotel pool and now its a rainforest. Cool!

Had the Mai Tai and it was OK, not the best or worst I've had. Needed the floater of dark rum to be perfect.

Pu-Pu plater was good, but again not great. The ribs were the best item,

We also had the butterfish (special) and that was really tasty. Best dish of the night.
