The band started around 8 and thanks god!!! They are outstanding, we wanted to dance right away and off we went. We could have stayed all night at the bar or table and just danced. But, the waiter had us out to turn the table. Not cool, but I get it.

The service is kind of a get em out and get em in. Our drinks seemed like they were ready before we ordered them. maybe tell the staff to sow down. I should have.

So, to recap...great band and space. OK food and quick service. So, grab a lei and try and get lei's...good spot and lots of fun.
author: Peter I.

description: Sure the Tonga Room is a little weird and a lot kitschy, but it's old school SF and totally worth a visit.  Maybe I impress easily, but I found the decor and periodic rainstorms super cool.  That said, some things I've learned: don't bother with the food as you won't be impressed.  Sitting at a table will incur a cover charge but there is plenty of room at the bar and on the dance floor if you go on a random night earlier in the week.  Drinks are sugary and strong, mai tais surprisingly good.  Oh, and if you feel like taking an impromptu dip in the pool, that can be done.  Trust me, I've seen it happen and with no repercussions whatsoever.
author: Joanne G.

description:
You know you had a good time at the Tonga Room when:

1. You and your pal shared a Lava Bowl and downed it in 5. MINUTES. FLAT.

2. You REALLY, REALLY liked the ChiChi cocktail so you named your pet rabbit/dog/iguana Chi Chi and guess what?!?  you don't even have a pet rabbit/dog/iguana.

3. You behave so badly and are obnoxiously loud, but instead of getting kicked out by the Don Ho waiter look alike, he sits down with you and drinks out of the same straw AFTER you told him you have cooties. #drunkloveknowsnobounds!

4. Hmmm....#3 may or may not have happened but the drinks made me forget.

Bring lots of cash or use your friend's credit card because the cocktails here are $12 and up! (Happy Hour cocktails are $8.50 but the lava bowls are still $14) You'll definitely get bang for your buck and while the drinks may look girly, they are anything BUT! Those of you looking for a place to take your out of town friend or simply looking for the authentic Tiki bar experience outside of Hawaii, it is SO worth the money. We were here for Grace L's bon voyage party and she will definitely be missed! 

The Tonga Room is the only place that I can think of where it's acceptable for manly men to happily sip away tropical drinks replete with a slice of pineapple and a little umbrella. By the time you leave here, your pores will reek of coconut and fruit juice and you know what? 

It goes perfectly with that pink umbrella behind your ear.
author: Janice C.

description:
This was my first time coming here and with fellow yelp buddy, Christine R, deciding we didn't want the fun to end after the Nespresso Bar event. 

I thought that the decor sent you back to an 80'-90's Hawaii, with a cool floating tiki island, full of DJ's playing oldies but goodies!

The ambiance felt very laid back and relaxing, with a front view of the dance floor. We saw so many older couples along with kids getting it down on the dance floor!

Now, as far as service, I just had to take two stars off as our waitress kept disappearing, each time I was about to ask for or order something. I came in still getting over a cold and sore throat, and while she had brought out our drink, I still couldn't get any water after 30 min and asking three different people.

The menu is not very big and it's rather pricey for what it is, on top of a cover charge for not being hotel guests.

I ended up ordering some Mahi Mahi, which was still moist and had good flavor to it but the portion was rather small for the price.

Overall, it's a great venue for just grabbing a Mai Tai or Pina Colada and then heading to the dance floor! I would probably skip dinner there and eat somewhere else beforehand.
author: Petra S.

description:
Come for the happy hour buffet. You get cheap drinks, an all-you-can-eat assortment of egg rolls, wings, fruit, fried rice, and chow mein.. And an amazing atmosphere to top it off. Service was prompt and delightful, and made me feel welcome. It definitely had a mixer atmosphere, encouraging you to mingle with other folks at the bar.

I did not have dinner here yet, but I will be returning to give them a chance. It made me feel like I was in Hawaii. Especially with the "storms" that pass through, where there's rainfall into a pool. Seems like a fun atmosphere for both kids and adults alike!
author: Ethan G.

description:
A little disclaimer, this review is based on the bar service. I did not eat here.

Now this place is worth a visit just for the decor. A tiki theme right out of the early 70's, tastefully tacky. A man cave from 1971.

OMG the band was playing on a boat on a moat. Sounds cheesy, it was but in a good way. 

Big plus is tropical drinks served inside pineapples and coconuts.   

Seriously I'm being a bit of a jackass on the review. It's worth a pop our head in for a look. You won't be disappointed.
author: Tim F.

description:
I was not as impressed with the Tonga Room as I had anticipated. 

I loved the experience of going through the swanky hotel atmosphere to get to this tropical rain-room, but I found that to be the most exciting part.

The service was just okay and the food did not live up to its prices. 

Coming earlier in the evening was also not a good decision because there was no music and hardly any other people to feel like you were eating somewhere popular and exciting. I'm sure it gets better later in the evening when there is a live band, I just wish I had known the extreme difference in the environment at an earlier hour.
author: Cali G.

description: What an amazing place as far as atmosphere goes however don't expect to have amazingly delicious food but expect very potent and delicious drinks. Love this place but don't move the food
author: Aaron D.

description: The Zombie was strong and sweet and delicious! Atmosphere was awesome and food  was great! I can't wait to go back. Chow mein was very good!! And steak was great too!! The live music and "rainstorms " were awesome!
author: Tara K.

description: The space was gorgeous and I'm glad I went, however, I was expecting a little more from the cocktails. Thanksfully I got them during happy hour, but for the full price I expected a little more.
author: R N.

description: Tacky Tiki to the max. There aren't many of these venerable old Tiki bars left, and we need to cherish them. The Tonga room lacks the fancy glassware and smoking drinks of some, but it does have a pond and a barge for the band. Definitely a fun spot for before or after dinner drinks, although I'd skip the pricey buffet.
author: Steve A.

description:
All my years of emulating Jean Grey have finally paid off. 

Apparently, I tapped into my telepathy at Tonga Room because one minute I was just sitting there, only thinking about ordering a drink (probably purple drink), when one magically appeared in the form of a giant booze filled gutted pineapple. 

Sounds like some pretty slick mutant magic, eh? That's exactly what I was thinking... until we got the bill and my pineapple that I never actually ordered turned out to be a $26 hole in my wallet that was made up mainly of a partially crushed ice-filled concoction that tasted like (surprise, surprise) a whole lotta pineapple juice... and only a wee bit o' booze. #Bummer. You made Spongebob sad with your barely adult beverage, Tonga Room. #CrabbyPatty

Honestly, I wouldn't lose any sleep sealing their fate at 3 stars after the $26 pineapple money pit, and I have to admit that though I was not thrilled with the $5 cover at a bar we spent less than 30 minutes in only to pay more for a drink (I did not order) than I payed for all the clothes I was wearing. But alas, the atmosphere can't be overlooked and the live music was undeniably outstanding. I'm a super sucker for cover songs, to the point that even when I go to concerts for bands I love, I'm most excited to see what cover song they'll do... and if nothing is covered, well, they're dead to me. Okay, not really that extreme. But I do leave really disappointed. and the people standing around me usually get all pissed off when they're yelling the names of original songs for request and I'm yelling the generic cry of "Cover song! Do a cover song! Cover a song!".  

Anyway, I wish I coulda mastered my telepathic powers into tricking the server into cutting a deal on my $26 mistake drink that had barely any drink in it, or maybe tap into my telekinetic powers and move someone else's moola into my wallet, or better yet- move more booze into my f*ckin' $26 pineapple. 

Ooh- way harsh, Ty! Okay, okay. I take that back. I've guess I've never actually cut a pineapple so maybe $26 is a decent price for that kind of service. It does look like somewhat of a tricky+stabby fruit to get into... so fine. You earned your 4 stars TR&HB... but until you can master the art of pairing correct drink with correct patron, this Phoenix is gon' have to hold you back from that 5-er.
author: Candice G.

description: Atmosphere here is great. Happening with the band and good vibe.  Food was way overpriced and mediocre and they were out of 3 things on their menu.   The drinks are all pre-made. I could drink with the best of them, however not even I could drink some of the swill they were pushing for $15+ per drink.  I think folks should save their money and go somewhere better.
author: Brian G.

description: I celebrated my 21st birthday here, so I have to show some love for this SF establishment. Drinks are tasty, atmosphere is lively, but the parking here is a bit of a pricey hassle. I haven't been to other tiki bars since, so I can't really compare tiki experiences, but this is a place every Bay Area resident should sojourn to at least once. The only thing I was disappointed in was that they didn't card me :D
author: Ghia G.

description:
Went for the Tiki Room atmosphere, strong drinks, and to relax after a day of walking around the city. Instead got some weak drinks and lots of loud kids.  This was definitely not a cool trendy Tiki bar, felt more like Disneyland. I was waiting for someone to knock a stroller into my ankles! On top of that their drinks are way over priced, not innovative, and weak on top of that.

Go to Smuggler's Cove, the Tonga Room might have been a good stop years ago but it was a wasted trip for us.
author: Jim G.

description: 3 stars for the unique experience (similar to the pirates of the carribean resto at Disney). 1 star for the poke appetizer which was the only good dish out of the 6 appetizers/meals we ate.
author: g b.

description: I took my boyfriend out for several special occasions. At first, it was very complicated to communicate with this restaurant. I was calling to tell them I will be ten minutes late due to traffic. I was so nervous my table I reserved will be given to someone else. I was upset coming into the place. The place itself is so beautiful and breath taking. I was happy I still had my table I reserved but a bit disappointed that it was not the table I really wanted. I wanted next to the water next to the live music especially for it being over a month reservation. It was still a good view just difficult to take pictures without someone being in the picture. The waiter we had was so nice and friendly and helped us out with our decisions and picture taking. The food is incredible!!There was no left over to take home. The drinks are pricey but worth it. It is really strong! It is  a kick every sip. The live music was the cherry on top! The band played good music and very upbringing. It had me dancing in my seats even though I wanted to stand up and dance. I think if the seating arrangement were spaced out I could dance without being in someone way. At the end, I talked to the manager and she was really nice and understood my concerns. She helped me for future help. Overall, really good place to go to. I am coming back with family and friends. My boyfriend was very happy with his surprise leaving him with a smile on his face, filled tummy and buzzed. haha.
author: Mariah G.

description:
Tiny bubbles (tiny bubbles)
In the wine (in the wine)
Make me happy (make me happy)
Make me feel fine (make me feel fine)

Really? You've never been to the Tonga Room? Oh c'mon, I thought it was de rigeur to go there at least once after a high school prom or for a bachelorette party or like I just did, with a bunch of colleagues looking for a little kitschy entertainment to talk about around the water cooler the next day. Anthony Bourdain certainly loved going there as part of his "Layover" episode in San Francisco. And despite threats of closure, it hangs on year after year looking almost exactly the same it did the first time I was there sometime during the first Reagan administration. It's the biggest tiki lounge I've ever patronized, and I've been to a few in my time, I must say.

Tiny bubbles (tiny bubbles)
Make me warm all over
With a feeling that I'm gonna
Love you till the end of time...

I guess people actually eat here, but I can't really comment on the dinner menu because I've never been tempted to try it. I just can't get my head around Hawaiian food as fine dining. Now don't get me wrong, my group did share a plate of the $15 BBQ Pork Ribs with Kona Coffee Glaze and the $16 Coconut Prawns with Mango Relish, both perfectly decent Hawaiian fare that is unlikely to shake the San Francisco culinary scene. The real dregs can be found during happy hour when they serve a buffet of predictably greasy Chinese platters that are simply execrable. But the only reason to come here is to have some tropical concoction with a long red straw and a little parasol on top.

So here's to the golden moon
And here's to the silver sea
And mostly here's a toast
To you and me...

Mai tais and pina coladas are too bourgeois for my taste, so I found a willing patsy to share the mysterious $13 Lava Bowl for Two (see photo). It comes in a ceramic bowl, and it's the only drink on the menu that doesn't list any ingredients. If you feel you are entitled to the "Nectar of the Gods", by all means, drink up because you won't remember it after you leave. It was a strong concoction, so watch your mouth if you're around people who are motivated to blackmail you. The place crowds quickly, as it is a known destination for rowdy groups of suits. The floating band eventually arrives on the barge in the converted pool, and they start to perform a medley of unrecognizable disco tunes. Time to leave...

So here's to the ginger lei
I give to you today
And here's a kiss
That will not fade away

COCKTAILS - 3.5 stars...share a Lava Bowl if you feel brave
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...the ultimate tiki lounge
SERVICE - 2 stars...pushy and not very responsive
TOTAL - 3 stars...not that much of a must-do but if Anthony is your muse...
author: Ed U.

description:
I came here last night for dinner with one other person, and I really enjoyed my experience here! We made reservations for dinner at 8:45pm, and even though we came ~10 minutes early, we got seated right away. There was some band playing last night so we got charged a $7 entertainment fee per person... but the band was fun so I really can't complain about that additional fee. I really like the atmosphere and layout of this place!! It feels like Hawaii or some tropical getaway... Whenever the band was playing music, families/couples/kids would dance together... soooooooo cute!! People of all ages were on the dance floor doing everything from fancy ballroom dancing to shaking what their mama gave them. 

Because we weren't that hungry, we ordered one entree... Fire cracker? It was decent, but I knew not to have high expectations for the food, so it didn't bother me as much that I was going to pay so much for mediocre food. I also ordered a Tonga Itch, which was a good, sweet girl drink. My friend and I also shared a lava bowl which was pretty cool to drink out of with the super long red straws haha. Our bill came out to be ~$82.

Service was okay... everything was REALLY slow... but it worked out I guess since we got to go dance, take pictures, etc. while waiting for everything.
author: Annie S.

description: Ate here on a Saturday night.  We had a reservation for 4 and then 5 turned up but the staff quickly added an extra chair.  One of our group has a severe peanut allergy and the attention to this detail was extraordinary.  Our waiter - Bash - was marvelous.  He knew the menu so could make good recommendations when we ordered.  He also mentioned the peanuts several times so we felt very safe that attention was being paid to this.  We enjoyed the band and the whole "tiki" atmosphere.  I see some other reviews sneer at the old fashioned style but it was exactly what I expected.  The reason I give 4 stars is I disliked being charged $10 per head for the band.  The food and drinks here are already pretty highly priced so I think they could absorb the cost of the band.
author: Joy P.

description: Beware if there is live music, as they will charge you $10 cover fee per person and will not warn about this at the moment of making a reservation. Food was ok, decent portions, but not impressed. Drink (lava bowl) was awesome.
author: Lorely G.

description: Expected a lot more. Reservation was messed up, service is horrid, people are snooty and prickish. I was reprimanded for sharing my table with some nice strangers. Expected sooooooooooo much more. I will keep to my tiki bar in LA, TikiTi, they have set the bar. So disappointed, I was really looking forward to drinking and enjoying here.
author: Patricia P.

description: This place is super fun! Just make sure to check out the information before you go. The music starts at different times depending on which night you go. I went on a Sunday night and the live band didn't get on till about 8pm, but that's okay because I really enjoy the ambiance of this place. Once the band plays you do have to pay an entertainment fee, so just be aware of that as well. The drinks are pretty pricey, but again you are also paying for the atmosphere. It's  almost as if you are in Hawaii with the occasional drizzle. This is my go to spot for entertaining out of towners.
author: Sheree C.

description: I admit I have a love of everything Tiki, and the Tonga Room & Hurricane Bar is everything I ever imagined a Tiki Bar could be. The atmosphere is great, the drinks are strong, and the food is delicious!
author: Lisa M.

description:
Went to the Tonga room the night before Thanksgiving  w/ my wife and two teenagers, looking to have appetizers for dinner.  We had been to the Tonga room maybe 15 years prior and I thought the kids would get a kick out of the place.  

I went in expecting fairly lame food but top-notch drinks, a-la the "Trader Vics" that recently closed in Los Angeles.  Exactly the opposite happened.

The food was surprisingly good. And the drinks were simply terrible.  

We had some Khalua Pig and ribs. Both were very solid - liked by all 4 of us.

My wife ordered a Pina Colada and I had a Fog Cutter. Now I loooove strong drinks so I'm not saying they were too strong, but there was nothing to balance the alchohol at all. We might as well have ordered rum on the rocks. The pina colada wasn't blended either. It was rum and a tiny bit of juice and maybe some coconut milk on ice. It was terrible.  My fog cutter was just rum and some cheap acidic mixer. I decided to give them another chance and order a Mai Tai.  It was so bad, I didn't finish it.

The Tonga room gets high marks for decor and atmosphere and decent food. I only wished I had known that the nearby Smugglers Cove was the Spirited Awards winner of Best American Cocktail Bar 2016. I would have gone there instead.

Also, they start charging a $7 cover charge at 7pm.  We arrived at 7:30 and paid the cover. But the band didn't start playing until about 8:20 !!! We heard three songs before we had to leave.  I thought it was pretty crappy of them to let the band sit there quietly for an hour while the cover-paying customers listened to their ipod playlist.

Bad drinks and mistakes like that, combined with Yelp, will put you out of business.
author: Dave S.

description: I went here last night with my friends for appetizers and drinks as we didn't have a reservation. We had to wait about 25 mins to be seated, which wasn't bad. The place is very nice, great tiki style decorations. I especially liked the pool in the middle of the floor, with the "floating band" playing great live music. The drinks were pretty good. We ordered several things, including the glass noodles, wanton tacos,  edamame a spring rolls. All delicious! The only thing I would "complain" about is our server not being the nicest or quickiest, but she out food and drinks out. I would come here again, maybe try a full meal next time.
author: Kim G.

description: Came here on a Wednesday for happy hour around 4:45 to line up for entry at 5 PM. I couldn't get a reservation, so I read that you can line up for first come, first serve bar table seating where you can have happy hour priced appetizers and drinks. When we got there, there was only one family ahead of us, so we ended up being second in the door. By the time we got let in, there were probably 6-10 more parties behind us. It filled up very quickly. By 5:10 all the bar area tables were taken so many people were standing at the actual bar. I ordered a Mai Tai ($10) which was very good and quite strong and my husband ordered a Kona Longboard ($5). We had a problem with a cracked glass and it was fixed immediately by a bus boy. We ordered garlic edamame beans, pork Shumai and vegetable pot stickers. All very good! My one complaint about the pork was it was a little fatty (which I am picky about) so it had some chewy parts that I didn't eat. Other than that, we cleaned our plates. We also very much enjoyed the rain show that happens every half hour. The ambiance is very cool and the place is super unique. The staff we interacted with were fine, but not necessarily friendly. Overall, I would say it's definitely a cool place to try once, but I don't know if I think it's necessary to go back.
author: Tara Q.

description: A San Francisco must-see! On the weekends this place gets PACKED, so I recommend going during the week. The band is always great and the rain is so unique. The drinks are slightly pricey but it's an experience so worth it. If you want to grab some apps, make a reservation ahead of time. The tables by the bar fill up very quickly.
author: MacKenzie B.

description:
Everyone with a negative review has no joy left. There's fake rain. There're fruity drinks.  A dance floor a cover band. The food is upscale pricey, Nob Hill meets pseudo Asian Polynesian. But it's at an upscale Nob Hill pricey hotel, so free range pork is expected. 

If you can't take it at face value, you need to lighten up.
author: Dee R.

description: I was here again this past weekend and had a blast! They're fairly quick on tables even if you don't reserve one and the band was really good. Def a great group/party spot. Try the zombie drink but keep in mind you really only need one- it will sneak up on you.
author: Debbie P.

description:
Hmm. Not my usual type of bar. There's definitely an older crowd here (30+), but I had fun nevertheless. I think my parents would really like it here.

Drinks were average club / bar prices: $53 for 3 beers, a margarita, cover for 2 people ($7 each on a Friday night), tax + tip. I was kind of surprised by the cover since I usually pay at the door, but whatever, $7 is cheaper than I'm used to anyway. The margarita wasn't very strong (but I didn't mind). Loved the live band that played mostly oldies. It was a nice change from the EDM you hear everywhere these days (and I actually like EDM).
author: Paulina L.

description:
This is a fun bar to go to that covers just about every cliché about stereotypical bars from the 80s including a major size pool in the middle of the floor. But Regardless of that fact it was pretty fun and I enjoyed my time here. Minus the $7 cover charge to enter the Tonga room and the drunk people starting a conga line when the house band played that 80's classic "feeling hot, hot, hot."

If you're coming here for the drinks and the 5 star meals then you're in the wrong place. The drinks are watered down and come in fun but tacky drinking glasses. When you arrive you get "laid", at the front door, but let's be PG here people. I'm talking about the lays you get when you arrive in Hawaii. Oh and did I mention there a love band playing all the hits from the 70's and 80's!

But despite all of that the Tonga room can be really fun and enjoyable if you let it. I'm a firm believer that It's all about the energy and the kind of people you surround yourself with. Those are key factors in making any situation fun. Outside of the atmosphere, including the live band and the simulated rain falls from the ceiling, the scorpion bowls are most likely the highlight of you're experience here. But there are other drinks worth trying like: the Singapore sling ($12), and the zombie ($12).

As for the food, as I said earlier it's delicious and comes in at reasonable price point. I loved the ceviche ($14) an appetizer served with fresh fish from south America. When you combine that with the fresh tomatoes, pepper and guacamole, it was so tasty. 

As for the main courses. I've had a few of them and enjoy most of them. The sea bass, pouched in butter as well as the hot pot served with peppers and a tasty spicy sauce, as well as the Pork Loin ($29). All in all the worst thing about the Tonga room I would say is finding park. In Nob hill it's almost in possible, unless you park in a garage. But just be careful because most of the garages close at 10pm. Which is very odd because you would think they would stay open late for people who wanna party in that area.
author: Donald W.

description:
I went to the Tonga Room & Hurricane Bar for my friends birthday dinner. This place definitely gets a 5/5 for the atmosphere. There was a pool/lake in the middle of the restaurant, and a live band playing in the middle on a boat (we got charged $7 per person because of the live music). There was also fake rain which was really cool and added to the ambiance. Unfortunately, there were 2 huge plants blocking our view, so we didn't really get a stellar view of the boat/band. There was also a dance floor as soon as you walked in. We left around 10 and it was actually getting pretty full. 

There were 6 of us, so we got 1 lava bowl for 4, and 1 smugglers golden punch bowl for 4. I personally liked the lava bowl better.

For dinner, I got Chef Alan's Kung Pao Chicken, and really enjoyed it. I think the serving size looks a lot bigger than it actually is. I was able to finish it all. My friend got a complimentary dessert for her birthday. 

The only bad thing about this place, like many people are saying, is the price. Also, since we came on Halloween weekend, some of the decorations that they had were pretty questionable (they had some right next to tables that would make noises, and that was pretty disturbing). Because of the live band, it's a pretty loud place, so don't come here if you're looking for a quiet, romantic dinner.

However, we were running late to our reservation and they gave us a 15 minute grace period, so the people there are very nice and friendly. 

Overall, although it is costly, I would definitely recommend trying this place at least once.
author: Meha M.

description:
I am so disapointed. We had to make reservations two months in advance and we get there and it is all beautiful and chill setting. We sit down and it's awesome, they quickly come up and take a our drink orders and we get our drinks quickly as well. The drinks were packed with ice and pretty strong but didn't taste good and just had huge pieces of mint. We sent one back. 

Then we ordered apps and we got the poke, dumplings and peel it shrimp. All had no flavor. The presentation was cool on the poke but it was completely bland. 

Then we ordered dinner, we got mongolian beef, Mahi Mahi, chowmein with beef, the Kahlua pork and the striper. 

Mongolian beef- was okay (the best of them all) not nicely cut and kind of meat hanging from fat

Mahi mahi- bland. No flavor at all and it sat on a bed of funky avocado puree that wasn't fitting and it just didn't go with it. 30$ for bland crap

Chowmein and beef- I can get better at Safeway, super flavorless.

Kahlua pork-horrible, L&L bbq is better and it was 27$

The biggest let down was the 44$ snapper . That they fail to tell you is a 2 ft fish, again bland as hell. 

So this place has good music, nice atmosphere and we saw it on Anthony Bourdain which gave us high hopes.  Super waste of money. We spent 400$ on glorified Chinese food. Don't do it!
author: L A.

description:
The Tonga Room has been around for years, the classic old Tiki Restaurant and Bar has seen many visitors over the years, but I swear since Anthony Bourdain hit up the Tonga Room on his show the Layover, it's gotten ridiculously popular all over again.

Happy Hour starts at 5, dinner service at 6 and by 5:15 p.m. the bar was at max capacity and the line was creeping down the hall. The reservations were completely booked and some would have to wait over and hour and half for drinks. My suggestion is to go early or make a reservation for dinner. 

We were happy to sit at the bar and order a couple drinks. Happy Hour has reduced price drinks (most 40-50% off regular prices). We started with the Scorpion Bowl for two ($13) and it was strong. Don't let the little bowl and cute long straws fool you. 

We enjoyed the rainstorms between cocktails and ordered the Lava Bowl (also $13), which completely seemed like the same drink as the Scorpion. After we finished the second bowl, we were quite buzzed and off in search of dinner. 

I'm really glad that the Tonga Room is not closing down, it really is a fun place to enjoy a couple cocktails and the occasional rain storm. I was heartbroken to hear that they might close it, but now it seems that would be a big mistake. Long live the Tonga Room!
author: Rebekah T.

description: Decided to come here with a few friends. The bar is inside the Fairmont hotel. We decided to use their parking because we were going around in circles for a while. The parking was $6 for 30minutes. The actual bar is spacious and cute. It was still happy hour so we decided to get the two shareable drinks.  The drinks were HORRIBLE. We could only muster to take a few sips of each. Our waitress was super nice and didn't charge us for them since we barely touched it. You're paying for the ambience and setup of the place. They also have food there which we didn't try but the drinks are definitely not worth it.
author: Ranika M.

description: This is rather expensive for the experience. Yeah its setup well but it mostly consists of tourists or an older crowd. I went here on a double date and was blown away by the small plates for the amount of money. The tonga experience is better than others though and thats what keeps people coming back.
author: Brittini S.

description: First off people it's a Tiki restaurant. I've seen a few negative reviews talking about the decor has never been changed...why would they change it?? MGM designed this place in 1945, back in the polynesian theme heyday.  It is a gem, a very unique experience that you will never have anywhere, and that's a promise. The drinks are "Tiki" all the way...full of rum, fresh juices, sugar and sneak up on you in the best of ways.  The food is really good too and pair great with those polynesian drinks.  Like Anthony Bourdain said "If you can't like this place, you're a sick lonely person with a lot of cats!"
author: Christopher S.

description: What can I say but that this place is awesome! Tiki lives and thank the tiki gods for that! Mai Tais are the best I've had anywhere. One of the last originals and if you are in SF it is a must stop. Gre at service at the bar even though they were busy.
author: Bob F.

description:
Everyone says you gotta go here.  Its a must see.  Have been wanting to see it for myself  for some time and am glad I did.  Yes, its got big pool in the middle of the restaurant with a floating stage, big drinks, and indoor rain.  But with all that, I wasn't that impressed.  

Once we found it...its a little tricky if you start at the hotel...we had to decide bar or restaurant.  Huh?   Anyway, started at the bar and had some huge shared drink with long straws.  We were going to go for the happy hour buffet but it looked pretty greasy.  Opted to get seated for dinner instead. 

We were the seated on the far end behind the floating band stage.  Band was just getting set up while we were ordering.  

Food came out and was just ok.  The calamari was overly breaded.  The fish was a little dry.  It was pretty non memorable.  But then, the food was competing with the indoor rain sounds for you attention.  

Bottom line is that yes, it has an interesting atmosphere and has large drinks but food does not impress.
author: Marcus K.

description:
I loathe three-star reviews. I really do. But this place has rock-bottom, one-star food and top-notch, five-star ambiance and entertainment. So, a three-star it shall be.

Luckily, their drink menu looked more enticing than the food, so my girlfriend and I dove right in. Mai-tais in fake coconut shells for me and zombies for the lady. We ordered the five-course meal (#YOLO, right?!) and were almost sobered up by the first courses underwhelming presentation and blandness; so, naturally, we ordered more drinks.

{insert two-three paragraphs about unflavored meats, and uninspired cuisine here}

Ok, you get it, the food sucks. So I'd much rather talk about the entertainment.

The first thing you notice when you walk in is there's a pool in the middle of the restaurant. Though my first inclination after a few mai-tais was to jump in and swim, I remember my mom always telling me not to get in the water until an hour after eating so I reluctantly sat back in my chair. There's also a boat, that at first was hugging outside of the pool and I thought was just merely a prop. That was until a fedora-fronted cover band boarded and it moved to center of the pool. They were actually pretty awesome and played from at least 8PM until the place closed around midnight.

There's a giant dance floor that gets pretty heated and the band takes a break around every 30-minutes to give the floor a break and the bar some business.

The Tonga Room definitely made for an awesome evening! I think if my girlfriend and I had just stayed for drinks, appetizers and dancing this place would have gotten five-stars. I know it's been a San Francisco staple for quite some time, but I can't stand a restaurant (whose business is literally their food) to bank on titles and not on their product. The food needs a massive overhaul but if everything else stayed the same, I'd be one avid Tonga Room-er.
author: Michael S.

description:
I have been a fan of Tiki for a quite awhile now and knew that my next trip to the bay area would require a visit to the Tonga Room.

We rolled through on a Saturday night and although, there was a massive line, it moved rather quickly.
I honestly didn't care how long I had to wait in line, this place is LEGENDARY!

We had a few of the bowl drinks and they were pretty strong and tasty.

The band was really entertaining and the overall atmosphere was just REALLY fun.

When the band started playing Creedence Clearwater's - Have You Ever Seen the Rain? I screamed because I knew exactly what was about to happen.
THE RAINSTORM!

It was so great and I am so happy I finally visited! :D
author: Angela C.

description: Maaan this place is a blast!! Its packed always.. Food is a bit pricy.. But if your looking for a good time in SF and want to have amazing drinks and delicious food and enjoy a lighting/thunder rain storm while a live band jams out on a boat in water in the middle of the restaurant then i suggest you stopping reading other reviews and go here!! Haha :D
author: Tuna O.

description:
Very hard to get into. You have to physically wait in a line to get in.

The decor of this place is unmatchable. It's comparable to a Disney World ride- really phenomenal set up.

Tiki drinks were good, and they have a $10 buffet at dinner.

Worth checking out as it's a very unique spot.
author: Rachel K.

description:
What. An. Experience. From heading into the hotel and down the Cinderella staircase, you are transformed out of the city and into a celebratory paradise for all ages. The service is spectacular and the pool with thunderstorms is quite the decoration.

Go during happy hour to indulge in the reasonably priced drinks and Chinese inspired buffet! And make a reservation if you want a table, otherwise go to the bar to snag a seat at the bar.
author: Regina D.

description:
I came back. Everyone from a certain networking company was there so it was crowded in the bar area. The renovations are great - it no longer smells like gym socks next to a swimming pool.

Props go to Roberto - the BEST server ever. He took our orders really fast and gave us our drinks about 2 minutes after arriving.
author: Karen S.

description:
Back with my son for his birthday...and this place didn't dissapoint, yet again! This round we ordered appetizers that we didn't get to try last time...and every item was insanely delicious! I'd show you a photo...but the food didn't last long enough to photograph! As usual, the drinks were amazing...delicious, and didn't skimp on the booze! Go here at least once in your life to scratch your sense of kitschy-ness...nostalgia...and plain old good fun!...

OH...and no the band they have here is simply awesome...playing oldies and goodies with an enthusiasm that makes your booty shake...even if your dead!
author: Richard J.

description: My boyfriend took me here for dinner! We loved the whole Hawaiian/ tropical style/ decor! It was Sooo pretty and The pool in the middle of the restaurant made it look so cool! I don't even remember what food we got but it was alright, the service was good and attentive.
author: Sally H.

description: This place is fantastic. It's pricey, but not one of those spots you'd go to every week (well on my budget at least). Came here with some buddies after going to a convention for a week to kind of wind down. The place has a nice Tiki/Hawaiian theme without being too overly corny. The front section is a first come first serve spot with a bar and a few tables for bar food. We had a reservation for four and were able to sit down already at our table. Our waiter was fantastic and very friendly. The water in the middle was awesome with the fake rain and lightening. There's also a band that plays later on a floating boat, but we left before this happened (shucks!). We ordered some calamari for appetizers which was great. We shared a Scorpion Bowl which was great (and a bit strong haha). I ordered the Kahlua Pulled Pork and it was very tender and I enjoyed the fact an over easy egg was on top with rice. We all shared a Tropical Banana Split at the end which was just fantastic too! It had a mix of sherbet and ice creams which really compliments everything. Overall, it was fun it had great food and a nice atmosphere. The plates are about $30 bucks a plate so keep that in mind. I would definitely come back again to let my GF try it!
author: James R.

description:
I'd give this place ZERO stars if I could. One of the worst customer service experiences EVER. Also, the service was horrible not simply from one server, but this was common to any one I interacted with here. They have no respect whatsoever for their customers.
Food is nothing to rave about. Cocktails were yuck as well.
author: Vivek G.

description:
A San Francisco landmark!

If visiting or just live in the area, you need to go. It rains in here. There is a little boat on the water that the band plays on. I mean come on! This is so cool! The drinks are great too!

I won't give too much away, but you need to stop by one night and enjoy a SF treat.
author: Steven P.

description:
4 stars for the crazy cool decorations and the overall ambiance of this place. Really cool tiki bar!

The drinks aren't exciting though. Other places like Smuggler's have really extensive drink menus with really unique and cool drinks. This place had the basics and nothing special.

I had the pina colada, which was fine. Creamy and not too sweet with a good kick of rum.

My boyfriend had the pineapple royale which was quite strong and sour, but good!

The layout of the place is pretty much what makes it! Really cool place to grab a drink and hang out with friends.
author: Connie H.

description: Good atmosphere. Cool drinks. Nice live music.  That said food is worse than Chinese take out food. Go for the drinks and skip the food
author: Joe J.

description: Do not eat at this restaurant! The staff is rude. Service is slow. Food is over priced. Tables were dirty. Food was salty. The food will make you sick! I do not know why the Fairmont Hotel keeps this place open. The cook and staff should be Fired!
author: Robert G.

description:
This is definitely one of those places that you go to say you've been. Call it a tourist trap, but I do think the Tonga Room is more than that. It's probably one of the places I've talked about most from my recent San Francisco trip. Everyone is fascinated by the tale of a pool room turned tiki bar in the basement of a swanky hotel. 

With a floating band and rain storms on the regular, the atmosphere certainly is lively. Order up a punch bowl and share Lady and the Tramp-style using straws that are at least two feet long. Don't expect strong drinks, though; ours tasted mostly of fruit juices.

Stop by for a drink but be sure to book a table in advance to skip the lines.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Okay, full disclosure. The Tonga Room is kind of all over the place. The staff vacillated between being really friendly and incredibly rude. The drinks are pretty spendy, but deliver a bang for you buck (I was toasted off of 1.5 zombies). But I am still giving it 4 stars for the following reasons.

My friends and I showed up on a Saturday night with no reservation and pretty much just barged our way without paying the $7 cover. And when I say my friends I mean there were 20+ of us. So the fact that management didn't just round us up and kick us out, I appreciated. 

We were getting down and dirty on the dance floor surrounded by several patrons who were elderly and dressed very nicely (we had just come from class and were not dressed nicely). At one point a drink was dropped and shattered, but they came and cleaned it up for us, once again, without kicking us out.

I set my drink on the railing while I was dancing and a server took it away even though it was only half done. I told a manager and he got me a new one, no charge.

All night we were staring at the swimming pool daring ourselves to jump in. Well, one of my friends finally got brave (and drunk enough) stripped down to his skivvies and canon balled in. Swam around for a while, dancing to the band. Employees were waiting for him with a table cloth on the other end, but they at least let him put his pants on before tossing him out on the street and didn't call the police.

So if I am out with a wild group who wants to shake their tail feathers, I will probably end up at the Tonga Room again. And this time, I'm going to make it in the pool!
author: Casey S.

description: What I don't understand is this.. There's about 10 tables that are open inside, but there is a line  outside to wait for seats. Why can't these tables be filled? The vibe in there is definitely special, as theres not that many places that starts to rain and thunder! Price range is high, probably because it is located inside the Fairmont Hotel. The food is medicare, I wouldn't take anyone here for their food, but probably for a nice drink at the bar.
author: Monique W.

description:
Warning: this is going to be a long one. This review starts with 5 stars...

Tonga Bar is located on the terrace level at the Fairmont so you can take the elevator down. Once there, just follow the signs down the hallways. You're greeted at the door and asked if you have reservations. I recommend making reservations especially if you go in a popular weeknight/weekend. Outside there is a sign that says $7 as a live entertainment fee, but does not specify for who. The lady did mention to the party in front of us that there was a charge, but they were going to the bar. We were not notified of this charge. 

Ambiance: you walk in and the bar area, which is a good size, is on the right. Right in front of the the bar is a dance floor and the "pool" with the boat which has the live entertainers is in front of the dance floor. All around the "pool" are tables. Once in a while, there's rain that falls around the pool. Kinda cool. The lights are dim and the place feels welcoming. The entertainers are pretty good-sing a variety of songs/make you wanna dance. Good job with the atmosphere Tonga. Review stays at 5 stars. 

Food and drinks: We didn't have much to choose from as the boy is a vegetarian, so we started with the jade dumplings and shared an entree: thai green curry with a side of the forbidden blend fried rice. I really liked the dumplings and would recommend those. The rice was ok. It was a little hard for my liking. The thai green curry...nasty. There was no flavor and not enough curry. It was nowhere what I'm used too when I have curry at Thai restaurants. Drinks: we got pineapple royale which comes in a pineapple and was the better of the two drinks. Also got this creamy looking drink-nasty as shit. Tasted like coconut oil. We couldn't even drink it and just had them take it away. -1.5 stars for food and drinks. 

What I didn't like was the fact that they charged $7 per person for the live entertainment. If you have customers come for the bar area only, I can understand the fee, but for customers who are there to dine at your establishment, with your prices, you shouldn't charge them an entertainment fee. As a restaurant, you are providing the entertainment for your customers and they shouldn't be responsible to pay for it. Instead, have a place where they can tip the entertainers. -2 stars

I wouldn't come back here and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.
author: Puja K.

description:
1. Ambiance- 5 stars. 
2. Service - 5 stars.
3. Drinks- 5 stars. Bf and I tried 6 things, all good. The Hurricane and the Pina Colada were fantastic. 
4. Appetizer- (tuna poki) 4 stars. Fresh and tasty, but could have used a little zest imo. 
5. Entrees- (trip tip and scallops) 3 stars. Flavorful, but the tri tip did not seem tender enough to be Wagyu, and the sauce in the scallops was one dimensional. Portions are rather small too. 
6. Desert- (coconut chocolate cake) 0 stars. Literally THE worst dessert I have ever had. We were laughing because it was so awful. It tasted like eating a vaguely coconut candle on top of one super thin (we're talking 1/8 of an inch) way-too-sweet piece of brownie. So nasty. Just. So. Bad. 

Would I go again? 
For drinks and apps- Any day. 
For dinner- Nah.  
For desert- Only if I'm dining with someone I truly hate.
author: Clarity B.

description: There are just so many rules!! Standing room only in the bar, no sitting at the tables in the bar (so why are they there?), no moving chairs from one table to anther, you can stay for 3 songs to decide if you like the band then you pay the cover charge etc.  The atmosphere is cool and the drinks are strong, but I'm more partial to Smugglers Cove...less hype, less touristy, same if not better cocktails.
author: Hayley H.

description:
Wonderful service thanks David and team at the dinner tables section. He always checked on us and was absolutely wonderful. 
jan 2016 thursday, listened to the band and had a great time.
Lychee martini from the bar was yummy.
Parking fee was $58!!! What!!! 
From 5:30pm-9:30!!!
author: Bing.kay B.

description:
There are bars that I will return to for the atmosphere.  There are bars that I will return to for the location.  On rare occasions there are bars that bring me back for the bartender - @TongaRoom is one of those gems.

I had the privilege of receiving an education on tiki cocktails from the skilled Christine at the Tonga room and I will return to further that education.  Christine brings old school dedication and skill to the art of the cocktail and executes the tiki cocktails here with only the freshest ingredients-a true master at her craft.

You see, it started like this - I dropped in here with some friends and I politely declined a tiki drink for fear of losing my man-card if I had one of "those umbrella drinks".  Christine immediately corrected me on the manliness of tiki drinks, explaining their history and association with returning troops from the war.  Props.  I stand corrected.

The next hour in between other patrons Christine continued educating me on the tiki cocktails and the recent changes at the Tonga Room, remaking the drink menus and shifting to only the best top shelf ingredients and freshest fruits and juices.  Certainly changes befitting the marquee location of this bar.

I was hooked and ordered a Singapore Sling.  

This week a business trip will find me in the area again and I will learn a little more about tiki drinks....

The Tonga Room itself is a space with a lot of production value if that is your thing.  I'm here for the drinks, thanks.

Added bonus, Christine used to work in Vegas and can give you a nice rundown on the bars to check out when you are over there.
author: Jim W.

description: Bad experience . My boyfriend and I (Hispanic and Filipino) got asked for our card to "open a tab" before we even ordered our food. We thought it was weird so just to verify we asked a table of Caucasian women if the waiter did the same with them, the answer was no of course. We left. Never felt so disrespected or humiliated in my life. I talked to the manager, who did nothing about the situation, long story short I won't be back here again.
author: Lupe M.

description:
TIME WARP!!!!! 1940s? 1950s?? 1960s??? 1970s???? Is that Roger Sterling and Donald Draper at the bar?

I just absolutely loved the Retro Tiki Tacky Shag-esque ambiance of this place...how have I not been here before? Its like being in Disney's Enchanted Tiki Room, sans the animatronic talking and singing birds, but with food, booze, live band playing hits from the 30s-80s, and with a sizeable dance floor. There's even a fake rain storm that occurs every so often. Its Fabulous! Its Beautiful!! Its Romantic!! And ...Expensive!?!?!?

OK, its not that expensive, I've done a lot worse fine dining in Vegas. But if you're taking out your Out-of-Towner-Cheapass relatives and friends, be prepared to drop some money since you're in an upscale restaurant, within a fancy hotel, and in San Francisco.  $7 cover charge per person will be added to your bill, cocktails run double digits, and the overpriced average food will add up quickily. If you feel like you're getting ripped off, pretend its someone's birthday so you can at least get a free dessert(It actually was my BFF's birthday...but I wouldn't hesitate to lie in the future!). All in all, the 10 of us rang up a $630.03 tab, and not everyone ate! Oh well...I'm definitely coming back someday with the Yelp Elite Erica P for some cocktails and dancing :D

FYI: There are some straw hats hidden around the restaurant, try them on for some fun photos! (see my photos)
author: Chun P.

description: My friend was adamant on taking me here during my recent trip to SF as I was staying in the hotel across the street. It is a cool establishment but is also rather expensive. It is worth a visit here and there but not a regulars spot. I would come back for the happy hour which looked to be rather appetizing.
author: John B.

description: ALWAYS use the phone to check if it's open, because it closes for private events and doesn't put notice on its website. One of the most fun bars in the world if you like it throwback and cheesy like I do, but management is complacent. You also may not get a seat--people who are eating get priority on those.
author: P J.

description: The food and drinks are ridiculously priced. That being said, the atmosphere and experience you will have here is worth it, at least once in your life. It's a place to splurge and enjoy yourself, if you have the coin.
author: Maggie K.

description: First time here after several people recommended it to me. It was super fun, definitely over the top in every way, but again - super fun. The live band was so fun, and definitely set the vibe of the whole place. And the drinks were good and very festive (tiki)! We didn't get the food - so I can't comment on that. There was kind of a funky smell... like damp from the water possibly? We spent most of our time here on the dance floor area, drinks in hand, enjoying the live band.
author: Tiffany T.

description: I love Disneyland so I love it here, it reminds me of it. I like the tiki ambiance the pool where live bands play. I like the cheesy fake thunderstorms...I like the Mai tai coconut cup glasses , the pina Coladas are pretty good. The food is fine , what you expect. The dance floor fills up when a good beat drops. I always have a good time .
author: Cecilia D.

description:
I thought it was Disneyland, but the Tonga room is the most magical place on earth.  Why is it so magical? Well, one of the reasons is that my Grandmother used to come here.  Opened in 1945, this is truly a San Francisco gem.  Before it was the Tonga room, it was the indoor pool of the Fairmont hotel, a favorite of old time movie stars.

Another reason the Tonga room is so magical?  Fake rainstorms and a barge-bound lagoon band.  The night that we went the band played older lounge-y songs from the 1970s like Copacabana, to which I oddly knew all of the words and was more than happy to sing along.  After dinner we even danced on the ship-like dance floor.  That doesn't happen at most dinner spots nowadays.  

I came here on a surprise date night with my husband.  Fortunately, I had a reservation.  Otherwise there would have been a line.  Or perhaps the line was for the bar?  In any case, my husband's excitement was matched only by my own.  The combination of over the top kitsch (including fake rain storms, palm trees, and aforementioned boat-like dance floor) with tasty fruit salad garnished bowls of alcohol makes the Tonga room an instant favorite.  We can't wait to go back and to bring our out of town guests to the Tonga room.  Especially the next time my Grandma comes to visit.

As for the food, it wasn't great.  I don't care.  FIVE STARS.  The food wasn't amazing, but it wasn't awful, and it was somewhat overpriced.  I am still excited to try their happy hour appetizer buffet. 

Mostly though, I can't wait to go back to the Tonga room for the shear child-like happiness that it brings me to be surrounded by faux Polynesian awesomeness and live barge music with a big bowl of fruity alcohol covered in tiny umbrellas.
author: Nicolette W.

description: We were charged $28.00 for an hour of music pretty bummed if we would of been told they were only playing for an hour we would of def not made the decision to stay.  The food was greasy the drinks ok.  The waitresss was tired.  Don't bother won't be back. ~ please notify your guests prior common courtesy
author: Susie M.

description:
Not your typical tiki lounge. Equipped with an indoor pool, boat&live band inclusive, this place definitely delivers a big city, over-the-top wow factor

Notes: 
1) I was here on a Thursday night for dinner, main observation was that the restaurant seems to cater to older clientele, probably due to its price and location in the Fairmont hotel
2) they charge a cover for nights when the live band plays ~$5

I would have to agree with other reviews on here- decor is a little done and did, brings down the class of the restaurant a lot, busboys/ waiters swoop in and take your dishes away before you are done

That being said though, the waiter for our table was incredibly kind and the food was great.

Recommended: 
(+) Seared Pork Belly Sliders.
Hoisin-papaya glaze, carrot & daikon slaw 
King's Hawaiian sweet rolls 

the King's Hawaiian sweet rolls are exactly what you could get at Safeway, but is lightly toasted and compliments the pork and daikon slaw well.  Interesting on the palate, would definitely order again.

(+) Tonga hot pot.
Perfect curry (not spicy), fresh shrimp, compliments rice well

(+) punch bowl (cocktail).
like a scorpion bowl you would find at a tiki lounge, spiced with ginger.  Goes down easy, enough alcohol to get you buzzed, even between 4 people
author: Patricia K.

description:
Meh. Cool experience, but overall wouldn't do it again. 
My boyfriend and I made reservations for 2 weeks out and when we walked in it was way cool! They had a live band which played in a cabana in the center of the water as it rained! My jaw dropped walking in for sure! The ambiance is definitely amazing!

We ordered the pork buns which were mouth watering. Heck, I would eat those over and over again! Next I ordered the stone valley ranch pork and my boyfriend ordered the mahi mahi. At both $30 a plate you would think you were getting a lot of food but they were so small! Another thing we noticed by looking around us was the drinks were small as well, and for $17 a drink you think you'd be drinking out of a fish bowl! 

The mahi mahi was delicious, like buttery mm delicious! My pork was alright but nothing too fancy. We received our bill and paid over $90 for our food with tip which was a bit steep but we figured we paid for the experience. :)

The band was awesome! Everyone was dancing and having a great time! I just don't think we would be back to pay the price even to stop by for a drink :(
author: Jennifer G.

description:
The Tonga room took over 1.5 months to book for our dinner.   Yes, it's definitely a fun atmosphere and the server was very nice.  The drinks were pretty good and the band played an array of oldies that were sung fairly well.  Having said that, the food was overpriced and did not taste that great.  

The biggest disappointment was  $25 for Mongolian beef that was hard to chew, the crab tacos were terrible IMO and the only bright spot was there blended rice dish.  We will never come back and only did this because we've lived in SF for many years and never tried the place.  

The whole place is kitsch, but, a cool kitsch.  I'd recommend just going for drinks, you may want to skip the food.
author: Jerry H.

description: Overrated and not worth it. There's better "Asian" inspired restaurant outside of this place. (It's San Francisco after all) and waayyyyy cheaper and MORE authentic!!! God's know why this place always fully booked. Tourist trap? MAYBE!
author: Charles S.

description: Tourist trap with mediocre overpriced drinks and it is impossible to hold a conversation when the band is playing due to acoustics. Parking on Nob Hill is outrageous and the Fairmont is no exception. There are so many cool bars in SF- why waste your time here?
author: Boris G.

description: I made reservations a few days prior and only had to wait in line about 5 minutes. Food is good with big portions. Awesome staff and drinks are amazing!
author: Jess V.

description:
Come for the drinks. 

Stay for the environment. 

A lot of fun at the tonga room especially during happy hour. 

Food is meh but a great way to soak up the alcohol from one to many tiki drinks.
author: Danny Y.

description:
I dined here a week ago after attending an event in the hotel. We didn't have reservations but  we were "lucky" they had an opening at the bar (I actually wished they'd turn us away).

Disadvantages of sitting at the bar = bar menu only. There was a limited selection on what to eat and our party of 4 were hungry so we ordered quite a bit of dishes...
Tables were also small so it could not fit all of our dishes and drinks.

Edamame: not salted enough
Bulgogi Lettuce Wraps: fatty beef slices, not enough lettuce
Chicken Wings: good flavor but extremely salty
Tuna Poke with Taro Chips: stale chips, great poke! 
Fried Rice: various grains (brown, red, quinoa?) with spam, tasty and probably one of the better dishes that night
Korean Short Rib Sliders: extremely difficult to eat because the meat was too tough to chew through.

For it being smaller dishes, we still had food leftover. Not sure if it's because everyone was full, or just because we didn't want to eat it... Everything was extremely subpar and especially at that cost, I wish I'd known sooner not to dine here.

Go to the tonga room if you're looking to enjoy a few (mediocre) drinks and entertainment, or place a reservation to get the real dining experience but do not opt for the bar food to satisfy your hunger.
author: Kim N.

description: Anthony Bourdain approved. That's where I first heard of the SF staple and tourist stop. But a bunch of friends suggested we go and try their restaurant. I think we tried to make a reservation a week before and they said they were full. We went early on a Saturday night around 6 and were seated right away. It was actually pretty empty inside. Not sure why they said they weren't taking reservations anymore. There was a line out the door but we think that was for the bar area. The bar area is not very big but great if you just want drinks. Not sure if you have to order food if you get seated in the restaurant. But we actually came for food so it wasn't a problem for us. We started with a pupu platter. I wasn't super hungry so I didn't really try anything on the pupu platter.  I maybe had one chicken wing and it was ok. For my main entrée, I had the steamed Hawaiian walu. It's a white fish with tomatoes, hearts of palm, and shrimp in a coconut lychee broth. The portion size wasn't huge but it filled me up. And the price doesn't seem to match the portion size. But you're paying for the ambiance. For drinks I tried the Singapore Sling and the Zombie. I found the Zombie super strong and it had some passion fruit juice which is delicious. They had some pretty cool drinks include punch bowls with super long straws and drinks served in real pineapples. We stayed for quite awhile and they didn't kick us out when it got pretty busy later in the night. Also the band started playing on the raft in the middle of the "pool" area, probably around 8. I think they played for half hour sets and then took a half hour break and did this for the rest of the night. The band was great and started playing more and more upbeat and popular songs towards the end of the night. People were all singing along and it was just a lot of fun. There's a small dance floor but it got packed later in the night. Overall a good time. Pricey meal with drinks but I'm glad I tried it.
author: Alison W.

description:
Fun! My boyfriend and I stopped in on our weekend vacation in SF and we both loved it here! Great vibes, music isn't too loud, and delicious drinks. 

We shared the Smuggler's Golden Punch Bowl -- really refreshing.

The crowd and music was a bit on the older side, but if you're looking for a mellow Sunday night out - this is the place to go.
author: Christina N.

description:
Very great bar experience!

Jacob the bartender was very attentive and great bartender . It was very busy last night and he was just a happy guy ! Honestly was bummed restaurant was booked but it's okay ! Enjoyed the pu pu platter and Mai tais! 

Great place ! A must do!
author: Cheryl W.

description: We went here with friends for the first time. The ambience was great with the band playing in the indoor pool, but the food was just okay. Not bad, but for the price you pay it was kinda bleh. I've eater better meals and paid a lot less! If I'm going to pay $70 for a meal, it should wow me!
author: Midori H.

description: What is going on with this place? You check in, they tell you there's a 2 hour wait and you see a sea of empty tables and glasses of patrons who have abandoned their drinks waiting for a place to sit down. The only reason I gave them 1 star is because their drinks are good, the bar staff efficient and friendly and the cheesy band rocks.
author: C T.

description: Food is extremely Americanized and mediocre at best and unjustifiably expensive.  They're comparable to PF Chang's, but double the price.  Decor is festive but it's nothing special or extravagant that it leaves me in awe.  Tried it once and I'm good for life.
author: Samantha C.

description: $15 cover charge per person after 9pm if your not a hotel member, food is nothing at all to brag about, it was very overpriced for the quality & quantity amount that you receive , the atmosphere , the band & setup was really nice,  if i were to come back it would just be for drinks & the band, had a good time  -the food.
author: Marceliano J.

description: If you have not been and want to experience something that you can't find just anywhere check this place out.  It is beyond anything you've experienced, especially for a high end hotel on Nob Hill.  It is their 70th anniversary and it doesn't disappoint.  it is a tad tacky to some, but I LOVE it.  Went for a drink last night with a small group around 10pm, they had a cover of $5 per person (they waived it for us since the band was ending soon) because they had a band.  Not too packed, but it was a Sun.  They are known for their exotic Hawaiian/Polynesian drinks and ones that you can share, but they have a full bar.  I have to be honest - all the times I've been here (maybe 5-6) I have never had any food.  Service is friendly and quick.  check out the pictures.  Enjoy!
author: Ali C.

description:
The Tonga Room is like an old friend. My Mom used to come here for her ballroom dancing. It was routine outing. Her escapade! She met a few good men here too, no one to write home about as they all turned out to be !@#$% .

I used to hangout here for their happy hour on Friday's after work. Back in the days, their 1/2 off drinks came with complimentary "high noon" dim sum for free. Yes, free, no charge. Today, they make you pull out extra dollars out of your pocket. Times have change. But hey, you know what they say, "It's a free enterprise!" :p

I must say their drinks here though were sick especially their "Mai Tai." That puppy will send you to the moon a few times if you're not careful. It's a kicker for sure and not a picker upper. Bring a friend with you if you're a lightweight. Their Pina Colada here was "hella" strong too and huge!! I always requested for an extra shot of rum and most of the staff here were always very accommodating.

Speaking of service, a good solid three star. I have to give them credit, they're pretty consistent at it.

The Tonga Room after 7PM is a full functioning romantic dinner for two after happy hour is long gone. It thunders and rains here on occasion (usually every half hour). There is a live band. They play mostly Hawaiian music with their stage being in the middle of the water. I am not sure if they still hit the tunes with "Engelbert Humperdinck." I had to squeezed that in "t'was" my Mom's favorite, and still is!! Though the last time we went, the lead gentleman singer was belching Madonna "Like a Virgin." It was a riot!! It just didn't fit!! LMAO I was petrified afterwards and that song with his voice got stuck in my head for days!!  WTF  LOL

However, may I suggest skipping dinner here if you are a foodie and do yourself a favor and walk down a few blocks to E&O Asia Kitchen.  This place will make your mouth water with their seafood delights such as their Ahi Tuna, Salmon crudo on Himalayan salt block, and their infamous Indonesian Corn Fritters? And remember to stick mostly to seafood here and you will have the time of your life.  

The Tonga Room never goes out of style especially for the tourist in the city who wants to experience a Hawaiian theme with Thunder, Rain and a Polynesian drink called "Mai Tai!"
author: Edwin R.

description:
Booked a table on OpenTable a couple weeks in advance. It fills up fast. I can say pretty certainly that they don't repeat business from the food though. It wasn't bad, but for what you pay it certainly wasn't awesome. The inside of the place and the drinks though.... That is what will catch you and keep you coming back. The place is filled with history. It's a very unique place. Went here with a couple of friends and listened to the band, ate and drank. There was a tropical storm that came through while eating and that was entertaining. The cover band sounded great and played on a little boat floating in the pool at the heart of the Bar. The decor is awesome Polynesian looking with Tiki flair. 

You have to go at least once to experience it for yourself. You'll like it! Friendly people there too!
author: Drew B.

description: Dinner was average,the drinks where decent our server was great. The atmosphere was a bit dated doesn't look like its ever been updated.
author: nancy w.

description:
We discovered the Tonga Room from "The Layover" with Anthony Bourdain. The bar looked like an interesting stop, so while we were visiting the city from out of town we decided stop in. We went on a Sunday night, which was one of the evenings the band was playing. It really added to the atmosphere, & also added a $5 cover per person to the bill. The bar is detailed on all aspects and makes you feel like you're at an outside tiki bar. The middle of the room is a pool with a floating boat stage where the band plays. The drink menu features a variety of strong drinks, lots of rum and tropical flavors with fresh fruit pairings. I ordered the Hurricane, & my partner ordered the Zombie. We both loved our choices (note, I am not normally a rum drinker). The service was good, drinks are pricey but strong, so you're getting your money's worth for that & the atmosphere. The people watching was also fantastic as many older, drunken, adults hit the dance floor as the band plays. 

This place is very unique & worth checking out if you're in town. An experience you won't find anywhere else. 

(They also serve food, mainly what looked like appetizers, but we didn't eat so I cannot speak much to that!)
author: Katelyn A.

description:
This is a fun place to go. 

It's pricy, but an experience you're not likely to forget. With tiki torches everywhere, reminds you of dinner on the beach or something.

Had a blast here while enjoying a few drinks and dinner. Good place to go with friends to let loose and have a good time.
author: Travis Q.

description:
This place is amazing!!! The service was wonderful and the food was awesome! It was our anniversary and they made sure we had the best table in the house and the best service. Although we were running late they kept our table (I just called and gave them a heads up). 

Bash was our server and he gave us VIP service. We are recommending this place to all our family and friends. And will be coming back soon. 

Thanks again for making our night special :)
author: Fiji K.

description:
Make reservations or arrive early to wait in the 'walk ins' line which the staff takes you to the bar area. 
Order one of their bowls, it will not disappoint. S-t-r-o-n-g. One bowl for two ppl is around $22, for four $32. The rice is delicious. 
Fun atomosphere with dark lighting.
The downsides are it gets very busy and parking is hard to find. You can either pay the hotel to do valet, or try and find street parking. St parking only allows you to park for two hours before 8 or 9pm.

Oh, and they do not have fries here. *face palm* :-o
author: Quinn Z.

description:
We are hotel guest... (Love by the way!)
Only came to Tonga for a drink, but we loved the atmosphere& tropical vibe! 
The Mai-tai was amazing& strong! We highly recommend! Great energy& something to check out while in the city!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Hideously run. This could be a fabulous place it goes back to the forties where my mother had her first date this is the third try I have given it the liberal mentality totally ruins the entire place you have to pay $7 to have a drink on top of the price of the drink if you're not staying at the hotel. The last time I was staying at the Fairmont  a
the service was still miserable the drinks are overpriced with no alcohol in them . The people who seat you are rude and snippy. They don't even ask you if you want to pay they just charge it to your room which they ask you the room number when you sit down so that they can charge you that $7 if you are not staying. The atmosphere is beautiful it is a crying shame. It wasn't even busy and it took 15 minutes to get someone to our table I think it was because the person I was with was African American honestly. Said it had happened to him before. Guess it doesn't matter that he was the highest paid running back  with the LA Rams...dumb asses
author: Patti P.

description:
My family and I made an impromptu visit to the Tonga Room...weren't sure we'd be able to get a table without a reservation but took our chances anyway.  Since we really only wanted to sit in the bar, we were in luck and were seated right away!  The space is very Disney-like... I was most surprised when we walked in by how expansive the restaurant is.  I'd been told (warned?) that the food wasn't great but we ordered a few appetizers and an entree anyway.  I thought the food was fine, albiet pricey.  Honestly, for me, it's all about the experience of being there and the tiki drinks!  I had a Mai Tai and a Zombie... both were delicious however I probably liked the Zombie a wee bit more.  Each drink was served in different vintage tiki mugs.  

I definitely want to visit the Tonga Room again... will probably skip the entrees/appetizers and try the dessert, though.
author: Janette M.

description:
My boyfriend brought me here last night for my birthday. Never been but I was so excited because the ambiance was different. When my boyfriend picked up my drink to try it a freaking roach came out of nowhere. We already ordered and had been driving around almost 45 minutes for parking. When my boyfriend spoke to the manager he only took off the drinks from the tab and my boyfriend barely touched his food. He was so polite to not make a scene. The hostess came by and checked on us twice. The manager was never to be seen but when we requested for him again. He ended up taking the most expensive plate a $2 difference. 
To me customer service is about satisfying your customer so they may return. You would think this day and age they would accommodate you. Nope, so we will never go back and I hope that they don't have anymore little friends appear on guests.
author: Maria G.

description:
In the tiki tiki tiki tiki tiki room...

I've been enamored with all things tiki since my early fascination with the castaways on Gilligan's Isle. The fact that the Tonga Room has all this interesting history attached to it (it ain't one of these "newfangled cheapy tiki bars), makes it all the more alluring to me. I *loved* looking at the photos in the hotel's hallway leading up to the lounge. I could have easily spent an hour in those halls, looking at photos, reading old menus (Halloween dinner! Christmas breakfast!) and admiring the souvenirs. 

So, the Tonga Room stirs up my fascination and appreciation for the past *and* tiki bars in one!

I typically avoid sweet drinks (hello, hangover!), but it was an absolute must to order a ridiculous coconut-y rum drink served up in a tiki glass. A must to sip this while looking out over the lagoon (sadly we were too early for the band platform that apparently *moves* up and down the middle of the lagoon... *SWOOON*)

Expensive, yes. Drinks that you know are made with well liquor cost 11 dollars. But they are tiki drinks and most tiki drinks elsewhere are at a similar price, without half the authentic atmosphere. Like... Did I mention the passing tropical storms? Seriously, periodically through the hour, thunder strikes and ain falls into the lagoon. Hello, awesome! I mean, I loved going to the Rain Forest Cafe of all places just to experience the storms, as ridiculous and juvenile as that sounds (hey, I may try to be sophisticated, but the little kid is always looking to come to the surface when kitsch is concerned.)

It always feels like it's a stormy Tahitian midnight in the Tonga Room. This, plus frozen fruity drinks, bamboo, palm and flowers everywhere, well, who needs to book a thousand dollar plane ticket to Polynesia?
author: Joi B.

description: It is a fun little spot to spend an hour or so with nice tonga room themed cocktails.  I visited for a drink but did not get any food.  We were seated by the bar area and it wasn't that crowded so it was a nice feel.  Towards the end of my visit people were starting to get ready for dinner and were waiting by the water.. perhaps the rain show was starting.  If you need a place to kill some time or are craving a mai tai this is the spot.  Nothing too ridiculously special but a good go-to if you are in the area.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Waited 30 minutes for a table. Came in and there were ~20 empty tables.

Got a Gin and Ginger drink....don't  think there was even one shot in the drink.

Overpriced. Not very interesting. Don't fall for the hype. "Bowls" were ~12oz. Really?!
author: Ann B.

description:
Came here for Happy hour and had made a reservation through Yelp, but got here and found out that reservations are only for eating dinner!

So... we had to wait in a long line to get in. As happy hour was coming to an end, we were all wondering if we were going to even get in for happy hour! Finally it was 10 minutes before the end and we got in. We were then told that there isn't any food on the happy hour menu, only a buffet we can get. Since we were here just to drink, we weren't interested in doing the buffet, plus, it just looked like some asian-fusion food that I wasn't interested in. Good thing we didn't opt for the buffet choice, because they took all the food away shortly after happy hour ended! Finally our waiter came and we just got an expensive platter of calamari and a few drinks. The drinks were good, and of course they'd be pricey. 

The ambiance was very romantic and unique. I really like how they transformed this old indoor pool which gets high marks from me since it's unique. Although it does king of remind me of Rainforest Cafe with the rain sounds. But this place is even better since there is real "rain" and lightning! It's pretty cool that it's inside a nice hotel, so you attract crowds of all different kinds and age groups. You have people who can sit and have a nice dinner and those who can go in for happy hour or go to the bar and grab some drinks to hangout. Next time I think I'll just head in to the bar and stand around to talk and drink with some friends.
author: Katherine L.

description: Meh...we arrived unfortunately at 5:30...1/2 hr too late when they opened. Standing room only in bar, place packed with Oracle millennials...somebody had pre-booked a bunch of HH seats...we didn't even try the HH food...but had one drink and off we went... oh well...we tried it...
author: Jan M.

description:
Update: For Saturday night, 7/29/17

We thought that we'd return to the Tonga Room and see if our review below was still on target and are afraid that it is.
