The dance floor is still crowded with the majority of people (over 90% by our estimate) who simply stand with drinks in hand and not dancing; and many appeared to be annoyed at us and others for actually dancing.

The good news is that, at least on this night, there wasn't as much of the frat boy mentality.  To be sure there was with most 20-somethings doing that, but not as many as our last visit.

We and several other couples whom we met who want to dance are sad to feel that we won't be returning; we wish that the Tonga Room was as much of a dance venue as it was 3+ years ago.

\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\
(Please note, the 1-star is only for the Tonga Room as a place for dancing)

We've been coming to the Tonga Room for years and after this past weekend's and other recent visits, I'm sad to say, in terms of a dancing spot, it's now awful.

Why?  The dance floor is packed with people (mostly 20-somethings) who simply stand and drink and many who glare at people who want to dance.  They're either clueless or don't care that the dance floor is for dancing.  The place to stand and drink is in the bar, not the dance floor.

Furthermore, what I find incredibly rude, is that many people who just stand on the dance floor treat the area like a frat party without respecting those around them.  People, you're not entitled to spill drinks on others, get so intoxicated you crash into people, and take up more space than you need when the floor is full of other people.  

Unfortunately, the above behavior has become the norm, at least from what we've experienced over the past year.
author: Bill N.

description:
My rating is solely based off the service I experienced at this place. Drinks were good, atmosphere was great. But wow... I have never had worse service anywhere ever. They scammed us out of $70. Kept us waiting for the bill for far too long. And were all around rude. 

DON'T GO HERE!!
author: Syd L.

description: This is definitely a tiki bar tourist trap. It was a lot of fun to come see the novelty that is the Tonga Room while visiting town, but not sure if I would pay to eat here very often. The food was mostly good but I thought the prices were a little high. Probably the best part was the punch bowls that can be ordered for 2 or 4. I would probably want to come back for the strong drinks and the cheesy, but fun atmosphere. The bar also seemed to have a good looking menu that I might want to try in the future. We came on a Wednesday night and were seated immediately. The bar seemed to be completely packed however. I would definitely recommend every tourist coming to town make this a stop on their trip.
author: Jessica R.

description:
All two stars are for the kitschy tropical ambiance, reminiscent of a Club Med vacation, complete with a pool in the middle of the dining room, where the cha-cha band floats around on a raft singing feel-good 80s tunes, made possible by the $7 cover charge. 

Besides that, the Tonga Room was a downer. The tiki drinks are obviously made with cheap booze, because the $12 Pipeline (a concoction of dark rum, coconut and orange juices) was so foul we had to send it back. The Scorpion Bowl might be the best deal, though it's literally like drinking tropical-flavored gasoline with a long straw. Don't light a match!

I get it, drinks are expensive these days. But, $24 dollars for a measly bowl of "Thai Basil Curry", with a tiny puddle of so-called curry at the bottom, and the vegetables thrown on top? Good Lord! I've had better meals from the frozen aisle at Trader Joe's. Sorely disappointing. 

On top of the sad drinks & food, our waiter rushed us the entire night, swooping up our plates as soon as we finished our last bite. It was not the sort of relaxing island atmosphere you'd hope to find. 

Even if someone else was footing the bill, I wouldn't be too excited to come back. Fairmont Hotel, you can do better than this!
author: Nique F.

description:
We're rating this as a 2 based more on the disappointing experience we had than the drinks or atmosphere.  

Heard from a friend that it was a must hit spot in SD, and after reading about the happy hour, planned our day around that on Friday night.  We arrived there at 4:50 and there was a line around the corner and down the hallway.  Little did we know, but in order to get the happy hour snacks, you need to have a table.  We were the first couple in line that did not get a table.  We were told we could go to the bar for standing room with drinks only, or wait for a table.  We decided to wait, but unfortunately couldn't bring a drink out to the hallway. 
We finally got seated after about 50 minutes and ordered drinks.  The buffet was very disappointing and confined the following foods: cold, unsalted edamame, semi-fried rice, noodle stir-fry, bbq wings and tasteless mini egg rolls.  There was on food station that never got refilled while we were there. 

While we got up to go to the buffet, our table got cleared and another person was sitting at it when we returned?!?  We had ordered a second round of drinks and the server wasn't very apologetic.  

The place was cool because it's been that way since the late 40s and I think that if we had gotten seated right away, we wouldn't be so disappointed.  Either get there right away for happy hour or make a reservation and eat dinner.
author: Danielle D.

description:
The Rib.

There's only one way to get to the Tonga Room if you live here, and that's by Cable Car. No sense half-assing the experience, and you'll have the default high-point of the evening. 

We waited on line to get in, for about an hour, the majority of that was at the literal front, there was a wedding, and those people were given priority on seating. Yes, they were on line too, coming up from behind, and had to be sat. Nothing wrong with that, I'll surrender my table for the wedding party every time, but if you show up at the Tonga Room on wedding night, you're either escorted immediately or disappointed with the "Private Event" sign. There's no in between, certainly not in this town. 

This place has coconut shrimp written all over it. Don't even need to see the menu, nor will I when the waiter eventually comes by. 

Live music and a table for four, couldn't have been any better.  A Scorpion bowl with family seating so backwash be damned, with a poopoo platter to wash it down. The vast majority of everything on that platter is available in the Safeway frozen food isle, but just the majority, not entirely. 

The Rib. 

It was so delicious I felt guilty eating the second. And not because I was slobbering myself while half my party is vegan, but because I had not accomplishing anything in the last 90 days worthy of my deserving that second rib, short of eating the first one. 

Live music with sounds and songs that yanked you out of your seat and plopped you on the dance floor with weather patterns more predictable than a California drought.

Four stars if they had the coconut shrimp. 

Take the Cable Car. Kiss the Bride. Get the Rib. Don't steal the bowl either, they're on to that.
author: Mark C.

description: Tonga room is one of the first Tiki bars in the U.S. And it's a trip to visit. Real tiki decor, a pool in the middle and entertainment acts on a boat in the middle. It sometimes "rains" inside. A real experience. The food, what I had at least,  is probably better than it needs to be. That said, it's not great and you pay extra for the atmosphere. Not a bad place...particularly as an escape. But not a real recommend either...
author: Eli L.

description:
I think the Tonga Room is a great place to go on a date, with friends, family, whatever. There are going to be haters out there with just about anything. The Tonga Room is no different, best thing you can do is completely tune them out. If the idea of a tiki bar appeals to you in any sense, heard things about the Tonga Room and thought it sounded fun and interesting, are into things that are different, blast from the past? Then go and check it out for yourself! I think most should experience this place at least once if you live in the area. It really is a shame not to. The place has operated since 1949. Can you imagine all the people that have passed through it's doors. 

Cut loose, drink some tropical sweet boozy drinks, laugh, let your eyes wonder around the space and in between all the different areas. Go for a fun time and you'll be sure to have it. If you're not a stick in the mud it should make you feel a little like a little kid again. 

The food is pretty good, maybe a little overpriced. But still very good. Standouts for us were the ribs. Holy melting-fall-of-the-bone. We got seconds. We tried several drinks. I was impressed with the margarita and several other drinks. Do yourself a favor and regardless if its 2 or 4 people. Get yourself a bowl for 4 people. It's just too fun not to, the drinks are good, and for roughly $32, think of how many of your small $10 cocktails need to go into this very large porcelain bowl to fill it. Yes, its a deal and a steal. 

Waitress was incredibly sweet and helpful, also over worked. She had far too many tables to take care of on her own, yet she was still completely attentive whenever possible, funny, nice. 5 stars just for her. 

**BE WARNED** if you are just all about the newest spots, with the most unique obscure food, $15 muddled cocktails that take a pretentious bartender 15 minuets to make. How popular a place is, blah blah blah, then don't go here. Don't get me wrong, I love those places for what they are, plenty. But they aren't the bases of comparison nor my standard of what a place should be. 

Look up some history on the Tonga Room, relax, let yourself have some fun, make a reservation for a table or get there EARLY (like just as they open doors) on the weekend if you don't have a rez and kick back for some fun and laughter. I promise. Can't wait to return myself :)
author: Christopher F.

description: I really like the Tiki decoration, I found the pool inside very stunning. I found it pretty awesome. The cocktails price are very similar to other places I have been.
author: Natalia M.

description:
The best of the best! 

I took my girlfriend here for our 6 year anniversary and we had the best experience ever. We sat by a river with musicians in a boat who sang while we ate/drank. The entertainment was excellent but our waiter was top notch. He did not rush us at all what so ever and was the friendliest throughout our time there. 

I do have to say one negative thing; the food isn't so great but the drinks over powered that. I would recommend appetizers and drinks here, not a meal. The funny thing is they call it a Tonga room but if I recall correctly Tongans/ Polynesians love to eat and the food was a little on the "minimal" side. But like I said the drinks are outstanding. I would recommend the piña colada and Hurricane. All in all a wonderful time and great experience!
author: Jerry W.

description:
I was overwhelmed to check this place out, but it turned out to be just fine. 
There is wait line if you want to get a table (and you might be seated in the area where you can't really see the band if that matters to you), and there is a $10 cover for non hotel residents (which is probably paying the band). The band members are amazing and they interact with guests, you will get a feeling of a welcoming and chill tropical resort. 
The host and the servers are very nice and thoughtful, and you will be taken good care of. If you are planning to step out of the room, make sure to get a stamp on your wrist, otherwise they will make you wait for a host to be back. 
It's a family friendly restaurant, so there are kids here and there. Some people are dressed up for a night out, some people are day time tourists. All in all, it's good balance. 
If you want to check this place and just get a drink and see the rain and thunder (I was not impressed at all), I suggest skipping the line and going straight to the bar. There is a big standing area or dance floor if you want to practice your hula moves, and you will get a really good vibes on the band and the little pond.
author: Katie K.

description: It was raining and what better way to lift our spirits then to get away at the Tonga Room? When we arrived, there was a line to get in however if you pay an extra $10 fee per person you can bypass the line and get a table. Zipped to paradise the whole experience is unreal especially with the band on the boat in the pool in the middle of the room. It was a blast! And the night we went there was a guy who stripped down to his skivvies and jumped in to the pool.
author: Teresa T.

description:
I love Tiki bars. The cool atmosphere, tiki drinks, Polynesian food is just too unique and always transports me to somewhere tropcial. 

Nestled within the historic Fairmont Hotel, this is one of the few Tiki bars in California. Decorated with sculptures, bamboo accents, and even a cerulean blue lagoon in the middle of space makes this one awesome place. 

We came here on a Friday for their happy hour. Cheaper drinks, and they also had a buffet for $9.50 that included edamame, macaroni salad, chow mein, a coconut spam and bacon fried rice, as well as hot and honey wings. The fried rice was so good! A hint of coconut, a blend of jasmine and red rice, and the spam just made the whole dish even better. 

For drinks, we got the Scorpion-comes in a bowl with cute umbrellas and pineapple as a garnish, and the Lava Bowl-rum mixed with fruit juices. They gave us extra long straws to savour these concoctions which made it extra fun.

We were also able to catch some of the live music that took place later on. It was very cool-the stage moved into the middle of the lagoon, a full band and a singer with a soothing voice singing classic jazz tunes. 

Good times.
author: Vincci L.

description: Nightmares ever!!!! Poor service. The manager was useless!!!! Never again :( The live music was just ok but not worth to get charged 7$ per person.
author: Mai M.

description:
First time and last time for me at the Tonga...

I'll start with the good.  The food was good.  Small portion, but very flavorful.  

Now, place is way overpriced.  We went on a Saturday for dinner and they charge $7 per person since they have a band.  They call it a cover charge, even if you are paying their full prices for food and drinks.

Service was very slow.  We practically had to flag someone down to place an order, ask for waters (and refills), and get our check.  Just expected so much more for these prices.  Have more to say, but don't feel like piling on.
author: Saleem T.

description:
It maybe be a hot mess of a show, but it's SF's hot mess and one of a kind. 

Drunk white girl dancing, premixed "tiki" drinks, a line to get in when there are tons of empty tables and ok live music. If you need to go to experience the tonga room do it once but never go twice.  Don't expect anything but a waste of $50.
author: Aaron H.

description: I have a better experience this time after I made a reservation for a month ahead and I don't see that rude host this time. The food is okay, it's a great place to check out.
author: Cory J.

description:
One of a kind... The cocktails were great and STRONG.

I don't know if I'd want to eat there, but I'd def go back for the drinks.
author: Sasha B.

description:
Really cool place great atmosphere. Food was gross. Drinks ok.....
DISAPPOINTED i really wanted to like this place but i did not.
author: Leo r.

description:
I'm an islander in the states.... Forever missing that island vibe so you can only imagine I fell in love with this place! There's really nothing like it! The show on the water with the love music was just incredible! 

The food is great but it's VERY expensive all around. There was a $7 cover charge for non hotel guests, $35 valet parking fee....and anywhere from $25-$45 a plate. It's family size but portions are SMALL! Family size feeds about 2-3 adults. 

The fishbowl drink for two was TINY and was $20! Definitely worth buying the bowl for 4.... All around awesome restaurant with great entertainment, I LOVED it
author: Jocelyn S.

description:
An enchanted evening! I made reservations several months in advance. This isn't a necessity, but it is if you want to get a table pool side. We arrived 20 mins early and were graciously escorted to wait in the bar and have a drink until our reservation got closer. No problem! I enjoyed that the bar isn't a free for all. The host makes sure there is room for you at the bar before escorting you. Some may see this as too organized, but I loved it. 

An entire menu of rums! Delightful. I went with the Mt Gay rum... The obvious choice for my pina colada. Once we were seated, we ordered the Lava Bowl for two. Very strong, and very delicious. Comes with two obnoxiously long straws for you to sip from. The "hurricane" storms come every 20 mins, and adds to the spectacular 1970s aloha spirit of the place. Rain falls from the ceiling while thunder claps! Don't worry, you'll be protected by the 'authentic' thatched roof. 

We ordered the Ohana meal- $56 per person. I highly recommend this because of the variety of food you get. Three different appetizers to try, three entrees, dessert, and coffee/tea. All the food was good- I especially appreciate the three dipping sauces each person gets for the appetizers. Hot mustard was... Hot! But oh so tasty on the egg roll! Prawns were perfectly cooked, and mahi mahi had a nice macadamia nut dressing with plantains on the side. 

This is not an experience to be missed! The live band starts at 8pm. Make your reservations now.
author: Nicole W.

description:
Oh what a let down Mr. Anthony Bourdain was. The first time I took his recommendation and I've never been so disappointed. Tonga room seem to attract many people for the indoor rain and thunder show, but believe me it's not as magical as shown on TV or as you've been told. 
I really didn't care much for the cocktails because they were all on the sweet side. The food was priced at premium but it was nothing special. If you're in the heart of San Fran, tango room is the not place to satisfy your taste buds. We tried the scallops and the bulgogi and they were both pretty flat/monotone in flavor. The coconut tuna poke was alright with the taro chips but it can actually do without the coconut, I think it was just a little sorry addition. 

The worst part of all was the service. We waited 20 mins in line to get in for just cocktails. In a split second, we figured it's worth it to get a table for food after the long wait. The door staff gave us the hardest time even suggesting that we go back to the end of the line when we asked for a table. Long story short, they give us a table but now we experience such poor table service. We ask for water, didn't show until 15 mins or so later. Server dropped a fork, promised to get a new one but didn't show for another 15 mins. We remind the server and she gives us a funny look, no apology, just said "okay" and moved on.

I promise you, this place is just not worth your time and money. Never again.
author: Elle L.

description:
Pros:
- DRINKS: Amazing alcoholic beverages! I took my beautiful girlfriend here for date night and we were feeling pretty good after 2 Zombies, 1 Mai Tai, and 1 Hurricane! Average price per drinks ~$15.00.
- FOOD: Amazing food! I order the mouth watering Tri Tip (best I've ever tried) with a side of season potatoes, fresh salad, and rice. My girlfriend ordered the delicious Mahi Mahi with a fresh salad and rice! Oh we also ordered some good calamari with 3 sauces. Great food at an average price per plate at ~$30.00.
-MUSIC: Great romantic and party upbeat music played by the band floating around on a boat inside the pool converted pond! Yes! This is a hurricane bar and it does feel like you're in the tropics! 
-AMBIANCE: About every 15 minutes the ceiling lights start to flicker, the sounds of a storm start to play, and you start seeing rain drops from the ceiling and into the pool. They sure create a romantic atmosphere!
-DATES AND GROUPS: Great place for a romantic date OR you can lounge off and get tipsy with a group of friends! 
-DANCE: They have a small dance floor overlooking the band and pond!
-BAR: They have a nice bar to get more drinks if you are tired of seating and eating!

Cons:
-POPULAR- not a bad thing but if you plan on grabbing a table best of luck! Expect to stand in line. Please do yourself a favor and book a reservation! I don't think you need a reservation if you're only going to visit the bar. 
-EXPENSIVE: If you eat and drink here expect to drop some money. In total our evening costs with drinks, appetizers, and dishes came up to $160.00. But Well WORTH IT!
-RESTROOMS: This is part of the Fairmont Hotel but there are no restrooms inside this establishment. Didn't bother me but just an fyi... restrooms by hotel lobby.
-PARKING: Took me almost 20 minutes to look for street parking. You can also pay for parking at the available expensive lots around the hotel or at the hotel itself. Yes parking sucks. Expect it all over San Francisco =D
author: Alan M.

description: Cheesy decorations and strong drinks are what makes this place an SF favorite. I was not a big fan of the band, but after drinking a Zombie, they were tolerable. The mahi mahi was delicious!
author: Sonia L.

description:
Kitschy as all heck, but if you come here knowing that, you're in for a good time.

I was a mermaid in a past life, so I love anything to do with pools. I love that Tonga has a giant poll in the middle of the room and you can dance next to it and watch bands play on a platform in the middle of it. I love the fake rain that comes down intermittently. It's all so deliciously aquatic.

A bunch of friends and I came here on a Friday night to unwind. It was insanely crowded due to some party/live band thing, but we managed to snag some room at one of the standing tables and share a bunch of drinks and food:

Punch Bowl - Like a scorpion bowl, but for 2. Fruity, sweet and STRONG
Lychee Martini - Pretty good, lots of lychee flavor
Zombie - A blend of three rums, citrus, pineapple, passion fruit and bitters. Too bitter for my liking
Tonga Colada - A blend of 3 rums, pineapple juice and coconut cream. Perfect for coconut lovers

Shiitake Egg Rolls - Loved that they included shiitake mushrooms
Coconut Shell Poisson Cru - Tropical fish marinated in lime juice and coconut milk. Tender and surprisingly tasty--this one got devoured fast
Shrimp Siu Mai - Gross. Tasted like warmed over frozen food

The bartender wasn't the friendliest, but on a crazy night like that, I guess I shouldn't have been surprised. The people at the entrance were okay, but rather stuck-up when answering our questions. Bottom line, I would have skipped this place if we had had to pay a cover, but thankfully we didn't, so we ended up having a good time.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Review is for service only - because we couldn't get in - I can't rate anything else!

While in town for a night, we were staying at the Fairmont, in which the Tonga Room is located. I spoke to the concierge ahead of the visit, who informed me that although the restaurant was booked, they keep several tables for hotel guests, so not to worry. When we checked in, I spoke to the concierge in person, and he said the same thing, but suggested I go down and speak to them directly ahead of time. My impression after both those conversations was that we would get a table since we were hoping to eat early and were staying at the hotel. Nope!

The hostess surprised what the concierges had told me, and that they don't hold tables for hotel guests. Okay...weird...so then when I asked how long the table wait would be, she said they don't let you wait for a table, but the bar should be wide open at the time we requested, so to just come back and sit in there. That sounded like a reasonable approach to us.

Until we came back less than an hour later and there was over a 30 minute wait to get into the bar!

Listen - I don't mind having to wait, I know that sometimes good restaurants book up in advance. That is all fine. What I am bothered with was how hard it was to get correct information. Shouldn't the hotel and the restaurant be on the same page? I feel like I wasted a lot of my time trying to figure this out, and won't bother again.
author: Lisa S.

description:
This place gets a good review not for the tiki drinks, or the somewhat cheesy, though fun, tiki atmosphere, but for the great bartenders. You might think all they do is tiki here, but you'll be pleasantly surprised if you ask them to suggest something outside the tiki box. 
Jake was very attentive and made some great drinks, both of his own concoction and twists on standard tiki fare like the "Rye Tai", a Mai Tai-like drink made with Bulleit Rye. So come here and have the obligatory tiki drink, but then do yourself a favor and ask for something you've never tried.
author: Daniel P.

description:
Disclaimer... I'm a Tiki Freak. 

I LOVE LOVE LOVE Tiki Bars! This place is among the most ridiculous I've been to because it has a faux rainshower that rains down into the faux lagoon. If that at all gets you giddy about kitschy polynesian themes, this place is for you. 

Is it the best Tiki bar in San Francisco? Definitely not - it's standard fare as far as tiki drinks go. But this place has fake thunderstorms, and other places don't.
author: Jeremy D.

description:
Was at the Fairmont for another event and decided to drop in for a drink at the Tonga Room w/my GF. It's a SF institution and is decorated like a tiki bar should be but it's really just a tourist trap with overpriced food & drinks. 

We only wanted to share a drink and were not permitted to sit near the pool which we were told was reserved for diners only.  So we had to sit in the bar area near some noisy hipsters but we tried to make the best of it. Ordered the Lava Bowl for 2 which was a strong rum concoction of some sort that came in a bowl w/2 long straws. Service was ok.  Water & the drink was served promptly but they take your credit card to make sure you don't walk out b4 paying. The waitress had to squeeze by our table frequently to serve others so it wasn't hard to find her when we were ready to leave.

Trader Vic's was THE premier tiki bar experience in SF but unfortunately it closed long ago.  The Tonga Room pales in comparison but it's the only high profile tiki bar spot left in the City.  However, if you want a more local & less expensive tiki dive bar experience, you should head out to Sam's on Geary just past  25th Ave where you'll save $ on drinks and are likely to have a much better time.
author: Martin C.

description:
Hilarious and ridiculous. Definitely not a spot I'd frequent, but when it was my BFs first time in SF I knew that Tonga Room was on the must-visit list. This place is too silly and elaborate to not appreciate. 

If you're gonna go tiki, you shouldn't half-ass it. You need to serve drinks that are on fire. You need to serve drinks out of pineapples. You need to have a band that plays bad covers on a "boat" in the middle of a "lake". Said band needs to take occasional breaks that are accented by "thunderstorms". You need to have a grotto-like bar and seating areas made of old ships. Because if you don't do these things, you just need to go home, because Tonga is kicking your ass.

The drinks are at once boozy as all hell and yet fresh and fruity. The bartenders are always incredibly friendly and patient, as I'm sure they have to put up a ridiculous number of tourists acting a fool. The drinks are expensive, but really not THAT bad considering the tourist-trap nature of the venue and the elaborate nature of each selection. 

This place is hilarious. Well worth checking out, if only so that you can enjoy a WTF? experience.
author: Matt E.

description: Went to the Tonga Room to celebrate our daughter's 16th birthday with her friends. I had previously made a reservation for 7:30 knowing that the DJ would start at 8pm and thought it would be perfect; after dinner the girls could dance. Unfortunately this was not to be. At 8pm a live band started. Not only was it now extremely loud and we could not hear each other but the band played Yacht Rock. Now, I had never heard of YR prior to this night and my husband had to explain the genre of music. Not only was the music horrible but totally undancable! He girls did not want to dance at all. On top of that, when the bill came we were charged a $15/person surcharge for the band. My husband demanded that they remove he charge to which the manager said that they posted this charge when we checked in to the restaurant. My husband proceeded to tell the manager that we us come to celebrate our daughter birthday but could not talk due to the loudness of the band and that he would not pay the surcharge for this shitty music and told the manager to go ahead and call the police. She immediately removed the charge. With all that said, the waiter was extremely nice and the food so-so. So instead of paying for the music, we gave that money to the waiter. I live in the city and have been here a few times but have never had such a horrible experience. We'll never go again.
author: Roberta R.

description: Lavish comes to mind when I think of the Fairmont and the Tonga Room. These types of restaurants are typically not where I choose to dine, but it was nice to come out to celebrate a friend's birthday. We started off with a whole bunch of tropical drinks - most of them consisted of pineapple and were surprisingly strong in alcohol content. We also had some very overpriced appetizers which were pretty delicious, and we were lucky enough to catch some live music (live band performing on a boat in the indoor pool). The restaurant itself is utterly charming, but the service can definitely use some improvement. Our waitress had this sassy attitude, which was shockingly unexpected, but pretty amusing :-)
author: Beatriz S.

description:
I took my prom date here years ago - and it was the best part of the whole night. No joke.

The Tonga Room is total kitsch and a place that every San Franciscan needs to experience at least once. Located in the prestigious Fairmont Hotel on Nob Hill, the restaurant is essentially a Trader Vic's tikki bar knock-off. Lots of Polynesian bamboo decor, palm trees, a man-made pond in the middle of the dining room where every hour on the hour there's a tropical thunder/rain storm (for no reason). And in the evening, a cheesy Vegas-style band floats on a raft singing everything from Cher, to Sinatra, to 80s tunes. Seriously - how can you not love that?

Drinks and food here aren't cheap. A Mai Tai or any other rum cocktail on the menu is going to run you $12 or more. But let's face it, you're not coming here because for 5-star cuisine or amazing drinks. You're coming here for a unique SF experience that you and your friends can laugh about later. The Tonga Room delivers that experience in spades.
author: Kevin B.

description: This is a San Francisco must-see. Nowhere else can you drink flaming tiki drinks (or entire booze-filled pineapples, if you please!) and see rain indoors. Oh, and did I mention there's usually a live band playing music while floating on a boat in a pseudo-river?
author: Sarah D.

description:
My husband and I have wanted to come here for a few years now (yes, after seeing it on Bourdain's show). We travel to the city quite often but due to schedules and other events we were never able to dine here. 

It was well worth the wait, food is decent but the atmosphere is what you come for anyway. We had out daughter with us (6 years old) and made a reservation a couple weeks in advance. We were about 45 minutes early but our pool-side table was ready. Of course my kid loved the rain shower and the band floating in the pool. It is a bit noisy so don't expect to have a deep, meaningful conversation while here, but it is perfect when you have a kid with you... I didn't have to keep kicking her under the table to remind her to use her "inside voice".

I had the mahi mahi which was great, my husband ordered a curry bowl and was please with it but had wished he chose another dish instead. My daughter loved her chicken dish and still talks about it over a month later. 

We will be back again for another fun dining experience!
author: Melissa B.

description: This was my last place is just for the vie of the restaurant. The dinner menu doesn't start till 6 pm and it opens at 5 pm for happy hour. Appetizers were so small for the price. Other than that the place was really nice and I enjoyed it.
author: Nancy G.

description: Customer service is AWFUL!! I called to make a reservation with a lady and she was so rude and disrespectful. She apparently was the lady in charge of reservations. My friends and I called before we got there asking if we could make a reservation and she said we couldn't because it was full. And then we asked her how long the wait was and she said she didn't know.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Had a group dinner for business.  Service was great, cool atmosphere with the boat, pond and storms.  Menu was great but the food was just mediocre.  Disappointing but it could be so much more, instead it was really simply mediocre Asian.

Best things are the drinks, which were nice and strong and tasty.  That said, at about $15/cocktail, not exactly cost effective.
author: Lloyd M.

description: So much rich history and lots of fun! Great food, amazing drinks and super cool atmosphere! Great date place!
author: Ryan K.

description: This was the campiest Polynesian restaurant I have ever been to. The Chinese buffet for happy hour was terrible and the mai tais were too sweet. I can't WAIT to go back! It was so much fun I cant begin to describe it
author: Tricia R.

description:
Los Angeles has a tiki bar.  It is in Los Feliz, it is the size of a walk in closet and filled with rusty license plates of decades gone by along with a thick cloud of cigarette smoke thanks to some weird loophole in the California smoking ban.  San Francisco also has a tiki bar.  It is located underneath the 5 star Fairmont hotel.  It serves Asian fusion food.  It rains indoors.

This place is truly unbelievable.  For many reasons.  Let's discuss them.

First off it is located under the Fairmont hotel.  This hotel is 5 star, gorgeous, filled with ornate furnishings and illustrious history.  And it has a freaking tiki bar underneath all this splendor.  How did this happen?  Decades ago the room that is now Tonga Room and Hurricane Bar was an indoor swimming pool for the guests of the hotel.  Think 1920's era.  From here the swimming pool morphed into Tonga Room.  But the swimming pool is still there.  In the middle of the restaurant.  With a mini floating barge thing that hosts live tropical bands.  Around every 30 minutes or so it begins to thunder, and rain falls from the sky and into the swimming pool which everybody tries frantically to take pictures of.  Not sure how that turns out but whatevs.

The day I went there was a guest walking around wearing a green dinosaur costume...costume?  He was soon sipping a tropical drink out of a carved coconut.  The place may sound sort of trashy but was renovated last year and is gorgeous!  Thick dark wood, lush tropical plants and carved status of Easter Island type people really makes you feel like you are in the South Pacific.  

The cocktail list is filled with tropical drinks and damn are they good!  Most drinks are served with a thick slice of pineapple and maraschino cherry.  They serve the famous stuff like pina colada but also have their own signature tropical drinks like Lava Bowl and Tonga Tart.

Trivia:  the deck (flooring) of the area around the pool is taken directly from the famous ship the S.S. Forrester.  This ship was used in the regular route from San Francisco to the South Seas.  Neat.
author: Heather F.

description:
I forgot how Cheesetastic this place was! In November/early Dec was back in the Bay, my "2nd hometown" and college stomping grounds. Stayed across the street at the Mark Hopkins, but some friends and I decided to see if the fromage factor was still alive and well in this legendary Tiki Bar...

Ladies and gents: it is. It doesn't pretend to be anything it isn't and you know what? Gd bless them for that. There was serious talk of it closing recenty, and that would be a crime against nostalgia. Places that bask in their schtick are few and far between. They are all in, here. Go for Happy Hour or later in the evening for drinks, definitely not a dinner destination IMHO. 

It is kinda crazy that such a schlocky spot is in the Fairmont (kinda fancy, love their main restaurant for breakie:lunch) Bourdain has even blessed it! Just go. At least once. There was an epic lounge lizard band (on the moving boat stage in the pool; yes, you read that correctly) playing by the time we made it here, after a long day and dinner. Sat in the back and shared obnoxiously large punchbowls and fruity drinks and enjoyed the "tropical rain showers" which come frequently...just sit back, sip your Girl Drink Drunk libation and enjoy. 

I don't trust people who hate the Tonga Room...And if you aren't familiar with Kids in the Hall "Girl Drink Drunk" You Tube link below: you're welcome (my fellow film buffs will get the TOTAL ripoff of Days of Wine & Roses; but sketch is CLASSIC :))

Yelp 100 Challenge (5 of 100)



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1GW22sAElpE&feature=youtube_gdata_player
author: Christie S.

description: What a great place. Live music and fantastic food. I highly recommend the chicken chow mein and the Royal platter. This is perfect for two people to share. I'll be returning, but for my next visit I'll make sure to make reservations.
author: Rose K.

description:
When you go to a nice restaurant with a sweet view, and the steak is $65 but tastes just ok... you aren't paying for the steak. You're paying for that big ass window overlooking the view.   That's kind of how Tonga Room is. 

 As you're thinking to yourself that the $30 or more plate you're eating is on par with the okayest Chinese food restaurant in your podunk hometown, you justify it by the fact that you're not here necessarily for the food, but for the entire over-the-top experience.  And being that you made dinner reservations, you're paying for the luxury of not waiting in the line of poor saps winding out into the nondescript hotel hallways.  I overheard one guy on the phone saying "Yea it's gonna be like 45 more minutes..."  as I whisked past him to my table. That's worth at least $15 right there. 

The complete Tiki/Polynesian/Quasi-Hawaiian decor disguising what used to be the hotel swimming pool- That's worth about $7.00

And the band on the little boat in the pool playing non-stop covers of all the hits I never thought I'd want to hear from; Sugar Ray to the BeeGees.  That's $5.50 easy. 

The fun, flavorful drinks came in fun containers such as:  coconuts, tiki heads, bamboo shaped glasses, giant blue bowls with extra long straws. Gotta be somewhere around $3.00 worth here. 

So top it all off with a mediocre dinner and you've got a solid fancy night on the town you can brag about to the schmucks back home. 

The people watching was pretty priceless tho. 
#weirdbangsstaredown #bachelorettepartydrinkreturn #bandagehands
author: Kirk S.

description:
Horrendous experience in a beautiful fun setting. First off they charge people $7 to have the opportunity to give them business. If you have a drink they will add that $7 on if you are not staying in the Fairmont Hotel.
We were hotel guests yet we still had the worst service the only time they gave us any is when we walked out because we couldn't get our check and they were right there then! We assumed she was charging it to our room. The happy hour is the worst they load the glasses to the top with ice.
The ambiance is that of the Tiki Room rain falls down from the ceiling around the pool great decor but for the money you will be irritated at the staff and the amount of alcohol. If you want to go in when its not happy hour and order the hurricane it is fabulous that is if you can ever get someone to your table
author: Patti P.

description: Good place for drinks, food ok (but hard to tell when your half drunk). Music was good, but cover charge is silly. Should be free.
author: Al Q.

description:
On a dark and stormless night, we slogged up absurdly steep hills until we came upon a secret hotel. We paid a toll* and did a dance for the gatekeeper, whereupon he reluctantly admitted us into a hidden grotto lined with tiki huts, a pirate ship moored in the middle. We offered up many monies, and the natives brought us pineapples full of liquor that could only be consumed swiftly with the traditional two-foot straws provided. There was much rum, music and merriment. 

When we awoke the following morning, we couldn't help but wonder if we'd dreamt the events of the night before.
_____________

*Required on Sundays, Wednesdays and Thursdays I believe.
author: Peter D.

description:
The Tonga Room is an interesting space.  I appreciate that they did something different and really like the band playing on a boat in the middle of the room.  I didn't try any of their house cocktails or food - just bottled beer - so I can't comment on that.  The staff were professional and attentive.  I'm giving it 3 stars because of 3 things:

1) The place is dusty.  There are dust trails on the ceiling next to the vents.  Clean the place for god sake!  There is dust on the fake stones and dirt - real dirt on the fake dirt basically.

2) The lead singer of the band is awful.  You couldn't hear him.  Either there was some sort of technical difficulty or he just doesn't know how to project and sing.

3) The chairs and tables don't match the design, look, and feel of the place.  So there's little cohesion in the design beyond the central pond and surrounding fence.

I will say I do appreciate the rain that falls from the ceiling into the pond.  The fake lightning is comical.

We went on a Saturday night and while it wasn't packed, it was a little busy.  The crowd is primarily made up of 50+ white people with a sprinkling of 30 somethings.  Some women really get into the "Tonga" and dress like they're in Fiji or Hawaii.  Watching the old people dance is hilarious.  They look like they're having strokes.  People watching here is priceless.  The vacationers get drunk and just make a fool of themselves on the small dance floor.

With all that said, I'd personally not return unless friends wanted to go.  It's just not my style.  It's not my scene.
author: Shaun W.

description: Came for the so called happy hour. In a word, sucked. 15.00 for the buffet. For what... crappy wings, costco spring rolls, fried rice, chow mein, mixed fruit. Disappointing
author: fred h.

description: Your bill can end up pretty high depending on what you decided to get, but if you want a unique touristy dinner this is one of the spots you should go when ever you visit San Francisco! All of there cocktails are great, but I would recommend to get the 1944 Mai Tai which comes in a coconut cup! I would also recommend to make a reservation if your party is more than 3+ because if you don't get there on time you will end up waiting in line for quite a while! Luckily we got there before the crazy line started and got seated right away! You do have the choice to either wait in line to be seated and enjoy dinner or just walk in and have a couple of drinks at there standing bar! If you do decide to go to the standing bar you will not be seated at any table or be able to try the food! Just drinks and live music is what you will get at the standing bar. That is why I recommend to make a reservation! I would Rate the service a 10/10 because our server did nothing, but put a smile on our faces and will definitely visit again!
author: Daniel R.

description:
In the basement of a really swanky hotel is a tiki bar. 

I know, that's a little odd and really not all that expected. But it's there. Also, you thought I was going to some witty remark in that line, didn't you? Nope, just laying it out there. A really nice tiki bar under a completely juxtaposed hotel. 

What's the appeal? It is the converted basement pool room of yesteryear converted into this Poly Pop wonderland and has been a staple in the tiki culture for decades now. 

First off, know your goal. If it's to snack on a really dirt cheap buffet with a two drink min. then you're going to join the old folks in line, cause this place does get busy. On the flip side, if you're there for heavy libations of pinky up sensation, then this is also you place to be, 

Fair warning, you will get white girl wasted here. I say that with the most sincerest tone in my voice. The drinks are potent and many you don't even realize how powerful they are until 20 minutes later when you swear the tiki god on the mug your drink came in is talking to you about how trippy the fake rain over the pool area is. 

Coconut shrimp were tasty, but again, things get blurry when there's tiki drinks to be had. Why the hell wouldn't you want to embrace the kitschiness of this place? 

You go now! Go!
author: Javier J.

description:
As my kid said: "they went all out here!" But.... what a waste. The live band, which is WAY TOO LOUD doesn't even play Hawaiian or tropical-themed music. I had to put cotton in my ears it was so bad. Best part was when they took a break. The food is just ok and over-priced. Stick to the appetizers. My kid liked the pork dumplings and the salmon lomi lomi satisfied my husband's quest for poke which isn't on the menu. If you're looking for Trader Vics this ain't it. I expected better from the Fairmont.
... I have to add this. Several hours later my son threw up, seems as though he obtained food poisoning from this place. Don't order the pork dumplings or chilled soba noodles.
author: Mary Anne B.

description:
So my bf and I saw Anthony Bourdain's layover in sf and decided we have to try the TONGA ROOM! Overall experience was great! My bf and I have never gone to Tonga room so when we got there we walked right in, straight to the bar. As for the line, I thought they were for dinner reservations! Turns out it was for the open bar and we were supposed to stand in line. LOL. When we got to the bar there were several seats open, i suppose the workers were slow at seating people. The bartenders at the bar didn't speak English that well but they were super nice! 

The drinks were not badly priced, $12 or was it $15 per drink? But they were super strong and tasted fruity delicious! I suggest getting the tembangi ubangi (sp?) for tequila lovers. It gets the job done.  We shared the bowl drink for 2 people for $30 and bought our own drink or 2 after. By the end we had a good buzzed. 

There was a band playing at 8pm. Great interior, enjoyed the fake thunderstorm/rain. 

I don't think i'll be coming back here for awhile, but i will def recommend this place to everybody including locals!
author: Rita K.

description:
I waver on rating and lean to upside because -  where else can a person find a tiki bar from back in the day?  We stayed at the Fairmont so, naturally we stumbled in here.  It is clearly a vintage copy of Trader Vic's.

Live music, dance floor, wierd use of former swimming pool.  On our visit, it was not possible for them to employ enough bartenders.
author: Phil G.

description:
We made our way up the hill through the pouring down rain. We arrived really early, so I took the opportunity to look around the hotel. Its historical charm has been preserved elegantly and thoughtfully. I felt a bit like Alice wandering through out the vast array of halls and stairways. There are so many beautiful things to soak in.

We arrived an hour early from our reservation time. Not only did they seat us right away on a Saturday night, they gave us a prime seat right on the dock.  The atmosphere is intoxicating, with or without a tiki mug in your hand.

I ordered a Mai Tai and a Zombie. Both drinks were a perfect fit for their respective tiki mugs.  The Tonga platter was pretty good but the shaka rice and pork buns were the stars of the night.

The service was surprisingly fast. Every time we ordered something, we couldn't believe how quickly it appeared. The server always checked on us and made sure we had everything we needed.

I had a wonderful birthday here, topped off with the waiter singing softly to me over the flaming volcano dessert. I was so full, I was only able to power through half of it. It was a perfect dessert for me, it wasn't chocolate heavy and had various tastes & textures.

The band played softer music during dinner, I appreciated that. They even played a couple of my favorites ala Sinatra. 

I am so glad I was able to experience this beautiful place. I look forward to returning in the near future.

I have a question. I love the pork buns so much, I want to marry them. Seeing as how the Captain of a ship has the power to perform a marriage ceremony, could the leader of the band serve the Captain's role in the Tonga room? If so, I may just be tempted to grab those pork buns and hop aboard.
author: Jenn N.

description:
This place is awesome! It's like a high school dance with a Polynesian theme; complete with live music and "tacky" decorations. 

I was staying at the Fairmont and so did not have to pay the cover charge, $5. But if you like the tacky aspect it'd be worth it. 

Drinks are pricey but huge sizes, and of course full of booze.
author: Jason S.

description:
I've grown quite fond of tiki bars in the past few years-- I just can't get enough of the tropical decor, fruity (and hang over inducing) drinks and the light hearted feeling I get. The Tonga Room/Hurricane Bar has been on my bookmarked list for quite some time but i've never really had an occasion to check it out yet. For my twenty-sexy after party, we decided to go head over to Hurricane Bar to see what the fuss was about.

Let me just start by saying that Hurricane Bar is clearly the crème de la crème of tiki bars. Where else will you find rain within a bar, a musical stage on a boat that will move back and forth and decor that will make you feel like you're partying in Tahiti. True story-- I posted a picture of me and my besties on Instagram with a caption that read "partying in Tahiti" and people actually believed me. 

I loved that they had a small dance floor for you to show off them moves. The music is not your typical top 40's but a variety of classic goodies DJ'ed in-house on a little boat in the middle of the restaurant that actually moves. 

Did I mention that they have rain and thunder through out the night? Coupled with the tropical drinks, Hurricane Bar makes you feel like you're truly swaying the night away in the midst of a tropical storm. 

Who knew such a gem was within the Fairmont Hotel in the middle of San Francisco. 

**Minus one star since you're not able to make reservations and have to wait in line (even for a party of 12).
author: Tiffany U.

description: We loved the Tonga room atmosphere and food!  What a great place to dine in San Fran. We will be back. Addison Jolley the manager was very professional as well.
author: Jodi J.

description: Just to have a drink! It was great! An a live band, the three was really good! Thank you for that evening!
author: Lynn D.

description:
I won't re-tell you what you already know from the other reviews, but here are a few tips:
1. Get there early to avoid lines. We arrived at about 9 pm and got to walk right into the bar. No bar tabletops available at that point and it still took a while to get drinks at the bar, but we found a little corner on the "boat" to hang out on. 
2. Drinks are strong and sweet. Get your own drink if that sounds overwhelming. We got a bowl for two and it was definitely too much for time we spent there. 
3. Stay through at least one set by the band. They are a great cover band - we heard music from 50s to 80s in the hour we spent there. But during their set breaks you get to enjoy a "rain storm". A little cheesy but fun to experience in a bar setting!
4. Very wide demographic of 21 to 50+. Everyone wants to experience the Tonga Room!
author: Meghan S.

description: San Fransisco has way better places you can spend your money for dinner. The food is mediocre and the band needs practice.
author: Andy A.

description:
Pricy food and drinks, but it's so much fun coming here with girlfriends and dancing to live music.  The rain and storm effects are awesome as well.

I got a small crab salad and a pina colada.  That, plus cover somehow ended up being $60ish dollars.  

But I guess you can't put a price on fun.  And I certainly had fun dancing and singing along to the live band.  I will definitely be back.
author: Jenny L.

description:
The Tonga Room is just awesome. The food is decent and the drinks are GREAT! The main attraction is the polynesian theme and I just love it. It's built around what used to be the pool at the Fairmont Hotel. Complete with a moving boat in the middle that hosts the band. The frequent rain storms, complete with thunder (don't worry, you won't get wet) add to the appeal of the Tonga Room. It's just pure fun.

Special Features:

Good for Groups, Neighborhood Gem, Romantic, Special Occasion, Scenic View, Hot Spot
author: Robert F.

description:
This place is an experience. I have been a couple of times. Reservations are essential. The place just has LOADS of character. The dance floor (and part of the bar area) is the deck of a pirate ship. There is a pool in the middle with a live band floating around on a covered boat. Occasionally there's a "rainstorm" in the pool. Just ... I have no words. This place should be some kind of national treasure. It needs to never go away.

The food is class tiki snacks: pupu platters, teriyaki beef, spring rolls, crab rangoon, etc. There are some fancier/larger dishes, but really your best strategy here is to drink as many tropical drinks as you can, with a steady stream of snacks to keep yourself feeling good.

Everything here is super expensive, because it's in the basement of the Fairmont. If you get a Fairmont President's Club membership (or, better yet, their credit card) they send you $25 gift certificates you can use at Fairmont hotels and the restaurants inside them (such as this one!) - so, go out there and get that drink inside a hollowed-out pineapple that you've always wanted!
author: Walt J.

description:
The Tonga Room is a San Francisco institution. Not only can you get tropical drinks but during happy hour there is an all you can eat buffet to soak up all that tropical boozy goodness. To be honest the decor is great, I mean they have rainstorms and a ships deck for a dance floor and Tiki statues. Plus the band on the float in the pool. Classic. In keeping with the truth the drinks and food are not top notch gourmet, but they're passable.
You will go there because it's been around since the 40's, it's one of the oldest Tiki bars in the city, and it's just awesome.
author: Ned G.

description:
The theme for the Tonga room was cool, I liked the rain water noise and the dark stained wood. The drinks were pricey but you get buzzed off one drink. The age range of the Tonga room was catered more for older white-collared people.

Stiff drinks plus loud and obnoxious corporate people make a unruly environment.
author: Michael L.

description: My husband and I while visiting the bay area decided to visit the Tonga Room for dinner. We could not believe all the people for happy hour. It was packed and a line waiting to get in. We had dinner reservations for 6:00 pm and had to wait approximately 10 minutes before we were seated, even though there was just one couple ahead of us for their dinner hour. They escorted us to a nice table for two next to the water, however, it was shortly thereafter they seated a table of 7 women who were there to party. It didn't take long before they were becoming loud so we asked to be moved.  Our waiter was nice enough to move us to a different table which we were thankful for. As the evening progressed these woman became party animals. So if you are looking for a nice romantic dinner you will be out of luck. However, we were quite surprised by their food. My husband ordered the hot sour soup and Kalua Pork. We have never seen so much pork on a plate and it was delicious. I ordered the tacos and Tonga platter. Both were excellent. Their prices were very reasonable for the amount of food you received. Our waiter Haobo informed us if we stayed pass 8:00 pm there would be an additional cover charge of $10 for each of us once the band started performing even though we were there for dinner. We elected to pass, but we did hear a song or two before we left. They were quite entertaining. If you are young and want a hip place to go this is for you.
author: Pam M.

description:
The good:
 - The Tonga Room's #1 asset is its history. It's a genuine relic of the glory days of the Tiki craze, and singularly unique.
 - The interior decorating is pretty fantastic--a controlled assortment of tiki paraphernalia, with the centerpiece pool that provides a floating stage for live entertainment as well as a simulated thunderstorm every 20 minutes or so. The dance floor is made to look like the best-swabbed ship's deck you've ever seen.
 - The service was adequate, with regular water refills.
 - The food and drinks have substantially improved over recent years, thanks to fierce competition from... just about every other restaurant/bar in the city. Also, there are more vegan/vegetarian options than there used to be (something that, even in SF, you can't count on, and a trend I'd like to see more of!).

The bad:
 - The food and drinks were good, but still not great. Though they are supposedly now using legitimate historical recipes from Don The Beachcomber etc., the cocktails we ordered were still noticeably unbalanced and inconsistent. Absent were the garnishes that you would expect from $16 beverages.
 - The restrooms are inconveniently placed far outside of the restaurant in the hotel halls. They ARE very nice restrooms, but I don't get why they can't do some light remodeling and have some restrooms in/attached to the TR itself.
 - The food is WAY too expensive--and we were only ordering apps from the bar. $13 for four egg rolls? Really? (Also, they were supposed to be spring rolls--$16). The drinks cost a few bucks more than Smuggler's Cove, but are still vastly inferior in taste, appearance, and consistency. The rum menu (which is nothing to write home about, but at least they try) charges more than I've ever seen. I get that they're the Fairmont, and you're really paying for the experience, but...

The ugly:
 - The music. Oh my, the music. Whoever was in charge of the playlist the night we were there should be moved to another part of the hotel, far away from the speakers. You just cannot operate a historic Tiki bar/restaurant without giving thought to the aural experience. Let me be clear--the music wasn't BAD, and I would welcome it at most other bars, but the modern alt/pop/rock sat in stark contrast to the ambience of the Tonga Room. From the moment my friends and I walked in, we looked at each other quizzically, and never really felt relaxed or at ease. I love this place for what it represents, but the music kinda made me want to leave and never come back. And that's a big deal. (We arrived at 5 on a Saturday and left shortly before the live band started; they're probably great, or at least what you would expect. Last time I heard them it was top-40 classics.)

Will I return? Yeah, probably, but only for special occasions, and I will look forward to it with trepidation. This place still has a long way to go to fully regain its former glory. Let's hope it does before they face another closure crisis.
author: C. S.

description: The atmosphere here is great.  The bartenders were helpful.  They offer bowls for two or for four. On the night I visited, the band came on at 8 and the thunder noises occurred every 30 minutes. I will definitely plan to return next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Erin M.

description: Another Tony Bourdain spot that I bookmarked.  I was very excited to try this spot because of the theme.  I am a sucker for tiki decor.  It is located on the lower level of the Fairmont Hotel on Nob Hill.  Pretty swanky. I wasn't expecting a wait, but there was a line to get in and a cover charge.  It was Saturday night, but I would expect that from a club, but not a loungy spot like this.  After about a 30 minute we got in.  We were warned by the host that the drinks were strong, so proceed with caution.  I ordered the pineapple cocktail and the Mister ordered the Mai Tai.  They were good, but we didn't get buzzed off of them, I barely got relaxed from it. If those drinks are strong then either my tolerance has gone up or San Franciscans are lightweights.  We chilled, taking in the ambience when out came the band...on a boat in the small pool area in the middle of the room.  They were cool, they played fun dance songs in the beginning, but as their set went on, they played songs that weren't energizing and fun to dance to.  There was a small dance floor near the area that was packed in the beginning, but dwindled down when the songs started to get whack. I am glad to have crossed this place off my list.  I am curious to try the other nightlife spots in the area.
author: Rochelle R.

description:
Drinks, dancing and fun people. Plus there is a lagoon with a boat housing a live band. And who doesn't love theatrical sound effects of real rain, thunder and lightning? This is an all around good time. 
Food is just okay. The band and atmosphere make this place 4 stars.
author: Cyndi O.

description:
The Tonga Room is in The Fairmont Hotel. 

First off, I want to say I love the large gingerbread house in the Fairmont Hotel. It's a must see!!

I had the impression Tonga room was going to be amazing food!!!

Why I was not impressed:

-Super long wait/line. You also need to wait in line to even sit at the bar!! 
-When we got seated, we didn't get any menus and our waiter didn't even introduce himself.
-Our waiter was LESS than enthusiastic. If anything, he seemed annoyed and didn't care.
-Service was beyond slow. I know there was a big party and big group that day but...they did not impress.
-Our appetizer (calamari) was luke warm instead of hot.

Only thing I like was the rice with the pineapple and the monogolian BBQ beef. Those were decent dishes. However, food and service is overpriced and rated. 

I wouldn't come here again. I don't recommend it.
author: Margaret L.

description: Came in on a Friday night after Tonga was closed for a private event. Lost a star because of the long line at 11pm. The punch bowl was good, with it being very busy it was a good place to check out, but somewhere I'd go to all the time
author: Nimisa P.

description:
I came here for a family members birthday party and I also expected a lot out of this place. I was a bit disappointed; here are the pros and con's

Pros
-place looked nice
-there is a pool in the middle of the restaurant for the band to play
-food and drinks came very quickly

Con's
-food was not good, not very much flavor
-drinks were too strong(some may say its a pro)
-the servers took too long for everything.. I had to wave them down to get our food, our drinks, and our check. They don't really come by to check on us and they only come over when you give major eye contact, we looked for our server for 30 minutes until he came to check on us. 

Also, this is a very nice hotel, but the valet parking was very pricey too, it was $56 for valet. 

I think this restaurant is more for the experience and not the food.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I totally have to agree with Charlie H's review on 11/24

Fairmont San Francisco wins worst service award for 2012!
When you experience this for yourself you will need a strong drink to take your mind off the annoying staff and lack of service.  Head to the Tonga Room and pull up to the bar for the strongest drinks around.  Mai Tai's are fantastic and the vibe although cheesy is sort of fun and so unlike the pretentious lobby and bars near the front lobby of the hotel.  The rain storms over the water get better and better the more you drink.  After 2 Mai Tai's I was looking for a rain jacket.
author: Raymond H.

description: The Tonga room is fun if you want to grab a tiki drink and listen to music. It's theme is a Polynesian village on the water and it's a cool environment to enjoy an evening. Stick to the drinks though as the food is super blah and overpriced. Also be aware of the cover charge, it's kinda lame. $10 a person.
author: Tyler T.

description:
This is one of those places where you come here to be able to say "I've been there!"  Located inside the Fairmont Hotel, you will be able to escape to the tropics without realizing it.  

and that's it.  

We were seated at the bar in the back of the room since we didn't come for dinner.  I believe some nights have cover charges since they have live music. I think we luckily dodged this cover for some reason..

The tropical drinks are watered down and ridiculously expensive.  I don't mind paying for an expensive drink if it ACTUALLY does the trick or something in there is special of some sort.  This was not the case though.  We ordered the punch bowl which was full of ice to the point that we had trouble drinking the watered down juices.  It tasted like a fruit punch.  

Imagine being at Disneyland in a Lilo & Stitch setting in the tropics and a boat with artificial rain pouring down in interval timing.  It was pretty cool at the beginning then it just got old. haha maybe they need to do it more often.  Dance floor deck is spacious enough making it seem like you are partially on the boat.  

Apparently Anthony Bourdain visited this lovely tourist spot :P
author: Kathy D.

description:
I'm not a tiki aficionado, but my girlfriend is. After talking up this place, we finally went for my first visit. While I didn't take part in the tiki drinks (only beer), the interior was definitely cool. 

Two highlights: the frequent rain storms that occur and the nuts that come with your drinks.

If you're in the area, it's worth a quick stop.
author: Jon T.

description:
After watching Anthony Bourdain's 'The Layover,' the boyfriend and I looked at each other and said, "We need to check the Tonga Room out!" 

O H ,  H E L L O  L I N E
So, as said- we decided to check the place out on a Saturday night. Not sure if that was such a good idea, because when we got there- there was a line waiting for us at the entrance. Oh yes, before I forget! There is a cover charge of $7 for Saturdays. Anyways, we waited for about 30 minutes before we were brought to our table. Not too bad for a Saturday night, in my opinion. 

S E R V I C E  T O O  Q U I C K ?
Not even 5 seconds after we plopped our butts onto our chairs, a waiter comes over with his pen and paper and asks, "What did you want to order?" I'm sure all three of us had the same look of, "Wait, what??? We just sat down!!" So, after getting some time to look over the menu- we decided to order the Scorpion Bowl, the Smugglers Golden Punch Bowl, and I ordered a pina colada just cause. 

P O '  U P ,  D R A N K 
The drinks came out a little after 5 minutes, which was quite surprising. Now for the taste test! The Smugglers Golden Punch Bowl was first, and the result? YUCK! Everyone made that oh my goodness, disgusted face. Okay, so let's see if the other bowl is any better. UH, NOPE- noway! I've had many scorpion bowls before, but none as fowl tasting as this one. It hurt my insides to take another sip, so I stopped after two and worked on the Smugglers Bowl. Which, in comparison to the Scorpion Bowl, was much better. I know, I know- what about the pina colada? Well, it wasn't blended. In fact it seemed as if pina colada mix was poured over a cup of ice, no thank you. 

L I V E  B A N D
This made the night more enjoyable, the band was awesome! They performed upbeat-get-your-butt-up-and-dance-whatever-your-age-is oldies and newies (yeah, I just made that up.), which kept everyone in the room very entertained! 

C O N C L U S I O N
Okay, so the drinks SUCKED. But, you don't come to the Tonga Room to get good drinks. You come to the Tonga Room to have a good time! Listen to a live band perform some of your favorite old school songs, or maybe some of your new school faves. Hence the 3 star rating! Oh, and the characters that this places draws in- I love it! There were little old ladies getting down on the dance floor (too cute), and a gentleman who connected several straws to drink out of our Scorpion Bowl, celebrating his 40th birthday (completely awesome)! You have to check the Tonga Room at least once in your life, just to experience it for yourself. :)
author: Heather C.

description:
Celebrated the daughter's 21st birthday  here tonight and it was perfect!

We taxi'd here at 4:30 and there was already a line of quite a few people.  But at 5 pm they pretty much let us all in and we got a great table and loved the ambiance.

Our server was super sweet and fast!  We had a Zombie, a Mai Tai and a piña colada.  The piña colada  was the only one we didn't like.

We also ordered the pupu platter and everything was delicious.  Ribs, chicken wings, egg rolls and a crab wonton.  With three dipping sauces.

Then the server surprised birthday girl with a Monet inspired water lily plate that had a candle with some chocolate covered strawberries and other little sweets.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Awful, food was terrible, we asked for vegeterian pot sticker, waiter brought pork and said that this is a different kind of vegetable. And he insisted that it is a vegetable after me saying no it's not....awful

I will never go there again if that is the last restaurant standing.

Very dirty and disgusting!
author: Uma A.

description:
So over-the-top that it works! Came for a date that was incredibly tacky, but we were expecting that and totally had a great time. The night included: a luau, buffet, roast pig, floating bandstand (that moved across the pool!), and even a fake thunderstorm. At certain points of the night the stage where the luau was held was empty so you could go up there and dance yourself.

The service was friendly and they come and take care of you right away even though it's a buffet.

Drinks were all good: mai tai, chichi (sweet cocont-y), tonga margerita (strong!)

Best part of the buffet: roast pig! Really tender meat.

Not-so-great on the buffet: dim sum items, the stir-fry, the taro eggrolls (I expected a sweet pasty taro filling as you would for, say, taro buns but it was a lot of hard and tasteless veggies. I wasn't sure where the taro was).

Dessert : pretty good little pastries.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Pros:
1. Live Music with band floating on island.
2. Nice atmosphere - tropical theme.
3. Historic.
4. Some food were tasty.

Cons:
1. Fee to listen to live music.
2. Loud (not good for dates).
3. Very pricey food.
4. Some food were salty.

Ohana style dinner:
bbq kona pork ribs - Yummy
egg roll - Yummy
forbidden rice - rich but very good
poisson cru (not poison!) - ok
kalua roast pork platter - ok
chicken dish - meh
coconut dome - meh

If you are bringing a group of people here, I'd recommend avoiding the ohana style dinner.  Sure, you get a lot of food but some of the main entree are mediocre items.  The only good ohana dishes were the ribs, egg roll, and forbidden rice.  If you order those individually and add on some eye catching items, you'll be more satisfied.

*** I liked the band in the middle of the pool.  Gives the place some atmosphere.  Too bad there's cover for the music but I guess everyone needs to make a living somehow.  If only the hotel pays for them so we don't have to foot the bill.
author: Ronald L.

description:
A bit of old San Francisco still exists at the "Tonga Room."  A fun place with great service, great food and drinks.  Get there early if just going for drinks, otherwise make reservations.  we got there at 6:00 and there was already a line. Checked in with the hostess and we we seated promptly.  

We really enjoyed the atmosphere and so did the other folks, especially in the bar.  Treat yourself to a rare part of old San Francisco located in the glorious Faimont hotel.
author: Pat C.

description:
the deco is definitely fun and rare to find in SF (even though you might have seen it a lot in Vegas). The "thunders" and "rains" were a lot of fun. The music is geared towards older crowds ( I am ~30). So you can see a lot of white hairs happily dancing and having great fun. no one under the age of 40 were dancing when i was there.  When the music is up, you can't quite talk anymore, so we left quite early. 

The food is ok, slightly worse than an average Chinese restaurant you can find in every corner, but double the price. The cocktails were great though- i had royal royal in a pineapple.
author: Shirley z.

description:
I remember going here 6 years ago and having a great time. Fun place with a tiki vibe and memorable cocktails. However, I went yesterday, tried to make a reservation ahead of time but it looked like everything was booked solid for 2 weeks. We called and they said its first come first serve at the bar. We arrived around 5:30 and most of the tables were empty but reserved so we couldn't sit, not sure why they don't stagger seatings, I'm sure people (including us) would have been happy to start drinks/dinner at 5:30 or even 5:00. 

Regardless, the biggest issue we had is they said that a table would be available in 30min if we wanted to wait (this would have been fine, we weren't in a rush) but we couldn't wait at the bar, someone from our group had to physically wait out front by themselves. I'd never heard of such an odd policy. We decided to stick around for a couple of drinks at the bar because the place is neat and then go elsewhere for dinner later. I don't recall the food being particularly memorable so this wasn't a big deal for us. 

If you are just want a couple drinks the bar is a neat spot, although there are no chairs and you can't have food or wait for a table. If you're okay with that then its all good, but you should know in advance. If you want dinner make sure you reserve otherwise don't bother. If you are against nonsense rules I'd suggest you take your money somewhere else.
author: Lyle G.

description:
Indulge in the unique cheesiness - that is the Tonga Room and you will leave with a big smile on your face.

Arrive early and be sure to make a reservation - because if not  - you will find yourself waiting patiently in line behind a crowd of suit clad young professionals debating aloud how much to slip the host.

If you're going to go big here, try to refrain from eating too much sugar beforehand - because their drinks - are oozing with the strong bite of dark rum and sugar.  Get ready for both an intense sugar and booze buzz. 

Get ready for LOTS of birthdays! The Tonga room caters to fun feisty groups, many of whom are celebrating birthdays, and the house band in between their energetic sets - will keep the crowd energy going - by getting a poll of just how many birthdays are in the house. There must have been at least 10 when I went this past week. At least.

Get ready to let go. Forget any hang-ups that you might have about pricey fruity drinks, boisterous crowds, and just enjoy the rain show, the kitschy band, the fun decor, and the special-ness that is the Tonga Room.

I'm so glad that I finally had the chance to bask in this historical spot.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: The Tonga Room is always a destination when ever I'm in San Francisco. The ambiance increases my leisure mood for the fond memories of the tropics. Always pleased with the Mai Tai and the shared conversations of my friends. What's that rain; cleanse the air.
author: Robert A.

description: Lesson Learned!  Up from LA to spend a long birthday weekend in SF and we were so excited to have a group of friends help celebrate with us in the Hurricane Bar.  I called a week ahead to inquire about whether reservations were needed for a group and was told that the bar didn't take reservations - that it was first come.  Then I called again two days before the planned get together and was told that it would be best for some of us to get there before opening (by 4:30pm or so) to be able to stake a claim to some space for the group.  All of that was fine.  We got there at 4:15pm and asked at the front desk direction to the restaurant/bar only to be told that it was closed for a private event.  I understand that since they don't take reservations for the bar, that they have no way to notify anyone when they decide to close down to the public - but it's very disappointing.
author: Bill W.

description:
It's like "FernGully" or the "Brady Bunch" Hawaii episode. The band floats out on a raft in the middle of the pond in the center of the restaurant, which has water falling into it. There's a small dance floor and tons of Tiki kitsch.

The food is okay. I had never had baked Alaska, and I can say that I probably never will again. The steamed pork bun was decent, though.

The star of this place is the drinks, which are big, mixed and tasty.

It's not a bad experience, but I could see it being more of a family/kid place or if you just want to be silly.
author: Zenovia E.

description: Believe the hype. Loads of tiki fun, deceptively strong drinks, and an awesome band that floats on water. Scorpion bowls were delicious. Inside the Fairmont hotel so you know it's a clean establishment. Keep in mind that they try and close earlier than a typical bar.
author: Rahul H.

description: This place is a joke. They won't let us move chairs in the bar area. The staff is not friendly or helpful at all ..... Rather they act like police officers.
author: Mel L.

description:
TONGA! TONGA TONGA!  It's as wild and silly as you could imagine.  A throwback to Polenysian places of the past. This place has been around sicne just after WW2, and it shows.  In a good way.  Everything is well kept, but it looks like a blast from the past.  It's a lot of fun!

My stars only cover the 2 Mai Tais my wife and I had - and the ambience of the place.  The drinks were silly fun, although we're a bit partial to Trader Vic's...

But this is a fun stop for at least one drink if you are in SF!
author: Andy R.

description:
Do you ever feel like your heart is floating with happiness? That's how I felt when I visited Tonga Room.

I am a huge lover of tiki bars, and this place is just the most fabulous of any tiki bar I've ever seen. I have a place in my heart for all tiki bars, whether they're kitschy or classy, and this place is definitely more on the classy-tiki side. It had a great energy while we had our small bites from the hot bar and drinks, but what really made this place epic was the awesome cover band that literally floated out on a boat to the middle of the bar's pool. The place erupted with dancing and singing. If I lived here, I'd come her every time I wanted to go out! Almost made me want to move to SF.

It should be noted that the hot bar didn't dazzle me...the chow mein was cold and there wasn't as much variety as I was hoping for, but how picky can you be when the it was an unlimited buffet for $10? Pretty amazing deal, even if the food was a bit on the disappointing side.
