I think when it comes to tiki-themed bars, this place is as good as it gets!
author: Melissa B.

description:
Such a fun concept and a really enjoyable experience! Standing in the lobby of the Fairmont, it's hard to imagine there's a taste of the islands waiting for you downstairs.

I came here for dinner midweek. Drinks were well made and surprisingly strong - I had the Mai Tai and the Island Margarita. The food was also excellent. We started with the papaya salad (could have been a little more papaya-y) and the calamari (fantastic), and I also had the tri tip (rare and cooked exactly as requested - highly recommend). Their desserts were decent, but not the best part of the meal by a long way. Service was about average for what one would expect at a place like The Fairmont.

They had live music from a boat in the middle of the water, mostly Motown classics. Our table was right by the water's edge (OK, the side of the swimming pool, but details, details) so we had a great view of the proceedings. The music could have been a little softer - it pretty much killed our conversation whilst they were playing - but this didn't really detract from the experience. They have a decently-sized dance floor that I was itching to hit up, but it was mostly empty.

Check it out! If conversation is a must for your dinner, stay away from the water. Eat, drink, and be merry, and then walk out into the fog and remember you're not actually in the South Pacific...
author: Seán O.

description: Can only speak for the drinks. The Mai tai (like all drinks) was expensive but had a decent amount of alcohol in it. Add that to the live music and awesome atmosphere and it's totally worth it.
author: Nicole P.

description:
Beware: This is a tourist trap! 
The food is  quite mediocre for the prices you will be paying. 
The live music was nice on a floating boat but if you want to have an intimate conversation or hear your waiter you're out of luck.
Overall it's an experience worth having if you are willing to reach into your wallet.
author: Stephen Z.

description:
A while back, I heard that they were closing the Tonga Room....good thing they didn't! It has pretty much become a SF landmark. I was surprise that even Anthony Bourdain went there while shooting the SF episode of The Layover. You almost don't expect the Tonga Room to be at the Fairmont, but somehow it works. How could you not like the cheesy tiki decor, fake rain and a singing band in a boat in a pool amidst the middle of the venue? It's fun fun fun! 

My advice is go for the ambiance and the island drinks, but skip the food. I've dinned there before and I honestly thought that the food was just so-so and quite expensive for what it was. Great place to grab some fun cocktails and bar bites though!
author: Liv A.

description:
This place is fun. Period. I went with three other people. We sat next to the swimming pool (yes, the pool). My favorite thing about this place was that the staff does not rush you. They want you to stay and enjoy the festivities as long as you'd like. 

And this, while people line up outside to get in (make sure you have reservations)

The food is fine. Not top of the line, but the experience is one-of-a-kind. Really fun, funny. Great people watching. Live band. Dancing. We will take our out-of-town guests here without question.

There is no other place like it and that is what makes it a five star experience.
author: John S.

description:
Fun places attract fun people. The 3 stars here come entirely from the atmosphere. It has NOTHING to do with the food, drinks, or service. 
Expect a line if you're going on a Saturday night. There was a good 25 minute wait when my friend & I showed up. When you enter, the lighting is dim. There is a small dance floor, and the room is divided by a large pool upon which the house band performs on a "boat". Those guys can SANG. I would have paid just to hear them perform those classic hits from the likes of Earth Wind and Fire and Barry White. Service was a problem though. Our server was MIA for nearly an hour. Then, when we finally flagged him down, he seemed annoyed. The drink prices were absurd for the sizes. Also, they were poorly made. We never got around to eating any food, but it looked horrible.
author: Jean Luc P.

description: Just...don't eat. The food is SO SO bad. But, if you're not planning to eat,  the servers are fantastic and the drinks are REALLY strong which is a plus.
author: Candy C.

description:
This is a review of a bartender named William. I had a great time at the tonga room. 

I ordered an Irish coffee when I got there. It was good. However, when I ordered a second drink he informed me that he couldn't serve me more alcohol because of safety. I am confident I could still drive a car legally at this point. No idea why he cut me off. 

We then asked the manager, but the manager wouldn't do anything about it because the bartender (William) scared the manager since he had been working there for so long. 


Bottom line. William ruined what otherwise would have been an excellent night. He needs to be let go.
author: John B.

description: I had their fishbowl drinks and man were they strong. The atmosphere was amazing I did not feel as if I was in San Francisco. The entertainment was awesome and the crowd was nothing short of fun loving.
author: Fernilla S.

description:
Zero Stars! This place was horrible. I have worked in the restaurant industry for 13 years and I couldn't believe how poorly run this place is. Very rude staff, I was in shock. The host was very mean to almost everyone she encountered. We waited for more than 45 minutes only to walk into a mostly empty place. Was told by a waitress with glasses and dark curly hair that we couldn't sit in the corner of the bar at some empty seats while we waited and that we had to move. She was not polite but very rude and acted super irritated. It ends up that later this woman is our waitress. Yay!

We waited more than 10 minutes before she even came to our table. She seemed irritated that we were there and was rude the whole time. It took 20 minutes to deliver our drinks and another 20 minutes just to get the check paid when we wanted to leave. The entire time my party and I felt as though they didn't want us there and we were an inconvenience. We just wanted to finish our 1st and only round and get out of there. It was such a bad experience that the entire hour and 15 minutes we were there that barely any of us talked to each other. We were all so offended and there was no conversation between us. I forgot to mention we were there for a friends birthday and all of us are servers. Will never go back and I will tell everyone I know that The Tonga room is a joke! It reminded me of that restaurant in San Diego called "Dicks" where the wait staff is rude on purpose! But the Joke was on us!

Remember, I work in a restaurant. This gives me professional insight into why things might go wrong. Slow service do to a packed place, cooks messing up food, POS systems going down, etc. That being said I would fire most of the staff. Never in my life have I ever wanted to not tip. I did anyway. Whoever is the manager is screwing over the owner of this place by clearly not caring for the customer. 

Last but not least the place was very dirty! Sticky tables, dust and grime in the corners of all the very old Tiki crap everywhere. The last time they put money into this place looks like decades ago.
author: John T.

description: Had the best time here!!!! Our waiter Roberto was top notch! We just had drinks and appetizers which were really good. The live music was great and environment was fabulous! Roberto had the kitchen make us a dessert for our anniversary and treated us well. We like absolutely return next time we are in San Fran
author: Andrea M.

description: This was so much fun! The decor is amazing. Live band playing were great! Drinks amazing but expensive.
author: Jen M.

description: Super cool place. Reminds me of a dive bar times a million. Can't believe that it exists. Amazing vibe down there and amazing service and drinks and super cool music!!!!
author: Cristian G.

description:
When it rains, it pours! When you visit SF its on that top places to visit list and of course, I have missed it every time until now. This and the Ghiradelli chocolate factory-damn. WELL I was gonna get some sugar one way or another! Giant frozen cocktail in a fruit gourd por favor, and light it on fire would ya? Thanks! Every little while thunder claps and it "rains" inside the dining room. How fun! 

The atmosphere in this place is delightful, but it is pretty tourist trappy. Since I was in a tourist kinda mood, I really liked it. We sidled up to the bar and our bartender, who had been working there over 20 years, presented us with the pictured menu of tropical delights. Mai Tai's in hand, then a volcano drink or two, we defiantly did Tonga right! 

Brad B and I even took a little spin on the dance floor-a silly drunky spin, but jealous? You should be! 

Can't speak to the food-but the atmosphere and drinks were a good ol time. It's $$, like Disneyland pricey. You're payin to play-they make it rain, YOU make it rain....that's how it goes in this tropical paradise!
author: Trish S.

description:
Service: 5 stars
Food: 1 star
Drinks: 0 stars 

I came here when I was younger and since family was visiting from Texas, I thought I'd take them to experience it...

First off- there is an underlying mildew smell in the restaurant and in all of the Fairmont... Not an 'old' smell that denotes history, a moldy smell.

I asked for a piña colada and the server said that ever since they changed management, they don't blend their drinks- they don't even have a blender! The drink didn't even have pineapple in it!! Hello Tonga room!

The food was less than mediocre. I could've gotten The 'Tonga hot pot' ($30) at May Lees Chinese for $7- not exaggerating at all. The pineapple rum cake--- didnt eat more than one bite... My relatives were also unsatisfied...the Hulu hulk chicken was gross, the spare ribs were not sweet Hawaiian style-it was really not ok!  I will not ever be going back :-( 

I would recommend going there for dancing and drinking unblended beverages! NOT food! Either that, or go to Disneyland's Pirate of the Caribbean and call it a day.
author: Heather A.

description: What a cool experience!! When you walk in you are quickly transported from fancy five star hotel to a Hawaiian island! We sat at the bar and enjoyed our hand crafted cocktails while listening to "storm" and watching the "rain". The bartenders were so knowledgeable and helpful in picking out a drink I would enjoy.... As everything on their drink list looks awesome! Our cocktails were delish!!
author: Julie M.

description: Over rated. Went here because I was curious after the mention on the Anthony Bourdain show, but was disappointed. If you're looking for a super crowded bar/restaurant, that overcharges for watered down drinks while a mediocre band plays on a mini floating barge in a kiddy pool; then this place is for you, if not then give it a pass. Will say the hotel it's located in is gorgeous in an historically flamboyant style.
author: Joy G.

description: We went to the Tonga Room for New Year's Eve and recently for my birthday.  I love the band and decor.  Unfortunately, they do not understand food sensitivities/allergies. I have a gluten sensitivity and although I called ahead to be sure they understood my sensitivity and explained it to the waiter, I still had problems with the food they served me and had to send it back. Most restaurants train their staff to have at least some understanding of this problem, but not this restaurant.  I would go for drinks and dancing, but not dinner. If you have no problems with food sensitivities, then I would recommend going there. I did bring this the management's attention and they did say they would try to train their staff better regarding food sensitivities.
author: Elaina D.

description: I'm sure this could be a fun spot after a few umbrella pineapple drinks but if you're staying at the hotel and want a decent meal you might opt for room service.  We had two very unimpressive dishes.  They didn't have the slow roasted pork dish - huh? So I got the beef dish. My friend  ordered the pork tenderloin. Both sub par - over priced Chinese food.   you're paying for ambiance NOT quality food.   Not a culinary experience.
author: Christine R.

description:
OMG loved this place. 

I was in town last weekend and I had some family going to the Tonga Room before dinner for some Mai Tais so I met up with them and I think I was smiling the entire time I was there. It reminded me of Adventureland at Disneyland but with an old 40's feel to it. 

First of all, it's inside the Fairmont Hotel which is just absolutely stunning...next time I want to treat myself (which is like...all the time), I will definitely book a room there. We were there around 4ish I want to say and there were a few other tables of people having drinks, but by the time we left at 6:30, the place was full, including a wedding party hosting their dinner there. 

The pool you see in the center of the restuarant used to be the hotel's indoor pool and was then turned into a restarauant at some point, but the pool remained so there is a "boat" floating in the middle of it and in the evenings the house band plays ON the boat. I was bummed I wasn't there for that, but all the more reason to come back.

I cannot speak for the food since we didn't eat here, but word of mouth is that the food is good, not great.

We had several different kinds of tropical drinks, including some of the tiki bowls and they were all good and STRONG. Our waitor was quick and friendly and not at all agitated that we weren't ordering food.

I think this was one of my favorite parts of this San Francisco trip and will definitely be a staple in future trips to the city.
author: Ashley K.

description: Last call is at 11:30. Which apparently means that last call is 30 minutes earlier and our group isn't allowed to have a waitress.
author: Anthony K.

description:
Listen up Yelpers!!!! A MUST VISIT!!!! 
I had the time of my life ! Food was fab! Service was great! Drinks were to die for and the rain was beautiful and romantic ! Every 15 minutes people!! 
Come give this place a try!
author: Helen G.

description: I can't believe I really never wrote a review about this place since this bar really sparked my Booze and Baseball across America journey when I came to San Francisco to see the Giants and go to the greatest Tiki Bar in the world. Well it did not disappoint. I will admit that Anthony Bourdain sparked my interest into coming here but, I love tiki drinks! What is better than a gigantic ceramic painted bowl of booze, fruit, fire and an umbrella! I did not eat the food but, why would you?? you come here to drink in a basement that looks like a cheesy 60's beach hidden in a nice hotel. You have to get the girl fruity Lava Bowl!! Preferably as a first drink to start your night because it will get you properly sugar buzzed. But, if you need a second then get a Zombie! This will probably end up making you roll down the steep hill you walked to get here but, it is worth it it.
author: Beau S.

description:
Awesome place to hang out, listen to live music and drink!

One second your in downtown SF and next your in Tropical Paradise!

This place is freaking awesome!
author: Michael O.

description:
Love the happy hour.  I wasn't here because of Anthony Bourdain but heard about all the rave.  :)  The food was okay for $10 bucks buffet definitely great service.  Compliments to the Chinese waiter guy who kept taking our dirty plates and was on top of it.  He was also on top of refilling water which was a plus.  Courteous last round calls for drinks, and was patient with us the whole time we kept deciding if we were to have buffet or regular dinner.  He was all part of the great experience we had there.  

Atmosphere was fun and rowdy groups around us but still romantic with dim lights and good Drinks.   :)  Will come back with friends.
author: Juila L.

description:
As good as ever. I was so glad to hear that this place was still open. It is the granddaddy of tiki bars. It has a pool with a boat (on which the band floats), thundershowers, a volcano-type cave for a bar, and a dance floor that looks like a ship's deck. How can it not be awesome?

The music is cheesy. The food looks terrible and expensive. The drinks are pricey. But go early, get a drink with lots of props and fruit chunks (and maybe even a souvenir glass), and enjoy how ridiculous it is.

I've had a number of great nights here. I brought the bf on a recent visit so he could see what I've talked about for a long time.

I was bummed that you can't make reservations unless you're eating dinner. But it's a must-visit to experience a blast from the past.
author: Cherie C.

description: This is definitely near the top of the list of  bars to visit when in San Francisco. It is said that every US President since William Howard Taft has stayed at this hotel. This hotel is the first place Tony Bennett ever sang "I Left My Heart in San Francisco." It has great live music entertainment on weekends. Sit at the bar to avoid the $7 'entertainment surcharge'. The drinks are exotic and delicious. There is a plentiful assortment of appetizers and small plates perfect for sharing. Prices are not unreasonable.
author: William H.

description: Okay so I went here for my Birthday with 4 other people and arrived at 6:30 and got seated (max 10 minutes) however after we entered the line, the line quadrupled and those poor souls were still there when we left at 9:30... So get there early... Or make a reservation. You pay the cover charge with your bill. So don't think you got away with it lol. Dancing was fun! Drinks were strong and delicious! AND WHATEVER YOU DO!!! GET THE FORBIDDEN RICE!!! (I'm still dreaming about it!) Super fun place to celebrate something!
author: Lorelai G.

description:
The food-
3 stars. I wasn't impressed with the Pineapple Fried Rice or Sample platter. Only thing tasty was the shrimp dumplings.

The drinks- 
4 stars. I liked the whiskey sours that I drank but nothing super special.

The ambiance-
3.5 stars. It's kind of like a tiki bar meets pirate ship meets buffet meets fusion sushi bar. It's great for large groups and for after work HH...but it was just okay.

If you want to try a HH spot, I'd say give this place a try but I wouldn't go back.
author: Dana L.

description: Boyfriend and I had a great time here last night. The band was awesome. I thought the food was pretty good.  Definitely a fun place for a special occasion
author: Alison T.

description:
Awesome decor and ambiance. Well, I like cheesy, and it was, in a good way. The food was excellent. We did the sampler platter, which was pork ribs, spring rolls, chicken wings, and crab rangoon, along with an order of BBQ pork buns and their tonga room rice. It was more than we could eat. We will definitely go back. The place is amazing, hard to believe you're inside a hotel in SF.
Only downside is parking is valet and pricey. It was about 15.00 without tip for about 2 hours. They do not validate.
But the good far outweigh the parking, it was worth it.
author: Don M.

description: Awesome place to get bar bites and food. Fun and unique atmosphere with live music. Will come back!
author: Bickie C.

description: Fantastic place !! The ambience is out of this world. Veg options are limited but very tasty. The drinks were spectacular and the band played such lovely traditional music. All in all its 5 starer.
author: Ayushi P.

description:
The food is fine, overpriced but fine and the atmosphere is old fashioned.

But, I had a horrible experience here and I will never return again and advise others not to go. Here's what happened.

A few years ago, I believe in Sept. 2012, I came here for my birthday, reserved a table for dinner and other friends joined afterwards for drinks. The server we had was rude, rushing us and NOT listening to me when I asked politely for requests. He rushed us and treated us like we were stupid, but we were very nice and not rude at all.

The other friends that joined us after dinner, waited for us at the bar and ordered drinks. There were 3 of them. The place was packed and there was a line out the door for people waiting to get in. A few of them didn't have a seat at the bar, they got up and were standing right next to the bar with drinks in hand.

A security guard came by and said they didn't have a seat, so they would have to leave. Mind you, they got in, paid for drinks, literally had drinks in their hands and were told to leave because they didn't literally sit down in seats at the bar.

I had other people coming to the party and I told them not to come, because I didn't want them coming to my birthday party and be kicked out. Totally ruined my birthday party, and after dinner, instead of staying and drinking and dancing, we all left.

I never, ever had this experience where my friends were kicked out for doing nothing but enjoying their drinks at the bar.

Ridiculous, overpriced dinner, drinks, and atmosphere is not worth being treated this way.
author: Elena O.

description: Cool atmosphere and this is where it end. Drinks are nothing special. Very rude personnel with lots of attitude. Very rude. One waitress was even making faces. Unlike other bars when they close you don't kick out people as you see them putting on their jackets. Lose the attitude.
author: Zori P.

description:
Really nice atmosphere, good drinks (they are strong), live music is a good add-on. But service is slow (we walked in without reservation on a Saturday night).

Frequently answered questions:
* You don't need a reservation, but then you will need to wait in line for bar *seating*. Wait time was about 30 mins @ 8pm Saturday. They still serve the full menu if you'd like. Note that bar seating does not necessarily have the best views (but who cares).
* If you don't want to wait and just want to grab drinks, you can go directly to the "standing room" to the right when you enter (but check with the doorman first just in case). I saw people shuttling between bar area and dance floor with drinks, which is fun.
* For restroom, you need to exit the bar and make two rights (poor doorman has to answer this same question over and over)
author: Oral C.

description:
Pretty terrible experience here. 

While the ambiance is cool and the live band was good, the service was horrible. Our server clearly did not want to be there - she seemed to have an annoyed look with every request - from ordering waters to asking for the bill. 

Oh, and with the bill. Since we weren't staying at the hotel, we were asked to put a credit card on hold (a strange practice?). When we requested for our bill, the whole tab was already charged on the credit card. We didn't even get to see the itemized receipt. Also, the server wrote in her own tip on the tip line. I'm not even sure if that's legal. I've never had a server do that before in my life. 

I'm certainly never coming back here again.
author: Sarah G.

description:
I admit I was skeptical about this place. Most of the reviews aren't that good, but I still wanted to try, and  ended up absolutely loving it! I had a great time at Tonga Room. The environment is really cool, the servers were all very friendly, ( a little slow maybe, but nothing that jeopardized our experience), the food was OK, with pretty decent portions and the drinks were great, very strong ( not sure about the reviews complaining about the watery drinks) and on top of that we got a Hurricane Glass! Super cool.!

I found it to be a great spot for a fun date! The band was amazing, playing only classic American songs, so pretty easy to sing and dance along.

I really liked Tonga Room and will definitely be back, but for a girls night this time!!!!
author: Paula C.

description: The food was very good.. The drinks were amazing!! The only thing I didn't like was the music was too loud I couldn't hear myself talk. Used txt messages to communicate with my husband. Lol but other than that good music.
author: Regina G.

description: Three stars because they were open on Christmas night. I ordered the "coconut shell salmon lomi" for $17. It was bland and unflavored. Their Mai Tai for $13 was strong. As soon as you barely smell it, you'll probably get tipsy with one drink. The service was slow (40 minutes to get a server) and it wasn't a busy night. It is suggested that you make reservations, otherwise you will stand in a "make you believe that we're full" line. There were many families and couples dancing to the live band they had on a Wednesday, which made it pretty cool. Besides that, I will have to question the fact that Anthony Bourdain recommended this place on his tv show.
author: Laura C.

description: I went to this place for the second time.  This time I brought my dad with me.  We liked the place especially the 'Rain' show in every 30min.   But the food was not as good as I expected.  And $50 cocktail was very disappointing.  I will visit again but be very careful choosing foods and drinks.
author: Anna H.

description: This hidden gem located in the terrace of The Fairmont Hotel, is a MUST when in SF. From the friendly staff, yummy tropical drinks and food, to the live band in the lagoon with people your parents age dancing the night away. How can this not be fun! We never leave SF without a visit and we've never ordered a bad drink.  Ask for a table by the lagoon and enjoy.
author: Darling N.

description:
We recently stopped in here on a long weekend in San Francisco.  We didn't have reservations but decided to wait since we were unexpectedly in the area and had read about this restaurant on many review boards. 

We waited about half an hour. There was a cover charge at the door (a live band playing, Friday night).  The cover charge was added to our bill.  The menu is a bit limited but maybe a good place to start or end an evening. I don't really suggest it for dinner.  A lot of people filled the dance floor so that is also a way to experience the ambiance if you don't want to stay to dine.  

The food was good, but not remarkable.  We did not indulge in a specialty drink.  Overall I think this is a great place to stop for a specialty cocktail and enjoy the cool surroundings, but it's not worth making it your dinner spot.
author: Sarah M.

description:
The adult version of Rainforest Cafe.

If sugar-loaded tropical drinks served in funky tiki cups are your thing, then you will have a ball at Tonga Room. If not, you will probably still enjoy it for the vibe and cheesy band on the "floating island," if nothing else.

The interior is fun and ornately decorated in a true tiki style. The overall ambiance, live music, fun drinks, and colorful food will quickly make you forget that you're in San Francisco.

Fun for an occasional night out, but overkill as a regular spot. 

P.S. Don't forget your umbrella - there's plenty of indoor "rain" to experience!
author: Mansi A.

description:
This has been on my list for the longest time.  So, when one of my friends said we were partying here on Halloween, I was looking forward to it.

Entrance was ~$30 (on an "almost out" sale).  No costume for me but it was fun watching your typical SF crowd get all out on this night.  

Pricey drinks and appetizer.  Good venue.  I would say more but we came here to be on the dance floor and the DJ that night was disappointing.  Bad mixes and the transitions from one song to another was just awful.  Cut story short, we left after an hour.

I'd still come and give Tonga Room another chance.  One of these days perhaps...
author: Pam S.

description:
I remember coming here _ _ umpteenth years ago as a kid. My family and I had just moved to San Francisco from Chicago. My aunt and uncle wanted to show us quintessential SF. They took us to Fisherman's Wharf where we ate crab, drove down Lombard Street, rode a cable car and crossed the Golden Gate Bridge. 

The Tonga Room with its tiki huts and giant tiki gods is a sharp contrast to the opulent and gilded upstairs lobby of the Fairmont Hotel. I remember the Tonga room because it rained indoors. As a kid, I thought it was an extension of Disneyland and waited for the animatronic birds to come out and sing. No such luck.

Last night, my friends and I decided to play tourist and celebrate a couple of birthdays here. We had a reservation so we walked right past the line at the door. We were seated right next to the "lagoon." 

Instead of birds, the music came from the 4-person band that performed in a boat floating in the lagoon. More enthusiastic than accomplished, they were nevertheless fun entertainment appropriate for the venue. 

Appetizers:
$13 Shiitake Egg Rolls: 4 pcs. (shiitake flavor too strong, my least fave)
shiitake mushrooms, carrots, onions, cabbage & Tonga sauce

$16 Seared Pork Belly Sliders: 3 pcs. (my fave)
Hoisin-papaya glaze, carrot & daikon slaw, King's Hawaiian sweet rolls

$15 Baby Back Pork Ribs with Kona coffee sauce (served cold)

$15 Crispy Calamari with ponzu aioli (best deal, huge serving)

Entree: served ohana or family style
$28 Huli Huli Chicken 
Wok fired roasted chicken, grilled pineapple, red onions, sweet peppers & scallions
$5 Steamed Jasmine Rice

Dessert:
$16 Sampler Platter
Chocolate Banana & Ginger Caramel Tart with Coconut Mousse Dome
Mochi Trio: mango, vanilla and green tea ice cream wrapped in mochi
Floating Island: Passion Chiboust with Blue Curacao Anglaise, Coconut Nougatine

Drinks:
$12 Zombie 
Blend of three rums, lemon, lime, pineapple & passion fruit juices, Angostura bitters 

$12 Pina Colada
white rum, fresh pineapple juice and coconut

Food was definitely old school. Drinks were strong but quality was terrible. Service was friendly and efficient. Our server gave us 2 complimentary mochi trios for the 2 birthday celebrants. While the TR is too kitschy and expensive to be a regular dining destination, this was a great nostalgic visit to a land of fantasy and adventure.
author: Cece E.

description: Like a Disneyland bar! So fun and drinks are fantastic! I recommend getting there early or a reservation. I got there when it opened on a Saturday and it filled up fast. Drinks are not cheap, but so worth it!!
author: Aaron J.

description:
Ok if I have to rate the food, it's probably 2-3 stars. I mean it's not bad just OK. It's Asian fusion, Hawaiian perhaps? The kalua pork I had came with egg on top and was pretty good, albeit a little small. The calamari was fine, may have been a little salty. The cocktails were delicious but not enough alcohol content for the price. I ordered the drink that comes inside a pineapple.. $24! I wanted a pic of it LOL But yes the place is pricey.
Now the reason I give it 4 stars is that you just have to come at least once and experience the Tonga Room. It's cheesetastic and kitschy, but I guarantee you will have a great time and so will your out of town guests. Be sure to come on a Friday or Saturday though when they have a live band FLOATING ON A BOAT in the middle of the restaurant while IT RAINS. Super cheesy but it just brought a smile to my face. 
So in summation, come here expecting a good time. Also expect to spend a lot of money (recommend the shared bowls.. of alcohol and the ginormous dessert with flame!). DO get a reservation, this place is popular. There are tons of tourists and no one knew we were locals, they thought we were there enjoying our vacation as well. And you know.. that's what this place felt like: a vacation.
author: Vol T.

description:
I felt like I was whisked away to some tropical island far far away from reality.

I totally did not expect to find a place like this inside the Fairmont Hotel.  Think Disneyland's The Tiki Room plus a few pirates here and there and then throw in some Asian flavor.  I totally loved it!    

There was artificial rain, a moving boat with a live band playing you songs from the islands, a pool right in the middle of the whole shabang, a dance floor on the pseudo deck, and strong tropical cocktails that will really make you fuzzy in the head.  

It would be such a cute date spot.  However, be warned.  It will not be a cheap date.  Everything is expensive.  Portions are fairly small.  (i.e. $16 for 6 little chicken skewers)  My friend and I shared two appetizers and we each had a drink.  Our bill came up to about $50.  The menu isn't very extensive either.

Oh yeah, please note that there is a $5 cover charge for the live performance..  We didn't know about this cover charge until we were paying our bill.  Eh.. 

It's definitely a novelty place.  Oh, and apparently, this is where the older crowd gets buck wild.  I'm talking about "men and women in their 40s to 50s getting drunk and dancing around in the hallways of the Fairmont to get to the bathroom" kind of crazy.

Food: 3 stars 
Atmosphere and decor: 4 stars
Crowd: 3 stars
Service: 4 stars
Overall:  4 stars just because it's just something different.

Side note: Anthony Bourdain did his show here!!
author: Cecilia S.

description:
The Tonga Room is a classic place for kitsch in San Francisco.  It's worth a visit maybe once a year for locals.  Be ready for a long line on a weekend night.  The drinks are sweet and come in novel vessels.

For a place that serves $13-15 cocktails and a hotel that regularly charges in excess of $300/night I would expect the bathrooms not to smell like the dirtiest, pee-filled corner of the Civic Center BART/Muni station.  Clean your shit up if you want to remain a class act.

Also, I waited 15 minutes to grab a glass of water at the bar while a manager stood at the terminal in front of me closing out the register and not acknowledging the fact that I or anyone else was there.  If you aren't going to pay attention to the customers, perhaps do this somewhere else.
author: Seth B.

description: Really a fun atmosphere with the band on the boat, thunder and rain...and the great Scorpion drink with 3 foot long straws for two!!!!!!
author: Dorinda D.

description:
One of the more interesting and unique bars I've been to. I came late to a party and hung out in the bar area and totally missed the show and got to an experience a little bit of the rain. Yes, they have indoor rain here. To be honest, as I didn't get the full experience on this place and was going to give it 3 stars, (actually 3.5) but, everyone I was with gave it 4 stars so I damn got persuaded.

Here's what I didn't like: I was there for 1 drink and left $20 poorer.  That is a lot of dough for a little, sugary mai-tai.  They charged $5 per person for a cover band which I heard all of about 2 songs before we left. Maybe been worth it if I stayed longer. The drink rang in at about $11/$12 dollars.  They mean business here.

What I did like: the ambiance, obviously this place is cool as hell. Dark, mysterious, again that indoor rain is the real deal.. way cooler than the Rainforest Cafe. Yikes, haven't been to one of those... I think ever. The place is huge, making large party groups doable on the fly. 

Again, I was in and out so I didn't get an appropriate visit for a more lengthy review. But, what I can say is, I'd go back for a visit with a group and if I've never been I'd most definitely see what the hype is about.  Definitely a unique experience!
author: Stephanie Y.

description: This is a tiki bar that looks the part with a pool in the middle and a band on a boat,  but doesn't exactly hold up when it comes to the drinks. They are in the $15 range but we had a varied feelings on if it was worth that price or not. There was a $10 cover if you wanted a table, otherwise the standing bar didn't require a cover. We stayed for one drink and moved on.
author: Sara K.

description:
Well-decorated island and ship themed restaurant and bar. The cocktails looked intriguing, although I didn't drink. The calamari appetizer is what I really went in for and it didn't disappoint.

It wasn't overcooked in the slightest, had a well-seasoned batter that was light, crispy and crunchy. It wasn't quite as light as a tempura, but not as heavy as a thick breading either. It was definitely enough for two as well.  The best part? ... little crunchy bits!

The sauces that came with it were decent, but left me wanting for one with more acidity. Overall, one of the better calamari dishes I've had.
author: Jas M.

description: Awesome place inside the Fairmont hotel.  Great cocktails, incredible atmosphere.  During the nights a band will play on a floating boat.  Also, be prepared for a lightning and thunder storm every 10 min or so! If your around I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Jason F.

description: After watching an episode of no reservation with Anthony Bourdain I was dying to try this place out. Came here on Valentine's Day and their computers were down so the wait was pretty long. Once we were seated it took about 15 mins for our server to come order our drinks. The drinks were okay nothing amazing. I enjoyed their pineapple royal (fresh pineapple juice!) and the lava bowl. Service was extremely slow. I had to get our servers attention several times and there were several workers just standing there looking at me. Now I understand every server is designated specific tables but it's just rude looking at the customer, knowingly that they need help and just stand there pretending not to see. Since their computers crashes they just seemed very unorganized. Meeh, not a place I would go out the way for if I was in sf.
author: Linda L.

description: This place is enjoyable because of the experience. It rains inside & the band is live. The food is just ok. The drinks are strong. We enjoyed watching the couples dance like they were on ABC Dancing with the Stars. I would come here again in a heartbeat!
author: Court S.

description: We recently we went to the Tonga Room and it had a very fun atmosphere. The cover band was great. The band plays on a floating boat and the indoor rain was really cool. I didn't order any drinks but the people I was with all enjoyed their drinks.
author: Paul D.

description:
My husband and I went here for our anniversary, and it was AMAZING!!! We are all about 1950's/60's kitsch so this lovely gem was right up our alley. Our waiter was the best ever, and the customer service was phenomenal! We made sure to make a reservation and I'm so glad we did. It was a Saturday night and the place was poppin! The line to get in was around the corner and we only had to wait about 15min. due to us being super fortunate to have made the reservation. 

Be expecting to lay down some bills. Both of our meals were in the $25 range plus we had quite a few cocktails all about $12-$17. We also made sure to highlight our evening  by capturing our great time with a Tonga Room memorable photo and matchbooks set $24, make sure to ask about this and the photographer will come by to take a snap shot of ya. If you would like to see the band its a $7 cover charge and they begin playing at 8pm, and every 1/2 hour there is a wonderful rain n' thunder shower. The lagoon, the band, the rain made for such a great atmosphere. Don't miss out on this!

The drinks were great, the food was also very good but not as good as I was expecting.  Perhaps it was just what we had ordered. It certainly wasn't bad by any means but I was expecting just a bit more and this is the only reason why I didn't give 5 stars.

To whomever out waiter was that night thank you so much for making our time so great at the Tonga Room!!! We will definitely be coming back to this wonderful time warp of a place : )
author: Valerie W.

description: First time in San Francisco and found this place as one of the most important places to see. I think it is true. Really different from bars and restaurants I've been before. Had only drinks. Perfect!
author: Mis M.

description:
I really enjoyed my evening here :)

The atmosphere gets a 10 out of 10. It was absolutely incredible. We got an excellent table right next to the LAKE in the middle of the restaurant. It rains over the lake and a boat floating in the middle plays music...its awesome.

The only caveat was the drinks and food were kind of average and super expensive. We left there with a $60 tab after only one drink bowl and appetizers. (Fried calamari and edamame) I just wouldn't go there again unless it was a special occasion.

TL;DR Fantastic atmosphere, OK food, pretty expensive.
author: Loryn F.

description: It's a fun atmosphere and definitely something to check out but I don't think I'll be going regularly. Drinks were not good although they have a nice presentation. Music was live and the band was good but I feel like they could've chosen more tropical songs. There were a lot of empty glasses left everywhere and it was uncomfortable to find somewhere to stand or even sit. We had to pay $10 per person to be able to sit at the tables so we just chose a little table next to the bar. Bar is small so one has to wait long time to get a drink. Staff was friendly and the decoration was on point.
author: Daniela B.

description:
Super awesome fun.  Ultra groovy Tiki bar.  You need to see this in person, photos just don't show the true detail.  This is an Amazing place.  Hang out, have a few drinks, wait for the rain and thunder.  ( Yes, rain and thunder inside the restaurant. ) 
This will be our go to spot every time we visit S.F.
author: Keith B.

description:
I'M ABOUT TO WRITE A "MEH" REVIEW FOR ONE OF THE MOST POPULAR DESTINATIONS IN NOB HILL. HERE WE GO:

I took my girlfriend here last Thursday evening to catch the last bit of Happy Hour, which runs from 5:00pm to 7:00pm Wednesday through Friday. It's $10/person.

That's a DEAL in this place, and in hindsight, I'm very sorry that we didn't take advantage of it. Even if the food had been shitty, we would have at least walked out of this place feeling like we got our money's worth. 

What I DID enjoy about the Tonga Room was its atmosphere. It was like walking into an adult version of Rainforest Cafe, complete with rain, lightning and thunderstorms; and as other reviewers have mentioned, there's something very "Disneyland" about this place (more specifically, if the Tiki Room and Blue Bayou had a baby). 

I can't very well, however, go onto the food without first setting the record straight in regards to San Francisco history. We were told by several staff members that the pool inside of the Tonga Room is "the oldest indoor swimming pool in San Francisco". THIS IS INCORRECT, unless they mean the oldest indoor swimming pool STILL IN EXISTENCE. Technically speaking, it was actually the Sutro Baths, which opened in 1896, which to this day still sort of "exist", depending on how you look at them...The pool inside of the Fairmont Hotel didn't open until 1929. 

ANYWAY...

I regret having dinner here. I really do.

If you don't make a reservation they will probably put you at the shittiest table ever, even if the restaurant is half-empty, as was the case when we came here last week.

For an appetizer, we ordered the Cha Siu Bao (BBQ Pork Buns). Anyone who appreciates good and cheap dim sum as much as I do will be shocked and appalled that we paid $15.00 for four buns that tasted no better than what we could have gotten around the corner in Chinatown for less than half as much money. 

For the entree, we shared the Fried Saimin Noodles, which was a strange combination of chow mein-looking noodles, sliced sausage and vegetables. A flavorless, poor attempt at...whatever it was trying to be.

My advice to you? Make reservations for a poolside table, come for the Happy Hour buffet, and leave before 8:15pm or else a per-person cover charge will be added to your bill. A band playing Top-40 music in a floating covered raft? Eh, I'd rather see Diamond Dave.
author: Jen O.

description:
Like OMG, I can't believe this place still exists! I am soooo happy. All the memories of partying in the 90s; deep-fried American-style Chinese/Polynesian pineapple laden foods; tropical (indoor) rain over the lagoon, the cheesy Hawaiian band playing on the bamboo float. 

Talk about escapism!! IDK, this place really does it for me. The crowds seem always open for meeting new people and sharing memories yet to be made. Great for office parties, birthday parties, first dates, after-work get togethers, etc.

If you're in SF and haven't been here, I highly recommend going. Even if it's only as long as you can put up with the Don Ho music and South Pacific decor. It's cheesy, but in a truly fabulous way!!
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
As a Party of 4 adults from Ct and Anthony Bourdain fans we were looking forward to our Tonga room visit on May 25. We arrived about 15 mins after happy hr had begun. Hostess was not very welcoming or friendly. We were told that because we did not have dinner reservations we could either stand at the bar area or wait for a table. We waited for 35 minutes and were seated in bar area which was very disappointing because it is away from where all the attraction of going to the Tonga room is. If you want to sit near the pool area it is for dinner only according to the hostess. 
Free Buffet was very good as were fancy drinks.
author: C R.

description:
After the initial fun kitsch wears off, this place has nothing. It's all smoke and mirrors. The food is terrible. The drinks are too sweet. Everything is fried and too sweet. 

This might be a place you go for a drink, and get the hell out. There are just too many good restaurants to eat at touristy traps like this.
author: Vadim d.

description:
This place was ok. The food was very mediocre, and there were some decent island style drinks, but most were very sugary. Other than the food being only OK, everything was cool. It is located in the basement of the Fairmont where the pool was located. They utilize the pool in a very cool way and have a raft that floats out with a cover band that plays decent music that can actually move some people to dance. Every few minutes, there is a rain storm that adds to the cheesy, but fun atmosphere.

This place is definitely only worth going to once, but if you are only in San Fran for a night or two, or its your first time there, do not waste your time.
author: Brian N.

description:
Stephen Spielberg as Producer , raised to the power of Indiana Jones Franchise

Multiplied by the sum of ...

Disneyland Safari Ride + 
Pirates of the Caribbean + 
1980s Tales of the Gold Monkey + 
Charlie Chan

= Tonga Room 

The umbrella drinks for 2 and dinner buffet are also a nice touch. 

Although too bad they're only open for half the week, they are nicely hidden within the bowles/basement of the classy Fairmont Hotel.

Ole.
author: Jay D.

description:
"If you have no love in your heart for this place, you are a sick, twisted lonely f**k with too many cats." - Tony Bourdain

That about sums it up. You HAVE to love this place. The setting seems like such pure kitsch... but it has been this way since 1947... this is where they INVENTED kitschy!! When the thunder struck and it started to rain over the pool while I sipped my Mai Tai  I was sooooo happy! The service was excellent and very friendly.  I do have to admit it was not a perfect experience... the food is a little underwhelming. Not bad by any means... just a little underwhelming. I had The Tonga Hot Pot which was billed as a red curry... the seafood was cooked perfectly but it was very bland. Maybe they are toning down the spicy Asian flavors for the tourist trade. That is an unfortunate mistake as this could be really GREAT. The menu is very creative... it just doesn't live up to it's descriptions. 

So here's my advice. This is a perfect stop for drinks and appetizers. The poo poo platter is quite excellent. The ribs and crab puffs in particular. Share a big bowl drink with your friends and enjoy the room. You'll be glad you did!!
author: Robert B.

description:
Tried to stop by on a Friday night but it was reserved for a private event. Came back the next night and had a great time. Drinks are expensive and a bit overloaded with ice but they're tasty. The bartender was completely swamped but did a good job attending to customers.  Decorations are great and provide a fun atmosphere. The gem is when a band floats out into the middle of a pool to play a variety of great tunes. People of all ages were out dancing. Fun times!

P.S. A sign at the door claims a $7 cover per person but we didn't get charged it going in for drinks. Not sure if those who choose to eat are hit with the fee.
author: William D.

description: We celebrated my and moms birthday at the tonga room. We have been there several times years ago and had great experiences. The menu has changed quite a bit from before. Nothing on the menu really excited me. We ordered the pupu platter to share with 4 people. It was ok, nothing to die for. We also ordered the calamari which was delicious!!!  For entrees we ordered family style. We had the mahi mahi, kalua pork, fried rice and fried noodles. The mahi was wonderful, pork was good also. Noodles were ok and the rice was ok. I don't think the food is the quality it used to be. Our server was wonderful and very attentive. Drinks were very expensive for what you got. Our total bill was $334 and $120 was drinks. Wow!!! Music was fun though. Enjoyed the atmosphere. If I went back I would do the happy hour buffet instead for $10.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Took the girlfriend here on a date night.  Make a reservation and they will try to seat you as close to the pool as possible.  Lucky for me, we sat poolside and got to check out the indoor rain.  It's cliche, but still cool.  The decor and feel of the whole place is great. the service is FANTASTIC. we had a great waiter.  

drinks - The Pinapple Royal is HUGE!  But not strong.  And a good way to get into the tonga room mood.  Mai tais aren't bad either.

food - started with the scallops.  the chow chow is great.  also had the curry.
author: Richard N.

description: Very cool, unique atmosphere. Fun drink menu. I personally was leaning more torwards a 3 or 3.5 because I felt the atmosphere was a bit cheesy and amusement-park-ish but since most people probably come here for atmosphere I'm rounding up to 4. I didn't have food, only drinks.
author: Kyle M.

description: Great ambience. Mediocre food. Service is average.  Basically you are coming here for the music and ambience.
author: Adam L.

description:
It's fun being a tourist in your own city. 

The Tonga Room is one countries first tiki bars and is a SF happy hour institution. I recently came here for the first time for a work event  and had fun.  

Tiki torches, bamboo chairs, mai tai's, hawaiian punches (taste like long islands) and the indoor lagoon with the floating stage of the cover band playing 70's and 80's hits. When the thunderstorm came and the band performed some Prince, I felt like I was transported back into this tiki bar's heyday of the 90's.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/458NXhlB0ZtEaJUPI3PPcA?select=WOHBhRh2oUh2_U16VcxMLw)

The best eats of the night were the Kona bbq ribs since they were juicy and the a-y-c-e Dungeness crab leg station. It's a crime not trying anything Dungeness when visiting SF. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/458NXhlB0ZtEaJUPI3PPcA?select=G9OWpiB9wPkGF9due11QEA)
author: Earl G.

description: This place has seen better days. Kind of like being in Epcot. I get it, it's theme...but even the rain storm with the lighting which is one flash of a lightbulb is lame considering the technology available today. All the waiters are polynesian or something and I don't think any speak english as a primary language, if at all. No explanation of the menu items. "Ken" was our waiter. He handed us a menu and wanted to know what we wanted. Then he disappeared until he brought the food back. I'm pretty sure the steamed pork buns are the same ones sold at Trader Joes. Maybe in its day this place was fun and kitschy but its a bit tired and worn, poor service and mediocre food at best. It was awful. And waaay too expensive.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
You don't go to Tonga Room under premeditated circumstances. You go because someone (who is more than likely wildly inebriated) has the moronically persuasive GALL to suggest going there and for some reason you agree, because you're feeling like you want to relinquish control of your flailing life if only for a moment, or a Hurricane or four and a goddamn tiny paper umbrella. 

Our story is lore. My roommate and I met up with two of our pals around 11--somehow, these rascals had already been soaking up the Tonga rum since 8pm. Eyes were glazed by the time we sat down at our tiki hut and there was a suspiciously large bag filled with over a dozen commemorative Tonga goblets. Apparently they had rung up such an exorbitant tab that the staff was giving them free shit. Side note: my friends are regular people, not tech moguls. I'm not rolling around with GD Benioff. What. The. Sam. Hell. 

The planets were aligned and the dance floor was packed with spillover from a wedding AND a bar mitzvah at the hotel in which the Tonga Room is located--we were delighted with the witching hour of an all-star showcase. Tonga Room, in this light, is a spectator sport. Moms who have had one too many Chardonnays heckling the band to play Springsteen, tottering precariously at the edge of the moat. The weird uncle that may or may not have hired an escort as a date and is convinced he is an Olympic-level salsa dancer. The lanky teen who was slipped one too many bevs at the earlier wedding's open bar, staggering around like a newborn fawn, just moments from imminent sickness like a ticking bomb about to detonate. Who will be the first to pass out on the island?! 

You better believe we heckled all of them. Until we were asked to leave at closing, when the waitstaff swiftly swiped an electric blue Hurricane from my friend's bare paws and poured the sludge into a styrofoam "roadie," if you will, which we all found even more hilarious as she angrily chucked it at a nearby building. 

Long story short, if you don't have an open heart and a soft-spot for saccharinely-tinged shenanigans, go be a douchebag elsewhere (Polk is a short Uber ride away, jerks). But if you're looking to get full-tilt, loosey-goosey, mom-drunk silly, there's a pineapple wedged Hurricane with your name on it at Tonga Room.
author: Meredith C.

description:
This place is such a gem from a bygone era. 

My husband and I went for happy hour. We enjoyed a scorpion bowl and two rounds of Zombies and Mai Tais. The drinks tasted fresh snd delicious, and at happy hour prices were a real bargain. 

We had reservations for dinner there too, but opted instead for the heavy snacks on the $10 happy hour buffet. Granted, it wasnt the most earth shatteringly good food ive ever had, but it was full of flavor and a perfect accompaniment to soak up the delicious fruity drinks. The chicken wings in Kona coffee barbecue sauce were the standouts and we each had 8 or 10. The spring rolls and tonga sauce were really tasty as well.

This place though is all about the ambience. Bamboo, rattan, ikat fabrics, dark woods, tiki idols and Polynesian carvings were throughout, and the center of the room is dominated by the Fairmont Hotel's old pool replete with a floating bandstand! Every half hour the ceiling erupts with thunder and lighting and a rain shower around the perimeter of the pool. So much fun and so unique!

PJ was our server and she was so friendly and told us about the history of the place and gave us great recommendations for drinks. She also gave us some tips on other places not to miss in the city.

In all, i cant think of more kitschy fun ive ever had in another bar, tiki or otherwise!
author: Kristopher C.

description:
3 star food, 4 star drinks, 5 star atmosphere.

This place is really a fun place to go. Bring a group as it really isn't a romantic place (sorry to the date I took there). 

Highlight of it all was the fact that my drink came in an actual pineapple. 

I would go back with a group, and with a focus on drinks and appetizers. Great location to tie one on.
author: A S.

description:
If you love Tiki cheesiness, this is the place to go.

My husband was here about 30 years ago, and says nothing has changed. 
Although, they are incredibly busy now. Anthony Bourdain helped this place have a massive resurgence. (So much so, they are woefully understaffed. Our server apologized and complained about that.)

On past visits there was no line, and was fairly empty. I'm glad to see more people are checking this place out, it's a bit of historical landmark.

We brought my friend here (that was on a layover, but not as long as Anthony Bourdain's.) Only one of us had a fun fruity drink, but the ambiance was enjoyed by all. Everyone we've ever brought here has loved it. If you've never been, this is definitely somewhere you need to check out, at least once.
author: Amanda G.

description:
Took my 90 year old mother here for her birthday. Service was good as  was the food.Drinks were also very good.My father used to play on the raft in the 60's and in those days everyone wore tuxedos and there was a 4 piece band. Today we get a key board operator and a drummer along with a singer. that part was a little disappointing , but hey the experience was great and my mother liked it.

They also remembered it was her birthday and brought her a special desert. Most places wouldn't have done this, even though I made mention of it on open table.

There was even a Bride there with tatoos!
author: Mike M.

description:
Based on the yelp reviews and pictures, I wasn't too excited to go here, but I ended up really enjoying it! The pictures don't really make the Tonga Room look as nice as it does in person. Imagine a Rainforest Café feel mixed with an upscale Tommy Bahama's Restaurant. I felt like I was in Disneyland or Hawaii! 

The whole atmosphere really added to the experience from the indoor water area, spacious, and very cool Hawaiian décor. It was a friend's birthday and we ended up staying here 3+ hours so despite the overpriced food, it balanced out with the environment and feel of the place. Also, very cool, chill music. A bit of Hawaiian, a bit of oldies... singing men on a boat with occasional 'rain.' Air-y and not stuffy as I imagined. A little dance floor where no one was dancing haha.

Yes, the menu is completely overpriced, but the food was good! I wouldn't say "out of the world" amazing, but I really enjoyed my meal and thought this place was worth it. The mahi mahi with coconut risotto ($28) was well-cooked and delicious. Yay. The only annoying thing was that I could barely taste any alcohol because our drinks were so stuffed with ice cubes. Shared a lava bowl ($20 for two) and thought it was over-priced for watered down alcohol. Boo. We all shared a flaming lava sundae ($24) between 8 girls and it was more than enough... but they freeze the whole bowl before it is served so it was a bit difficult to scoop it out. Boo. The free upside down pineapple cake/mocha for the birthday people was also a nice touch. But the pineapple cake was dry. Boo. 

The service was awesome. I really enjoyed our waiter, David and the rest of the staff. Super attentive and went out of their way to make it a positive experience for my friend's birthday and our table. Yay.

You can dress up or down. It's darker so it doesn't matter, but it was nice seeing some people dressed up.

Don't let the menu prices, pictures and yelp reviews scare you. I was impressed and really enjoyed this place!
author: Nina K.

description:
I wanted a Birthday dinner, somewhere fun! I walked up to the Tonga restaurant, the host told us a 10 minute wait. Excited to go in a have a few drinks with the girls. Another host comes up after 15 minutes and asked if we want to sit in the lounge. I told the original host we wanted a table. The 2nd host says there isn't a table available for another 2 hours... Mind you, it's not busy at all! The 2nd host wAs one of the rudest hosts I've come across! A "Manager" came out with his Hawaiian shirt on and told us we can't hAve a table for another 2 hours. He knew the original host told us A different story.  Didn't apologize for the misunderstanding, didn't offer another alternative that would make us happy. 
Pros:
Lovely small waiting area
Cons:
Rude hosts/managers 

Don't take my word to not go here, find out for yourself... If you like rude employees.
author: Niessa D.

description:
Rating 2: Not really for me.  Dinner wasn't good at all. Drinks were the only okay part. Probably would be fun for tourists and adults.

Food: An asian fusion. My date and I ordered the crispy calamari and the Kalua Pork.  The calamari appetizer was pretty big and was actually good!  The Kalua pork was pricey, small, and disappointing. There was absolutely nothing special about it.  It was a bit dry too. And it was pricey. 

Drinks: During the first time (with the date) and second time with friends, have ordered all 3 of the bowls.  They're decently strong and fun to share with friends. 

Price: Not happy with the price for the quality and amount of food. 

Entertainment: The live band playing oldies was fun, but SO loud.  I was expecting island music. There was a dance floor which I'm sure many people could appreciate. 

Service: Great, nothing to complain about. 

Overall: It's a fancy, supposedly entertaining, expensive restaurant / bar.
author: Jennifer W.

description: A bit expensive, but the ambiance is worth it. The food is distinctly Hawaiian, which is lovely. I just like walking through the lobby and feeling fancy at the Fairmont.
author: Kendra B.

description: Stopped in with a few coworkers for a drink before a big dinner elsewhere. It was a great spot to relax and grab a fun cocktail. They have music later in the evening as well, which is really fun.
author: Alicia T.

description: Ambiance is better than food. The food tastes like something you get at the Westfield mall, or at the hot lunch bar of Bristol farms grocery store. Basically, ur paying $$$ for the scene.
author: Happy C.

description: It's unfortunate because the Tonga Room is really cool and somewhat of a landmark, but it is really DIRTY! I was in the lounge area and the table was sticky and dirty, plus, my feet stuck to the floor.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Our drinks were incredibly watered down. $15 for a drink that I couldn't even taste the alcohol in...
Plus there was a $5 fee EACH to sit at a table because of the live music.
author: Emily N.

description: Just because it's Tonga room! There is no other place like this in the city. Yesterday we took the cable car from Market to Fairmont hotel and visited Tonga room for Happy Hour. Great cocktail and atmosphere! Food? I wouldn't mind to skip it. If you have kids, they'll love it!
author: Ichi Y.

description:
Come here for happy hour, which is from 5-7pm on Monday through Friday. Entertainment starts at 8pm on Friday through Sunday. There is a cover charge at 8pm, no matter whether you are already inside before then. It doesn't open until 5pm so people start lining up before then. Your whole party does not have to be present when entering. If a person shows up late, they may go to the front of the line, but someone from inside have to go fetch that person. That person must also have a seat. Dress well and tip well. The service is incredibly friendly and professional. This is probably the classiest tiki bar you will ever go to and it is located inside a classy hotel after all. There are tables under straw huts, ship hull, fake claps of thunderstorm, indoor lagoon, and occasional rain that all add to the effect.

It's pricey, which is all the reason to go only during happy hour when drinks are half off. There is also a $10 buffet of appetizer items during happy hour. It's reasonably priced, but the items are mediocre. The lava bowl and scorpion bowl come in sizes for 2 or 4 people. The lava bowl uses two types of rums while the scorpion bowl uses a rum and brandy. They are definitely some stiff drinks. I would most definitely recommend going at least once to check it out.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Food and entertainment were excellent. Makes me homesick for Hawaii. Missing a star because parking is difficult, unless you're a hotel guest you may get stuck with the public parking garage for close to $3 per 15 minutes ouch!
author: Emily L.

description: The Tonga Room is AMAZING. Rich in history, amazing food, and for heaven's sake, the band floats out on a barge in the middle of what was once the hotel pool. Tiki fabulosity at its best!
author: Anne C.

description: Really cool concept! They had a live band playing on the water. The atmosphere and service was great! However, didn't like that they charged us cover to come in, even though the place was almost empty inside. Food is ok, but better place for just drinks.
author: Vicky M.

description: Very neat place. The floating boat with the band and the rain from the ceiling was unique. Drinks were a bit pricey but for the bay area it was reasonable. Standing room only at 7 pm on a Saturday for the bar area. We luckily found a great spot near the pool to watch the band on the boat.
author: Steven B.

description:
This is just a unique place you have to try in SF.  Yes, the food is overpriced and the drinks are overpriced, but it's the ambiance you are paying for.  Go on a night with live music to get the full experience.  I had the Huli Huli Chicken which was tasty but nowhere near worth the $27 price... thigh meat and a bunch of vegetables does not stipulate almost thirty bucks to enjoy.  Also, rice did not come with the dish, had to order separately, at a charge of $5 - for a scoop of white rice!  Good thing the entertainment factor was high, otherwise I would say we were robbed blind.  

The drinks were tasty (also expensive) - my wife had one of the drinks out of a hollowed out pineapple... pretty fun.  Oh, and we also sat a few tables away from Nicholas Cage, Vince Neil (Motley Crue), and Carrot Top.  Apparently they are best buds, which I never knew... what a crew that is!!! My mother-in-law unabashedly took a photo of Carrot Top for visual evidence that we saw them.
author: Brad W.

description:
To anyone who doesn't shower this place with Yelp love: you are a fun sponge.  Yes, the food is average and ragingly overpriced (they call it "Pacific Rim comfort food").  Yes, you may be sitting next to tourists or a birthday party for 7-year-old girls.  But here is what you do: you skip the food, order yourself a pina colada, and thank your lucky tiki stars that a place like this exists in the world.  

This is not to say that I just wonder into the Tonga Room for a casual Wednesday night drink (OK, I am actually going to do this tonight). But this is a must-visit destination when I have guests in town.  Pro tip: get here early to avoid the cover charge, which I believe is around $5 on weeknights and $7 on weekends.  The band usually starts at 8pm so if you're in and out before then, you're cool.  Or, of course, just embrace a full night of tiki.  And take advantage of the fact that this is one of the few places in the city where you can get up in the middle of dinner and have a dance with your sweetie.  Old school dinner and dancing: that is something that the world needs more of.  So this is my recommendation: have a scorpion bowl, some appetizers, and kick back and listen to the rain (you'll see what I'm talking about) and the sweet sounds of the fantastically lounge-y house band.  

Viva la Tonga!
author: Eric S.

description:
Wow... just... wow

If Trader Vik's had a baby with Vegas, and that baby had a really bad sense of entitlement with an attitude to boost, this would be it.

This place proved to me that:

1) It is all about customer service.  I cannot state that enough.  Maybe if I had been treated properly, I would have bought something.  I made a point not to purchase a thing; being treated poorly by 3 different people results in no service at all, and I was going to try a few items on the menu initially.

2) You can really bond with people over bad experiences (in this case, terrible employees).

3) White people cannot dance (but the dance floor is great for people watching).

Let me go into more detail.

My friend wanted to have her birthday here, and we all decided to meet up around 9:30 - 10 ish.  Parking in the city was a disaster, so we were a bit late.  We walk up to the place, and are greeted with a huge line, which really at this point made me feel like I was waiting for a ride at Disneyland (music blaring in the restaurant, lights blasting out into the line...).

I calmly went up to the host and stated that we were meeting a group for their birthday and that they were inside.  I was given such attitude for asking if we could just go in, instead of waiting for a "table because this place is too full."  Mind you, the group HAD a table, and it was for the guests of the birthday.

We were let in ONLY after my friend got us out of line (really? even after I gave you the reservation name and facebook invite?) and then, to my amazement, saw that over half the tables were EMPTY.  The place was not even close to capactity.  It was in fact, half empty.  I could not believe this.  I was told before that I would have to wait an hour if my friend did not come get me, and was also given rolled eyes, sighs, and if looks could kill, I wouldn't be writing this right now.

So, I get to the party, which has about 30 people.  There are about 8 seated at the table, and the rest are lingering around.  I politely asked another employee if we could use another table so more people could sit (there were so many un-used tables, and we were going to PAY for FOOD at the BIRTHDAY).  He said no, and make a big stink that none of us paid $7 for the entertainment fee (what entertainment fee?). No pay, no table.  Well, sir, you lost any money and respect from me.  Also, if there was a fee to "sit" at a table, I should have been given this information before I was so kindly let in.

He then handed me off to another kind gentleman who began to berate me and my group.  I left and told some friends about what had happened.  Apparently they got attitude as well.  For instance, some people had to stand in line (including the birthday girl herself) after leaving to use the bathroom.

What a joke.  This establishment has a lot of promise, if they lowered their prices and raised their standards on customer service.  I will never go back here, and strongly advise anybody to stay away.
author: Kirsten A.

description: Great place to go to with family and friends.  Family included young ones (under 19 yrs old). Had dinner reservations at 9 p.m. but got there at 7:30 to stand in line to have appetizers first so that we didn't have to wait for 9 p.m. to eat appetizers.  I loved the band - they played some cool oldiers that are not your typical ones such as  Earth Wind and Fire's "Fantasy".  Also songs like "Lovely Day", Copacabana", "Peg".  Food is pricey for small portions.  Eat before going there because you may still be hungry.
author: Cynthia R.

description: I don't know how this place can get less than 4 stars based off the awesome atmosphere alone. The hubs and I came here (granted it was after a couple of beers) ordered the poupou platter and some sort of sugary rum infused drink that was served in a bowl. Service was quick, food was good, and drink was sugary but what you'd expect from a tiki bar. I must say the band playing on a barge in the pool was kick ass.
author: Karen S.

description: Ok let's just call it what it is. This place is horrible. It's a hotel bar plain and simple, except it has a theme, Tiki. I like a good tiki bar but this one is a bit much. The drinks are so so, not much to them. Not even a kick. The service is nice (it's a hotel), and the prices sorta ridiculous. Not my fave by far and would totally choose another tiki bar over this.
author: Greg G.

description: I didnt like the food and the customer service. The place looks like good but the other things like a food and customer service are not good at all
author: Catalina R.

description:
Well, you don't go to Tonga Room & Hurricane Bar for fine dining--even though they charge fine dining prices. Roy's Polynesian this isn't, but the over-the-top original tropical tiki scene, complete with hotel pool repurposed as floating Asian lounge act lake and overhead "rain storms" is the real reason you go. The drinks are strong (Mai Tais, Pina Coladas and the like) and the Hawaiian-style pork delicious, but the prices and the rest? So-so. You'd swear the band on the floating Polynesian barge was taken direct from a Hanoi Holiday Inn. 

If you love tiki, rum and kitsch you'll have a great time. Just don't come expecting great food.
author: Craig H.

description: So if you're in San Francisco and want to go to some unique bar check this place out. Not only is it located in the deep basement of the Fairmont, it had a pool inside of it! I only had the drinks here so I can't comment on the food. The drinks are gorgeous to look at and hand made deliciousness! I really liked this place due to it's uniqueness, this isn't your everyday bar.
author: Courtney R.

description: Skip the so-so bar buffet and enjoy drinks and excellent dinner appetizers at a poolside table instead. Bar fills up within minutes of opening. Drinks are good, especially off-menu creations. Hubby and I enjoyed coconut shell poke and steamed spring roll appetizers, then shared an excellent fried whole rockfish. Service was extremely good, there was no pressure to vacate our table despite it being a busy evening. A tad pricey but absolutely worth it.
author: Debbie S.

description: I had a great experience! This was my second time at the Tonga Room and I'm still amazed by the rain. The environment is breath taking and the service was excellent. However, I was not impressed by the food. I was shocked but the food was not that good.... Oh well, I still had a great time. Don't go for the food, go for the drinks; which are amazing. They have top notch bar tenders :-) I will go back, but next I'll be at the bar! Oh, additional TIP ~ make your reservation early online at Open Table, during the week is best but if you have to go on a weekend, book a month or two in advance. The Tonga Room is busy :-)
author: Dew S.

description: Good luck trying to go to this place. They will shut down the whole thing for "private events" without any notice. It's really messed up especially when getting to downtown SF is difficult. If you're lucky enough to get here when they are actually open (remember they are closed on both Monday and Tuesday and will close at a moments notice for private events hosted by tech companies on other nights), you will find the drinks underwhelming and overpriced. You will also get docked with hidden $10 surcharges if the band happens to be playing.
author: Donnie W.

description: While waiting for some friends, my wife walks outside to check if they have arrived because of having no reception and the staff refuse to let her back in and they tell her to wait in line. We've been inside for half an hour and we have no cell reception inside this building so she had to wave frantically at me from the reception area until she got my attention. The attendant dismissed my wife who told him that she has no reception here and he was then was utterly rude to her. Not coming back and we were looking forward to meeting a good group of friends here. None of us came back.
author: Sean W.

description:
Oh my god! No no no no no!

7 people.  $600.00.  HORRIBLE service.  The thunder continued through the live music.  Grease, white rice, and soy sauce.  I am embarrassed and appalled.

How this has survived an earthquake, fire, and Yelp...I have no idea.

The worst 90 minutes of my LIFE!!
author: Mike M.

description: Nice place to hang out. It was my first time there. Not too crazy environment. Nice place to go and have a drink and listen to live music. I LOVED the live music. The band was great. I will definitely return again.
author: Janette S.

description: Very disappointing experience today at the Tonga Room. It was closed because of a private party. Not even a word mentionning this on their website despite what their unwelcoming staff claimed. Anothet sign of the easy life in today's SF hospitality business?
author: Eric G.

description:
God-awful.

My husband and I are sort of tiki enthusiasts. On a recent 4-night stay in San Francisco, we visited three different tiki bars. We were super excited to try the Tonga Room, but it failed to live up to any of my expectations.

I appreciate the history of this place, but it has not aged well. I don't enjoy sitting under bright lights, at a rickety table next to a slimy-looking old swimming pool, with the smell of years upon years of greasy food and an intermittent rotten fish odor wafting through the air, while a cover band plays "Smooth" by Santana featuring Rob Thomas and a cranky server brings me a mediocre drink in a pineapple for which I inexplicably paid $18.

I enjoy it even less when I am scammed and overcharged for the experience.

Our total, with tip, for two drinks, a tiny dessert plate, and a $5/person cover charge, was $65. I know this for a fact because after reading several Yelp reviews about Tonga Room's habit of overcharging, I photographed the receipts. SURE ENOUGH, Tonga Room decided to charge us even more and billed our credit card for over $70.

We're currently waiting for the manager to return our phone call.
author: Michelle M.

description: Awesome tiki bar. We came for drinks and to check the place out. They had a live band that was floating on a boat in the middle of a pond in the restaurant / bar. I got a drink called the zombie, and this morning I figured out why they called that. My GF got a piña colada. Both drinks were tasty, and strong! We both had tropical flare flowing like lava out of the top of our drinks. The lady at the entrance said there was a $7 cover per person for a table. Or we could go in for free to the "standing area" which we opted for. In all I would go again as I enjoyed myself. I think the place slightly annoyed my GF with the level of cheesiness. But I thoroughly enjoyed it. The dance floor had all kinds of ropes and wooden pulleys etc. and resembles a pirate ship. I have been to my fare share of these kinds of places. Well if pirates of the Caribbean ride, and the tiki room at Disneyland count. So I consider myself a master at judging these types of places. This place is right up there with the best of em! I'd give em 6 stars if I could. Just because the door lady didn't push us to get a table, and now we have $14 saved that we can put towards breakfast!
author: Anthony C.

description:
I've wanted to come here for a while and I finally got the chance. 

The bar food/drinks were more expensive than they were good but they weren't bad. (Had a scorpion bowl for 2, a mai tai, and char sui bao). 
The place was a little crowded when I got there (around 7pm) but cleared out a bit as the night went on. As for the "storm", don't have too high of an expectation about that. 

This place is maybe more worthy of 3.5 stars but I met some wonderful people there and that really helped shape the atmosphere/my experience.
author: Bella S.
