description: Ok, for tiki lovers it's a must-see because of the decor. The drinks were good but service was slow and the clientele was business types and tourists. They need to allow for more bar seating. Why have half of the seating empty for diners that aren't even existent and have everyone crammed into a crappy bar area standing? How can you share a Scorpion bowl with no table? Less people go there to eat than drink. I wish they'd play exotica and lounge music. I won't go back. Once was fine. Also, the hostess was rude when we asked her about being seated.
author: Sally M.

description:
Ok for the novelty factor (fun decor, a swimming pool in the middle of the room and a rain-fall that goes every half hour... woo) but drinks are overpriced and the service is shoddy. 

We arrived shortly after the bar had opened but our waitress clearly didn't want to be there- she was very slow taking our order, snappy when we asked questions, and didn't check back to see if we wanted to order anything else.

If you love Las Vegas you'll probably enjoy this more than we did- this bar is a little slice of Vegas in the basement of a San Francisco hotel.
author: Kate B.

description: Anthony Bourdain had us sold on trying this place when we came to visit. As soon as I walked in I was a little nervous because my first impression was that it was a touristy place that could be in Hawaii (which is where we are from). Ambience is cool with live music in the pool but there was a $5 cover for that that was added to your tab. The bar food menu is hardly exciting and the drinks weren't as strong as we thought they were going to be. Seems like they would accommodate large parties well and the dinner menu probably has a better selection for food. On a brighter note, our server was excellent. Glad to say we tried it but I wouldn't hurry back
author: Nicole K.

description:
We came in search of the Tonga Room after seeing all the fun that Mr. B had on his show. After making it through the lobby with a minimal number of awkward stares (no need to elaborate, you know why...smh), we made it to the elevator and were on our way down into the the bowels of the Fairmont Hotel.

The Tonga Room is the complete opposite of everything that exists in the lobby. The people are friendly, down to earth, fun, and don't have their hands on their purses while staring awkwardly.

We ordered the large punch bowl for two. We casually sipped the spirits while watching the lightning and rain fall from the ceiling. Great ambience and staff. 

Check it out!
author: Justin R.

description:
What a great atmosphere. A must check out if you're visiting San Francisco. I've never experienced anything quite like this. The music is always fun (can't go wrong with a band on a boat surrounded by water in the middle of the restaurant/bar)
The food is quite good, what I would deem as Americanized food from the South Pacific. 
The drinks, though fun and different are a little on the pricey side. But you have to try them and experience what Tonga has to offer.
author: Kristopher P.

description:
*DONT EAT HERE... DRINKS ONLY*
You are the winner of my first bad yelp review.... Congrats!!!

Price 1/10
Food - 1/10
Atmosphere - 6/10
Drinks - 7/10
Service - 5/10


Food - Menu is basic and very bland. 
Had the Seared Diver Scallops and Tonga Hot Pot. Both lacked any flavour what so ever. Very bland.... Scallops were over cooked. 

Service - had to wait 15min to even speak to the waitress to tell her we had a booking. Had a booking at 6 and didn't get seated until 6.30.

Drinks - presented well and VERY strong.

Price - Very expensive for what you get. Plenty of better places around compared to this. Save your $$$ this is definitely a tourist trap and we fell for it. 

If you want to check the place out I suggest you just go for a drink at the bar.

Thank god there is still some leftover Tony's pizza in the fridge!
author: Glen C.

description:
I came here on a random Friday, and was surprised they had a buffet. It was actually pretty good for a bar-tonga-islandthemed-buffet situation.
The interior was pretty nice, as it was very thematic.
My friends said that the drinks were strong. They're asians with alcohol-allergies, so you can adjust to scale.

Go here... if you... want to? There's not really an in-your-face apparent attribute that I'd say would be its main appeal, but it's a nice spot to go to if you want something with a twist.
author: Sean H.

description: They get a little crazy with the cover charges, but I understand given how popular this place it.  Yes, it's a kitsch - it's an indoor swimming pool turned into a tiki bar that actually has a 'rain shower' periodically.  This isn't a bar being a retro Tiki Bar, this place has been tiki since that concept was first cool.  We've had appetizers but not dinner, so I can't comment on that.  The drinks are expensive, but strong.  Despite all of that IT'S TOTALLY WORTH IT.  There is just nothing else like it in the U.S.  It's just something you HAVE to do at least once.  If you haven't been there, just go.  It's just too cool and such a San Francisco classic.
author: Greta R.

description:
I finally get to cross this off of my to-do list! I've long known about this place and the bad reputation it has on its food. That's why I stay away from it and instead had a drink and embrace the atmosphere. An amazing transformation from a swimming pool, to a "pirate ship." This place has so much potential to become awesome, yet it doesn't. I assume it's because no matter what, they'll have business.

5 star for the interior and theme.
2 star for the drinks, a bit over priced.
author: Mandy D.

description:
I love this place!  It has a super cool ambience and there's a band playing on a boat in the middle of the water! 

We only went for drinks, we went to the bar and got drinks which were all served in cool cups. Then we hit the dance floor.  I don't know if they have the same band all the time or what, but they were GREAT! They took requests and there were tons of fun people dancing! 

The Tonga Room is pretty expensive. All the drinks are around 14 or 15 bucks.  I would not recommend the Ti Daiquiri.  I don't know what it is made out of but it tasted real bad.  

We did not spring for this, however, they have big punch bowls if you are into that scene!
author: Erin D.

description: Take your Zantac because the drinks, food, and the check will give you heartburn. Having said that, if you don't mind over-paying for over-salted below average food the experience and ambience is cool. Most likely a one and done restaurant.
author: Birdie B.

description: Really you should go for the experience. The bar is too themed complete with a pool in the center. Didn't eat, but did have drinks and they were delicious.
author: Therese M.

description:
Came here with hubby recently - a place where we don't feel like the old geezers!   I'm still stick by my previous review - this place is cheesy but fun.  

It was pretty full and there were kids under 10 to seniors in their 70s - all dancing to the funky tunes on the dance floor.  

Cover charge is now $7.  For this evening, I had the strawberry daiquiri - $12 each.  First tasted just like smoothie, I think it was a virgin.  The second one made up on the alcohol.

Hubby had crown royal on rocks - $10 each - good price. 

Wanted something to munch on, had the ahi poke ($16) - not very good, doesn't look or taste fresh and the spicy edamanme ($4) - great snack.

It was a fun evening with a little bit of dancing.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Good:
Excellent cocktails!

Food:
Strange, unclear, wierd.
They tried to do fusion - tried too hard, so I'm still not clear who comes up with such menu.

Ambience:
Great decor. Seems like there are more staff, than visitors.

Overall - I got the feeling that I'm in a very expensive chinese restaurant.

It worth visiting once just for cocktails and decor.
Have been here twice, in 1998 and recently. Maybe will go again in 10 years.
author: Alex P.

description:
Absolutely love the atmosphere!! I was a bit disappointed when I stepped out and realized that I wasn't on an island. I love the entertainment and the boat on water!

The not so great.. 
Prices are ridiculously high!! $15-32 for an alcoholic beverage (and I didn't even get to keep the cup!) $20- 40 for a meal plate. I ordered the "pu-pu" platter. A small appetizer for $30 bucks. The $10 extra for 'ohana' style is only suitable for 2 people .. which isn't really a family size to me. 

Lastly, the most annoying thing is that they charge $7 cover AND automatic gratuity (we only had 4 people). So we ended up paying a good $50-60 on top of the very overpriced meal and drink items. 

Good first time experience but I probably won't be back.
author: Robyn S.

description: Decor pretty much topped the list, and that's where it ended!  Drinks were ok, pre mixed and poured out of a pitcher instead of made to order fresh!  Bartenders were not friendly, and no collectors mugs!
author: Steve K.

description: "This place sucks, but it's, like...famous," said the guy behind me, while we were leaving. My sentiments EXACTLY.
author: Erin W.

description:
I had a great time here up until the bill came. BUT before you excuse my review because you think I'm cheap let me explain to you my experience here, and hopefully spare you a surprise at the end of your night.  

I came here with a few friends from out of town. Since I wanted their trip to go smoothly I made a reservation for 4 at 9PM on a Friday night. (I had seen other reviews recommending a reservation.) We ordered a few appetizers including calamari and BBQ pork buns (both were decent). On top of that we ordered "Smugglers Golden Punch Bowl" for four and a few other drinks. We had a great time, we really enjoyed the live band and the overall atmosphere for an hour and a half. Now, the things that threw me off:

1. When we were ordered our drinks and appetizers our waiter asked for a credit card to pre-run or something. I thought it was weird, but didn't mind so I gave him my card and went on with the night.
2. The waiter placed the check on our table 30 minutes before we were done with our drinks and food. The place wasn't close to empty, so I thought it was rude.
3. Once I finally opened and looked at the check as we neared the end of our drinks, I was SHOCKED that he had charged us an additional $7 COVER PER PERSON! Our bill was already over $120. 

I'm guessing this happened because I made a reservation and we didn't order entrees. However, based on the prices of their entrees, we could have easily eaten dinner rather than have drinks and appetizers for $120!

Despite my 2 star review I might be back if we have company in town and want to take them somewhere unique. But next time I'm sure as hell not making a reservation, I'd probably just spend time at the bar. Anyway, I hope this helps you better plan your visit to Tonga Room if you decide to go.
author: Kristin G.

description: Tonga Room exceeded my expectations. I had mentioned to the SF locals I was visiting that I had wanted to go there, and became worried I was dragging them into a local tourist trap. I was relieved to find out some of the group actually frequented the bar, and even considered it a neighborhood joint. So, it not only has its Bourdain approved tourist credentials, it has the local as as well as the tiki communities' stamps of approval. That seems like a delicate balance, but then again they were quite capable of balancing a good tiki drink. Better than Trader Vic's but not quite on par with Smuggler's Cove. Glad I was able to make it.
author: Grant L.

description:
A visitor to San Fran celebrating our honeymoon with my husband, we went here for the fun atmosphere and because we stayed at the Fairmont. In truth, the live band is awesome, the ambiance is fun and includes real rain and thunderstorms but sadly, the food was spotty. We had the coconut shrimp (which was delicious) for a starter followed by the Pineapple Chicken and the Lamb for our entrees and both were incredibly salty. Hubby and I both felt like we were eating pure salt! We ditched our food and danced the night away instead. Still had a fabulous time but the food wasn't worth the cost.

In brief, go for the atmosphere and do apps and drinks only but be prepared to spend a decent amount per drink.
author: Molly J.

description:
Finally, I've made my way to the Tonga Room! My loving boyfriend surprised me with a dinner date here because I had been talking about how much I wanted to come here! 

First off, it's in a hotel. You have to either get the valet service and park in the hotel, or park on the street somewhere. When you walk in, it literally feels like I've left California and entered a Polynesian resort. There's tikis and flame torches everywhere, and in case you haven't noticed, there's a giant pool in front of the dane floor with a boat on it that hosts a live band! The band played Africa, which I personally appreciated. The decoration and ambiance is 10/10. They do the most and they succeed!

Know that the menu is intended for family style eating! We started off with the Pu Pu Platter, which consisted of deep fried crab wontons that were to DIE for, eggrolls (eh), duck legs that were perfectly sauced and ribs that FALL OFF OF THE BONE. so delish! For the main course, we got the mahi on coconut risotto, which we cleaned up and the hot pot, which was so large, I had no room for it. Throughout the meal, I ordered two drinks. One was the pina colada. which was surprisingly strong and the Zombie, which I expected to be strong and it DEFINITELY did the trick! The drinks are so worth it! After all of this, my boyfriend proceeded to order the Volcano Sundae with 6 flavors of ice cream, each scoop being the size of a softball. We barely put a dent in it, it was so big! Definitely meant for a larger group and not two people. The toasted coconut was my fave though!

The bill ended up being around $160(not including top), but considering everything we got, it was WELL WORTH IT. The only reason I knocked off a star is being the service is nothing special. They do their job and nothing more. But I would definitely recommend going for the experience!
author: Kathleen N.

description:
Yeah it's a tiki bar. Yes it's popular. Did I like it? No. 

The place was unnecessarily crowded and we waited in line for like 35 min, at 6:15pm. It's not a nightclub - it's a tiki bar. My party of 2 got Mai tais and a smattering of bar food. I hope I don't get sick from the poke, bulgoni, or crab wonton tacos. Overall we left hungry and thirsty.
author: Reba N.

description: Good to go at least one. Small dance floor, professional staff. Live band w good atmosphere. Very expensive. 4 drinks plus a sampler appetizers cost about $100. Not a romantic restaurant to go, has kids, noisy but worth to try it
author: Joyce C.

description:
This swanky Tiki lounge took me back to Hawaii. Located inside the Fairmont Hotel. It has quite the atmosphere. Soft lights, rain storm simulation.  8pm the live band plays and you can take your moves to the boat deck dance floor. 
For Dinner, I recommend the Pineapple Royale, it's sweet with a bitter tang and refreshingly dangerous to 'light weights'. Get the Mango Glazed Mahi Mahi it's lightly tangy and the coconut risotto on this dish is fantastic. This could be my comfort food. 
Staff was very friendly. Our server was very accommodating and attentive. Thanks for making our date special.
author: Charlene K.

description:
There is something special about this place because it is nestled in the Fairmont Hotel. The foods are fusion between Chinese, Thai, American. The ambience is cool. A litle bit pricey but acceptable because its offset with the music, and the atmosphere

Once for trying is enough
author: Talia S.

description:
Take bart to the Embarcadero, pick up the cable car at the bottom of the hill in front of the Hyatt and ride it all the way to the top. If they ask you for money jump off quickly and avoid oncoming traffic.

I only go to the Tonga room during their happy hour and even then their prices are ridiculous. One Mai Tai however, will knock you on your feet and that is all you will need. Afterwards, check out the lobby of the Fairmont hotel, play on the piano and then roam the city - chinatown and union square are both within stumbling distance. Make sure you leave before they start to charge you for their entertainment fee and definitely skip the buffet.

Sometimes its nice to get dolled up and dance on lamp posts around the city and on these occasions I go to the Tonga Room. There is something special about that place, a simpler time, an over the top Disney feel, but special none the less. It's the Tonga experience.
author: Daphne B.

description:
If you gotta ask: "What is the Tonga Room " or "Is the Fairmont a hotel?" , you are better off not going. 

Go for the for the kitsch & history .... The Tonga Room is worth a visit ... it just be a fun thang.

HINTS: Its not really about sampling fine cuisine. Its not about ordering a bottle of Chateau Lafite (I think I spelled that correctly, which should cause pride or shame depending on which end of the wine bottle spectrum you reside), Its the Tonga Room at the Fairmont, and I am grateful it has survived .... all these decades.

http://www.tongaroom.com/509/history
author: Matsuo U.

description: The food sucks and the menu is misleading. The entire restaurant is stuck in the late 50's.
author: Josh S.

description:
This place is the adult version of the Rainforest Cafe, but with worse food.  I paid $30 for the "Hibachi Grilled Wagyu Trip Tip" 4 slivers of a tri tip, beans and what looked like crappy potatoes.  

I understand that this place is about the atmosphere, but at least hire a chef that can make you decent food.  The Mai Tais were ok, just disappointed that such a nice hotel would have such a crappy restaurant.
author: Lani B.

description:
My favorite place in SF.  I go as often as I can.
It's pricey, but so totally worth every penny.
The atmosphere is incredible. The staff is punctual and super nice. 

There is a band, on a covered boat, in a lagoon (that has frequent showers, thunder, and lightening), in the middle of the restaurant.  It's pretty freakin magical.

I just recently had my 30th birthday party here and we all had a wonderful time.
Dinner, dancing, drinks.  Perfect place for a date too! (hint hint)  :-)

oh....and beware of the Zombie.  A sneaky drink that tastes great, but will creep up on you unexpectedly. haha. No more than two! (I actually don't think they can serve you more than two) 

Also, it's inside the magnificent Fairmont Hotel.  Its a lovely hotel that is also worth every penny.
author: Rebecca K.

description:
Food: Good, but not great.  I feel like I could get comparable food from your average Chinese restaurant.  The cocktails were better, although the Mai Tai was too sweet for my taste.

Atmosphere: I liked the faux-Polynesian decor, and the live band that started at 8pm mostly distracted from the tourists taking pictures of everything during dinner.

Price: Way too over priced for what you get.  $62 per person (before tip and tax) for a 3 course meal and a cocktail would be fine, if the quality was better.
author: Carlin F.

description: My first time here due to watching an episode of Anthony Bourdain. The experience and atmosphere was pretty unique, with its rain storm and pool at the center of the restaurant. The decor and service was also great. That being said, the food itself wasn't particularly delicious for the price that was charged. I ordered pulled pork and mahi mahi, both was which were mediocre and nothing memorable. Each of these dishes were $28 or so. We also ordered Monk Walks into a Luau. This drink came with a bowl for 2 or 4 people. For 2, the drink was $32 and again, it wasn't really the best cocktail I had (it was the most expansive!) Overall, the three items we got came out to be $95 or so. It was a unique experience, but the food and drink weren't something that I would come back for in the future. The price really couldn't justify the experience.
author: Sammantha T.

description: It's a classic must try when you're in SF. It's a little pricy, but the Tonga Room has a lot of wow and pizazz when it comes to the food and decorated drinks. The drinks are strong, which is good! This place is great for an adult bday party. And the live music is the best part. One tip, make reservations ahead of time.
author: Megan N.

description:
Kitschy and cute. The drinks were ok. The atmosphere felt like something out of Disneyland. 

Am I glad we checked it out? Sure. Will I be back any time soon? Most likely not.
author: Allison L.

description:
I'm guessing The Layover has given the Tonga Room a new lease on life? came here back in november (pre layover) on a saturday night and just walked right in, the place was pretty empty and it gave me a sad feeling that business wasn't doing too well. i am glad to hear that things are picking up, but not excited about waiting because i want to go back asap!
Bourdain perfectly described it..these drinks are LETHAL. expensive (because it's really about the glass your drinks come in) but worth every penny. it's tiki. it's freaky. it may even be a little bit tacky? but goddamn i loved it here. such a unique experience, and you even get to experience some polynesian weather!
i definitely want to come back, and yes, i guess i'll even wait in line this time.
author: Liz M.

description: Pretty pricey and I forgot what days you had to pay for live music.  But the scene in this area is great since they have live music where they are playing on this little island and a dance flor.  They have a great selection of drinks as well great to have a party at
author: Danny C.

description:
What an absolute glorious tourist trap.  

Overpriced drinks.  OK food.  Annoying photographers.  Slow service. 

and loving every, every minute of it.  Go here.  Dance to the incredibly tight band.  Order a bunch of drinks.  Take a taxi.  Love it!
author: Paul K.

description:
The food was mediocre in addition to being extremely overpriced. However, the drinks, live band and atmosphere were amazing! 

The Royal Pineapple cocktail took me away to a tropical paradise for a moment. 

The only advantage to having a dinner reservation is the bar/lounge area is extremely crowded during peak weekend hours. We watched as people fought for an inch of personal space. 

Service was lackluster- our server reeked of cigarette smoke. 

Word to the wise: Stick with the drinks and appetizers only ...
author: Jessica N.

description:
Never seen a place like it before. We went here on a recommendation by our caterer. She said "you have to go to that one bar where it rains every hour." What? A bar where it rains? So, I Googled it. Google Image pictures looked okay, so we went.

The decor was ridiculous. Think Tiki bar on steroids meets pirate ship. Ambient lighting was poor - too dark! There's this large pool in the middle of the room and it 'rains' into the pool maybe hourly. Not only does it rain though. It also thunders and has lightning. That's really the only reason we came. Needless to say, not really worth it.

Drinks were strong but still $9 for HH cocktails. We were starving so we said yes to their $10 buffet option. They had two different kinds of drumsticks (yet called them wings) that tasted exactly alike, spring rolls, edamame, potato salad, fruit, and fried rice. Very sub par.

But we came, we saw.
author: Summer F.

description:
The Tonga Room is a pretty fun place to hit up in the city.  It's a place to bring guests and impress.  Is it overrated?  Sure.  Will you have a good time?  YES.  

It's a place that you have to know where it is and know where to go.  You also have to act like you are a guest at the Fairmont, which is both fun and demeaming at the same time.  I don't even want to know what a hotel room costs there.  Just walk in the main entrance, turn right and walk to the side of the building and find the nearest elevator.  Go down to the lower level (elevator button will say Tonga), get out and turn right and keep walking down the hall until you see the sign).    

Tonga reminds me of the Tiki room at Disneyland...is it still even in the park?  Probably not.  But the Tonga Room is much better because they serve alcohol!!  The drinks are fantastic, but perhaps a bit pricey.  But they taste of the islands and are delicious.  Plus you get to drink the mai tais out of coconut cups.  Adorable!  There is always a great live cover band that plays on a boat in the center of the water and it rains (INSIDE!) about every 45 min or so.  It's quite lovely and can be packed some nights.  Plus the water in the center used to be an indoor hotel swimming pool.  How cool is that?! 

My suggestions:  I've heard the food is overpriced and not too great.  Hit up Tonga late night for drinks after you've had a much better less expensive dinner somewhere else OR come a bit earlier and hit them up for happy hour.  Either way, you won't regret your decision.
author: Sheryce S.

description: Get there for Happy Hour and skip the cover charge. Drink was fab and the thunderstorm scenery was an added bonus. We had a group of two and were able to skip the line and get a seat right away!
author: Bethany B.

description:
So rude and unsympathetic. Came here for a very special engagement, arrangements were made with concierge but folks here said they didn't care. We had to wait in line and ruin the surprise that was to await the newly engaged couple. After some pressing, they agreed to let us in after waiting 30 minutes if we guaranteed the purchase of one dinner item each. Terrible rude dismissive view of customer experience. Only our stored repository of Karma and persistence allowed it to almost work out (just as planned, but not without frustration and harming our positive vibe). Just disappointing, but that's why I won't come here again.

Service was slow, food was mediocre, drinks were super sweet and overpriced.
author: Chris H.

description: This bar located in the Fairmont exceeds all expectations of bars in hotels. It is your very own Disneyland escape, with live music performances on a boat, dancing, and lava bowls. What more can you ask for. In order to get a table, there is normally a cover of $7 unless you are staying in the hotel or you can easily just sit by the bar. The Scorpion bowl for 2 is $20 and for 4 it's $32 which are pretty strong. This place is worth coming to check out, you won't find any bar like this in San Francisco. This is my go-to for sure.
author: Karen C.

description: First- Make Reservations! Second-Don't get their signature drinks. Their hurricane tastes more like the Thailand Tsunami washup. If you've had a Hurricane in New Orleans- your taste buds will say "WTF!". The Mai Tai, although, shown in a coconut- does not come in a REAL coconut, doesn't taste like coconut, in fact, they have something against Malibu because they don't offer it. You would think a drink styled after a coconut would taste like coconut, but I digress. Their atmosphere makes up for the bad drinks and their food is good because you're just having too much fun listening to great music played by the band on the boat!!! HAVE FUN AND DANCE!
author: Liliane L.

description:
The food was good here, but it wasn't enough to make this a place I could recommend.

The style is equivalent to being at Disney World or the Rainforest Cafe.  Hokey and the kids will like it, but not enough for adults to enjoy.

Our service was abysmal.  Our waiter was horribly indifferent, kept us waiting long periods of time, etc.

Factor in the high prices of an in-hotel-restaurant, and this one gets a thumbs down.
author: Jen G.

description:
Yay, another Anthony Bourdain place.  Tonga Room is in the basement of the Fairmont.  It is basically Rain Forest Café for adults.  Polynesian/tiki themed, with a lagoon in the middle, and rain and lightning episodes. 

 I was only here for drinks, and enjoyed my Singapore Sling, one of my favorite tiki drinks.  My colleagues seemed to like their Mai Tai and margarita.  I was not thrilled about a $5 entrance fee (Thursday) for a lame cover band.  Service was horrendous - our server did not understand us at all, nor was she friendly.  I can see how it would be fun though, with enough drinks and the right crowd.  Plus, it is an excuse to walk through the beautiful Fairmont.
author: Lia M.

description:
TONGA! TONGA! TONGA! That's how excited we were to come here. A little chant was had in our hotel lobby before we started the trek up Nob Hill to the Fairmont Hotel which houses the Tonga Rooms. 

We had a group of 10 and called ahead to make a reservation which we got despite only booking a couple of hours in advance. When we arrived we were promptly seated. We all opted for the sharing platter starters and a cocktail to begin the night. The cockails may be pricy but boy, are they strong. I got the Hurricane which came in a  huge glass. It went down a little *too* easy because it was perfectly made and deliciously fruity. Deceptively strong though. The platters were tasty. They came with ribs, spring rolls and chicken. Perfect to tide us over until our mains.

We all ordered different things. The chicken and vegetable dish looked and smelled divine. I tried the ribs and the mahi mahi which were both good. 

It's great fun. The atmosphere was buzzing and the band in the middle were great. They played some cheesy classics like Toto's Africa and we all had a great time. Then something dangerous happened! One of our table ordered us some punch bowls for four for the table which came with long straws. After my Hurricane and a little of one of these I had to make my excuses and head to bed because my poor little head couldn't keep up. 

This was my second trip to San Francisco and Tonga. If I return to San Francisco I will be back to Tonga for another fun night!
author: Lotta M.

description: Amazing spot for tourists and locals alike. Live music that floats over a huge pool is a see to believe wonder in themed restaurant history. The drinks are sweet and so is the service.
author: Wally S.

description:
Again, the experience of the Tonga lives!

This is a destination people... understand what you're getting into before you get here. Yes, it's crowded. No you are not a special snow flake. Suck it up and kick back, this place is one (or two) of a kind left in all the country. If you show up expecting a hip mission bar you're in the wrong place (and really half the city is the wrong place for you... so go back to Lafayette...) that being said, for the actually hip (yes, it's still a word) people still reading this and not rolling their eyes eyes they drink an appletini while looking at the cracked screen of their iPhone at a crowded bar, where they should actually be talking to their friends, here we go.

Friends in from San Diego... after the Mai-Tais & Pineapple Royals... BBQ Kona pork ribs & whole fried Tai Snapper (EAT THE CHEEKS!) & forbidden rice it was hard to keep the navy men at the table out of the pool!!! A good time was had by all.

Yes, the band is not for locals. Yes, you should make reservations (and really if you want a table anywhere decent in the city, who doesn't know to do this) and yes, cocktails at hotel bars a little overpriced... BUT THIS IS THE TONGA ROOM PEOPLE. 

Look around you, this is the only place left like this on the entire west coast. And it's one of the places that is keeping SF the way it should be.

Thanks again TR & HB you are a classic.
author: Morgan D.

description:
The Tonga Room & Hurricane Bar first opened in 1945 and is named after the South Pacific nation of Tonga. It's apparently still open as the controversy between fans of the Lounge (including preservationists) and hotel management (who have higher profit motives) continues. Here's my take (and based on personal experience of course):

- It's overpriced kitchy fun and worth a special occasion visit.

- This is San Francisco and there's plenty of better kitchy fun out there.

The Tonga Room replaced the Terrace Plunge, an indoor swimming pool that was installed in the Fairmont in 1929. The pool was transformed into the Tonga Room's lagoon. The restaurant was redesigned again in 1967. Some have called the Tonga Room a "historical resource." Citing the Polynesian-themed bar's artificial lagoon, rainstorms, and lava rock, one report said: "The Tonga Room exhibits exceptional importance due to its rarity and as one of the best examples of 'high-style' Tiki bar/restaurant in San Francisco."
author: Eric B.

description:
The Tonga Room is cool! It's kitschy, but here's what I like:

- Tropical drinks. Solid pina colada that almost has a coffee like taste. That may sound weird but it went down smooth.
- Live music ($7 cover). They've got a cover band that plays and they're actually really good!
- Roomy. Unlike most SF bars/lounges, it's actually quite spacious and you can get a table and just chill here for a couple hours.

The only negative is that the food here is pricey. We only tried appetizers but it was $16 for 3 sliders! Eek.
author: Liz L.

description:
I give it 1 star for the atmosphere and nostalgia. My parents use to take me as a kid here. It's more of a tourist/family atmosphere since there is a live band and part of the Fairmont hotel. There is a dance floor, but it's mainly populated with parents and their kids, don't come thinking it's a club.

I'm giving it a low rating because the food was not good and the waiter service was slow...it ended up being a 3 hour dinner....starting from ordering to finishing with no dessert. The waiter never came by to check up on us!

I ordered the hot pot which was decent compared to the other dishes. The rice was very small and doesn't fill you up like it should. My brother ordered the singapore noodles which was EXTREMELY salty as if they dropped the salt shaker in it. 

I also got the pina colada which was really sweet, but still good.

The menu is limited and out dated. In the intro it talks about how "the actor Ronald Reagen" has visited the establishment.
author: Dorris W.

description:
I am really, really besotted with the Tonga Room. Yes, I have a thing for tiki bars (see also: the Pirates of the Caribbean ride at Disneyland) but I also just love it here for the atmosphere and history of the Fairmont, and I attempt to drag everyone who visits SF here. I'm sure 3294832 other reviews mention this, but the Tonga Room is built over and around the Fairmont's old swimming pool, which was built in 1929 and closed (I believe) in the 1930s; it serves as the current lagoon. The Tonga Room opened in 1945 and was redesigned in the late 1960s; it had, when I moved to SF in 2009, been the subject of much "is it or isn't it" debate regarding its historical site status, and plans were made to close it forever (sob!) as the hotel expanded. While it seems it has a reprieve, I'm not sure if it's permanent, so best to get there while you can. The cocktails are expensive, but they're worth every cent -- trust. Go! Sit under an umbrella under the colored lanterns, listen to the thunderstorm every half hour and tell me your $13 drink served in a ceramic coconut wasn't worth it. I always try to get a table on the water, but there are no bad seats. It gets more magical with every Mai Tai, too, I promise. 

In the interest of full disclosure, and as much as it pains me to admit it: I've never had a good meal here.** (Please see update below.) The food is overpriced and bland, and the chicken dishes I have had seemed to have really off-quality meat in them. The fried vegetables were tasty as an appetizer, and their desserts are good, but don't go for dinner (entrees are $28-30). This is a much better (and budget friendly) experience for drinks and appetizers and/or desserts. I have read that they revamped their menu, and I will revisit if I have dinner again. This review is based purely on past experiences.

**One other word of caution: Be sure to check the Facebook page or call ahead if you're thinking of making the trek up to Nob Hill (particularly on foot -- oof!). The Tonga Room is frequently closed for private events -- and closed Mondays -- so it's better to check before you go. There is also, I believe, sometimes a cover charge on weekends.**

EDIT / UPDATE: Since the revamp, the menu has drastically improved! Even though I had no complaints before, drink-wise, I could taste the difference in the cocktails (which are now made with fresh fruit juices, rather than with artificial boxed / canned mixtures). The food menu is excellent, too -- we started with the Quintessential Pu Pu Platter, which is comprised of chicken wings, BBQ Kona pork ribs, shiitake mushroom egg rolls and Dungeness crab rangoon (3 of each), all of which were excellent. For dinner, I had the green curry, which was great, but I tried the grilled Hawaiian ono (with roasted corn, mizuna, mashed sweet potato coconut with green curry sauce) and it was phenomenal; I will definitely order that next time. For dessert, we shared the Tonga Dessert Sampler Platter (mini gingered banana coconut tarts, mochi trio and a mini coconut floating island) -- they were tasty, too.
author: Katie M.

description: Bring in like Hawaii, the theme & experience is unbelievable. My girlfriend I went & had a blast with the band & the food was very good + too notch service!!!! Love this place
author: Dominic A.

description:
A San Fran institution. I come here every 5 or so years to remind myself of the place. Happy Hour has $9 cocktails with the Margarita being better than the Singapore Sling, IMHO. For an extra $10/person you can have the happy hour buffet which consisted of chicken wings, edamame, macaroni salad (wtf?), fried egg rolls, and some other random picnic style salad. Not impressive.

And having been to Benihana in Las Vegas, the Tonga Room just isn't as impressive.
author: Allison J.

description:
Parking:  Just go the Stockton Sutter Garage.  Climb the steps of the Stockton Street Tunnel, and you're less than a 10 minute walk to the restaurant.  I paid $6 for parking on a Wednesday night.

Fun place.  Go in knowing you'll be paying $60 a head for a fun time, and don't obssess over food value/service etc...  A visit here is the sum of it's parts, and it's best not to be in a hurry. We were laid back, stayed for about 2.5 hours, and enjoyed the whole time.  It was great.

And the food was pretty good.
author: NoCal S.

description: Drinks were great, music was great.  Food was limited and subpar: our table ordered the mahi mahi and the seafood hot pot, both had unpleasant flavors, edible but not great.  Our waiter was great but the bussers were way too aggressive trying to take the plates away from the table.  We had to tell them multiple times we were still eating.  We will be back for drinks only.  I wish they had more appetizers and more options that do not involve pork.
author: R X.

description:
This place is loud and tacky. The band on the water is so loud that you can forget about having any conversation. 

However, that's not my main problem with this establishment. My main problem is that they are careless to dietary restrictions. I came here for a company event, for which my company specifically requested vegetarian food. We sit down and are served something that looks like stir fry. I ask if it's vegetarian, and I get an unwavering "Yes."

This being San Francisco, though, I know better.  I then ask "Is there any fish sauce or fish oil in this?" and receive the answer "Oh, I don't know. Let me check." The waiter comes back and says "There's oyster sauce in it. If you have a seafood allergy, the only thing you can eat is the steamed vegetables." I don't have a seafood allergy. I'm vegetarian, which is why I wanted a vegetarian entree. I'm not sure why something prepared with oyster sauce was considered vegetarian.

I then asked if I could get something actually vegetarian, and a bowl full of steamed/fried vegetables was placed in front of me. Seriously? No rice, no tofu (which the non-vegetarian stir-fry had), nothing. The waiter's attitude was "You only eat vegetables, obviously, so I'm giving that to you." 

Not only did they lie to my company in preparing the menu for our event, but then they didn't even have the professionalism to apologize. Never again.
author: Natasha B.

description: Fun spot to unwind. Loved the tasty drinks, the live band playing on a floating boat, and getting down on the dance floor. Wait staff was great.
author: Sheena B.

description: Touristy, but you have to try it at least once. Very tiki bar themed drinks. There is typically a band playing in the middle of the indoor rainforest. I didn't eat here.
author: Leah B.

description: Horrible service.  Hostess was very rude to our group of four. Seated us and didn't bring us menu nor acknowledge us. Was not a busy evening, Natalie was the name of the hostess, disappointing experience.
author: J T.

description:
We came here for my mom's birthday per her request. 

This place has all the potential to be a much better restaurant and lounge. Located within the Fairmont hotel, it definitely caters to the hotel guests/tourists that are staying nearby.  It definitely has the feel of a touristy lounge where non-locals come to have dinner or a drink or two.  They have a live band that starts playing at 8:15 that floats on a tiki hut. The place is dimly lit and is supposed to add to the "ambiance".   I would highly recommend making reservations if you want to have dinner here as the place was quite busy and I did see a line of people waiting when we got here (we had a Friday 6pm reservation).  Definitely plan ahead. 

The food & drink are wayyyyyyy over priced. I would not recommend coming here if you really want value for the price you are paying for dinner. I hear they have better Happy Hour specials so I'd probably go down that route if I ever come back. 

If you do still come here for dinner: I'd recommend 
Huli Huli Chicken
Kalu'a Pork
Pu Pu Platter. 

For dessert, we had the lava sundae, which is definitely great for sharing but once again very overpriced ($24 for dessert, geez!). That definitely can be split among 4-8 people. 

I'd avoid the Hot Pot, not very good. Also, the sliders in the appetizers are blah. 

Our server was nice but a bit annoying in that he kept coming over asking if we wanted more drinks (nice to ask but he was a bit pushy). 

Also, parking can be expensive (as they have 2 hour parking till 9pm). Try and find a metered parking space that ends at 6pm so you can get there right before and not have to pay much.
author: Phillip D.

description:
Ordered Pina Colada which tasted worst.
Food is very mediocre. Desserts are also not great. Way overpriced for what you get.
author: Priyank G.

description: The Tonga restaurant's food is marginal... the Kalua Pork was so dried out it was not edible.  There is a high ratio of families with young children due to the pool with fake rain and lightening.  The staff was very nice.  The adjacent Hurricane Bar had some dancing and happy hour, which attracted a medium aged crowd that appeared to be professionals bundled in winter jeans and down jackets willing to wait in line, pay a cover and ridiculous prices for cocktails.
author: Jes J.

description: We had so much fun here. It was early in the night but still incredibly busy. However, the bartenders were very friendly and attentive. Our drinks were delicious and worth their price. I would love to come back for dinner sometime.
author: Rose H.

description: The first Tiki Bar! Enough said. One of those touristy spots you need to try if in the San Francisco area. You gotta try the Mai Tai's. Average upscale Asian Fusion food.  It's kitchy cool!!! A must do!
author: Bob L.

description:
Of course since Bourdain ate here, I had to follow. An interesting bar built in the former swimming pool. 

We had some Mai Tai and the happy hour buffet. If it weren't for the historical significance of the hotel and cool decor this place would rate two stars. Lo Mein that is over cooked and chicken wings that have no crunch or bite. Typical buffet food you would get at some strip mall in the burbs. 

The drink was ok. They could at least chill the juices as it's warm on the bottom and cold at the top near the ice. Very average.
author: Steven C.

description:
This is not a venue for the regular post-work happy hour gathering. The drinks are way too expensive to make this a habit. What this place IS good for is the occasional escape from reality, with bonus points if you've just had a rough week (which some people in our party did). 

The decor is wonderful. The regular "rainstorms" are pleasant, and the live band, floating on a platform in the middle of the "lake" is totally worth the $5 cover you pay. The food is overpriced, but you should only get drinks here anyway. They serve their drinks in cute tiki cups and glasses, and they are decently mixed drinks for the price. We got a scorpion bowl and really made it worth our while.

If you are craving an escape, this is the right place. But be prepared to shell out some cash.
author: Angeline P.

description:
Loved the 80s music that the band sang on a floating tiki boat in the middle of the pool in the restaurant.  The decor is pirate ship meets Hawaii.  Very cute, clean and classy (but in a nice, casual way).  The food was not too memorable except the large, juicy scallops, skirt steak and the forbidden rice (real buttery and good texture).  

We had a table of 16 people so we bascially ordered almost everything on the menu except dessert since we had a cake.  They charged a cake cutting fee of $26.25 for 15 people (they didn't count the newborn - how nice of them).  Almost half of our bill was alcohol, yet they still charged a cake-cutting fee!  Would never come here with a cake or for the overpriced food.  The Tonga platter serves 2 and it's $25 for two pieces of rib, two fried shrimp, two small chicken skewers, two mini eggrolls and one other thing, I forgot.  The food is really overpriced here, but what do you expect at the basement of the Fairmont!

Also, parking is a nightmare.  You can park at the AMPCO parking lot for $4.75 for 15 min or something ridiculous like that.  Would not recommend for large parties unless you want people to be mad at you!
author: Chris L.

description:
You can't argue with the retro/historic appeal of the Tonga Room which has been around since the 40s in SF. I'd say that if you haven't been, go for a drink and maybe an appetizer knowing that the real star here is the room itself, which is a 'high-style' example of Tiki rooms that were so popular in the 50s and 60s. If it weren't for this I would have given one star!

TERRIBLE FOOD AND MEDIOCRE  DRINKS!
On our particular visit the food was terrible and WAY overpriced. The drinks - just OK. The band did a fine job for what they were doing; if you're into that. (70s-90s Top 40)

SHADY BUSINESS PRACTICE!! PAY IN CASH!!!!
The real disappointment came when they decided that they would charge us an additional 25% above what we actually signed for upon checking our CC account!  This in spite of the fact that we gave a standard 15% tip which was not even well deserved. SHADY!!! To top it all off, our dinner companions got charged DOUBLE what they signed for!! 

Won't be back!
author: Christian M.

description:
If you're looking for a fun, cheesy night at a Tiki Bar feeling like you're at a wedding full of dressed-up older people swaying to not-so-danceable music, this is the place to go.

The drinks are pricey, the ambiance is a bit ridiculous with its "Polynesian" theme, and the music is very white (the band plays on a "boat" in the middle of the pool in the center).

Overall, can be fun time although we'd recommend drinking out somewhere else beforehand and coming with a crowd.
author: Amy D.

description:
We went here this past Friday night and this place is seriously a place to overcharge tourists for not good food, karaoke entertainment at best and rude service.

We ordered ceviche to start and it came with 2 chips!  Wtf? The chips were tiny and more like a decoration than an actual way to eat the ceviche.  Luckily we requested more and I'm surprised that they didn't charge us $10!

The rice was dry, the chicken was dry and the waiters sense if humor was dry .

The real kicker is we spent $200 and they added a $38 entertainment charge to our check without warning and we only had dinner.  They would rather charge you $38 than have you spend $200 to eat.  Total BS!

We live here and always have and would never go to this place for a good dinner of course but we thought the tiki bar would be fun.

Do yourself a favor and go to Rainforest Cafe if you want to see rain and thunder while eating mediocre food, it's cheaper and there is parking!
author: Dana A.

description:
It's all about the spectacle. The experience. The fantastical voyage into a tiki room that takes you miles away from San Francisco and transplants you into a dimly light tropical tavern on the lagoon. 

I suppose "the spectacle" isn't en vogue these days and people are like, so over it when someone tries this hard. But Tonga's ambiance comes off as effortless. Or at least, a lot of effort along a simple concept: fruity drinks, and old hotel pool turned into lagoon (complete with floating boat that doubles as the band's stage), all tucked neatly into the bottom of one of SF's most stately hotels. 

Spaces like this are best enjoyed in good company. Not just because you want to snap a few pics of your pals near the indoor rainstorm, but because of the colorful drinks. Champion among them are the mahoosive vats of alcohol served with lots of comedically large straws that you can share with your entourage. There's really nothing like being served half of the produce section stuck around the rim of a brightly colored bowl of booze. Get it. Slurp it. Love it. 

You may be faced with a cover charge (certain nights when there's entertainment you'll pay). I'm a notorious hater of covers, but didn't really feel too harsh of a sting. After all, the band did play from the boat and you've got loads of vibe to pay for. Plus, the gentlemanly Don B offered to pick up my cover charge. A hat tip to you, my friend.

Hopefully the powers that be keep the place and don't swap it out for something "updated" or "swanky" or "bourbon." Those kinds of spaces do have a place in this world. But this is a treasured piece of San Francisco. A unique oasis that needs to live on.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
My sister & I recently took my parents here for their 45th anniversary celebration.  This restaurant is old SF tradition and has been around since their younger days.  We had heard in the news that there was some debate on how long they would be open for and remembered that our parents wanted to eat here one last time before if and when they closed.  We were glad to hear that  the proposed condo conversion deal fell through, so they'll be around much longer.   We purchased the $31 for $62 deal on Facebook which included the $45 Kao Island Dinner, $12 Mai Tai or Pina Coloda & $5 Cover for the band.  My parents really enjoyed the live band and 5 stars to our waiter.  If you're thinking of making reservations on a Wed, Thur, Sun keep in mind the band doesn't start playing till 8:15pm.  We had 7pm reservations and only stayed for the begining of their first set.

The Kao Island Dinner is served family style and includes: 

Appetizer
-Shiitake Eggrolls
-Tonga Aloha Ribs
-Vegetable Tempura

Entrée
-Fire Cracker Prawns
-Mongolian Beef
-Huli Huli Chicken
-Szechwan Green Beans
-Jasmine Rice

Dessert
-Banana Mousse Cake

We probably could have just gone to Panda Express or a chinese restaurant in Chinatown just two blocks away and ordered it all for $50.  

However on the flip side I would have given the restaurant 5 stars back in '93 when we came here for our freshman winter formal.  I still remember we ordered the lamb chops & steak.
author: Stacey L.

description:
BEWARE OF YOUR CREDIT CARD BILL !!!  

Food was just ok, the ambiance very fun to start a night out on the town.  

Biggest problem -  when we check our credit card bill, they OVERCHARGE US.  THey rounded up our tip to an extra $5.
author: Aida S.

description:
I LOVE this place! I can see this being a tourist lure as it's such an interesting environment in a lovely cute hotel. However, the drinks and food both delivered amazingly. They have a great list of different tiki flavors. They are on the sweet side masking the alcohol successfully but some still too sweet for me. We tried a variety that included both hits and misses for different taste palettes in the group. I was shocked that not everyone liked the ginger in one of the tiki flavors (tasted like a Moscow Mule but I can't remember any of the drink names anymore). That was my favorite! I couldn't stomach the whiskey based one as it was way too smokey for my tastebuds. I definitely recommend trying a few. At the minimum, order the deep fried beef jerky. It was incredible and life changing. They said it would be a long wait ~45minutes for that but we were just starting a fun night there so it was no problem. 

We lucked out and came right when they opened so there was no wait. A long line built up shortly after waiting.
author: Amanda N.

description:
Go early.

It was a Thursday night and we got there at 5:05 (it opens at 5) and got some of the last few seats in the bar section. They don't allow standing in the bar, so there is a wait to even just get drinks. Never seen that before.

We just had drinks. They were a bit expensive for happy hour, but then we found out why, they have a lot of alcohol in them. We watched the pours and they were not at all stingy. I had the Tonga Itch (they need to rename that) and husband had Bora Bora. Both were great. We split a lava bowl (rum & orange juice) for two after that. Thoroughly buzzed from that.

Cool atmosphere, bartenders are not friendly, but they're efficient. I did find a piece of glass in one of my drinks... that was a bit disturbing, but I wasn't sure what to do about it... I was at the end of the drink so I just stopped drinking it. 

Overall, it was worth seeing, but if I were a local, I'm not sure I'd like dealing with the crowds.
author: Lindsey N.

description: I gave it 1 stars due to hearing a rainstorm inside otherwise 0 stars.  It is a tourist place with overpriced underrated drinks.  The band was not exciting.  DO NOT waste your time.  What a joke.
author: Nicholas L.

description:
I'm giving this place four stars mostly for the atmosphere. We tried and failed to make a reservation online. We spent about 15 minutes trying to get through open table and the Tonga room site. We decided to just show up and hope for the best.
After a very confusing conversation with the hostess and which one of us that we were being seated for dinner and one of us thought we were eating at the bar, We waited about 20 minutes at 8 PM on a Sunday and were seated for dinner.
The place is a real trip. My partner has a thing for tiki bars and this pretty much delivered on all of the things we heard and saw including Anthony Bourdain's trip there.
Definitely go when the music is playing since that pretty much makes the night.
We ordered the pineapple drink which was insanely powerful. Neither of us drink much and I could hardly drink it. The food was fine. It's food I would expect for $8-$15 in any other restaurant. $30 for some tofu vegetables and rice seems absurd but the experience was definitely a great one.
author: Janna K.

description:
Love. Love. Love the Tonga Room.  

I have been coming to The Tonga Room for a long time.  You can't come here and have a bad time.  It's just a fact.  No matter the weather outside or your mood -- Tiki ambiance, fruity drinks, band playing on a raft, parquet dance floor, thunder & lightning... 

While I started coming here for happy hours after work years back, I've since realize that this is a key spot to take out-of-town family or friends too.   And, kids think it's pretty cool too.
author: Sam F.

description: After seeing the tonga room on t.v, my boyfriend and I had it on our list. When we made a trip to San Francisco, we made sure to stop by. While we weren't very hungry, we knew we wanted to grab some drinks. If anything, we wanted to go for the experience. We ordered a bowl drink for two, which was great! A quick trip to the tonga room turned out to be one of the best nights in San Fransisco.
author: Alexis M.

description:
This place is a trip.  In the basement of the fairmont, and a little unexpected.  You walk into a real deal tiki lounge complete with rain and a pool in the middle.  It was a little weird, a little trippy, and a whole lot of fun.

Drinks are ridiculously priced  - $12-20 - but damn those things are STRONG.  After the first, I was like woah, after 2 - I was buzzed, and then 3 = 3 sheets to the wind.  The food selection was whatever at best, and the service was very much attentive and on the ball.

Would I hang out here regularly?  Probably not.  But it's worth a trip if you've never been - and certainly fun for tourists.
author: Arthur Y.

description:
I returned and had even more drinks before AND enjoyed their food!

Tasty! The service was slow at times, but it was an incredibly busy weekend and there was a bunch of us coming from all over the bay area. Although annoyed, the hostess did save our reserved table and we got right in after passing a very long line. 

We all enjoyed a full meal--appetizers, entrees and desserts. Don't forget drinks. I tried everything from the Bora Bora Horror (try saying that drunk. JUST TRY IT!) to the pineapple full of booze. Also really liked the Banana Chi-Chi and the Blue Hawaiian (RIP Elvis) was on point. This place knows how to make a drink, and like a potato chip, you don't stop at one. 

Our servers made it a really fun night--lots of joking and fun. For a busy Saturday night, didn't have to wait too long for anything, and I made sure to order a fresh drink fairly often. 

The band had a new singer who made sure I had my 15 minutes of birthday fame. He not only gave me a shout out from the floating hut, but took a special request and sang a song I had asked for, which was much appreciated. He was a lot of fun and a better singer than the woman who I had seen perform previously. The songs were a good mish mash of old cover band standards to tasteful more recent stuff. The band definitely helped in us having a really good time.

All of our entrees were well prepared and nicely presented. My mom got a steak that was large enough to share with 2 other people. I had salmon with a side order of broccolini and that was delicious. Only complaints came from the two who were dumb enough to order noodle dishes. Though they said it was good, it wasn't snazzy enough to be an entree,  but better off as a side dish. Whatever, they got some steak and broccolini and whatever else the rest of us didn't want. 

We all ordered different desserts, and I received some sort of flaming thing because it was my birthday (I was pretty deep into my drinks at this point). Everything was incredible--my favorite was the chocolate cake and green tea combo. 

At the end of our meal, one of our servers took our picture and wrangled us into buying a large photo package--not cheap, but definitely something you want to do once in your life for a special occasion. I now have a matchbook with a picture of me and my bestie on it that I truly treasure from that night. 

Not  cheap, but a great place for a memorable special occasion--birthdays, anniversaries, etc. Make a reservation up to two weeks ahead. Buy the photo package, why dontcha.  ORDER THE PINEAPPLE OF DOOM!
author: Bianca U.

description:
NO,

Don't go here.  It's a bit, well, it's a HUGE amount of hype!

Done!
author: Dean P.

description: Rude door man that had no idea how to speak English. This is not being rude just a fact.
author: Mark B.

description: The ambiance was exceptional.  The food was heavily overpriced for 'what you get'. $28 scallops that were bland, $32 for under seasoned ribs (no salt at table)...  Maitai was great, but not worth $14 a pop.  I was here 20 years ago, may be worthy of another visit in 20 more years.  Maybe not.
author: Coco L.

description: I love this place great drinks ....the most importantly Tina is the greatest server of all TIME, she deserves a raise.. everyone needs a someone like her.
author: Rynell W.

description:
Do you love the seventies? If you're a fan of the decade or just a fan of the Jackson Five, you will looooove this place! The drinks are so strong that they will knock you on your butt and leave you acting like a lunatic...so beware. I really enjoyed watching the band sail out on a tahitian barge while taking in a mystical rain shower that seemed to come from nowhere.
    I really can't remember when I've had so much fun in going out to a bar. I went with a large group of people who pretty much ordered every drink on the menu. They were all good, but especially terrific is the pineapple rum drink that comes out in a huge whole pineapple. AMAZING. 
   The people watching here is also highly recommended. I think I saw everything from Travolta dance moves to "the running man" out on the dance floor. AWESOME. Get your Tonga on....you won't be disappointed.
author: Julie V.

description:
My boyfriend and I saw Anthony Bourdain come here on his show and had to try it out! So we came in for drinks one Friday night. I must say the decor is great, very exotic and unique for a tiki bar- not tacky like most.
The water in the middle of the room brings a fun tropical vibe to the restaurant, every 30 minutes it "rains" and "thunderstorms" which is a fun experience for kids and adults alike. One weird thing is they played Hawaiian music all night- not Tongan. At least for me being from Hawaii, it was nice to hear music I don't hear much anymore. The live entertainment began an hour after we got there and the stage floats in the water. The musicians were fun. When we left we saw an additional entertainment charge for those coming in once the entertainment started.
Since we didn't have reservations we just had drinks and an appetizer. Wow this place is pricey! Expect $13 and up for drinks! $15 and up for appetizers.
I had a lychee martini, others had a Zombie and the piña colada. The waiter warned my friend that the piña colada was not a traditional one because it was made with Jamaican rum which is darker and molasses to sweeten it so it has a coffee flavor to it which he was right! I can't say I liked it however. The lychee martini was delicious that is until I ate a lychee and it was soaked in alcohol which tastes like rubbing alcohol- the fruit flavor was ABSENT! And that completely ruined the drink for me. I've tried many lychee Martini's home in Hawaii and here in the Bay Area- although a "drunken lychee" sounds cute people order this for the lychee flavor which is sweet. I couldn't continue drinking it after that horrible taste in my mouth!
The calamari was standard, nothing great but we scarfed it down because we were hungry. 
Overall good experience, save it for special occasions because you shouldn't pay these prices on a regular!
author: Ciara C.

description:
What a disappointment! I showed up on a weeknight with my family. No reservations, and expecting a possible wait. I really just wanted to show my kids the room, as they have never been before. The door man was so rude, he started by telling us to stand in the corner. (There was no one waiting, and restaurant was not busy) when the hostess got back she was getting ready to seat is and he snapped at us, there would be a cover charge/drink min even with dinner. Again, whatever with the charge, but he was so rude and unwelcoming. I really thought about tourists who come from out of town and how they must think that this was incredibly out of line. I was embarrassed for our lovely city. We should be welcoming business, not snapping at people who are willing to pay for these landmarks. 
Huge disappointment. 
I didn't even want to give them one star.
author: Janee A.

description: Coolest bar/restaurant! Great atmosphere! Thunderstorm and boat inside! Great drink bowls for two. Happy hour is a must, 5-7pm and buffet for $10!
author: Alex B.

description:
This has to be my favorite place in the entire city, or maybe even the entire country. Despite walking by it for the past 25 years and having several people had tell me this was a happening place I still had not ventured in until Nov. 2011 and I completely wished I had been known what a gem this was. The Tonga Room is an SF institution (my parents frequented while dating in the 70's) and has been maintained and updated to keep its classy Gilligan's Island theme.

What I LOVE about the Tonga Room is that it is family friendly, you can bring your little kids and they can enjoy the rockin' dance floor and 80's music along with you. If I threw myself a birthday party, this is the place I would choose!


The food is also really good as expected with the Fairmont tradition. Expect a long list of tiki bar type drinks served in pineapples, etc. as well as some non-alcoholic punch type options.
author: Tricia K.

description:
Was staying at The Fairmont Hotel for a conference, and when I found out the Tonga Room was located there, we had to check it out. We heard that there was a happy hour from 5-7, so we got there right after 5 and were seated immediately.

We ordered a round of the world famous Mai Tai's and grabbed some plates to check out the buffet. The buffet consisted of an assortment of items: chow mein, spicy edamame, macaroni salad, rice, hot wings, sweet & sour wings, egg rolls w/ peanut sauce and cut up fresh fruit. I found the spicy edamame delicious and the egg rolls surprisingly good. As we sat down with our plates, our drinks arrived. 

Presentation was great, complete with pineapple wedge and paper umbrella. The Mai tai's are good and quite strong, so one goes a long way! We stayed awhile, sipped our drinks, enjoyed the buffet and took in the kitschy tiki decor and enjoyed the indor rain storms. 

If you are in the area, I highly recommend checking it out, it is a very unique experience!
author: Danielle G.

description:
Food: Excellent mix of Hawaiian and American food. Very interesting selection ranging from calamari to fine steaks 

Service: Quick and responsive to the customer's needs 

Restaurant Ambiance: Dark, with a live band performance and plenty of palm trees

Price: Around 140 dollars for a party of three, plus I believe 30 dollars for the family photo stamped The Fairmont at the end of the meal

Drinks: Plenty of non alcoholic and alcoholic drinks 

People: Tourists visiting San Francisco as well as the hotel guests of The Fairmont  

Parking: Valet or roadside 

Attire: Casual to Dressy

View: Island with hut and live performing band
author: JK C.

description:
"I wanna know have you ever seen the rain?" More specifically, have you ever seen it rain indoors?...as you're enjoying a fabolicious dinner?...listening to a live band playing afloat a massive pool of water? 

The Tonga room is one hell of a party spot. It's a hawaiian/island getaway themed venue; Tiki heads, torches, and even a pirateship's wheel are just a few of the many festive decorations. There are many seats around the room, perfect for big and small groups. Exotic dim lighting draws the attention toward the pool of water in the middle of the venue. There's a little boat that the band plays on in the middle of the water. As they play, water would cascade from the ceiling and trickle into the water. There's a bar lounge and mini dance floor as well for you extreme party goers ;).  

Not to mention that the food is delicious! The whole venue was reserved for our big party and the food was served buffet style. There was a generous offering of ribs, pork buns, potstickers, siu mai, eggrolls and plenty of restocking! They even had little togo boxes that we could fill and take home, now that's what I call service! Cocktails and mocktails were served too...although the virgin lime margarita I got one wasn't as tasty as I expected. That doesn't really matter because I had a great time and recommend it to anyone who's down for an exotic experience!
author: Tina O.

description:
I never thought anything with spam in it would be tasty, but the spam fried rice was great! 

We went for happy hour and thoroughly enjoyed the whole scene - rainstorm, happy hour buffet, tropical drinks. Reservations are a must if you actually want to sit down - even in the lounge. We got lucky and found some seats at the bar.
author: Angela L.

description:
While The Tonga Room is a definite tourist attraction, it is lacking as a restaurant. The atmosphere is fun & certainly different. The historic nature & grandiosity is impressive. The menu is comprised of different, fusion-like food. It is pricey & the food isn't worth the price paid. A PF Chang's has far better food for half the price. The drinks are great but expensive with the range from $12-18 per drink. The staff are friendly & the service is good. We were there on a night with the band playing. They weren't bad if you like poor 70s song renditions. 

Overall I think you would be hard pressed to find a local San Franciscan here. This is a place better in concept than reality. It is  absolutely a trap for hotel guests & visitors who, once seated at a table, are stuck with a high-priced, mediocre meal in an entertaining venue. My advice: find other gems in this great city to dine at while in town.
author: Amy R.

description: We wen there last month (Four friends, my wife and I). Three of the party were vegetarians. We really enjoyed the vibe, the music and the food. We all danced a while as well, The food was very nice and the service was excellent.
author: Manu S.

description:
The good: 
Michaela in the bar is s great server and absolutely made our night. We were a party of twelve for a 30th birthday and she helped us secure a couple tables and was incredibly attentive; kind enough to bring the girls water after seeing how many dragon bowls, Mai Tais, etc. they had consumed. Those tropical drinks can sneak up on you and Michaela knew it and helped the ladies out big time. She was great. 

The bad: 
Let me preface this by saying that I initially made a reservation for 10 knowing that the Tonga Room fills up on a Friday night I wanted to ensure that our party would be accommodated. I was unaware that reservations required a full dinner service. The hostess was kind enough to call and fill me in in this at which point I told them that we were just coming for drinks and apps but would definitely put up a table worthy bill. When our party arrived they were again informed of the dinner order requirement (quite rudely as if the Tonga Room was not for our kind) so we said never mind we'll just occupy the bar. The hostess with the English accent was polite enough;  the other hostess with the short hair was incredibly rude and would not let members of our party in while we waited at tables in the bar. It seems that they were upset about the reservation fiasco and we're trying to thwart our good time. I still cannot believe the attitude that the short haired hostess displayed, people like her do not belong greeting guests or interacting with them. Her attitude of superiority and rudeness is the bane of the service industry. It's the Tonga Room not the Fontainebleau , chilll out.
author: Ryan P.

description:
The basement tiki bar in the landmark Fairmount Hotel. The fake rainstorms on the half-hour are entertaining, as is the clientele. A man in a dinosaur suit walked in with his friends and drank one of those monster-sized cocktails meant to be shared with friends via long straws. Hey, it's San Francisco; I've seen stranger...

Anyway, not really impressed with this place. The decor is as cheesy as one would expect for a tiki bar, and the drinks are as sugary as one would expect from a tiki bar. The skimpy wine list was a big disappointment for me, a fervent believer in the proposition that sugar and alcohol do not mix. 

Expensive and cheesy, that's my estimation of this place. I won't be back.
author: Angela L.

description: We had a cockroach crawl on our chair. too bad we saw it after we ate.  Nobody seemed to care. Our waiter excused the behavior stating that the building is old. "Unfortunately, we can't catch them all." Ummm. I don't think so buddy!
author: Sylvia M.

description:
The food and atmosphere is so fun! Ordered a soup and the pork Ohana style. The smoked pork was very flavorful, but a tad expensive. 

Order one drink, came out tooooo sweet and sour. The manager walked by and asked us how things were. We told him, and he made us another one, but less sweet. Came out and I found that it was less sweet, but still too much. 

Overall great service, good food, and drinks need some work. Might have been that we were there during a quieter period.
author: Matt L.

description:
We stayed at the Fairmount for my birthday and had reservations here for dinner. 

This place is like a throw back to the 60s. Such a fun themed restaurant, and my boyfriend loved the moving stage and rain. The singer was also really good. 

The drinks were fantastic, and I knew they would be going in based on others' reviews. I was worried about the food, as others had said it was only so-so based on the cost. I disagree! We ordered the sliders as an app, and I had the short ribs. The boyfriend had the mahi mahi. All three dishes were phenomenal. 

We had such a good time. This is the go-to place to take non-locals, or for special occasions.
author: Gina B.

description:
Yes! Shaka rice, Tonga sampler platter, pork buns.  Drinks: Hurricane, Zombie, Mai tai.  I have to say, I really enjoyed all of it.  Me and Mrs N that is.  The music was live and was a plus.

What's not to live about the Tonga Room?  The walk from BART was loads of fun, but that's not really about the restaurant.  It pricey, but it's a food experience. I'm a sucker Polynesian or Tiki type places, so I'm all about this experience.  I'll be back....
author: Steve N.

description: Atmosphere is pretty neat, music was good, and it was a fun place to go for a date night.  Kinda pricey, but what isn't in the city?  Cover charge for music, along with the high prices held me back from giving 5 stars, but the service was good and we had a great time.
author: Larry J.

description:
This bar is amazing. Super fun decor and live music to dance to. The drinks are strong and a bit on the expensive side. I had a mai thai, it was delicious and super sweet. It was also served in a cool faux-coconut glass. 

I need to come back here to try some of their food, the menu looked pretty good but I had just finished dinner...
author: Stephanie T.

description:
After a hellish two weeks of work, I was reminiscing a recent vacation of sun, sand, and tropical beverages. I wanted a damn cocktail umbrella in my drink, and nothing less would suffice. My yearning for tiki drinks brought me here and my experience was decent.

The ambience is totally kitschy with the boat  in the middle of the swimming pool complete with 70s wedding band, pirate ship-themed accents, and little umbrellas in the drinks. Hell, the little umbrellas were half the reason I came here in the first place. I ordered a Zombie and my companion the Singapore Sling. I enjoyed my zesty Zombie and my bf compared his drink to a "Poor Man's Wet Woody" (if you've ever been to Gar Woods in N. Lake Tahoe, you know what this is). 

Here's the catch. Of course you'd expect to pay $12-15 for a tiki cocktail. That's a given. But the food is seriously, and no pun intended, overpriced hotel food. We ordered the $30 puu-puu platter and yeah the food was good but obviously overpriced for what it was. This bar is in a hotel and clearly milks the "expensive hotel food" stereotype for all it's worth. 

Service was great, everyone was cheerful and didn't make a fuss that we didn't have reservations. I'll definitely be coming back the next time I need a tropical drink (and getaway) locally.
author: Liz G.

description:
I live only 35 miles away but despite my endless searching for tiki bars this is my first visit to the Tonga Room. The space is beautiful with super high ceiling, tiki decor with the addition of pirate nautical and comfortable bamboo upholstered chairs. 

Here's how it works- happy hour is 5:00- 7:00 Wednesday thru Friday in the bar area behind the desirable pool area. But in the back corners there are two circles of table seating that are fairly close to the pool. Happy hour drinks are $8.50 for singles and $13.00 for bowls. The happy hour buffet is $10.00 for spam fried rice (sparse meat), chow mein and wings. Every 30 minutes there is a thunderstorm with thunder and rain water on the pool. Drinks are not up to the Tiki Ti- the Scorpion Bowl for two is good and not too sweet, but the Mai Tai tastes off and the Bora Bora is too sweet. A strawberry daiquiri was sweet but delicious. 

The desirable seating by the pool opens at 6:00, where the drinks are $12 but the selection better. Here the dinner menu is served with main courses about $25. At 8:00 a band plays on a raft in the pool but I didn't stay for that. 

If you arrive for happy hour at 4:40 you might be the first person in line and can get a really good seat in the front corner of the back corner bar seating area and life is good. Latecomers sit way in the rear and have limited view but they had no less fun.

So come to soak up the atmosphere and enjoy good service while downing sweet Tiki drinks. My server recommended the Bora Bora and when I asked whether it was good she responded "it's the Tonga Room" so take it whatever way you want. I'm glad I came and would come more often if the location was more convenient to drivers. Just bring a little lime juice to tone down the drinks.
author: Jon S.

description: Very different  and unique spot when in San Francisco. You would not expect to find a place like this in the city and that is why it is great.
author: German R.

description:
Went here with my boyfriend after seeing Bourdain go there on the Layover.  I know another reviewer followed the same direction and wasn't impressed, but I really enjoyed myself.  The place is super unique with a really fun atmosphere.  Our reservation coincided with the live music beginning, which was a treat.  You should ABSOLUTELY make a reservation.  The line to get in was at least forty people long when we left (and it is not worth that).  

Pros: live music, "rain," and the food was delicious.  I highly recommend getting the family style set menu--you get a little bit of this and a little bit of that and it was all really quite good.

Cons: service was slow and we got charged the cover fee (seven bucks each) despite the fact that we ate a two hundred dollar meal.  Not the best way of encouraging diners to come back.

I'd definitely go back at some point in the future, but probably not that often.
author: Shannon B.

description: First let me start off by saying this place is a scam!!! They charge you a cover charge without any warning on your card and they apparently tip themselves. We had a group of four and split the bill 4 ways so we had to pay 33 each which is fine so I put 33 no tip cause I was tipping cash.
