Then I checked my account the next day and I was charged 66 so I call the hotel and ask to speak to the manager. This manager was so unhelpful saying he'll call accounting and find out what what happen and call me back. I've been waiting a few days and still no call so I called again and he told me it should be only 33 not 66 so check it again so I told him I have bank statements here and it says 66 and 33 was never returned. Why was I charged 66 and receipt even says 33 so where the fuck did the number 66 come from. I was then told hey it happens like it's okay... Needless to say we went back and forth for another half hour before he said he'll call me back and hung up... This is total bullshit and will never be returning ever again
author: Eric R.

description: You pay for the ambiance. Food lacks identity trying to mash Asian Indian and Chinese cuisine.
author: Gerald H.

description:
Honestly, I expected better after all the hype. Consider this a 2.5

The good - The live music on Friday night was great (entertainment fee added to your bill ???). The water falling from the roof onto the pool in the middle of the restaurant was cool. Great atmosphere! The drinks were strong....

The so-so - I would call it cruise ship style cuisine. Not anywhere close to the level of my other Fairmont experiences. The service was poor with too few servers trying to do too much.
author: Glenn S.

description:
Dark, dingy, oily food, horrible service, and expensive!!

The meat was very chewy and cheap tasting. There was nothing memorable about this meal. The service was unacceptable, they didn't refill water, they seemed to be depressed, and they only time they came to our table was to try to push us to drink more of their overpriced drinks. 

The "band" was depressing with no soul.

~~ $5 cover charge even if you're eating there.. wtf?

If this is supposed to be  a festive place why is it in a dark cave with strobe lights trying to imitate lightning? It seemed like a dungeon.

2 stars because of the novel ambiance albeit not really glamourous it's still different.
author: Kathy S.

description:
I'm shocked to see the 3.5 rating as this was the highlight of my recent San Fransisco trip. The ambiance was unlike any other. I can leave you with a million $ tip: start things off with the Lave Bowl for drinks.

Also, get there before 8 p.m. to avoid the cover charge.
author: Tim P.

description: Was last here in October of 2008, and was very impressed with both the drinks and the cuisine!  Great décor & ambiance in yet another one of San Francisco's classic dining locations!
author: Ken S.

description:
I love the Tonga room- its such a cool old school space- in such a beautiful hotel! I never thought much of the food or drink, would usually just go for the retro cheesy cool atmosphere! 

But-- guess what- its a whole new food and drink menu now!  Blackstrap molasses Pina Coladas and finely frenched chicken wings (I thought they only did that for lamb-apparently I was wrong!)  at the buffet has given this place a whole new level of sophistication. 

I spent 4 hours last night at the bar and drank 3 exotic cocktails all revamped and adjusted for todays modern saavy cocktail consumer. I will go again and will bring friends- both old school and modern ones alike! 

If you haven't been to the Tonga room in the past few weeks you must GO NOW and experience their revamped menu!
author: Rachel Z.

description: Came here for a friend's birthday. I really like the falling rain in the center of the room, it reminds me of Las Vegas. The atmosphere is fun, the decor is nice, and the drinks are good. The only thing is that the food and drinks are way overpriced. Other than that, this place is a pretty cool spot to chill with friends.
author: Christine B.

description: It's definitely kitch. I'm surprised something so tacky/corny is in the Fairmont. They do make up for the decor with excellent (and strong) drinks. I tried the Singapore Sling, the Mai Thai (what they're known for) and the giant pineapple drink. They're super tropical without being cloyingly sweet. They're well balanced drinks that will give you the courage to go up to that overly made up indeterminably aged lady that's a bit too old to be wearing a skirt that short :). Drink up!
author: Alice W.

description: Great surroundings and the bar tenders are on point. Great location with a very nice crowd..music is cool but the drinks are what we're here for.
author: Terry E.

description:
good for occasions just to try it once is enough for me  

Pros:
very nice ambiance
good music
unique

Cons: 
Pricey
Food is Bad 
slow service
loud
the drinks taste nasty!
$7 charge for live band music 

we order:
calamari
soup
curry veggy
fish 
rice 
cocktail drinks for 2 and our Total is $140.00 it's ok because it's our anniv but we will never come back
author: Ruzzet P.

description: Crazy place!!! They have live music on a barge! Great music great drinks, terrible prices for drinks that are well worth it!
author: Johnny G.

description: What's not to love?  It's a cheesy tiki bar in the heart of a city that you wouldn't expect to find a cheesy tiki bar in.  I've never eaten here so (sorry Anthony Bourdain worshipers) but I've been here several times for drinks.  The one thing I love about the Tonga Room - no tv.  So you can fully enjoy the music or have a decent conversation when the band isn't playing.  Pro tip - take a cab or cable car here.  It's a heck of a walk!
author: Mark M.

description:
Great atmosphere for a date. I loved the live band and the thunder time.
Foods are okay.
author: Ruth K.

description:
Kitschy kitschy kitschy.

$10 all you can eat buffet and happy hour specials. Strong rum cocktails, and really fantastic rain and lightning/thunder display after 6pm. 

You have to make a reservation for a pool side table and the service wasn't all that great, but it's an SF institution and we couldn't leave the country without going for a quick drink.
author: May T.

description: Had Thanksgiving at the bar here. Though the dining area was completely booked, we were easily able to get spots at a table near the water by just ordering from the bar. Strong and delicious tropical drinks, decent Asian-Hawaiian fusion food, and great ambiance. Loved the Zombie I had. Prices are a little high, but I totally expected it to be that way. The drink portions are generous, and food prices aren't that bad if you stick to just ordering appetizers to share around the table. A must-visit for drinks in San Francisco. It's a fun tiki bar experience.
author: Katie B.

description: We had very good service but the band played 70's tunes, very interesting atmosphere.
author: Tim R.

description: Cool, kitchy  place, could use more bar seating. Ahi appetizer was fabulous!
author: Lisa K.

description:
Hard working staff, but understaffed.  Was seated quickly, but the wait for drinks, for food, for dessert were each uncomfortably long.  Menu was very limited and the food was average at best.  A little on the pricey side given the decor was a 1950-ish Tonga and Tiki look.  Seemed old and musty-looking although not musty smelling.  The venue has a band that starts at 8pm... But were quite late (30 min) at getting started so we didn't get to hear the.

Overall... Very unimpressive.  Given the Fairmont's elegance, I wondered what this run down shanty was doing here.  I'd give it a one star, but, man... Those very few waiters were working their tails off.

There are plenty of other eateries of like kind right down the street in Chinatown that beat this place hands down. Take a walk and visit those instead.
author: David M.

description:
Awesome environment. Live entertainment, indoor rain, and drunk people dancing - can't get any better than that. They *sometimes* charge a cover? $7 I heard.

Definitely go for one of the punch bowls - Scorpion or Lava. Found both to be strong and will give you the worst hangover the next day. But it was fun while it lasted! Would definitely come back again.
author: Michelle L.

description: Very meh. The band/music was good, but the "experience" was sooooo blah. You can't sit down because "there's no open seating" for cocktails. Not enough bartenders to serve up the drinks. THIS PLACE NEEDS JON TAFFER to RESCUE THE BAR!! This is a place in search of an identity.... move along, people, there's nothing to see here. Even the dramatics of rain, Thunder are awful. Better experience at The Rainforest Cafe at the Wharf!!
author: JM C.

description: Reflecting on my meal this evening, I am compelled to give no more than one star to this place despite the amazing atmosphere. We are staying at the Fairmont for the weekend and decided to check out this SF landmark. Needless to say, it was incredibly disappointing.  Even for two people who were fresh off the plane and starving, the food was literally  inedible - way too salty. (We are eating Jack in the Box now to compensate our stomachs, which is superior in taste). And the drinks were just alright - a bit sugary but tolerable. The service was sub par for the prices you pay to sit in this establishment. Do not go on an empty stomach.
author: Gloria C.

description:
I kind of have a love hate relationship with this restaurant. Kind of like the menu at Trader Vics its lacking sometimes. And I'm usually to drunk to remember what I had here before that was good. 

Except this last time I did remember and had it again. It was the Hupia Prawns or something like that. Prawns with mushrooms, sugar snap peas and carrots in a bacon, coconut cream sauce. The sauce is so good I just want to eat it over rice like cereal. My husband had the duck which was OK just to many onions in the side dish. 

The drinks kind of suck to. There's just something wrong with the rum drinks. I just don't like them. I haven't been happy with any drink that I ordered off their menu. I even went pretty plain with the banana daiquiri and that sucked too. 

I do however love the moat in the middle with the rain and lightning sound effects. They got new lights or something because the lightning is really cool this time. 

Then there's the band. I love the band. I love singing along because no one can hear you sound bad. And you know what this time they even sang Billy Joell. I requested Billy last time and they said no we don't do any of his tunes. Well they must of caught on because it was a big hit. The band is the only reason they have 4 stars.
author: Ivy R.

description: It was nice and cozy. We had their oyster and delicious. The beers they had were excellence. I would recommend this place. The price was reasonable and service were quick.
author: Regina D.

description:
HAHAHA....so do you want to be thrown back into OLD San Francisco??  Here you go.  This is a historic tiki bar with strong tropical concoctions that evoke dreams of a Gilligan's Island gone awry!!!  And the walls and decorations scream of an adult version Disney's Pirates of the Carribean ride complete with dark lighting.  The person missing is Capt Jack Sparrow himself!!!  Nestled on the bottom levels of SF's also historic Fairmont Hotel, a grand place to visit itself full of famous stories and some say even....GHOSTS....

If you are from middle America visiting the big city, this is a fun getaway that you might appreciate and have fun with.  There's even a small dance floor where you can boogie when the live band comes out for their set every hour.   This place is great fun for a group of your friends to enjoy several hours of your San Francisco evening.  Though unless you are staying at the Fairmont Hotel, I'd say go try out some other local places too.  The last thing is that on the weekends there is a line to wait unless you arrive early or were already eating inside.  So come early or make reservations!!!!

The food is reasonable when it comes to taste but who's really here for that?  THE DRINKS!!
author: Cary L.

description: Had dinner here last week.  I wanted to like the food more, but everything was bland and tasteless.  I think the best dish we got was the appetizer sampler with chicken satay, coconut shrimp and egg rolls and even that was on the tasteless side.  But the atmosphere is fun and the drinks are good so I'm giving them 3 stars.  I wouldn't come back here to eat, but the Tonga Room is a fun place for drinks!
author: Elena N.

description:
We were staying at the Fairmont Hotel, so we had to take the grandchildren here for dinner. We had the Lamb Curry (fair), Tonga Platter (also fair), the Thai Basil Tiki (ok), and the Little Huli.

This is a unique restaurant with occasional tropical thundershowers. Fun for the kids. Unfortunately the food is average and the service has a breezy, insincere serve-food-to-the-masses-of-tourists attitude.

Atmosphere - 5 STARS
Location - 5 STARS
Food - 3 STARS
Service - 2 STARS
Value - 3 STARS

A solid 3 STARS here.
author: John D.

description: You truly are paying for the ambience.  The food is not worth the prices.  I was expecting a bit more "wow" with the tropical rainstorms that were advertised as really it was a sheet of water that ran every so often. Fun to go at least once but I won't be going a second time.
author: Jeanette W.

description:
All you guys can say what you want because this place is MY SHIT! And by that, I mean it is exactly the kind of shit that I love every single day of the week. I don't think they're open on Mondays and Tuesdays, so that kinda sucks. But I love this place because it is like a bar, and a time machine. 

If you come on a weekend or after 8 or so, you are probably going to have to wait in a line. If you don't like waiting in lines, you might want to make reservations, but they are by no means neccessary. 

But seriously, Tonga Room is the shit. I'll spare you the extensive history, because you can read that on their website and I'm sure lots of other people have mentioned it, too, but it is its unique and authentic retro atmosphere that draws people in here year after year. Yes, there is a band that plays on a floating platform in the middle of a fancy tiled pool. There are also Rainforest Cafe - esque "thunderstorms" every once in a while. There are also little straw hut/cabana booth tables (I don't know what else to call them) and even a small dancing area by the water.

The drinks vary in strength (some you can barely feel and some hit you hard right away) but they are all delicious. They're on the pricier side, with most of them being in the $12 - 15 range, but it's a nice bar, and they're pretty ingredient - heavy drinks. I'm also a sucker for anything served in a pineapple. As far as the food goes, I've only ever had appetizers here, but they have a great variety, and they've all been really good. Especially the coconut shrimp. Damn I love that coconut shrimp.
author: Angela S.

description:
Me and my friends went to Tonga for happy hour.  I always wanted to go there and I wish I didn't. I think when Anthony Bourdain went there, he was either high or paid to speak so highly about Tonga, because Tonga is a tourists' trap with crappy food and drinks. 

If you think you get a good deal by checking out their happy hour, you are making a huge mistake, drink you'll be getting will be served in a regular glass, not the special glass that you would see on a regular menu. Therefore, you'll be getting a much smaller drink as well. 

Their "special" drinks, advertised to be really strong, are pretty much alcohol free and contain only a strong amount of sugar. I would not call them special at all. 

The buffet is the biggest waste of money. You'll get a choice of having a soggy chow mein, old and dry fried rice, or tasteless spring rolls. 

The inside looks sort of tropical but super old and outdated, plus the rain drops look really pathetic and cheaply made. 

We have so many great happy hour places in San Francisco... Don't waste your time and money... make yourself a favor, DO NOT go there!!!!
author: Andrei S.

description: Once in a life time experience. The scorpion bowl they no longer start on fire but it is strong and gets the job done quick. Also he thunderstorm and rain and floating bar are awesome with a decent size dance floor for the ladies!
author: Melissa D.

description:
Touristy & Silly

the band that comes floating out is pretty cheeseball. i mean i expected kitchy, but this place felt like i was stuck at a Tommy Bahama party (old people included). music is like "adult contemporary" so be prepared for lots of old people gettin' down to songs you listened to as a kid at weddings, that your parents dragged you to. 

another yelper mentioned that this place has potential & i agree. i think if they didn't cater to the 50 year old+ crowd & make it so touristy it could be a real fun little gem. i kinda expected better from a fairmont hotel. 

drinks yes, they are overpriced. but that's because you're at a touristy hotel bar. my favorite was the one that comes in the pineapple. 

food there is decent. 

service is great. 

would i go back? no. i'm not a clubber, but when i go to a tiki bar, i want it to feel tiki. this looks the role, but feels much more geriatric
author: X-tine N.

description:
I came here with a good friend and I had the Butterfish. Do give it a try. We did like the taste of the drinks but didn't think they were that strong, that is until we stood up. Nice.

2 Lava drinks $20 each
1 Ahi Poke   $16
1 Butterfish $28.
Chix Satay   $20

with tip $126.00

The price to happiness ratio is great. It is and adventure, especially when it rains. Give it a try.
author: Justin S.

description:
So me and bf are sitting on the couch watching Anthony Bourdain's new show, The Layover, and our lovely city by the bay is featured.  Among the awesome places Tony slurred his way through was the Tonga Room.  

We looked at eachother and thought... "why have we not gone there?"  Sure it's kitschy and cheesy and (WAAAAY) overpriced, but it's a City landmark, within a landmark.  So we gathered up some friends and went the next night.. ha!  

Would I go back... yes, but stirctly with out of towners.  It's a bit of a trap--okay, it's a huge tourist trap--but SF needs to just own it and love it.  I can't believe they were gonna shut this place down!  Where else are you gonna see a thunderstorm inside! (oh god please dont say the Rainforest Cafe!!)
author: Olivia D.

description: Yeah yeah, it is a cheesy tourist trap, but so what? The idea of jazz musicians playing on a barge that floats in a deep swimming pool in the middle of the restaurant while fake rain occasionally pours around them is unique if not fascinating... good food doesn't hurt either! Our server was pleasant, knowledgeable and efficient. We would definitely recommend this place to all the visitors of San Francisco... just don't forget to make reservations!
author: Violeta H.

description:
Something that everyone should experience while in SF. Is it cheesy and over the top? Perhaps. But if you're going to drink 1,000 calorie cocktails in tiki glasses in the middle of an urban rainforest, it comes with the territory. 

The bartenders are awesomely smiley and friendly, and make the booziest of cocktails I had while I was in San Francisco. They come with a hefty price tag, but three was more than enough for me and well worth the experience. 

While you're there, make sure you check out the ornate and breathtaking lobby at the Fairmont. It's even more beautiful after a few Singapore Slings.

Note: Attire is dressy. I felt pretty underdressed in my jeans, as most people are visiting for drinks after work or they're glitzed up and ready for a night on the town.
author: Gloria C.

description:
I had great expectations for this place. I'm an avid Anthony Boudain fan and had to check this place out based on his recommendation.

Well my faith in Bourdain is now shattered. Went with a large group of friends, getting reservations was almost impossible. It's crazy expensive for what is it and the food is far from fantastic. Band was cheezy, only thing that saved the night was the booze and good company..womp womp, two thumbs down
author: Giligirl G.

description: Saturday was our first time here, Roberto helped us at our table, great customer service , good food and drinks
author: Roger L.

description:
We love the 5 to 7 happy hour at the Tonga Room. $10 covers an assortment of delights including chicken legs/wings, fruit, egg rolls, macaroni, etc. Drinks are reasonable and strong at this time. 

Fun, south seas atmosphere complete with rainstorms and a lively crowd make it a must visit spot when in town. 

No band at this time but no cover either.
author: Pierce S.

description:
I love tacky kitschy things. And I really like the Tonga room. That being said, this isn't the most positive review in the world.

Came here with my husband, his brother, and his brother's girlfriend. There were waterfalls and a band playing.

I made a reservation, but I wasn't aware they wouldn't seat you anywhere near the band if you are just there for drinks (and the full half of the room was empty - as it was near closing time). We all had to choose a food dish off of the menu, which was annoying since we had all eaten dinner.

No matter, we ordered off of their overpriced menu. Everything was good, but not mind-blowing. I had the brussels sprouts and they were only adequate. I don't think I've ever had a Bad brussels sprouts dish, but it definitely does not rank anywhere near the top. 

I think of all the drinks, my Zombie was the best-tasting drink. 

Everything is perfectly a-okay. You pay for the ambience and for the opportunity to go to a "San Francisco institution". It's also filled with a lot of older people. Kinda like Harry Denton's starlight room.
author: Sylvia L.

description: This Tiki bar is located inside the beautiful Fairmont Hotel.  This bar is probably one of the best Tiki bars ever! This place is kinda on the pricier side but it's a lot of fun to try the diff tropical drinks here.  There is also a live band that plays in the middle of a makeshift island surrounded by water and there is also fake rain that comes down around the band during their performance.  Great music and stiff drinks!
author: Rissa K.

description: Ambience = spectacular, feels like you are in Hawaii. There's live music, nice touch. Food considering it's price, below average. I will never eat there again but will go just for drinks.
author: Minh H.

description: Absolutely love this place! Richard, our server, made our night so memorable! He is such an incredible server!!! The night wouldn't be the same without him. Be sure to request him! The food was outstanding. I would recommend ordering the banana split when you're finished. Thanks Richard for an amazing night!!
author: Katie L.

description:
I've always been curious to see the legendary indoor rain storm and live band on the water. Unfortunately when I went, there was no band.

The ambiance was nice, although the rumbling thunder on the PA was too loud for my taste and interrupted conversation.

The food was alright, but vastly overpriced for what it was.

The drinks were overly sweet and not very enjoyable.

It's a San Francisco relic, and I really wanted to enjoy it, but I don't think I'll be going back anytime soon.
author: Michelle R.

description: Be prepared to get your cheesy on and enjoy the atmosphere at the Tonga Room.
author: Gavin M.

description: We came after dinner to drink and dance, cocktails are good, we had fun dancing with a live band but i think they could do some updates on the repertoire, we had the lava bowl sundae sooooo good!!!!! try the Hurricane drink! would be coming back!
author: Abby M.

description: Such a fun place for a drink and appy. Great sharing drinks, great date place, great atmosphere.  Totally not what you expect. Thought it would be a total tourist trap..... But we Loved it.
author: Krista N.

description: It's been a while but my wife surprised me right before my son was born.. Anyway, this place was phenemonal the band played some stevie wonder so I danced with my wife on the dance floor. The place had a tropical feel. The phone was delicious as you can get a course meal.. A great place with friends so you can go dancing without being bothered by the usual club crowd.
author: Mark N.

description:
With my departure to sail the seven seas with the Navy, my time in the Bay Area is coming to a bittersweet close. To ring in this occasion with spirit of aloha (and to ring in my two week vacation to Hawaii before I ship out), I decided to have my going away party here. 

Little did I know how much I was loved because my friends came in droves, driving in and/or BARTing from Antioch/Pittsburg, San Jose and beyond. Gosh, did I feel the love! But I couldn't help to feel bad for my guests who, after traveling as much as an hour by car or by Bart, were standing in different parts of the atrocious line to get in. A good part of my night was bouncing back and forth to my friends who were in line and my friends who were already seated inside. This alludes to the most important part of the Tonga Room Bar: THERE IS NO STANDING ALLOWED. Their bar is completely seated. With that said, there was a line and a frustrating wait that was longer than the wait for the dining area. When do you ever see that happen? I found myself endlessly apologizing to my guests, completely unaware of this Tonga Room snafu. Let me just say that I'm lucky to have friends that are patient. 

Despite the hassle, I had a great time. I had my fill of girly island punch bowls that snuck up on me pretty bad by the end of the night. On top of that, one of my friends was pretty impressed that they had cinnamon schnapps to make a carrot cake shooter, which I had two of. And other friend wanted to do shots of Patron. And another wanted to chug a punch bowl for two. The last thing I remember in the Tonga Room was being dragged onto the dance floor by one of my girlfriends and we twirled, spun, and acted a fool in front the entire restaurant. Being the ones on the dance floor only drew more attention to us, but I loved every minute of it! It was happiness at its best.

Overall, I think I would give this place another try the next time I'm in town if I had a smaller group with me. I definitely wouldn't suggest this place for a huge gathering. Expect to wait in a line along with tourists that are beaming with curiosity thanks to Anthony Bourdain.
author: Grace L.

description:
Tonga Room is a fantastic place to go to. The food was delicious, and the atmosphere was quite stunning. we enjoyed the live band and the frequent pouring rain. 

Definitely a place to go to for special occasions.
author: Henriette K.

description:
What can you say about a San Francisco institution? 

Well, what I can say is that if the management would do something about the bar staff, this place would be perpetually busy -- as it is, it survives on the ebb and tide of hotel guests, conventioneers, wedding reception expatriates and curiosity seekers, who are willing to pay a premium for the room and the location. 

The Tonga Room is almost always worth the visit, but it is staffed by the surliest, most inhospitable bartenders in nearly all of San Francisco. I would love to see the owners of the hotel bring the staff up to a level worthy of such a landmark destination.
author: West R.

description:
I cannot believe I got talked into coming here.  Damn Anthony Bourdain viewing friends from out of town!
CONS:
A.) The host wanted to charge us a $7 cover even though we were dining.
B.) The food was terrible.  I would rather eat a Volcano Burrito for $3.
C.) The food was ridiculously over priced.
PROS:
a.) Our server, Richard was friendly
b.) The umbrella drinks were fun and strong,
c.) The band was pretty good and festive
BUT, I will never come back here.  Ever.  Well, that's not true.  I'd come back if I were in the mood for a cheese-ball evening with $20 umbrella drinks.
author: Alex T.

description:
Came here to celebrate a friend's birthday. I like the atmosphere - on the dark side, band on raft in a pool of water (simulating a lake) - it's a cool place to have fun. Food-wise, it's just OK - not horrible but not spectacular either. I ordered fish (Mahi mahi) and could tell that it wasn't very fresh. However, my friends liked the drinks and the music here and they stayed till almost closing so the stars for this post are from them!

KPI (Key Performance Indicator) ratings (1-5, 5 - best):
Quality: 3
Service: 4
Cost: 3
author: Dorene S.

description:
I'm bringing Tonga back! 

Them other places don't know how to act!

I loved this place! A total SF staple. Live music on a boat that floats above the former indoor pool at the Fairmont. The cutest older couples you've ever seen dancing circles around the younger folks. 

Great stiff overpriced fru fru drinks with yummy fruit and cute umbrellas. Cute tiki decor galore. I just can't get over how cute this place is. I can't wait to go back and dance the night away (well at least until 1am when they close).
author: Caro S.

description: FUN! Good drinks pricey but good! I would definitely suggest going here at least once if your a SF local.
author: Nicholas D.

description: The drinks are not as strong as Anthony Bourdain promised, but the glass noodle salad was insanely good.
author: Goumada S.

description: Need to have a reservation for dinner. Went in for drinks and appetizers. Drinks were strong and appetizer was good. Very overpriced though. Totally not worth it at that price.
author: Eli G.

description:
I cannot believe this sterling example of all things San Francisco has been amiss in my reviews. This will be rectified NOW!

The history of the room can't be beat:
http://www.sfgate.com/default/article/WHEN-PLUNGE-WAS-A-SPLASH-2652696.php

Wait a couple of months after the Bourdain backwash has passed and you'll find the largest, tackiest, over-the-top, wonderful extravaganza of a lounge. Quite a few hours of happy were spent here, reveling in the overly-sweet tropical cocktails, fried snacks and the band singing on the boat in the lagoon and timing the indoor thunder.
author: Rene D.

description: Service and Ambiance were exceptional.  The food was a solid B.  This is a place of go for the experience.   They create thunderstorms while your eating to give it the tropical island feel.  Dinner and 8 drinks for four people $400 after the tip.
author: Scott M.

description: I had heard about this place on my past trips to San Fran and decided to check it out. Long be hold I was disappointed. We got a surprising visit with 60s and 70s music mostly old fashion for a what is described as hip joint. Anyway, the chef and food was not something to be desired. Let's say the chef was in love with salt. I think this place has lost its mojo. As a matter of fact so has the hotel. The whole place lives in 70s and has a long way to modernize itself for a city that is the cradle of technology. Go check out a jazz club instead my friend and be thankful you read this review.
author: Saeid Y.

description:
Do you need to go here at least once? I'm not sure. 

Yes, I knew it was kitschy and a total tourist-y/weird experience awaited our group however it was hard not to feel sorry for the obvious out-of-towners who looked bored and sticker-shocked from the "I take myself too seriously as a musician" floating band and the highly inflated menu prices.

(I kinda felt sorry for us too, but we knew what we were getting ourselves into, at least mostly).

Cover charge was supposed to be waived until 7 or 8 and we were seated before that time so we thought it was included. Nope, since we were there 35 minutes after the band started playing, we too were soaked $7/person to hear "More Than a Woman" and other soft-rock hits of the 70s and 80s belted out by a soulful Jon Bon Jovi wannabe.

The "rain' was kind of fun but it didn't happen too frequently. The drinks were ok but really expensive ($12 for a mediocre zombie or mojito?) 

I was with a gang who wanted to go  -and yes have dinner there- and the entrees were ridiculously over-priced ($26 for a stir-fried beef dish and rice was a la carte at $3?) 

I guess we knew what we were expecting, we had fun despite the prices and the weird tourists who were taking the whole experience just a bit too seriously or looking bored and looking around like they'd fallen onto another planet.

Years ago I heard they had a huge and complimentary pou pou (spelling?) platter during happy hour. I don't think they do that anymore. They want to sell you a bunch of over-priced appetizers and ridiculously expensive entrees (that are mediocre - surprise surprise).

Before I went, I was sad the Fairmont might tear down the "historic" Tonga Room. You know what? Demolish it and build the damn tower - go have drinks across the street at The Top of the Mark!
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Cheesy interior.  Felt like a bad version of Pirates of the Caribbean. 

That and the food was horrible and at best uninspired.

We actually got the check and instead went out and got tacos.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Oh, the Tonga Room. What can I say? Tropical drinks, on-cue rain that falls in the middle pool, where the band sits on a platform that slowly drifts back and forth. So. Typical.

But really, it was fun. It's just a thing you have to do in the city. I don't think I'd go back, simply because the drinks and the food aren't really up my alley, but it was an enjoyable experience. 

The good: entertaining.
The bad: it's contrived.
The weird: over-zealous waitstaff.
author: Amanda B.

description:
If you go into the Tonga Room expecting a kitschy experience, you'll enjoy everything it has to offer.  They don't make them like this any more!   The restaurant features a pond (with a floating band), thatched roof, and period thunderstorms compete with indoor showers.  (As a midwesterner I wondered if San Franciscans unaccustomed to thunderstorms might find that more interesting than I did.)

The drinks are not to my taste--too much rum and fruit juice--but one can't knock a tiki bar for having tiki drinks.

The food was good.  My wife enjoyed the Chicken Satay and I preferred the Ahi Tuna. The egg rolls were only okay--you can skip those.

Tonga is worth the experience if you're up for a quick kitschy, Disney-like trip to a Pacific island.
author: Augie R.

description:
I LOVED the atmosphere at this place.  It's the ultimate tiki bar experience. Straw-thatched huts, tiki torches, a band playing on a 'boat' in the middle of a 'lagoon', fake rainstorms every half hou or so, etc.  It reminded me very much of the Rainforest Cafe.  So kitch!!  This is a pretty historic place too, going back to at least the 1940's - that's as much as I gathered from all of the literature on the walls right outside the restaurant.

After a few minutes of settling into the awesomeness of the place, we waited to be served.... and waited.  The service was definitely slow.  But the restaurant wasn't that full, even though it was a Saturday night.  There were some empty tables here and there around us (and no line to enter, as we had expected). 

The drinks were ok.  Typical sugary "tropical" drinks, all adorned with a thick slice of pineapple and maraschino cherry.  I asked the server if sugar was used in the drinks, and he said that syrup was added.  I asked for mine without syrup, since I hate sugary drinks, and I'd rather taste the alcohol than have an awful sugar-induced hangover.  I don't know if he really understood me, since my drink was still pretty darn sweet.  (And I still somehow ended up feeling awful the next morning even though I didn't drink that much.)

The food was just awful. The ceviche was bathing in a pool of thick mayo-based sauce. With my first couple bites, I couldn't even tell if I was tasting fish. It had become completely mayo-fied.  The calamari was nicely crispy, and I guess you could call it "juicy", since I'd get strong squirts of salty oil with every bite.  We also got a Tonga appetizer platter, but there wasn't anything spectacular on there.  The chicken was overcooked. The ribs were way too salty.

Overall, I think this is a place worth coming to, but skip out on the food altogether.  Order a punch bowl to share (more bang for the buck), and just enjoy the music/decor.
author: Jeanne L.

description: Very touristy and very pricey, but it really is a one of a kind experience. Staff was friendly, food was good, drinks were potent.
author: Dev K.

description:
Overpriced. Bad servers. 

An order of Two greasy egg rolls was $14, and they charged us twice for the food--once on my credit card (which I was told was "starting a tab"), and a second time when I paid cash. Even getting water brought to our table was treated as a big deal.
author: Chikodi C.

description:
Good cheesy fun.  If you've never been, go just for the experience.  It's a great place for those times when you're having that "been there done that" feeling.  

IMHO late night or happy hour are the best times to go.  It might be a fun place for a date if they have a a good sense of humor, or if you need a built-in ice breaker.    

There are certain requirements to living in SF, getting thy butt to the Tonga Room is one of them.
author: Tonie C.

description: Over priced. Mediocre food. Ridiculous wait time. Waited for over an hour to be seated at the bar. Service was extremely slow. I ordered a sample platter. The portions were small and way over priced. My food arrived cold! Asked our waitress for items multiple time and they never arrived. They also add a $7 fee to listen to the live band! Really? I have to pay for something that I'm being forced to listen to?! Extremely disappointed with this place. I don't mind spending $ for good quality food. This place was NOT worth the $! I would've been better off going to Panda Express!!! Don't fall for the decor and "cool vibe" the food and service is terrible!
author: Cris C.

description:
The Tonga room is a hoot!  Floating band (the guys play great dance music), the indoor thunder storm and perfect decor all add up to a great time.  Go there with friends and dance the night away.  That part of the room gets 5+ stars.

The menu and drinks are solid, but leave you a little wanting considering this is San Francisco.  You need to be selective on what you order to not feel like you've overpaid for mediocre fare.  This part of the room gets 3 stars.

So . . . we average the two to get 4 stars.  Under rated for atmosphere and over rated for food and drinks.

If P.F. Changs took over the food service, then the place would be 6 stars!
author: Mikal B.

description:
Tonight we went to Tonga with a lot of excitement. We saw on the website to make reservations, so we did. I was singing the "tiki room" song all day because Tony Bourdain had been here and tonight I was celebrating my new engagement. 

We called from our dinner saying "We are still eating dinner can we move our reservation to an hour later?" they said yes and moved it to 10. When we arrive they ask if we are eating dinner or just having drinks. We said just drinks but we had told them earlier what a special night it was for us and asked for a poolside table. We were seated at the pool and ordered drinks. When our waiter asked us what we wanted for dinner we nicely said we had already eaten. THEN HE YELLED AT US!!!! We were planning to maybe get an appetizer and a few drinks now we were embarrassed and yelling at us did not make us hungry. We apologized for the confusion and were VERY clearly told that for future reference reservations were for dinner only. Fine, sorry, noted.

A few minutes later, after the waiter had clearly ignored us for a while, he comes back with a manager. The manager tells us the same thing we now knew. When the manager leaves, the waiter YELLS at us AGAIN just to make an example of us I guess. 

At this point I am POed!!! No one treats me like that especially on a special night. So, I find the manager and tell him how he has ruined our night. He comes over and apologizes to my fiancé and friend and leaves us. My fiancé had one more drink and we leave without giving a tip. As we leave the manager stops us asking if we wanted to sit somewhere else and he could get a complementary dessert for us. I'm sorry but as we said, we ate already we are now so upset that we wouldn't be hungry if we wanted to be and a free dessert will not fix that I was already writing this review in my head. This has been the WORST part of my first time to SAN FRAN!!! We said no thank you and we left.

I would say no stars, but the cover band was awesome and worth the extra 7 bucks. I wanted to hire them for my future wedding they were so great. That made my one star status.
author: Blair H.

description: An institution, but forget about going there during HH; you'll need a reservation because it is a MADHOUSE.
author: Smelly S.

description:
If you honestly come to the Tonga room for anything more than the atmosphere and the sheer brilliance of Mel Melvin, well, frankly, you're an idiot. 

I often describe the Tonga Room as the Tiki Room for adults, with food, alcohol, and dancing. I'd heard of the place for years, but I'd never been fortunate enough to see it for myself. I have an intense love for kitschy, tropical things, so of course I knew I'd have to see this little jewel sooner or later.

Well, sooner came around and I had dinner here on a rainy Wednesday night with some friends, and of course, I was instantly in love.

From the band floating on a barge in the middle of the "lagoon", to the ridiculously sweet drinks, to the fake rain, I was hooked. When it came time for my sister to plan my bachelorette party, I knew exactly where I wanted to have dinner. 

The Tonga room isn't about the food, or the service, or even the drinks. It's about the lore and history. I don't feel you should be allowed to call yourself a bay area native if you've never set foot inside the Tonga Room. It's like a rite of passage. Along the lines of a trip across the Golden Gate, taking in a game at Candlestick, browsing through the hanging ducks in China Town, or seeing the Christmas tree in Union Square. 

This is one spot you surely shouldn't miss. I plan on visiting much more frequently than I have in the past. It just makes me smile!
author: Lauren S.

description: Really fun place to go for a bar! Not sure about the restaurant but the bar is fun and the drinks are fun themed :) The entire environment and tiki themed decor is really cute and adds to the mood. Plus on the weekends a live band is there and they play in the middle of the pool! We had a lot of fun dancing :)
author: Jenny E.

description: I love this place!!!! I went here for my birthday and it was the best birthday dinner ever! The ambiance was so beautiful and really out of this world. There was a live band playing great music on the water and a nice big dance floor. The only thing I could say is their food needs a little upgrade (hence the 4 stars instead of 5), it was alright but nothing special. The ambiance is really breathtaking and even though the food isn't the greatest I am still crazy about this place!!! It's really magical. Can't wait to go back!
author: Nicole V.

description: I have been wanting to visit this place for the longest time and I finally had a chance to go on Saturday with my friends who were visiting from SoCal. The location itself was fun and unique! The drinks were delicious! Only complaint was the service on behalf of the bartenders who served us, which being part of a high end hotel, I expected at least a smile. They did look burnt out but I suspect the place must be a popular location so it's expected to be busy from open to close. I expected the service to be better. Other than that my friends and I had a great time listening to the live music and drinking!!
author: Francis S.

description:
Maybe I didn't order the right things but the food was mediocre. But their drinks are good and they have some sizable concoctions. 

The venue however is really really cool, all decked out. There's live music from a hut thing on the water, and it rains and thunders (whoOoOo). They usually play a mix of oldies and contemporary songs. Sometimes people dance on the little dance floor area, and the bar is always pretty packed and loud. Definitely touristy, the kind of place you have to check out once, and probably just once unless you're showing someone new in town.
author: Nan L.

description:
This is the second time I have been here.  The food was great the first time, but the second time I went the food was a miss.  I went with 6 people and I tried everyone's dish.  Everyone's food lacked flavor.  We had to ask for chili paste just to add some flavor to the food.  The food is overpriced for what it is.

The drinks were good - nothing spectacular but they were good.  

The entertainment was great!  I would only go back for drinks and maybe some dancing with my mom (since they played a lot of songs that I know she would appreciate).  

I would recommend only going for drinks, not food.  It is good for large groups.  

Places to go afterwards: Smugglers Cove to fit with the Tiki theme or go across the street for drinks at the Top of the Mark.
author: Vagabond V.

description: The sweetest Mai tai I've ever had and I don't meant that in a good way. This place is really about the atmosphere and I just didn't spend enough time soaking it in. One thing is for sure, Tonga Room is one of a kind! I need to come back here when I can be more dedicated to a full night of Tonga craziness, but for now...3 stars.
author: Ryan P.

description:
well.....
This restaurant has a really authentic atmosphere.

food.... service..... meh......

just for a good experience....maybe...
author: Iguanatte S.

description: If you stay at hotel you don't pay cover. The lava punch for 2 goes down waaauyy to easy.
author: Ma J.

description: The experience was fun because of the theme and decoration but the food was way over priced for the quality and taste. The service was extremely slow as well. We were going to get dessert but our server took forever so we changed our minds. The band was great! I felt like I was at a resort or some place in Vegas.
author: Mai N.

description:
My fascination with Tonga Room is over.

The drinks and food are terrible. My boyfriend and I ordered a pina coloada, mai tai and the polynesian itch. The drinks were syrupy sweet with a terrible aftertaste even the sugar couldn't mask.

The fried spring rolls had a funny smell, like cat food. Later I realize they were suppose to be kalua pig spring rolls. They were super greasy as were the fries which were soggy and drooped over when you picked one up.

I wish I could give five stars for the space and one star for the food, but that's now how Yelp works. I love the fun decor and I love tiki bars but a bar with bad drinks is not acceptable.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Great live music and drinks!The ambiance was amazing with live music and tropical theme.The food was decent but the reason I am giving them 5 stars is due to the drinks,great service and ambiance!A great place to try if you have never been there.
author: Billboardlive W.

description:
Anthony Bourdain fucking ruined this place.

Once upon a time, you could come here with a group of friends, roll up to the bar and have a great time getting wasted on boat drinks that you sip out of bedpans with long bendy straws.

Now, you wait in line for three days behind a gaggle of midwestern grandmas who heard about this wonderful place from that nice man on the teevee.  And once you get in, you're required to stay in your little assigned table area, even at the bar.   The magic is gone, people.  Don't bother.  Go back to Nebraska.

Bleh.  The only thing worse would be if that spikey-haired food-tv fatass Guy Coronary came here and ate a sandwich.
author: Tim R.

description: Best Mai Tai I've ever had. The Royal PuPu Platter is delicious.  Pricey but worth it!
author: Silvana T.

description: I absolutely loved the decor & ambiance of this place! The live music was on point! But the service was terrible. It took 15 minutes to be acknowledged and have waters brought over, 20 minutes to get our drinks & then we had to flag our server down to put in our app & entree order!!! I don't know if he was just slammed with too many tables or they were understaffed but being patient people, our patience ran out! The food was not spectacular and over priced. Our pineapple royal drink didn't taste like it had any alcohol in it.  Fun place to check out but it's kinda disappointing. It could be improved to be a way better spot.
author: Karina R.

description: Great ambiance. amazing food, but the drinks are a little watered down and the deserts are small. but the quality of the food is definitely worth it ! great for a party or date night. also the coolest part is that they have dancing, and the ceiling pours rain to making it look like a tropical storm =) cool beans
author: Cecily B.

description:
Seriously? People flock to this slumhole? Whatever. Some of you have some truly questionable tastes. The Fairmont Hotel is simply spectacular, but the Tonga Room, in the basement of this classic hotel, is like that festering abcess on your ass crack that you couldn't ever lance with a spear and a prodigious application of Kentucky moonshine. 

Whatever. There's kitschy, and there's tourist traps. This is the latter, a dim, depressing flophouse where the drinks are poured by some dour-looking bartenders that are ridiculously stingy with the booze. No, man, I don't want a Hi-C with a cute umbrella on it. Go hard on the vodka, fucker.

Also, too many drunk business types, especially that female SVP that looks forward to these trips so she can get away from her boring husband and get stupid drunk and hook up with a random stranger, and then wake up the next morning with a thumping hangover, a random stranger in her bed that's got more hair on his back than Ron Jeremy, and the boozy-caked blood in her veins flowing and soaked in Mai Tais and shame.

Eh. I'll chalk it up to that once-in-a-while time where you just have to go through the motions and endure a truly abysmal, so-called "must-do" tourist-y thing.
author: Gus S.

description:
The Tonga Room at The Fairmont San Francisco is intentionally cheesy, which works.  With its simulated thunder and rain, it's a lot like a Rainforest Cafe for adults.

The environment is fun.  There's a dance floor and a pool (which isn't meant for swimming in but often ends up serving as a swimming pool anyway after the potent beverages that the staff serves have taken hold).  A (good) house band plays on a "boat" isolated at the far end of the not-for-swimming swimming pool.

The cuisine is Asian fusion and it isn't half-bad.  In fact a couple of menu items proved to be quite good.

The beverages are tropical themed (although you can certainly order pretty much any non-themed beverage of your choice) and, as previously mentioned, pack a punch.  Two Blue Hawaiis had me feeling pretty comfortably numb. :-)

Overall, I give The Tonga Room 4 stars for its fun atmosphere, serious beverages and decent cuisine.  I wouldn't however make it a frequent stop; more like a once-in-a-while deviation from the normal dining experience.
author: Joe G.

description:
When I met April at the Fairmont Hotel she was less-than-pleased. We were there for an event (Cochon 555) and while looking for it she inadvertently stepped into one of the hotel's ballrooms. A staffer quickly walked over. "No, no," she explained, "I think you need to be downstairs." April quickly descended the stairs only to be faced with the Tonga Room. A single word flashed across her mind: "Bitch!"

Being profiled as a "typical" guest of the Tonga Room isn't flattering. When my friends learned that I had never been, the reaction was, "We need to take you." You will note that this is distinct from "we should go," or "it's great." There is a certain excitement in escorting a neophyte to the mouth of this island volcano and watching his face react to the syrupy, boozy, bubbling lava within. 

It's only appropriate that me and the gang slurped down a Lava Bowl for four. It's a rum punch that runs about $30 and contains a whole sack of refined sugar. Refined for the unrefined. You won't just get intoxicated; you'll bray with the giddy enthusiasm of an eight-year-old hopped up on pixie sticks. You'll black out and end up drinking on a boat and stapling your roommate (but that's a different story).

I can't complain too hard about any venue where I end up zozzled and wearing a little paper umbrella in my hair. But a typical guest or regular I shall never be.

Obligatory Title Pun: It takes (at least) two to TONGA.

Menu Readability: Papyrus.

Need to mention: At times there is cover because of the live music, which is played on a barge in the middle of a watery lagoon in the center of the bar.

What this place teaches me about myself: I'm not cut out for island life.
author: Vivek S.

description:
Cool atmosphere, most likely haunted, but hey, i dont work there. The drinks weren't anything to rave about and were pretty expensive too. So 3 stars for entertaining my inner child.

Did you really come here for the food?... you arent from around here are you?...
author: Devon P.

description: We wanted to go somewhere fun for our anniversary and I suggested that we come back to the Tonga Room.  This time we ordered ala carte and split the tropical salad for starters, then shared the other items we ordered, the grilled ono, the kalua pork, grilled asparagus, Szechwan green beans, Hawaiian fried rice and tropical dessert sampler which consisted of 3 different flavors of mochi - banana, mango and green tea as well as a coconut tart and a strawberry.  I also ordered a pina colada but the waiter realized that he gave me the wrong drink and quickly replaced it.  Service was good, the food was ok, nothing spectacular but the cover band was good and we got to try out our hustle dance moves!  I'd say if you have a celebration bring a group because it's a lot more fun to party!   It's the place to bring out of town visitors as well.  A bit expensive, food is so so but it's the fun atmosphere of it being unique and at the Fairmont Hotel
author: Karen W.

description:
Food = subpar.  Pacific Rim Pan Asian, blah blah...it was greasy, boring, and just odd flavors.  Chicken wings...only drumsticks, interesting; khalua pig with noodles = greasy mess; their macaroni salad could've fooled me for prop food, given the shiny and dry look of the pasta.  Sorry but their only saving grace had to the fruit salad (and that was, hopefully, because, it was fresh fruit and not rehydrated/flash frozen/etc).  

I ended up eating most of the fruit salad, as everything else was, like I already said, greasy.  As for the drinks, we had virgin daiquiris (wasn't in a true drinkin' mood), and they were supposed to be passionfruit flavored....all we tasted were ice and sweet&sour mix...hello??!  It was not a free drink......we were required to buy it!    And you're supposed to water down alcoholic drinks, not non-alcoholic ones!!! 

Decor = cheesy, tacky, and all as expected.  I found the hydroponics and huge 'pool' of water in the middle of the dining area to be quite a pathetic attempt at putting an 'oasis' inside of an otherwise nice historical hotel.   The decor of this restaurant/bar, truly belongs in some horror version of Hawaii Five-O http://tiny.cc/ra00z  Oh, and adding in sound effects with strobe lights and then making it 'rain' indoors, in the middle of the room = lame.  It really could have been done better.  

Prices = reasonable.  But you really do get what you pay for.  And in this instance, we had the happy hour, all-you-can-eat-buffet for $9.50 per person, with a 1-drink minimum ($6-9/pp).   

Oh and by the way....they used the smallest plates on earth for the buffet.  I'm not asking for ginormous UFO saucer-sized plates, but could you at least offer some larger plates, so the few items we put on the plate doesn't actually FALL off onto the FLOOR?!?

Service = deplorable.  There is a sign posted "Please wait to be seated".  They either did not see us, or chose to ignore us at the door.  Then we waited forever for them to give us the bill, and then the receipt.
author: Fannie S.

description: The rain wasn't event that cool, the lights were fake, it was super lame-"OMG THERES LIGHTNING" exclaimed my girlfriend. Water you talking about, did it taste like something you know about? You know exactly what it means, what else could creamy water mean? The egg rolls, also, we didn't pay for the buffet but I grabbed an egg roll out of that beautiful golden pile of holiness, and I gotta say it was great. Just like the all of the tonga room. Very great. Very cool. PEACE IM OUT, "WHAT IS THIS A NOVEL??" Added curiously by my girlfriend. I hope it rains more.
author: Ryan K.

description: If you really want to feel like a tourist, wait in line for over an hour for a $7 cover of a Jimmy Buffett parrot fest, and pay $15 for drinks, then be our guest. We were intrigued by the Bourdain reference, but decided that the tiki intrigue gave way to our general disgust at a place that profits off of bros and Tommy Bahama wearing fools.
author: Sven And Krysta G.

description:
Great place to have a party or a birthday with ur date :) I do not give great credit for the food as it is a bit pricey for what they offer.. But the drinks are great at the tiki bar and the live music from the floating boat in the center of the restaurant is something you must see if you are eating here. 

To conclude, you are mostly paying for the location and the atmosphere here.
author: Rio S.

description:
3.5 stars

There were rumors a few years back that  Tonga Room might be closing its doors, but a mention on Tony Bourdain's show breathed new life into this place. 

Bf & I had dinner reservations on Friday night & we had to bypass 50 people (who obviously saw the fateful Travel Channel show) waiting for the $9.50 buffet (which btw, looks janky as fawk! Chicken wings, egg rolls, chow mein & rice--I'll pass...)

The over-the-top Disneyland tiki room theme is part of Tonga Room's 'appeal' (I use the term loosely.) You can't take yourself, or your partner, or the decor too seriously. The fake rain & flickering lights...the boat in the middle of a fake river...so deliciously hokey & campy. 

We ordered:
-- shrimp scallion dumplings ($13): surprisingly good! Four nicely-stuffed dumplings. Skin was not too thick & filling was mild, but still tasty. As good as any decent dim sum joint...for real...
-- Tongan rice, $7: the roasted pineapple, toasted coconut & spam pieces intrigued us, but I did not enjoy their 'forbidden blend' of rices--jasmine, red, black & pearl (?). I *hate* red rice. Tasted too smoky. Very salty. I'd pass on this. 
-- Tonga Platter, $26: appetizers of spring rolls, fried coconut shrimp, BBQ ribs which were all decent, but chicken satay was pretty gross due to the sauce.

Reservations are not accepted for the buffet (5-7pm on weekdays, I believe.) our server was bustin' his ass & delivered fast, efficient service. The valet guys are hella cool. 

Fun experience! Bring your buddies who like to drink!
author: Fancypants X.

description:
I always wanted to check this place out. I finally got a chance to last night and I was not impressed. Atmosphere was nice, but the food was NOT good. Way overpriced and the menu selection was limited. I ordered the green curry, and what I got was a bowl of green beans, eggplants, and what seemed to be a gelatin like texture of a sauce. I thought curry had coconut milk?

Probably won't be coming back here anytime soon.
author: Denise L.

description: Good for ambience. But too expensive food and felt it was Bad. It is always crowded so check for appointment. There is no parking space in the hotel but there is public parking right next in their left side. It's worth a try.
author: Insuvai A.

description: Wow! This place was everything we hoped it would be and then some. The kitschy decor, the food and drinks, the indoor rainstorms, the service, the house band ... it was all terrific. We had a very memorable night at the Tonga Room. Special thanks to Alex, our server.
author: Scott W.

description: If you have not been here, this is a SF staple.  Bad liquor tiki drinks while it rains in a basement with a band playing.  Total run on sentence.  Go, it's fun//
author: Mot Y.

description: We saw this place when Tony Bourdain visited several years back and it looked interesting. The club itself is unique and beautiful, with the centered pool and tiki tables. We would have loved to sit down as there were scores of tables all night that were empty and "reserved for 5 weeks." Apparently if for some reason you do get a seat, then they charge a cover of 10 bucks/person. Most people stood close to the bar, seeming confused as to the queue system. There were zero waitstaff floating around that we could see, except at the bar. Waiting for drinks took 10 years. The tropical menu was fun, but the drinks were overly-sweet and all kind of tasted the same. Still, all of that said, we felt like we were experiencing a piece of SF 1945 history and the people-watching was a blast! All different walks of life are in there. Their tropical kitch glasswear make for silly selfies! Glad we went, but it was probably a one-time deal without a seat. If they want to step up their reviews, they will need to mix drinks with fresher ingredients and have more service available. This IS in the basement of the Fairmont afterall!
author: Andi G.

description:
"If you have no love in your heart for this place, you are a sick, twisted lonely f*ck with too many cats."  - Anthony Bourdain

The west coast does tend to make us softer, more forgiving of places like the Tonga room.  Don't come here for the food, don't come here for the service, don't even come here for the drinks- come for the memories of days gone by.

When I was young, my parents used to sneak away for the ocasional date night- one night my parents came back with a photograph framed in cardboard from their night out at the Tonga Room. " What was this mysterious place" I thought to myself....It seemed to be an exotic hideaway where adults could have fun, drink cocktails with umbrellas and watch a live band float mysteriously on a barge in the middle of the pool.  To intrigue me even more my mother told me that it rained! INSIDE! NO way....I thought to myself.  

Unfortunately I had to wait many more years until I could attend this magical Tikki bar myself.  And it was everything that I expected it to be- even making my boyfriend take me here for date nights so that we too could have our photograph taken in the same spot.  Now my friends roll their eyes at me whenever I suggest it- but I dont care...sometimes you want to relax on a cold night at the Fairmont and pretend that maybe-just maybe- you might be able to use your vaction days and get away for a while.
author: Sarah M.

description: Loved the ambiance and drinks!  The food was just ok and very pricey.  A great place to go and celebrate something special.
author: Trudi S.

description:
This place is at best a tourist trap and at worst a horrible representation of San Francisco restaurants.  

We went for a birthday party on a Saturday night and didn't book a table so there was a line to get in which was expected...no big deal.  

Once we were in they seated us in the lounge area.  The decor of the place is interesting but tacky at the same time.  Looks like it belongs in Disneyland rather than the Fairmont Hotel in Nob Hill.  I'm not going to get into what the place looks like because there are plenty of pictures all over the web for those curious.

Pretty much from the very beginning our service was almost non-existent.  We were never introduced to the place or our server, the menu was never explained, we had to hunt down our server to order anything,  and the wait time for food and drink was two to three times longer than it should be.  The only time our server made any effort was in collecting the bill at the the end of the night.  

The drinks were very poor especially considering the high price you paid for them.  They were watered down, overly mixed with juice and sweeteners, and loaded with ice.  I've had better cocktails with the jungle juice you get at a frat party.  I had their Mai Tai, it was garbage.  I didn't have much of the food but from what I can see others order it looked like typically bar food, nothing special except for the exceptionally high price.  

The best part comes at the end of the night when you get your bill.  They charged our party 15% gratuity, which would have been ok considering our group size, except that they pretty much ignored us all night. Reading through the bill they actually calculated the tip amount after the cover charge! This is ridiculous.  So we had a group of 15 and the cover charge was $7 so thats a $105 in cover charge times 15% gratuity.  Now I don't mind tipping on food but I have never had to pay a tip on a cover charge as well. We tried to point this out but she didn't care and blamed it on the computer system.  So whatever we paid the bill and left.

If you are looking for tacky atmosphere, mediocre product, price gouging and awful service you have found your spot.
author: Nick F.

description:
Sadly we came back today and the drinks were mediocre and on top of that the happy hour buffet was very disappointing

Wings were practically all fat

Chowmein was oily 

Fried rice was flavorless 

Food just a hot mess

2 stars solely for drinks and happy hour food

3 for service
author: Natty N.

description: This classic place is pretty cheesy but always fun.  There is a dance floor and line on weekends.  The food is expensive and just so-so.  The drinks are sugary but entertaining.  There is a nice mix of people there including corporate travel types and families.
author: M S.

description:
When my fiancé's sister and husband came to visit, the Tonga Room was on their shortlist of places to go based on the reviews of family and coworkers. We visited early on a Friday night for Happy Hour (we found street parking nearby after several loops), and while there wasn't a line, we had to wait about 30 minutes for a table. Once we were seated, we waited some more for a server, and finally we had to seek out someone to get menus and take our orders. The waitress was not at all friendly, answering our questions about the menu rudely and offering us no introduction or small-talk. Although the Room was busy, there's no reason for a server not to be friendly.

The four of us ordered two drinks each, and they were all yummy enough in that almost-sickeningly sweet way of tropical drinks. I split the Tonga Platter (bbq ribs, chicken satay, spring rolls, and coconut shrimp) with my fiancé, and while the food was all fine, it certainly wasn't worth the $26 we paid for it. Indeed, the future sister-in-law ordered the appetizer buffet, and she seemed to get much more bang for her buck.

The decor is dark but fun, and the atmosphere is neat when it starts to rain on the central pool. We didn't want to pay more when the band came in, so I can't say anything about that. Overall though, I don't think the drinks and atmosphere are enough to get me back into the Tonga Room. I found it overpriced, and our server turned me off completely.
author: Kristen L.

description: Food is average and really at a 50% discount I still really couldn't recommend it. But it's a fun spot nice atmosphere and good times ...
author: Vance H.

description:
Date nite on V-Day... Neat place with Good Food. 

Con:
Service was slow and sloppy. Waiter eventually came around to take our order and brought our cocktails. He came back about 15 minutes later and asked if we were ready to order dinner and I said in a few minutes. He then insisted that kitchen would be closing in 5 minutes - he could and should have warned us when he bought our cocktails.

Pros:
Great menu (a tad salty) and kewl live music.
author: Madhusudhan R.

description: Saw that Anthony Bourdain came here for one of his shows and so we put it on our list of places to go while we were in San Francisco for our wedding weekend. We weren't disappointed, awesome atmosphere, great vibes from everyone there as the venue has a great ambiance. Lots of smiling faces having a great night out, drinks were strong and unique which is what you want when going to a place like this; my favorite was the colada. Really highly recommend if you want a fun and unique night out with friends. We loved it!
author: Mai M.

description:
Over priced. But fun place. They revamped their cocktails with local french ingredients. Very tasty. 
It rains every 30 minutes too!
author: Dakin G.

description: Large, fabulously decorated tiki bar. I didn't get to try the food but the drinks were good. The music did not fit the theme at all and the bar was over run with dude bros. I would definitely give it another chance if I'm in the area.
author: Alyssa C.

description: Fun place for a night out in a different, interesting, and lively setting.  My husband is a tiki fanatic so we when travel we must hit all the tiki bars on his list.  This place does not disappoint.  Strong drinks, as all tiki bars have, live music, and a decent food menu for the evening.
author: LJ M.

description:
We stood in line for an hour even though the place was empty.  They said they couldn't take a party larger than 8 so some of us had to sit at the bar even though the rest of our party was literally THE ONLY GROUP OF PEOPLE on that side of the restaurant.  Someone in our party had to get us menus after we'd been there for 20 mins and it was another 10 before our waitress showed up.  She then brought one plate every 5 minutes.  The last thing we ordered showed up 20 mins after everyone else had finished eating.  The food was over priced and awful.  The atmosphere and strong drinks are the only thing going for this place.

Scallops where rubbery, chicken was clearly microwaved as it was cold in some spots and luke warm in others, ribs where tough (but the Kona sauce was good), orange chicken was soggy and bland.

terrible experience.
author: Erin G.

description:
Would I ever come here again? No.

However, if you're in the vicinity while you're visiting SF or love Tiki Bars I think it could be worth checking out.  

The drinks are truly just meh, but some of them are served in cool containers (for example, a pineapple). If you take pride in having a good drink don't go to the Tonga Room for that. Go for the ambiance, the experience, etc.  

Also, the drinks at the Tonga Room are rather expensive, so try visiting during a time when you don't have to pay cover to get into the bar. Or even better, go during a time you don't have to pay cover and order appetizers instead of a drink (trust me, you're not missing out).
author: Abena O.

description:
I want this place to be great, really I do.
However, the service is very slow, not friendly, the menu is shockingly small.
The music was good ($7.00 cover per person magically appeared on the bill)  it would have been nice if we were told that up front... rather shady 
There was a long line to get in, but surprisingly there were MANY empty tables inside...

bottom line:
poor management
under staffed
grumpy employees
very few choices for dinner
expensive drinks that are not balanced, they pour 'em way too hot...
music was so loud, forget about ANY dinner conversations

overall not an enjoyable night there

We check back once a year or so, because we really want it to be a good place, because it is so different from all the other places... 

My girlfriend each had ONE drink and one appetizer, 
and we also split an appetizer order of fries... 
$75  

not worth it...
author: C J.

description:
They get a star for the landmark location - that's it. And because you can't give ZERO. The hotel is beautiful. Parking is a mess, but that's expected in SF. You can valet in the hotel lot for $15/hour (that's the price for a guest of the restaurant only - it's less if you're staying the night in the Fairmont).

Do not expect a refill on your drink unless you paid $12 for one with alcohol. I had a sip of a friend's and it was strong. The alcoholic drinks had cute umbrellas and were in Tiki glasses, but were out of our budget.  My husband had a Coca Cola & I had an iced tea. If a restaurant chooses to serve a drink in a tiny glass, be prepared to return often to refill it. I had to request refills for my husband & myself several times. Our meal literally took hours - it was terrible to have an empty glass! Don't punish me for being a responsible driver. 

Don't go with a group - we had 10 people & a 6:30 reservation on a Saturday night. They sat us once our entire party had arrived (around 6:45) - they did not take our orders until after 7:15. That was the last time I checked my husband's watch. To me, this is outrageous. Our server was not to be seen, or would come back and rush by. Once we did order, it was appetizers only. He'd come back for our meal order. I ordered an edamame dish ($4) & my husband ordered sweet potato fries.  When our server brought out the table's apps, he announced I'll put these in the middle so that everyone can share and took ours to the other side of the table. We let him know that NO, we ordered those and they were part of our meal. We'd decided to split a dinner and weren't interested in sharing apps. This is unprofessional unless you first ask the person who orders the item. I will say, the edamame was a huge serving; though hugely boring. No flavor.  The sweet potato fries were warm in the middle of the bowl/dish but cold up top. Like they'd sat a long while. I tried the calamari someone else ordered and I'll say it's some of the best calamari I've had anywhere - ever. Nicely breaded. Thick cut pieces. I would order it if ever I were forced to go back here.

For dinner we split the sampler appetizer. It consisted of 4 items: coconut shrimp, spring rolls, ribs, and chicken satay. We also added an order of Forbidden Rice ($6) & the "steamed & brown rice". ($3) Given there were two of us, our served should have said that these are 2 different menu items. We ended up with THREE things of rice and three charges for it. The "steamed & brown" wasn't combined like I took the menu to mean. At least it was a small extra charge. I still blame the server for not clarifying this.  The items on the sampler each had three pieces. When is the last time you sat at a table for 3? Ever?? Make it four! For $26 do not be cheap. It leaves a bad taste in your patron's mouth. About as bad as the peanut sauce on the chicken and BBQ sauce on the ribs. Both were drenched in sauces that were too strongly flavored.  Which is shocking since I asked for hot sauce (twice) and each time received a TINY spoonful on a plate that also had a soysauce and mustard sauce. What don't you get? I want some hot sauce. After asking twice, I didn't ask a third time. I used the small amount the table was to share also (since nobody was interested in it); then I just gave up. The Forbidden Rice blend was great. I'd recommend that.

While you sit (and wait, mostly) they do have a pretty pool to look at and at intervals it "rains" & "thunders", which is cool. There's a boat floating in the middle. Once they start playing you get an extra $7 tacked onto your bill and you no longer have to talk to anyone at your table, because unless they are sitting next to you it's impossible to hear them. Oh? You like conversation? Bummer. We gave up talking to the people across from us for the most part. Yelling for an hour was unpleasant. Our server did waive our "cover charge" for the band, for the entire table. I don't know why, but I was glad. NOT worth $7 if you're eating. The music was good and they have a great dance floor, so if you're there to drink and dance it would be awesome. Lots of good tunes and the band did a great job covering them. I wish we'd stayed after dinner.

When it came time to leave we asked for OUR bill & were told it could not be split up. When we sat & ordered, we'd asked for a separate tab & he said he'd do that at the end. Well, here we are & NO he can't. So everyone figured out what was there's & after a LOOOOOONG time, he came back & grab our cards. At this point it'd been over two hours - which is the time limit for street parking near the hotel, if you don't want to overpay for a garage. Thankfully we had no ticket.

I don't see myself returning here. I was so disappointed. The food wasn't great. Service wasn't great (at our end of the table) - I swear the other end had full drinks!!  It was very expensive and I didn't think the portions were worth the price for the quality.
author: Amy S.

description:
I was so excited to go here as I love kitschy restaurants and fun touristy type things, but the Tonga room was a huge dissappointment...horrible service and a horrible drink. We wanted to a big drink to share, and at the advice of the waiter, went with the "mai-tai" tasting one and not the zombie. (NOTE: there are no descriptions of the drinks so you just have to assume your waiter knows what he's talking about). It tasted like a big $13 bowl of stone sour. Awful. We had two sips and then tried to find our waiter for the next 10 minutes to get the check. He never asked if our drink was okay or even seemed to notice when we asked for the check with a still full drink. 

Save the disappointment and go to Rain Forest Cafe.
author: Kirsten A.

description:
Worth it for happy hour (apparently before 6pm) and also just ONCE for the experience. You feel like you are at Disneyland.. I didn't know what to expect so was REALLY surprised.

i went for A drink on a friday night .. got there about 6pm and walked right in to meet with the group already there.  I did notice that people were already waiting to be seated even though there were tons of empty tables.

A waiter came by to take my drink order within 5 minutes and I loved the fruity options!  The drink was good and reasonably priced at $7.50 (sounds like it goes up as it gets later... + cover??).

I say go if it's early and you don't have any restrictions, cover, drink minimums, etc.  It's worth just seeing - sort of funny it's at the Fairmont...seriously, sort of tacky, but fun! 

Heard the food isnt good though.
author: Melody T.

description: If I could give one star I could. Just called and the woman said if we stopped in it would be 45mins for a walk in table in the dinner room. Not the case. We are nob hill locals bringing tourists. We were completely embarrassed when we were told by the hostess we would be seated shorty. Then the head hostess came 15 mins laser to tell us she had nothing until 945. Seriously? No apologies or other offerings. I haven't seen such a stuck up, rude staff in SF in a long time. Luckily they are in a hotel, because we will never be back. And will let all our local friends know not to go either. Thanks tonga staff for the hospitality lol
author: Shawna M.

description: What a weird place... it's literarlly stuck in some bygone era... we had to come here because we've seen it on a zillion to-do lists, and this year we decided to stay at the Fairmont, so we decided it was time to do it.... we took the tiki plunge... and it wasn't worth the hype.
