The food is terrible (and expensive) we had the tuna poke appetizer, (tasted funny and looked a bit off) my husband had the fish special (which was pretty gross) and I had the singapore noodles (which had plastic in it)- you are probably better off just going down a few blocks to chinatown for some better food. People come here for the ambiance.... (I guess) which, if you love "cheese" then this is the place for you. We tried to get drinks here on a saturday ( we were turned away, told it would be a few hours wait....) then we decided on Sunday to call down and make a reservation... (tip: make a reservation) they charge an "entertainment fee" - $7 per person, the entertainment is also on the cheesy side (kind of like being on the loveboat, circa 1970s..) and the drinks are syrupy and strong (which gave us both a hangover like nobody's business) It is a very, very expensive trip to a "tiki paradise" .... and like a two hour tour that was ill-advised - I would suggest you skip it.
author: J T.

description:
Whoa, there is some serious tiki going down in here: as I descended into the thick of it last night with both locals and fellow travelers in tow, we took in the sights: the thatched huts, the delightfully cheese-ariffic cover band that was banging out the likes of Steely Dan and some Al Jarreau-like wonders, the giant bowls full of straws about the length of my first car, the pineapples Frankensteined together with booze in the middle, straws beckoning from beyond its expanse at the wonders within. It really was something to see. 

For the uninitiated, the cocktail list is classic kitch, and most of the drinks on it are meant to be shared and experienced as a group: the scorpion bowl arrived with six straws to boot, and the menu beckoned others. Note that things can get a little pricey, but for the things that were a little less fun (I waited on a drink a little longer than usual on a couple of occasions, for example), there were also really positive takeaways, like the spontaneous arrival of a new cold one after a friend accidentally knocked over my previous glass, shattering it. In all, the attitudes of staff seem pretty great: our waiter, for example, seemed to have an opening act, who popped by, picked up glasses from the previous party, did a couple of bits and wandered off into the night. 

Go if you can: one thing the Tonga Room is not is dull.
author: Kevin N.

description:
We have been here twice now. Once girls night out and then next Christmas with the kids. The kids had a blast dancing on the dance floor and other were dancing with them... so cute.. 
Beef and broccoli was amazing! Ordered it both times bc it was so good.  Mai Tai was fabulous.. Staff was so friendly and very quick. Floating band was great..

ONE Huge downfall which lost them a star was the cover charge. We had a $350 tab for 4 ladies and 2 kids and they still charged us a cover charge. Obviously we were spending in there. Cover charge cheapens the place! If you are having just one drink bc of Anthony Bourdaine then a cover charge Maybe? but if you are spending some money then it should be waived.. We ordered many many drinks including the punch bowl, apps, meal and even desserts..

Worth a visit.. We will be back but they should think about the cover charge..
author: Lynda N.

description:
A San Francisco institution.  You have to come here just for the kitsch factor and the experience, like no other.  They really don't make these bars anymore.  Very old school, food and drink menu are in the realm of tropical tiki and
 matches atmosphere.-  It is fun in a 'it's so bad it's good' kind of way, except the food really isn't SO bad and neither are the drinks.  Definite must see and experience in SF.  I will be sad if this place closes becuase it is a great place to come with a group and make some great memories.
author: Anibel B.

description: Really enjoyed the vibe, food, and service at Tonga. Thanks to a local tour guide for sharing this treasure. The food was exquisite  and the music awesome! Can't wait for our next visit to San Francisco.
author: Joe B.

description:
Go for the drinks and atmosphere. Don't go for the food. 

Came here with some friends for a birthday back in April and the experience was mediocre. I loved the theme, drinks, and live band but the food was horrible. The portions and quality of food was like a chain restaurant similar to elephant bar, chili's, or applebees. 

Luckily, the drinks are strong and the environment is fun and exciting as there is a dance floor. However, parking is difficult or extremely expensive.
author: Amanda L.

description:
We were prepared to embrace the kitschy Hawaiiana bar with its loud and strong drinks. Afterall, we were here for a business dinner and money was no object. So what if it costs $17 to drink out of a pineapple?

Alas, even though I didn't  shell out a single cent, the experience was way below par. I can't imagine what my review would be if i actually had to pay

Service:
The hosts checking us in were so clueless. The person who made the reservations clearly said we were here for dinner, but when we arrived first, they asked us if we were there for Happy Hour or Dinner and were reluctant to let us in until we could figure it out. 
Then they told us the some from our party had come by but left because they were confused about whether we were dining or just drinking. Confused, we waited outside until someone from our party came out to look for us- they'd been at the bar the entire time. 
whaaaaaa?

The lame service continued with the servers; they were So aggressive and abrupt. I felt like I was in Chinatown, the way he barked at us for our drink and food orders. Is this the theme? did i miss something? 
He kept pestering if we were going to order entrees- i get that he was anxious that the 12 of us weren't just gonna plonk ourselves down for drinks, but seriously, mister. We had just sat down and were on our Second round of Overpriced drinks. We had Just ordered a ton of overpriced appetizers (16 dishes++); surely you can give us a few mins to decide is we want entrees?
When i told him we were still deciding, he was clearly miffed.
did he really want to push the gross entrees on us when we were Clearly ready to spend a lot of money drinking up a storm? 


Food:
I didn't think anything could be worse than Panda Express. But clearly, I was wrong. I can stomach Panda Express when my flight is delayed @ O'Hare. Never again will i subject myself to the food here. 
The ribs, coconut shrimp and fried rice were the only dishes that were semi-good. 
The chow mein was $20 of nastiness- way greasy and just gross tasting. The S'pore noodles @ $24 was just as bad. $24 could have bought me 3 delicious dishes at Ler Ros, but that's another story. 
The dimsum @ $8 for 4 pieces- yuck. Peking duck dumplings? i think not- i KNOW peking duck. this was NO Peking duck. I'm not from Kansas. 
I couldn't even look at the satay and spring rolls. 

Drinks:
Probably the only reason i gave this place a 2*. 
They were huge, strong, but WAY sugary. 

Dessert:
Baked Alaska 
it was definitely theatrical with its flaming meringue. 
But it wasn't very well made. some parts of it were drenched with alcohol; some of it was just plain sugary sweet. 

I'm all about embracing kitschiness, but not when it's so clearly overpriced and have such little regard for their quality of food. 

My stomach was Not feeling so good that night. 
I won't be back here again, even though i live across the street. 
Horrors
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Eh, we went here because we heard that there was good live shows and that it was themed well - and it was. But the drinks are just awful. They have very little alcohol and tons of sugar. My brother and I left there with stomach aches and no buzz. 

It' reminded me of a place you might go to in Times Square NYC. Something touristy with drinks that sound really fun to drink, but are mostly made of juice and soda and cost a lot.
author: Kane A.

description:
Went for their happy hour and it was pretty amazing.

I didn't get any food though since I was planning on dropping by Off The Grid with my friend afterwards. 

Split a Pina Colada with my friend and it was amazeballs. Very fruity, but strong. Even my friend who's normally not the biggest fan of rum loved it. 

I can't believe it, but I gotta admit it's pretty sad that this is the first tiki bar I've ever been to in my life. But it's soooo cool, so I'm not too sad for that. 

I love how they have indoor rainstorms just like in the tropics and they literally have a huge pool in the middle of the restaurant that captures all the falling water. I think it rains every 15-20mins. 

I'm not sure I'd come here outside of happy hour or even eat the food at all since it honestly didn't look that great to me. But that might be just me, since I tend to not like Asian fusion. 

Note, the waits for a table at happy hour might be long if you don't get there early. My friend and I were late in meeting people but luckily they'd gotten there early enough where it was not an issue for us. But we did see a large number of people outside waiting to get in.
author: Constance C.

description: I had to see what all the fuss is about and this place was a good time. Drinks are a bit on the high end as far as price goes but they were good. Deff a must if your in San Fran its a nice experience. I haven't been in a bar like this ever. The "thunderstorms" every half hour are pretty cool to.
author: Nick C.

description:
As a Tiki enthusiast this was a must visit. Unfortunately we got there too early for music, but the setup is great.

The rain show isn't brilliant, but it is an institution. The maitai was ok.

Definitely worth a single trip for a quick drink and a few photos...
author: Ross T.

description: Yes Please, I said to the fruity drinks with umbrellas, Rain-showers a giant Tiki, its like the Hawian Brady Brunch episode in here... in a good way! I had the best waiter ever who was helpful and attentive while seeing to hundreds of others. Yes its a bit over the top but why not!
author: Tara M.

description:
I have to admit, I would never have thought to visit if it wasn't for Anthony Bourdain. Yeah, I am one of those people who realize a place is 'cool' after everybody else in the world has already figured it out. If Mr. Bourdain went to the McDonald's on Van Ness, I'd probably go there too.

That's not to say that the Tonga Room is anything like McDonald's; it's a 1000 tiki torches better! My first visit here was definitely an experience. My friend and I skipped getting food and stuck to the drink menu. My island drink of choice for the night: The Zombie, a concoction of rum and fruit juices...what kind of fruits I couldn't say since the only thing I could taste was the rum! In short, it didn't take many drinks before I was up on the dance floor doing my impression  of Elaine Benes and her little kicks from Seinfeld, quite fun!

Everything from the drinks to the band playing cover songs on the barge in the middle of the tropical river make this place nothing, but a blast. Sure, there are probably places around that mix a better drink and have a better dance floor, but you don't come to place like the Tonga Room expecting this (if you do, you're crazy!). It's the adult version of Disneyland; a little bit kitschy, and a whole lot of fun if you don't take it so seriously.

I read some reviews that the service can be spotty; I had no such problems on my visit as our waitress was on the ball with our drink orders and constantly checking in on us. Overall, a fun night and definitely an experience any SFer should go through.
author: Chris J.

description:
Disappointing!!  We are big Tiki and Polynesian fans and we know good when we see it.  

We made online reservations without any issue but when we arrived we found a little sign at the host stand saying that on Friday and Saturday nights there is a $7 charge per person added for the entertainment (band). The band was a very loud cover band that wasn't even good. The band was so loud that you couldn't carry on a conversation with the person seated directly across from you from any part of the restaurant.

Upon being seated we weren't even given menus nor saw a waiter in our area. This coupled with the overly loud atmosphere made us leave within 2 minutes of being seated. 

This is definitely a tourist trap with large 10-15 people tables filled with sweet alcohol drink-drinkers that just added to the unbearable noise.  

Don The Beachcomber in Sunset Beach CA is the real Tiki experience and they invented the Mai Tai!
author: Christy S.

description: This is a fun little tourist tiki hut kinda bar/restaurant. I came here for a company dinner once.  They have a live band on a raft and it rains inside. The volcano drinks can get you pretty tipsy before you know it and the food is pretty good. It's a fun spot for a big group thing.
author: Sumeena B.

description: I stayed at the Fairmont upstairs and stopped into the Tonga room every night for a drink. The unique atmosphere is timeless. Gigantic drinks served in an entire pineapple with umbrellas, a floating band that is pulled in between sets and of course the rainstorms inside during the intermissions. Yes it rains in here. This is a timeless bar that makes you wonder what decade you are in. It is a must see if you are into novelty bars. I have not tried the food but it looked decent.
author: Scott M.

description: Fun if you've never been there - it's once of those "I'm glad I went but I don't need to go again" kinds of places. It's worth it if you're from out of town and/or don't have much opportunity to go to Polynesian-themed places. It's cute, if a little cheesy.  But the drinks are way overpriced and the service is very mediocre.
author: Sheila C.

description:
First time ever at this legendary Tiki bar.

We hadn't made reservations so we waited in line.  No worries.  It wasn't long before the very friendly staff sat us in perfect view of the dance floor and pool.  The band was playing so it was a little loud but in a good way.

The waitstaff was incredibly friendly and attentive.  

We sampled several of the featured cocktails and ordered a PuPu Platter.  Yum!

This is such a fun place for a special occasion.  Folks were singing and dancing and everyone was smiling.
author: P T.

description: Had to wait for a table at the bar, but not long for a Saturday night.  Waitress got our drink wrong...but we were going to try what she brought us anyway.  Really fun place to go!!
author: Michele P.

description: We went for the happy hour, which is from 5 to 7. We made it there 15 minutes before 7 and there was a line. Nobody told us we can just walk in to the bar and order drinks, instead they asked us to wait. We missed the happy hour. Then we tried to argue with the waitress and manager. The manager came up without even asking and was really rude, saying there is absolutely nothing they could do. Such a terrible experience. Will NEVER come back again.
author: Yu X.

description:
DRINKS:
All the drinks I've had here are good and pretty strong! Bowl of rum tropical cocktails with long straws, and garnished with fresh fruit.

SERVICE:
Cover charge to get in.. which is ok, for the novelty of the atmosphere. C'mon, Frank Sinatra came here before!!! It's a classic place!!! Table service at the bar area - - haha... it's ok.. older asian ladies who seem a little impatient.


ATMOSPHERE:
:D You're on vacation! Feels like in tropics just enjoying vacay with the floating live band in the center... fake rain and thunder storm... dance floor... it's fun. Definitely fun to go to, and definitely meaningful coz of the history too :)
author: Angela L.

description: If you like cheesy restaurants with tiki torches and  fufu drinks everywhere, moving band stage on an 11 foot pool, drunk tourists dancing the night away, check this place out. Food is okay, drinks are super  sweet with different bright colors . Even if you have dinner reservations, they still charge you 7 dollars per person for entertainment charge, which is another word for cover charge. I think that is sleazy..
author: Claudine V.

description: It was a cold rainy day in December. Not to mention my birthday!  So for starters I went to make a reservation a week before our actual date (dec 17) and the host had said that the latest time she could fit my party of 5 was at 6:30. Now have in mind that their dinner hours differ than most restaurants; also they offer a live band--which they do charge an additional 5 dollars per person for entertainment costs. On our way we were stuck in traffic and I had called to let them know we were going to be arriving later than expected. NO PROBLEM! The host I had talked to on the phone had happily moved my reservation to 7 from 6:30 and guaranteed a table for us if we were coming in later. Food was ok. We ordered Ohana style (Aina Ahiahi Ma'alahi) which was 56 per person. It isn't all you can eat but they do give you generous portions. If I had to recommend this place I would only suggest coming for the nightlife. It was a cool experience coming here for my birthday but from my personal opinion I would only come back for the bar and the atmosphere.  3/5
author: Jon B.

description:
Looking for a Tiki bar with some retro music, well this is the place for you. A couple simple tips for everyone:

1. Reservations help out a lot. I initially asked where the Tonga room was and I was told there was a private event going on.  I told them I had a reservation then was happily directed to the Tonga room.
2. The drinks are super sweet, so be careful on your orders. 
3. Service isn't the best but order the appetizers, they are not as expensive as everything else. 
4. The band isn't that bad, its pretty cool when it rains inside.
5. The crowd is mostly older so come with friends. 

Overall, the place is alright. It was a bit expensive but worth the experience. A great place to bring out of towners.
author: Pete N.

description:
I've been wanting to come here ever since Bourdain's SF Layover episode. The experience was great, but it was quite the adventure to visit. Firstly, street parking took about an hour to locate. We actually parked in a garage initially and then realized the hotel staff was evacuated due to a fire (fire alarm?). It was windy, foggy, and freezing. We left, then decided to try again after the fire situation cleared. Secondly, the bar was very difficult to find. We kept going further down, and eventually asked a kind hotel staff member. 

Be aware there is an entertainment fee, like a cover if you will. It is worth it though. The drinks are spendy, but the Mai Tai was very very strong. Overall, expect to spend a decent amount for drinks here. Stay a while, it'll be worth it. I just don;t see myself frequenting this place more than a few times.
author: Angie Q.

description: Love this places' vibe and character and laid back nature! The drinks are just right on fruity and kick, great prices for happy hour buffet! Perfect place to have a life changing conversation!
author: David Q.

description:
I'm not going to lie, I wanted to come here after I saw Anthony Bourdain's The Layover. I just moved here, so I basically took notes on places that looked like fun. The Tonga Room was on the list =)

I went with 3 friends, when we got there, there was a huge line. That part sucked, but there's a app for that =) Broke out my iPhone, went onto Open Table, clicked on a reservation for 20 minutes from then, we went upstairs to the Fairmont bar, had a drink, walked back downstairs, passed the whole line & got seated right away. That's the way to go.

I would have never guessed a place thats on the boarder of cheesy would be in a Fairmont. When I say cheesy, I mean it in the best possibly way. It was like being on a little vacation, or on a cruise ship. Not somewhere I would go everyday, but will most definitely be back.

The 4 of us shared a Lava Bowl, which tasted like striaght booze (no compliants), we had the appertizer sampler plate, I got the Dragon Beef that our server recommended & one of their rices with sausage I believe, forgot the name. It was FABULOUS. I tried my friends Butterfish, great as well. Then we had a round of Zombie drinks. Even stronger!

The check for the 4 of us was $283 before tip, but we each got our own entrees but they are definitely big enough that I would share next time, I barely put a dent in mine it was so big. Not bad for a Lava Bowl for 4, appertizer sampler plate, 4 entrees, fried rice for the table & 4 Zombie drinks.

Great band playing, people dancing. Made for a fun start to a Saturday on a rainy San Francisco night. Fun expierience.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night during a quick trip in SF.... One of our friends had read about this place and we decided to visit. 

Maybe I am a sucker for historic places, I kept thinking what this place was like 40-50 years ago and the people that might have patronized this place. 

The drinks were a tad pricey, but you are not paying for just the alcohol and the salty service, it's also for the ambiance and the band (via cover charge automatically added to the bill). 

It's a great experience and the band made it a blast to sit listen to the music, the thunderstorm, and watch crazy people dance on the dancefloor.
author: Michael G.

description:
Tonga room! Its just a touristy place but who doesn't like it. I wouldn't say to expect a high classy restaurant when you walk in.

But if you like fun drinks with a band playing on the water and dancing you'll enjoy this place.

Its a must see at least once. Go with a crowd or friends.
author: Jess O.

description: Ambiance is amazing! The customer service is decent. The band is superb! The food is awful. Well at least stay away from the huli huli chicken. The BBQ sauce or the marinade lacks taste. A dish with such flavorful ingredients like BBQ chicken, assortment of bell peppers, onions, pineapples, shouldn't be so flavorless.
author: Ila B.

description:
This place was BONKERS last weekend when I held my birthday party.  I hadn't been here since before Bourdain showed up and the crowd was a bit overwhelming.  Some of my guests had to wait in line (I had no idea there'd be a line!!)

Having said that, however, it's still an awesome place to spend an evening.  The food and drinks are delicious, the staff is efficient and friendly and the atmosphere CANNOT be beat.   

(Be prepared to pay for an entertainment fee on nights when the band plays!)
author: Lydia L.

description: If you are able to make a reservation, you just might have the most amazing experience here. Without one, you will most certainly have the worst.
author: Taylor W.

description:
When the BFF said that Tonga Room was a grown up version of something that should be at Disneyland, I was intrigued.

The girls and I came by on New Years weekend, and had a blast. I loved the band playing in the middle of the pool, thought the faux thunder storm was fun, and LOVED the giant punch bowl the 4 of us shared.

The crowd here was so varied, I couldn't believe it. We were dressed to impress as Tonga Room was just one of many stops. There was an older gentleman that looked like Karl Lagerfeld dancing up a storm, there were middle aged couples, there were even a few children. It was like a really casual, fun wedding reception.
author: Jessica H.

description: VERY VERY over priced.. Drinks were not tasty.  Food was ok.. The Apps were amazing! i'd go back only for the apps..  Service was great.
author: Patty A.

description:
Don't come here if you're hungry. The food is terrible. If I had to come here again, it would be only for drinks when I'm in a get-the-hell-out-of-SF mood. The atmosphere is sufficiently entertaining with the transformation into another, shall we say better, world. A small step up from your average tiki bar, but I expected more from the Fairmont.

Luau night with the buffet is definitely NOT worth $55 per person.

The Fairmont must have a hard time pay their employees, because they charged $26.82 in gratuity for a "large party" and there was only 3 of us.
author: Traci S.

description:
Oh, Tonga Room.  How I love you.  I hope your resurgence in popularity isn't going to your head and getting you all fancified.  If you turn into Roy's, I'll be very sad.

A beautiful tiki wonderland with all the requisite trappings, from drinks to pineapple-and-cherry-laden food, to bamboo, wood and tiki mugs, Tonga hits all the right notes.  When I was last there, it seemed a little perfunctory and slightly down in the heels, and I wondered whether the Fairmount isn't just a little bit embarrassed by their garish, drunken hanger-on, and wishes they could just send it home.

But what delights me most about the Tonga Room - what will FOREVER delight me and keep me coming back - is that damn thunderstorm.  It's not even slightly believable and it somehow makes it all the more clear that this bar is built on top of a swimming pool, but I just love it.  Twice an hour, I giggle, clap and bounce in my seat.
author: Gerry S.

description:
We held our Rehearsal Dinner here because we wanted a fun, family-friendly atmosphere. Having come to case out the environment at dinner back before we booked the rehearsal dinner, we knew that we were mostly paying for the fun, themed atmosphere. The food was pretty good and the drinks very good. Once the band starts playing, it becomes hard to hear conversations at your table. We opted to hold our Rehearsal Dinner right as the restaurant opened and before the band started, so we were able to hear each other. There are only 2 group menus to choose from, but we and our guests were happy with the food quality and quantity. The service for our group dinner was definitely better than when we had just come as a group of 5 for dinner
As long as you know that you're partially paying for an experience, the prices are easier to take. It was a a very fun experience!
author: Angelique F.

description: Charges a cover and you wait in line for mediocre drinks. Skip it. The hotel is also really old and dumpy for such an expensive one.
author: Louis N.

description: Worst idea ever! I came here for my 5 year anniversary and I honestly was not satisfied. We ordered calamari as an entree and it was still raw, nor crispy at all. If your not a sea food person don't come here. Service was alright. The only thing I could complain about is the food. It's a little over priced and the music is really slow beat, more like love songs. Should've just gone to Chris Ruth's Steak House.
author: Laura D.

description: Great live music, delicious food and powerful cocktails. Definitely coming back. It's a great place to take visitors to San Francisco and for a group dinner.
author: Liz S.

description:
This is a kind of place, which you will mention in passing to your friends and colleagues, when they are talking about fusion cuisine from Hawaii, and restaurants that serve them in San Fran. 

They tend to seat couples too close to large families, even when the rest of restaurant is empty. The prices are high, but you went in knowing that. However, some of the portions are too small. It is quite possible to go to this place spend $150 on dinner for two, and come out hungry. 

Service is nothing to speak of. It is mediocre, at best. Will I go there again?Hmmm....not sure. Food is good, but nothing that will make drive to this place.
author: Nocturnal K.

description:
Damn you Anthony Bourdain! As guests at Fairmont, for 2 nights we had to wait in a ridiculous line to even enter the Tonga Room. The first night, we just gave up and went over The Big 4 at Hotel Huntington. The 2nd night, we just waited.  I want to believe its because of all the conferences that were going on at the hotel but, I think Anthony had a lot to do with this line. I bet Anthony didn't wait in the line...lol. 

After a 45 minute wait, we are seated at the bar. The bartender was super busy. I think he was the only bartender working on this Saturday night. I feel bad for the guy because not only did he have to serve the partrons at the bar but, he had orders coming in from the waiters on the floor...Sheesh. We sat at the bar for about 20 min before another bartender (or waiter) decides to take our order. 

The drinks were amazingly strong and huge and after 1 drink....I feel good :) So good, we go back to the hotel room to prepare for a night out and end up falling asleep  for hours. LOL.

The rainstorm and thunder is pretty entertaining and everyone seemed to be in a pretty good mood. I like it here.

Ooooh and if you come on a Fri or Saturday and you are there when the band starts around 8pm, there is a cover charge of $7.00.
author: Chantelle A.

description:
THIS PLACE.

1. The drinks. Are. Deadly. (and delicious). 
2. The food is pretty mediocre, but gets the job done.
3. IT RAINS. INSIDE.
4. The band plays on a boat in the middle of what used to be the Fairmont's swimming pool.

This is a fantastically kitschy place to take friends who are visiting or to celebrate an occasion.
author: Lauren F.

description:
We wanted to check this place out after all the hype from being showcased on The Layover. I took the advice of other Yelpers and decided to only go for happy hour rather than dinner. Happy hour is Wednesday, Thursday and Friday from 5-7. $10 per person which includes the buffet, but there is also a 1 drink minimum per person. The food was totally 'meh' chinese food (fried noodles, fried rice, spring rolls, chicken wings, macaroni salad). The drinks are pretty strong. 

The indoor rainstorm was somewhat cool, but lost its novelty after about 10 seconds.
author: Garrick L.

description: Went for my birthday and had an amazing time. We had had dinner elsewhere, so didn't try the food, only went for drinks and dancing. The drinks were fun, the atmosphere is awesome, and the band they get was perfect. I was with my mom, who remembers going to Tiki lounges back when they were originally popular and she said it was 100% accurate - decor, music, vibe. We had a really fun time - definitely an unforgettable memory!
author: Claire A.

description:
So.. you don't know how a place is like until you really go and look for yourself. I was thinking just that, and the curiosity was really getting to me! I must know. I must know! Thursday night 11 pm, plenty of seats, no wait, you can feel it the place was winding down. The servers were kind but probably tired by that time, wanting to go home and hit the bed. 

Don't need to order food , unless you want to spend $30 for Mongolian beef. Erm?
Lava bowl for two= $20. The bowl is small, but tasty. Blended ice + alcohol. Pineapples+cherries+ umbrellas. Longgggg straws so you can reach across the table. 
The lightning was what I felt low key. I think Rainforest Café's lightning +sound effects + elephant cries are more extravagant. I wish there would be fake rain everywhere instead of only in the middle where the pool is. 
Just as everyone says, go once, so you don't have that voice in the back of your head telling yourself take me there take me there please!

I would take out of towners here for FUN, but only if walking. Def no street parking around here!
author: Veranna N.

description:
So over-the-top cheesy it's fantastic. Strong drinks with umbrellas. The band plays songs like "Africa" and "Easy". Drunk people with limited dance skills throw their hands in the air and wave 'em like they just don't care. If the drink prices and/or cover charge bother you, they have happy hour (complete with buffet).

If you can't have fun here, you are taking your boring self WAY too seriously.
author: tracy b.

description:
This is part one of a sequel.  I feel that it's not necessary to save the best for last.  In this case, I'm bringing you the best in a saga called, "The Good, The Bad and The Ugly."

Is saw a great deal on Facebook for a Prix Fixe dinner at the Tonga Room.  $31.00 per person for a complete dinner with cocktail.   I hopped on the  deal and purchased 2 (one for me, one for hubby) and proceeded to update my status and share it with my friends.  We ended up with four couples in our group.  

Imagine my panic on the day of the event when Facebook wouldn't bring my voucher up and kept giving me an error.  I tried to reach Facebook.  Really?  What planet do I live on, you can't reach Facebook.  So I tried to reach SugarPoP SF since they sponsored the deal.  NOPE.  No help (but those are separate reviews).  

After brick walls, looping voice mails and extreme frustration, I finally reached someone 2 and a half hours before my reservation.  I explained the problem and the fact that I didn't want to drive all the way from the North Bay, only to be turned around.  The lady at the counter (I'm sorry I forgot your name, you were awesome), advised me that she would look me up and that if I could print out something from the facebook page she would take care of me.  And she did.

After walking up from Union Square (DO NOT TRY THIS), and the anxious moments of ensuring my voucher would be honored, it was so nice to be whisked to our table.  The dinner was spectacular.  Our entire group enjoyed everything from the diverse menu.  While enjoying our free drinks (Mai Tai or Pena Colada), we were serenaded by the live band.  In between fresh courses, we danced on the bow of the ship.  Service was impeccable and we all enjoyed a wonderful evening.

Yes it's kitschy, but it's so much fun.
author: Bee D.

description: Overpriced a tad, but come here for the novelty and touristy vibe, not to be wowed.
author: Adam C.

description:
I'd never been to the Tonga Room before, but now I'm not sure why I waited so long! A sucker for theme bars, the Tonga Room is over-the-top Tiki! 

Things I loved:

1) NOT waiting in line or paying cover. Thank god the birthday girl got there before us, and schmoozed with the bouncer. The boyfriend and I got to bypass the line and jump right in.

2) The overall atmosphere. Who doesn't love indoor rain or a live band?

3) Who doesn't love fruity, tropical drinks...though I will admit, some were stronger than others...and some just were awful.

Things I didn't love:

1) I don't think our server was a big fan of us. Chick seemed to have a major attitude problem. Or maybe we just were THAT obnoxious.

2) The price of cocktails. $14 a pop is a little steep for this chick!

Rumor has it that this place is going to shut down. This would be a true shame, as it's a true San Francisco experience!
author: Annalise F.

description:
This place is so funny. Dark, polynesian-looking wood, the lagoon, the thunderstorms complete with rain, the ridiculous cover band that appears on a raft - as everyone else has said, this place is kitschy-awesome.

I had a really strong martini, but sipped a tiki drink that tasted nice enough. I didn't see anyone eating food, though.
author: S D.

description:
Enter Fairmont hotel. Find main building elevators, then travel down to floor T. But if you do that, you might miss the roof garden on the entry level, which was delightfully abandoned and serene when I happened upon it (and only in San Francisco would the roof garden be located on the entry level).

The Tonga Room was anything but abandoned and serene. Wow. Yeah, this really exists. It makes Kowloon in suburban Boston look restrained.

My drink was unpalatable, but I'm not really a tiki drinks person unless I have a whole passel of people with me to do scorpion bowls (and it's been a few years since I've swung that way, anyway).

Minus: I got seated at the bar where I couldn't really see anything.
Plus: I didn't have a cover charge added to my bill.
author: Bria D.

description: Don't do it. We had horrendous  food so so drinks for $230 and we were then charged $10 each for the band. The band is good don't get me wrong but really?  Won't recommend it to anyone
author: lynn p.

description:
The cheesiest bar in San Francisco, but fun if you're with a group of people. I've never eaten the food so just reviewing the bar and entertainment.  I stay at the Fairmont a lot and I usually come after 10Pm. I never experienced waiting in line at all. However, this place always seems packed on the weekends.
Their speciality cocktails are horrible.  I ordered the lychee martin and it was the worst lychee martini I ever had.  I think the lychee was from a can and it was expired. I've had the scorpion bowl and it was ok, and tasted like the jungle juice I use to make in my college days.
The house band was not that good, and I heard the worst rendition of a Bruno Mars song ever.  Despite all this, this place has a good vibe and everyone else seemed to be having fun, even if half the crowd were tourists.  I'll bump up the rating to a 3-star based upon the fun-factor you and your friends will have.
author: Emmett B.

description: This place has been around forever-iconic in that sense.  It was fun just to go to try it.  The food was ok.  Ribeye dish was the best with sweet potato fries.  Waiter was great to steer us away from the orange chicken.  The wok and roll dishes were good choices.  Salmon wasn't cooked thru.  The combo appetizer platter was very tasty.  Servers were all attentive and great!  It was just fun to go.  The line to get in for Happy Hour was ridiculously long and was a wait.  We went in for dinner and had reservations so it was easy.
author: Denise L.

description: Love this place...decors n its Polynesian theme's awesome!!!  But...not worth ur $ to spend if ur aiming to have a group.  Had 30( @$65 per Pax Adult n @$28 per child.. ) people party here n requested to sit upfront n won't mind seating separately but next to the band n water..n I requested a month in advanced...plus set menu etc...per person was $Day of party...we were seated at the very back...n food was OK...like a pricy PF chang.  However we got charged for extra plate food  and they didn't serve the right dessert for kids as I have requested....I did not bother calling them to correct everything coz I had a bad experience from beginning... So gud luck if u decide to host ur party here...
author: Lokelani M.

description: Too loud, and the food was ok, but not really worth the price.  We celebrated a birthday there tonight.  Great atmosphere !!!  The service was great, but when the band started all table conversation was lost, the music was so loud.  We asked the manager and the waiter to help, they moved us to a table in the back which helped a little.  We love music, but that was headache inducing.  The calamari was great, crispy, perfectly cooked....the sauce was bland.  The scallops were gritty, and for $29.00 and only 4 medium sized scallops...not worth the $$$.  This place is excellent for a date night at the bar only, dinner is overpriced and "rocked" out
author: Christy D.

description:
IT'S LIKE THE DISNEYLAND TIKI ROOM FOR ADULTS!

My mom has bragged about this place since I was a little girl. She and my dad used to go out and leave us with the babysitter. Well now it's my turn! My mom and I went to the Tonga Room for my birthday...and it was seriously the best birthday ever. (Well...aside from the Sweet 16 when I got a car...but it's a close second).

Parking was frustrating. We drove around forever but couldn't find anything so we finally ended up paying $50 for valet parking at the Fairmont.

We were late for our reservations but called on the way and they adjusted them, when we got their they seated us immediately.

The atmosphere is a dream. There's a huge pirate ship that has been converted into a dance floor, and palapa-style huts that are the tables are situated around the Fairmont's used-to-be swimming pool. A live band plays from a boat that floats out onto the pool. Seriously? Can it get better.

Oh yes...yes it can!

Let's talk rum. Yup. You heard me. Who woulda thought that high on hill in San Francisco you'd find a tropical tiki bar that serves countless island delights? I ordered a mai tai. It came in a coconut-looking glass with a little umbrella. Wow, heaven! 

Okay, to be honest, I loved the look of the mai tai but it tasted awful. Even the second one. It's not your typical orange juice, grenadine, rum kinda mai tai. So not as sweet as I'd like. But after that I ordered pina coladas...and those were blissful. ($12 a pop)

I have heard that the food here is mediocre but my mom and I had a completely different experience. We both ordered the rib eye and it was the BEST steak I've had in years. So tender, juicy, moist, and cooked just as I ordered. The sweet potato fries were actually rounds, not strips, and they were tempura battered and delicious.

Okay...atmosphere, check. Drinks, check. Food, check. Oh...the band!!! I was so impressed by the band! They played a great mix of classic rock, disco, R&B...just all those hits that everyone loves. Multi generational and amazing. After dinner mom and I hit the dance floor and had a ball...especially after those pina coladas...

Dessert...skip it. Not even worth talking about. Just order another drink instead.



Afterwards my mom took me up to the "secret" garden on the roof. Wow. Incredible! A beautiful hidden gem on the roof of the hotel. 

This place was amazing and it was a fantastic birthday. What a special, unique and fun place to go. I can't wait to go again someday with someone who has never been there and see their face light up like mine. Five stars, definitely five stars.
author: Amanda H.

description:
I am really suprised by the good reviews for this place. I'll give it that it's fun and if you're curious you should check it out for the experience. It's like dining in a Disneyland ride.

But here's the thing - the food was pretty awful. Everything was overcooked, overseasoned, and oversauced. It was almost like getting panda express but for 5x the price!

I figured the one advantage should have been the drinks. But the specialty punch cocktail i got was SO sweet it hurt my throat.
author: James F.

description: Received extremely poor service when I came here with a group of friends. Talked to the manager about it and he said he wouldn't help, extremely unhelpful. Haven't felt that frustrated with an experience at a restaurant in a very long time. Was really looking forward to it.
author: Gaby M.

description:
Fun but not the best place on earth by far. Sorry Bourdain. 

Yes, it a tourist trap. And yes I wouldn't touch the food with a ten foot pole, because I know I can find cheaper and better food down the road a bit. And yes there are a lot, I said a lot of old people there. The drinks are sticky sweet and the bartenders a bit curt. 

I'm sorry $40 plus for 2 drinks and calamari - Trader' Sams here we come! 

Since I am a bay area native I can't believe that it took this long to get the place checked it off my bucket list. Next!
author: Jade W.

description:
The Tonga Room is kind of cheesy, kind of touristy and probably over-hyped but it's still a good time. The drinks are fun, kind of expensive but strong. The crowd is mostly tourists. The music was great actually - they played classic songs that everyone can dance to. The type of songs that were played at the daddy daughter dance I used to go to. We actually had a great time here dancing, meeting some people... good, PG rated fun. 

This isn't the type of place I'd frequent but it is fun and definitely worth going to at least once!
author: Alison B.

description:
On Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, the Tonga Room has an "extensive" happy hour buffet. The buffet is all-you-can eat and it is only $9.50 (plus a minimum of one cocktail)! If you go for dinner, sometimes you pay $9.50 for just one dish, and then once you finish it's done, you can't ask for more (very rude). So paying $9.50 and getting more is an amazing good deal and that is why Sophie, Jason and I decided to go to the Tonga Room Tiki Bar!

When you get there you have to ask for a table. They will offer you a table on one of the sides of the room, on a deck that looks like a ship, or in the middle of the room between a lot of people but close to the bar. If you aren't sure which table you want, get the one on the ship because it's better. If you want to be close to the bar, don't, because you have a waitress that can get you anything from the bar.

The tables are made of wood and the chairs too, but they have pillows which are really soft. That is good if you plan to stay for a while. The room is very dark and tropical. There is a candle on every table and light-lantern style strings. They are nice because they give a nice mood. There is a ship's wheel and straw hut roofs, and in the middle of the room is a giant pool, but a dark one and it's not for swimming just for mood. 

It is important that you order a cocktail. You have to, because that's the rule of the buffet. They have a selection, and every cocktail is $7.50 because it is happy hour. Normally the cocktails are more expensive. They have a selection, and one yummy cocktail I had was the Tonga Itch. It sounds nasty because itches are STDs sometimes. This is a cocktail and it is delicious. 

In the middle of the room is something that could be a dance floor, and there you will find the buffet. When we saw the buffet we were very surprised. It was on a table that was not very long. This is what they had:

- Chicken wings in a sweet chili sauce
- Macaroni salad
- Spicy edamame
- Fried rice with ham
- A mix of cantaloupe, honeydew and pineapple, but mostly it was honeydew
- Asian style noodles with vegetable style stuff
- Mini spring rolls with a sauce
- More chicken wings in hot sauce 

This list isn't missing anything. This was their buffet. I was very disappointed and sad.

- The chicken wings in the sweet chili sauce were tasty, because chicken wings and sweet chili sauce are yummy and everyone likes them. I had lots of chicken wings, and one of them had the most meat on it I have ever eaten from a chicken wing! That was nice but could also mean the chicken was bionic.

- The macaroni salad was very horrible. I dont like macaroni salad because I don't like mayo, but sometimes you eat something you don't like and it's okay. This macaroni salad was very disgusting. 

- The edamame were okay. They had very good intentions because of the spicy stuff, but they didn't taste very fresh and it's edamame - it's not a real food you cook!

- The fried rice was very normal. It was fried rice, and if you don't like meat it sucks because it had bits of ham in it. I like fried rice, but it usually fried rice has stuff in it except for ham. Like pineapple. It didn't. It was boring.

- The fruit was very horrible, too. It wasn't fresh fruit and it tasted like they got it from a can. Pineapple is always yummy, even from the can, but they didn't have much pineapple, mostly honeydew that was disgusting. I used some pineapple and ate it with my fried rice so it would be less boring. 

- The noodles were very oily and boring. They are the noodles you get at a Chinese buffet when you pay $4. I ate them and they were whatever. 

- The spring rolls were okay. They had a sauce which was good because they were the kind of spring rolls that are dry. They tasted like spring rolls that you get and you eat but don't comment on because they are normal; not delicious or disgusting. You just eat them and talk to your friends. 

- I didn't taste the other chicken wings. But they are chicken wings and hot sauce, and everyone loves chicken wings and hot sauce.

It was very disappointing and sad, and I had 4 servings because I was hungry and I wanted to eat more so it it would feel less expensive to pay for a Chinese dinner at a tiki bar. 

In conclusion, the tiki bar in the Tonga Room was nice, but the food was sad. But if you go to the Tonga Room and read this review first, you will feel less bad about it, because you will go for the experience and not for the food. And the experience was nice, and the cocktails were nice, and if you aren't facing the people coming in and out of the gym next door, you can see a nice room with pretty lights and have a good time.
author: Tizia B.

description: The ambiance here is incredible. You really feel like you're sitting outside at a tiki bar listening to the rain outside. The band is incredible, the restaurant decor is amazing, and the service was outstanding. I was expecting better food for the prices.
author: Ankita D.

description:
From a first time Tonga Room client.  Good atmosphere.  Funky decor.  Karaoke entertainment.  Unfortunately, that's where it ends for me and it was pretty much all downhill from there.

This is what happened to us:
1) We were rushed to order drinks and food.
2) Every recommendation was the most expensive one on the menu.
3) None of the dishes were described in detail like other restaurants that serve very expensive food.
4) When we mentioned the prices we were called "cheap" and then told "you probably voted for Obama"
5) Even though we were a party of 8, the total did not include the tip so we added the tip ourselves. Split 4 ways, the bill was paid via cash by one couple and the rest paid by card.  We told the server to keep the change from the cash.  The next day, the 3 couples that paid by card noticed an extra 18% added on to the charge.  Isn't this illegal?
6) Don't be fooled by Anthony Bourdain's experience.  Obviously for PR reasons, he did not experience any of the above.

Take away from this experience.  Food quality is very typical Asian food disguised in fancy arrangement made to look expensive.  Hoping that the service would compensate for the priciness, it turned out to be even worse.  I'm not sure the entertainment makes up for it either.  I have never been to ANY restaurant where I was treated this way.  I will not recommend this place to any of my friends and I will never go back.  I guess I can now say I've been to the Tonga Room but it was, unfortunately, a horrible experience.
author: Reggie Q.

description:
So The Tonga Room for me is a just once in a while kind of place and it is very mixed in my rating. This is how I would break it down:

Drinks - 5 Stars
Service - 3 or 4 stars depending on your server
Food - 3 Stars
Kitch Factor - 5 Stars

So, overall 4 Stars. Prices are high and I think the cover charge is ridiculous, especially since I did not really enjoy the band that was playing. But my musical tastes do not really align with "merely passable covers from the 70's and 80's." I understand that some people might come in here and just oggle the place and not spend any money, so have a minimum charge per person. But paying extra just to be there? 

Anyway, the reason I come here with my best friend is the drinks. They are yummy, huge and they will kick you in the head. HARD. First time I came here and I had a Zombie and I left one as well. This last time I had a Hurricane, which was $16 but it came with a souvenir glass and that was a nice take home from our girl's weekend. 

As we were standing in line to get in we realized that we were suddenly starving so we decided to order some Kona BBQ ribs. They were fine. The sauce was pretty tasty but they were definitely not hot enough temperature wise. I think in the future I would avoid the food and just stick to the drinks. 

Come here with people who you enjoy once you are obnoxiously drunk, because you definitely will be feeling it on your way out.
author: Lisa H.

description: I love that this bar is in my neighborhood.  I love that the atmosphere is both party hardy as well as completely casual.  Plus, the floating island in the middle.  It's all spectacular.  I am so glad that there is a hardcore group of locals who will protect the Tonga from reconstruction in the future.  A true SF landmark!
author: Mel G.

description:
I first went to the Tonga room around 1980. As a 9 year old, I was entranced by the crazy drinks (a fancy Shirley Temple for me, I'm sure), the pool, the band on a boat, and the rain storms!

Flash forward to 1998, it was exactly as I remembered it except I could drink. 

Then took my wife here a couple years ago. Wow, still the same...
author: Chuck K.

description: There's a whole lot of tiki fun to be had at the Tonga room! Get ready to listen to a band on a boat, have it thunder and rain while sipping a stiff tropical drink and having some good laughs with friends.
author: Susan A.

description:
If you like live music, dancing, delicious food and great alcoholic beverages, this place is for you! 

I came here on a Friday night (it had a 7dollar fee for the band - sooooo worth it) and it was spectacular. Though You DEFINITELY should plan ahead aka make reservations or come stupidly early if you want a table. Seriously though make reservations, it really is worth it. ANYWAYS

I arrived a few minutes late but they still held my table (note - if you're going to be even just a few minutes late definitely call ahead and let them know) we were greeted and got the lava bowl- SO DELISH and some amazing appetizers such as the duck spring rolls, and this really yummy fish dish with chips and avocado - SO GOOD. 

For an entree, I got the buttered fish which came with mushrooms and a crab salad. My date ordered the hot pot and we got rice and veggies on the side. SO MUCH FOOD and SO GOOD. It was literally So hard to stop eating it and we got a box to go which was lovely. 

For our second drinks we wanted something with a tiki man, so we looked on the list and found our tiki men and proceeded to order some delicious cocktails - AMAZING

Dessert is always my favorite, I got the green tea chocolate cake and my tastebuds were more than satisfied. I couldn't believe how delicious everything was and my date couldn't have agreed more. The whole atmosphere, the vibe, the random rain around the pool with the music and everything was just SPECTACULAR.

Seriously everyone should come here at least once in their lives to experience the spectacular vibe of the Tonga Room.
author: Julia L.

description:
I was here on Tuesday night and came prepared for cheesy Tiki fun. In other words, I had my expectations for food and service appropriately in check, and I came to have a good time.

What I failed to account for was how much crappy service and even crappier food and cocktails would impact my good mood. Not even the fabulous decor - even more amazing than I'd expected - and hokey AWESOME rainstorm could make up for them.

If this place was a dive bar, with prices to match, the unbelievably brusque waiter would not have bothered me. The watery roasted corn served with the fishy scallops and gristly bacon would not have bothered me. (Well, that would have bothered me, but I would not have been paying $26 for it, so it would have bothered me a lot less.)

It took 25 minutes after we were seated for our waiter to appear to take our drink order. By then my friend had gone to the bar and gotten drinks for us there, since every person who passed our table had managed to ignore our desperate wavings. Finally the waiter arrived and said very rapidly and abruptly, I quote: "Oh, you have drinks already. What would you like to order?" Zero apology, zero welcome, and zero mention of the special of the evening (which we had to ask to find out.) 

I can say without exaggeration that I have had more gracious service at fast food restaurants, and that I have had better cocktails at most dive bars. Yes, I wanted fruity, froo-froo tropical drinks but I was not prepared for cocktails so sweet they made my teeth hurt. I ordered two different drinks and each was undrinkable after a few sips, I finally gave up and ordered wine (again we had to chase the waiter down, actually literally, to get an order in.)

This is San Francisco. I don't care what kind of decor or experience you offer, If you are going to charge $26 for a plate of scallops it had better be worth it. If you are going to run an historic restaurant in a fancy hotel, make sure you hire waiters who have a shred of graciousness to them and then staff your dining room appropriately so that customers aren't left hanging.
author: Mary B.

description:
I give this place a 2.5 stars but of course have to round up to an even 3.  The food was a 1 but the ambiance was a 4 so I'm averaging the two out.  I visited the Tonga Room last Friday. The atmosphere is so much fun!  The decor is very cool, and the live band really adds to the ambiance.  I wasn't blown away by the service but also wasn't disappointed by it in anyway, it was more than fine. 

We started with cocktails, I had the Singapore Sling which is made with Tanqueray, Cointreau, Cherry Heering, lemon and pineapple juice and Angostura bitters.  It was tasty and strong, just the way a $12.00 cocktail should be.  Hubby got the Zombie which is made with three types of rum, fresh lemon, lime, pineapple and passion fruit and Angostura bitters.  He also enjoyed his drink but opted not to finish it because he wanted to make sure he was fit to drive home. So far so good.

For Apps: we got the Shrimp and Cilantro rolls ($13.00) that came with this great Chili Ponzu sauce for dipping, and also the Shiitake Egg Rolls ($13.00) which came with wasabi, spicy mustard and some sweet mustard sauce for dipping.      We were really pleased with both but this is the point the in the evening when the direction changed course.

Entrees: I ordered the Seared Diver Scallops ($28.00) which the menu described as coming with braised leeks, a tomato-lemongrass broth and radish & cilantro salad.  What I actually got: 4 colossal scallops (which were cooked perfectly) in a bed of what looked like soggy cabbage in a broth that tasted like Swanson's chicken broth.  I was not able to identify any cilantro or radishes in the bowl before me.  Hubby ordered the Fried Saimin noodles ($26.00) which were described as being served with Portuguese sausage, scallions, carrot, bean sprouts & crispy mushrooms.  What he actually got: greasy noodles with what looked and tasted like pieces of sliced up hot dog, and dehydrated mushroom which were in no way "crispy."  We also had a side of rice that was mushy in some parts but crunchy in others and an order of Sichuan Green Beans. The green beans were described as being tossed with garlic and having a black bean glaze.  What we actually got: Green beans soaked in what tasted like over salted soy sauce.

Dessert: Didn't want to put ourselves through the experience of any more bad food, so we opted to skip dessert. 

Overall: We did have a really fun time listening to music and looking at all the interesting decorations and decor.  So I would put this place into the same category as Hooters in that you don't go for the food, you go to look at pretty, interesting things and for a unique experience.  And this place really delivers on giving patrons something out of the ordinary.  But if your main draw is great food this is not the place for you.  I would also say that if you want to have a nice quiet intimate conversation you might want to keep looking, the music is quite loud and while it makes for a fun high energy environment, it was hard to carry on a conversation. My final thought is that neither Hubby or I became ill after eating, so there don't seem to be any issues with food sanitation or cleanliness, just poor execution.  I think if they revamped their menu or changed chefs they could be absolutely unstoppable!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Do not come here on a Friday or Saturday night. There is a $7 cover for the live band. Unless that's your thing.

Do not come here unless it's happy hour. That's the only time they have their free buffet.

My first experience at the Tonga Room was four years ago. I remember it fondly because it was so unexpected. Pretty drinks in a fun atmosphere.

I came back last weekend and found that my experience varies wildly with my company. You have to come here with people who are down for a cheesy indoor pirate ship and fruity drinks. Or maybe I've just gotten older and the appeal of those things has waned a bit.

The drinks are still potent (there were no less than a dozen people that were stumbling, literally in a few cases) out the door when we arrived. I found the drinks to be so overly sugary that I had a hard time drinking after a few sips. The four-to-share bowls are the best deal. The other drinks were in the $12 to $16 range so expect to shell out some money, that is if you can get past all the sugar.
author: Cristofer P.

description: I had been looking froward to the Tonga Room ever since I saw Anthony Bourdain's visit on television and it didn't disappoint.  The floating band was lively and fantastic.  We had the Royal Pu Pu platter as an appetizer for 4.  Also, the Lava Bowl was a good choice.
author: Joey W.

description:
Went here on a Friday with one other person at around 9PM. We waited in line for about ten minutes then got sat at a table. We ordered the Scorpion Bowl and another called Smuggler bowl (I think?). They were both $20 a piece. Neither had a much alcohol despite it's large size. Tasty though.

We people watched and chatted at our table. There was a large crowd near their back bar. Occasionaly groups would go out to dance. The music was a little.. interesting. I think it was trying to appeal to a large audience. They would play things like "brown-eyed girl." The crowd at the Tonga room looked to be mostly 30-40 year olds. I may not have been the right audience being in my 20s. 

Overall, I'd give this place a 3.5, but probably higher had I been older.
author: Shannon S.

description:
BEST: The atmosphere looks like you are in some Tropical island outside with a wooden deck, pillars, exotic statues, and a boat in the middle as it rains every once in a while.

The seating is casual and comfortable.  In no way does it look like a lounge or bar.  It's more like a restaurant situated in the Fairmont Hotel.

The fact this restaurant is in the Fairmont Hotel makes it seem worthwhile to go visit the hotel as well.

WORST: Music with a cover charge of $5.00 per person
The cost of drinks and meals are expensive and the food is not even that great at all.

The waitresses are rather mean and abrupt.  I wasn't sure if it was because they were busy but when I went there, there weren't that many people that needed their behavior to be as such.  It took me a while to flag down someone and a long wait to receive my order of the Tonga Platter which was just Shrimps, meat on a stick, and some spring rolls.

Reservations should be made well in advance especially for weekend nights.  However, even though a friend of mine couldn't get a reservation of the night we went, we still were able to get in.  This was on Mother's Day night on a Sunday.

The valet parking is $15.00 per hour with a max out at $54.00 as of May 2012.
There is another parking lot across the street that is roughly the same cost.

My Opinion: It is probably the best place to JUST get drinks and socialize with a group of friends.  Likely Happy Hour is the best time to go as there is probably discounts for drinks.

Dinner (Open 5 days a week) Reservations for dinner are recommended.
Sunday, Wednesday & Thursday: 6:00 p.m to 10:00 p.m
Friday & Saturday: 6:00 p.m to 11:00 p.m.

DRESS CODE
Casual

There is a small dance floor near the boat area.

Music is like Classic 80's Soft Rock
author: K G.

description:
I've heard of the Tonga Room for such a long time that I was excited to finally go experience it for myself.  Now that I've been, I have no reason to return.

The ambiance is awesome.  Let's start there.  The place is a neat room, well-decorated and lit appropriately.  It's a tiki lounge and feels like it.  There's a dance floor that looks like it's part of an old ship (along with the wheelhouse part of the ship, which you can sit and sip expensive drinks in).  Every 15 minutes or so there's a fake thunderstorm that lasts about 30 seconds.  (They could really do with a subwoofer or three to help sell the thunder.)  There's a pond with a floating bandstand.  it's a neat environment.

My impression of the place began to suffer after that, though.  They are very inflexible about their rules.  I was there with a group of about 9 colleagues to have drinks and perhaps dinner.  Some wanted to eat, some already had eaten before arriving.  The bar area has very small tables and really wasn't suitable for those who wanted to dine.  However, they were unwilling to seat us in the dining area (which had plenty of vacancy) unless EVERYONE purchased an entree.  So we sat in the bar area because two people weren't eating.

This place is EXPENSIVE.  The drinks are $12-16.  The dishes are $13-30.  I ordered the Chow Chow, which is a greasy chow mein-style dish.  If you want some protein added, the dish runs $30.  It was tasty enough, but certainly not $30 worth.

After we'd been there drinking multiple $13 frozen drinks for about 90 minutes, a band started playing on the floating bandstand.  They played all covers and really it just made it more difficult to carry on a conversation.  They weren't remotely interesting to me, but whatever.

Then we got the bill.  We'd already had plenty of time to be prepared for the shock of the prices, but there was a little bit of added fun that I have never seen before:  $5 cover charge per person added to the dinner check!

It's not enough that we were absolutely gouged for food and drinks, but because there was an awful cover band playing, we were automatically subject to $5 apiece extra!  (It turns out there's a note at the entrance that tells you this, but at no time did anyone bother to ensure we were aware we'd be charged just to enter the room.)

Am I glad I have finally experienced the Tonga Room?  Sure.  Will I be back?  Only if someone else is footing the bill.  Will I recommend it to my friends?  Not bloody likely.
author: Jory P.

description:
If you're a tiki fan, the Tonga Room is a must do.

The ambiance of the Tonga Room is the best thing though.  Fake rain thunderstorms.  A lagoon.  A raft that floats out on the lagoon with a live band on it.  That's some serious tiki kitsch right there, and I love it.  But honestly, that's the only thing worth a damn at the Tonga Room.

As for the tiki drinks, they kind of suck.  They aren't the worst tiki drinks I've had, nor the best.  Just mediocre.

As for the food, it's Asian-fusion.  And it's quasi-decent.  It's edible but I've had better.

But the service was top notch though.  Partially due to my jet lag and having a drink in my, I had dropped my water glass on the table, where it shattered into many sharp pieces.  I ended up with a lap full of ice water and a small cut on my hand.  I was very embarrassed that it looked like I had pissed myself and I was bleeding, so I high tailed it to the bathroom to dry off and stop the bleeding.  The staff of the Tonga Room was very nice about it all though, making sure that I was OK and didn't need medical attention.
author: Amanda W.

description:
In the Fairmont? Aaarrrr you sure? Yep I am Matey...

Imagine if a Pirate ship were placed in the middle of a Hawaiian themed restaurant on the strip in Vegas...except its on Nob Hill in SanFran...

Dance floor, fancy fruit drink concoctions for about $12-15, fake rain thunderstorms, floating island complete with lounge singers just begging the question where are the blue haired ladies and slot machines?

Regardless, the place made our little group laugh a lot, the drinks were well made, there was plenty of seating and since it was close to our hotels it was a nice place to wind down.

So embrace the corny, order a sugary but highly alcoholic drink in a tiki head glass and talk about the crazy chicks on the dance floor getting their groove on to Neil Diamond-esque tunes.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Great ambience & strong drinks
My husband and I didn't have any food, so I can't comment on that part. The bar area was packed and lively.
author: Tara B.

description: To be honest- I went here because Anthony Bourdain did, and I feel he can do no wrong.  But in this case I questioned him.  In all honesty we didn't eat and the drinks were great- but the atmosphere is just so odd and touristy.  The rainstorm is just strange, and the whole thing seemed like a slightly nicer version of a Rainforest Cafe, and in San Francisco you just do so much better.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I could sum it up as San Francisco's version Blue Bayou (The Restaurant in the Pirates of the Caribbean ride).

Water features?  Check
Endearing Kitschy decor?  Check
Decent food?  Check
Fruity cocktail drinks with small umbrells?  Check

Like Disneyland,  this was a post WW2 creation, where most people haven't travelled to the extent that people do today.   The food is more borderline Chinese food, rather than "island food" (though quite a bit of island food is of Chinese origins).

I went with a part of 10+ people, and ordered the "Ohana" package meal.   The portions were good, the food is decent and the quality of the ingredients are good.  Nothing to complain about.  It is a bit on the pricey side for what you get.  But, you're paying for the ambiance; which was top notch.

If you want good Chinese food, walk a few blocks to Chinatown.  If you want (okay) island food, go to Hukilau or even Hawiian Drive inn.  If you want a fun night, you can come here.
author: Victor P.

description:
I was in town for a day and after going to several places in just a few hours, a friend recommended that we check out  a Tiki bar inside Fairmont Hotel.  it seems fairly quiet and strange walking into the hotel at first but once you step in and see this exotic find, you become amazed at how hidden this place is! The bar opened at 5 and although it was only 5:20 when we arrived, we already had to wait in line. Once we got seated, we ordered the lava bowl for two and the calamari dish. The drink was adorable - incredibly long straws dipped into the center of a bowl filled with alcohol and ice with pineapple hanging off the side. For such a small drink, it was VERY strong but sweet. For me, the calamari appetizer dish stole the spotlight. A thin fried layer around a big piece of squid crunched in my mouth  after every bite.  It tasted even better after I dipped the calamari into a white dip that has the texture of tartar sauce with a tasteful hint of lemon and herbs that leaves a pleasant aftertaste, making me crave for more.  I would come back JUST for the calamari next time!

The atmosphere of Tonga was fun. It felt like I was in a different country really and the sudden thunder and rain at the pool made it even more fun. This place would be great for parties and I highly recommend it! (just don't forget to make reservations first!)
author: Lilian N.

description:
Very touristy place, but quite nice.

The food was way average...I've had better and cheaper elsewhere.
The drinks are pretty pricey as well, although I'm not a big fan of cocktails, I think the Lava bowl was the best overall. Plus, you can share! 

The ambiance was surprisingly stunning. There was a live band in the center of the room, playing music above water!

Great date place, but for just a casual hang-out place, I'd prefer going somewhere else.
author: Jamie Y.

description: We stopped by for a round and had the Mai Tai and the Zombie. Both were okay, and there's good reason this landmark remains popular beyond the drinks (i.e. the decor), but nothing worth sticking around for.
author: Matthew N.

description: Great tiki decor, rain over the water in the center of the restaurant, live band playing on a boat in the middle, great food, great drinks!!! A little pricey but it was a special birthday so we were willing to splurge. Only complaint was the waiter could have come by a little more often. Overall we had a great time. The birthday boy enjoyed it!
author: Jenn L.

description:
Where should I start...

We got convinced to check it out while staying in the hotel (The Fairmont) by the quirky funny sweet security guard, he was raving about it and told us we must see the raining sky... "raining sky"! How could we say no?!

Perhaps we could've... seated at a sticky smelly table, listening to a somewhat decent male Asian cover band, to hits by Celine, Aretha & Whitney, we ordered their specials; Mai Tai & a strawberry frothy thing. I couldn't stomach the Mai Tai and we tried to be nice and ask the bartender direct if he could make it less sweet or something. He refused to talk to us and turned his back. So odd. Then finally he snuffed we had to talk to the waitress. So we asked the waitress and she says "you'll have to talk to the bartender" LOL... We told her he wont talk to us. We then said we'll return it. But with her evils looks, we suffered through trying to make the sugary pink one work and were too scared to order another. 

Not worth it... unless you have just gotta see a boat on real water and a raining sky in a bar.
author: Lana M.

description:
My friend saw this place in a magazine and reserved a table (doing this all from the Philippines for his visit to SF). The instant we get inside, it felt like home (the tropical feel). My friend was amused cuz he flew all the way here to be back where he started.

Everything felt "pinoy" except for the prices. I knew the prices of the food was expensive but i didn't think my drink would cost $12 (out of a fake coconut) and I had to pay for cover charge (which i found out on the bill). 

The music was too loud too, i was yelling half the time over cheesy 80's covers.
author: Carla C.

description: Went here because of Bourdain's show. He must have brought his own booze, because the weak drinks are basically sugar syrup with some fruit juice. The appetizers were worse. Felt like a Rube sitting there with the fake lightning and completely bored wait staff.
author: Jack A.

description: Excellent  Food, Great atmosphere n ambience, Excellent drinks and awesome live band and Pirate Ship deck dance floor! I'm a Native SF'ian and I have been to many different restaurants, clubs etc and I can Honestly say I have never left here unhappy! We always have a great time!!  You won't regret it ! Also the service is great !
author: Carina M.

description:
My boyfriend and I got the Kao Island dinner. Thank god I purchased this dinner through Google offer. I can't imagine paying full price for this meal. Let me break it down for you.

APPETIZERS (just a note, you only get 1 per person)

Shiitake Egg Rolls: Tasted like a plain egg roll.

Tonga Aloha Ribs: Pretty tasty. The flavor reminded me of the Chinese style beef jerky, the juicy kind. The meat was very tender, I couldn't get enough of it. 

Chicken Satay: The chicken was a little dry, the sauce was ok. Nothing special.

ENTREES

Fire Cracker Prawns: Big, fat juicy prawns! 3 per person. It also came with lots of red bell peppers and peapods. I only remember that they were juicy.. I can't seem to remember what kind of flavor it was cooked with. Guess it wasn't that good.

Mongolian Beef: This dish didn't taste like the usual mongolian beef you get outside, it was better. The beef was very tender and my boyfriend loved the mushrooms that came with the dish. It also came with a crispy, chip like noodle. Just a piece of advice, break up the crispy noodles and add it to your plate when you're going to eat it  but do not mix it in the sauce early on! It will get soggy. I enjoyed this dish very much.

Dragon Chicken: I didn't really care too much for the dragon chicken. It was cooked with a black bean sauce, the same sauce chinese restaurants use to cook clams. I think there was some kind of choy in it too. This was my least favorite dish of the night.

SIDES

Szechwan Green Beans: WOW! Yummy! Who knew green beans could be so delicious. I couldn't stop eating it! I really like my vegetables cooked well but not overcooked. They had a wonderful crisp to it, it was like snacking on popcorn or something. It was so flavorful too! 

Jasmine Rice: It's rice.. there's nothing else I could really say about it.

DESSERT

Banana Mousse Cake: Let me start off by saying that I don't really like banana flavored things. I told myself I would just take one bite then I can grab dessert at a nearby ice cream shop. I expected to be disappointed. BEST DISH OF THE NIGHT!!!! The mousse itself had 2 layers: banana mousse on top and the bottom tasted like banana cheese cake, topped with a slice of dried banana with peanut butter banana flavored sauce on the side, and a little bit of granola on the other side. WOW WOW WOW!! Soooo good. We each had our own dish, thank goodness.. or else we would've been licking off the plate. We both finished our dessert in no time. I didn't go to the nearby ice cream shop as planned, my stomach was happily filled with the banana mousse cake.

The interior was nice, I truly felt like I left San Francisco. The lights were dimmed, I sat under a little tiki tent made of straws, there were a lot of dimmed decorative lights, and my mai tai came in a cup that looked like a coconut topped with a mini umbrella.  I had dinner around 6pm so the band wasn't there yet. It would rain over the pond every 20-ish minutes with thunder sound effects. It was a good experience even though the food (minus the dessert) was just ok. When the bill came, it was $144 for the both of us without the certificate. We paid $107 ($67 google offer, $10 tax, $30 tip) for the meal. I don't mind paying what we paid ONCE in my lifetime mainly because of the atmosphere. With that said, I don't think I will be coming back. I think I can get all the food I ordered at a Chinese restaurant for a third of what I paid.
author: Laura L.

description:
So dorky. So Perfect. And just what I expected. A pseudo-Tongan retiree filled Disneyland with live smooth jazz and drinks in coconut shells. Sadly, the coconut shell was porcelain. 

I needed a place to kill an hour before dinner reservations downtown. I had heard the Tonga room was closing a while back and regretted missing out. Still open. Still funky. Only stayed for one drink but its a pretty one dimensional place. I'd love to go back one night and commit to it.
author: Zac H.

description:
Where else can you be seated next to an indoor pool that has the occasional rain coming down from the ceiling and a live band a'paddlin' around? Throw in tiki drinks in weirdass tiki mugs and you have the Tonga Room!

We went here for a pre-New Year's Eve celebration with friends. Despite getting there early (6ish), we still had to stand in line. We managed to get a table and steal some chairs and the place was still pretty busy. Service was a bit slow, reflecting the sizable crowd, but overall it was a fun place to hang out for a few hours.

Fair warning: the drinks are *huge* and this is also evident in the price. You're getting the equivalent of two to three drinks at *least* in one single tiki drink. Moderate your intake carefully. I know I was certainly walking a very crooked line when I left. A happy crooked line, mind you... those drinks were fabulous!
author: Cassandra J.

description: Tonga me to heaven!  Good times!  It's pricey but fun.  The staff are helpful and nice but, sometimes the crowd at the bar can be snobby and obnoxious.  Come on people, when you go to the Tonga Room, don't be a square.  Embrace your inner Frances "Baby" Houseman and enjoy this Kellerman's Hotel loungey, tiki time warp that is the Tonga Room!  I think I see a Conga line heading toward my table right now...
author: Rose P.

description: Wow very cool venue but rudest staff woman ever. You wait in a long line and then eventually are asked if you need a table. I said no we'd just like to have a drink at the bar.
