We are let in and told to go in to the right to the bar area which we did. Most of the table seating areas are closed off, and of the area they were seating in the tables are at about 30% occupancy with still 30 people in line. We went to order drinks and a bar stool became available, sitting down to order, were promptly told by a passing "hostess" those were for people waiting in line. We did wait in line! But if we wanted our butt to touch a chair, we were told we should have waited for a table. Rules are rules but these are very unaccomodating, vague, and communicated very, very rudely by the dark haired staff hostess. Pretty much everyone coming in after us went through the same confusion and assault by this woman. Hilarious though we put our jackets and coats on a chair and no one threw them off! You can't sit but it's ok if your coat and purse do! What a shame, such a great hotel and fun bar experience was ruined by bad staff attitude. However, bartenders and cocktail waiter were great and the indoor rainstorm and floating band were fun but the mean Asian lady was really rude when communicating basic info and not at all accommodating.
author: B S.

description:
Ha. When I walked up to the Tonga Room, I actually laughed. This place is over the top, but in a very good way. I love tiki rooms, I love them so much I'm considering converting a roomin my basement into a tiki haven. And this was probably the coolest one I've been to state side.

So, we didn't have a reservation and there was a big reserved party on a Sunday night (day before Labor Day), so we ended up putting in our name, and returning a few hours later. (This is when they also told us there is a $5 cover charge per person for the band).

By the time we got back, this place was pumping! They had a live band, playing classic rock (?) but the band plays on a boat in a pond. And before their set break, it rains over the pond while they play cheesy rain songs when this happens (ie. Who'll stop the rain, Have you ever seen the rain).

I also thought they had good food. I've seen some other reviews where people mention it's bad. I'd really disagree! I was happy with everything we ordered. They also have strong drinks! Because there was a big party the night we were there, the dance floor was packed, which made it seem like a bad 80s wedding... but in a good way. I danced with myself, my husband, and strangers. Hey, I was drunk off crazy ass tiki drinks! Don't judge.

I woke up the next morning with one of the tiki glasses next to my bed. Neither of us remember how the hell that happened, but again, I can attest these are some really strong drinks!
author: Heather H.

description:
This place used to be one of my favorite places to randomly get my inner-Jimmy buffett on.  However this tiki adventure was put on a spit and the natives chanted for ruining a great place. 

I went there around 9pm on Saturday with some out of town guests. We were surprised to find a line wrapped around the corner of the entrance.  After about an hour and fifteen minute wait we finally got seated.  It wasn't the wait that got me upset (actually I was stoked they were doing so well).  The problem was there were 30-40 empty tables.  Yep this tiki town thought they would be LA and try to create buzz by having a line for NO reason.  Granted I was impressed with all the beautiful people in their cheesy hawaiian gear showing off their amazing dance moves that usually only see the light of a dance floor at a wedding but it wasn't enough to create a fake wait.

The only reason why I am giving them two stars is because where else are you going to see an amazing band (seriously...they are great) on a floating stage in the basement of a hotel during an indoor rain storm.

Stop with the fake lines Tonga people and let the loud shirt wearing folk get there tropical drink on!!
author: Brandon M.

description: Went here for my birthday party and I loved it. The atmosphere is a bit kitschy but that was exactly what I wanted. The fake "thunderstorms" and rain were great. The drinks were being poured strong, and the food was delicious. And I loved the band. They played covers from the 80s and 90s that everyone can dance to. This restaurant would be good for a family or great for a group of friends. Glad I went :)
author: Meg K.

description: My experience was amazing ! Its such a fun place to be in. With live band, variety drinks and such fun people around, you have to get off that chair and get your feet moving... I loved their appetizers too specially the shrimp rolls. Go here to enjoy your time and have fun. Dont go here for food as they dont have much variety .
author: Mansi J.

description:
I was transported from the poor service of the fairmont to the tropical land of TONGA! 

Very strong pours here on the island, definitely would go back and enjoy a few more Mai-Tai's. my only wish is that they would use fresh squeezed juice instead of Rose's lime juice and that bright green sweet and sour. Leads me to serious hang over land the next morning.
author: Charlie H.

description:
We loved it. They did charge the $7.00 per person for the "entertainment fee" but when we asked they explained that anytime live music starts is when they charge. I wasn't happy, but figured it was worth it. The Island Groove band was playing and did a fantastic job! Would hire them for any event I am planning for in the future. 
  As for the actual restaurant. You have to go there. If for only one time in your life, it should prove to be worth every penny you spend for your dinner. Drinks were good. I ordered the Singapore drink. I didn't care for it, but I had never had one before. My husband had the Merlot, and he said it was pretty good. The food was great. Worried we wouldn't know what to order, but we loved what we ended up with. We ordered a Pu-Pu platter, and Tropical Greens Salad with crispy Tofu. YUM! And then we also added the Salt & Pepper Prawns. It was so good! All of it. So a must for at least once in your life. We plan on going back and whenever possible, we will bring our guests too.
author: Gwyneth F.

description: Love this because it is over the top, so when you go there leave your issues and expectations outside, get into the Tiki mood by buying a cocktail bowl (the ones for two are far more manageable), drink it and repeat.  In our case we were a group of  2, but we called in friends and by the time 6 people were together we were all diving into lava bowls, dancing to the live band and having a blast.  When we left a couple of hours later,  there was a 40-50 person line up so it is obviously a popular place.
author: Valerie G.

description: Fun, cheesy and down right entertaining. Yes drinks are expensive but it's all in good fun. It's like going back in time. I'm a local and i love this place!
author: Tanuki T.

description:
I went with a group of 7 people two weeks ago on a Friday for my gf's birthday. Having seen the 'Bourdain effect' at other restaurants featured on The Layover or No Reservations, we decided to get there 15 minutes before happy hour started and were second in line. That was a great decision, since the line was about 30 people deep by the time we left 2 hours later.

That said, we had an absolute blast at this place. It's completely cheesy and very much like a Pacific Island version of the Rainforest Cafe, but the drinks are incredible. Here's a rundown of what our group had:

Blue Hawaiian - mixed rum drink, fairly tasty.
Tonga Mai Tai - a little tangy, very boozy. In my opinion, Roy's has better Mai Tais.
Pina Colada - my friends who aren't Pina Colada fans loved this, so that says something.
Zombie - solid mixed drink, but nothing to write home about
Lava Bowl - fun because it lives up to its name. Feels like lava going down your throat. Fruit chunks and lots of booze. I drank one by myself, since the serving size for this particular drink aren't as big as you'd think. 
Scorpion - my second favorite drink of the night. Very strong, not too tangy, and easy to drink.
Bora Bora Horror - the unanimous favorite. If you're not a banana fan, you may not like this... but it's delicious.

Can't recommend this place enough for happy hour. Tasty drinks, a buffet, and an awesome environment!
author: Ryan K.

description:
We went for a birthday celebration and had a great time! The food was so delicious (we had the prawn skewers, calamari, cabbage and papaya salad). The dumplings and spring rolls were ok. I had the Kung Pao shrimp for dinner, yummy. We shared two Scorpion Bowls for 4--we definitely felt them. The pineapple rum cake tasted stale. 

It was just a fun, fun place to be. The only suggestion I have is for the band to be more lively. It's such a fun space with a dance floor, so I would have preferred some more upbeat music.
author: Kate J.

description:
We stayed at the Fairmont. Having lived in Hawaii, and missing it always, I was excited for a restaurant with Manapua, etc. on the menu.
When we checked in, we were told we should go there for happy hour, even with our baby. So we hurried, got down there, and were turned away because Happy Hour was full. Huh? And a table for dinner was not available for the rest of the night. She said we could wait 30 min to see if a Happy Hour spot opened up. Um, hi, see the baby? Yeah, I don't think so. 
We weren't deterred though, and made reservations for the next night, right when they opened. I didn't realize that meant zero entertainment. She should have said that.
The food was just eh, ok. I had the scallops, my husband had the kung pao. It had no pao. The only thing that was really yummy was the shrimp dumpling appetizer. And who charges $6 for a side of rice with Kung Pao???
I would never go again. Not unless the prices were cut in half.
author: Kristen M.

description: We were tourists and we had to come here after seeing The Layover. This place isn't as big as I thought it was. The tiki theme, pool, and rain were definitely pretty cool. Nothing looked appealing on the half-assed overpriced menu. Good thing we were only there for drinks. Beware they charge a cover for some nights. The band on the island was decent playing some really old oldies. We ordered a lava bowl for 2, a mai tai, and some tiger beers. It is one of those places you should go if you never been. But we came and are not going to keep it on the list of places we want to come back to.
author: Tri V.

description:
Atmosphere: Over the top decor, borderline Rainforest Cafe for adults. The live band was decent with a cute little stage. The crowd was sparse and confusing because people were dressed casual or over dressed

Food and Drinks: I didn't try the food. The drinks on the other hand were god awful. The shared bowl was very gingery, lacking fruit, and alcohol. We sent it back. Then ordered a Mai Tai which tasted like Emergen-C (for those who dont know its a vitamin powdered drink). We ended up leaving.

Service: Since the drinks were horrible, the guy was real nice about getting us new ones. The service was normal nothing bad nothing special
author: Simone D.

description:
I go out all the time in SF as a resident and occasionally as a "tourist." I'm one of those people who goes on tours in my own city and tries experiences most would forego because if I'm going to recommend something, I'm going to have tried it.   Some young kids on my team booked the room for a fun experience for a going away party.   We booked a table of six.   I knew instinctively when I arrived we were in the wrong place....no ambience and as several reviewers have said, an overall apathy.   When I arrived as the host of my party, the hostess did not make eye contact and greet me saying she'd be with me...instead she and four waiters appeared to be negotiating where people got sat...nothing says opportunism more than that to me.   I arrived at the table, saw the menu prices (outrageous), drink prices (OK to over priced) and then saw people helping themselves to a buffet.   We'd been given menus at our places, and mind you, it was 1/5th full at 6:30 PM.    I asked about the buffet, and the waiter said, only 20 minutes left it closes at 7 PM.  I don't know about you, and as someone who never really looks at how much my check is, I'm not a penny pincher, but I HATE it when you're somewhere, there's a buffet or happy hour and the team doesn't have the courtesy to tell you pre-emptively as a choice.

I looked at the menu I had which said buffet, $65 each and I looked at the very casual clientele and asked the waiter what the offer was, he said "$10 per person only until 7 PM"...my guests and I quickly served ourselves and sat down having ordered our first round of drinks.   Only after we brought our plates back did the manager come over and say, you know, you were supposed to order from the dinner menu, and we'll make an exception for you availing yourself of the buffet, just this once.   I looked around and didn't see any distinction between where we were and where the happy hour folks were sitting...it seemed very very SCAMMY to me.    

We proceeded to order close to $200 in food & beverage, and I was prepared to spend more, but the indifferent service coupled with inferior outrageously priced food as well as 2 out of 6 water glasses rimmed in lipstick made me tip the least I have in 30 years....I was highly disappointed, trying not to show it for my guests, but we could have had a totally different night...I will never recommend this place.   My Mai Tai was 2/3rd ice and 1/3rd drink....and costs more than several great mixology institutions here in SF. What a total missed opportunity...it needs a smart marketing & food/beverage company to take it over, make it Mad Men glam, offer great food and get rid of the jaded, greedy staffers.   Ick.
author: Kimberly C.

description: If you are a tourist, Do It! It's nice. Locals rarely go here. The hotel is nice and Obama comes here when he visits (if you care)! The lounges in the hotel are very nice with good and pricey drinks.
author: Elena D.

description:
You know we happen to be walking by and I've always wanted to go to the Tonga Room, I've heard people talking about it. So it's 5:15 on a Friday night and we think we are just gonna waltz right in to the bar. Yeah right, so did the other 20 or so peeps lined up at the doorway. Some leave when they hear that the bar is at capacity and it could be 45 minute wait. (My husband doesn't hear this as he's playing on his phone as we stand in line). We had already waited 45 minutes in line to get into Swan Oyster Depot, if he'd actually heard that he would have bailed. But me being "good things come to those who wait", I don't tell him. After a half an hour the guy at the door starts taking in small groups of 2 or 3 at a time. The two groups in front of us must have had 4 because he all of a sudden looks and us and says "2"? The table is near the door and we just figured we'd have one drink and then take off.
It's a fun polynesian atmosphere, with periodic rain storms and lightning with thunder over the pool. The drinks aren't cheap but they sure are potent (or I'm a light weight...yeah I'll admit it) just call me a cheap date. I had the Mai Tai house special...with fruit and bacardi 151...hubby did a strawberry Marg. It be fun to come with another couple and next time make a reservation...duh...but I'm glad we finally got to stop by. Maybe we come next time and stay the night...oh yeah!
author: Susan D.

description:
Went there last night with relatives who came in town for the weekend. Yeah, it was brought to our attention because of the Bourdain show. But we also went because we knew we were going to be out in the city all day, and wanted a cool place to take the kids and have drinks. So we made reservations the day before, which was the smartest thing to do. The line was crazy long for people waiting for the bar, but we just breezed right through to our table.

Service started out good. Got our drinks right away and my 4 year old niece got a little extra attention with umbrella in her juice. They sat us in an area where I could park my daughter's stroller and not be in anyone's way. Drinks were good, but overpriced as hell. Considering they were using well liquors, it wasn't worth the high price. Guess you're paying for the decor and the manufactured rainstorm. They even ran out of pineapple juice because of the "larger than normal" crowd, but seriously they had to know the crowd was going to be big after "The Layover" aired. Whatever.

Appetizers were good, main courses were average and pretty much the same, cubed meat or tofu with veggies and steamed rice. Good after 2-3 zombies.

So I give it 3 stars. 1 for decent drinks, 1 for decor and cheesy ass band, 1 for the appetizers. They lost 2 stars for the prices and the fact that when we ordered our second round of drinks, the waiter asked if I was the nanny to the kids, my niece and my daughter, in an attempt to try and make conversation. Really? Ok my husband, sis in law, and niece are white, i'm black, and my kid is biracial, but why'd I have to be the nanny? Could I have been the family friend at least? Geez..
author: Erica S.

description:
If I were to come here for drinks only, this place gets a 5. You won't find a unique tiki bar like this anywhere in the US of A. It freaking rains inside every 30 minutes. What!  It's true. Their drinks are stout and delicious. The 4 stars is because the food.....is borderline bad. We had the edemame and the Tonga platter which consisted of ribs, chicken satay, spring rolls and something else that obviously wasn't good enough for me to remember. All of them were poor. For an Open Table restaurant, your food should be better. 

But the experience is what you're after. Get a table by the water, order a few scorpions and enjoy.
author: Jake O.

description:
Anthony Bourdain called this "the best restaurant in the history of the world" -- or something like that. I would dare to say...I totally agree. First off, you'd never know it was there. It's hidden in the back of the gorgeous Fairmont Hotel at the top of the hill in San Francisco and upon turning the corner inside the hotel's long corridor, you are welcomed by a bit of both a time and place warp. 

The restaurant -- built in the late 40s -- is a south pacific haven away from city life. It is centered around the original hotel pool, which now serves as a stage for the boat that carries the most awesome cover band. I felt like I was on stage in South Pacific and in a 1970s tiki dream at the same time...all the while, drowning in cocktail/asian food heaven. 

The mongolian beef was out of this world -- made with gorgeous beef tenderloin. The tequila cocktail was my favorite (tematangi ubangi).

There is a dance floor, a big bar, and great, super kind service. I will be back again for sure.
author: Autumn N.

description: Came here with my husband for birthday party. Mix Drinks are almost $20 each water down. In a table of 5 people. Food includes an appetizer,  3 entree, and a desert. Drinks are not included.  To be honest food is a little better than panda express. Total costs is $72 PER PERSON.  Not to mention the desert is taste like a dark giant brown twinki. Its was a total waste of money. Its a complete disappointment!!!
author: Mindy C.

description: This place is okay. The decorations and music makes up for the quality of the food. We went for happy hour with the buffet. The price was pretty decent, but the food that came with it was pretty standard. This restaurant is definitely a spot you want to try once because of the atmosphere. I haven't ordered from the regular menu, but it can get pretty pricey. I wish the service was a little better.
author: Jadelann J.

description: Slow service and was charged a cover charge. Never been charged a cover before after I reserve a table days ahead of time. Very greedy for Disneyland prices.
author: jessica c.

description:
We were recently in SF for the day and decided to recreate Anthony Bourdain's Layover San Francisco.  So we decided to stop in here and check it out.

We got there around 7:00pm on a Fri night and there was huge line.  My wife went to the front and found out the line was for the bar.  So, she asked if we could be seated in the restaurant and were seated almost immediately.

The foo foo drinks were fun and fairly strong.  We ordered duck spring rolls and shrimp and cilantro spring rolls to start.  Both were very good.  

For dinner my wife ordered a Hot Pot with Scallops, Prawns and Fish in Red Curry Coconut Broth.  Very tasty.  Large fresh scallops.   I ordered a Rib Eye which was perfectly cooked and lightly basted with a Polynesian style sauce.  I would have passed on the sauce (not a fan of sauce on steak) but it was also very good.

Who would have thought a South Seas Tiki palace under the Fairmont Hotel built around a historic 1929 swimming pool.
author: Stewart B.

description:
I'm in love.

Amazingly less cheeky than you think and well worth seeking out on your next visit to SF. My only minor critique is so crazy small that it does not bring down the total score of the visit.

The tiki mugs that come with the drinks are made in China. Really Tom? That's what you are complaining about. Not complaining, offering up a great replacement solution. Check out tikifarm located in San Clemente CA. Buy locally made, custom tiki mugs and this would be the ultimate tiki bar. 

All that aside- amazing.
author: Tom S.

description: This place is unreal. It's definitely touristy, only because it's a San Francisco institution. We went on a Friday night at 10pm and had to wait about 20 minutes to get in. We didn't get any food but we did get their giant tropical fishbowl cocktail that was rum mixed with rum with a dash of rum. We drank two amongst the three of us. The atmosphere was magical. My friend described it as a Rainforest Cafe for adults. The coolest thing about the bar/restaurant was the pool in the center with a live band floating in a little boat. They played the most wonderfully cheesy covers and every 30 minutes they played CCR "Have You Ever Seen the Rain" and it would literally rain. There was the occasional bachelorette party and group of bros, but the vibe wasn't douchy at all. I think everyone understood we were on holy bar ground and that we were expected to behave. The fishbowl of alcohol was $30 each, but that's a deal if you're sharing, because we were each getting about two drinks out of it. I don't know that we needed to order two, but we were slightly "turnt up", as the kids say. So much fun.
author: Kat R.

description: This is an over hyped place with  terrible  service. Everyone  who spoke to us was rude and didn't care that  we had waited for more than an hour for our table. Our party of  5 had a terrible experience  here and we are never coming back. I hope entitled establishments  like this  go  out  of  business.
author: Maddy K.

description:
The announcement on Tonga Room's Yelp page says it all:

Things are a bit crazy since Mr. Bourdain was here...We strongly recommend making a reservation to avoid the lines...
http://bit.ly/ylprsvr

Um, yeah. Before The Layover, I could roll into Tonga at almost any time and immediately get a seat at the bar, even during their well priced happy hour. Now there are bouncers with earpieces and hour long waits. Is it worth it? Well, if you have a desire to see it rain inside a building and don't mind waiting, then sure! I can't recommend eating here--the food is expensive and just not that good, and the buffet is awful. But the drinks are strong and tasty, and it is a fun spot. Take their advice and make a reservation, or go early and queue up for happy hour, then have dinner elsewhere.
author: Lesly S.

description:
Loved it. Finally made it with my partner on a Saturday night.

Skip "The Greens" salad - it's bland and earthy.

We shared the Lava drink for two, and then got our own Bora Bora drink. Tasty and didn't get too drunk (unfortunately?).

We shared the Mongolian Beef entree, Shaka rice, and Szechwan green beans. It was amazing! And no leftovers, because it was so delicious!
author: Jenna P.

description: Food was great, drinks were okay.  I think people really go for the ambience- I mean, where else can you get serenaded by a live band floating on a fake ship in the middle of a rainstorm on a pool?  Fish dishes were great, dessert was delish, but drinks were a bit too sugary.  Be prepared to spend big bucks, as drinks & food are pretty costly.
author: Kristin K.

description:
I'll give it to you straight: You'll have a great time here and it's one of the most unique places in SF, but you should expect:

- EAT ELSEWHERE.  they serve food, but it's mediocre and reminds me of a Chinese restaurant in an ex-urb at three to four times the price (think $20 for a single serving of sweet and sour pork).  don't treat this as a restaurant.

- DANCE.  they have a great dance floor and standing bar.  Kitschy music and a live calypso band or similar.

- RELAX. they also have tables and won't let it get too busy.  for best results, go on a week night.  no one, including tourists and B&T, likes waiting in line for an hour.  starting early here is a good idea, too.  Don't trudge up Nob hill after you're 5 drinks in in North Beach like everyone else does on Friday and Saturday nights, only to complain about the line, and pay $10+ for drinks you are too drunk to taste.  the service is neither fast nor slow.  It's a place to laze and chat with a drink and friends.

- TAKE FAMILY.  This is the closest thing to Disneyland we have here in SF.  Your parents will love it, your kids will love it.  they make great virgin drinks, and give you a spicy snack mix, too.

- DRINK.  the drinks are the stars here.  Served in fancy glasses with all kinds of fruits growing out of them.  Waiters can suggest based on your taste, and they customize drinks, as well.  My favorite has vodka and coconut juice.
author: Lauren J.

description: I have been here twice. Once for happy hour and once on a Saturday night. During happy hour it was not that crowded. The prices were reasonable and a nice evening. However on a saturday night for the bar section we had to wait 30-40minutes to get in to the bar area for standing. The crowd average age is 45, if that is your preference.
author: Emel M.

description:
Not bad, but not that awesome either.
Rainforest cafe does the whole jungle/rain-vibe thing much better :)
This place is meant for an older crowd, so giving it an extra star, cos I am not their target audience to begin with.
The floating band on the pool playing retro music is pretty awesome... abba++
Dinner here sounds expensive, but not a bad place to go to for a drink, snacks afterwards.
author: Aditya M.

description: The place is cute yes, but the employees are horrible. Upon waiting in line, which we did expect after all it is a popular place, we were told we had to pay a $7 entree fee per person. When we enter we find out that the fee was optional if we were willing to stand, which we totally were. Service was god awful, it took us 40 minutes to pay, I had to ask 4 different employees and walk around the entire establishment to eventually find out waitress. Lastly, and most importantly, the ripped us off one more time when paying, we were told we could split the check 3 ways, between my card on file and 2 other cards. They ended up charging my card the price for all the drinks $76 and also charging my friends an extra $20 each. I've been trying to contact them but there has been no service or help. No response, finally I'm told that I have to call back on Monday, but by the tone in the lady's voice I already know I won't be getting my money back.
author: Brigitte C.

description:
I arrived here on a Saturday night with my husband and was quoted a 1 hour wait.  A few of the people in front of us ended up leaving and we ended up being seated within about 45 min which was nice.  The atmosphere in this place is amazing.  The whole place is decorated like you are out in the jungle.  There is a pool with a boat and a band that plays catching songs.  On the dance floor you will find a mix of all type of people from young children, wedding parties, couples on dates, girls out for girls night out, and many birthday celebrations.  Overall I would give 5 stars for the atmosphere.  Plus every half hour or so the band plays a song with the word "rain" in it and it rains down from the ceiling. Pretty cool!

We visited this place twice on our vacation since it was right across from our hotel.  The first time was on Saturday night when we just had drinks.  The drinks were very delicious and were super strong.  I though the drinks were a good value for the price, as another reviewer stated- they are deadly!

For a place for drinks I would give this place 4 starts, however, on our second visit we went for food.  I found that the food here was lacking in flavor and seemed to be very greasy.   Overall, I would recommend this place as a fun night out with friends for drinks, and a great place for tourists to stop in as it is very unique.  It is also a fun place for dancing for all types of people.  

I would not recommend going here for the food as I believe you can get much better food somewhere else.    Go for the dancing, drinks, and great music!
author: Erin G.

description:
Dark, noisy, average food, over priced for the quality. 

The thing that annoyed me the most was the "Entertainment Fee" ($8?)charged for the noisy band that played music in the middle of the "pond."  I'd rather pay a "SHUT UP FEE!"  Look it's 2011 and we are busy professionals trying to catch up during dinner.. not forced to listen to cornya$$ music.. it's my fault for going.

I will never come back because I can barely hold a conversation with all that crap going on and the fact that I have to think REALLY HARD to remember what I ate there.. which means that their food is insignificant. :\
author: Catalina C.

description: This place is so much fun! I went here for a bachelorette party and it was great! Fun cocktails, good music, dancing, good food, great service, not expensive...the list goes on. I would highly recommend it for a cheesy, good time, and an out of the ordinary night out.
author: Louisa W.

description:
To dine in the Tonga Room is to step back into the days of the Rat pack, people saying things like Buster, Creep, Dame and Broad. 
It's kitchy, it's kooky and it's fabulous all in one. 

I expected only the themed decor, watered-down drinks and sub-par food. Yes, i had high hopes. I suppose I am a rampant prejudger. Jam from the jar with a cuter label tastes better than the less attractive one. 
Clothes that cost more than another are of better quality. Large feet on men indicate that their...shoes are also large. 

So, imagine my surprise when the food was not only edible, but quite good - in fact, even great. The drinks were not watered down. The service was good - for the most part and if you don't count the waiter bumping my friend and causing a whole drink to go flying into her lap, without so much as a word. 

Yes, the ambiance was fun, the food good - so why just the 3 stars? 

Well. 

They have the floating band, that is certainly not there out of the goodness of their blood sucking hearts. How do I know? Because anyone in the place after 8 is charged $7 on their bill for the live entertainment. And "live" is a l m o s t stretching their description. Every last thing on the menu is overpriced and I do have to say, their dessert falls very short of delightful. 

I did love my Hot Pot of succulent scallops, tender shrimp and fresh fish in a subtly spicy broth that really never seemed to end, and my onion flat-bread with the coconut and toasted macadamia nut dip was a delight, but those two items plus two Gin & Tonics set me back $100. 

ONE HUNDRED DOLLARS. 

Come 

ON.
author: Katie W.

description:
This is the legendary restaurant that really did not live up to its reputation.  The food was terrible. Not just one entree was bad, they all were. The singapore rice noodles for example, were so bland and the orange chicken seemed like mush. Its very expensive too for what you get. And the valet parking is $20 an hour!!!
The only redeeming thing is that it is really kooky and fun. The band was good and everyone seemed to be having a good time so that is why I'm giving it 2 starts instead of 1.
author: Clive L.

description:
I am a tiki bar aficionado so it surprised me that I hadn't gone here before. I wanted to have my Birthday Happy Hour in the East Bay at Conga Lounge or Forbidden Island but my SF friends hinted (more than slightly) that their snobby SF-butts aren't coming out of the City during the week so I had to find a Tiki Bar in the City.

Enter the famous Tonga Room. Per Yelp, I made a reservation so I would have guaranteed entrance and (thankfully), they didn't push us to have dinner. The drinks were yummy and I didn't get sticker shock because again, as a Tiki bar aficionado, I know the drinks will be pricey.

All in all a good experience but the layout wasn't really that conducive to partying like FI or Conga Lounge...the dinner table made the party seem more formal.

But the waitstaff was nice, the "rain effects" were cute, and the drinks were nice.  All in all a good birthday.
author: MakeUp M.

description: Can't believe that the host told us to leave last night after we paid $90  for drinks and food between 4 of us .. Yes we were there for happy hour but the place wasn't even full. That was totally rude. I am so disappointed. I am an event planner and was thinking of putting an event there on a monthly basis. Now I have to reconsider because we were treated so badly because the hosts and  waiter moved our handbags and jackets without our consent and told us that we need to pay an extra $7 each for the four of us. They were so adamant to get us out of there.. I have stayed at the Fairmont many times and have gone to many of their restaurants thoughout the years and had never been treated so badly. I have 600 members in my organization and I will certainly let them know not to go to the Fairmont Tonga Room
author: Joce J.

description:
I LOVE this place.
The interior is so beautiful and unique. I also love their live music.
I wish I can ride the boat inside of the restaurant. ha ha

The food and the drink are good also, but a little bit pricey compare with the quality of food.

You'd better book for a table for the weekend, otherwise you have to wait.
Also, it's better idea to minimize the number of cars, if you are a group.

If you love to dance, this is the place.
author: Jullie A.

description:
Read the top few reviews and am amazed at how many people do not seem to understand the purpose of the Tonga Room -- which is this:

The Tonga Room is where you go after a wedding and you are dressed up and 3/4 sloshed and having a great time with a big group of people and not ready to go home and need someplace that can match your weird "special occasion" energy and drunkeness. (And I mean this has been true since at least the early 1970s -- I graduated from college in 1979)   I would say it would also be a good place to go after a prom, but attendees are often not yet 21. 

Kitsch at it's finest -- atop Nob Hill in my beloved home town.  No place like it!

 "YOU LOVE THE THUNDER, AND YOU LOVE THE RAIN"  -- Jackson Browne
author: L M.

description:
I had to go to this place after seeing Anthony Bourdain go there. 
The drinks are really good and the alcohol content is high. The free mixed nuts are also a plus. 
One annoying thing about this place is that you can't sit by the water if you just want to have drinks. I guess you have to have a camera crew with you in order to have a nice seat if you're not planning to eat.
author: david l.

description:
Went for happy hour from 5-7pm.. I had a great time! When we got there we did have to wait 10 min for a seats to open but once we sat down our waiter was very attentive and even suggested the best drink on the menu. Waiter suggested their specialty drink, it wasn't the lava bowl but the other one (sorry, can't remember the name). It was strong! Strong is good, definitely left there with a buzz.  

Appetizer bar was so yummy! Sweet chili wings and spicy wings (really tasty!), veggie chow men (okay), egg rolls with a sweet peanut sauce (so good! Kept going back for more.), also had fried rice (wasn't that good).. Oh and macaroni salad. Nevertheless it filled both my friend and I up! Each of us had one drink and we were both buzzed when we left.

The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because parking is a bit difficult. This place is located in Nob Hill one of the most expensive places to live in SF, so parking can be really pricy ($27 for 2 Hrs). If you're lucky you'll park on the street... We parked in the lot, there are some that are less expensive just drive around until you find one with decent rates.

The ambiance is so lovely! It's not fancy smancy like the Fairmont hotel, it's like Piarates of the Carribean with a dash of islander influence. I am Polynesian and saw not so much island style but shiowreck at sea? Anyways this is a great place to check out, see the hotel and walk around and take in all it's beauty. Afterwards a nice walk the car and take all the beautiful sites in nob hill!
author: Briana W.

description:
3 1/2 stars. Drinks are deadly, definitely worth the price. However, food is over priced/typical and service is so-so. Good music though! 

Definitely a tourist spot! Locals beware!
author: Courtney A.

description: The Tonga Room is a lot of fun! The decor is gaudy, the band played a lot of old school tunes and the drinks were really strong! I would definitely go back.
author: Sonia L.

description:
oh Tonga room! I appreciate your historic significance and your gorgeous ambiance but when it comes down to the cocktails you need to step it up a notch. maybe hire a cocktail consultant?

 I say keep all of the classics of course  (mai tais, pina coladas, scorpion bowls etc) but the tonga room needs a real make over to how their drinks are executed. the quality of the juices is definitely lacking and everything just tastes corn syrup laden. with rum and punch competition from places like smuggler's cove and rick house, the quality of drinks at tonga room has fallen very behind in san francisco. i couldn't even finish my third cloying drink (over a few hours) and it hurt my stomach.

no comment on the food. they serve a lot of tiki bar classics like Polynesian chicken wings, veggie egg rolls, and spam fried rice if that is your thing.

bartender and staff were very friendly.
author: Leuwam T.

description:
I love this place and always have.  I have heard that it may close or at least be moved to make way for condos.  That is a shame. 

Although the food and drinks can be somewhat uneven, this is the real deal for true tiki places.  It's been around since 1945 and is one of the very few remaining true old tiki places, a legend.  The place itself is great, around an old pool that has a boat for a live band, "tropical rainstorms" with water pouring down into the pool, a ship deck dance floor, great tiki decor.  Drinks can be mediocre (pina colada-types, Bora Bora Horror) or very good (Tonga Itch, Tonga Mai Tai) and the food is a similar range (if tending to be rather salty).  Overall, this is not the epitome of fine dining, but it really delivers for a satisfying, fun night, fully achieving exactly what it's supposed to.

It can be great for adults or kids and all in between.  I loved this place as a kid and my 8-year-old daughter loves it now.
author: Wulfstan C.

description:
After reading about this place and seeing it on TV (Anthony Bourdain's Layover) I said I have to come here.  I'm a huge sucker for these type of gimmicky atmosphere places.  Does this place remind me of Hawaii?  Not the slightest until they played that one song that they kept on playing in the Sheraton on Waikiki.  For whatever reason this is a hot place for happy hour, we waited for forty minutes before getting a table.  If you get a drink, any drink, and pay $10 you get all you can eat happy hour buffet.  However there are only a few things to eat and they include chow mein, fried rice, two types of chicken drumsticks (hot and sweet chili), egg rolls, fruit and some kind of salad.  I heard there were more options such as bbq pork bun and satay before.  The food wasn't great and I think rainforest cafe does a better thunder and lightning.  When it rains, it doesn't rain on the entire pool only in a rectangle shape so the middle of the pool doesn't have water coming down.  I had an ice tea with pineapple juice, my wife had a pina colada and we both through the drinks weren't well made.

I think if you are a tourist you should definitely come, it can be a pretty memorable place.  However as a local, I was hoping for a place that I can come back to but I don't think that will happen.
author: Pierre L.

description: The ambience of this place is quite childish especially with the fake rain dripping in a pool, and the overly generic music. The wait staff is mehhh, and the doormen think this place is something special....which it is not. The drinks were godawful....a blind man could make them better. Overall this place is an embarrassment to the fairmont brand and should defiantly be avoided if you have even the slightest bit of taste and class.
author: Shak K.

description:
Tacky . Overpriced . Tourist Trap . 

Yet you still want to go. 

Why?

The Tonga Room is a San Francisco legend. A historical landmark. An excessively decorated tropical treat. An excuse to have an umbrellaed drink and an easy way to get "lay-ed" after you eat. 

Behind the Fairmont's fancy doors you'll find a gilded head of a three-faced goddess. Enter into the dimly lit space filled with electric tiki torches. Thatched roofs over the tables. Acres of plastic orchids hanging along the walls. And every thirty minutes, an indoor rainstorm, complete with thunder and a cooling breeze. 

The atmosphere is unbelievable - a mini theme park hidden inside a stuffy San Francisco hotel. A Pacific Rim / Asian inspired cuisine ties in perfectly to fit the setting. Appetizers feature macadamia nut flatbread spicy chicken skewers, and coconut shrimp. Feature entrees include both small and large plates - a well rounded mix of dishes to delight every diner. Do not miss the pork lettuce cups,  "huli huli chicken", or the delicious "forbidden blend" fried rice. And if you're looking for a treat to top it off, try the "Flaming Tonga Volcano" to complete your meal with a festive flair. 

A mini vacation into the tropics of San Francisco is a must. I can't wait to return and enjoy a syrupy sip, a simulated storm, and a lovely lagoon.  Give this place a try.....  you're one cable car ride away from a fantastic summer getaway! 

Mahalo!
author: Caroline J.

description: Love it! You don't have to be dressed up the music was really good. I had the pupu platter the dungness crab Rangoon was excellent!
author: Lisa E.

description: You don't go here for the food. The ambiance was fun but the band wasn't even that great. I didn't try the drinks so I can't review those. My biggest warning: DON'T GET THE SOUP. I got food poisoning from it the very next day and threw up 6 times.
author: Emily L.

description:
Go Here!  

If you're in SF, make reservations at least a week in advance.  Its worth it. Its located in the Fairmount Hotel.  Great ambiance.  

We stayed in Union Square, and the 3 blocks up that steep hill to get there was well rewarded with a great evening we had.

The Food and Drink: 
Both phenomenal and stayed with the theme of the restaurant.  The rain storm, pool, and live band playing on a moving boat were probably the most over the top things I've seen in a restaurant. All that being said, it's still has the tiki bar environment to keep things casual and not too uptight.

Music:
Live band covering classic songs from every generation.  Almost like a wedding band would.  The sound was done well too, you'd think there would be some sort of pitfall to setting up the sound on a moving boat, but it was pretty rad nonetheless.  

One final note: (again) Make reservations.  There was a pretty long line of people when we showed up who were waiting to get in. That line doubled 1/2 hour later when I went to use the mens room. Put this on your To-Do List in SF.
author: Tim R.

description:
The decor is nice but the food is crap for the amount they're charging.  I came here for a sorority alum dinner and most of the girls got that special groupon/livingsocial-like coupon that gave them a 3-course dinner for $30-ish.  What did they get served?  P.F. Chang-ish Chinese food.  I refuse to eat Chinese food in a restaurant whose theme is revolving around a Pacific Islander theme.  So I got the Moon Salad.  Bland fish in soy sauce with few scatterings of greens.

It also doesn't help that when I ask for a description of a dish, I have a server yelling in my ear without giving me much of an answer and then demanding that I order within 5 minutes of being seated.  That's the kind of service I expect in a cheap Chinese restaurant like ABC in MP.  Whatevs.

Other than that, the place is really nice inside.  Which is probably why it attracts so many tourists.  At least 75% of the patrons that night looked like tourists.

Perhaps this is a place to go to for drinks but definitely not for dinner.
author: Linh V.

description:
Overpriced. Cheesy. Mediocre food.

But, its a must. At least once. Its hard to beat a hawaiian band playing sugar ray on a fake boat with fabricated thunderstorms while you eat your food that surely came out of a can.
author: Sean H.

description:
We came here with a group of friends - reservation at 8:15 PM for a group of 7, we were seated with just three of us at 7:50 PM. Drink orders taken and delivered quickly while we waited for the rest of our group. Food was good but didn't wow anyone in the group. The Hawaiian Fried Rice was good. The drinks are delicious, with many options to choose from. We sampled 75% of the drinks on the menu and there wasn't a bad one in the bunch. 

We happened to be there on a Friday night which was great for the live band. Although, beware - if you plan to have a nice quiet dinner, maybe try this place during the week. I loved the atmosphere. Everyone should go at least once to check it out - even if it is just for drinks and dancing on a Friday night. If you plan to have dinner, try to plan ahead and get a reservation. If you don't have a reservation, get there by 8:00 PM - the line for walk-ups only had 2-3 small groups when we arrived but was wrapped around the hallway as we were heading out.
author: Melissa W.

description:
This place is expensive, and the food was just OK.

We had mai tais, miso soup, smoked shishito edamame, forbidden blend rice, and fire cracker with beef.


Pros: 
-The best thing about our meal was the beef: it was the most tender beef I've ever had; it literally melts in your mouth.

Cons:
-Mai tais were just OK; expensive, of course, just like everything else at this place. Not too much alcohol in them for the price.
-Miso soup was bland; no miso flavor; only chicken broth. The worst miso soup I've ever had. You can buy better tasting soup at the market. 
-The edamame was typical but with a pico de gallo powder on it. Too salty for our tastes; but the edamame was OK.
-Rice was undercooked.
-Vegetables (fire cracker) were just OK; they were grilled with a soupy broth. Not much flavor to it.
-Parking: if you park at the Fairmont Hotel: $5/20 minutes; max. rate was $55 I believe. We ended up staying 1 hr 15 min and didn't rush through our dinner. Good luck finding a spot on the street; as everyone else parks there, including the local residents. You pretty much have to park at the hotel or somewhere nearby, and your wallet gets reamed for it.

Conclusion:
-If you want a similar environment/ambiance, try The Rainforest Cafe. Your wallet will thank you.
-After seeing this place on No Reservations, we were excited about it and anxious to try it out; expecting great/stellar food. Total disappointment.
-My wife has rolled out better dishes from our humble kitchen, albeit at a far cheaper price.
-The value just wasn't there, and we won't go back.
author: Chuck S.

description:
I stumbled upon this place with my friend in the early evening, and it looked like a really fun place! The place is decorated like an old ship. From 5-8pm, there's no cover, but there's also no entertainment. Therefore, I came back here on a Saturday night in the evening, paid a $7 cover (1 min drink required) and listened / danced to a live band playing the oldies. 

The band was pretty good and plays on a boat in a middle of an old pool. My bf and I joined other people on the dance floor and danced to some classics. It was definitely a fun environment to just relax.

Every hour after 8pm, there is a fake thunderstorm that takes place, while the boat "docks" so the band can take a 15-20min break.

The drinks are good and a bit pricey, but I expected that. My bora bora horror was strong, but my pina colada was extremely weak.
author: Margaret R.

description:
Stayed at the Fairmont while playing tourist in the city with the gal. 

What used to be a swimming pool back in the days (days long before any of us were born), they decided to build a Tonga room with a hurricane bar. Thanks for ruining this historical part of the Fairmont with a Tropical Rainforest rest theme. Free for hotel guests but theres a cover charge which is injustice for terrible decor, pricey drinks and mediocre food. One thing though, and I've said this already, drinks are expensive but the Lava Bowl (try two Lava Bowls!) is out of this world. It's mean, its strong and its nasty.

After party guaranteed.
author: Ken C.

description: Best spot for the punch bowl, ambiance and great waiters!
author: Christopher B.

description: Great place for a first date or a special occasion. The drinks are kind of pricey and kinda small. Can be a little overcrowded on weekends.
author: Erick M.

description:
One of my classmates had her bat mitzvah party here in 7th grade and I missed it because I was at someone else's bat mitzvah.  DRAMA!  I finally made it to the Tonga Room as an adult, and it is everything I dreamed it to be.  I appreciated being leid on my way in, and the dance floor was POPPING on that particular night.  I don't think I would eat here because based on the price of the drinks I suspect the food would be even more expensive, but for a fun night of tropical drinks and dancing, you can't get any better than this.

I tried to get my students to have their prom here last year and failed, so maybe this year.  HOW GREAT WOULD THAT BE?!?!
author: Nora S.

description:
$7 for "entertainment charge" per person on Fridays and Saturdays is pretty steep. 

I came here on a Friday night, suggested by a friend and the first thing that I noticed was the uppity vibe. A classy Hawaiian restaurant. Interesting.

The overall experience was cool. It is definitely a fun place. It has a dance floor, a band that plays on a boat that moves and it rains everytime the band takes a break.

They have HUGE drinks. Usually recommended for four. but if you want to get SLOSHED get a lava bowl to your face. It will put hair on ur chest.

The food was decent. You will not find authenticity of any sort here, but it wasn't bad.  I Highly recommend the Mussels. They were seriously the best mussels I've ever had. Our group also ordered mongolian beef, chicken, calamari, coconut prawns and the fried rice.

With exception for the mussels everything else was just mediocre.  Nothing really stood out, it was all pretty standard.

We did the whole experience with the old school picture and the matches. I just think it's a try it once kinda deal. It was fun but I really wouldn't come back here willingly.  I just feel like it's over priced for what you get.
author: Zu W.

description:
Came to the Tonga Room after a wedding...so we had a party of maybe 10-15 people...the bouncer/door guy was so rude saying the place was too crowded however once we got inside it was totally  empty. No one was even on the dance floor. 

I like the ambiance and decor, totally touristy and cool to look at with a good buzz but I was really disappointed that our party got smaller because we were having a hard time getting in.
author: Lidia Z.

description:
The band was great! Atmosphere was fun and lively. 

Overal a little loud, which made it hard to hear/have a conversation. 

I enjoyed the food. I got the pork curry which had a really nice flavor. Others in my group got vegetarian fair as well as appetizers and everyone seemed happy. 

The drinks are pricey, but they don't skimp on the good stuff. Very flavorful.
author: Cassie F.

description:
I went to the Tonga Room last night for a birthday dinner. Around 5:00pm, we called to see if we could change our 8:00pm reservation. Turns out they didn't have our rezzie in their system; good thing we called! 

The service is quite good, both from the Fairmont Hotel and the restaurant itself. 

The food is mediocre. I had the Hot Pot entree, which has loads of seafood, but not much flavor or spice. The only flavor I could detect was ginger. 

The drinks are where it's at here. They are expensive ($12 for a single cocktail) but they are strong. We got a Lava Bowl for our table and would have ordered another one, but we had to drive home some how. 

The ambiance is also fun. The rain, the live band, and the decor all add to the experience. 

I wouldn't come back here by myself, but if I was hosting out-of-town guests, I would certainly bring them here, especially if they were staying at a hotel in the area. (Note: this is not a "local hangout" or similar; it's a tourist draw, not that there's anything wrong with that.)
author: Anne M.

description: I enjoyed the atmosphere, my daughter thought it was cool when it started raining.  Now for everything else..... Let's start with WAY OVERPRICED!!!!  Basically we ordered dinner for 4, came with a shared appetizer, 4 shared entrees, and dessert.  Food was just okay, nothing tasted out of this world or worth the $248 bill, not including tax or tip.  Parking is a hassle and expensive.  As far as service goes, again nothing special.  I am glad we tried it out, however I would never go back again.
author: Andrea B.

description: Awesome food, great music, strong drinks, and a Damn good time. Try to make a reservation before going because the place fills up quickly! You can wait in line to get in but will probably wait around 30 minutes to 1 hour. Definitely worth the wait in my opinion
author: Sara I.

description: Three of us had a great time in this very unique bar/lounge/restaurant.  The location in the Fairmont Hotel is lovely!!  My one and only critique is that the drinks and food are a bit pricey, guess you pay for the presentation and the entertainment, that being said, both the pool and the food are delicious!  The food is very fresh, nicely prepared, perfectly seasoned and beautifully presented.  The décor is fun and comfortable.  The bar area is a happening spot.  The floating band plays a very nice variety of tunes and they don't blast you out of the place...it's fun to get up and on the dance floor. Will definitely go back here on our next visit to San Francisco.
author: Patricia G.

description: The Tonga Room is amazing. This Tiki Room is  beautiful and a world  class  act. The  Tonga is one  of the most  authentic and elaborate Tiki Rooms in the world. Although the Tiki drinks are good there a bit pricey. The pool floating rafts thunder and lighting make  one feel like you're in the tropics. The music  is tropical and soothing. I feel like I am on vacation every time I come here. People  come from all over the world to go to the Tonga Room .This  place is a definite  must see.
author: Alexa S.

description:
Read the news that business is not doing that great and that they have plans of either closing or renovating it.  That is how I got to know about Tonga Room.  Loved the place.  Reserved through opentable and they kept their word on the special requests :) 2 stars.

By the time me and friend were there, the band had started playing on the boat and they had pretty good beats from Santana, Ipanema, some jazz hits.  2 stars

Drinks were amazing.  We had bora bora horror and some pineapple drink (forgot the name), dessert.  Food was mediocre but the drinks were pretty good.  They served it in tikimugs - cute :) 1 star.

All in all good place for special occasions, parties.  Got to go again to check out the buffet style appetizers =-)
author: Hema K.

description:
I am staying at the Fairmont Hotel this week for a business meeting, so my colleagues and I decided to check out the famous Tonga Room. 

As we walked in, you feel like you are in a tropical rain forest.....or in a Hawaii bar/lounge.  As we sat down at our table, the rain began to fall and thunder could be heard.  In the middle of the restaurant is a lagoon with a floating tiny island for the band to play on.

Once the thunder and rain show subsided, the band started to play 80's music........cool:)

For the meal, I ordered the hot/sour soup and the duck breast.
The soup was very avg....nothing specail at all.  I have had better at the Mall.  The duck breast was sliced and came with a tangy, sweet orange/lemon sauce and a bowl of rice.  Very tasty and satisfying.

Overall,  not a bad place to check if you are a tourist......ONCE in a lifetime.
author: Raider J.

description: It saddens me to write this, as I have always loved the Tonga Room. After a miserable episode of food poisoning, however, I can no longer recommend eating there. I understand that you can't know with certainty which meal caused food poisoning, but a variety of factors lead me to believe that the Tonga Room meal was indeed the cause of my illness. I also understand that the best of kitchens can slip up from time to time, but here's my complaint: they didn't care. They never got back to me, despite repeated calls, demonstrating zero interest in hearing what I'd eaten and whether they might need to review their kitchen procedures. This was the worst $150 I ever spent on a meal, and I am extremely disappointed in their callousness.
author: N D.

description: By mixed drinks they mean 90% alcoholic beverage and 10% mixer. Dont be surprised when it hits you! Also the lake and music were great.
author: Danny D.

description:
It was our last night in town and it was LATE. The only thing I wanted to do was go to the Tonga Room, and so as we were heading down there at about 11:15pm, my husband looks at reviews. It was not looking good for us!

Yes, I am one of those people that discovered this place due to the Anthony Bourdain show, "The Layover". Reviews said it had become over crowded and filled with little old ladies. Perhaps since we went just an hour and a half before closing we got there after the so called little old ladies had gone home to bed. We had a nice table right next to the "lagoon" where the band was playing on the "barge" and we loved every second of it! A bride and groom who had just gotten married in the Fairmont (the hotel where the Tonga Room is locate) that night were downstairs having their own little after party...it was really quite sweet!

Our server was quite nice, the band was pretty good, and the drinks were delish!

Fair warning: there is a $7 cover charge if you are not guests at the hotel :(
author: Laura T.

description:
It can be very easy to forget to do all the touristy things when you actually live in a city. For example, I lived in New York City for a year, but I never went to the top of the Empire State Building. Perhaps even worse, I grew up in the Bay Area and have lived in San Francisco for a year now, yet I have never rode on a cable car. I know. It's pathetic. Luckily, I crossed one item off the San Francisco Tourist To-Do List the other night when I went to dinner at The Tonga Room, one of the city's quirky landmarks.

The Tonga Room and Hurricane Bar is nestled within the Fairmont Hotel, which is great because you can pretend that you are a rich and fancy person when you go to the swanky restrooms. As for The Tonga Room itself, it's a lot of fun, with an element of Las Vegas-esque theatricality. Seated in a bamboo chair under a thatched hut-style roof, with tribal masks on the walls and a bright blue lagoon in the center of the room, it feels like a little slice of "Disneyland for Adults" right here in San Francisco.

My friends and I went to dinner with a coupon we had all purchased from PopSugar City, which entitled us each to half-off the "Kao Island Dinner" plus a cocktail. Of course, there's an extensive a la carte menu, but The Tonga Room is perfectly suited to a lively dinner with a large group, and to that end it offers three variations of a family-style menu, ranging from the Kao Island Dinner ($45/person) up to the Pangai Island Dinner ($65/person). Our menu included the following:

1st Course: Baby back ribs with Kona coffee barbecue sauce, shiitake mushroom eggrolls, and vegetable tempura.

2nd Course: Szechwan-spiced firecracker prawns, Mongolian beef with crispy rice noodles, "Huli Huli" chicken with pineapple and water chestnuts in a soy sauce glaze, Szechwan green beans, and jasmine rice.

3rd Course: Banana mousse cake with a peanut butter ganache and a macadamia nut crumble.

Generally, at restaurants that are all about the atmosphere, the food tends to be subpar. However, the food at The Tonga Room was actually quite good! Take my advice and show up hungry, as we weren't able to finish even half of the food that was brought to us.

Our coupon also included any cocktail costing $12 or less. I asked the waiter if it was true that they were famous for their mai tais, and upon his confirmation, we ordered those around the entire table. The mai tais are made with Bacardi 151, so be prepared for what you're getting yourself into! That being said, they are quite delicious and come in funny tiki cups adorned with mermaids and, of course, a paper umbrella on top.

The meal wouldn't have been complete without the entertainment of the Island Groove Band, a cover band that plays on Wednesday through Sunday evenings around 8pm (with a cover charge of $5 or $7 depending on the night). The band performs on a boat that "sails" out onto the lagoon - retreating, of course, when it is time for the periodic fake rainstorms.

The Hurricane Bar also offers a solid happy hour on Wednesday through Sunday, which additionally includes an all-you-can-eat buffet for $9.50 on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays.

There has been some controversy in the last couple years over rumored plans to move the Fairmont's ballroom into the area currently occupied by The Tonga Room. My friends and I had a fantastic time at dinner the other night, so I'm happy to report that those plans have been shelved for the time being. It doesn't sound like The Tonga Room will be closing its doors anytime soon, but still, if you haven't yet checked out this San Francisco oddity, I'd suggest that you round up some pals and book yourselves a table soon!
author: Katherine K.

description:
I went here last night (1/13) nice decor - you feel like you're on a pirate ship or something. not so nice bartenders which is one of the reasons for the 2 stars along with $13.02 drinks! (listed as $12) on the menu. Add on a $7 cover and you're looking at $20+ for one drink! The bartenders were really unfriendly, didn't bother asking if I wanted another drink and checked A FEW TIMES whether I paid my bill even though I was sitting there still and could have wanted another drink! how tacky! My friend said when she ordered her drink, the bartender was coughing without covering his mouth saying he was sick; she asked him not to make her drink! there's a great dance floor and a live band playing in the middle of a pond, which was cute.
It's very touristy, but I still liked it minus the terrible service.
author: Melody T.

description:
Like going to Disneyland....
expensive
fake Hawaiian stuff
greasy food
when your done, your done
Been there, done that....
P.S. We ordered the vegetable tempura and it came with 7 pieces of okra tempura and one piece of zucchini   How does that happen????
author: Cassie P.

description: Very unique fun place!  Atmosphere is excellent!  Very well done.  Band on boat in lagoon, it rains and there is lightning and thunder.  Very fun.  Drinks are excellent and Strong.  Only reason not 5 stars is it was $45 for two people, two drinks total, $13/drink + $5/person band cover + tax + tip.  Very nice. But Expensive.
author: Scott R.

description:
It was a dinner date with my wife and I chose Tonga Room at The Fairmont in SF (she hinted at some time back :) )
Well, Tonga room Restaurant and Hurricane Bar is located in the Fairmont so you will be met with grandeur of the hotel when you enter. Classy for sure! 
From the classy interior with loads of antiques & picture-filled classy corridor of the hotel you suddenly enter The Tonga Room! Amazing ambiance! I would say you will be drawn quickly into relaxing mode with t he atmosphere created by the dimm yet beautiful interior! Every top of the hour it rains around in the artificial pool created with lightening effect! AT 8 Pm or so, I think over thew weekend, you have a live band that plays exactly what mood you want to be in such a beautiful place! Of course you can join your partner on the dance flor if you want to :) 

Now for the service, A++ for sure. Very fast, responsive and informative yet friendly! 
Cocktails are out of the world, if you are going there for the first time , Mai-Tai is highly recommended!!! 
Presentation for the food and cocktail is unique too! Food taste is healthy though! Very light potions for most of the time. Desserts are beautiful, we ordered Baked Alaska and it surely did not disappoint us. 

All is all if you want a good romantic dinner in SF and would not mind to spend a few extra bucks for it, I strongly recommend Tonga room and Hurricane Bar at the Fairmont in SF!
author: Mandar S.

description:
Something must be wrong with either my party's appetizer or drink. My gf and I both felt DROWSY badly after the appetizer & drink (we shared one of the appetizers) and we lost all the appetite. 
We guess either the Singapore Sling is too strong, or something wrong with raw fish in the appetizer Maui Wowie something. Disclaimer: we are not allergic to any alcohol or raw fish. 

Ambient is fantastic but I won't come back again.
author: Bo W.

description: We went there for a birthday celebration, made a list of food to order, gave it to the waiter, and it was perfectly executed.  the waiter even suggested if he can order dessert for our group which i approved.  Everybody enjoyed the food, the band, the service!!! this is highly recommended... And lastly just spending a night in the Fairmont Hotel makes the night magical.. Will definitely come back for the food and entertainment...
author: Marnie P.

description:
"San Francisco Institution"????

We finally decided to try out this San Francisco treat from the olden days. We paid an $8 entertainment fee for the most incredibly horrible band I've heard since a bad country wedding.  Where was the Polynesian Music or live Hula, we have a world renowned Halau right here in San Francisco. I understand kitch and camp, what I don't understand is $20 absolutely horrendous drinks made with well liquor.  I glanced at the menu with prices equaling some of the best restaurants in town for what looked like General Tsao's Chicken and frozen pot stickers.  This place is an easy $140 evening for two and I can guarantee you'll leave wishing you had dined at some of San Francisco's finest for less and so much more.

The Tonga Room has so much potential.  It's time for a total overhaul.  I can see really terrific drinks with fresh juices as opposed to canned pineapple juice with cream of coconut.  What about great fresh food from the Pacific Rim?  We have some of the best restaurants in the world, we can do so much better.

The ownership of the Tonga Room has a responsibility to the city and the world to maintain a San Francisco Landmark to higher standards than this schlock.
author: Perry V.

description: Restaurant has awesome decorations and food is excellent. They have asian Hawaiian type food it's actually pretty unique. Reminds me of a restaurant that would be in Disneyland.
author: Natalie N.

description: Writing a review not about the venue itself but about the terrible experiences I've had the 2x i've TRIED to go there. Both times in larg-ish groups but everyone was very respectable (late 30's & no one was drunk). Both times we were made to wait a really long time despite the place being practically empty. Both times we were told ~10 mins and at ~25mins we just got fed up & left. Feedback I will be sending to this place is - if you don't want big groups coming, just tell them. Don't make us queue for 30 mins & stuff us around. Very annoying. If you're in a group of 3+ don't plan on going here without a reservation as they will just mess you around.
author: Bianca H.

description:
if what you crave is disneyland with liquor, accompanied by indifferent, lackluster service and so so food, go stand on line for the tonga room. granted, the decor, what with its pirates of the caribbean feel (sans the drunken pirates, such a shame...), definitely amused, and the thunder, lightning and rain that showered down every half hour on the little lake-y/pond-y center excited. around 8:00 or so, the booth in the center of the lake became the source of musical entertainment, with 3 musicians playing elevator renditions of today's favorite soft pop, much to the delight of the inebriated masses who had taken much advantage of the tonga's generous happy hour, which, in turn, delighted me from my vantage point.

since we weren't there for happy hour, our server didn't seem to care at all about providing us with menus, timing our meal, or removing empty dishes. i suppose we were the tip he would actually have to earn since we weren't going to race over to the happy hour buffet in its last 5 minutes just to avoid paying full price. I eventually had to get menus myself, we cut our food with forks, and, even though our table was super tiny, all our food basically came at once, to the point where we were emptying one plate to put it on another to make room. and then, we were ignored and had to get his attention in order to order dessert and then later to get the check.

food wise, i would say very ehhhh. my dining companions enjoyed their coconut prawns but found the egg rolls hollow, the shitake dumplings had utterly no flavor and were simply moist fat wrappings of rice flower over a scanty supply of shroom. the spicy broccolini was lovely and the green beans were average. the chi chi, a pina colada with vodka in lieu or rum, was delightful.

overall, i'm glad we went because this is definitely an entertaining venue, but i would only drink... and probably i would not return. i prefer my tiki cheesiness to be more dive-y...
author: Wendy S.

description:
We were looking for something special to celebrate a milestone birthday/ anniversary. Having grown up on an island, an Island themed venue seemed like the natural choice. 

We made the reservation before bothering to read reviews on Yelp. Imagine our horror when we read about the food and service! We have lots of options for this event and were not about to fork over a fortune for cheap Chinese. So we shared our concerns with the catering manager and went in for a tasting with fingers crossed. 

Ken was our server on the night of the tasting. He was amazing...attentive but invisible except when needed. After sampling the Tonga platter, we found that the chicken satay, crisp shitake spring rolls and coconut shrimp were spot on in terms of temperature, flavor and presentation. The hot and sour soup was not the corn starchy goo you get at Panda Express. We enjoyed various fruity concoctions including pina coladas, margaritas, a Tongan itch, Mai Tais, lava bowls and Pineapple royales. The cocktails were tasty if a little fruity. But they were  in line with expectations.  

After a little back and forth, Lucas the manager got us hooked up with a menu consisting of Tongan platters, miso soup and choice of fennel crusted butterfish, smoked chicken with Tongan fried rice and rib eyed steak with salad. Our party of 20 got seated on one of the pirate decks as we had requested. Everything on the menu was greeted with enthusiasm. The baked alaska with pineapple ice cream at the end of the meal was rich and delicious. And although we had planned on cutting out before the cover band came on, some of our guest wanted to hang out a little longer. So we stayed. The next thing you know, two and a half hours have elapsed. And the place was closing. 

Our night at the Tonga Room not only pleased our palates and satiated our appetites, but it exceeded our expectations in every way. So if you are looking for an unforgettable evening or a venue for a special occasion, I recommend you give this place a try. For us, this was a night to remember.
author: Angelica S.

description:
Surprisingly good food, great service, and drinks that directly attack your liver. 

The Tonga Room is a restaurant/bar/lounge in the Fairmont hotel. As it is deep within the hotel, it is a very very large windowless "room", decorated in a hawaiin theme. All the chairs have "leys" on them, and the center of the gigantic room is a floating stage on  a pool of water. They float the stage out into the middle of the room while the band is playing, and retract it when the band is on break.

Service was top notch. My water glass was always full, and they were very quick on the drink refills. A note on their drinks, I had some strawberry frozen margaritas that I think I could have put back all night if cost was no object, and the rum based drinks were quite potent. 

The food itself was surprisingly tasty, and fresh, and was served 15 minutes after we ordered it. I was pretty stuff.

There's a dance floor as well designed to look like the deck of a ship...kinda annoyingly placed as you cannot walk to and from your table without passing through the dace floor...as the restaurant is in a hotel, the bathrooms are a good 5 minute walk outside of the restaurant down a hall.

All in all, a great time for my friend's birthday and a change of scene. The music was great too, but they did all covers of slightly older/classic tunes.
author: Jordan C.

description: We love coming to this SF classic! We held my Dad's 65th birthday here and had a reservation for 50. It's a fun place to bring the whole family including kids! Live music, fun drinks... kids menu. The food is not the best, just OK style Chinese, but this place is so much fun. Everyone had a blast!!!
author: Amanda R.

description: This was our first time visiting the Tonga Room after hearing from a handful of people that we should try it out while visiting the city. Great decision! We made reservations the day of and on arrival we were greeted and seated very promptly and were seated right near the water and entertainment. The service was great from start to finish. Food surpassed our expectations, the dumplings were delicious! The drinks were an extra plus! We were surprised with pleasant and fun entertainment by the band and unexpected dessert on the house to celebrate our anniversary.
author: Erika B.

description: Really liked this place. It was a nice change from the ordinary and the drinks were nice and strong.
author: Julia D.

description: My co-workers and I headed here for drinks one Friday night. We got there early (right at 5pm) because we had 7+ people and wanted to get a comfy loungey table. This is a great place for happy hour and also to bring people from out of town! Its very interesting on the inside, has different types of seating and will keep you chatting! The service was great and the drinks were strong! Happy hour specials are not to miss!
author: Amber M.

description: This is a great San Francisco treat. If you are visiting or live here.  You need to go
author: Bill N.

description:
Cheese, but it works.

The Tonga room is overpriced and the food is not that great. You can find much better for one third the price. The drinks are also overpriced and not that great. I got a strawberry margarita that I had to send back because it tasted like cough syrup. And I NEVER send stuff back.

But I still loved coming here. This is a good cheesy special occasion place if you go on a night that there's a live band, you want to dance, and that you think mini indoor rainstorms are cool. Even though disneyland and rainforest cafe do this way better.

It's funny, I write all this and it sounds so negative but I still gave it three stars. Why? Because It's really fun to be transported to a different world - even if it's cheesy. To be with a ton of different people and watch a cute live band playing songs in the middle of a pool.

I'd definitely come here for a happy hour or maybe just for dessert or drinks.
author: Courtney A.

description: This place is crazy. It's all about the atmosphere: The fake rain showers, the pool, the 80s cover band, the dancing, the tikiness. Crazy awesome. Everything else? Not so good. Weak, pricey drinks, and otherwise pleasant staff trying to get you to order the incredibly expensive, overpriced, mediocre food. Look around: No one's eating, for good reason. If you can, come early (to avoid the cover), come drunk, order a drink for yourself and a scorpion bowl for the table, and dance.
author: Kent L.

description: Wow.  Time warp back 50 years in time.  A cross between the Love Boat and Fantasy Island...just waiting for Tattoo to run out yelling 'da plane, da plane'.  Pretty good service, good drink and even better people watching...
author: Todd L.

description:
Classic San Francisco right here. Where did all the old bankers hang out in the 70s and 80s? Right here.

Drinks that will seriously (and quickly) mess you up. Yummy appetizers and bites. Crazy decor and dance floor...oh ya, old people dancing....So tacky it's awesome, and their happy hour is pretty legit. It's like a grown up Rain Forest Cafe, complete with hourly rain storm to coincide. 

My friends and I seem to end up here after an extremely boozy dinner or an early evening filled with obvious bad decisions...Tonga Room being one of them. So bad it's GOOD!
author: Meredith M.

description:
there's a water feature in the middle of the room
with a boat on it
and a band
the whole thing moves
and sometimes there's fake rain

i'm not saying any of that is good or bad.  but your reaction to that information should tell you everything about whether or not this is the place to you.
author: David P.

description: I'm going to assume 99% of SF patrons have seen Anthony Bourdain's "The Layover" in which he visited the Tonga Room, because its been packed ever since. We arrived on a Friday night around 9:30pm and there was a line out the door waiting to just get a drink. Yes folks, there was line just to stand at the bar. Ridic. Once we got in after 45 mins of waiting we got a prime seat by the water. There was a live band playing that I actually really liked. 5 stars for them. We shared a lava bowl for 2 and a mai tai. Holy hell, those drinks are dangerous. They are SO strong that we both could not drink them. However the novelty of it was great.
