We enjoyed the rain showers, the live music, the stiff island drinks and the crazy themed "Gilligan's Island" parties.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: Granted I was with great people but the service was awful. I waited at the bar for 15 mins to get a drink while a bartender ignored me while cleaning. It wasn't until a lady finally asked what I wanted, then she told him that he needed to stop and get my drink, the guy said not one word the entire time, he proceeded to take the half full glass that I had on the counter and dump it out. I nicely told him that I wasn't finished, not a sorry, nothing out of his mouth. The same lady asked what I had and he filled another glass a quarter of the way and handed it to me. Still no words out of his mouth..... $13 later for one drink and not to mention he made it wrong I was finally able to return to my group. Never again!
author: Lauren M.

description:
What a disappointment.
I was really looking forward to try Happy Hour in a nice place. Their $9.50 buffet (with at least one drink order) sounded very interesting.

Alas, the food was mediocre at best, and cold.
Their drinks list is also very unoriginal, and they did not taste really good.
The service was not bad, but I wouldn't call it good; mostly non-descipt and a bit awkward at times.
Also bad reception, hard to check in on your favorite site :)

The decor I must admit, is pretty amazing, as is the ambiance, with their intermittent rain/lightning thing.

All in all, typical case of style over substance. Not coming back.
author: Vithiet L.

description: This place is hilarious. Huge tropical cocktails and the band performs on a boat in the water area that's in the middle of the bar (used to be a pool, I think). Every hour or so there's rain and thunderstorms. The service is great. Would be a funny and eclectic first date choice.
author: Sonya Z.

description:
Laugh out loud HILARIOUS!

I totally got a kick out of this place.  I was cracking up so much; I thought I had been transported to a lounge in Las Vegas...from the 1970s!

Cheezy is a serious understatement.  I don't know what was funnier--the band on the boat, or the mass of middle aged tourists gettin' down to the band's corny music.

And yes, the food is mediocre, the cocktails are gigantic, and the decor is tacky.  But somehow it all adds up to laugh out loud fun.

I think this place is a San Francisco "must try".  Just go and enjoy the experience!  

If you don't find it funny, you must not have a sense of humor ;)
author: Angella S.

description:
Had my 2nd experience/dinner at the Tonga room and now feel compelled to give my 2 cents worth...I AM A FAN.  I get a kick of being in the middle of the super cheesy Pacific Rim feel, with a fabric flower lei to wear to keep the experience "fun".  Yes, it is very spendy but what would you expect being that they are located inside the Fairmont hotel anyway?  And if the company you're with isn't entertaining enough, the place surely will...lots of decor to gawk at.

The food we get is delicious, my fave is the Mongolian Beef Tenderloin and the Kona bbq sauced pork ribs, ribs were definitely different and tasty.  And I adore cover bands, I knew every single song they played.  Just keep drinking and the view, entertainment and night gets more fun...
author: Emy B.

description:
I took my boyfriend here for his 29th birthday. I made reservations online and in the comment box I put I was coming here for my boyfriend's birthday. 

When we got there- it didn't feel like we were in California anymore. It truly felt like we were at a tourist attraction in Hawaii. I loved how there was live music and seating all around the pool where it "rains." There is a decent size dance floor right in front of the pool, and seating along the sides of the pool. 

The drinks come in the cutest cups ever! They have little coconut cups and tiki guy cups. They are a bit pricy, but they are strong. I did not taste the fruit juice. 

Food...The food was in all respects very tasty. But...a little overpriced. 

Dessert..a little over priced as well, but the green tea and chocolate cake dessert was fabulous! They surprised my boyfriend with a volcano coconut type of dessert for his birthday but it was not that great. It looked awesome though...ha.

What we got: 
Firecracker prawns (nothing special), Dragon Chicken (recommend), green beans (highly recommend), white rice, 2 cocktails and a lava bowl for 2, and one dessert- along with the freebie dessert. Which put us at a grand total of 149+ tax.  They also charged 7 dollars per person for entertainment fee that is included in the 149...

So unless you are willing to drop a good amount of money on someone I wouldn't go here.

But...I can tell you we stayed for around 3 hours there and loved the fact that while we waited for food we were able to dance. My boyfriend loved it and I wouldn't have taken him anywhere else for birthday. I have no regrets. 

Just enjoy yourself and have fun! =)
author: Corie C.

description:
I cringe each time I am dragged here. This is a place to take out-of-towners but I would not consider it a spot for locals. The kitsch 60's tiki atmosphere is more disney-esque than it is charming. Their tropical drink menu suffers from a lack of innovation and their diner menu is sub-par for a foodie-full town. 

If you want legit tiki bar i suggest smuggler cove or forbidden island in alameda.
author: Jordan P.

description:
For a supposedly well-run, relaxing venue, I seemed to have to wait a lot--in the line to actually get to the bar, at the bar while trying to glean some guidance on the best island cocktail to select, etc.

The main reason that I can't give the Tonga Room 4- or even 5-stars is that the clientele there when I stopped by on Friday evening was just the type I don't like.  Too pretentious and upscale--and a lot of tourists playing big-shots.

The whole experience just seemed a bit too contrived and tedious to be enjoyable.  Sorry, folks.  I don't think that I will be back.
author: Terry F.

description: fun place with all the gimmicks (indoor rainfall and the band plays in the middle of the pool)- great for a date. However, the music was not around my taste. (maybe it was because there was a wedding on the opposite side of where we sat). Food was decent but not great. Overall, this is a place to hang if your intention is to talk and not for good food.
author: William S.

description:
Ambiance -The darker ambiance totally sets the mood for dancing, which most everyone participated in throughout the night. I can see why people like to throw dinner parties here. We sat at a table next to the pool and had a great view of the band (they perform on a boat in the pool and the boats floats up and down the pool!) It was nice to have live music. Loved the thunder and lightening storm!

Food - I've always thought that concept restaurants focus too much on their décor and theme and not enough on their food, but the food at the Tonga Room was really good! I liked everything that I had on my plate. I especially liked the Mongolian beef and the grilled prawn salad. Save room for dessert! We had the Baked Alaskan, the Chocolate Bread Pudding, and the S'more Brownie and they were all so delicious. I would highly recommend! 

Service - We had Bash as our server and he was so friendly! We were a group of six having dinner and I really appreciated the fact that he left us alone and didn't come by our table too often to ask how everything was. He respected our space but was always around and happy to help when we did want to order more food. Our group wanted to eat family-style so we ordered a couple of dishes but Bash was really helpful in recommending some dishes too.
author: Pam C.

description: Great spot for dinner in the City. The beef was so tender and the service was attentive. The live music really kicks it up a notch. Make your reservations in advance, there won't be any space available for a walk-in dinner. The bar is a good spot to catch a specialty drink before you hit the town.
author: David H.

description:
It's hard to really rate this restaurant due to the fact that I came here for a corporate event... Normally when you eat at corporate events - everything is pre-made and just nuked warm. So I will rate this place primarily on the staff, drinks, atmosphere and then the food. 

Love the atmosphere - it definitely creates the allusion that you are no where near home - instead you are on some typical island with rain storms and floating boats that host live entertainment. The drinks and staff make you feel the same way - always pleasantly serving another Mai Thai.

As far as the food is concerned, it's not my favorite. I think people are really drawn to Tonga for it's atmosphere not the food, but then again I was here for work. Dinner was buffet style - I wasn't able to order what I normally would.
author: Crissy H.

description:
San Francisco has so many places with better food at more reasonable prices. In other words, the high prices are not justified by the quality of the food. Don't have dinner here. It's truly only a place for appetizers. You really are being charged an arm and a leg for a makeshift tiki bar complete with cheesy thunderstorms throughout your evening. Service was good, but it took a very long time to get my check and for it to be picked up (10 minutes, but they weren't busy?)

Summary: Tourist Trap. It can be a fun place if you're with a group just for drinks, appetizer and the experience of visiting once.
author: Marjorie G.

description:
So surprised this place has more than two stars. What a total fail!
We came here based on the reviews knowing how "intimate" this place can be. We were super excited to give this place a try and heard the food would not disappoint. This is suppose to be one of the places to come when you visit SF. Not only that but the reservations to get a table can be a bit long too..high demand high product right? I honestly walked away completely disappointed and hate that I have to only give this place 1 star but the Tonga Room does not deserve more.  

We had a reservation thankfully because the line to get in was crazy. Where could I begin?....
The service here was terrible!!! Now I am only speaking on the service we had on this particular night. I know places can be a little over booked and understaffed and I am okay with waiting but I am not okay when the server comes around to my table after a long wait and slams my plate down and gives zero effort into showing me he knows what customer service truly means. 

The food here is decent. The appetizers are over priced and so are the drinks. Our bill was nearly $100 and let me tell you we left hungry, not that we could have ordered more food because our server was no where to be found. We even waited a very long time just to get the check. We had to walk around and find our waiter in order to pay so we could finally leave! 

As far as being intimate...not so much. This place has room for potential but the music was so loud I could barely hear across the table. This is super casual as well. If you walk in dressed to impress you wasted time because there are lots of people who come here in jeans and flip flops. There are lots of party groups here so you will see people dressed but again it isn't what you would consider romantic. 

I did see the manager walk around and look at how busy the place was but did not see him stopping to check on guest and to me that was disappointing. If you are looking for customer service to make your night extra special and make your date, your party, or your guest feel like they matter then maybe you should think of another place. If you decide on a more relaxed night where no one will notice if you are at your table then you found the right spot.
author: Melody C.

description: This is a place a little off the beaten path of the SF hipster scene. If you are in the mood for some great ambiance and a laid back island feel (in the basement of an amazing old hotel) make sure to grab a drink here!
author: Tom C.

description: If you're looking for a nice place to hang out and relax after dinner in the city, then this is the place. I love the ambiance and the laid-back atmosphere. I came on a Wednesday night and there was a live band, which was pretty cool because they played a lot of old favorites. I would recommend the Pineapple Royal, it comes served in a real, whole pineapple! Oh, and yes, it was finished quick.
author: Dung N.

description: Ribs and tots were mediocre. Service was terrible, Roberto should be fired, he literally ignored us over and over. Don't try this place, it's all hype.  I have stayed at the Fairmont several times, but now I never will again just because of this experience.  Thanks for the negative memories!
author: A W.

description: Truly an exceptional place. It transports you into a magical place. A all in all fun experience. Some of the best tropical cocktails i've ever had. Not only tasty but deadly (be careful). Food is a tiny bit pricey but very good as well. I've now made it a point to stop here everytime i'm in the bay.
author: Shirley L.

description:
Tacky decor, good music, good food and high prices were what we expected coming into the Tonga room.

What we got was good music, mediocre apps, good entrees and a pushy waiter. 

5 minutes after being seated our waiter arrived with menus and asked if we wanted cocktails.."uh...you just gave us the menus, can you give us a few minutes?" 2 minutes later he comes back, takes our drink order and asks if we're ready to order our full dinner..."wtf? Can we get our drinks first" Does a quick sigh and saunters off to grab the drinks.

Beer is all Bottled no taps, sadness. Settled on a Tiger and my brother in law got a Sierra.
2 of the girls shared some kinda Lava drink...which was lukewarm...kinda weird but oh well i had my beer!...in a bottle. shit.
birthday girl got a mai tai and she didn't complain about it so must've been all good.

Waiter comes back 5 minutes with the drinks and asks "Are you ready now to order your dinner?" No we'd like to order appetizers...he sighs again...takes the order and 10 minutes later the appetizers start hittin the table. 

Tonga platter, you should skip, well the Chicken Satay wasn't bad. Order that on it's own
Ceviche was okay but it tasted better than anything on the Tonga platter

I could be wrong, don't think so, but I thought the point of going out to a fancy hotel restaurant was to have a relaxing meal, have good conversation and to enjoy the atmosphere? After we received the appetizers we then proceeded to order dinner and more drinks.

Butterfish - GOOD! Get it!
Mongolian Beef - GOOD! Get it!
Yellow Curry with Beef - GOOD! Get it!
Scallops - These were just okay but I'm not into scallops in general so eh...

The thing that made the night though was the band! A good mix of old and new stuff in the songs were performed and they kept the dance floor full the whole time. I stayed at the table to just listen and enjoy the music and Mongolian beef burps. 

Needless to say we probably won't be coming back, the food was decent enough, price wasn't too bad, but the waiter ruined it for us. He seemed more interested in turning the table than to help provide an enjoyable night. Oh well!
author: Angelo B.

description:
This place is MAJESTIC.

It may be slightly overpriced and kind of weird because it's at the Fairmont, but who cares?!? All I know is I had a delicious pina colada and it RAINED INDOORS. 

Enough said.
author: Molly S.

description: Unique place and food was pretty good.  The waiter was very friendly and great with my daughter.  It rains and storms every so often around the pool whic is pretty neat.  Definitely like the Hawaiian decor.
author: D D.

description:
I love that my boyfriend and I came by before Anthony Bourdain gave the Tonga Room a shout out. 

We came by for their happy hour buffet a few months ago.  The buffet was very streamlined and for our needs, not very filling.  They served spring rolls, shrimp chips, chow mien (American version), teriyaki wings (tiny wings).  We told ourselves next time we would come strictly for the drinks and ambiance.  *They forced us to give them a credit card as we were seated as a hold (even though we told them we were paying in cash).  They charged us on the card for the buffet and we paid cash for the buffets and drinks.  It took a few days for them to reverse the charge and irritated my boyfriend for the inconvenience. 

Aside from being overcharged/inconvenienced up front, the decor is soooo COOL.  I love the retro tiki theme, staged area in the middle of the water and the pseudo rain showers with sound effects.  The tropical themed drinks and decor wrapped up in a unique time warp at the Tonga Room is a must see.

This would be a perfect place to host a birthday party or a mid week escape!  ***Just be clear with your server that if you plan on paying in cash, you've been given the heads up that they are known for overcharging people (forcing you to use your card when you plan on using cash).  Tell them that if they want you to pay up front and you plan on using cash, to let you pay cash up front.  You'll avoid the nightmare afterwards of having to call back and forth trying to hunt down a manager who will reverse the error.
author: Kristina F.

description: This review is specifically for the bar portion of Tonga. We went here on a recommendation of a friend and it was a lot of fun. We got there about 10 minutes before it opened and there was already a line. It seems like the reservation portion of this place is for the restaurant, not the bar, because we didn't have one. I'm glad we got there when we did because it was packed pretty soon after! They're famous for their Mai Tais but I really liked the zombie. And although the ambiance is definitely kitschy, it's pretty fun!
author: Brenna H.

description:
I took my friend here for a late birthday celebration on Sept 19. I didn't think of making reservations because there was just the two of us. We got there and they made a fuss about how we didn't make reservations and it would be really hard to seat us. After a total of 5 minutes staring at the guy trying to find us a table we were escorted to our table while the restaurant was half empty. We were there for over an hour and it never got more than half full. 

We ordered a pina colada. That was what the waiter suggested. My friend didn't like it but I thought it was pretty good. We ordered the chicken kabob and egg rolls both like $12+ each plate. Each plate came with 4 pieces. Definitely not worth it. 

We got there around 6.30pm. Only thing we saw was the fake rain. We didn't think it was worth 7 bucks for the live entertainment which started a couple hours later.
author: Sarah C.

description: Being inside the Fillmore Hotel one can only assume it will be slightly over priced. We went on a friday night and got a table (which they charged $7 additionally for the band). We did show up without a resi and had no issues getting a seat. If you stand at the bar you do not incur this fee. We got mules and margaritas and the drinks were delicious and then decided to order a few bites. The food was decent but nothing to write home about. We got the sliders and poke. The atmosphere is really why you should go here! They have a neat tiki atmosphere with the band playing on a boat and there even happened to be a rain storm and lightening. It's worth checking out for a drink and the atmosphere.
author: Michelle R.

description:
We went here on a Saturday (mostly just to try it since we've heard so much about it) and it was very consistent with the reviews here. You have to get there early. We were there 30 minutes before it opened and still had to wait for a table for 6. The staff moves you around with some urgency and there isn't much warmness by the servers. The drinks are what's to be expected at a place like this, overly sugary and tropical served in fun glasses. We had a sampling of most of the appetizers and they were mostly average with nothing standing out too much to recommend. 

The ambiance was fun and drinks were okay, but probably not worth the wait in line. We might be back with friends, but this isn't a place I'd visit on a regular basis.
author: Mike D.

description:
I'm only giving it four stars because it's a pirate ship bar. Whoa. 

There's a pool in the middle of the bar. Like - full sized pool. No joke. 

BTW - is there a word for a douchebag once they grow up and have a lot of money? Just wondering. 

The drinks were on the steep side but if you are in a big group you'll have fun. The band was entertaining and so was watching the wedding party that was there. Alcohol does wonders for people's inhibitions.
author: Carlos A.

description:
PLEASE do NOT go here. Just don't waste your time. The atmosphere seems fun at first when you walk in and you can't  wait for your 1st Mai Tai. The pool with floating band and the history is very intriguing and for sure the best highlight of the place. HOWEVER, we had to send back our Mai Tai's because they tasted like tainted, old pineapple juice. The food was Ok. Not horrible, but not great. The service was the worst part. Our waiter was down right rude and annoyed with us, the food, and everything about his occupation. Don't waste your time. It's Pirates of the Caribbean at Disneyland meets Rainforest Cafe (which is wayyyyy better) meets PF Changs.

Save your self the hike up the hill or cab ride. No need to go. Not even for a cocktail.
author: Darcie S.

description:
I came to this place a year or so ago because I heard it was closing (I guess that turned out to be a lie!)

The fiery volcano drink is a lot of fun and so is the live band with the tropical rain.  Yes, it's kitschy but it embraces it's kitschy-ness!  The band was pretty good too, but maybe that was after a few of the huge drinks.

Would be 4 stars except for the cover.  This place really should not be charging a cover.  Have a drink minimum or something.  Maybe if you go you can lie about staying at the hotel.
author: Rem J.

description:
- Bar Review - 

The hurricane bar reminds me of a gas station next to the airport, you get prices that are way too high just because it's a pain to go anywhere else.  If you're at a hotel on top of nob hill, they know you don't want to walk down and then back up for a drink, so they charge you for the convenience.

You just can't justify spending $15 a cocktail for drinks that just aren't that great.  They aren't bad, but I can walk 5 minutes and get drinks that are just as good at half the price with better atmosphere.

I haven't had any of the food, which people seem to enjoy, but I just don't see what all the hype is about.
author: Dave S.

description:
we've been here twice 
once in 2011 and once more tonight.
everytime we come here it's such a great time, the waiters are so lovely. 
 our waiter was very generous we ordered a fish to share and he gave us 2! then once dessert came he gave us 2 of that too even though we asked for one. 

he was busy running around but he still provided great service. the band is also pretty cool and fun. 

love this place.
author: Bernie V.

description:
Totally touristy, totally kitschy, totally lovable if you can get up here! The tiki Polynesian themed restaurant goes all out in its decor: grass hut roofs, tropical drinks served in pineapples and coconuts, a "rain shower" every 30 minutes and a live band that plays on a little moving stand on the lagoon. The place has theme down pat! 

Since it's located in the Fairmont, the couple of times we have been there are always folks who come after the wedding and you know those folks have had a bit to drink already. 

It's a fun place where geeky dancing seems appropriate and there's a dance floor on what appears to be a deck of a ship. The band plays your classic cruise ship favorites and everyone just wants to have a good time. 

Getting up there is hard though, parking in the hotel can run you up to $50 and nearby parking isn't that easy to find unless you park down the street and walk up. 

Oh, ignore the " $7 service charge" the lady tells you about in the front. They don't collect on it if you get drinks. 

For those who love a good themed bar, this is definitely the place to go!
author: Betty C.

description: Such a fun bar. $5 cover pp for a table or stand at the bar. Was worth it. Band on a boat on a small pool. Rain and thunder special effects. $7 imported beers. $12 delicious rum drinks in super cool glasses. Fun crowd. Nice staff. Super cool décor. Drank there every night after I found this place but didn't eat although it looked great.
author: Gerard H.

description:
I chose the Tonga Room for my 18th birthday celebration in San Francisco (we came up from the Peninsula). Little did I know when I picked it, it was expensive! We weren't old enough to sample the tropical cocktails (and were escorted by my parents!) but we were the perfect age to don Hawaiian attire and silly synthetic leis.

The food was yummy but not good enough for the price. The non-alcoholic tropical drinks were yummy but super overpriced. We took home the huge tiki ceramic bowl to compensate though...

The experience was great and funny with the old Fairmont pool converted into the Tonga Room lagoon. The live band played cheesy tunes and we danced along on the stage overlooking the lagoon. Good pics and fun times!

I came back to Tonga Room for happy hour because I'd heard about the cheap appetizers. These apps were delicious but we spent much more than we usually would at a happy hour. I believe we had to each buy a regular-priced cocktail in order to get the all-you-can-eat $8 appetizer deal. Worth it for the scene though...
author: Meghan P.

description:
This is a really cool place very very good service. It even rained inside!

Excellent place to bring your date. Very historical.
author: Bruce E.

description: OK - it was my husbands 50th birthday - I made reservations and asked for a nice table by the water so we could watch the band - while they did seat us by the water we were behind a speaker and their were plenty of tables but the hostess was extremely rude and said those were reserved - by the time we left 90 minutes later those tables has not been occupied *** I was also told he would get their famous lava cake for his birthday and the waiter simply brought a three scoop ice cream something (it was terrible) and said happy birthday and placed it down along with the check *** overall bad dinner, service and rude wait staff - never did see the band either as by 8:45 they had not even started playing and we had reservations at another club in an hour anway - place looks great from the outside but don't expect too much on the inside
author: Nicole S.

description: It was a great atmosphere for a fun evening out, but the food was mediocre and really expensive.
author: Meaghan H.

description:
Well, what can I say....
This place is an institution. My Grandparents use to come here. The drinks are expensive, but strong. The interior is total tact-o-rama... I loved every minute of it. Keep it old school.
author: Scott S.

description:
Went there with my boyfriend and his mother to celebrate an early mother's day. Once we were seated and had our lavishly decorated drinks in front of us (my boyfriend and I shared a Scorpion drink for two), it was so easy to slip into thinking you're actually somewhere far, far away on vacation rather than in the middle of a busy city! The lightning, thunder, and rain started as the band entered on a little boat playing music that brings you back to when.. you know, those times. 

I ordered the duck breast, my boyfriend had the "catch of the day" which was sea bass and his mother ordered the mongolian beef. We ordered the fried jasmine/black rice mix to share. Best rice ever and the duck breast literally melted in my mouth!

As the night came to an end, we had spent about $80 on 5 drinks (yikes!) but it was well worth it. The only downfall was leaving the place and snapping back to reality that, being it was a Thursday night, I was NOT on vacation and had work early the next day :( . Wonderful experience though.

I recommend being seated next to the pool so you can get the full effects of the rain and band.
author: Jenny Y.

description:
If you look at the photos for this place, it's not hard to find a reason for wanting to check it out. The decor and ambiance here is simply amazing, but I wish I hadn't eaten here. It's very expensive, not that great, and for some reason, after about 30 minutes I was itching to leave. This would however be a great place to grab a drink/appetizer before hitting the town for the night.

Also, I didn't realize there was a $7-each cover until I got the bill. Pretty snake if you ask me.
author: Jason L.

description: I really just like the fact that they managed to fit all that stuff into the hotel. It's pretty cool. Cool until you realise you overpaid for what you get here. Still hasn't stopped me from coming back when I'm in the area though.
author: John B.

description:
You have to hand it to this place for surviving in its current location. A lot of people around the city have said "I've always wanted to go there!" and then of course Bourdaine gave it the thumbs up on his show. So I finally went! 

Despite the overpriced (but definitely boozy) cocktails, the place is a hoot. The whole tropical/pirate ship ambiance really puts a smile on your face when you walk in the door.

And that's all you need to know about this place. It's a fun, goofy cocktail lounge. Definitely a destination.
author: Stephen R.

description: Just returned home from the Tonga room. We went for dinner and I really wanted to like this place, but really didn't. The food was awful. The steak had zero flavor and the pulled pork was so bad that I couldn't even eat it. I am giving it two stars because the waiter did the best he could considering the circumstances and didn't charge us for the Pork dish. I think it could be an okay place if you just want to drink and hear some okay music. But the food is expensive and really pretty bad
author: maureen G.

description: This place keeps getting worse. Be prepared to wait 30-40 minutes before you can place your order.
author: anna p.

description:
The place looks nice with the TIKI bar style; the fake rain and thunder was fun for me too.
Live Band was also nice touch.
The food was just ok though.

Cocktail: what a disappointment! I tried 4 of them and they all tasted like Mai Tais; there was just an OK one from the list

The sever was nice and everything but she just wasn't able to give me a recommendation. I asked her a simply question: what is the best for you on the drink list? and she just replied "I can't tell you what is the best but Mai Tai is our signature cocktail". Really? Everything on the list seems like their signature cocktails (10 of them I think) even tho all of them are the classic drinks that you can find every where.

We ended up going to Smuggler's Cove to try a real TIKI bar with excellent drinks worth my money.
author: Aphrodite L.

description:
Major kudos go to this long standing (and hopefully continuing) tiki bar. I can't recommend the food - it's adequate, but hardly inspired - but the drinks and ambiance are exactly what you want in tiki bar. Bamboo, dark, artificial rain, and quality service. 

Once the hotel pool, this watering hole has a lot of space and a lot going for it. Happy hours are genuinely happy with specials on food and cocktails. Located under the Fairmont Hotel on Nob Hill. 

Hotel bar lovers will like the Fairmont, Mark Hopkin, Huntington triangle :)
author: sketch f.

description:
Ok it's so weird and goofy I have to admit that all-in-all, my recent visit to Tonga Room was pretty fun. Best part is that the staff and floating band take everything seriously...

Highlights: 
1. Strong drinks
2. A cover band that floats on a boat in the middle of a fake ocean of  water and "sails" back and forth all night. Oh and did I mention the storms?
3. A big ship themed dance floor. 

Lowlights: 
1. Everything is very expensive for what it is. 
2. Staff can be curt and often pushed their carts through too quickly
3. Food tastes like Americanized Chinese and isn't much to write home about.

So was the $100 each worth it? No way. Granted my dining buddies drank like fish-ies (I'm looking at you Mike and Jon) , but the bill was still an eye popper. 

So maybe go once when someone else is paying or go with only teetotalers to avoid emptying your entire piggy bank in one sitting.

Disclosure: Tonga Room is a Yelp advertiser and I work at Yelp.
author: Jeremy S.

description: I would give this place 3.5 stars if possible.  The food is nothing to write home about but it was adequate.  Don't go here looking for gourmet cuisine go for some tasty (and strong) drinks and some dancing.  The tropical drink selection includes many good options.  All expensive but good tasting.  The thunderstorms are fun and the floating band is actually pretty good.  The songs were recognizable and made us want to dance.  The little dance floor got pretty crowded.  Overall go here for the atmosphere, it's a fun place to go once.
author: Daisy T.

description:
Occasion: Dinner with family 

What I Had: Grilled prawn salad 

Food Review: The grilled prawn salad was very good, not too salty. It included "Kaffir Lime Vinaigrette" and was a nice light dish for someone who had eaten a lot earlier in the day. 

Service Review: The service here was fantastic. My younger brother (who I am very proud of!!) had actually interned at the Fairmont this past summer, and so he made sure we had it arranged with his buddies at the hotel that we got the best seats in the house by the simulated rain exhibit and all. Everyone was very friendly!    

Venue Review: The food was great, but I think it was the experiential part of the restaurant that made it memorable. Every once in a while, the pond in the middle of the restaurant with the tiki tiki hut and other decorations let down buckets of rain and thunder sounded in the background as we ate.  

Overall Impression: Not my #1 place for good food, but it's a fun place to go with friends or family for sure! Not noisy, so great for facilitating conversation, too, and the service is top notch.
author: Rachael K.

description: Made reservations three weeks in advance for a group of us.  We made our reservation for 7:30 because the website said they charge a cover fee starting at 8:00.  The day before our reservation they called and said they will be adding the $7.00 per person charge to our tab.  Now that is what I call SHADY!!!!
author: Michele M.

description: This San Francisco institution is more of an expensive dive, but worth going to once.  They simulate rain during Tiki band performances - but will try to charge you a cover even if you are already in the restaurant/bar area before the show started.  Kinda odd.
author: David S.

description:
I think I'm in love. Last night, I suggested to my husband that we move into the Tonga Room. Here's why...

Firstly, I love tiki rooms. They thrill me with their over-the-top commitment to outlandish decor, fruity drinks and demon rum. Smuggler's Cove is our local pirate bar, but I think Tonga Room has fully blown it away in terms of grandeur and it's provision of edibles. As soon as you enter Tonga Room, you are greeted by massive totems, huge ikat wall hangings and colorful lights strung between the palm-thatched huts of a small village around a pool. And on the water, there's a houseboat. That's where the band lives. And it rains inside this tropical paradise. Seriously. But I'm getting ahead of myself...

Okay, secondly, Tonga Room ran a killer Facebook deal: $31 for one Kao Island dinner and a mai tai or piña colada (a $62 value). This deal was extra wonderful because of its take on multiple deals per party--the minimum number of coupons per table was two, and the fine print actually encouraged inviting friends. This allowed six of us to redeem our deals at a big, festive dinner together, and also left room in our budget for extra fruity drinks. *applause*

Thirdly, when I called to make our reservation, I was specifically asked if there were any food allergies in our group. This is golden customer service!! I have to avoid gluten, which the lovely lady minding the phone duly noted. Every person taking table reservations should be trained to do this--many food allergies can be made less annoying for both staff and customers with a little advanced warning, and that can be facilitated by simply asking at the first point of contact.

Fourthly, our waiter was absolutely adorable! He was friendly and attentive, and dealt with my food allergies carefully and amiably. He was absolutely wonderful! While tropical offerings are often easy dining for the gluten-free, he was mindful of what modifications my food needed and always made sure I knew what I needed to about what was on the table. (Thus saving me from myself--were it not for this kindly gentleman, I would have tucked into the Kona coffee-glazed pork ribs and been in a world of hurt, as their soy sauce admixture has gluten in it.)

--Any place that not only anticipates food allergies, but also accommodates diners with special needs so delightfully deserves special commendation. My dinner was tasty and plentiful--as an added bonus, my specially segregated servings were particularly large, ensuring that I wanted for nothing and even had a tasty to-go bag at the end. *standing ovation*

Finally, the band was awesome. This dashing trio of songsters floated out in the midst of a tropical downpour to delight us with wonderfully delivered tropical treats. Several mai tais in, my musical friend was noting their brave choices--Night Fever was delivered in a truly awesome falsetto to make the Bee Gees proud, and Santana's compositions were covered with panache. I have a high cringe factor where music is concerned, and these guys never once triggered it. After many potent potables served in volcanoes, totems and coconuts, we were happily singing in the rain. It was so much fun.

To top it off, this fabulously outlandish establishment is nestled in the elegant environs of the Fairmont Hotel, so at the end of the evening it is easy to get a taxi out front while marveling at the heights of Nob Hill. Aces all around.
author: Kimberly M.

description: Food ok but pricey , nice music and atmosphere but they charged $ 5 each for cover as live music was  playing even though six of us had dinner there ! The waitress then lost my cr card and said I never have it to her luckily she found it on the floor at another table!  They credited $ for cover in the end, but service lacks the class expected of a restaurant in the Fairmont hotel.
author: Ed C.

description: My friends and I came here on a Friday night and had an absolute blast! We hung out in the bar and had cocktails in fun coconut glasses, the band was great. We even danced! We're definitely coming back again and having food :)
author: Nicole P.

description: $7 entertainment fee?? get the F outta here... when we started to walk away, the host chased us down and was like, ok you don't have to pay if you just sit at the bar. Didn't get any food, just had drinks. The bartender was friendly enough and the drinks aren't bad, but way expensive! $16 for a mai tai. Every drink comes with an umberrella and pineapple wedge, so guys if you want to hold on to your man cards, just get beer. The live band plays cover songs on a platform in the middle of the pool, with fake rain display. If you're into that kind of stuff, it's cool, if not, it's super cheesey. The crowd is definitely older, I'd say 40-60, we were no doubt the youngest people there that night (we went on recommendation of my friend's much much older brother, should have known...)
author: Claudia Z.

description: We had heard such great things about this place and went there for Happy hour. I guess I had a lot higher expectations. I was extremely disappointed. The dining area looked nice but was closed and the happy hour buffet was really not very good. It had a lot of mayonnaise based pasta salads, very underwhelming. There was no music, no lightshow, and no band. Maybe it was the time we went, but even the server we had was ok, but not great.
author: Gina W.

description:
Yarrrr...

Avast ye scallywags and landlubbers.  OK..that's all the pirate sea speak I know, and I know that this place isn't even really piratey, but is it bad that i associate all things ships with pirates?  Tiki's and boats and raining pools make this place pretty awesome.  Awesomely tacky.  I love tacky.

This was the first stop in a fantastic charity date, where Eric was a pimp and Twee and I were his escorts for the evening.  Or was it the other way around?  I mean we paid for him.  We shared a lava bowl for two adorned with three really large straws. OK, we should have ordered one for four, because as Eric called us...we are professional drinkers.  We had green beans as well, and enjoyed some lovely conversation set to the tune of a sporadic rain.  We got here at 7, and apparently the entertainment starts at 8, but next time....there will be dancing on the deck of the ship, to the band on the boat in the middle of the pool.  I've been here before.  I did the conga.
author: Lauren F.

description: It's awesome if you don't mind the wait to get in .. Live band is on-point and drinks are great
author: Amar S.

description: Was staying at the Fairmont for a business trip and decided to check out this place the first night we were there. My colleague and I sat at the bar, ordered a few appetizers and drinks. Overall, the service was just OK and the food/drinks were a little pricey, but decent nonetheless. The atmosphere and live music were awesome though! Didn't think I would make it back down as I wasn't overly impressed, but we ended up a few nights later just for drinks. Everything was great, but they stopped serving us at the table we were at, claiming they told us it was last call for the dining room. They didn't, but oh well, we moved to the bar. Everything was fine, again service was not outstanding, but it would do. Once 11:45pm hit they told us last call as they closed at midnight. I find it a little odd that every bar/restaurant in a hotel closes at midnight, but that wasn't our biggest issue. Once the clock hit midnight, they literally stared us down and told us we had to leave immediately and couldn't bring our drinks with us. We informed them that we were hotel guests and they still denied us. I was very disappointed with the lack of service and respect that they give their guests. Luckily, I will never be staying at the Fairmont again and will most definitely not visit the Tonga Room.
author: Megan R.

description:
If you go to experience the Lava Bowl the way Anthony Bourdain did, forget about it. They no longer put a Bunsen Burner in the center, and they were out of long straws. When I asked the waiter about the fire, he said, "Sorry, you're not on TV." Nice.

Had the happy hour buffet which was mediocre, so we didn't stay for dinner.
author: Kym B.

description:
+1 star for the live band, they are awesome. 
+1 star for the atmosphere, they really do tiki well.
+1 star for the fake thunderstorm, kinda cool.

-2 for the decent, yet over priced drinks and hohum service.
author: Kevin K.

description:
I love the authenticity of this classic "tiki temple"* and I came to a conclusion about this place in particular last night while I was waiting in a theme park-like line to enter the joint: the atmosphere imparts upon the enthused visitor just enough likeness to a fabulous "fantasy island" vacation to fool one into shedding all frugality upon entering the igneous-fringed portal to paradise that guards the Tonga Room. The excitement of the exhibit, mixed with the exorbitantly priced "exotic" libations, "oriental" munchies and a band that somehow manages incorporate shred-worthy synthesized guitar solos into songs like Louis Armstrong's "What A Wonderful World", puts guests at the risk of developing family-holiday-in-hell feelings that dictate one's plying themselves into a stupor with punches, daiquiris, and slings a-plenty to weather the tropical depression of what should be a genuine "am-I-still-in-San-Francisco?" experience. At $7 a pop for the initiatory ordinance (or "entertainment fee") we scratched our tropical itches elsewhere last night. 

If only the good folks at Smuggler's Cove could plunder the cocktail menu and let the natives sacrifice the band to Pele or whatever; do the right thing and slap some Lyman/Denny/Baxter up on that dusty hi-fi squirreled away in the S.S. Tonga's hold.

*two stars for enduring "tiki temple" realness (there isn't much out there that can rival the Tonga Room when it comes to decor)
author: Kelly O.

description: Here's my honest take: I love the tiki bar atmosphere, Tonga is hidden paradise. The food, although pricey is really good. I really expected a restaurant with such vivid decor to have below average food, but I was pleasantly surprised! Drinks are exciting as well. My only real criticism is that when they have a band play, the music is far too loud, especially if you're pool-side, it can make conversation impossible.
author: Jesse G.

description:
Pros
1- Beautiful ambiance for special occasions
2- Excellence fresh food. We had poke tuna, and calamari for appetizer. and shared sea food rice noodle. 

Cons
1- Service was slow to bring our drinks
2- Drinks were a bit too blend for my taste even though they had exotic names. Had a lava for two, Mai Thai, and all very ordinary if you remove the exotic glass and umbrella
3- Line out the door just for the bar. 

TIP: make reservation for a table. We  were seated in no time.
author: Guio L.

description:
After surviving the rainiest March in San Francisco since 1904 the last thing I needed was an artificial storm. The Tonga Room & Hurricane Bar is tucked somewhere beneath the earth in the Fairmount Hotel and the establishment proudly "offers a tropical and festive atmosphere with live entertainment, dancing and a rain storm." I didn't see any live entertainment (which they charge $3 for after 8:00pm) or dancing on my recent visit but I did get a fake rain storm. 

We were served by a waitress that's been working there for twenty-five years, and I am willing to bet the decor hasn't changed a bit during her tenure. On many levels visiting the Tonga Room is like going back to a time when a trip to Hawaii was actually considered "exotic". Happy hour is the only time worth coming to the Tonga Room, and even then once is likely more than enough. From 5-7pm the all-you-can-eat buffet is a $7 per person with a one drink minimum. Drinks are decent, but not worth the 20+ minute wait it took for one person at our table to get his.
author: Miriam W.

description: Do not come here.  Atmosphere is good but service is horrible!!!!  Food is not worth the price.  $70 cover charge? You have to be kidding me!?!
author: Derek B.

description:
Whoa, they were totally serious about the tiki theme. I went here with a bunch of co-workers one night and we had a glorious time sucking down all the girly looking drinks. You can even purchase the tiki themed glasses! I heard that the drinks could be really watered down but that was not the case the night we went. I had several Blue Hawaiis which were delicious. I also had the "Zombie" which was basically just rum and ice. 

I have two complaints though. My first is that there were so many families there. It didn't totally bother me until around 9pm when there were an equal amount of drunk adults and small kids. It made the night slightly awkward as I don't think the bar area is really family friendly. 

The second complaint is that the service is truly terrible. I think they must have the same waitstaff as when they opened the Tonga Room in the 1960's. Two of the servers actually got in a huge argument by our table. One of the waitresses actually spilled a drink on someone at my table. And it took forever to get our orders taken, so thank god the drinks were as strong as they were. Otherwise I'd unfortunately be sober in this delightfully tacky establishment.
author: Monica C.

description: We had heard so much about this place and wish we had read the reviews more for thought the place was terrible.  We liked the decor and some of the food items were good but it ended there.  Service is terrible, place loud, and servers very unfriendly.  We won't be trying this place again and asking our friends what were they thinking?
author: John F.

description:
TIKI ROOM- UNPLUGGED!

In the Tonga Tonga Tonga Tonga Tonga  room.
In the Tonga Tonga Tonga Tonga Tonga room.
You can have all the appetizers you can consume!
In the Tonga Tonga Tonga Tonga Tonga room.

OK, so there are no singing birds or flowers. But there is rain with thunder every 20 minutes and the decor of this funny yet lovely room dates from the 40s when people were too busy saving the free world to make fake singing animals. (And while I'm a great fake animal lover, I find the Rainforest Cafe too fake!)

When I first ate here years ago it seemed cute yet funky. This time, it was charming and elegant, and as close to eating in a quiet version of Disneyland Tiki room as you'll find (it's quiet before 8, when the band arrives, and the band is fun).

The service was EXCELLENT, our waiter was there when we wanted, invisible when we didn't. No hovering, but also no waiting.

The food is thoroughly Americanized Chinese (with a touch of Hawaii), and it's very fresh, well made and tasty. Don't expect anything gourmet, like Tommy Toy's, or authentic and spicy (like Chinatown), but do expect that everyone you bring here can find something to eat and enjoy. My favorite was the Huli Huli chicken, which is in a sweet pinapple sauce, and the Mongolian beef which was not really mongolian, but very tender steak.

The portions ARE large enough to share. We had three diners and we each ordered and entree, and there was enough to take home for a dinner for two the next night.

Entrees start at $23, which is high, but you're paying for the experience and if you like this kind of thing, it's well worth it.

Weekdays from 5-7 you can get the all-you-can-eat appetizer buffet for $9.50 (plus one drink, which'll set you back at least $6.50).

This isn't an everyday place--but it is fun, and unique, as there are very few original tiki restaurants around anymore.

The big drawback for this area is parking. Street parking requires a miracle (my wife will soon be sainted for twice finding a spot). Parking in the Fairmont costs around $18 per hour, which is highway robbery sans highway. They do NOT validate.

Depending on the day and time, you can park for a flat rate of as little as $15 at the Brockelbank Garage at 1040 Sacramento--literally right next door to the Fairmont. I was there before 6 on Sunday and it was $15. At 6pm it promptly went up to $20. You've been warned.

So, know what you're getting into and ENJOY IT, it's fun, like a wonderful WWII time warp.
author: Daniel W.

description: While I am glad that I got to experience it, now that I have I won't go back. The service was great, but it is just too overpriced. The pupu platter is just an appetizer sampler, and it is almost 30.00 for a few ribs and wings. A complete rip off. Besides that, the drinks are strong and pretty fun, so that makes up for that. I didn't see the rain, but tried to get charged for the horrible band playing. My recommendation is to make a reservation and just have drinks , then go somewhere else. Worth one trip.
author: Chris S.

description: I couldn't wait to visit the Tonga Room on our trip to San Francisco. Our first night in town, a Wednesday, we went and there was a line out the door as they were at capacity for a special event. We didn't feel like waiting, so we went back the next day for Happy Hour. The Scorpion Bowl for 2 tasted great, but I was really disappointed at the size. Everywhere else I've been, the Tonga Room's version of a Scorpion Bowl for 2 has been the size for 1. Upon learning about the Happy Hour Buffet, we decided to partake. Strangely, you can't put your name in to wait for a table while you sip a drink at the bar, and you can't have a drink outside the dining room while you wait. Oh well. We sat outside the dining room and waited about 10 minutes and were brought into a table to begin our dinner. For $10, especially in an expensive city, the buffet was a good value. It included fruit, fried rice, 2 kinds of wings, lo mein, and mini eggrolls. You have to purchase at least one drink per person, so I tried the Mai Tai, which was good and strong, and my boyfriend got a ChiChi (Pina Colada), which was also delicious. The atmosphere is the big draw here. Who doesn't want to drink tiki drinks in a place with a pool, floating boat and thunderstorms? I'll most definitely come back next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Krista D.

description:
Ah, yes the infamous Tonga Room.

Their drinks are on the sweet side for my palate, and their food is generally overpriced, but can you really put a price on kitsch? 

I'll miss this place if it goes away, I've spent many a night here listening to crappy music while the mai tais flowed.
author: Makena S.

description:
You need to know what you are getting into before you arrive. This is a Hawaiian themed restaurant that is made to look like you are on the island (complete with faux thunderstorms).

It's a kitschy place to grab a drink. The Mai Tais and Scorpion drinks are very good (and very strong).
author: Adam L.

description:
The Tonga Room is a fun, classy joint but you definitely don't come here for the food. You come for the atmosphere: the indoor hurricane, which happens about twice an hour and consists of rain falling into the indoor pool with bad "storm" sound effects and a strobe light. Do they warn people with epilepsy? Also, the band in a boat. The band is terrible and they play in a boat. Wearing Hawaiian shirts. I kind of loved the band in the boat. I felt like an American Idol judge as I sat there listening to them croon "Change the World."

The happy hour drinks menu is moderately priced and each drink comes topped with one of those mini-umbrellas that instantly make everything more festive. The "Pineapple Royale" (from the regular cocktail menu) is a slushy mixture that comes in a hollowed out pineapple with a gigantic straw. It was so cool to be drinking out of a hollowed out pineapple with a gigantic straw that I didn't really notice how it tasted. The pina colada is pretty good, if a little on the weak side, and there is a drink whose silly name I can't remember that comes in a cool tiki glass. 

The macadamia garlic spread appetizer is very heavy-handed. We needed to scrape most of the spread off our bread because it was ridiculously dense and garlicky. It was like day-old naan with nuts and relish for $12. 

Dinner menu is overpriced pan-Asian food and while I didn't try any of the meat entrees, I can say that the the sole vegetarian entree, "Alena's Mix", is a whole lot of badly marinated tofu with carrots, broccolini, and mushrooms for a whopping $24. I've made better at home. My friend's "Mongolian Beef Tenderloin" was apparently pretty good but the $9.95 happy hour buffet is probably a better deal for most people.

For dessert, we had the volcano, some kind of mousse concoction with a raspberry center that was covered in whip and topped with a chocolate triangle that was served flaming. It was surrounded by chocolate and raspberry syrup on one side and two mysterious powders on the other. We ultimately decided it tasted like ground-up red velvet cake doused with gasoline, but not in a bad way. 

Service is slow but they give you leis! It's hard to be unhappy about the service with colorful fake flowers around your neck, especially if you're kinda drunk.

Six drinks, appetizer, two entrees, and dessert for $160. Nearly three hours of tiki goodness. Worth a visit.
author: Annie C.

description: Great Music, food was ok, I liked that most drinks had 151 in them.
author: Steve D.

description:
When we first started planning our trip to San Francisco, I knew that we had to hit up the Tonga Room, since it's considered to be high on the list of endangered tiki establishments. Unfortunately, the Fairmont folks have gotten the idea in their heads that they can make more money by turning the land where the Tonga Room is into condos. Super lame!

Anyway, the Tonga Room feels more like an attraction at Disneyland than a restaurant: diners are seated in an enormous A-frame with outrigger canoes or beneath thatched huts with a simulated night sky above. Not to mention the "rain storm" that occurs every 20 minutes or so, with thunder sounds and lightning and water falling into the lagoon (er, pool). 

The setting and decor are unquestionably awesome, but the food is widely considered to be bad. Most folks advise to go during happy hour, but we weren't able to be so choosy with our time of visit so we took our chances with dinner and I actually was pleasantly surprised. I wasn't all that hungry, so I got the mussels with Portuguese sausage, Maui onions and shoestring potatoes. The broth was made with Kona Longboard lager and it was so savory that I had to sop it up with the bread. I also nabbed the miso eggplant from my boy's plate of flatiron steak, which was doused in a sort of sweet sauce that we enjoyed but not might be to everyone's tastes. 

It will be such a shame if the hotel's plans come to fruition because the Tonga Room is just on another level, definitely one of the best tiki bars in the country. In fact, it's so awesome that I saved it for my 100th review!
author: Becky S.

description: The drinks definitely don't mess around. Really good, and strong. Good idea to go at happy hour for a price break. Fun place to go before dinner.
author: Alexis D.

description: The atmosphere is the only real draw for this eatery nestled inside the fabled Fairmont Hotel. Though the food isn't bad, the presentation and service is much better. We had the peppered prawns, which were no more than 4  blandly seasoned shrimps on wooden skewers. Prawns they were not! The drinks are pretty good, albeit on the pricey side, and the entertainment was like listening to Don Ho taking a crack at 70's hits. All in all not a bad experience for a one shot deal.
author: Vern R.

description: Such a unique and fun place to go! The scene is set here for a Polynesian theme and the food and drinks were great! The lava sundae is delicious and large! Large as in for 6 people at least! Sat by the water and the boat, having the rain storm made it that much more fun. Service was great too!
author: Kim G.

description:
My favorite tacky afterwork spot! Who doesn't love a bar/restaurant with a lake in the middle! It's like the jungle cruise with booze.

Get me a fruity drink with an umbrella in it, turn on the "rain" and the cheese-tastic lounge singers and bring out the happy hour dim sum buffett and i'm SET!
author: Nikki M.

description:
The much-lauded happy hour at the Tonga Room...  I'd heard so much about this happy hour and was excited when I had the opportunity to try it on a Tuesday night.

My friend and I arrived at the Tonga Room at 6:35 p.m.; we were told that the food would be cleared promptly at 7 p.m. (when happy hour ends), so we would have to eat fast! We decided to go with the $9.95 happy hour buffet since we probably weren't going to have a chance to eat dinner otherwise. 

I was pretty disappointed in the food selection - almost all of the food was greasy and fried. There was a selection of fried egg rolls, fried won tons, vegetarian chow mein, kalaua pork, cheeses and fruit. I had the egg roll which was fine (mostly just tasted like fried-ness) and vegetarian chow mein (which mostly just tasted like grease). I ate a bit, but it probably wasn't worth our $9.95. The happy hour drink specials (which run the gamut from mai tais to tropical takes on margaritas) were $7.50 ($1.50 off the normal $9 price). If you're in the neighborhood around happy hour and need something to eat, it's not a terrible option (since there isn't much in the immediate vicinity), but definitely not a destination (not even for the fake rain - the fake rain reminds me of when they water the vegetables at Safeway).
author: Wendy L.

description:
Five stars for the attentive servers!  

This place is kitschy and fun!  The Tonga Room is hidden in the basement of the Fairmont Hotel.  I was told that the happy hour fills up fast, so my boyfriend and I got there super early.  Maybe we weren't there on the right night, but there definitely wasn't a crowd.  In fact, we were the first ones there; however,  it did start to fill up after we were seated.  

I was disappointed in the drinks.  The prices were good (happy hour is awesome!), but each cocktail I ordered was sweeter and weaker than the one before.  :(

The buffet was kind of disappointing, but the lightening, rain and thunder show made up for it all.  What a neat experience!
author: Chelsea B.

description: Very fun and cool place to go.  I'd recommend visiting at least once just to check it out while you're in SF.  Food was actually pretty good but the drinks were a bit too sugary.
author: Alyse S.

description: Below average food that's way overpriced.  Painfully slow service.  Pina colada was meh at best.  Ambience is different, but we won't be coming back here again.  Waste of time and money.
author: Tracy H.

description:
6 of us bought the Facebook Deal ($31 for a $61 3-course meal, drink, and dessert pre-selected menu). We made our reservation for Sunday (today) at 6pm. The Tonga Room called 2 days prior to confirm the reservation and let us know that if we would like to stay for the live band that starts playing at 8pm which we did not end up staying for. 

There was no hostess to greet us when we arrived. After waiting for several minutes the manager came to greet us and walked us to our table. The staff was very nice and accommodating and the decor was whimsical and created a fun atmosphere to enjoy with a group. We were seated along one side of the pool/ lagoon which was fun. When the thunder and "rain" storm would start it was a little difficult to hear our conversations, but the rain only lasts about 30 seconds each time and the intervals were pretty far apart so it was still a fun touch.

The food. Ugh! I wish I could say better things, but it was basically mediocre Chinese food, at best. They served us appetizers which were a few rib pieces and 4 pieces of tempura veggies.They only brought out 2 plates even though there were six of us and they should have brought 3 for the money. Also, the Mai Thai was much better than the Pina Colada. 

The "Mongolian beef" wannabe was not the tiniest bit spicy as you might expect. Everything was edible, but nothing special. And when our bill came we were charged for tax and tip, which ended up being $91 a  couple (including the $31 x 2 people deal and tax & tip). So, the tax and tip was basically half of the bill because it was charged on the full amount before the discount was subtracted. We talked to management but they said that's the way the deal is set up. 

I would have preferred to go almost anywhere else for dinner for a fraction of the price. The themed-restaurant experience is not worth the money you pay for poor quality food. 

The best part of our meal was the excellent company and willingness to laugh about the mistake in judgement on this whole dining experience.
author: Aggy A.

description: Went here for my birthday because I heard it's a San Francisco institution and wanted to try one of their Mai Tais. Nothing that we ordered tasted particularly good, including the Mai Tai that they supposedly invented. We were there one of the nights that they had a band playing over the water, which was fun to watch, but with inattentive service and overpriced food, we definitely won't be back.
author: Rebecca S.

description: Although the theme is cute I think a $7 charge per person is ridiculous. The food is mediocre at best. I thought it is impossible to fuck up fried calimari ...I stand corrected the batter fell of the calimari and the aioli tastes like mayo with lemon juice. The singapore noodles were tge biggest joke first of all they are nothing like Singapore noodle and they taste bad they also cost 25 bucks. You can get delicious Singapore noodle in Chinatown for 5. I dont usually care about service but that was bad too.
author: Dan K.

description:
There is a reason why a restaurant/bar would be located on the bottom floor of a large hotel on top of Nob Hill on the decline in the event something shook.

My quick 6 starred checklist:

Atmosphere: cheesy
Food: mediocre and feebled attempt at fusing American/Asian
Crowd: mediocre
Music: sucked 
Men: some cute ones, but not too promising
Drinks: Weird plastic cups resembling little logs 

Would I come here again?

No way.
author: Miika M.

description:
We had reservations last Saturday night. The atmosphere and decor were fun, rather like the Disneyland Tiki Room, but I went in open-minded and just enjoyed the silliness of it all. We started by ordering Hurricanes, which were delicious, but I'm not sure how much rum they had in them -- I barely felt a buzz, and I'm usually pretty sensitive to alcohol. The Pu-Pu platter appetizer was definitely the best food that we had there. The entrees were nothing to write home about. My husband had the "special" that the waiter described. It was basically just stir-fried beef and veggies in a sweet, thick sauce. My entree was from the menu -- Grilled Tri-Tip. It was OK, but on the bland side and not served as piping hot as I would have liked. For dessert, I ordered the sampler and my husband ordered the pineapple cake. They were good, but we were pretty stuffed by then, and I wasn't able to eat all of my dessert. We ordered coffee, and were each given a little pot to refill our cups as needed. That was a nice touch, I thought.

The periodic thunder and rain were fun, the band on the boat was good, and our waiter was friendly - just the right amount of attentive, and very efficient. We had a  pleasant experience, all in all, and hope to come back again sometime with family members for a fun evening. I think next time, though, I'd come for drinks and appetizers and to enjoy the ambiance and the music, but maybe pass on the meal. I'd give this place about 3 1/2 stars.
author: Cyndy S.

description:
Positives: Fun enviornment, decor & vibe. Reminds you pf the priates of the Caribbean ride at disneyland.  Dance floor. Great people watching. Awesome Tiki drinks.

Negatives: Line to get in sucks. $7 cover charge :/
author: Rah F.

description:
This place is okay. I wouldn't spend money and time coming back here because frankly the Asian-fusion food is overpriced and the drinks are only all right. My friends and I had bought an online coupon to come here (for the Kao Island Dinner), but in general, the service was slow, the waiter asked us for a higher tip anyways, and the food was only so-so. Maybe I'm not an Asian-fusion type of girl...

The live band playing was pretty sick though! Plus points for the atmosphere, the rain/lightning effects, and the ambiance.
author: Jasmine G.

description:
Saw this place on few specials on travel channel so I wanted to see why it was so.  Well, it was not that great.  I went here with huge expectation, so that would be fault on my part.  

Just go for happy hour for average cocktails, nothing more, as this was my experience at Tonga room.  Thanks for hyping it up Mr. Bourdain
author: S B.

description:
Get the Mongolian beef, and the seafood hotpot.  You will not regret it.

Everything else is a little too tropical for my taste.... but, try anything once!
author: Kristen S.

description: Love this place! It was my second time going after a party with my girlfriends about a year ago, this time I went with my husband and we had a blast! Food was amazing and service was friendly and fast. I forget the exact name of the food we ordered, but it was good! Live music started at 8:00 , THERE WAS A GUY SINGING IN A MOVING BOAT WHILE IT RAINED INTO A POOL!!! We had a delicious and BIG dessert of 4 different types of ice cream in a bowl with a flame in the center! We danced, listened to music, and relaxed for the next hour before heading back to the main hotel (by the way great hotel). Over all had a great time and will definitely be going back!
author: Vicky O.

description:
I'd heard about the Tonga Room/Hurricane Bar from a friend who recently had seen it featured on Tony Bourdain's Layover show. So, being in San Francisco last Sunday night, and me and my four friends needing something to do after our business dinner, we hiked up the hill to the Fairmont to have a drink. 

Talk about tiki-kitschy! From the huge tiki that greets you to the thatched huts, the room has all the 70s Trader Vic's flavor you would expect. The bar was pretty empty at 1030 on a Sunday night but the band was rocking. (The band, by the way, plays in a little hut in the middle of the pool that is located in the center of the room).

We drank fruity drinks out of tiki mugs with paper umbrellas (except for one friend who had a beer, but we outfitted him with a paper umbrella as well). Drinks aren't cheap, but this is San Francisco. 

The highlight of the evening was when the lightning and rain started over the pool and the band finished its last song as their hut receded out of sight.

bordering on tacky, the Hurricane Bar was a great stop to enjoy a drink with friends.
author: Barb H.

description:
A must experience for anyone who is a fan of kitchy fun.

Say what you want about it being a tourist trap / magnet. whatever, it's true, but who cares?! I'm not sure that I would eat here, but sharing one of their scorpion bowls ( tons of liqour. tons of sugar. tons of tiny umbrellas. 4-5 straws. whoever sucks the hardest wins!) with a few friends while enjoying the hawaii shirt clad cover band was a fantabulous way to spend the evening! I don't want to give too much away, but think disneyland, with booze! I think I must have lived in differeret era, because dinner / drinks and show is my idea of good time. come on, give it a try. at least once. I promise it will be fun.
author: Caddy M.

description:
I bought a deal from HomeRun.com a while back because A and I had been talking about how we wanted to go to the Tonga Room.  How could we both have been born and raised in San Francisco and never been to the Tonga Room?  And then, lo and behold, they have a 50% off deal on HomeRun.com!  How could we pass that up?

Anyway, we both kind of forgot about it until I realized a couple of weeks ago that it was going to expire soon.  We still put it off until this past week and I just went ahead and made reservations for Saturday night at 6pm.

We arrived right on time, were greeted, and seated at a table right by the water/pool.  A's first impression when we walked in the restaurant - "This is like Disneyland!"  Seriously, it is.  It reminds me of the Blue Bayou Restaurant in the Pirates of the Caribbean ride, except without people riding by in boats watching you eat.

We really liked the whole decor.  The dark wood, the boats, the lights, the thunderstorms...it's all very kitschy, but super fun.  The service was a bit slow though.  Our waiter was awesome - very friendly and extremely helpful, but it seemed like he had to handle every table on that side of the restaurant.  That might account for why the service was a bit slow.  I actually thought they might charge us the cover charge for the band because we were there after the band started, although, seriously, the whole time the band was playing, we had already been done eating and were waiting for the waiter to bring us the bill.  And no, they did not charge us the cover charge.  We were only there about 15-20 minutes while the band was playing.

As for the band, they're pretty cool.  They play on a boat in the middle of the water/pool.  I think the singer was smiling at A.  

I thought it was interesting that everyone that worked on the floor of the restaurant were Asian or Pacific Islander.  The Fairmont really wants to keep the authenticity of the restaurant intact.

As for the food, our deal entitled us to the Kao Island Dinner for 2 - originally $90, but we got it for $45.  The food was good, but I'm not sure I'd pay $90 for it.

Appetizer:  Shared, 2 of each.  Egg rolls, pork ribs, vegetable tempura.  This also came with a special sauce, which was really yummy.  The appetizers were good, but nothing special.

Entree:  We picked the Mongolian Beef (other choices were Firecracker Prawns and Huli Huli Chicken) and it came with string beans and rice.  We also asked for their chili sauce, which A says was super yum.  The entrees were really good and they give big portions.  We took the leftovers home so I could eat it for lunch today.

Dessert:  Banana Mousse.  This was pretty good.  Banana mouse with a giant banana chip sticking out of it.  The plate also had some crumbled nuts of some sort and a peanut butter tasting sauce.  When you eat it all together, it's really good.

Drinks:  We both ordered some non-alcoholic drinks.  I forget what A ordered, but I got the Fruit Loopy.  It was fruity and loopy!  

All in all, a very fun (yet kitschy) experience with yummy (but not outstanding) food, and good service (although a bit slow).
author: Kris L.

description:
Yay! I'm a fan!

Same as many people, the four stars are based completely on how much fun I had here. In all honesty, food is mediocre, almost unacceptable (especially for a restaurant that is in a hotel), but that's not the point. The point is that this place is hella fun, has a great vibe, is casual and cute, and you will have a good time!! Yes, it's touristy. But who cares? Stop being such a snob! Just be a darn tourist and have fun, people!

Cover band (comes on at 8 PM) is great, and their music is mellow enough to not overpower your dinner conversation but still demands your attention because it's so good.. And a singing drummer? Wooowww... that's mad talent right there.

The place is super fun, has a great vibe, so forget how mediocre the food is and enjoy the atmosphere! And when you're finished with your meal, go on upstairs to the hotel lobby and check out Fairmont's life-size gingerbread house, gorgeous (and gigantic) Christmas tree, and beautiful holiday lights and decorations (of course, this is for the holiday season only). 

This place is so dang fun! Be a tourist and enjoy yourselves, people!
author: Bonnie L.

description: Very cool old school tiki lounge. Yes, it is very touristy. But, I think it's still a fun place to enjoy tiki drinks with your friends and listen to a live cover band play on a raft on the old pool of the amazing Fairmont Hotel
author: David D.

description: This is an upscale and UNIQUE spot. The Pacific Island atmosphere and ambiance is really cool. The band that plays on the floating "tiki house" is well above par.
author: Chad S.

description:
Being an SF local, I was excited when I got the chance to check out the "famous" Tonga Room with a dinner deal from HomeRun (one of those groupon sites)...welp, I'll definitely never be back here.

The food was average to bad, the "strong" scorpion bowl was essentially watered down fruit punch, and the band reminded me of the bar mitzvah I just attended last week. But the worst part by far was the service. When I presented my coupon, the waiter snapped at me and my date and started yelling at us about how we should be paying more, and shouldn't be getting away with a discount...the original bill came out to $150!!!! for 2 people (for some dry chicken, rice and green beans). 

Terrible food, terrible service, outrageously overpriced, and the band should've paid me a $7 cover to put up with them...skip this place.
author: alan R.

description: We wandered in here after a friend suggested we meet her at the hurricane bar, and boy was it a sight to see! Tonga Room and Hurricane Bar take "kitchy" to a whole new level! Aside from the 25 minute wait to enter, we had fun. I am sure you've already heard about the band who plays on a boat in the pool, and the rain storms, and the pirate ship dance floor...we were lucky enough to get a table for two and surprisingly quick service. We ordered the punch bowl for two. It was really fun and refreshing to drink. My hubby ordered some vegetarian spring rolls and noodles for appetizers. I tried them both and was pleasantly surprised. The reason I say I was, "pleasantly surprised," is because often times when the ambiance, performances and bells and whistles are what the bar/restaurant is known for the food isn't very good. We thoroughly enjoyed our apps, however. Aside from the drinks and food, the music was all very catchy. Oldies but goodies greatest hits kind of songs. I kept thinking if my dad were here he'd be dancing the night away! Although Tonga room is definitely touristy, and as a result a bit overpriced, it is a sight to see if you've never been before.
author: Kelsey K.

description:
It's extremely kitchsy and looks like something off the set of the Love Boat, but there is definitely no place like the Tonga Room in San Francisco and there is probably no equivalent anywhere in the States. This is now my default spot to take out of town visitors. 

The other reviews are correct. Yes, the band is very cheesy and plays Ricky Martin covers from a floating platform in the middle of a lagoon. Yes, it "rains" and "storms" every 20 minutes. Yes, you can dance with your grand-parents on a pirate ship dance floor. And yes, there is an endless supply of strong and tropical cocktails to enhance the experience.

The only downside is the "entertainment cover" and the high-prices for food and drink.
author: Dave S.

description:
A few weeks ago my girlfriends and I went here for one of my friend's bachelorette party. Now, I'm an absolute sucker for anything tropical, so this place definitely rocked my socks off. Upon walking in, you feel like u are boarding a pirate ship in a very tropical place. Each little table area is covered by a straw canopy, so you feel like you are in an island bungalo, and then in the middle of the restaurant there is a little pond-pool thing.

We had reservations so we were seated right away, right by the water. After looking at the menu, the food was a bit expensive so I decided to go with a kids meal--chow mein with a spare rib, for $12 (compared with the $27 adult meal). The menu did look quite delicious though. Us girls also decided to get the four-person lava bowl, with fruit juices and rum. This drink didn't taste really good, but the concept was awesome. It's a big bowl that they put in the middle of the table, and then you are given these extremely long straws so everyone sitting at the table can enjoy the drink. Very fun concept!

The food arrived and it was quite delicious, and I would say the perfect portion size as well. I finished mine (and no, it wasn't because I got the kids plate-it was the same size as an adult plate), and I was perfectly satisfied... not too full but not hungry by any means.

While we were eating our meal, a live band started to play, and this is where it gets really cool.
