The band was standing in a little tiki hut-type thing, and then it separated from the side of the pond and floated to the middle of the pond, becoming a boat. How freaking awesome is that?!?! The band was pretty good too, they played good music and were a lot of fun. Plus they also gave a shout out to the bride-to-be, which is always fun. 

I would say that if you are willing to drop some money, and really like island-themed places, this is the place to go. Definitely would be fun on a date or with a group of people. Ya'll better hurry up and get your butts there though, I hear that they are closing down soon. I sure know I'm going to try going again soon!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Great ambiance and atmosphere! Plus the food is good. Their drinks are known to be pretty good as well.  The waiters are usually polite and attentive also.

The live band on the boat and the rain preceding their entrance is a great intro!

Try the Forbidden Rice!  It is a fresh, flavorful and colorful blend of several types of rice that will party in your mouth.
author: Miz M.

description:
I heard about this place by word of mouth. I checked this Yelp page for pictures to see if the ambiance was suitable for me and my girlfriend's anniversary. Having just come back from Hawaii a few months ago, it was nice to have that whole "Hawaii" feel again. The random rainstorms here and there were pretty cool. It rains somewhat heavily onto the pool area, so it's not just flashing lights and thunder sounds.

Onto the food:

We started off with a couple drinks. I got the punch, which I expected would be watered down, but it was surprisingly strong. Just the right about to taste the alcohol, but not too much that it was nasty.

My girlfriend ordered the scallops and I got the butterfish. The scallops were a pretty reasonable size (even though there was only 4). The butterfish was fully of flavor and the crab on top was delicious. Unfortunately, like many high-end restaurants, the portions were ridiculously small. Good thing we ate a few hours before our dinner at the Tonga Room.

For dessert, we got the banana mousse with peanut butter...so good! I'm a sucker for peanut butter and the combination of banana and peanut butter was perfection.

Overall, we had a pretty fun experience. Our timing sucked though because as we were paying our bill, the band was just setting up, so we didn't get to hear any music during our dinner. A pretty good restaurant, definitely no regrets. Where they lack in portion, they make up for it in flavor. This place was a bit pricey, so I wouldn't eat there for a casual dinner. For our anniversary dinner, it was fine, but definitely not cheap. Two drinks, two entrees, and one dessert came out to about $95.
author: Jeff L.

description:
DEFINITELY GO HERE..... once.

The Tonga Room is all about the experience.  The restaurant used to be an indoor pool at the Fairmont until they converted it into a Tiki bar.  This is sure to impress guests at least for the first 15 minutes.   On top of the pool floats a band that plays good dance music.  

The bar is well-equipped, serving a large array of sweet alcoholic beverages.  Some of the combinations are interesting.  

The service is also pretty excellent.  A server tends to come to your table the minute you are waiting for something and this adds to the great experience of being totally immersed in a tropical poolside bar/restaurant.

Where this place falls short?  The food.

Make no mistake.  The menu may SOUND cheap (because it probably should be), but the meals are very expensive.  The Tonga Room offers your traditional American/Asian cuisine with a hint of Hawaiian flavors, but for steakhouse prices.  

For example, I believe the Mongolian beef was around $35-40.  I remember having a seafood hot pot for $27.  It was basically a soy/butter bomb with what tasted like frozen fish.  Almost every dish I have had there seems to be a little overdone on the salt and fat ratio.  This may be pleasing after a few drinks, but it can weigh pretty heavily on you if you've got things to do later that evening...

Also, one thing that isn't mentioned enough is the cover charge for the band.  When I went last time it was $7.00.  

There is also a floating photographer that will charge you Disneyland prices for photos of you.  Watch out for that if you don't want to see him come to your table with photos already made including two sets of match books...  

You would think that the band and photos would be included with the food for how much they charge for simple dishes that are only slightly better than what you could get for $6-12 at any restaurant in China or Japan town...
author: Rocky S.

description:
We had a work Happy Hour here last night, and it was quite enjoyable mostly because of the company kept. 

I satiated my curiosity of the HH Tonga buffet finally and found it to be quite tasty! Most memorable were the chicken dumplings, noodles with vegetables and coconut fried rice. They give you tiny plates, so grab two plates, pile them up and go back for more while you can! I would definitely go back for the buffet, especially since it is so close to my home. 

The drinks were eh...my first Tonga Tart was pretty good (strong but good), but the 2nd round must've been made by a different bartender because it was a bit too tart for my taste. Then, I had a Bora Bora - eh...the first sip tasted too syrup-y banana so I let it "simmer" in the ice. It tasted better with a little time. 

This is the first time back at the Tonga since their renovations -- I sure enjoyed the distraction of the rain, thunder and lightning every hour! Very dramatic and fun! We skid-addled out of there quickly though when were told if we stayed after a certain hour that we'd be charged to listen to the cover band. We passed and swiftly left -- til next time!
author: Maile N.

description:
in summary, loved the ambiance, thought the food was just ok.

loved the live band and the "rainstorms" and the fries!

the ribs and chicken were just ok to me.

would definitely come back to bring some out-of-towners
author: Ray R.

description:
This is the place to go after work on Hawaiin Shirt Fridays!  A real mismatch of a place for the glamorous Fairmont Hotel.  Entering the stunning, jaw-dropping lobby, I descended a few levels to finally enter the Tonga Room.  "Wtf is this?" was my first impression.  Granted the decor is well thought of with fine wood paneling, indoor pond?!?!?, and tall columns.  It's one of those SF places you should visit at least once.  The service staff here is rather impersonable.  The waitresses collected plates as they pleased w/o asking if we were finished.  My tropical drink... I think it was just Tang mixed with a pound of sugar, and perhaps a splash of cheap vodka. Ooh and of course a pineapple slice with a lil brolly stuck through it.  Happy Hour?  Where is the Happy when drinks still cost $7.50?  

If you like kitsch and having a cheesy time, this could be for you.  (Sorry, no karaoke to be found here)  But if you're here for a fun time with the gang... eh, take the cable car down to the Financial District and find a nice dive.
author: Chris T.

description:
After much anticipation for a girls night out, I finally made my way up the hill (literally) and tried it out.  I thought I better call ahead for a reservation, they were booked a day ahead so I nervously figured I'd wing it.  I probably waited 20 minutes at the most on a Saturday evening--not bad!  Tables were full so I was brought over the the bar area, where I was accommodated with a food menu and decent size table.  I was super excited to sample one of the bowl cocktails, which was dangerously delightful and may or may not have turned into more than one (I shared, I swear!).  Well, in terms of the food, it was just okay.  Definitely not worth the stupid prices.  I really don't mind paying more for good flavors and quality but trust me,  I left disappointed.  My friend and I took our leftovers to go and gave it to homeless people.  To top off the experience, a fee was added per person to the bill for the boring, live band playing clear across the restaurant that I payed no attention to.  Lastly, the rainforest cafe has better effects than this place.

If you still really want to come here after this review, so be it-- but don't say I didn't warn you!
author: Britt B.

description: Great happy hour special with $9 beverages and $10 buffet until 7pm. The venue is very cool.
author: Ali C.

description:
Let me just say I'm giving it 4 stars for the amount of fun I have here, not the food or the service! Here's my Tonga Room advice:

1) Don't eat here. It's overpriced and tastes like crap. 
2) Happy hour is great and inexpensive, but you miss out on the bad (good) cover band. 
3) Go with a crowd, and drink wine or beer. The mixed drinks are horrendously bad (and overpriced), but the atmosphere can be really fun if you are willing to take in the kitsch and just have a good time. 

I hate reading reviews about this place where people are shocked at the price and scenery. It isn't a regular weekend place, just a once in a while when you need a laugh thing. The Tonga Room is what it is-a tourist trap with a silly concept. Don't expect anything more than that and you'll have a good time.
author: Marina M.

description: I give it one star only for props for being a themed restaurant, otherwise, I would give it zero if that were an option.  It isn't located in Snob Hill for no reason. We arrived about 30 minutes before the 6pm dinner time for drinks. They had one standing table left, so we took it. Waited 15 minutes, no service. Not even an acknowledgment that we were there. Went up to the bartender to let them know, and he said he'd send someone over. Waited 15 more minutes and left. Worst customer service I've ever had. This place is way overrated.
author: Riana F.

description:
The Tonga Room is a restaurant you would never expect to be in one of the nicest hotels in SF. Not because the restaurant itself isn't nice but because it just feels out of place. The Tonga Room is something you would imagine coming out of Disney Land or some other whimsical amusement park. 

There's literally a lagoon in the middle of the restaurant (apparently it was the old Fairmont pool) and it looks like something out of Gilligan's Island. A ship comes out every 20 minutes or so with a live show on board. When I went it was a woman singing but I'm not sure if they change that up. My friend and I thoroughly enjoyed ourselves and had quite a few laughs. 

The food was good but nothing special. Because it's in the Fairmont the prices are way too high for what you get. However, if you're looking for a unique experience and just want a little fun over dinner, you can't go wrong here.
author: Julia N.

description: it's really cheesy, but I LOVE this place! It's so much fun, older crowd which is nice, more "tamed", music is good and the pool, the boat and the rain, it's quite a scene. I can't wait to go back!!! I think I might even celebrate my birthday there! =) [i'm a local]
author: Tiff W.

description:
I USUALLY RAVE ABOUT THE TONGA ROOM! I mean it is quite the San Francisco institution- but instead of just cocktails- I decided to have dinner here one night with a Bloomspot coupon. First off I had an 8:30pm reservation. We show up and have to wait about 30 minutes for a table. Then we order and the server was quite rude- I think he was pissed because we had that Bloomspot deal and we were not ordering the $14 drinks as quick as he would have liked. 

So I understand a cover charge on the entertainment when having drinks but when you have dinner... a $7 per person cover charge for entertainment on the bill. I KNOW THIS IS A TOURIST PLACE- but seriously? They should waive that for people eating dinner in the dining room. I really like the Tonga Room but feel like they are just nickel and diming me when I am there. I am a local and they should have no cover charge for locals- you know like the Vegas clubs do for locals. I was upset with the service and then the additional fees- even when you eat a full meal in the dining room. 

If I ever go back- I just know now- have a couple drinks & pay the cover- the food isn't that good and overpriced.
author: Kimberly M.

description:
For those who love the kitsch of tiki bars, the Tonga Room is a must visit.  Big fruity drinks, the 60's South Pacific theme, and thunder and rainfall every 30 minutes make this place a unique San Francisco treat.  

Went here with a couple of friends after a long day in the city... only had the drinks (no food this time).  Huge drinks with big pineapple decorations (in fact, my drink was served in a hollowed out pineapple!)... lots of rum and other delicious juices and liquors.  Service was extremely friendly and it was cool to overhear the waitstaff who have been there for 10+ years.  

Our initial reason for visiting was because we heard it was going to be torn down so The Fairmont can re-build their hotel.  But then we overheard from a waiter that this won't happen for another 2-3 years, and there has been so much talk from the local community, it may not even close down after all.

So give this place a shot in case they do get rid of it... fun times!
author: Angie M.

description: The cheesey worn atmosphere was fun. I really enjoyed the tack. The service was decent enough but the food was mediocre and pricey. I had seafood hot pot. It was a joke for the price. The sauce tasted like bile.
author: james b.

description:
Tonga...you are the BEST!  This place is like the Regal Beagle, mixed with Gilligan's island, and then smoked out with the cast from that 70's Show.

I feel like Janis Joplin, & I want to invite all of you to the Tonga Room with me for a drink!
author: Laura G.

description: After seeing the Anthony Bourdain recommendation I had to check this spot out. It is a trip to walk into the luxurious Fairmont Hotel and then turn down a hallway into a Peter Pan Neverneverland movie set with sailing ship, indoor lagoon, rain and waterfalls, and fantasy island vibe. But really, 5 minutes was about plenty for me. It was a little more corny than campy, the drinks were sooooo sugary and not so much boozy, and the appetizers were greasy and pretty mediocre. On a saturday night there was a band and dancing to 70's soft rock island classics, if that's your thing. Meh for me, but I can appreciate that others might be more into the experience.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Came here with friends to have a drink and a bite to eat before going dancing. I love the tiki theme going on and though the DJ booth was completely cute (it was on it's own little island). We started off with a round of fruity drinks -- Daquiris, Mai Tais, etc. The drinks were not cloyingly sweet and you could still get a taste of the alcohol. 

We each ordered our own entree but ended up sharing everything family style anyway. We got the Mongolian Beef Tenderloin, Tonga Vegetable Chow Chow, and the Sonoma Duck Breast. As we waited for food, we people watched everyone on the dance floor. I noticed it was definitely an older crowd with a few families speckled in. Who can resist little kids trying to dance to Frank Sinatra?! 

The food came out pretty quickly and we dug in. The Mongolian Beef Tenderloin was the winner in my eyes as it was flavorful and had nice texture with the crispy rice. The Duck Breast wasn't bad either with a hint of mango. The Chow Chow was a bit mushy, but tasted great with the meats.

It was a fun experience, but I probably wouldn't come back unless someone else insisted. Maybe when I pop out a kid who can cut a rug too.
author: Vinh N.

description: An experience! Lots of fun however it is a bit loud when the band is playing!! Great food and excellent service!l. Love the experience!! Great place for a Mai tai and a good time.... Just don't try to carry on intimate conversation when the band is playing! Love it!!!
author: Christian P.

description: A little corny.  Felt like Disney!  Food was good (not great) and it was way over priced!
author: Jason A.

description:
Don't go on band night unless you want an extra cover fee charge of $7 a person. 

This place has wonderful ambiance, and is, by far, one of my favorite places for tiki food. It's a second to Trader Vic's. :D

It is also the oldest tiki bar in SF, which i pretty damn awesome. However, Lou Wolf is shutting it down. Major downer.

I highly suggest going here, for these reasons alone. On top of that, the food is well prepared, the tiki drinks are amazing, and most of the service is great. We happened to have an incompetent server recently, but I won't hold that against the Tonga.

Like I said, just beware the band nights. Extra $7 charge for band cover. And it's not that great of a band.
author: Katie O.

description: The service is great and the drinks are very fresh, i'm only reviewing the bar because I did not eat there, only caribbean and Hawaiian style drinks, I had a very good Daquiri and Pina Colada, they are served up or on the rocks which I like
author: Hector R.

description: Wow! What a disorganized place! I live in the neighborhood and wanted to check this place out for future visits and let me tell you that I will never go back nor take anyone here. We sat in the bar area at an open table with the permission of the hostess only to be yelled at by the cocktail waitress "Tina" for sitting at a dirty table, she then asked us in a very accusatory tone "was it a man or woman who let you sit here??!! You are not suppose to sit here!!!!" we didn't know what to say. There must be issues between the hostesses and servers because we got the brunt of it!! We ordered two zombies but only got one, thank god for this because I almost died and became a zombie from drinking this disgusting concoction!!  If you are planning to go there wear a bullet proof, ear plugs and a bottle pepto-bismol!!!!
author: K R.

description: Super expensive for what you get. Great ambiance, and dancing. Food quality is not up to par for what you get. They make you pay $5 cover charge per person, EVEN IF YOU HAVE DINNER THERE. Yikes.
author: Tina I.

description: Fun, entertaining, creative drinks. Kind of like Pirates of the Caribbean meets Tiki room meets Red Robin. Service was great. we did not eat any food so can only rank the drinks, service, and atmosphere. Dark and festive equaled fun. many more places to go in SF that were better but its OK to start the night off with a strong drink.
author: Graham Y.

description:
I was quite surprised to be disappointed. I had heard of the Tonga room at the beautiful Fairmont Hotel. The atmosphere was fun and they make an excellent Manhattan. 

If I went just to have a drink, I would have rated the place higher. You cannot just go into the bar. You have to wait until there is space. There was a huge line, maybe 100 people and there were 40 table available at 8pm on a Saturday night. 

The service was rushed and the Chinese style food was just average. I've had better in American Canyon. There are far better places to spend your evening in San Francisco.
author: Michael S.

description: Rum drinks with umbrellas and island music, what more could you want?
author: Steve R.

description:
Please, for the dear love of God, do not eat here. I don't know you, but I want to stop you. Seriously. This is the worst restaurant I have ever eaten at. The food is appallingly bad and the service matches. Do not go. Need details? A summary before the details - fatal allergies ignored 2x, grease, grease and more grease, "would the vegetarians all please sit together" and we were overcharged. Imagine the greasiest, worst, cheapest Chinese you have ever had. It is worse. 

We made a reservation for a party of 18 to celebrate an event. We clearly noted a nut allergy on the contract we were required to sign as well as other dietary restrictions. We even phoned before making the reservations just to be sure they could handle a few vegetarians and a guy with peanut allergies. No problem! 

As the dinner part started, the waiter *repeatedly* asks me to have all the vegetarians sit together. I must have looked puzzled. Otherwise, he tells me, it is going to be difficult for him. Really? I point them out kindly instead. Everyone is already seated. This is an absurd request. Earn the tip we have already contractually agreed to pay you. 

As the first course arrived, it did so with chicken wings covered in satay sauce, ribs and vegetarian spring rolls all on the same plate. No mention was made of the peanuts. The company CEO, the allergic one, leaves the table - the overwhelming smell alone is enough to affect his breathing. I remind the waiter that our contract called for no peanuts. He looks confused. I point to the wings. "Satay sauce," he says. Yes, I say, made with peanuts. "Oh. Did he eat it?" he says while looking at the empty chair. No, he left until the next course, I reply. He assures me that they do know about the peanut allergy, and encourages me to have him eat something else off the plate (with peanut stuff on it) instead. Mind you, despite being told about the allergy and saying they knew about it, they served it on the same plate with everything anyway and failed to mention it at all. Wait for the sequel. Nuts will make a glorious return. Meanwhile, the vegetarians puzzled that you'd serve vegetarian appetizers on the same plate next to the pile of ribs to the right of the peanut wings. 

The food. I have written 3 books, but don't know where to start. It was just greasy in a gross way. You could literally see the grease pooled in the veggies and the plain white rice was plain and white and rice. The chicken, beef and shrimp dishes were likewise greasy and absolutely horrible. This is insane and true - we paid a $1500 bill for this group which included a $200 discount from the manager and then went to a local diner to get something to eat. Honestly, the food is that bad. The salads which were served to the vegetarians contained tofu which was deep fried and tasted of chicken. After the taste nearly made one vegetarian barf, the manager assured us they were fried in a fryer separate from the meat. I ate one myself, and let me tell you, it actually did taste "just like chicken."

Lest you think this group is composed of only salad-slugging vegetarians and a guy for whom peanuts are kryptonite, let me assure you that is not the case. Thank God they had alcohol or the whole thing would have been a flop. 

Dessert arrives - a meringue made with YES YES nuts! Nuts in the meringue, on the plate and, for presentation, a swath of macadamia nut butter across the plate. The CEO dies (he didn't, but that would have been a very dramatic conclusion to this tragic, true tale). Instead, he just leaves again. The manager is summoned, and I tell him how horrible this has all been. It's the second time we have talked that night, and I am being discrete - I don't want everyone to know - but  he, too, is surprised to hear their dessert has nuts in it. "That part?" he said, pointing to the meringue stuff. "There are nuts in there?" I mean, come the hell on. We were fortunately warned by an employee. The vegetarians who refused the egg meringue were not offered alternate desserts. The CEO was, but by this point, we had already decided to go elsewhere to eat.  The manager wondered if he could get a drink or something for us. I told him he would be discounting the meal. That is all we wanted. 

It was just horrible, embarrassingly so. Really. This was supposed to be a great celebration for a product we just shipped. Instead, it was greasy garbage with terrible service, and the CEO missed two of the meal's 4 courses. 

Just writing this has convinced me to call to talk with the hotel where this thing is based and demand a refund of the food and gratuity portion of the meal. Doing so, I realized we were charged for 19 meals for 18 people. I spoke with an assistant manager at the hotel who was wonderful and courteous. I hope for a return call.
author: Brenda G.

description:
Those look like pirate ships!!!  Need I say more?

Ok, fine.

Tonga Room's pretty nifty if you need a place to escape the bustle of the city.  Prices are a tad more than what your average joe would go for, which explains the yuppy-ish and older crowd.  This makes it a perfect spot to sneak away for private conversation and banter while the hustle and bustle of the city gets shut out.  The entertainment's ok, but nothing that really makes you go wow.  Honestly, I think they should install some cannons to fire off some smoke to liven up the place!
author: Sam W.

description: Unfortunately, the Tonga Room's novel ethos is all it has going for it. The food was slightly below average, and frankly, I was not expecting much. Two people cost $125 for the night, so plan to spend a pretty penny. In hindsight, it's a great place to go for happy hour or only for drinks, but not a very good place for people who can discern the difference in taste between pork and marinated cardboard. That said, service was very good, and as mentioned, great atmosphere. Parking is also difficult.
author: Cami J.

description:
3.5 stars...

The historic Tonga room is located on the ground flood of the prestigious Fairmont Hotel. Luckily you don't need to be a guest of the hotel to go in, enjoy it's lavish and gorgeous lobby and make your way down to the Tonga room. Keep in mind the Tonga room isn't open on Monday and Tuesday and opens at 5pm (restaurant at 6pm). The Fairmont hotel was built in 1907 while the Tonga room opened in 1945, just about 10 years after the countries first tiki bar, Don the Beachcomber, opened in Hollywood. It is more of a restaurant than a bar but cocktails do take center stage for most people here, besides the decor anyway. The room is absolutely transformed to a tropical paradise, nothing cheesy and plastic but more classy and wooden with lots of Polynesian touches. The center of the room is a huge pool and every 1/2 an hour it rains over the pool accented with sounds of thunder and flashes of lighting, it's very cool. I knew the prices here would be too high and that the food would be too average so I did what everyone who wants to check out the place should do. I went when they first opened (if you go the first couple hours all drinks are a few dollars off-$8ish instead of $12), and just stuck to drinks. I got their famous Mai Tai and a Tonga Itch. Unlike what I've read elsewhere, the drinks were not served in a carved out pineapple or coconut but they did include the obligatory slice of pineapple and little umbrella. They were good, not overly sugary or too weak or too strong, both were a tad on the sour side though, nothing amazing but nothing horrible either. I was just glad that I got to see the inside of the Fairmont and to check out the decor in one of the countries most historic, beautiful, and well known tiki bars.
author: Matt E.

description:
You have to go here at least once in your life! It is amazing inside!

Weekends there is a cover from 8PM so be aware! $7 per person. As we arrived at 7:30PM and had evening plans we only stayed for one drink, it was delicious though! Singapore Sling & Passion fruit Pina Colada are both highly recommended.

It is a little on the pricy side with cocktails running between $12 and $16 but worth it for the atmosphere

The band enters on a small boat on an interior lake to thunder and rainfall... it is pretty cool!!

I look forward to sampling the week night happy hour, and some food.

Visit soon!!! so the rumors go it will be gone soon :(
author: Chris M.

description: The food is good but the bar is better. I had so much to drink that I don't remember my drink,  but I do remember that it was in a pineapple. This only happened twice. % )
author: E G.

description:
Ok, I'm giving this place a 5 star rating because, YES i am a huge Tiki fanatic, but also because this place has stayed untouched, and the decor is just stunning.

Sadly, I keep hearing how the Tonga is about to get torn down.

The drinks were good and packed a serious punch.. The waitress I had, was a little tough, but I learned she had been serving there for over 34 years. WOW, that means she has seen some serious time there and I give her a kudos for sticking it out.

If you have a means to come visit soon, YOU SHOULD. this place is a landmark and needs to  stay!!
author: Carlos C.

description:
It saddens me that the Tonga Room has been on the brink of closure for quite some time.

What is there not to love? Tasty beverages and an ambiance so kitschy it almost hurts.

Yes, it is expensive. And in today's economy, I suppose that is where the downfall lies. But the food is always delicious (and bountiful), and the cocktails never disappoint. I especially like their pina coladas.

I've been there a couple times now, and the only thing that bummed me out on my recent visit was the fact that they have decided to start charging for the live band. $5 cover charge per person.

The band was fun and all when it was free. They basically only play the top radio hits (which I can't stand), but I never really minded because it was all part of the cheesy touristy experience. And with rum filled cocktail in hand, everything is sunshine and ponies, right?

But to have $20 added to our bill for that? We already spent around $200. Come on Tonga Room, that isn't going to help you in the long run. I think after a certain point, the show should just be included. After all, I have to listen to those tunes everyday at work. I would almost pay them $5 NOT to perform those songs.

Nevertheless, I do encourage you to bring friends from out of town here. It makes for a really fun experience. Frilly umbrella drinks in coconuts. You cannot go wrong.

I would also love to try out their happy hour sometime, if they survive for a bit longer. If not, I'll always have Smuggler's Cove and Tradr Sam's.
author: Katie S.

description:
This place is one-of-a-kind.... a Cinderella's castle of tiki splendor all doctored up in the basement of a nonchalant hotel. Go before they desecrate its badass historical self.

Facts:
- It's just a must-do. Great place to start the night or to bring friends from out of town.
- It may be closed certain nights of the week. Check hours before you walk up that huge hill.
- Sometimes they charge a cover for entertainment, around $5. This depends on the day. If you are with people who are anti-cover at all costs, either prep them (with rumors about the polynesian ukulele band which plays on a mobile gazebo raft) or ditch them in advance.
- As with any place I strongly recommend bringing only people who are extremely excited to go. If someone says they hate Disneyland or fun, get rid of them since the magic of this place is best enjoyed by positive groups who are ready for it.
- The Scorpion volcano bowl is freaking strong and a solid way to get a group outing off to a great start.
- Frozen drinks are in the neighborhood of $12, so not immensely cheap, but they are served in large hurricane glasses and will sugar you generously!
- The pirate ship-deck themed dance floor (with rope ladder edging) is not only impressive, but a magnet for the most interesting hotel guests and aging San Francisco fascinati. Pick a table with a great view so you can properly peep the rhythmic mingling of old interesting people.
- I visited to celebrate my 25th birthday, and left with a Tonga Room themed hurricane glass. I have never been so honored in my life.
author: Megan G.

description:
Starting at 3 stars...
+1 For Awesome Atmosphere. Rainstorms every 30 minutes. Cute live band. All makes you feel like your in a jungle or something. Corny but fun.
-1 For the mediocre food that comes w/ happy hour
+1 For the yummy drinks
-1 For the LINE! if you go for happy hour. GET THERE @ 5!
+1 Just cause its an experience. If you live in the bay or if you are visiting... you gotta do it once :)
author: Anya W.

description: I anticipated good tacky fun when I arrived, and that is what the Tonga room is all about.  The fruity drinks have more adornments than alcohol in them, but are very fun and tasty.  The band plays everything.  But the best part the reason I ventured into the Tonga Room was the storms.  About every half hour, lightening strikes and it rains over the pond/pool.  It's tacky, it's fun, it's a really good time.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Cheesy and cliche....but heck I had fun!  They had a band when I was there that floated out onto the water and there was fake rain.  The drinks were fruity...not always my favorite but I found one that wasn't so sweet (sorry can't remember the name).  Good place to take visitors after a trip to Chinatown.
author: Lily B.

description:
Quick Tip: $5.00 entertainment fee! Cool!

I've heard people talk about this place for happy hour, however, we went to this place WAY after happy hour since my brother was in town from Cleveland for a quick visit and he wanted to check it out.

i saw it on Amazing Race, and wanted to check it out myself. There was a pool in the middle of this restaurant, and upon walking around discovered that this place use to be a swimming pool area for the hotel. It was converted to a restaurant a couple of decades ago.

The drinks were good, but were on the pricey side. We also had to pay a $5 cover charge because of the live band performing. We enjoyed the music they played because they were actually pretty good.

It's lit with tikki torches, but the place is still pretty dark, so people will know you're taking pictures due to your camera flash. They give free nuts to nibble on if you aren't looking for a meal, but careful because you don't know whose hands have been in there haha

It's worth checking out again, maybe during happy hour and grab a few plates of appetizers or so. We'll have to see...
author: J D.

description:
On a recent visit to SF me and the old lady went there for happy hour. Yeah, it's cheesy and touristy, but it was a good time none the less. Make sure you get there early, it fills up FAST. The drinks were big and awesome, they have a buffet too. I didn't eat, I decided to drink my dinner.
  
  There are periodic "rain storms" in the place with fake thunder & lightning to make your experience complete. The staff there are good, plus they offer expert advice, like not sharing a Scorpion Bowl with my wife and instead just get 2 Mai Thais "because there's more alcohol that way". How can you go wrong with advice like that????
author: Dan H.

description:
I just heard that the Tonga Room may be closing? Please say it isn't so!

Despite its ticky-tackiness, it is fun. As Miss Flor D. says - There is nothing like the Tonga Room when it comes to themed bars. The Tonga Room has a definite uniqueness all its own.

Where else can you experience a storm, complete with rain and thunder indoors?

Love the live band that comes out in a boat in the middle of the pool.

Restaurant patrons dress up in luau wear and wear fake leis - what else could be tackier? 

Food was decent and drinks are pricey, but definitely on the fun side. I saw two couples down a huge tropical drink complete with multiple umbrellas and fruit garnish. 

Please don't close, Tonga Room!
author: Mercy B.

description: Great place to hang out as long as you get a good waiter covering your table.  I was a little annoyed towards the end trying to get the check last time.  Management needs to train the staff better ~ it's inside a 4 star hotel, I expect better service.
author: Ronald W.

description: We had a great time !  Our server David really took great care of us from helping is order a wonderful meal to getting me champagne for my birthday :-)
author: Julie W.

description:
This one is for you, Obama.

Happy Hour:
For $9.50 you can get the buffet with happy hour.  The buffet is a deal, but you get what you pay for (read: the buffet food is crappy).  The mixed drinks, expectantly pricey, were unexpectedly stiff.  This is great if you're a lush, but not so great if you're expecting a tropical cocktail that tastes virgin.  Overall, I'm glad that I tried out the happy hour, and was pleased that it was a more positive experience than dinner.  

Dinner:
You would think that dinner at a 4 star SF hotel would be good, if not great, right?  Well, I thought that, and I thought wrong.  For the dinner menu at the Tonga Room, think bad Chinese food at extremely inflated prices.  I ordered the chicken curry, and paid $30 for it.  It tasted like something that could come with at $4.99 combo at a cheap, take-out only Chinese place.  At least at a normal Chinese take-out place you'd get the soup of the day and an eggroll with your meal.  

Overall, the Tonga Room provides very unsophisticated food and drink at a very high price.  Although I can concede that the place is somewhat charming in decor, I was happy to hear that the Tonga Room is going to close.  Hopefully whatever replaces it will be better.
author: Sandy K.

description: This place is not what it was hyped up to be. The food was nothing special but the drinks were very tasty. Our server decided to give himself an extra generous tip, more than what I signed on the bill. NOT acceptable. Be aware...check your bills/bank statements!!! Tonga Room is a RIP OFF!!!!!!
author: Christina I.

description: Underwhelmed by the overpriced food at the Tonga Room. The space is very unique and worth checking out, but would likely only come back for drinks the next time around.
author: T C.

description:
I suggest getting drunk before you come here because the drinks are way overpriced and service is not great

people watching is the best

the band played HOTEL CALIFORNIA

the end
author: Alison C.

description: This place gets 4 stars just for the ambiance. Don't get me wrong the drinks are really tasty, but you can't beat the underground bar/pool situation. I had no idea it was in such a swanky hotel either! Would love to go back with a little more cash and spend some quality drinking and dining time here.
author: Madison O.

description:
My best friend and I were wanting to try this place for awhile. We finally did about two weeks ago. We didn't have time to make reservations and took a chance anyways. The restaurant is located in a really nice hotel. The hotel is located about 4 to 5 blocks away from Bart- if that's the form of transportation you'd like to take. If you are wearing heels, take a cab from Bart. If you aren't and don't mind walking, it's all uphill. 
We didn't wait very long for a table at the lounge area by the bar. The service was slow, but it was to be expected since the place was PACKED. Our waiter was very sweet and informative. I give 5 stars to the food and drinks. I recommend splitting a dish and a bowl of alcohol for two if you don't want a big bill. Even after ordering a dish to split, we still had leftovers that we brought home.
The drinks for two were fancy and festive....strong, too. The bar is separate from the Tonga Room. It's down the hall and theirs a cover charge. Maybe next time when I don't empty my wallet out at dinner...
author: Linnea H.

description: I really really really like this place. I celebrated a friend's birthday here and luckily got there during the happy hour where the drinks are affordable and you by pass the cover charge.  I've tried to come back a few times with friends and visitors but they were closed due to parties. Too bad!
author: Vanessa L.

description: Really touristy. Located inside a hotel so a lot of hotel guests frequent here. The buffet inside is cheap but limited. And the bartender was friendly but not very attentive. Decor is 5 stars, but lacking in all other areas. Good to check out once, or show your friends from out of town. But besides that, eh. Drinks were strong though, and we all know how I love my drinks strong!
author: Nick S.

description: I guess it's because I'm a San Francisco native, but the ambiance and flashiness was not appealing to me. It's a nice gimmick though. Our waiter looked super depressed, he served us but looked miserable throughout. We had an appetizer sampler and the best thing on there was the ribs. And out of the 5 entrees we got at the table, the Rib Eye was the best. Maybe it's because we're Asian and we're use to better Asian food, even Asian fusion, this was not worth the price. And the band played about 5 songs and that was the night. I would say, if you have never been to a place like this, go ahead try it once. But it's not a place you would frequent.
author: Kimberly S.

description: This is a cool venue that is fun, creative, and entertaining.  Once you've entered you feel like you've left San Francisco and time traveled to Fiji.  Make sure to grab a Mai Tai and enjoy the show with live music and colorful dishes.  I can't say it's the best food I've ever had but the feeling of being in San Francisco and yet so far away makes up for all the rest.  I hope it stays around for good.
author: Kevin J.

description:
I think the Tonga Room is funny.  I mean, come on, it's cheesy and is in a hotel.  You have everything from tourists, airline attendants to newbie college coeds coming here to enjoy a good time on a makeshift pirate vessel.

I met my boyfriend's brother and some of his friends here and was filled with that same giddyness I get when I ride the Pirates of the Caribbean ride at Disneyland -- it even SMELLED the same!

The drinks were priced rather high and had very little alcohol in them.  The cover band (that rode in on a fake boat!) was cute but I just couldn't get in the mood to dance to them.  I also like the fake thundershowers - cute.

This isn't exactly a place that I would go to with friends just because.  I would come back to enjoy cheesy decorations, sweet drinks with little alcohol and a boat deck to dance on -- and then laugh about it later.
author: Carmel U.

description: Fun, Fun, Fun. Make a reservation you won't be sorry. Going in know service is very spotty and not friendly and slow.  Food was  way better than expected. Atmosphere is very fun. It's very dark in there.
author: myra f.

description:
TONGA ROOM!!! 10 STARS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
MY 100TH REVIEW!! 100 STARS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Gotta love this place, been here forEVER and it's always a blast!

You have to get into the spirit of things and order a Scorpion bowl, or Mai Tai or Hurricane (Of course they have every other drink under the sun available if you don't want to "get with the program!"  They have really yummy appetizers but  I was stuffed from dinner (House of Prime Rib) but I've tasted before and their chicken satay and dipping sauce, those egg roll thingies, really yum and perfect nibbles!

The cover band they have on Fridays and Saturday's is a blast! I'm not really the dancin' type...more the "Posin' til Closin" type" ...but the combination of the Scorpion bowls and the rain storms/lighting (it rains every 20 minutes inside this place) and "Copacabana" playing had me up and dancing!!  Yeah, it's definitely wedding reception music (from 25 years ago) but thats part of the charm of this place! Everyone was fun and dancing and drinking and enjoying the vibe!!!!

Thanks for the fun Tonga Room! May you Reign (RAIN?) forever!!!!
author: Karen S.

description:
After reading all the reviews of the Tonga Room and the rumors of its demise, I figured I better go check it out.  So last night, armed with some girlfriends, we did just that.  I was expecting it to be festive and fun.  It was definitely not.  First of all, I thought I was on the set of "The Shining" walking into the place.  (What a weird and creepy hotel!)  The hostess was snotty to everyone she was speaking to.  The male servers were all (and I'm not exaggerating) at least 65 years old.  It was dark and the mood was definitely NOT fun Hawaiian.  It was more boring, dark hotel restaurant.  

We had some drinks (which were good) and then got our table for dinner.  The food was okay.  Not bad and somewhat better than I expected for what the reviews said.  Overpriced but not terrible.   

We were talking about how lame the place was and how we were hoping the band would liven things up.  When the band finally came out, here's the first song they sang.  Wait for it.....
"Sailing" by Christopher Cross.  ARE YOU KIDDING ME?!?!??!
Followed by "Fly me to the Moon".   Yeah, this was a fun time.  We couldn't wait to get out of there.  

Now we know.
author: Karen N.

description: I love this place but...it is what it is... a fun and festive tourist stop or a great place for a small occasion. It is great for first timers and a fun happy hour. The line staff is friendly but the people working the door could learn to smile and be polite...not very welcoming.
author: Tyler S.

description: Food was okay. I expected it to better than it was. There wasnt anything special about it. The drinks they serve are AMAZING! They charge a $7 cover per person for dinner fri-sat nigths for the live band on top of what you pay for dinner. Music was a little too loud, I had to yell across the table just to have a conversation.
author: Krista R.

description: After seeing rave reviews from anthony bourdain, I insisted on visiting the Tonga Room for my birthday.  Did I enjoy my birthday? Oh absolutely BUT the food poison my boyfriend received from the butter fish ruined our weekend.  I can understand not every experience is perfect and I usually would not leave a bad review but when we called to notify the restaurant, they showed little concern.  The manager was brusk, and uncaring. The one thing I expect when I spend over $200.00 for is a meal is to be acknowledged and treated with some common courtesy. We were promised a return phone call in May....It's July. I think I've waited long enough.  Don't waste your money. This restaurant obviously doesn't care about their customers, or preparing a decent meal.
author: Emily P.

description: I really enjoyed this tiki bar! I love tiki bars and this one was awesome. The Mai Tais were good and the ambiance was spot on. The only downside was the line to wait to get in. It wasn't too bad when we got there, but was significantly longer when we left. Since we weren't staying at the hotel, the server asked for a card when we ordered, and then automatically ran it at the end when we were leaving.. Just a heads up for parties who may be splitting the bill! There was a $7 live music fee on Friday/Saturday nights, but not a big deal since it's just one fee per table. Definitely worth coming and checking out!
author: A J.

description: We made reservations several days ago for a B-Day at 7:30pm on a Fri. Called to confirm with Kelly that my 14 group party still had reservations. Confirmed twice as I needed to call about dress codes. We were running late and I was told that we had to be there by 7:45 as they provide an additional 15 minutes wait before they give up our reservations. We got there at 7:29 on the dot. The hostess asks how large the party and said it was a long wait. I said we have reservations and she comes back that they do not take reservations for Fri/Sat.   I told her to check for our reservation. She looks and finds it and says we can't seat you because your reservation is for next year (2015). Wow. I asked for the manager and he looks dumbfounded and doesn't understand how they booked my group for next year. He explained that they outsource there calls to a call center. Not my problem and you need to find us some tables. Another hostess was trying real hard to have us leave and did not provide any sympathy. How is it that we are being blamed and being punished for there mistake. So they have us wait near the bar after 45 minutes of explaining their mistakes. We were provided 1 round of drinks on the house and our seats will be done by 9:30. We ordered there 2 appetizer sampler at $28 (Pricey for very limited food).Time goes by and the manager says they are waiting on another group to leave and should be seated by 10pm. We looked at the menu and because I couldn't get reception for internet I couldn't look at what the food looked like. So I wanted to get the most expensive thing on the menu which was the Ohana style at $56. Required four people to order but waiter let us have 3 people order the Ohana style menu. Food came up and each entree came with 3 little pieces. Wow. $166 for 3 people and still felt hungry. Food taste good, but couldn't really gauge because we had been waiting since 7:30 and was pretty much hungry to begin with, so anything would of been good. Let's just say this was not worth the time or place. Overall experience went downhill once the hostess lied about not taking reservation, their mistake in our 2015 reservation, outsourced reservation call center, expensive selection of food (This is not Plumed Horse or French Laundry). Don't use the Fairmont name just to hike up your status. Never will I refer nor take my business here. This was not my choice and I was dreading it based on some past yelp reviews. You might ask why we didn't just leave. Well how many SF restaurants would of taken a 14 group party at short notice on Labor day weekend. We thought that the manager would be a bit more accommodating for their mistakes. But a round was the equivalent of our tip.
author: Jr V.

description:
The atmosphere here is fun and unexpected in San Francisco. 

That said, I had an AWFUL experience here. I was with my girlfriend, we ordered two drinks and two plates of food.... the waitress was strangely so rude to us... she was middle-aged and Asian. The rudeness persisted... so we did not leave a tip... when my friend checked her account the next day, they had ADDED in their OWN TIP.  They added $12 on a $50 check. so... they STOLE a pretty good tip at that. Can you believe that?? my god, the nerve!!! 

So... I'll never go back there...
author: Claire b.

description:
This used to be one of my favorite bars in the city.  Unique, great ambiance, and live music!  I've been coming here for years, even before they were in trouble of shutting down and after my recent visit I think it will be my last.

You now have to wait in line even if you want to just chill by the bar and grab a drink! WTF! They were very rude too when I casually walked in like I usually do bypassing the dinner line.

Makes me feel bad for supporting and telling people about this bar for soooo many years!
author: Peter S.

description:
Is it cheesy?  Yes.  But that's what Tiki is all about, isn't it?  Plus, there's some awesome hipster watching to be had.  But we'll get to that.

I last came to the Tonga room while I was staying at the Fairmont.  What's better than a bar you can stumble back from?  I certainly couldn't tell you.  ;)  We started with the Chicken Satay and the Vegetable Tempura.  The Satay was shockingly good while the tempura was about what you'd expect.  The star of the food was the winter squash curry.  It was AMAZING with enough heat to make it interesting and beautiful pieces of perfect squash.  Yum!!  

And of course there are the cocktails.  I love a fruity umbrella drink and this place does all the classics.  While I didn't end up getting drunk there, it wouldn't be too hard to lose yourself in all that rum.  

They have a boat.  Yes, a boat.  On which the awesomely random cover band plays.  There's so much awesome in that string of words that I don't really feel like I need to say anything else.

Except that it rains.  Complete with thunder and lightning.  And the crowd there on a Saturday night (at least recently) includes so many ridiculous hipsters you'll think you've wandered into http://www.latfh.com/.  I love people watching and making catty comments, so this was a GOLD MINE.  All around, a great experience.
author: Liz P.

description:
Land mark smand mark...I gave this place 2 chances and it still sucks. 

An awesome happy hour does not consist of horrible service and 6 dollar beers.....even if it is a tourist trap. The buffet was put together worse than a super 8 motels managers hour. It consisted of nasty wings, pasta salad and some super salty noodle dish...that is it.  

The whole tiki theme is very nice but a few decorations from the 60s only gets you so far.  

Basically I need to rethink my living will cause this place should have had it's plug pulled a long time ago.  Poor Mr Fairmont for just wanting Ms Tonga to go peacefully.
author: Marc J.

description: So what's the hype? Ok this place is unique with the pool and the band playing in the pool, I give them that. The drinks, they are too sweet and not enough alcohol, or maybe I'm just an alcoholic and there is never enough alcohol? The food was good but not amazing where people are standing in line out the door to get in. Or is the line out the door only because Anthony Bourdain claims this place is one of his favorite spots in SF? Well I had a fun time with my friends here but the bill was so not fun to pay. We dropped $300 between 8 people for drinks, fried rice and appetizers. I think if I come next time I will do happy hour prices. Oh FYI there is a cover charge tacked on when you get your bill, surprise!
author: Karen T.

description: Six words for Tonga Room & Hurricane Bar: A bizarre portal to another time.
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Love it.  The atmosphere is fabulous (makes all other tiki bars hang their oversized plastic Easter Island heads in shame) the drinks are strong, the food is solid, and the crowd there is always great.  Whether surprised Fairmont patrons from out of town who didn't know what they were stumbling into, or polyester-clad hipsters looking for a virtual trip back in time, everyone I run into there is looking to have fun.

Unlike some of the reviews on this site, I've always had good experiences with the wait staff there.  I've waited a bit for a drink once or twice, but there are few bars in the City where that won't happen on the weekends.  When it's not busy, staff are happy to take time out to talk with patrons, adding a neighbor feel to this cavernous bar in the middle of downtown SF.

The live band is a lot of fun, and it's hard not to feel their infectious energy when the boat -- floating in the middle of the bar in a sizable pool -- shakes back an forth while they play, with "lightning" flashing and "rain" pouring down from the lofty ceiling.  Definitely worth the relatively low $7 cover on the nights they play.

Bottom line: If rumors of Tonga's demise are true, I'm going to go back as much as possible until the last tiki torch is extinguished.  Long live Tonga!
author: Leftcoast G.

description:
I admit it, I'm a sucker for a Tiki bar. This place has been around awhile, but only since the '60's which was the tail end of the first Tiki boom. Yes, the rain and thunder definitely pin the needle on the Cheese-O-Meter but the place has such a wonderfully campy fake South Seas vibe you have to love it. It is also fabulously out of place at the Fairmont Hotel. A bit like putting fuzzy dice in your Rolls-Royce.

Obviously not a place for true Polynesian or Asian food aficionados, but I enjoyed my meal, some kind of chicken and rice dish. And the cocktails had umbrellas in them which offset there somewhat high cost and relative weakness in the alcohol department.

Well sadly there are rumors the place is closing. So I strongly urge every Tiki fan and lover of San Francisco tourist attractions to VISIT THE TONGA ROOM WHILE YOU STILL CAN. Then you can bore your Grandchildren with stories of how you were there BACK IN THE DAY.
author: Andrew D.

description:
How cool is this place? I have been in SF for 8 years now, and went to Tonga Room for the first time yesterday. 

The drinks, while a little pricey, are strong and eye-catching. The decor is very warm and the rainstorms are very cool. 

Don't be fooled by the fact this place is in The Fairmont. It is very approachable and very fun. 

Keep an eye out for Anthony Bourdain--I heard it's a favorite of his.
author: Michael C.

description:
This was my mother's choice on our our recent vacation to San Francisco. She had heard it was closing and wanted to go to a tiki lounge like she remembered from "the good old days". Unfortunately, although the Tonga Room tried, it ultimately didn't live up to expectations. 

My two stars are for the atmosphere alone. It's fun and kitschy, like the Rainforest Cafe, as others have mentioned, and you get a free fake flower lei. The live band, whose presence commanded a ridiculous $7 cover charge, played covers of bad music throughout the decades (from the BeeGees to Buble). 

The food was terrible and really, really overpriced. It was oversauced and tasted worse than food court Chinese. My mom and I shared the Mongolian beef and huli huli chicken. Server asked if we wanted rice but didn't explain why it might be a good idea (SAUCE), or explain the family-style nature of the dishes. 

Server was also terrible. Felt really rushed, even though the restaurant was maybe a quarter full. Food came too quickly, implying it obviously wasn't made to order.

If you want to go here, I would recommend skipping Friday or Saturday night when the awful band is playing and just go for drinks or dessert at the bar.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Old fogies, abound!   And our waitress was a bit brash.  They need more veggie options for the HH, like, oh...I don't know, french fries?!?  (They have french fries in the tropics, right?)  How about some rice?  I was left stuffing myself with seaweed and macaroni salad.  That said, their frou frou drinks were halfway decent, which is where it should count.  

The Fairmont is very classy, however, whereas the Tonga Room is just tacky...what a huge contrast.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Hearken back to your SAT days and try this one...

San Francisco : The Tonga Room :: Denver : 

A) Sushi Den
B) The Buckhorn Exchange
C) Casa Bonita
D) The Fort

The correct answer is C) Casa Bonita. 

For those of you who've seen that famous "South Park" episode and  wondered, "is that a real place?" Oh yes... yes, yes, yes. Casa Bonita is 100% real and it's just like Matt Parker and Trey Stone played it up to be. There are indeed cliff divers (feel free to check out my review). 

The Tonga Room's food is a bit (no, a LOT) better, but the price reflects that. Then again, the Tonga Room doesn't have cliff divers.
author: Kym G.

description:
Years ago the Fairmont decided their swimming pool was being wasted on exercise when it can be used for a boat containing a band. Instead of towels and lounge chairs, they surrounded the pool with people drinking rum and wearing leis; this was the correct decision.  

The Tonga Room is to Tiki bars what Notre-Dame is to churches. They serve strong drinks that come in large, island themed containers while there is the occasional indoor thunderstorm.

The unfortunate part, is that the Tonga Room is located on top of the fifth largest mountain in the world, Nob Hill. One drunken slip on the steep walk home will start you tumbling the mile and a half to the bay, and getting eaten by sharks.
author: Michael F.

description:
Hmmmm....Gilligan's Island 

As the rumor has spread that this place might be closing soon, We decided to check this place out. I had actually never heard of the Tonga Room before but my friends at work had been here years ago. We decided on happy hour and enjoying the buffet. I must admit that my expectations were low, I checked the yelp reviews before hand and they didn't help. But if I know one thing, I make the best of any situation or bad food experience. 

I went for my total girly drink "I like Pina Coladas" (song playing in my head now). The buffet was not much of a buffet, for around $10 bucks I was hoping for more. The items were, Mac Salad, Seaweed Salad, Fruit, Veggie Mini Egg Rolls, Wings (sweet sauce) and garlic noodles. Yup that was it, it was more of appetizers than a buffet, especially with the plate size. I am sure if I were to come here next time, regular appetizer would be a better option. Plus the buffet food was Meh.I've had better.

Anyway, The experience was great and the conversations are always interesting when we get together. We left right when the music/band started. I notice they have dancing, that was funny, drunk people dancing way off beat and too fast for the music. LOL.
author: Norma Denisse S.

description:
Tonga, Tonga, Tonga! How I love you!!!

Seriously, y'all... this place is classic SF at its kitschy-est, cheesiest, funnest, and drunkest!!

While I'd love to give this place 5 stars, the food just ain't that good... but everything else about this amazing establishment more than makes up for the lack of gourmet cuisine here. I like this place more for drinks than dinner, but it's fun to sit by the water with your Scorpion Bowl or Mai Tai, donning a Lei and listen to some mediocre classic oldies music, all while experiencing an indoor thunder/rain storm. Does it get any better? No, no... I do not think it does. This just may be the closest San Francisco will ever get to Heaven.

I heard they may be closing this place, and I really hope that's not true. It was built as a pool in 1929 and then renovated into what we know today as the Tonga Room in 1945 by a Hollywood set director... This place is old school, charming and a hoot for all. They simply can't close it!!!
author: Felicity M.

description:
The Tonga Room is definitely a fun experience and everyone should check it out, at least once...well because many can only afford to go once. 

Yays: Awesome cover band. Great ambiance with "rain"! oooh! Food is pretty tasty and specialty drinks are interesting. 

Boos: We had reservations, but still had to wait 20 minutes. Portions are on the small size. Two desserts should be ordered for 4 people. Drinks and food is pricey. The lava drink for 4 people, is really meant for 2 people and the drink for 2 people, is really meant for 1 person. They even ran out of the Hurricane souvenir cup. 

Dinner for 4: Green Papaya Salad, Aloha Baby Back Ribs, Pork Lettuce Cups (flavorful), Mongolian Beef Tenderloin (very tender), Fire Cracker Prawns (not too special), Island Lamb Curry (good), "Forbidden Blend" Fried Rice (all I wanted to eat!), Pineapple Upside Down Cake (small but good),  some Green Tea Dessert ( delish! ), Lava Bowl for 4, and a handful of other drinks. 

Total Price: $300! 

Fun Times with Good Friends: Priceless...so save up!
author: Rachelle T.

description:
Totally tiki kitsch here, ladies and gentlemen ... but that's what makes it cool. It reminds me of the days I went to Kauai or Kona back in the 70s. A-lo-ha!

So, yeah, I dig the tiki vibe here. It's pretty cool if you're into that. But, I've got to say, the happy hour buffet in the Hurricane Bar was a not really my thing. The mini friend egg rolls were kind of like frozen ones you might find at the grocery store. Good enough, but ehhh. The sauce, though, was super delcious. The noodles were tasteless, fruit wasn't ripe, mac salad ... well, that was pretty good (unfortunately for my waistline). Chicken wings were fine, but those chickens don't have much meat on their wings. 

Happy hour drinks were good, but not a huge value. Oh well, it was fun to get a drink with an umbrella. 

Rumor has it that this place may be closing soon. The Fairmont is going to be renovating. My server tonight said they won't know for sure until April. Go now, while you can!
author: Ryan L.

description:
I remember having family parties here for the evening as well as my own birthday party event here. The interior looks nice, with a band on a boat as well as indoor rainfall. The food was fine, thus the 4-star rating and the mocktail pina colada is friendly as well.

Good place to escape for private parties :D
author: Pierre B.

description:
Happy Hour drinks in SF should range of the following deals: 

- $3 beers and wells (Zebulon) 
- Buy one beer, get one free (Columbus Cafe) 
- Free botanas (Maya) 
- Be under $5 

Tonga reminds me of those cheesy places that hotels on the Waikiki strip on Oahu have to design for the tourist that want that tropical theme. When me and my coworker (as well as bday boy) got to Tonga there was a line already forming. We were lucky and were at least seven behind. 

Here's where it gets just a tad bit iffy: the service is so chaotic and not one person could speak a coherent English sentence. The manager-on-duty was rude and apparently this place does not have room for any party over six. The HH drinks are $6.50 for the fruity, goofy drinks with umbrellas on them. And the rules to sit by the bar are stupid. Plus the all you can eat buffet for $9.50 isn't worth to me when the food is on a table with no sneeze guard in site. There is no bathroom, the patrons have to walk out of the restaurant and down the hallway of the Fairmont to pee. 

Here are the plus sides of Tonga: the bartenders made the drinks strong (especially the Mai-tai) and the cool rain effects and the pool in the middle are neat. Wish we got to see the band play, but whatev. All in all my coworkers and I did have a good time, but I don't think I'll come back.
author: Jamie L.

description: They have no idea how to make a gin and tonic, it's more like a gin and ton. Far to strong to be nice. Other drinks are really strong, but mostly ok. Loved the music and dancing was fun.
author: Russell S.

description: Nice deal starting at 5pm- $10 buffet with a minimum one drink purchase. Some wings and fried rice and fruit. Light fare. Fun atmosphere! Get there early- it gets busy!
author: Rosie C.

description:
The ambiance is definitely spectacular. The decor is appropriately tropical and there is a pool with a boat/bandstand floating in the middle. They even have a simulated rainfall and thunder show every half hour which adds to the authenticity of the ambiance. Sometime after 8pm they have a live band that do cover songs. I'm not sure if they rotate the live musical acts but the performers on the night we dined were quite good. Some people around us got up to dance and it was a fuzzy feeling kind of sight to see. Mom dancing with son, an older couple that looked like they have been dancing at the Tonga Room since the 1950s, and younger folks. These are the rememberings fresh in my mind so I thought I would get those thoughts down first. 

The food was ok. The quality ingredients are there but the conceptualization and execution seemed very lazy. We had the Kao Island dinner and you do get everything listed under that header which promised variety but the entrees were pretty much just stir-frys. I imagine if you paid full-price here you would be a tad bit disappointed. 

I would definitely go back for drinks and the entertainment. I doubt I would return for dinner.
author: Rachel M.

description: Went again last weekend. I think I might be too young for this place? It has such amazing decor that I could really see it being a great club (if only...). Is it weird that it kinda reminds me of being at a wedding reception? Like that type of crowd? Drunk older people dancing to songs that were made when I was 6.
author: Cesie A.

description:
Fun place .. 
There's live music .. Some sort of simulation for lightning and rumbling...
Not a lot of vegetarian options ... Was a bit disappointed on that end since the menu is Asian-inspired ..
Drinks are GOOD though !!
Our server was a sad lady and dint smile even once ...
Well that's fine ... The ambience is great and I would totally go back when in the area ..
author: Neha G.

description:
honestly, i'd give Tonga Room 3.5 stars, but decided to round up to 4 instead of down to 3.

the ambiance and decor is kitschy but doesn't cross into tacky territory.  fun, sweet, and surely put a smile on my face.  the drinks were wonderful and the mai tai was probably the best i've ever had.  the appetizers were delicious (veggie spring rolls and coconut shrimp).  my husband said his steak was really good, but i was on the fence about my entree, the hot pot.  it was good, but lacked a certain flavorful depth.  a little on the "blah" side, especially considering it was $27.  but after a few mai tais and feeling giddy and silly every time the rainstorm started up again, it didn't really matter.  

in the future, i would probably come back here for drinks and appetizers but not likely for dinner.
author: Anjanette M.

description:
Home Run Voucher and finally I'm eating at the Tonga Room!  My BF and I were celebrating an anniversary and wanted to go somewhere fun.  We just went to the Dining Rm at the Ritz a couple of weeks back for my birthday and driving by the Fairmont reminded me that my voucher was going to expire soon.

This place is neat.  It reminded us of the Pirates of the Caribbean ride in Disneyland.  Upon arrival there are two lines.  One for reservations and hotel guests and one for walk-ins.  The guy/host greeting people did not look happy.  Oh boy, is this a sign of what's to come?  NO!  Our server was delightful!  He let us know exactly how to order off the menu and made some suggestions for us.  We shared 3 appetizers: the ribs, egg rolls and vegetable tempura.  Then we moved onto the Mongolian beef, and green beans.  The portions are huge!  The beef was super tender and the green beans were not overcooked.  The banana mouse for dessert was super yummy but a little frozen still.  I think I liked it frozen though.  Overall, 4 stars!  I would give it 5 but $90 for two people, not including drinks and tip is a little pricey for Chinese food.  

FYI:  Valet is $50!!!  They suggested we park somewhere else around the corner for about $30 something but I think you should just suck it up and pay.  Who wants to run up and down the block to get your car anyways?
author: Rosalind S.

description:
I went to the Tonga Room this past Sunday with a group of people.  We received the worst level of service I have ever had in 9 years of dining and drinking in San Francisco.  It was a full 30 minutes before our waiter came to take our food and drink order.  Our waiter was rude and indifferent as he couldn't be bothered to actually perform his job at a competent level. The drinks were awful and cloyingly sweet.  

If you must see the Tonga Room take a walk through the restaurant then exit the hotel and light $100 on fire.  That would have been better than my experience.
author: David B.

description: Very touristy as expected. But fun drinks and enjoyed sitting around the bar. Prices are high but expected as you are in the fairmont. Go for the lava bowl, tasty!
author: Nicole S.

description:
this is kind of a fun place with water in the middle and the band moving back and forth.  but when you see the bill you wont want to come back every again.  and thats my advice, dont come here

we came here on a saturday night for dinner and drinks.  the line to get in was long!  we said down and ordered lava bowls.  strong stuff!  the food was not bad but so overpriced for chinese food!

for apps we got spareribs, spring rolls and chicken satay.  for mains we had string beans, shrimp, and mongolian beef. then dessert.  

when we got the bill we realized it was over $100 per person!  for chinese food!  they had tacked on a 21% gratuity.  and also a $7 per head cover charge.  ugh
author: claudia y.

description: Ambiance is always great. Food, usually is good. This time not so great. The waiter was super nice though and we will probably still go back. It's not the food that brings us here, its the drinks.
author: An G.

description: My ex husband & I stayed at the Fairmont on our honeymoon back in 2008 & we ate here twice during our stay. We both have pretty high food standards, and we really liked the food - esp for the price. Not really my style as far as decor goes, and the service was lacking, but the food was good enough for us to brush that off. But the most important thing is the food, and for that, I'd definitely go again.
author: Kim D.

description: We wanted to take my Mom & our son to the Tonga Room since they have never been. It has been a few years since we've gone ourselves. The best part of the experience is the ambiance. My 5 year old son LOVED the water in the middle of the restaurant, the ship deck and the fake rain and, of course, his virgin pina colada! Sadly, the meal itself was just okay. Many of the dishes lacked seasoning. We ordered the snapper and it was flavorless. The kalua pork, however, was the highlight as far as dishes go. The kung pao chicken did not have much chicken and was oversauced. It's definitely a fun experience if you're into ambiance however, if you're as picky about food as I am, there are definitely much better places to go for the price you pay here.
author: Rica R.

description: Drinks were strong. $20 for a lava bowl which my boyfriend and I couldn't even finish.there was a large business group there which must have thought our table was the empty bottle pick up station which was a little annoying. Music and vibe was good.
author: Nicole S.

description: Such a fun place. We were there on a Sunday evening when they had entertainment and were seated by the water. The band was great, the Tiki atmosphere was perfect. Drinks were good food a little mixed. The chicken and rice dishes and appetizers the best choices. I want to go back during happy hour time, when it will be a better value. Because I'm a fan of "Tiki done well" I'm giving the Tonga room 4 stars.
author: Karen J.

description: This Bar and Restaurant are fun but I think they need a bit of a facelift. I didn't eat there but since I was staying in the Hotel, I went there for a Mai Tai. I was encountered by a line of people waiting to get into the bar but I discovered if you tell the host you will stand at the bar they let you right in. The bar staff was efficient and understaffed but they worked their butts off. The Mia Tai, which cost me $14.44 was just average and not memorable. The famed rain storm occurred which is nothing more than a rectangular array of perforated pipes. It was cheesy, and I think that the Hotel should give it a facelift. It is not quite a candidate for Robert Irvine or Bar Rescue but I didn't feel I  would like to eat there
author: Terry M.

description: Came here for dinner one night. I like the thunderstormin', theme, & atmosphere. Food was pretty good. Mom got the drink in the pineapple, Pineapple Royal, I think it's called. Then I shared a tiki bowl drink with my boyfriend. The band that was playing along with the singer sounded pretty good playing oldies. Oh and they charge cover even though we're eating dinner there. :(
author: Amy C.

description: Great place to unwind after work and the happy hour is pretty good.  Don't get the Happy Hour Buffet....for 10 bucks you can save your money and eat something better afterward.  Drinks are good...but not great.  I recommend you drive and don't walk.  We caught the BART and tried to walk up the hill and almost had a heart attack...would recommend you go atleast once to say you were there.
author: Rob A.

description:
Cue some fake thunder and lightning, add a variety of extra large tropical drinks in a chilly San Francisco setting.  Throw in one filipino lounge singer belting out "feelings" from a bamboo raft floating on top of the old indoor swimming pool of the Fairmont Hotel. Mix all this together, and presto, you've got the Tonga Room.

Priceless.  Don't close this place.
author: Georgio N.

description:
Came here on a recommendation - fun atmosphere. 

Service was so-so, not incredibly attentive, nor helpful with food recommendations. We'd asked our server what to get, he went with the traditional items- Mongolian beef, sampler platter appetizer, etc. 
We then told him that we wanted something we couldnt get elsewhere. He didn't stray from his initial recommendations. 

The green papaya salad was tasty as was the Opah entree. Forbidden rice was very tasty, but the spicy shrimp was ok. 

This place felt very authentic and didnt feel like you were in a Fairmont hotel except when the managers walked by in their suits. Oh well.

We took advantage of the Yelp offer - we got a free drink per entree we ordered. That was awesome considering how much we spent!
author: Kristina C.

description: I was really excited about going to the Tonga Room, but I was kind of disappointed. Walking through the Fairmont Hotel was breathtaking to say the least, I love the idea that big-time historical figures had been there, and the tiki decorations were super fun, and for that they get three stars. The food and drinks were overpriced, extremely tiny portions, and not even that tasty. I ordered the Hot Pot, which is seafood in a red curry coconut sauce. I love red curry, but this was kind of watery and low on the flavor. I still think it's worth visiting but a drink or two would suffice to experience the fun atmosphere. Eat dinner elsewhere!
author: Sarah N.

description:
Got headache? 
Wanna put the hurt on the wallet? 
Well a-we-mah-way look no further for a night at The Tonga Room guarantees both!
Oooooo look ! Outrageous faux Polynesian decor! Sugary drinks served in skulls and coconuts !! A mock lagoon complete with floating Filipino band !!! OMG!!!! It's raining!!!!!
Only possible conclusion - the food here must be great !!!!!!
Alas no - but who cares? My first Mai Tai was not bad. The second even better. By the time I finished my Hurricane the coconut shrimp were downright delicious. Next came the Flaming Bathtub of Booze which comes with VERY long straws so you can blow bubbles in your drink.
I don't remember what happened next but I did return the next day to ransom my car from the Fairmont impound lot - oooopz - I meant valet parking. 
$350 clams for 4 people but 2 were teenagers who weren't drinking (I do like to set a good example for the kiddiepoos). Oh and $63.51 for some embarrassing photos which will probably show up on Bookface someday - total with parking about $500.

Bottom line - a great time was had by all.
author: Rock A.

description:
I remember coming to the Tonga Room when I was first legally able to drink and thinking it was the coolest place ever LOL

Well, I still think it's a cool spot if you're with company who enjoys the cheesy atmosphere this place has.  Love that it rains every 20 min but have never heard a live band here nor had to pay a cover to get in.  I've never seen anyone wearing an aloha shirt or a fake lei so I don't feel like I'm walking into the over cheesyness of the place...I just tell the host that we're there for the bar and take a seat.

Always order a drink from a bowl rather it be the lava or scorpion because who doesn't love suckin alcohol thru a tremendously long straw from a community filled alcohol bowl?!!

I must be lucky cuz I always get the bowl plus one additional drink and I'm in a good place ;0)
author: Ninja H.

description:
This feels like good old fashioned fun in here.  Located in the Fairmont, it was definitely a treat to come here!

The food was good but wasn't amazing (which was disappointing considering the prices).  We had:

Sonoma Duck Breast - found it to be a little dry & tough
Mongolian Beef Tenderloin - salty & saucy and absolutely delicious
Island Lamb Curry - this is stuff that non-lamb fans would love!
Seared Diver Scallops - I actually did not try this, there were only 3 scallops (@ $27!!!)

You definitely should order plain rice on the side to mop up that delicious sauce from the beef & curry.

Drinks made good and strong!  Major plus.

Desserts were fun, exotic looking and ON FIRE!  No, seriously, get the Flaming Tonga Volcano.
