Live band!  Cover charge of $15.  3-people band, they all sang great!  Small dance floor.  Lot of oldies music.  Loved dancing (lot of families out there, I didn't feel self-concious at all!).

Obviously you don't come here for the food, but for the amazing singing, dancing, service and just plain-fun atmosphere.

Yeah it's definitely expensive, definitely an "only-special-occasion" dining but YES I will come back!
author: Kimiko Q.

description: The drinks here are nasty.  I am glad Bourdain went here.  Keep all the tourists in the shit holes.  Thanks
author: Fatty A.

description: Me & my husband just celebrated our 2 yr wedding anniversary here...and i loved the atmosphere the waiter & waitresses were extremely nice. and its just a couple of blocks away frm powell bart station =D i will be coming back here again
author: Carolyn B.

description: Was ok ... went there after I heard about it on Bourdain ... tried the drink with two long straws ,... tasted soapy .... The decor was polynesian and somewhat interesting ... mostly a hotel crowd with little kids dancing on the open floor ... will not return.
author: James R.

description:
My first visit to the Tonga Room was for my senior prom with a group of 20 some years back. We had internet then (I'm not THAT old!) but I recall making the reservations the old school way by calling 411 and obtaining their phone number and nervously asking to make reservations. After all that was said and done, I received a confirmation back via snail mail. I went back a couple times after that and I always seemed to enjoy the cheesy islander decor, the band on the river with the thunder/rainstorm every 15 minutes. 

The food, I would have to say is not the best. It reminded me of the food that we all used to order from this $1 a plate Chinese restaurant nearby my high school. A little fancier, though (sorry). At least now I'm old enough to legally order drinks.
author: Esther A.

description: This place is the quintessential Tiki-Bar, except for the fact that it's kind of a tourist trap. Truthfully it's cool to visit this place once to get it out of your system, and then move on to better SF scenes. The drinks, I have to admit are pretty cool looking and are fairly decent taste wise, but the place is so crowed and loud that it's hard to sit relax and enjoy them. We did order some appetizers, and they were ok. Overall, I would have to say, if your in to the Tiki scene it's a must, but if you can live without it, please do and find a cooler place to hang out. Like upstairs in the Fairmont Hotel's Bar (Laurel Court Bar), it's classy and surrounded by a beautiful Lobbey/Lounge. You feel like you're back in the 1920s.
author: Brian M.

description:
Yes it is cheesy but there is a line to get in when they open at 5, so hey, it's not "that" cheeeeesy. It's a San Francisco institution.  

I like the rain and the thunder and I imagine it can get pretty entertaining at night with the live band and the dancing. Granted it might be a bunch of tourists, but where else can you feel like you are quasi in the pacific islands in SF? 

Plus, there is something to be said about sharing a lava bowl with their extremely long straws!
author: Natalie S.

description:
Save yourself and choose a different restaurant.  We were sooooo disappointed.  When we arrived we were impressed with the beautifully decorated restaurant, high energy of the place & music!  We did not like being charged a $7. cover per person since we were having a dinner...but we were good sports and sucked that one up.  But actually that's where the bad stuff started.  Our Waiter quickly came by to take drink orders but we barely got the menu open and since we were not ready he quickly ran off.  In fact he was so rushed through our whole dinner that we felt more like we were imposing on his precious time.  This left a bad impression on us!  Anyway, we did order our drinks and the house wines were not good at all.  I expected better since we are from the East Coast and here we are close to Wine country!
  I ordered Singapore noodles with Shrimp (came with pork but I asked to hold the pork). Whoa...the shrimp was something I would serve at a Barbie doll tea party!! Shrimp looked more like "plankton" than shrimp.  A good Waiter should have warned me of that!  I mean these were finger nail size shrimp...the kind that I think comes in a can.   Our waiter was not familiar with the menu...he could not answer questions on a few of the dishes we inquired about.  I must mention...the menu is not large either!    
We sampled each dish (4 of us) and only the "fatty" ribs were the best meal out of the 4.  This is not a place to go to for the food.  I don't mind paying top dollar for quality food but this was top dollar for canned food.  Our meals came out really fast too so you know it was not made to order.  Anyway,  only a few nights in SF and we wasted one quality night here   Darn. Like I said...save yourselves...this is not a quality restaurant.
author: sherri s.

description:
This place made me puke, literally.  I've now been here twice, didn't want to write a bad review after only one time but last night validated my first impression.

My friend wanted to meet here for her birthday on a Friday night.  We were charged $7/each for the 'entertainment fee' and unable to make reservations ahead of time, brought 30 people that never would have stepped foot in the place otherwise, beverages were stupidly expensive and the specialty menu started at $12/drink.  I've got no problem paying extra for fun signature drinks but these were too sweet and not mixed tastefully - I might have well been in vegas. The staff is weird, not rude, but just kinda awkward and unsocial and seem to not know what is going on - we certainly didn't feel welcome.  

We ordered a few appetizers and my olfactories immediately rejected whatever that rotten-flesh smelling mass was, however my boyfriend bravely grabbed a chicken satay, took one bite, and discretely stuffed it into a napkin. As much as I love my friend, we snuck out of there after one drink, and promptly went home so i could hurl.  

one star for atmosphere, which really is cute, i get why tourists would like it. But it's not even worth me going back for the happy hour everyone seems to enjoy, gross.  I hate giving bad reviews, but I'll consider this a public service.
author: Loralyn S.

description:
The Fairmont Hotel is not the kind of hotel my family stayed in when I was growing up.  Instead, it's the kind of hotel I worked at to help pay for grad school.  This makes me somewhat prejudiced every time I go to a tony hotel like the Ritz.  It's because I know things like, they don't allow the workers to use the same bathrooms as the customers, and they make the workers eat their dinner in the dungy basement.  Well, in the basement of the Fairmont is a fabulous kitschy place I'd happily frequent again and again.  Or at least any night I wanted to shell out $50 for tropical drinks.

The service is excellent and the entertainment is a blast at the Tonga Room.  The house band is actually pretty amazing, with a wide range of style, playing anything from Jason Mraz to Elvis.  The decor of the Tonga Room is everything you'd hope it would be, including indoor rain and lightning.  There's plenty of room on the dance floor if you feel like working off some of those tropical drinks you'll definitely end up consuming. 

We went for drinks and spent $50/person, which included a $7 cover charge (for the house band).  We got seated at a nice table for drinks with hardly any wait.  It worked really well to go as a group of 4, but it also seems like it'd be a real blast to have parties here.  If you want to go for dinner on the weekend you'll need reservations.  I'm giving this a Five Star rating because I'm judging it as a bar and not a restaurant.  I didn't go for the whole meal as I took the warnings not to (here on Yelp) pretty seriously.

Some other people on Yelp made reference to a Rooftop view, but when I asked them about it they said it'd been closed since 2000.

Even if you don't think the Tonga Room is your cup of tea...visit the Fairmont to enjoy its beauty and fancy bathrooms!
author: Kimberly B.

description:
OH NO! CLOSING?!?

I loveeee this place!  Came here for a holiday party and it was awesome. Friendly staff, good food (pina colada dip to die for) and the best decor! They had shitake mushroom egg rolls, skewers, macademia fried rice (drool) and other goodies. 

A BAND THAT PLAYS ON A FLOATING BOAT? I guess i am cheesy but I loved the psuedo rain and thunder

Hoping to go again soon!
author: Amy S.

description:
I'm tempted to give this place two stars.  Have you ever drank too much and been hungover waking up not being able to get horrible tiki lounge music out of your head?  It's nightmarish.  They played a Christopher Cross song and the lyrics: "oh I, will never be the same without you love, I'd live alone, hide myself behind my tears..." is living inside my brain thoughts like a mosquito in a supermarket filled with packaged blood.

It's really annoying.

Anyways this place is outdated tiki; marked up chinese food that tastes good but that is no better than other places where it's 300% less in cost; a water showering system that's supposed to replicate tropical rain.

Eh, after 5 drinks it seemed well engineered.  All in all, it's a little too loud and the sound system for the band is very bad.  The dim lights are nice.

I'd be a liar if I said I didn't have fun so, ok, I'll keep it at 3 stars.
author: Tony U.

description:
Remember all of those times you've been dragged to a rainforest cafe and been totally pissed at the shitty food, ridiculous drinks, screaming children and freakish animal animation things. Well that was tiki restaurant hell, Tonga room, is heaven!

Lets start with the food:
Delicous. Anything from the ocean is a go. Also the papaya salad is quite good. You can basically order anything from here and be stoked.

Drinks: SWEET! So excited about this portion. OK- so I know 16$ is a bit much for a cocktail, but it's totally worth it, the pineapple royal is amazing. They take a pineapple and fill it with rum, brandy and of coarse pineapple juice. It's great to share. 

Music: They have a band playing on a barge in the middle of a mini lagoon in the middle of the restaurant. Need I say more? Oh ya there a top 40 band of coarse! And while some may just want to listen others can get on up and dance on the floor of an old S.S. ship.


Oh and it rains. Not like the forest cafe, but like you would expect from gilligans island. 

Great for any occasion, and like ive said before don't ruin it by going there with assholes!
author: Katie M.

description:
Will remember this place for my 50th birthday! Jokes aside we actually had a blast for my friends birthday on Saturday. 

The crowd was definitely a bit older but the cheesy music and great decor contributed to a great evening!

It's more of a once in a lifetime kind of place...
author: Nez B.

description: Just like a Disney resort feel..cheesy but a must when in SF
author: V. R.

description: We had been wanting to go here for over 2 years when we saw this location on the final leg of the Amazing Race. We went for happy hour, and I was pleasantly pleased that the other people who were there for happy hour made a line. They don't open the doors until 5 so you are standing outside the whole time. The bar area is pretty big, so everyone in line got a seat, but they escort you in one by one. During happy hour they have a buffet with chow mein, 2 types of chicken wings, Hawiian style fried rice, fresh fruit, and egg rolls, which were delicious. All of the carbohydrates  probably complimented the big drinks very well. The food was hot and the staff replenished the food quickly, only complaint was the other idiots in line who wouldn't close the lid on the food, so the heat kept escaping. We would have enjoyed listening to the band, but happy hour  was from 5-7 and the band didn't start until 8, so I guess we will have to come back to listen to that. As an fyi, if you are there when the band is playing there is a $7 cover charge per person, and the regular priced drinks are pretty pricey. The one good thing about the Fairmont being on the top of the hill was that we felt we were able to burn some calories before the meal on our hike up, and after the meal, on the steep walk down.
author: Lisa H.

description: Let me just say that this place is really good for entertainment for good music, food, and great customer service. My husband and I were there yesterday to celebrate our 1 year wedding anniversary. The food was great and their alcohol drinks are yummy; I highly recommend their Pina Colada. My husband go the Hurricane and you get to keep the cup when you order it. Our waiter was very nice. He knew it was our anniversary and complemented us with a yummy volcano dessert. He would check up with us and see if everything was okay. As of the entertainment, the band called Island Groove was great!! They sang all the right songs and they can get down. They are a very talented band and they can all definitely sing. I would definitely go there again!!
author: Maricar B.

description:
The Hawaiian Decor is nice! i like going here with friends for Happy Hour Buffet $9.50 per person for apptezier food--& Mai-tais are good. Dinner is good too. My friend is hooked on the lamb and my favorite is the fried rice. 

The reason why I am only giving it 3 stars is because not only the dinner prices are way over-priced--drinks are $10.00+ during Happy Hour and like $14.00 regularly for 1 drink. But also their service sucks!!--The managers are nice but some of the other staff just can't get it together! We waited like 20 minutes to be seated when the place was empty. I think they didn't have enough employees in the front. Also we once we got seated we later asked to switch tables so we can be closer to the water...when we did the waiter (older asian man) gave me attitude when I asked if I can switch to the table. For the amount of money that they charge for dinner here, they should treat their customers alot better. 

I heard this place might be closing due to lack of business not sure if its true?? This place has potential to do better...May I suggest lower your prices!! Add more choices to the menu!!! And give your employees customer service training to be more courteous!!!
author: v v.

description: This place was hella fun and the live band was great! But the Food not so much! I had the Hot Pot which was decent but not anything to write home about! My friend had the Salmon dish with wasabi mash and veggies, it was overcooked and tasted like dry chicken! Totally not impressed.The drinks were great we had the pineapple margarita and the Mai tai. Finally dessert...It was actually the best thing of the night it was the Smore Brownie. It was good but not the Best. Overall the atmosphere was great but the next time we will only go here for drinks. By the way be prepared to spends somewhere around $120 for two diners!
author: Armanda B.

description:
It's dark. Ropes of a beached ship welcome you just inside the entrance. A "blue lagoon" sits in the center of the room, tables and tiki decor all around. You hear thunder. Rain begins to pour over the pool. Then, you hear it: the jams of a band, entering on a little boat that pulls out into the middle of the pool! A passionate trio of rockin' middle-aged guys who've been doing this forever play the drums, guitar, and keyboard, and are headed by a soulful young songstress. And they're good! They play all covers and you can't help but tap your feet or even get up on the dancefloor!!

I love this place! It's so fun!!!!!! It's cheesy but in a good way! If you give into it, it's so worth it!

After eating here twice on two special occasions with my fiance, I would advice not going for the FOOD. It's mediocre at best. (Although the service is very good and fast). 

I suggest going for a night of drinks (they have all kinds of colorful, island-themed drinks on the menu), maybe an appetizer, and definitely some dancing. 

Plenty of people celebrate birthdays, anniversaries, and other special occasions here. There seemed to be plenty of tourists, as well. There are also LOTS of people who just want to have a great time! 

Take a chance on this "island adventure" and you will be glad you did!
author: ILoveLA H.

description: For better and for worse, this place makes you feel like you are off somewhere on vacation.  The place is kind of corny and expensive like a touristy spot would be.  At the same time, however, the Tonga Room/Hurricane Bar is such an old school San Francisco landmark, that it's a must do at least once during your life as a San Francisco resident.  Don't come hungry, the food is not good and is not cheap.  Drinks are about 10 bucks a pop.
author: Bert N.

description: We had a great time!  We were a party of 12 and it could have been a mess!  But....Casey, our waiter, took GREAT care of us!  He is an expert at what he does and LOVES his job!  His customer service skills were out of this world!  There was a bit of a miscommunication with the purpose of our visit (he was told we were there just for drinks and appetizers but we were there for a full dinner) but he handled it with ease and confidence!  We wanted to stay all night just to be catered to!  And to top it all off, the food was fantastic!  It's a great destination restaurant and well worth the money. We will be back!
author: Marquel T.

description:
Meh.  I love Anthony Bourdain, but this place is just okay.  Yes the decor is cool and it's at a great hotel.  However the service is poor.  Everything was so fast - drinks came out right away, then our food came out after 3 minutes.  Our waiter was pushy and rude, we felt like we were being pushed out.  The bus boy, tried to take away my husbands drink when there was half left.   Then he to take away our noodles when I had chopsticks it in, still eating!  The food is crazy overpriced for what it is - simple Asian fare, so I guess you just pay for the location.  The drinks are very tropical & tasted good.
As we were given our bill the waiter waited for us to fill out the tip and sign!  Then when I stood up and leave - the bus boy was 4 inches behind me waiting to push me out and clear my chair.  

Save your money.  Just go look inside & take a peek.  Then eat and drink elsewhere.
author: Kerry F.

description:
This place, in general, is pretty awesome. A little cheesy, yes, but awesome nonetheless. There's rainfall in the center of the room, a band playing on a boat, a pirate ship-cum-dance floor, tiki torches and mini paper lanterns everywhere. It really is like being in Disneyland. The drinks fit the theme: mai tais, margaritas, daiquiris and pina coladas topped off with mini umbrellas. 

Now, I would normally give this place 4+ stars based on the overall vibe, but the bar service was TERRIBLE and since I rather value good customer service, this was a biggie for me. The Tonga Room is in the Fairmont Hotel so I really didn't think that customer service would be this place's downfall. Naturally, I assumed the $12 drinks would be the part that I found most jolting. I was absolutely astounded by the chaos at the bar. We waited for 15+ minutes to get a drink and the bartenders were the antithesis of what you would imagine you'd find in a fun-filled, tiki torch-laden lounge (not to mention in a hotel of this calibre). I was already a bit put off after having to miss out on some stellar MJ songs on the dance floor whilst waiting for drinks and then to top it off, the bartenders were just unfriendly. I'm not sure if they were understaffed that night or if they weren't expecting the turn out that they got, but I really don't think that the service should *ever* be an issue at this place, especially when people are paying $10 - $15 for drinks. Icing on the cake? My boyfriend was overcharged. As if we weren't already paying inflated prices, go ahead and tack on an extra drink that no one actually had! Perfect!

Note to the Fairmont: this is the perfect place to have fun, young, bubbly bartenders who act like they ENJOY life. Whether you were understaffed for the evening or the turnout was better than expected, I would imagine that this is something a business would be prepared for. Making people wait 20 minutes for a subpar $12 drink served by rude bartenders after paying a $7 cover is just absurd. Friendly staff would easily take this place from a 2 star to a 4 star!
author: Shannon E.

description:
Atmosphere - tropical, fun and very unique. The rainstorm and stage in the boat is a trip. Love it!
Food - very good.
Drinks - the highlight!

Always fun when visiting San Francisco with first timers.
author: OC L.

description: The environment and the live band floating in the middle of the indoor swimming pool was a great ambiance!  You are going strictly for the show and the feeling of escaping SF to a tropical paradise as the food/drinks are mediocre at best.
author: Min P.

description:
I have been to Tonga Room many times and it never ceases to impress me. Above all it is really a unique experience all around (come on, it rains indoors!).   The food is phenomenal and the menu changes seasonally. The ambiance is so fun and inviting.  The drinks are nice and strong and served with umbrellas if you want.  There is even live music on the weekends!

I go to Tonga Room above any other place in the city when I want a fantastic meal,  exceptional service, a good drink, and a mini vacation :-)
author: Giana D.

description: go once just to see it.
author: Hugh B.

description: Ambience is very interesting with the artificial rain. The drinks are just ok. We had lava bowl which was overly sweet - tasted like sugar cane juice :) If you're just interested interesting ambience and some dancing and don't care about drinks, this is great place to go.
author: J P.

description: Cool ambiance but horrible food. So over priced and too much salt in their food. Tofu too hard. My kids and I walked out of there thinking we should have eaten at panda express. I feel sick after eating that much salt.
author: K G.

description: Finally got to have drinks here and check it out. It's a hoot! We had our holiday party there and had a smashing time. The music was almost too loud though and I found myself shouting in my colleague's face at one point. Otherwise it was great time.
author: Nicole O.

description:
Been here several times with a mix of different crowds each time. Go for the drinks and the cool tropical atmosphere. It actually "rains" inside! 

The live band is great. They play the type of music you would find on 98.1 KISS FM; old school and R&B. Though I have only ever been there on a weekend, so during the week, I am not sure what kind of music is played or if they have a DJ as opposed to a live band. I happen to enjoy that type of music, so I will take a few spins around the dance floor whenever I am there. 

I know they serve food there, but I have only ever gone for cocktails. Their specialty drinks are really good, and worth the prices, because everytime I have had one, it has been pretty loaded. They don't skimp on the alcohol, that's for sure. But  they are still tasty and nice to look at, especially if you order the one that comes in a fresh pineapple!

 The crowd is mostly an over 30s crowd, but can be stretched to a "late 20s and up" crowd depending on what night you go. Try it out on a Saturday night, and enjoy some great cocktails, good music, and unique atmosphere.
author: Crista R.

description:
I finally visited the vaulted Tonga room. We went for happy hour.  Just be warned that happy hour drinks aren't cheap, I think 7 dollars was typical for a beer or glass of wine.  We ended up drinking mai tais at the bar.  In hindsight, they really packed a punch and are large, so it's almost like a 2 for 1 special.  

It actually seemed a bit stuffy in there, but maybe because it was during the president's cup golf thing. Lots of secret service guys hanging out everywhere.  I'll go back and give it another try.
author: Chris W.

description:
I am more of a fan of the atmosphere but not so much the service or limited menu. I ordered the chicken salad. Smaller portion but for $12 at this place, what can I expect. Most dishes were in the mid $20's. We were just looking for a small bite before a comedy show.

The chicken salad was too sour, too much vinegar? Not my favorite. The soda is not free refill but the iced tea is.

Our waitress seemed rushed, short on customer interactions so she almost came acrossed as rude.  We waited in line to get a seat. Not your typical put your name on the list and have a seat and wait. It was stand in line and they took you when they had room. They had a different line for hotel guests and those who made reservations. So, make a reservation!

All in all, I call this place the grown up rainforest cafe
author: Heather C.

description:
I like this place for the dancing on Thursday nights. The band is super fun and plays music you can swing, west-coast swing, and salsa to. Sometimes they play a Rumba or two. 

This food is edible, but kinda over priced and not that good. It's one of those things you have to bear in order to get a table with a group of people. The drinks are over priced as well, and sometimes they really miss the mark. 

Like I said, I go for the dancing and super fun atmosphere.
author: G F.

description:
Man I love this place.
Where else in the city can you dance around with a lei on and sip a fruity drink with a ridiculous straw? 
Oh and ridiculous cover band in a tiki hut that moves around in the water??
OK so I have never been here sober, but god this place is a gem.
Oh, and never try to kill a spider bowl solo.
author: Kathleen E.

description:
Smells like the log ride at Disneyland in here. 

I had a surprise Birthday party thrown for me here a couple years back. All in all it was a good time. I'm a big fan of fun... and The Tonga room has that. Quality food ehhhhh not so much. 

Albeit I was here for my birthday, so I don't remember THAT much of it, but from what I do remember, the drinks were fun, the food wasn't great, and the rain storm band was playing MJ classics (he had recently passed). 

They have a fantastic gimmicky photographer who got the best of me. He took a group photo, of course I had to buy it, and then he also made matchbooks for each person with their own face on it! What an awesome souvenir huh??? (That is until your roommate uses all of the matches from your matchbook...) 

I'm sure our party was being loud and obnoxious... but so were the servers' shirts! (zing) I felt like this sort of behavior is acceptable at a place such as the Tonga room which has its band on a barge... I mean, I was tempted to pull an "Its a Wonderful Life" and jump in the gigantic pool in the middle of the room.
author: C. M.

description:
this place is so so so expensive, it really is. and the food is really pretty terrible. but i liked the drinks. and its a total experience and wonderful and amazing that it's still around and not torn down like everything else awesome in SF, but really, don't go there hungry, grab an app and two drinks and eat your main meal somewhere else, the food really isn't that good and i love food.
ps! don't miss peeking in the Cirque room and the roof garden. Makes you want to scream from the roof " San Francisco! I'm here! and I'm never leaving!!!"
author: Holly H.

description: This review is only about the Happy Hour.. I stepped backwards into college and not in a good way. The Happy Hour is a massive weird buffet/overcrowding of drunk college kids who were singing, screaming, climbing on tables, it was a mess. We had some drinks, some were good some were ok, but couldn't even talk to each other because it was extremely loud. We looked over the buffet and it smelled and looked like microwaved snacks and people were eating with bare hands out of the containers.. nasty. Our server was nowhere to be found half the time and got our order wrong twice, then i had to hunt her down for my card and tab to close out... I don't know if maybe hitting this after happy hour would have been better, but overall i thought it was not worth the hype that everyone has picked up, including us, from Anthony Bourdain.
author: Amanda R.

description: This place is hella overpriced. But, it's cheesy in the best way possible. The food is tasty and fried, etc. and the drinks are cloyingly sweet. But, the ambiance, think fake thunderstorm every 30 minutes, is so endearing. Much classier than, say, Rainforest Cafe. The space is beautiful. You should go. Once in a while.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I visited the Tonga Room for after work happy hour for the first time on a Friday night and I had a blast! Stepping into the Tonga Room from the historical Fairmont Hotel was like stepping into a different world, imagine a cross between the Pirates of the Caribbean ride at Disneyland and the Rainforest Cafe.

Our group arrived at 6:40 PM, just 20 minutes before the happy hour buffet was about to end so we stocked on some food. For $9.50 you can get very full on just the buffet which contained:

1. Spicy Chicken Wings
2. Some sort of spicy edamame (delicious!)
3. Mixed Fruit
4. Spam, pineapple, and coconut fried rice (also very good)
5. Vegetable Chow Mein (noodles a little over plump)
6. Vegetable egg rolls 
7. BBQ chicken wings (tasty, I ate a lot of these)
8. Macaroni salad 

They have a nice selection of happy hour drinks and I ordered a pina coloda which was yummy. I also sampled the Scorpion for two but it was disgusting. It certainly had a bite to it, but it bit like rubbing alcohol. They brought us these super long straws to drink the shared drinks. 

Service was pretty good, they came by to give us a last call for the buffet line and our drinks came out fairly quick. They also warned us about the $7 entertainment fee around 8 PM (if we left/paid before 9 we'd be okay because the computer automatically adds this charge) so that was great because I'm a cheapo. The water pond area simulates a rain storm about every hour I think, and in the middle there's this boat where a live singer and band provide live entertainment. After happy hour buffet they brought us some asian trail mix. If you come with a group that plans to drink a lot your tab can add up very quick, our party of 7 got charged a mandatory 15% gratuity fee and our total bill came out to $254 after tax (but we order about 16 drinks total). The only complaint I have is that they took about 20-30 minutes to get our check back to us after we had paid. When we left at 9:10 PM there was a short line of people waiting to get in, and I can see why. Overall it's a great place to unwind after work and step into a different world in San Francisco. I highly recommend it as a happy hour destination.
author: Monica W.

description:
Wow....one word: Disneyland. At least that's what it felt like. 

Now I like a little Kitchiness now and then, but this was full on ridiculous for the price you pay...completely overrated and overpriced. Drinks  were not so good. ("Um, was there actually alcohol in this?"). At least give me a stiff drink to help me forget why I'm there spending my money. The food felt like bland cruise ship food (not that I've ever been on a cruise ship, but uh, you could imagine).

Service was not great at all. I went with a group of 7 or so people. Not all of us got the happy hour buffet. A friend of mine grabbed a bite of what I was eating and the waitress charged her for the buffet. Come really, a bite...seriously?

Honestly, would never go there again.
author: Sarah L.

description: Whats not to love, Tacky decor, big citrus drinks with too much garnish, umbrellas in them and kinda watered down.  Don't get me wrong, we had a good time here.  Drinks were pricy and weak.  The buffet was cheap and good, for the price.  Staff was bordering on rude.  But, I suggest everyone go here once, have a big-ass drink, watch the thunderstorm and then don't come back.
author: Steven H.

description: Great little place for a different experience.  Who would have thought this place would be in downtown SF?  Not me.  I thought this was a fun restaurant and would love to bring my wife here just for the kitchiness of it and maybe the dancing.  The food is OK, the fake rain is cool (for the sound) and the BAND is awesome.  Once they started playing I really thought, oh no, don't ruin these classic songs for me.  They didn't.  They nailed each song.  It was great.
author: Brad S.

description:
Tonga Room is a very fun hang-out spot, whether you're on a date, with a few friends or a huge group!

I love fruity, tropical drinks, so this place hits the spot.  I've been here a couple times, and the drinks were just ok at those times.  So, I'm hoping in the future, I'll find something on the menu that I love!

What I really love about this place is the AMBIANCE.  The live band on Friday and Saturday nights does a fantastic job of entertaining and keeping the mood just right.  The ship/dance floor is a great space to get your groove on...and for you young guys out there, beware of the cougars!  Just kidding.  It also "rains" every 30 minutes or so, which gives the place that "tropical" effect.  It's like you're in Hawaii!

Normally, I wouldn't be a big fan of things that exploit the islands or people from there...but for the Tonga Room, I'll make the exception.  It's located inside the beautiful Fairmont hotel, and a chill spot to kick it.  No long lines, big crowds to deal with or fancy dress codes...and I like that!
author: Christine E.

description: Well, I did return for drinks with some family that were visiting.  I thought it would be a fun place to show 'em and have a mai tai in the lava bowl.  Big mistake!  We sat at the bar and ordered the big bowl with four straws.  We all started sipping and came to the conclusion that we couldn't taste any booze.  All four of us!  We called the waitress over to let her know that all we could taste was pineapple juice.  Instead of trying to remedy the situation, she only made it worse.  She said:  the bartender puts four oz. of booze in every one of these, do you want to ask him?  Then she said:  you all must be heavy drinkers!  WTF?!  We said:  take this back and return with our money!  ADIOS!
author: Michael R.

description:
Ugh. Hate giving bad reviews...

-Bad Wait Service
-Mediocre drinks
-Sketchy play at "we need to hold on to a credit card for the whole party to open a tab, but we won't charge it"...only to see that they did run my CC through bc my account indicated a charge the next day  (Who does that in a restaurant- ask for a CC to hold onto for a big party???)

I came here with about 50 people all sitting at our own tables and the good thing was we had separate checks per table.  Great- every table was responsible for their own orders.  Everything else went downhill upon arrival.  The wait staff were so brash, unwelcoming, abrupt, throwing down drinks, and there was never a smile. 

The credit card fiasco was a total turn off.  Boo on Tonga Room.
author: I love t.

description:
This place is only memorable due to the decor. Very campy, tiki-style interiors and fruity island drinks.

The band was sub-par. The dance floor was empty expect for the few middle-aged tourists. Drinks were watered down and covered up in elaborate displays of umbrellas and cherries.

The fake rain, thunder and lightning put this place well beyond kitschy and straight into weird.

$7 "entertainment" charge per person is ridiculous. With 6 people in our group, $42 of the bill went to the lame band floating on a boat in the middle of the restaurant.
author: Ryan M.

description: This place is fun.  The atmosphere is breezy, tropical, and cheesy - but in a good way.  There is a boat that goes back and forth across the room with a band playing on it.  The drinks are good - not stupendous, but good - and the staff is attentive.  It's fun to come here to dance and have an old-fashioned silly good time.
author: Evan B.

description: Great place for a large party! As long as you like to dance and eat great food. Fun Fun Fun. I made reservations in august for our party in December. You must plan ahead but it will be well worth it.
author: Michael K.

description:
over priced for "Chinese" food.

Even though it claims to be Hawaiian, but it really is more like Chinese food, stir fries, or curry dishes, whatever you eat there, they resemble very much like Chinese cooking.

each dish is about $30, so if you order drinks or appetizer, the average bill came to be about $55 per person (without desserts).  $55 per person for Chinese food?  I think that is ridiculous.

the live music is nothing but loud and obnoxious.  I get it that they try to imitate the Hawaiian atmosphere as much as they can, but it was just way too fake, or "trying too hard".

the service was negligent, slow and lack of.

Don't think I would want to go back there again.
author: Shanna W.

description:
OK, happy hour is a pretty good deal as long as you go there hungry. For $9.50 per person for the buffet style appetizers in a hotel, you can't beat that. They had macaroni salad which was good, seaweed salad, spring rolls and the fresh fruit was decent. They had some kind of stir-fried noodles that were kind of on the salty and soggy side, and finally the chicken drumsticks were good, although my friend didn't like it with the sauce on it. Not a lot to choose from, but not a bad selection either. I wonder if they change it up all the time. I ate enough that I was able to skip dinner :P

The cocktails were good and pretty strong for $7.50. For $5 beer wasn't that good of a deal. 

Waitress was friendly but they were kind of busy on a Friday afternoon. There was a line most of the time we were there. We arrived around 5:30pm and had to wait 5-10 minutes to get seated. Would definitely recommend going earlier. I would definitely come here again
author: JET T.

description:
Yes this place is kitschy and a SF landmark, but it's extremely expensive ($10 for a vodka grapefruit), they are are sneaky with the billing (added a $7 cover charge) and the staff is very unfriendly and overworked.

Save it for a very special occasion.  Locals try something else.
author: Michael A.

description:
Dance, prance, and relax
A unique experience
At the Tonga Room
_____


The first thing I thought as I walked into the Tonga Room was, "Wow, this place is awesome!  Why haven't I ever been here before?"

The second thing I thought was, "Holy crap this place is the most expensive bar I've ever seen!  No wonder I've never been here before."

But in all honesty, I recommend it.  My SO couldn't make it this time, and I can't wait to go to the Tonga Room with her so we can dance and relax and have an all-around great time.  I wouldn't be able to go here too frequently because that kind of decadence seems somehow immoral, but it seems like a great place to go with a group of friends once in a while when you get tired of the dive bar scene.

The drinks and food are pretty good--not exactly amazing--but way, way, way^2 too expensive.  Maybe it'd be a good idea to grab a cheap early dinner first, then roll over to the Tonga Room and have some late night snacks while you enjoy the atmosphere.

I hear they're considering tearing it down, and that would be a crying shame.  *tears*  Stay in business long enough for me to go a few more times, okay?
author: Jin D.

description: This might be the coolest restaurant/lounge in the city! As you're walking through one of the most beautiful hotels you turn a corner and fall right into an authentic Hawaiian tiki lounge. The buffet style happy hour leaves you and your wallet feeling full.
author: Mike P.

description:
it's all hype. this place has nothing on tiki ti (http://www.tiki-ti.com/)! 

$7 cover charge on a saturday night, expensive yet bland food, and the drinks were just meh. the band was ok if you're into that thing.. 

i'm not from san francisco but i know never to go here again. my time is better spent at Li-po in chinatown.
author: Lara P.

description:
Okay, so I'm not quite sure what to make of this place. I stayed at the Fairmont for a wedding, and one of the nights my hubbie decided to venture down to the bar for a drink. I will admit that the experience would have been WAY better if we had 5 or 6 previous cocktails in our systems and we were with a group of people, but seeing it was just the 2 of us, I will say my experience was a bit disappointing, but also very entertaining and worth the trip down the elevator. 

You should go to check it out and just have a drink. The 3 person band that's squeezed onto a little boat and floated into the middle of a pool was definite entertainment, and the music wasn't half bad either. 

The perfect way to sum this place up is that its Disneyland-esk....kinda like when you go get your spaghetti dinner at the Pirates of the Caribbean restaurant after riding the ride...same atmosphere only its ironically located in the Fairmont...one of the classiest hotels in the Bay Area. 

Oh, and we didn't eat there, so I can't comment on the food. After reading the reviews on this place, I don't think I ever would.
author: Torstors D.

description: Was there with a friend of mine earlier this year. I had the huli huli chicken, the volcano dessert and a mai tai. Was pretty good but not for the 45 dollars it cost me. Service was decent but a tad slow. The band coming out on the boat into the water is cool. Used to be bossa nova but they changed that...
author: Stephen H.

description:
The Tonga Room Restaurant & Hurricane Bar in the Fairmont Hotel
offers a retro-kitschy tropical atmosphere w/ live entertainment, dancing, & rain storm, replete w/ bamboo & palm frond decorations galore. 

Rainstorms, thunder, & lightning enhance your dining experience & can be controlled at your request for special events/occasions. It is available for private bookings.

The Tonga Room serves Pacific Rim Asian Cuisine along w/ their locally famous Mai Tai. 

The all-you-can-eat buffet is a pretty good deal at $9.50 per person w/ a one drink minimum. Non-alcoholic beverages count. I know, since I don't drink. :) Desserts can be had for $10.00 a pop. 

The Tonga Room features live music Wednesday, Thursday, & Sunday from 8:15 pm to 11pm & Friday & Saturday from 8pm to 12:45am. There's a gleaming dance floor for those who wish to dance the night away to the combination of current hits & classics. If you get onto the floor before 8pm, you avoid the $5.00-7.00 "entertainment fee". 

The Tonga Room is open seven nights a week.
The cocktail lounge opens nightly at 5:00 pm & the dining room at 6:00 pm.
Happy Hour Buffet is available Thursday & Friday 5:00-7:00 pm (excluding holidays).
Dress code is casual. (Hawaiian shirt not included or required). ;P

Santa's Yelper sez: "Stereo-typical island deco, fusion-y Pacific/Asian food, & scary weather!"
author: Tadashi Y.

description: Happy Hour review only. Arrive by 445pm or you might need to wait. They seat only the amount of seating available. No reservations for Happy Hour. The buffet, well it's $10. It's nice for bar fare. The drinks, they're pretty darn good. But you've gotta go there just to experience it. Shout out to MICHAELA...Great server. I think she had power feet as she hauled butt the whole time we were there.
author: Frank R.

description:
This place was really good - live band was REALLY good and played a variety of music, a good amount of people were dancing, the ambiance & decor was beautiful, my food was great & very family-friendly if you have kids.  However, the service was very slow, they seemed to be under-staffed.  For the amount of money we paid for our food and drinks, we assumed that there would be no cover charge if you get a meal there, however they tacked on a $7 per person charge ON TOP of our crazy bill!

Good:
Ambiance & Decor
Live Entertainment
Food
Good for groups & families

Bad:
Service (slow)
Expensive
Cover charge even if you eat dinner there!

If was nice to go there once, but I probably won't go there again.
author: Amy P.

description:
Expensive (bad) drinks.

Cover charge for a bad cover band.

"Interesting" moves on the dance floor.

I want the Tonga Room to be better so I can hang out more, but not sure it's gonna happen.  I really like the cheesy island and rainstorms, just nothing else.
author: Aimee B.

description: Overpriced but lots of fun. Drinks are really strong which ain't a bad thing. Take a cab there, the hill is brutal to walk.
author: Bruce H.

description:
This place is kitschy and serves tooth-rottingly sweet drinks and is horribly wonderful in a lot of ways. But being a gimmicky bar in a hotel,  it is naturally overpriced. The kicker for me is that on top of that, the staff here decided to choose their own tip amount -- charging my card an amount over what I had authorized.

CHECK YOUR ACCOUNT ACTIVITY if you dine or have drinks here -- you know you're going to pay too much for drinks as soon as you walk in the door, but don't let yourself get robbed blind.
author: Jane D.

description:
For a place that may be closing soon, the Tonga Room doesn't let on.  I remember the last days of Don The Beachcomber, Malibu--sitting in thatch roofed booths, in front of picture windows looking out over the surf, and watching the staff lounge about, talking without concern for  the customers nearby, and playing their own top 40 music on the sound system--you could feel the doom.  

Not so at the Tonga.  Yet.

I've done happy hour here, and I would suggest you do too.  You do want to see this place before it closes, and dinner is an extravagance you don't need to experience.  We had the fried Calamari (because Michael Bauer hates the stuff) and the teriyaki veggies for app's, and then did the Wok beef tenderloin, and shrimp with peppers.   I ordered a side of steamed rice.

I'm not a big rice fan, let alone white rice.  Then again, I've ordered at the local Thai places and taken the rice as delivered,   and have eaten every last morsel, marveling at the nutty flavor--how could it be so good?  At the Tonga Room, it isn't.  Bad rice?  

Yes.  Tinny rice actually--flat, starchy, no real flavor.

The beef was tender, moist, and in a thick, mildly salty cornstarch sauce that was vaguely asian.  The shimp was served with big chunks of red and green peppers and yellow onions, and while not exciting, it was at least interesting. All of it was all low-brow Chinatown, at $27.00 a plate.

I must say that I was thrilled to find they do have chimney glasses--the tall cylinder glasses, and my Bombay+soda actually had gin in it, and it came with the lemon twist I ordered (75% of the time  I order it, it either comes with a lime, or a lemon wedge).  Spot on.  And they had Anchor Steam.

Roughly every thirty minutes the thunder would begin, along with the rain, a Tonga Room highlight.   For this reason, I would suggest you do not take lagoon-side seats as we did--sit inland, in the middle set of tables or against the wall--you will have the thrill of a fake storm without seeing the strobes and pipes.

I was wondering about the band.  Given the uncertain future of the space,  I thought perhaps there would be no band, and in any case, it was a wednesday.  And then the stage was drawn across the lagoon, and the band, a trio, boarded.   At this point, I should point out that my last memory of the band--thirty six years ago--on the first time I visited the Tonga Room, was that it was incongruous--way out of place, playing  1970's soft rock.  

Well, it still is.  

They hacked their way through Sade and other late-century pop music, on an over-amplified yet muffled sound system.  It was like being in the Holiday Inn at Topeka International, or in Evanston, Ill.  Don't these clowns get the ambience?  The darkness, the tropical vibe?

Of course not.

Had I been able to keep to my thoughts, looking at the wood carvings, the thatch, the bamboo and the outriggers, it might have ended wistfully.  I might have lingered over a port and dessert.  But with that idiotic trio I couldn't wait to get my check and get the hell out of there.

You should be able to walk out into the fading dusk as we saw it, with the Dashiel Hammett fog shrouding the hill--it nearly made up for the band.

Yes, you need to go to the Tonga Room, just because it's the City's last big "polynesian" restaurant--one of the last of the original tropical joints left on the Coast.  But do the happy hour buffet--dinner is no better and lots more expensive--and leave before the band starts to play--this isn't the Titanic, but the band will definitely sink your night.
author: Paul T.

description:
Wow, a ton of reviews for this place!  No matter, I'll throw mine into the pile.  This review is for dinner in the main restaurant on a Saturday night.

3.5 stars, but if you ask my tiki-loving, Polynesian kitsch adoring, mai tai swilling alter ego, it's a solid 4 stars.  This place is everything it's cracked up to be - a blast from the past where tourist trap meets ironic throwback.  We came after the infamous Bourdain visit and were wise to make a reservation about a week in advance.  After trucking up the hills from the Omni to the Fairmont ("Boot and rally, honey! Boot and rally!") in the chilly mist, we were greeted to a solid line and the strains of music from a tropical paradise awaiting us inside.  Once the host showed up at the desk, we were promptly whisked inside and skipped the line, past folks trying to change their 10pm dinner reservations for an earlier time, and see and be  seen types trying to bribe the front desk for a table.  Really?  Are we in Vegas all of a sudden?

We passed by the band swaying in their little boat atop the former Fairmont pool, crooning old soul classics and parrothead jams - a weird combo, but oddly, it worked.  We liked them so much, we didn't even care about the $7/pp extra charge for the music.  Our waiter came to take our drink order and was brusque at first, which we chalked up to the place being busy.  Turns out that after we ordered our entrees, his mood totally changed - I think that his knowing that we weren't just ordering one appetizer and a few drinks and then bailing made him nicer.  That or the fact that the table of 16 that he was waiting on just left.  Still, it was a whole lot better once he perked up a bit and even eeked out a smile.

The food is wicked expensive for what it is even though it's tasty enough, but I can't say that I ate anything worth the price tag or even worth returning for.  I imagine that many people come here focused on the drinking, so the food oftentimes serves to soak up the tsunami of rum swilling around in their bellies.  We had the appetizer sampler of crispy coconut shrimp (eh), chicken satay in peanut sauce (eh), veggie rolls (eh) and pork ribs that went from eh to ooooo from a little dollop of the accompanying chili garlic sauce.  I was hoping that dinner would be a stunner, but it was pretty average - mongolian beef was tender cubes of filet that were way oversauced, and the Tonga Rice with bay shrimp and sausage was toothsome, but not anything you couldn't make yourself with ingredients from Trader Joe's.  The lava bowl for two that we split was not bad, but easily could have been a drink for one.  And the mai tai was alright, but not the best I've ever had or anywhere near the hype that it gets.  I think our last bites of coconut cream pie were the best bites we had all night, a sweet conclusion to a festive evening.  I was happy to sip away and sing along to the songs from the band, but I don't necessarily think I would return unless it was for a special occasion.  It seems like the perfect place for a birthday or a party with friends, but not somewhere I'd want to regularly lay my hat.  And isn't that the point of a tiki bar?  Shouldn't it be the place where you go to get away whenever you need it?
author: Angela G.

description:
Ok, so let me just discuss how epic the journey is to get down to the Tonga Room.
 
First, you enter the Fairmont Hotel and walk through their "lobby"... I say "lobby" because what it should REALLY be called is "Fairy Tale Palace." Omg... You seriously feel like royalty walking through all these beautiful marble columns, insanely tall floral arrangements, swanky looking couches and sparkling chandeliers. Then you get to the elevator and head down to the level that the Tonga Room's on. Stepping out of the elevator, you're in your average upscale hotel lobby... And then BAM! You get to the Tonga Room and scratch your head in confusion, wondering when you entered Disneyland and why you don't remember having taken a plane ride down to Southern Cali to get here. ;) Omggggg! Huge wooden tiki statues, a giant pool in the middle of the room with a boat on it where the band plays, strings of lights all over, rainstorms that occur sporadically as you sit... And the entrance to the place looks like you're gonna be stepping on board a pirate ship and you seriously wonder when Jack Sparrow is gonna pop his head out and say hi. Lol!

So, 5/5 for ambiance and uniqueness. The rest in a nutshell:

PROS:
- The food was great (though a bit overpriced, but what did you expect? It's San Francisco and you're inside a fancy hotel!).  The rice with the spam and pineapple in it, the tuna, and the shrimp spring rolls were all super delish!
- Drinks were great and super cute... our mai tais came in little plastic coconuts. Aww. :D

CONS:
- The music the band played? Ummm.... Their website says "current" music, but unless current  means late 80s/early 90s soft rock then... Yeah. Their website is a bit misleading. It got preeeeeetty cheesy when the band started playing Billy Joel and Sugar Ray all night, and it sucked leaving the place with corny song lyrics in your head. Lol
- Our waiter was heeeeeeeeeeeerra slow. Oh geez! On three separate occasions, my friend and I wondered if we should just leave because he STILL hadn't brought us the check! :P

BUT! Despite all this, I would definitely recommend that you check this place out, whether you've lived in SF your whole life or are from out of town and are looking for something fun to do in the City. Though the experience does have a few downers, overall you're sure to have a really fun time and a really unforgettable experience.  You totally won't regret going. Do it!!!! :D
author: Shari B.

description: Really retarded place. I cant believe this restaurant is representing Fairmont San Francisco. I wish that the higher higher managers would take time to review this place. Servers have no attention to detail. You're more like an inconvenience than a customer. Servers and hosts need to get serious training about customer service. This place is an embarassment. I heard this place was gonna shut down til anthony bourdain made a mistake of coming in and of course he gets super VIP treatment, which is not always the case w customers coming in, so he thought this was the best place on earth and raved about it. Now they are doing good and back in bussiness.. But with the same service, this place is only good for a little while until people are sick of it again. I say change the staff or get them proper training. Fire people who can't keep up with the job or can't perform what the job entails which are simple things. Your servers and hosts represent your restaurant, if they are shitty, everybody else is. IT ALL STARTS FROM THE TOP. There should be zero tolerance for BS, after all this is the Fairmont hotel.
author: Patty P.

description: This was on the must visit list, as I hear it's absolutely insane inside. However, the wait, in a very uncomfortable hallway in the hotel, was more than an hour on a Friday night. No thanks! We left after waiting for 20 minutes and  not having anyone greet us or tell us an estimate of how long it would be...we had overheard how long the people in front of us were in line. Pfeh!
author: Celeste T.

description:
had their scallop salad-yummy! very fresh! small portion, but we were here to drink. =)

I had the "hurricane" and my fiance had the "zombie" drink! Let me tell you-those drinks have a "knock you out, make you have a good time and slap your mama" amount of alcohol! If that even makes any sense! I didn't even feel the walk down that huge hill in pumps! Instead, my fiance and I were laughing soooo hard the entire way down that hill... 

con-paid $7 each for a cover charge b/c they had a cover band, unfortunately the waiter got the bitter end of that stick with his tip. we're good tippers, but the service was okay. we are in our mid 20's and this was for a bit of an older crowd, but we had fun anyways! =) on the pricey side too!

pro-atmosphere, fresh food, great drinks, we made reservations, so we didn't have to wait in that HUGE line! 

HINT! make reservations and bring plenty of $$. Just like Anthony Bordain said, it is something you have to experience at least once!
author: Cynthia R.

description:
Locals and tourists alike have to experience this San Francisco classic bar at least once in their lifetime! From double dates, happy hour with friends, post wedding after parties, and dinners with my family, I've been here several times and the Tonga Room never disappoints. 

The food is great! The Pacific Rim Asian cuisine has a variety of family style or a la carte items on the menu. Some faves are the appetizer sampler, Huli Huli chicken, Forbidden rice, & the Tonga Volcano for dessert!

The atmosphere resembles the Tiki Room but is more of an "adult Disneyland" between the island decor and the wide variety of fun fruity drinks on the menu. Some signature faves include Mai Tais and Hurricanes. A great group drink to order is the infamous scorpion bowl! While dining, guests will also experience "a rainstorm" every 20 minutes or so and have the opportunity to overlook the lagoon (which actually used to be the old Fairmont pool). By far, the best part is when the band performs songs, on a boat in the middle of the restaurant, ranging from Bobby Darin, Frank Sinatra, The Eagles to other more modern day hits!  {And I promise you will blush when the lead singer (complete with his striped fedora and all) passes out "special alohas" to the crowd}!

On a side note, if you visit during the holiday season, it's fun to also check out the decorations upstairs in the Fairmont lobby, including the life size ginger bread house, tree, and nutcrackers!
author: Carla V.

description: I couldn't really decide whether to rate this place a 3 or 4 star, but I'll go ahead give it the upgrade to 4 star due to the unique nature of the interior. The place is designed to look like you are in some caribbean getaway complete with a floating island in the middle of a pool where the band plays, canoes hanging in the air, island huts, and rain coming down into the pool every 30 minutes. Tonga is located in the swank Fairmont hotel. To get to it, you have to walk straight into the lounge area and take the winding stairs down. The only real complaint I had was that the drinks are horribly expensive at $10-17 a pop and there is a sneaky $7 cover charge per person added to your bill that no one notifies you of when you are seated.
author: Henry W.

description:
This place is HILARIOUS and should only be experienced once in a lifetime for a special occasion.  

-The fun factor is 5 stars: Great ambiance, excellent cover band (which plays on a boat in the middle of the restaurant where it rain with lightening every 30 min. or so), and a dance floor.

-The food is 3 stars: Its good but not great.

-The drinks are 5 stars: Decent prices and mixed STRONG! We got the lava bowl for a party of 4 to start off with.  It came in a big pineapple bowl with four straws... very fun.

-The price is EXPENSIVE!  

Like I said, once in a lifetime experience and you have to get drunk.  TONS OF FUN!!!!!! Eat and drink your ass off to a great live band.

P.S. Joe Montana was there when I went which was an honor.
author: Julian P.

description: I'll give it two stars because they've been doing there thing at the Tonga Room for far longer than the Rainforest Cafe. Their so called Southeast Asian comfort food is ridiculously over priced! In a town with such an enormous Asian influence I expected more from the menu, in quantity and quality. Of the four cocktails we ordered the Mai Tai and the Singapore Sling were our favorite. This place is highly lauded by my grandfather and rightly so since nothing has changed since  the 1940's when he was courting my grandmother. The old world nostalgia is probably the best part of the venue. If you want some serious Asian comfort food don't go here. I would have a drink to say I did and run for the door.
author: Travis G.

description: Ok. Just a large, famous (thanks to Bourdain) tiki bar. Wish they had appetizers available late. Rain is kinda cool. Band was playing when we went. Drinks are strong but not anything special. They can be acquired at other similar tiki bars.
author: Raul S.

description: What a disaster.  30 min wait and the restaurant was only a third full during the holiday season.  Food options were minimal and nothing really for kids.  Only reason I am giving it 2 stars is because the overloaded servers had a good attitude considering.
author: Christian M.

description:
Great service! Great atmosphere!
Food was good but very overpriced!
The band was good but obnoxiously loud!! We all had to tear chunks out of our drink napkins to make ear plugs to just enjoy our meal!!! We definitely couldn't have any kind of conversation with someone sitting across the table... AND we had to pay $7 each for the band just to have our ears tortured during dinner!!
author: Ron K.

description:
Celebrated a friend's birthday here. The food was really great. The beverages were not as great as they were hyped up to be. The dance floor was packed which was fun, but made dancing somewhat difficult and sort of smelly!

All in all had a good time :)
author: Negar P.

description:
I'll give this to them...the atmosphere was cool and the service was good, but it all went down hill from there. 

4 of us went there for dinner last Sunday night.

1) The Fairmont validates at the Laurel Court Restaurant, but not at the Tonga Room -2 stars for $30 parking for 2 hours

2) The food was extremely mediocre at best. The Huli Huli chicken was the highlight of our 3 course meal for 4...and I could have made better at home. The mongolian beef, that looked great on the description was an extremely odd cut of beef or it was just cooked very strangely...it was gross. 

3) It was NOT cheap either - the meal for 4 was around $230 and totally not worth even $60. 

Fun atmosphere, but we will not be back.
author: Michelle N.

description:
In most reviews, I judge based on price vs what I get.  This time, I'm not going to focus so much on that.  It is on the pricier side for what I would expect to pay for the meal (about $60 ish for two mediocre dishes), but we were going more for ambiance and it more than made up the difference. 
There was an incredibly long line down the hallway on the Sunday evening my fiance and I went - thankfully we made a reservation.  We arrived at just the right time because the 'storm' had just started.  Every ten minutes or so 'rain' sprinkles into a pool in the center of the dining area with a storm sound effect and dim lights.  This place has a very tropical feel.  We ordered a tropical drink in the coconut cup which was very delicious.  Our food came out next - Mongolian Beef and I had some sort of chicken stir fry, both with a side of rice.  There was MORE than enough of both dishes but the flavor wasn't out of this world.  

The entertainment started at 8 and we were just able to catch the beginning bit.  They were a very talented trio who performed on a little boat in the center of the pool. 

I think what draws so many people here is Anthony Bourdain's recent revelation that this was the best place on Earth or something.  I don't know if I'd go that far, but it is a little different slice of San Francisco.
author: Amber E.

description: I would give them a two star, but I'll give them the benefit of the doubt, since there was a wedding there when we showed up. The place has really awesome decorations and ambience, but the drink were pretty over priced considering their size. Once I saw their "bowl" they served the punch in, there was NO way I was willing to shell out the $20+ for the "drinks for two". There was a live band playing in the middle of the pool on a tiki themed raft, but again... ALL WEDDING SONGS!!!! Not good for dancing unless you were already hammered, which since we showed up at 11:00, most of the guests already were! They say they close at 1, but they shut down the music at 12:15 and blasted the lights up and ruined the previously said fun ambiance. Again, maybe it's because there was a wedding there BUT, maybe there should be a disclaimer for the non-private party guests to not waste the "$7 live entertainment fee" which we were NOT charged, but I pity anyone who was!!!
author: Cassie O.

description: I went here for a friends birthday, the atmosphere was beautiful but with the fake rain and thunder sound effects it seemed a lil themed kind of like the rainforest cafe.  However the wait staff was very friendly and helpful. The drinks where fruity and the food was salty.  The food wasnt horrible but not worth the price i paid.  Another thing i thought was tacky about this place is that even though we had dinner we were still charged a $5 cover charge to eat there.  I will probably never come back to this place, the foods not good and the drinks suck.
author: Ernesto Z.

description: We had a very fun time during our stay at the Fairmont. One night we went down to the lounge and there was a band on the boat in the pool and everyone was dancing and having a great time. We got a drink meant for four and it was strong and magical. I love the long straws, the strong drinks and the retro them that the place has been designed with. Its a shame though that there isn't a pool because of the lounge in the hotel.
author: Linden G.

description: Try the Mongolian Beef! I was amazing at how good it was. Not sure why I wasn't expecting much, but it made the experience all the better. Floating gazebo with a band upon a converted swimming pool? Check. Super-sugary hawaiian themed drinks? Double-check. It's expensive, but you won't forget it.
author: Michael H.

description:
To be fair the last time I was at the Tonga Room I was 4 sheets to the wind when I arrived.  So my impression of the place was somewhat blurred by several beverages at other establishments.  

But maybe thats kind of telling.  First off the place is surprisingly dark.  Not only are all the walls a dark color but there are very few lights.  It just creates a slightly Tenderloin dive bar kind of vibe that I don't think is appealing to everyone.  Add to that the regular assortment of colorful characters that visit this kind of place and you've got a novelty to visit once with out of town friends.  Not a regular establishment for a native.  

Yes - I know.  The rain shower is cool.  But come on people!  The rain shower is cool like 5 times.  After that it gets kind of annoying.  

If the Tonga Room closes I'll be disappointed.  I'm not sure where else I'll find a indoor rain shower.  But thankfully this is San Francisco and colorful characters can be found all over.
author: Peter C.

description:
Stopped in to this famous SF institution, hoping to have a fun experience and see what the hype is about. 
Having tried unsuccessfully more than 1-2 weeks in advance for dinner reservations, gave up and just stopped into the bar for a cocktail, just to say we'd been there.
The (curt, unhelpful) hostess informed us the "bar was full", but that we could wait for a table. 
We asked if we could go inside and wait in the bar area, and have a drink "standing up" to wait for a table.  "No, you have to wait out here for a table".
Us "Is there a wait list if we do that?"
Her "No." 
Us "So.... we can go inside and get a drink, but we can't wait INside for a table, and we can't bring our drinks OUT here while we're waiting for a table to open up where we just ordered our drinks?"
Her "I suppose"
Us  "And if we go inside and stand to have a drink, and see a table in the bar open up, can we take it?" 
Her "No, you have to wait out here for a table." 
Us "But.....there's no 'wait' list, and we can't have drinks other than standing at the bar???" 
Her  "Well it IS after 5pm.  We get busy."    (unsolicited comment, why she thought it necessary to be snotty to us, have no idea.) 

The hostess was very unaccomodating, very cocky, and very unhelpful.  She seemed pretty "judgy", too, and was really seeming to discourage us from even patronizing the place.
This place just seemed stuck-up, way too trendy, and the front line staff too snotty for my taste. 
I doubt we will be back - - we can live without that kind of experience, I don't care how many tropical flowers & toucans & ukeleles they have.  
Especially when we saw the food & drink pices....maybe they think they can afford to be snooty to us riff-raff.  

Meh.  I'm over it.
author: J J.

description: Tropical cocktails and fake rain.  Love it!
author: Kristine M.

description:
This only gets 2 stars b/c of the decor and the "atmosphere".  The drinks were way over priced and the service staff were old and unfriendly.

They seemed jaded by the "tourist" type of bar patron and didnt really care about delivering proper service.

I will definitely not be going back.
author: David W.

description: You need to go here and order a Hurricane.  The old Pacific Island relics will charm you.  The umbrella drinks will enebriate you.  The tikis will impale you. If you're a white girl, you'll think you are Ginger or Marianne... if you're not, you will still love this place.
author: Julie B.

description: BEWARE - Just like Amy G. who went to Tonga one week earlier, I also went with a large group that paid more than 1/2 cash and the rest on 3 cards. The waiter, who'd already been super slow and unattentive, came back without the cash and stated we had given him less cash then we did and still owed more. None of us were drunk and 3 different people in my party added up the bill on calculators. One of us was charged the wrong amount on her card, but it was reversed and corrected. Another friend was overcharged and is planning to call the restaurant.
author: Erin C.

description:
We went to Tonga room recently for a friend's birthday, because we thought we would have some happy hour fun in its famous "kitschy" environment. Needless to say, we didn't.

First, there was a line a mile long in front of the door, ostensibly because the place was "past capacity". NOT. The place wasn't even a quarter full. I didn't think a 2nd-rate basement restaurant would stoop to the old conceit of keeping people out of the club to make it look full  - but apparently management didn't get the memo that we are in a recession. 

We finally get in and  order a drink from the bar to save some time (our friends who had gotten in ahead of us already warned us of the slow and snooty service). The bartender looks at us and says "are you with that table? Because if so you have to order from the server". Again, are we or are we not in a recession? And do you or do you not want our money?

We get to the table and the waiter appears in 10 minutes (had any of us been experiencing a medical emergency we would be dead by then). We order drinks and ask that it be put on a separate tab so we didn't end up with 1,000 drinks on one credit card. Surprise surprise, the server (who maddeningly called me "Miss" the entire time) refused. "It's our policy, miss" he says. I then ask if I can just order from the bar so that I can just pay for my drink. "You can order from there, miss, but if you order from there, you can't come back to the table". REALLY? I can't come back to where my 20 friends are standing, waiting for you to take their money, just because I have ordered a drink from the bar? "That's right, miss."

And if that wasn't bad enough - the drinks were weak and overpriced even for Happy Hour standards,  the "buffet" was oily and had the variety of a McDonald's kids menu, and did I mention the service was inexcusably, epically terrible?

Keep your fake thunderstorms and rainshowers, Tonga Room. If I wanted to get hosed, I'd use my lawn sprinkler.
author: Michi V.

description:
We came here after the place was recommended by a friend. The location was very nice and memorable, but overall the place felt to be a little above "okay".

First off, the food was so-so. Perhaps we came from the wrong occasion, but it felt more like food that should have been served as a compliment to an evening of heavy drinking... rather than a dinner course as we had planned. The place was also very pricey, not just in terms of the food and drinks but also the cover charge because there was a band playing. The service was also very poor, with infrequent visits and a general lack of attention paid to us.

Again, though, the place excels at its decor and atmosphere. The tiki lounge look is excellent, and they have a dancing area as well to satisfy your urge, although the age group participating was more family oriented than we would have expected.

All in all, it was a decent place to visit once, but its not something we are likely to return to.
author: Sami R.

description: We arrived at the tail-end of happy hour -- mai tais were $8 each, I think. The indoor thunder/lightning and rain began at around 7, and the band went on at 8.
author: Chad S.

description: Food is not good, but we would come back here for the great entertainment - the band, the bar, the tropical thunder and rain. Its like being back in Hawaii.
author: Henry C.

description: Drinks are great! Nice and strong, but food was terrible. We ordered the butterfish and nothing buttery about it at all. We would've been better off spending our money at Roy's. Highly over priced for the tasteless food they brought out. Good scenery and environment.
author: JujUb Z.

description:
When you first arrive, it's unclear that there are two separate lines before you enter: left if you have reservations, right if you don't. Some signage -- and a less harassed host -- would be helpful. It was frustrating that they let the line build up when there were clearly tons of open tables. But, we were allowed in at last, and the short wait was worth it!

You have to see this place in the context in which it was originally conceived; it has a long history. The setting is outrageous, the drinks are strong and delicious, and the band floating in the pool is awesome. If you come with an open mind (and wallet), you'll definitely have a good time.
author: Anna R.

description:
Been in love with this place since the first time i stepped in it. Why? The tropical atmosphere. Being an 'island girl' from asia, this place is so cool. Songs of the 70's played by the live band, intermittent tropical rain just gives me that home feel. 

This place makes me feel so 'at home', I have to admit that each time I come here, I turned into a lush, lol! Hey, I feel happy when I am there, what do you expect! 

I am looking forward to my next visit there...and party again!
author: Elly G.

description: As a business owner in the restaurant/hospitality industry, I was very surprised by the very poor level of service from a reputable establishment.  The initial service was as to be expected for a Friday night happy hour in SF, but that is not where my complaint lies.  Instead the service I received in resolving a billing dispute was the issue.  In addition to the cost of the five happy hour dinners, they charged an additional amount exceeding $700.  I called the restaurant the following day to inquire about the charge and I was brushed off quickly and rudely by Kim, and finally got in contact with the manager (Michael) a few days later who was equally uninterested with helping me with this matter.  Thankfully American Express isn't this incompetent, they were able to handle the matter immediately after a short investigation. The Tonga room's unwillingness to assist with this disputed charge has unfortunately left me in a position where I will not return.  I cannot recommend this location to my friends or family due to the very poor service.
author: Jong Y.

description: Snobby, rude service at the bar. They charge for happy hour appetizers. Came once and likely won't be back.
author: James W.

description:
(Disclaimer: I may have been nicer on this review than I should have been due to my cold.)

I came here on a Thursday night when I had an awful cold. I couldn't smell anything, I couldn't taste anything, I couldn't care less. But since the bill was being taken cared of, I figured I might as well get some dinner in my stomach.

I get to the Tonga Room and there's a line out the door. I asked a guy (who probably thought he was going to get lucky that night with the girl he was with) what the line was for because I didn't believe it was to get into this restaurant. It was! So, I went up to the host and told him I had a reservation with a party and I didn't even have to wait in line. When I got in, barely half of the restaurant was filled with people so they probably just didn't have enough coverage for the evening. 

I liked how the Tonga Room looked--dark with huts and a pool of water in the middle of the room. There's even lightning and rain every so often which was nice because I love the rain!!! I think they do live music because there was a little band stand in the middle of the water. How they get to that stand is beyond me.

The staff is pretty friendly, but with the little coverage, the service was somewhat of a wait. (Keep in mind, barely half the tables were seated.)

I got a lemonade and ribs (Weak, I know! I didn't think I should have alcohol in my system while I was sick). The ribs, or at least what I could taste, were what I would describe as teriyaki-ish. Not a fan. The carbonated lemonade came with a slice of pineapple and cherry, which made me happy. 

All in all, not a bad place. Doesn't burn a hole in your wallet. I think the food's okay and the drinks are good.
author: Maureen B.

description:
BEWARE: Visited the Tonga Room for the first time last week (brought two out of town visitors). Tasty drinks made up for the less-than-friendly service UNTIL I checked my credit card statement this morning. 

We payed for 1/2 of our bill with cash and the other 1/2 with a card. I signed a receipt for my portion of the bill, only to discover today that the $40 in cash we paid, mysteriously disappeared and the entire bill was charged on my cc. 

Waiting to get a call back from them, the person at the front desk didn't seem too concerned. Glad I caught this myself, but bummed out by the shady person who "forgot" about the $40 paid in cash. Sad to say, I won't be back.
author: Amy G.

description: As long as you are not budget conscious, you will have an excellent time here. Enjoy a big drink to share, get some delicious apps and enjoy the atmosphere. You will forget you walked into a hotel at all.
author: Robert M.

description: Ah, the Tonga Room. Of coarse brought here by Tony, anyways arrived mood was great overall. Drinks were delicious but our waitress was horrible.
