We specifically asked her if the buffet was an all day thing, she said yes, anyways she comes back 15min later and says, "Oh, you should probably get some more food, they close it down in five min." This after already purchasing the meal. Yeah... After that i wasn't really feeling it. Go for a drink though pretty good!
author: Genesis R.

description:
I was really excited to try this place for my friends 25th birthday. I had heard from friends that it was a San Francisco institution and a "must do". I definitely woun't give it the same praise.

I made reservations through open table and then had to extend it over the phone because I had 11 people, which is more than the maximum number on open table. It was definitely  nice that we had reservations because the line out the door was insane. We were seated within moments and our drink orders were taken. Drinks are a little pricey, but anything that with dragonfruit in it's name usually is. Plus, the drinks are usually never my biggest complaint at a place..

Now for the food. I tried to order the dumplings for the table as an appetizer, but the waiter said it wouldn't be enough food and offered the meet platter filled with ribs, coconut prawns, chicken satay, and other goodies. The group decided it would be too much food, plus a full meal, so we passed. When we began to order our entrees, we kept asking, 'is this too much for one person?', 'will it be enough to share?'. The waiter was very clear that one dish would not be enough for two people. I ordered the hot pot and a side of rice. This was by far the largest pot of food I have ever seen (and for $27 + rice, I'd sure hope so). I had two servings and it looked like I didn't even touch it. The same with everyone else. Each plate could have easily fed 3 hungry people. I find it very disappointing when a waiter doesn't take my best interest into consideration. Why couldn't he have shared that the portions were so large? I know it seems silly to complain that portions are too big, but our bill was $70/person and most people only had 2 drinks. 

So yes, $70 was way more than I wanted to spend for two drinks and a slightly above average meal.
author: Erin A.

description:
I did not eat any food at the Tonga Room, so I can't speak about that, but I did come here on a Sunday night with a group of girlfriends for a fun night out.  We had been talking about going to the Tonga Room forever and we finally did it.  

The decor is so over-the-top, the dance floor is a giant ship-type thing with the very nice wood floor designed to seem like the deck of a ship.  There are real masts from ships on either side with some rigging and cool nautical antiques- all from ships that sailed in the SF bay of course.  There are giant Tiki statues and tables underneath thatched roofs.  The band plays some island-loungy versions of everything from Frank Sinatra to Van Morrison to the Girl from Ipanema.  It is perfect to get out there and have a dance- especially with a date.  We agreed that it was a fantastic date spot, as well as a great place to bring kids.  Seems like that wouldn't work, but it does.  It looked like a great time for kids- they can have a crazy fancy virgin drink and dance around on the ship.  It was really cute to see parents dancing with their kids during the band's first set.  Later on it was more of a couples dancing type thing, although a couple of us girls got out there for the island band version of a BeeGees song.

The drinks taste wonderful and the presentation is everything you could ever ask for.  The winners in our group were the drink that comes in a fresh pineapple, the pina colada, the Bora Bora Horror (in tiki monkey cup), and the lava bowl.  They were a bit expensive, but the experience made it all worth it.  Come here if you want to have fun and put tiki umbrellas in your hair and enjoy a fake indoor thunderstorm!
author: Erika W.

description:
Stop #2 for Friday night's Happy Hour. 

I used to love the Tonga Room. I still do, in a nostalgic way, but it's not the same. I used to come here for their $3 happy hour buffet & cheap tropical drinks. I still think that the HH buffet is a bargain at $9.50 (esp. on Nob Hill) but we skipped it this time. No time for eating! I just had a beer but my friends ordered the Scorpion Bowl for 2. Now I am sure that these used to be bigger, they are still served in a bowl but it's pretty tiny. They give you 2 ridiculously long straws that make it seem like you are sharing a drink for 2 when it's really the same size as any other drink on the menu. 

The staff is overly unfriendly & we had to practically beg for a bowl of mixed nuts. Then they gave us our bill without asking if we wanted anything else.  

I was so sad when I heard they might close the Tonga Room.  Now I don't really care much either way.
author: Erin S.

description:
This is a review for drinks and atmosphere only.

I met up with some friends at the Tonga Room during the recent holiday weekend. I used to come here a ton for happy hour over ten years ago.   Not much about the restaurant seems to have changed since then with the exception of the prices.  (The HH buffet was $5 back then.)

I sampled a mai tai, a pina colada and a strawberry daiquiri from the drink menu. The mai tai was great but the pina colada was exceptional.  All three were strong.  The service was indifferent, but that is to be expected at a place that caters primarily to tourists.

The thunder and rain seems to happen only once an hour now, but it's all fun. Many of the clientele this evening seemed to be on their honeymoon. Several couples were wearing leis.

If you come here with the right attitude, you can actually have a good time.  Pretend you're on vacation and just go with it.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description: This place was recommended to us by a good friend, what a cool place! Having lived in Hawaii for many years I usually don't have a great appreciation of old school tiki themed places. I prefer just to go to the true source, but after taking in some of the history of it & realizing it was a place for Soldiers to get R&R in the City, I was very charmed by it. It's pricey & even pretty hidden actually. The hours are even odd.  But who can deny that a pool converted into a tropical destination with a band playing on a raft and even
author: Nicole H.

description:
well after coming here for years i finally decided to write a review.

I love this place, the decor always reminds me of the restaraunt that you float through in the Pirates of the Caribbean and the Enchanted tiki room at disneyland, but for adults.  

This place is one of the oldest if not the last of the OG tiki bars in the states.  I mean where can you go wrong with a hotel pool room that was coverted to a bar/restaraunt just after WWII? Thats 1945 for you non-history minded folks. The pool is still there and has a floating houseboat which features a cover band playing the smooth hits of the 70's and 80's. YES!

The drinks, well thats the reason you go here, they have all the classic Tiki Drinks from Pineapple Royale's (served in a fresh Pineapple), Bora Bora Horror (for banana lovers) my personal fave the Singapore Sling, Scorpions (gigantic) Lava Bowls (gigantic), Zombies, and a whole bunch of other super sweet-tiny umbrellas-cornucopia of fruit-massive amounts of rum in crazy glasses concoctions for you to enjoy!

The food is asian or pan-asian depending on what you order and while not the greatest believe me your not going there for the food only. Its an experience.  Thurs and Fri from 5-7 they have the happy hour extravaganza so for 9.50 plus a drink you get all you can eat appetizers, which are surprisingly pretty dam tasty.

Fellas if your looking for a first date experience or just looking for a change of scenery this is the place! 

So whisk your girl away to the tropics for the night! remember it does rain every hour or so but no need for an umbrella, there's bound to be a few in your drink.
author: Cooper M.

description: Oh yeah!!! Tiki fans unite!   The drinks are strong, the nights are long an the band is floating about in a boat!!!! Whats not to like????!!!!!!
author: Michael H.

description:
The tonga room does its job. 

1. Greeting people at the front who are sitting and waiting.
2. Serving fairly strong but overpriced drinks
3. Decent "tiki" type food, nothing to complain about though it's expensive.
4. Retaining the Tiki atmosphere, to a T
5. Crowd control
6. Decent happy hour with lots of ribs and stuff

The waitresses aren't that great, but they are perpetually slammed. As I was entering this evening several women were leaving saying "this was the worst experience of my life." 

Listen people, this is an old San Francisco institution, crap included. Don't go there expecting a friggin Michelin experience, ok? You don't rate, anyway. Find solace in a pu pu platter and some fake rain, and a band that plays oldies in the middle of a swimming pool. Thank god for this place. It's not overly crowded, you can almost hear the people you're with, and folks of all ages still enjoy it 40 years later. Get over yourself. xo
author: Roxmarie M.

description: I went here for my birthday because I really miss Hawaii and wanted to feel tropical as I couldn't make it "home" this or last year.  The rain was cool, I had a lovely table on the water, my mini baked alaska was a nice touch but the food was at best mediocre.  Drinks were yummy though.
author: Synnora B.

description:
I've come to enjoy the atmosphere of this place 3 times now, and I think it will be years before I think to go again, if ever.  Reason being:  the food doesn't compete.  It's just chinese food.  It doesn't stand out.  It doesn't thrill.  And, I'm sorry, for an average $25 a plate it better make me sing.  

Of course the environment is unique, fun, and entertaining.  The band is pitch perfect and on time note for note.  Them playing on a mobile craft is a pretty impressive touch.  The set list choice will definitely get you on the dance floor, but if you're just sitting at your table and trying to hear what your company is saying to you then forget it.  The band is way too loud and it becomes a shouting competition that gets old and annoying super quick.  The band seems to play for about 30 mins., 15 min. break, then the cycle repeats.  In my opinion (which is greatly influenced by the decibel overload) it's too much.  

Making a reservation seemed to not matter AT ALL.  There's a line if you have a res and a line for walk-in.  My girlfriend and I noticed the people in front of us (before we realized there was a separate line for reservations) were sat at the same time as us, and we showed up right at our 8:30 reservation.  So, no point it seems.

The drinks here are pretty tasty.  Dark rum is a good way to go and fits perfectly with the theme and decor.  Your wait staff are very nice, buuuuuut don't seem to know a lick of english and we found ourselves repeating our orders more than a couple of times as confirmation was a challenge.  

But, the food.  Like I said I've been here 3 times over the years and it has never made me happy I chose it.  Once we ordered different meat dishes that came with vegetables, but when it arrived it was all vegetables that some meat accidentally fell into...or so it looked like.  I remember we made a remark to the manager and they were very cool in giving us a significant credit.  We returned on that gift and had another meal there.  The chef staff was noted to not flake on the protein.  This third time our mongolian beef and Afi chicken came out in only 5 mins. of ordering.  In that quick preparation they musta forgotten the special ingredients that justified the $26-$27 charge per plate because nothing really said anything to us about these plates.  For a restaurant to go so above and beyond to create a specific motif you would think they would emphasize the flavor of the food in correlating fashion.  They don't.  In none of my 3 ventures have I walked away thinking, "this restaurant serves a distinct spectrum of food and flavor."  

My advice?  Go for the drinks, music, and dancing.  That's definitely worth your money.  The food is not special and only somewhat good at best, but for the price it's completely unworthy.
author: Nick J.

description:
So today in the Talk threads, I come across a post that mentions the Tonga room might be demolished to make room for new condos:

http://www.yelp.com/topic/san-francisco-save-the-tonga-room

I'm not even a diehard fan of tiki bar culture but I do appreciate its kitsch once in a while (actually, I was here a couple weeks ago having some delicious rummy cocktails and sharing a lava bowl) but I'm sad at the thought of this place possibly going away. I mean, it's so cheesy, fun and part of SF history at the same time and how can you not like the indoor rainshower?
author: kristin e.

description: Love this place.  Good tropical drinks, good food and great dancing.....I can't tell you how many times I come here....that many!
author: Kenneth G.

description:
I don't know what was worse: the food, the service, or the place in its entirety.

This place is so overhyped and overrated. I've heard my friends and Yelpers rave about this place so me and my family decided to go here for my uncle's birthday.

Uh, no. Bad idea. We went for happy hour, thinking the buffet would have more selections or at least be delicious since it is the Fairmont and their valet service was 50 bucks. The $9.50 all you can eat buffet with one minimum drink should be worth it, right? Wrong. Horribly wrong. The Tonga room sounds Tongan or at least tropical but they served Chinese food. Greasy spring rolls, rubbery chicken wontons, pork chow mein that didn't have traces of ANY kind of meat, and some rice with some fancy name like macadamia pineapple rice or something like that. The best combination I could figure out was the shrimp chips dipped in the pina colada sauce. One star for that.

The drinks were awfully disgusting. I got the pina colada and believe me, I've been ordering pina coladas for a long time now and this place serves the worst! The 60-year-old bartender mixed it in 5 minutes so I guess he used some premade cocktail mix and added the alcohol in it. Ugh. Nasty. I'd rather drink water.

I think this bar/restaurant caters more to the older crowd rather than the youngins like me, which is probably one of the reasons why I didn't enjoy my experience here. I'm 21 and I felt really young when I walked through the place. Everyone else was at least 20 years older than me, not that that's a bad thing though. I just wish they'd do something fun with the place. With the renovation coming up, I sure hope they'll change things around a bit.
author: Michelle B.

description:
The Tonga Room is the zeitgeist of kitschy fun.  

Tiki mugs, bowls of tropical drinks with ridiculously long straws, fake plastic leis, a shipdeck dance floor, and a band on a boat (the guy's a human jukebox!) floating in the indoor pool.

Some might think that only God can make rain, but oh no... make that God AND THE TONGA ROOM!!

Enjoy!
author: .caroline. ..

description:
So I had been wanting to visit the Tonga Room for a while and finally got around to doing so. Based on pictures of the entrees posted by other Yelpers compared with their menu prices, I could see how some people claimed that they were over-priced. To get around this we decided to go for Happy Hour. The first time we tried there was a line and the manager said that we couldn't get in unless we had a reservation. We decided not to wait. 
I went home and made a reservation for the next Happy Hour on OpenTable, even though the Tonga Room website said Happy Hour was "first come, first serve"...contradictory much?
Upon arriving for my reservation, I had a little trouble getting the table even though I had a reservation and the bar area was only half full. It took forever to get a server to greet us and get our drink order. Good thing it was a buffet. The food was pretty good (besides a hair in the noodles) and the drinks were great! Don't count on getting too drunk though, the server doesn't bother coming around to your table but once every 1/2 hour. I guess that should be expected considering the Happy Hour prices?!?
The thunder, lightning and rain were cool, but I've definitely written this place off as one of those one time experience sort of places! So glad I didn't waste my money on a full course meal!
author: Daisy A.

description: If you want something called "Saturday Night Fever", this is the place. I recently went here, and the restaurant looked like it was an 8 star restaurant. Have you ever seen a band in a restaurant on a moving boat with a waterfall? I don't think so. If you ever go to Fairmont, just swing by here and see what I mean.
author: Dario D.

description: I love this bar sooo much!! Make sure you make reservations otherwise the line can get ridiculous.  Even with reservations, there was a slight wait, but in my eyes it was worth it!  I went on a Saturday night and there was a live band that was doing a lot of Earth Wind and Fire (who I love) covers, and they were actually pretty good! Had everyone singin and jammin at their tables!  The food is not great... Actually it's borderline bad. But the drinks, the decor, and the ambience make up for it!  It is truly a great place to just go and have fun!
author: Taylor B.

description:
With prompting of friends I returned to Tonga Room.The 50 year-old funky Asian band did 70-80's covers (middle-to-upper class white people wedding music) along with choreographed shoulder dips.  Even the lead's Michael Jackson falsetto hit the right notes. I liked when they'd start playing and the 'rain' would fall gently. It became increasingly humid while I watched several wholesome-figured people do some sexy hip rolls.

One of the guys in our group kept swinging from the 'boat' ropes. He nearly kicked several people in the head and mysteriously was never thrown out. Maybe it his convincing story we were all from the south and he was fresh outta jail. Plus, if he didn't have ropes like that at home so when would he ever get to do this? It's a solid argument.

The drinks still taste like burning. Our waiter was a sweet kid. I left feeling dizzy, but happy.
author: Angie O.

description:
My friends and I had to go here once before it closed. In a nutshell, don't come here for the food or you will be disappointed. It's pretty expensive, and you're paying for an experience.

That said, hanging out at the Tonga Room was like crashing a retirement party. The music is so awful. I was expecting The Girl From Ipanema and Copacabana but instead I got Billy Joel and My Girl, what? The music was less tiki party and more bar mitzvah. My expectations weren't really high, it's just sad because someplace so campy really has a lot of potential, a band with a great repertoire of covers could totally turn things around. Seriously, even an Elvis impersonator would be a huge improvement. 

I ordered the most ostentatious drink they had, it came in a pineapple but I was disappointed to find not much of the actual pineapple had been carved out so my drink was probably half the size of my friends' drinks and $2 more. I paid $24 for some really bland (and definitely not spicy as the menu suggested) chicken, and had to pay extra for rice. I could have had better in Chinatown for $9. 

We were here on a Friday night and it was maybe 1/3 of the way full with tourists and sad looking blind dates and plentiful camera phone flashes. I guess that's why it's closing, now I can say I've been there once.
author: Beth D.

description: I really wish I could rewind my Saturday night and go elsewhere. The food was lousy and they must have paid Anthony Bourdain a ton of money to mention this spot on his show. That's the only thing keeping this place in business. Too expensive and it feels like a Disney tourist trap. Plus, even after spending a fortune on food & drink they want us to pay a cover per person. Totally embarrassed that I suggested this. What a waste.
author: Elysa S.

description:
Are you kidding me Fairmont?

http://www.boingboing.net/2009/02/22/tonga-room-san-franc.html

Is this some sort of stupid joke?  You're going to kill this for multi-million dollar condos in the midst of the worst real estate market of our lifetimes?   How dumb are you?
author: Beau G.

description:
This is SAN FRANCISCO HISTORY, people!  .....at it's finest.

Buried below ground in the Fairmont  ......the giant Tiki welcomes
you to this dark and moody vintage Tiki Bar..... 
Quite fabulous and large in scale.
Dinner there can be pricy.....but.....their Happy Hour is
one of the City's best!  Half price drinks like .......Scorpian's.....Mai Tai's....
Pina Colata's......  Have one.....leave happy....  Have two....leave really happy!  Plus ......a Pupu Buffet.  .....around 9 bucks a person.  The waitresses wear beautiful kimonos.  This is a really fun thing to do when you are showing people around SF all day, and need a place around 5 to sit and have a fun drink.....and a pupu!  The water feature in the middle used to be the pool when the Fairmont opened.... Now it looks murky....and is the centerpiece at Tonga....where there is a floating stage for the band.......and the indoor 'rainstorms' are things that are not done much anymore!  A SF institution!  Long live the Tonga Room!
author: Bryan M.

description:
Respectable 4 star venue and dining.  Me, I'm more of a standard fair kind of guy.  I went here a few times with the family before an opera or play, and found the food decent.  

I don't go there too much anymore, but it's a good establishment with a South Pacific Island theme going for it.  Give it a chance.
author: Blue G.

description: The Tonga Room is very touristy but I love it anyways! Haven't been there in awhile so I took a friend that was out here for a visit & I forgot how much fun it is! Gotta love that tiki atmosphere & of course the thunderstorms! It's a great place to get a drink! We shared the Lava one!
author: Ava O.

description: Very disappointing!  After learning about the Tonga Room from The Layover my bf and I couldn't wait to visit this place. Despite being told over the phone that the wait was close to an hour we still decided to drive over to the city and check it out. The long line is credit to Anthony Bourdain's visit here.  Long story short.... The food is over priced and terrible and the whole atmosphere was cheesy. I felt like I was at Disneyland's Tiki Lounge. The drinks were alright. Will not go back!!!! BTW on Fri & Sat night there is a $7 cover fee for the live band.
author: Judy c.

description: Before I write this review let me just state that I love the Tonga room. The atmosphere, tiki history, being transported to a Polynesian paradise is why we keep coming back. It's like going to Disney land in San Francisco. We're sad that we won't be coming back. The reason for this is the horrible service and the ridiculous price and quality of there food. It was Saturday and I just got off work. I wanted to take my girlfriend to the Tonga to have a tropical beverage and just relax. We ordered a volcano bowl which was pretty tasty and enjoyed the ambience. I could sense a little rudeness from our waitress when I was inquiring about the alcohol potency of each bowl. She had a short demeanor. I felt like I was annoying her with my questions. I let it go, but it was warning for what was to come. My girlfriend decided that she wanted a appetizer. She ordered the shrimp egg rolls, they were pricey ($13). When they arrived at the table it was literally two egg rolls cut in half with some dipping sauces. She tasted one and told me that it tasted average and did not warrant the $13 dollar price tag. We got the waitresses attention and told her that we're not satisfied with the egg rolls and that we wanted to try something else. She became very rude and apprehensive to exchange it for something else. She said we should have not taken a bite of the food. If the egg rolls were great we would have no problem paying that much. We needed to try them first. My girl decided to talk to the manager about the situation. He told us that there in the process of hiring new waiters and waitresses. Not very comforting, there keeping the rude servers around until they can find replacements. After this experience, we decided to leave. We were disappointed because the Tonga room has so much potential.
author: Neil P.

description: Go for the hurricanes. Stay for the drinks and nuts. We loved our drinks. I had a Pineapple Royal and my boyfriend had a Mai Tai. I loved both of them. Not that I drank both, but mine was tasty, and so was his. And of course, what a great nut bowl, if you're into nuts. But really, they had a nice assortment of nuts. What more can I say, we had a great time at a very unique place.
author: Reyes H.

description:
Every city has to have a themed bar, seriously.  It is necessary and a requirement.  Sf has many, but nothing like the Tonga room.

There is a ship. 
There is a pool.  
You can make it rain here. 
Ask the guy to press a button, and BAM-rain.
Complete wit red light to set the mood and tiki inspired artifacts...
All that's missing is Johnny Depp, that sexy fool.
author: Flor D.

description: Great environment , themed restaurant.... but my bartender just made everyones "tropical drink" extra sugary. basically sugar water, fruit syrup and alcohol. The food was ok.
author: B H.

description: The ultimate tiki lounge, so much fun, fancy smanchy!!!! Hsve to get a dri mms k in a pineapple!!!!
author: R. S.

description: When I looked at the menu online, it felt overprice (Fairmont standards), and expected generic Asian fusion. I ordered the Hot Pot, with the forbidden fried rice. It was really good! The forbidden fried rice was a blend of 4 different rice, very flavorful and delicious. There were plenty of large scallops, shrimps and fish in the Hot Pot. I really enjoyed my dish. The drinks are all very pretty and colorful, but definitely not as strong as Anthony Bourdain described them to be. Fun place to go to for the experience.
author: Charlie A.

description: Strong drinks- nasty food.  Decor is a little tacky but thats why we were there. FUN!
author: Vi V.

description:
I came here for the kitsch, but there was a catch! They wrap up that buffet faster than you can say "MekaLekaHiMekaHineyHo"!

My gal pals and I came here for happy hour. It was a time to sit back, catch up on the '08 wrap up and drink strong, tiki drinks. Mission accomplished.

They make it rain here, people. I know, 400 other reviews said the same damn thing, but in the rain deprived bay area (well, prior to this week) that was amazing to me. The thundershowers and fake lightning got me as excited--if not more--than the little fake rain storms in the produce section of your major grocery store. Who doesn't love a good broccoli thunderstorm?

Now, onto the buffet. Seriously, I scowl at buffets. I've had my fill of vienna sausages and shrimp cocktail and egg rolls, but this buffet was actually good. So good, in fact, we made several trips as a group back to the table for more.

They tease you with those little plates you see....but I am a Jenga master, and I have mastered the art of stacking egg rolls on my plate to a level even you would be envious of. 

It was better than your average buffet. And they know it. For $9.50, for two hours, you can stuff yourself silly and then pretend to fall asleep on this ship in the rain. How nice. The only bad taste left in my mouth was the fact they took away all the plates, all the sliverware and left the food out a little past magical buffet time. Guests were still picking, perusing, drooling if you will, and wandering around like lost children in a department store filled with fried goodness who just lost their mother.

"It's closed! No more!" the waiter said, but we all just looked at eachother, grabbed a handful of napkins and stole those dumplings right off the table.
author: Jessica P.

description: Dinner was good: salmon, ahi, chicken. Desserts were awful: pre-fab coconut cream pie, tasteless bread pudding, brownie sludge with charred marshmallow. Wait service was like the churn at a bad Chinese restaurant; food was slow to arrive.
author: Roger T.

description: Before I start talking about anything else, let me just say that the manager Mike was very accommodating to our group. We had 14 people total in our group and it was to celebrate a birthday. The entertainment was great and there was even an area for dancing which was fun!! We would come back here for the entertainment and ambiance for sure. The food was good, but a bit pricey (we understand since it is in a touristy area). I felt like I was back in Hawaii when we were there. Now, the reason why I didn't give 5 stars. The service was extremely slow and I swear we were flagging down our server multiple times or trying to get other servers to find him. On top of that, we felt like we were being rushed for being there. The bus boy came back numerous times taking plates from our table even though we weren't finished with our food yet. He didn't even ask if we were done!! At one point, he even took a plate someone was still eating from and moved the rest of her rice to the person eating next to her!! Wth?? Do you want people returning or not? We explained to the manager what was going on and he took care of it, which was appreciated. I suggest not going here for groups unless you don't mind being eyeballed constantly by the bus boy taking all your plates away...
author: Mertani G.

description:
On a conference with a couple of teachers, and a few seniors from my high school. Dinner "on your own" means it's time to find a kitschy joint that our students will dig, and that will allow us adults to drink stiff cocktails from tropical fruits. Enter the Tonga.

Turns out, they just happen to be running a promotion that comps the typical $5 cover for Yelpers. Suddenly, we could not afford to look any further.

We arrived at about 8, and were seated immediately. The service was awesome, the band was thoroughly entertaining, and the food was shockingly good! 

My students took a tons of pictures, and were genuinely blown away by the experience.
author: Joe A.

description:
Hadn't been there in 8 years so went with a group. Cheesy and old school atmosphere (kitschy Polynesian theme) but good drinks. Strong mai tais to boot. $9.50 price for happy hoursbuffet is a bit much - just some noodles, chicken, macaroni salad, shrimp chips, and a few other salads. But fun every other year or so. Can't believe there's a $7.50 cover charge for music after 8 pm.  

Tourist to local ratio is 10:1 - can tell by shorts (in SF) and shopping bags.

I hear Tonga Room may close so I guess will have to go to other tiki bar by Geary and 26th avenue when the mood strikes.
author: Dan L.

description:
So first off, I found out about this place because of the Travel Channel. A lot of times, television has a way of making places look better than what they really are, but in this case I was not disappointed. 

First thing, depending on what you day/night you go, there will be a cover which will be included on your bill. I was a little irritated at first, but it turned out to be worth it. Their drink selection was very good and very extensive. As far as taste is concerned, their drinks had the right amount of alcohol, if not more (which is never a bad thing). 

The reason a cover is charged is because of the live entertainment, which I must say was very good. A lot of dancing from different age groups, which I thought was cool. On top of that, you have the occasional rainstorm being getting lei'd. Very cool place. I would definitely go again.
author: Daniel R.

description:
Oooh, swanky. 

Walking in here I half expected Frank Sinatra or Tony Bennett to appear from behind one of the pillars (or perhaps that one Pilar...couldn't resist, sorry!) in full tuxedo and microphone in hand. To say this place is old school is an understatement. 

Neither did (and considering that Frank's no longer with us I would've been more than a little disconcerted if he had), but there was a nifty boat full of musicians playing *mostly* oldies. 

The appetizers and drinks are expensive, and the service isn't all that great, but considering that there's a freaking boat in a pool in the middle of the room, complete with periodic rain showers from the ceiling, you're going for the experience more than anything else. It also helps that I had the best pina colada I've ever tried here - not particularly strong, but incredibly delicious. I suggest getting it with banana (though I'm sure the pineapple and mango are excellent too). 

The only thing that jars one out of the 1950s ambiance of the place is the music selections played by the band - catchy, but more Bobby Darin and less Sugar Ray please. :|

I love me some Trad'r Sam's, but it's nice to experience the classier version every once in awhile.
author: Sus... B.

description: The atmosphere and drinks make up for the so-so food.  Glad to see they now have a couple of reasonably priced children options.  Wait staff is very friendly.
author: J.K. S.

description:
The legendary Tonga Room is scheduled to be torn down and replaced with something, and whatever it is it certainly won't be as cool as this place is. The Tiki Trappings are very well done, great lighting, great effects (thunder storms), with great attention to detail. A Total Tiki Mood.

Unfortunately, the food, the drinks and the service are at the opposite end of the scale. And it's quite pricey, especially considering the poor quality of the food and drinks.

First the cocktails. I had a Mai Tai and it was easily the worst I've ever had (and I'm an aficionado, definitely). It was over-sweet, hardly any taste of rum and the juices tasted like they were from a can. There were 8 of us and the drinks were uniformly bad. San Francisco has so many great places for quality cocktails, and these tasted like something you'd get somewhere in the sticks. Terrible.

The food was also over-priced and not at all good. We were intending to eat dinner there, but after some appetizers and a drink, we were out of there!

And even though the place really wasn't that crowded at all, it was difficult to get the attention of servers.

If you're looking for a Tiki Experience at a higher level of quality in terms of drinks and service, the Kona Club in North Oakland, Thalassa in Berkeley (both owned by the same guy) have the full tiki effect *and* good drinks. And Trader Vic's in Emeryville has better food and drinks, although not nearly the great ambience of Tonga Room or Kona Club.
author: Tim W.

description: Fun and kitschy.  There was a line but it didn't take us long to get in.  Drinks were tasty and strong.  Dessert was so-so but we were there for the atmosphere.  Our waitress was very polite.  We didn't stay long and she didn't add the cover charge to our bill which was a nice surprise.
author: Marsi N.

description:
There's no place quite like it in San Francisco, and it never gets old for me.  Where else can you get a tiki-themed bar, an indoor lagoon complete with "rainstorms" every 20 minutes, and a band on a floating raft?

With decent food, and strong albeit slightly over-priced cocktails, this is definitely worth checking out on a Friday after work for happy hour.
author: Tim N.

description:
This place was alright.  I loved the ambiance of the venue: being at the Fairmont hotel; having creative tropical decor and the setup of the tables and bar.  When I was told it would "rain" randomly throughout the night, I thought it would be scattered rain, or at least :not: a rectangular line of rain around the pool~ Maybe I was expecting too much...but I thought the rainforest cafe was more inventive.  I actually did like that there was a floating stage for the band in the middle of the rain pool~ 
I felt like the service could have been nicer for being known as a pricey place to eat~ and the drinks should have been better in general.  We came for the happy hour, and weren't that impressed.  We had the "buffet" which I expected to be more spectacular than the limited selection of:

Fried shrimp chips
Fried wontons
Seaweed salad (not very good considering you can buy it tasting a lot better in a prepackaged ready to eat bag)
Spring rolls
Macadamia Pineapple Fried Rice (only good with the sauces)
Garlic Noodles (only good with the sauces)
Fruit Salad (only special with the sauces)

The drinks were definitely not shaken, probably not even stirred but poured straight into the bowls.  We got the two large bowl drinks -for two- and they were unbalanced, where one was so strong in hard alcohol that it ruined drinking for me for the rest of the night.  

I think this place would be more fun for a group outing, happy hour style~ but not for two.
author: Katherine B.

description:
An open letter of apology to the people sitting at the table behind us:

Hi, guys. You might remember me as the chick that was drinking $6 MGD's at a fucking tiki bar. Perhaps you may also recall that I was the young lady that kept bending over and flashing her garter belt and ass to you. To be perfectly honest with you all, I'm not entirely sure which I'm more embarrassed about. I mean, only an idiot would deign to spend $6 on a bottle of Miller Genuine Draft. But it takes a special kind of lady to flash her naughty bits to an entire table of strangers.

I realize that you were all horrified and shocked. Things like that probably don't happen in Minnesota much, do they? In my defense, I must say that I was just terribly moved by the atmosphere of the Tonga Room. Middle-aged men in business suits hitting on me, a waitress that seemed like she didn't give a fuck whether we all lived or died so long as she got her money at the end of the night, a roarin' cover band that played on a BOAT in WATER. How many bands FLOAT on a BOAT in WATER INDOORS and play Van Morrison covers, I ask you? Huh? 

Right. Not many. And, honestly folks, the food that I ordered really put me in the mood to be a little feisty. A lukewarm plate of appetizers for $30 really gets me in the mood to flash people. After biting into those delicious, 100% NOT just-microwaved ribs just made me want to crawl all over my friends and shake my healthy butt in your unsuspecting faces.

What I'm really trying to say to you is...I'm sorry. All right? I'm SORRY. Please find it in your hearts to forgive me. And please tell your lawyers to drop the lawsuit against me. 

Love,
Pamela D.
author: Pamela D.

description: Where else can you go and the ceiling rains while your eating pupus. A fun tradition. We took out of town guests there last week. Its an icon of San Francisco.
author: Jan B.

description: Great atmosphere for happy hour or dinner. A real treat! Everyone deserves to come here at least once in their life.
author: Nicole W.

description:
So I heard about the Tonga Room from a musician friend who plays alot of "voodoobilly"music and told me all about the famous Tiki Hide-away. Well, I was super excited to see and expierence it and when  friend from San Francisco made me aware of cheap flights I booked one. I was Tonga Room bound.

I made a reservation on their website and recieved 3 confirmations and also forwarded them to my friend who would be joining me. I had peaked at their menu and knew that their prices were outrageous but figured it was a one in a lifetime expierence.

I get there and found the door and host staff to be VERY RUDE! VERY VERY RUDE! If I am going to spend alot of my hard earned money, then you need to talk to me with respect. Their was a couple in front of us, whom apparently later where going to have a group of 10 more people later joining them. The host said they couldn't find their reservation and was not accomedating at all to the couple. Next we walked up, I knew I had a reservation, and they said that I did not.... Next the RUDE asian host insisted I had no reservation, and apparently I could not be seated in the area I wanted without one. I stated that I made one online... and he had the nerve to tell me that he didn't know what I did but I did not make a reservation, then he said that online has nothing to do with them????? WHAT?????? I made it on your website.... I got a billion confirming e-mails. 

Annoyed that my beautiful expierence was shattered and I was made to feel like a low class citizen, I took a seat in the bar area.... with no view to anything. I ordered the pu pu platter and it was very good... but it was also 25 bucks.... I also ordered a lava bowl for 2, which was small but strong... typically a lava... or volcano bowl is in a big bowl with a flame in the middle.... most tiki bars serve that for 2.... there lava bowl honestly was tiny.... perhaps their $30 lava bowl for 4 was what most places serve for 2? 

The atmosphere is nice, the people are really rude, even the waitress, and bartender.... they yell at you... all of them.... asian.... yelling like... "No, No... you get this... No, No... you do this.... no, no... you pay this".

You can't help but wonder what you are paying so much money for... the location is nice, but with high prices, rude staff and smnall drinks... it's not an enjoyable expierence. I say... ask if you could look around... be rude back to them... don't pay all your money for rude service.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
As a lover of all things cheesy, the Tonga Room warms my little ol' heart.

Most recent excursion was for date night on a Friday.  Grab dinner in Nob Hill and head on up the hill for at least one Scorpion Bowl.  Tip: there's no entertainment fee if you say you're just going to the bar to grab a drink.  Saddle on up to the bar and order something extra fruity (you'll have plenty of options).  Enjoy the decor and fake thunderstorms that are something out of Disney World.  Be sure to leave your seat to shake your groove thang on the dance floor, to the 70s cover band playing in the middle of the lagoon.  Watch your step -- there always seem to be plenty of semi-pro ballroom dancers there that love to show off and take up tons of room in the process.  Laugh at the mixed crowds of middle-age tourists, yuppies celebrating rehearsal dinners, and grandpas dancing with their small granddaughters.

So glad the closing of this place is moving slowly.  I plan on hitting up the TR several more times before it closes its doors for good.  Suggest you do the same.
author: Deidre B.

description: This more of a three and a half star review... Love me some tiki bars and this place is definitely tiki! Probably would have been a four or five star review if it wasnt so freakin expensive!! Also, the crowd tends to be a little...ummmm....mid life crisis which sometimes is really entertaining but sometimes a little out of control. Definitely a must go at least once for anyone who's feeling rich and in need of large flaming drinks and floating boats with cover bands, but there are probably other places a bit more laid back and affordable.
author: Maya W.

description:
Was watching the Travel Channel and saw this as a highlight spot on "Extreme Bar Hopping." Because if it was on TV, i was immediately attracted to go up to the city to check it out.

A friend and I made our way to the Tonga Room for some cocktails on a Sunday night. With her previous experiences from the themed restaurant, I trusted her to navigate through the historic Fairmont Hotel. If I wasn't with her, I wouldn't have known which of the many elevators to catch to get down to this gem.

Secluded on the bottom floor with the lights very dim, I got shivers from seeing the indoor thunderstorm over the pool. I was amazed to hear the cover band playing as I looked at all the very decorative interior. As we got to our table next to the Hurricane Bar, a very cool Tiki feel to it. 

The two of us ordered a Lava Bowl for four. I know, right? Well, we were thirsty. Wasn't planning to eat, but we ended ordering their Appetizer platter, which was perfect for two people, but not really a  "platter" size I expected. The platter was decent with its coconut shrimp, chicken kabob, egg roll, pork ribs, and something fried. The $25 price was outrageous for my usual expectation of a platter, which to me, should feed 3-4 people or so. 

The Lava Bowl came out to our table and it felt like it took more space than our appetizer platter. Pineapples, cherries, umbrellas, and straws were burst out of the ceramic coconut bowl. The $27 Lava Bowl for four definitely hit our indulgence that night, which made me forget about the price of the appetizer. 

Note: When the cover band is playing, a cover charge is automatically added to your bill.

The live music from the cover band influenced the 4th star on my rating. I loved the karaoke songs the cover band played, secretly we were both singing along at our table. Very relaxing environment to grab some tropical cocktails.

I'll find myself back here for a possible happy hour session or nice dinner occasion.
author: Paul D.

description:
this place far exceded my expectations yesterday.

i have been many times but i am always being told not to eat here because the food is no good....

well, i ate there for the first time yesterday, and thought my meal was delicious.  add to that the fabulous tiki enviornment and a couple of cocktails and it as a great expierince.
author: inky l.

description:
It's a supppper cute place, a perfect place to go for any special occasion. I was here for my birthday two weeks ago and was here again for a girls' night out last night. Making a reservation is highly recommended if you do not want to stand in line for over an hour. 

The place is very dark like any Tiki bar/restaurant, but has a very happy and laid back atmosphere, as there are live music and a dance floor. I had a very good time stumbling drunkenly on the dance floor with the bf...

The food can be a hit or miss. I had the Ahi Poke as an appetizer the first time, which was amazing with the avocado. The Firecracker with tofu wasn't anything to write home about, although the Tongan rice was great as a side. I really liked the smoky flavor of the Tongan rice. The second time at the Tonga room, I ordered the Smoked Salmon, which was very tasty, I especially liked the sauce and wasabi mash. 

The drinks were good, but nothing to rave about. Although I must say, the drinks were very strong. I think I was good after one, and I'm no punk when it comes to drinks...

My experience went well, although there were a couple of issues with two of my girlfriends' entrees. Upon being close to finishing her Butterfish (which was very good according to her), she found a large piece of cardboard in her food mixed amongst her mushrooms. We went ahead and let a manager know, in which he was apologetic for, and brought out a new plate of food for her. We later find out in the bill that her entree was also comped. 
My second friend ordered the Thai Basil Curry, which she wasn't very happy about because it was incredibly bland and watery. Since she was absolutely starving, she went ahead and finished the food, but let the manager know that her food wasn't very good. He also offered to comp her meal but she declined since she had finished the food already. 
I will say that the quality of the food is a hit or miss, but they do their best to make up for their shortcomings by doing whatever it takes to ensure that you are a satisfied customer. The waiters and hosts were very polite and friendly.

If you walk upstairs to the hotel lobby, the place is gorgeous! :) Super pretty ceilings and chandeliers, and there was also a guy playing on the grand piano. There was a weird lady wearing a kimono-type dress dancing around the guy on the grand piano though. I'm not sure if that was part of it but still a very entertaining thing to watch. 

Anyway, I had a great time the two times I was here and will most definitely be back!
author: A L.

description:
Everyone loves the Tonga Room! If you don't you're a grump!

Lava bowl, yes please (the Lava is better than the Scorpion)! Kitchy entertainment, yes please! Interior rain storm, oh yes please!! Historic haunted hotel with great Tendernob charm - definitely.

But beware of the kitchen.  Not incredibly tastey, it is a hotel kitchen after all.  The few appetizers I've had were a let down, and the kitchen itself is scary looking. 

The best way to navigate there is to enter on the California Street side, not through the front hotel entrance.  You don't want to go in the doors nearest to Powell where the signage is, but actually the doors mid street up - a little confusing.

Minus one star for the entertainment price.
author: Leia K.

description:
This place is hilarious... anyone who's been to Tonga knows it's more faux 'Hawaii' than Tonga. But that's only academic so lets move onto the fun stuff.

I have heard about the Tonga Room for as long as I've lived in SF. I have heard about the rain, fog and band playing covers in a Tiki bar kinda space. I have heard about the excellent buffet, and that the tropical themed cocktails aren't so bad either. All of which are true.

What wasn't told was that the service is sssllloooowww. It took our waitress 15mins before she realise we just got seated, and another 5 before we got a drink on the table. Perhaps it is a lounging sort of place but man, it wouldn't be a lounge until I get at least one drink in me, would it? Oh, and our second drinks wasn't any quicker.

Regardless, its fun and surprising space within a hotel that belongs to the 'Historical Hotels of America'. Come here when you have time to lounge and want to be wow'ed by craziness.
author: Joyce L.

description: We really enjoyed the unique experience/ambiance/history here. Service was excellent, and food was good, but we thought the menu was pretty boring and lacked originality...certainly not food that would bring us back. Drinks were very fun (Hurricane and Mai Tai). Love the atmosphere. However, the live music was SO loud!!! Way beyond that 'live music' loud. Additionally, the music the band sang was completely out of style with the Polynesian theme and music that had been playing prior. The band experience is what took our rating from 4 stars to 3. We would consider bringing out-of-town friends here (before the band comes on at 8p!) for the experience, but we wouldn't return on our own...kind of the thing you do once, since the food was neither unique nor incredible.
author: Gia A.

description:
This place is totally overrated. My b/f found this place in the book we had and wanted to see it since it was built around a pool that is supposed to thunder and rain with lightning. Uh yeah, I think I can make better special effects. From far it was cool but up close, it was a disappointment. 

The food was really good but overpriced. We got the appetizer sampler which had 2 egg rolls, 2 macadamia flat bread things, 2 breaded shrimp, and 3 spareribs. This was $25. Drinks are $10 and up. 

Normally I'd give these places a better review since sometimes prices are to be expected. The thing that really got me is the service. While we were seated right away (and the hostess was wonderful), it took almost 15 minutes for someone to acknowledge our table. And that was how it was for the rest of the time. We wouldn't see our waiter until he happened to pass and we could flag him down. When we got the check, my b/f needed change to leave a tip so instead of waiting another 15 minutes, we tried going to the bar. The bartender's reply to us was "Get your waiter to do it." Are you serious?!? You would think that a place like this would be more accommodating to its customers. 

I wouldn't recommend going here unless you had preplanned this as a party or something. The food was great but the service was less than mediocre.
author: Jessica H.

description: Good drinks if you have deep pockets go early to avoid the 7.00 cover charge after 8pm. Would go back lot's of fun..
author: George E.

description:
Who doesn't love this place?   Groovy grass huts, a pirate ship dance floor, booming thunder and rain, great 80's lite rock on a floating cabana, overpriced umbrella drinks and greasy hawaiian-esque food... why its a tropical heaven right here in our backyard!  


********************
********************

Please sign the petition to help save our beloved tiki landmark:

http://www.savetonga.com/

Make your voice heard!

********************
********************
author: SFnativeGal ..

description:
It's a Disney experience for non-Disney and Disney folk alike. Part Tiki Room, part Blue Bayou-Pirates of the Caribbean... atop one of the city's most acclaimed hotels. If you are going with me, be prepared for me to order the fruitiest drink there is and dance a lot.

Cover charge for a live band is always worth it. Don't mess around with a quiet table in the corner, when you can sit waterside by the lagoon.

So the food sucks, and the drinks hedge on overpriced, but I love the Tonga Room any way. It's lovely to pass by the Mark Hopkins, the Ritz Carlton, Stanford Court, and the Fairmont all in a short series of Nob Hill blocks... albeit steep blocks if you come via way of California street. :] To me it's like a small piece of New York done up San Francisco style -- I approve.
author: Angela H.

description: Touristy, cheesy looking kitschy expensive bar that is also fun: Zombies are lethal ;)
author: dean d.

description:
I'm not a fan of surprises.  Actually, I take that back - I love good surprises, but loathe bad ones.

Like the time I got a call from my boyfriend of 18 months, who was in jail for growing pot in that secret room in his house that he would never let me see.  That's the tip of the B.S. (Bad surprise) Iceberg that periodically crashes into the Titanic of my life.

Fortunately for me, enough bad surprises have happened over the years to change me into someone who expects very little from people.

The Tonga Room surprised me in a good way.  It was cheesy (expected), but fun and with a very lively crowd.  They played Journey (expected), but I loved shaking it with my date on the dance floor. They served drinks out of pineapples (expected), but that didn't give me a sugar headache (although the rum did the next day)...

This is my kind of saccharine, unpretentious, chode-free, Journey-loving environment. 

Voted: Best place to start a Conga-in-the-Tonga Line by Janney B.
author: Janney B.

description:
Ohmygodwhatafuckingripoff.  The Tonga Room was terrible, just terrible.  I was initially thrilled to discover that the Tonga Room has a $9 happy hour buffet (one drink minimum per person).  It seemed perfect for my guests from NY who only care about seeing kitschy old school restaurants.  Unlike Empress of China, the Tonga Room's decor actually lived up to expectations.  The tiki village with the water and the boats all looked amazing.  Too bad that we could barely see them from the area back by the bar where they corralled all us cheap ass happy hour patrons.  We could only glimpse intermittent slices of the decor as they appeared between the broad-backed businessmen and corn-fed tourists packed like sardines by the bar while the rest of the restaurant was all but empty.

I cannot speak badly enough of the buffet.  The offerings were beyond meager and each one vied with the others to be the most nauseating.  There were only four or five dishes- spring rolls, shrimp chips, fried won tons, noodles, and fried rice.  Each more awful than the last.  And the next.  Somehow, in the bizarro world that was the Tonga Room happy hour, that sort of thing was possible.  To top it off, the schisters who run the place weren't content to serve insanely crappy food, they also didn't stock the buffet with any normally sized plates.  Just try and fit $9 worth of spring rolls on a saucer, I dare you!

The only thing that's keeping me from filling this review with nothing but ALLCAPS and expletives is the fact that when we told the waitress how awful the buffet was (so very bad that Boyfriend didn't even bother to eat anything) she only charged us for one person.

If you absolutely must see the Tonga Room, go on an off-hour and just have some drinks at the bar.  If you're ballin' (or looking to do some balling), spend the money for the regular dinner menu.  There isn't any situation I can think of that would justify having the buffet.
author: Lauren C.

description: My mom & I had so much fun here even though our drink was completely terrible and headache inducing.  We had to wait an entire hour to get into this place for no real reason but we had SO much fun in a total Disneyland sort of way. Sometimes you just want fake rainstorms and a drink in a pineapple. This would be a great place for a birthday party and I love the fact that this is old (the pool is from the 30's). Somehow if this had been built more recently I'd probably be put off by all the kitch but as it is a relic, I'm totally content w/it. The waiters were super friendly even though we barely ordered anything. I wonder why they don't have any standing room. Go after 8 pm on the weekend. There will be a $7 cover but it's worth it to catch the live entertainment playing in the boat. Afterall, this place is all about atmosphere not food!
author: Kristin S.

description:
Come on , shake your body baby, do the TONGA!
I know you can't control yourself any longa!
Feel the rhythm of the music getting stronga!
Don't you fight it 'til you tried it, do that TONGA beat!



I AM SO GETTING MARRIED HERE.



y'all are invited.



seriously.  


we're going to do the tonga.    AND the electric slide.
author: lulu p.

description:
I'm going to pass on the link to save the Tonga Room because I would hate to see its demise!  

http://www.savetonga.com/

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/02/25/BAS1164CAH.DTL

The Tonga Room has a special place in my heart because I always heard stories about it from my parents, even before I had ever been to SF.   My parents used to go there when they were dating and loved the tropical drinks, rain and thunderstorms, and most of all the band on the barge! They even ordered the pictures of themselves on the matchbooks.

I won't discuss the food in this review since it has been too many years since I've eaten there (although I do remember liking the coconut shrimp), but I have been there a few times recently for the ambiance and tropical cocktails.  While nothing beats a Trader Vics Mai Tai, the Tonga Room's version is strong and sweet, as is the Scorpion Bowl.  And of course, the classic tropical glasses are always fun.

I have to admit I'm partial to tiki bars because I love the tropical drinks (and maybe spent too much time in the Tiki Room at Disneyland as a kid).  The Tonga Room is still one of my favorites.  I just went back with my dad and he told me that his first trip to the Tonga Room was in 1970 when he was in town for a convention.  And he said it hasn't changed much since.  While it can be kitschy, touristy, and pricey (it is in a hotel after all), I still think it's a part of SF that is not to be missed.
author: Laura B.

description:
Why I love the Tonga Room:

* Kitsch, but Original Kitsch
I hate those comparisons to the Rain Forest Cafe. This place opened in 1945. So WHO is biting WHOSE style, huh?

* Happy Hour!!! 
Where else in SF can you feed AND distract a bunch of your cousins' kids for under $10 while you get bombed on Mai Tais and laugh your butts off at the expense of other relatives with bad judgment.

* I LOVE my Gram
The Fairmont was my gram's favorite SF hotel. And one of my last and most treasured memories of her was sharing a Scorpion Bowl during a hurricane while my Grandpa said, "Hell, that ain't no hurricane! Why, when I was in Korea...blah, blah, blah"

*Cover Bands
I am always secretly super psyched to see the bandstand float out into the middle of the water. Sure they're going to sing cheesy songs, but chances are I'll know them all and even be compelled to dance to at least one. Especially if the Lava Bowls are stiff that night,

* Rooftop Garden
Once the clock strikes 7 and happy hour comes to a close, you can saunter out to the rooftop garden for the flippin' amazing view. SImply priceless! You can watch the cable cars scoot by beneath you, the TransAmerica pyramid in the distance, and cuddle your sweetie in almost complete privacy.

http://images.travelnow.com/hotels/SFO_FAIR-eview-3-fairmont-hotel-san-francisco.jpg
author: Vanessa L.

description: Very disappointed with their service.  I called close to two months ahead of time to book a large party on a busy holiday night.  The reservationist accepted all my information, told me they had availability and that someone would call me back.  After never receiving a call back, I once again called and left a message on their 'managers line'.  No one returned my call again, not even to tell me they were full.  Now since the original reservationist told me they had room, I didn't call other places yet since I thought I had this secured.  Finally I called reservations back and was now told they were completely full and had no trace of my 1st reservation.  I asked for a manager and they once again said no one was available.  How frustrating!  They are missing out on a large party and couldn't even bother to call back.  If they don't value my business, I won't return.
author: MaryAnn V.

description:
In some bars, yuppie kids can pretend to be "slumming" because the bathrooms are nasty; in some bars, they'll have your favorite drink ready before you even sit down.  In some bars, you get tremendous alcohol value for your drinking dollar.  

The Tonga Room is not that bar.

The Tonga Room is about ginormous drinks that come in ceramic coconuts, imposing tiki jars, and huge bowls with umbrellas.

At the Tonga Room, you'll discover that a fru-fru drink with a shit-ton of rum in it can actually not taste like fire and assplosions in your mouth.  

The Tonga Room manages to pull off the tiki-bar vibe without feeling shabby or run-down.  You'll forget you're in one of the great old hotels of the city, until you sneak out to the immaculate bathroom and experience the amazing paper towels.

In the Tonga Room, you'll dance with your friends and loved ones to a band that somehow manages to pull off both Christopher Cross and Bill Withers while floating in a thatched-roof boat.

Whilst lounging at the Tonga Room, you'll see dancing children, waiters in floral shirts, hostesses bearing leis, and old men in white tuxedos dining with photographs of their dead wives.

The Tonga Room will let you make it rain without dropping the cheddar.

In the Tonga Room, you'll get caught up with friends old and new, and wonder how the hell rum, juice, and pineapples can cost so damn much.  (Make like the bear and show up on an empty stomach to get maximum value for your drinking money)

When you stumble out of the Tonga Room into the night, you'll marvel at how the lights and signs glow in the fog, jump when the fireworks thump in the distance, and realize that the Tonga Room is yet another wonderful little gem that helps make San Francisco the greatest city in a nation of great cities.

If there was a God, I'd thank her for San Francisco, and for the Tonga Room.
author: Jim C.

description: This place is a serious joke, they charge a $7 cover charge, drinks are between $10-20 and entrees run between $25-40! Its outrageous and not even worth it because the food is not even tasty! The music is good but SO loud, you can't even hear yourself think. Parking is non existent and I don't plan on returning here.
author: Julia R.

description:
Ahhhh, there's no better place than The Tonga Room for sipping on a ridiculously expensive Mai Tai by the fake lake while watching a lovely gal on a floating barge sing a medly of Gloria Estevan songs.  

I went with a bunch of friends (highly recommended) and we ate so-so pupus and drank something that came in a huge bowl with several straws in it.  I don't remember what it was called because it had three gallons of rum in it.  

But it definitely got us in the mood...I walked home humming "the rhythm is gonna getcha!" all the way...crap, now it's stuck in my head again.
author: Kristina R.

description: Was recently in San Francisco for four days for a little mini vacation and stayed across the street at the Mark Hopkins.   A friend of mine insisted that I try this fun bar and restaurant with a Tiki theme.   I thought it was going to be super cheesy, and it was, but in a great way.   We had an absolute blast here.  We had cocktails (the big Chi Chi in a pineapple was so good), appetizers (vegetable spring rolls - YUM), and dinner.   The food was plentiful and delicious.   Our sever was prompt, friendly and courteous.   Loved the band on the floating boat and the hourly rain and thunderstorm in the middle of the restaurant.   Definitely a unique experience and a must do for first time visitors to SF.   I want to go  back there!
author: Rob N.

description:
The Tonga Room is just plain stupid in every way.

As a follow up to the company party at the University Club in my last review, we went down the street to the Tonga Room.  You would think that such amazing, hip people would have some clue about where to throw a party.

They have a band on a boat.  This band plays covers of all the songs that ever crossed the line from pop to motion picture soundtrack.  It's not that they play the songs poorly, it's just that they play the most generic crap because everybody will know it.

The drinks are way too sweet and overpriced.  I had a Blue Hawaiian, partly because of where I was, and partly because I wanted to give a lesson on complimentary colors that involved my dark orange tie.  That was the best part of the drink.  The Makers on the rocks was a good sized pour, and it should be for what they charge, but I really think it was only so great in volume because the old man knew I was watching him.

Again, I need to express, in order to spare the feelings of the wonderful people I was with, that they know how to have a good time, and they are spectacular party people, but the venue did not enhance my experience.

The decor is pure cheese, and not in that ironic/Butter sort of way.  The crowd is largely Midwestern tourists who find this place in the same outdated guide book, and the fake rain storms are silly and senseless.

Avoid at all costs, unless you are taking your alcoholic grandmother from Ohio on a tour of San Francisco.
author: Quinn S.

description:
First the good things: the atmosphere rocks - pool, Tiki look - you feel like on holiday! I loved that I could share a double cocktail with my friend, and the drink was pretty good. Not exceptional, but I liked it. The band was ok, the singer wasn't great but I liked their selection of classic fun songs.
Now, the things that really set me up: our waitress, Tina. First of all, she did not serve us for more than 20 min (half of our party of 6 was here). One of my friends was so hungry, she got really upset. Then she would come to our table, mumble something about how she will be back in 1 min and at least she gave us the menues. It took 40 min (!) until we could order drinks and food! She never smiled once, she was outright unfriendly. It was only later I realized why: they include a 15% gratuity with parties more than 6 people, so she knew she gets her tip anyway. After ordering food, my friend and I got up to take a walk around the pool and look at the deco and everything (we were seated in a corner). After a couple of steps we ran into our waitress and now she became plain rude - she asked me if she could help me. I said, no thanks, doin' alright. She then said (I still can't believe she really did that!): "We don't like our customers walking around when other people are eating" in a very rude tone. I looked at her, unbelievingly, shrugged my shoulders and was like, "I understand" and just ignored her and kept on walking. Then she added "Did you not understand me?" I looked at her, furious now, and said, "Oh I did" (but still kept on walking around). I mean really, how can you treat first time customers like that?? We didn't stand in anyone's way, we just walked around the pool one time. And it was not that crowded either. If it wasn't that we were waiting for two other friends to arrive, we would have just stood up and left the bar.
The food was ok, but did not live up to our expectations or the price they charge you. Also, small sized main dish, mini sized appetizers! I recommend the Pupu platter. 
The crowd at the Tonga room was mixed, young and old, dressed up or dressed casual, lot of people had fun on the dancefloor.

Also, beware: they take one credit card right in the beginning as a security when you are not a hotel guest - I found that pretty strange - as if you were not trustworthy. Never had that at a bar before. In addition, we paid 5$ per person cover fee on a Thursday. Over all, it was quite pricey which would have been ok had not Tina ruined it for all of us, she destroyed the fun with her rude attitude.

Summing up, my friend was like, we should have gone to Smuggler's Cove. Tonga Room is definitely overrated!!
author: Satura E.

description:
A friend and I went to the Tonga Room for a few drinks, appetizers, and dancing.  Ok not dancing, I swayed like a log stuck in a whirlpool, she laughed at me and said "no one is looking!".  Yeah right.  Back to the review.

I am trying new ways of rating, so your input is appreciated on what is helpful to you.  Do you want quick recaps on the front side or the back?

Atmoshphere - 5 stars
Ambience - 5 stars - I know, similar as above
Cocktails - 3.5 stars - pricey for what you get
Food - 3 stars -  very tasty but see below

We started off with Mai Tai's.  They were tasty, but I was not overwhelmed by the flavor.  I am not sure if I have had a Mai Tai before, but I still prefer Margarita's.

As was very hungry when we arrived.  When I looked at the menu, nothing jumped out and grabbed me.  I was looking for something that was new to my taste buds, something exciting.  

The waitress recommended the Jumbo Ginger Garlic Prawns.  Very Very good.  The Prawns were larger then the "red lobster" lobsters.  They were cooked perfectly and packed some great flavor.  The Prawns earned 4-4.5 stars.  The reason I gave the overall food a 3 was for the selection on the menu.  At the moment, nothing reached out and grabbed me.

This place was a very cool place to spend the evening.  Worth the trip to the Fairmont.
author: Jason B.

description:
I honor it with my 200th review.  It is a dire hour for this true mid-century Tiki Establishment:

SAVE THE TONGA ROOM:
http://www.thepetitionsite.com/1/save-the-tonga-room---san-francisco

http://www.savetonga.com/


Yes, the service, on occasion, has been surly. And Yes, the drinks, on occasion, have been downright dastardly.

BUT!  It's still one of my favorite Tiki Places in the Bay Area.  The Happy Hour is well-attended and a good bargain in San Francisco. The indoor "lagoon" and rainstorms are historic and the only other place left in America that still has them, barring The Mai Kai in Ft. Lauderdale. The Ship Deck dance floor is a priceless piece of nautical decor.
author: Amelia R.

description: My parents went here for their prom over 50 years ago! Just based on that I had to try it. Drinks were strong-that was great!  Spareribs, shrimp spring roll, and mushroom dumplings were tasty.  Butterfish was excellent especially with the crab and mint salad on top of the butterfish.  The butterfish sits on a bed of sautéed mushrooms! Yum!
author: Charla B.

description:
What an awesome place - themed bars can sometimes be a bit tacky but I think they got it spot on here.

Having a pool in the middle of the room with a live band aboard a boat is a unique touch that adds to the fun and this is enhanced by the choice of shirts on the band members - yes they are 'authentic' style but they are still largely inexcusable and that makes them wonderful.  The music is great as well, playing plenty of feel-good anthems allowing you to cut loose and throw whatever shapes you feel like throwing - which probably explains the high frequency of 'embarrassing uncle at wedding reception' dance moves on display, but it's all good fun.

I went here for drinks so I can't comment on the food but the bar menu/service were great with myriad cocktails and a very attentive drinks waiter.
author: adam m.

description:
First off I have been to the Tonga lounge many times before and actually enjoyed myself.  So I'm not sure if the management has changed or what is going on but I had one of my WORST experiences here the other night.  It began at the door.  Our party was already inside and there was a line to be seated.  I asked the man at the door if we needed to wait in line even though our party was already at the table, he said yes very rudely.  Then, after waiting for a few minutes the SAME man said "oh if your party's already here you can just go in"..... hmmmm... maybe shoulda been a sign that they are unorganized and rude.... but nonetheless we continued to our table.  This is where the fun really began.  We were with a party of eleven.  Eleven.  They had seated us at a small round table and there literally were not seats for everyone.  I know this place is not fine dining.  But how can you take people to a table without enough chairs or even space for people if there were chairs and just leave?!?!?  We were literally left standing in the middle of the dining room untill someone sitting at the table next to us offered us a chair and we moved it over ourselves.  While this was going on there was another huge party next to us, also not given adequate room and to make matters worse their group was spilling into our area.  SO NOT FUN.  I tried to get the waitress a few times but she ignored.  Finally I called her over and she rudely said "one minute ok"  I said, could I atleast order a drink?  She rolled her eyes at me and grabbed a napkin from the table and wrote down my order!!!!!  REALLY????  After fifteen minutes of no drink or even a menu given to us (still no chairs either)  I decided to go to the bar myself.  After ordering a drink, standing in the bar area and drinking it.  Man #1 from the bar came up to me and told me that I had to return to my table, They couldnt have people standing in the bar area.  First off, I have NEVER had someone say you cannot stand in the bar, especially at a restaurant where there are grass huts everywhere.  I told him I would love to return to my table, unfortunately we had no chairs at our table, and no room for our party and our waitress would not take our orders.  At this point he looked over and said he would take care of it after seeing the disaster happening in our area. I returned to the table only to find out that while I was gone our waitress had yelled at the bday girl when she asked if we could have a bigger table, maybe some chairs and menus.  She yelled at her to "just wait!!!".  Mind you, we were not being impatient, we had now been standing in the dinning room for 15 minutes.

Finally, the man at the door got us another table.  We were happy to move out of that dreadfull womans section.  She cashed us out and brought over our check where she had already written in her tip.  A large one also.  I refused to pay it, and everyone at the table agreed.  This was not an automatic gratuity, she had actually written herself her tip in the tip section on the credit slip.  I dont even think that is legal.

So we moved to anther table, things are getting better right?  We have a normal waiter, still not particularly nice or efficient, but adequate, (he didnt yell and brought us menus so it was a huge step up).  My boyfriend and I decided we should just try to have fun.  We ordered drinks served in pineapples.  When we got the drinks they were cute and good and we were starting to have a good time.  That was untill we noticed something green on out pinapples.  Yes.  THE PINEAPPLES WERE MOLDED!!!  We told our waiter who said sorry, got us a new one, but didn't even offer to comp it or anything.  That was it for us, we left and went somewhere else.  All in all a HORRIBLE experience.  We will never go back there again.  It really is a shame also becuase the decor is cool, it's a fun idea but there are way to many cute/fun places in SF to go to one where you're treated horribly.  If there is any hope of this place surviving they should fire everyone and start over.
author: Nanette D.

description:
Delightfully tacky. 

The rain storms that come every thirty minutes are fantastic. The drinks are priced as you'd expect from a place in the Fairmount. On my last trip there was a ballroom dancing group having an outing - they were great to watch, especially the 80something year old woman with silver glittery shoes - that woman could move! The service is a bit surly though. 

I wouldn't come here regularly, but it's fun to take out of towners.
author: Suge K.

description: A tourist trap with ok food but the service was great. I would recommend stopping by for a drink at the bar if you want to see the place but spend your money on better food somewhere else!
author: Kathy D.

description:
Kind of cheesy, kind of fun, this is at least worth bringing some of your tourist friends to, at least for the simulated thunderstorm. They have a surprisingly fun happy hour.

Oh, if you go when the band is playing on the boat, you will think you are some sort of Polynesian Idol show!
author: Nish N.

description: I have visited the Tonga Room now a total of four times and I have to say: this place is consistent. Great service, great food and really good drinks. The knowledgable staff will make everyone feel welcome here, even if you're not paying the $490/night at the Fairmont upstairs. The Tongs Room has always been of the bet kept secrets on Nob Hill. It has become noticeably busier since A. Bourdain featured it on his show.
author: Lars X.

description:
It's corny, but there's a place for corny every once in a while. However, I would prefer to pay a lot less for corny. 

The saving grace of the Tonga Room is that the food, appetizers and drinks are all good. It is expensive, but at least the food does not make you think you are throwing your money away. None of our waiters spoke much English, so I assume they were native Tongan. I feel honored they welcomed my friends and I into their village by placing leis on our necks. Huzzah to the Fairmont Hotel for employing them. 

Anyway, all of which gets me to the theme. It's got a "rain forest" in the middle and there is a "tropical storm" every half hour. Bravo. Oh, and just like on the real Tonga Island, they have a cave bar and big screen televisions.
author: Lupe P.

description: The food here was A+. The music was ok.  Atmosphere was nice.  Food was pretty expensive, but it was a very nice hotel, so No qualms about it.  We had the 8 course meal and there were tons of leftovers.  I will be back when I have visitors in town because it rains inside.
author: James C.

description: Great place to have fun and dance. Although I must say, the night we were there (last Friday) it looked like a scene out of "Dancing with the Stars". There were so many ballroom dancers on the dance floor.  But, there was still room for us uncoordinated, Scorpion-happy dancers. As others have said, the food is mediocre. But, we didn't go for the food. We went for the kitschy island atmosphere and fun.
author: Jo Anne G.

description:
