A friend of mine, whose opinion I completely trust, told us that the best bar he'd been to was at the Fairmont in San Francisco.  Boyfriend and I did a North California (including SF) trip last year, so we had to check it out.  After walking the near-45 degree trek up Nob Hill, we finally got to the hotel.  We walked into the hotel thinking, "Um, what's so special about this place?  It's the lobby of a fancy hotel with lots of gold, marble, and some piano music.  Not exactly 'cool'."

OK, so we finally figured he was talking about the Tonga Room, which is a little harder to find in the hotel.  It was also CLOSED for a private party, which was a huge disappointment.  I love nostalgia-type places, especially tiki places.  Apparently this one is completely over the top and awesome, but I can't say that first-hand.

Last weekend I was in SF again with a friend, and thought, "We should totally go to Tonga Room!".  We got all gussied up, took a cab (with a super-stoned driver) up Nob Hill, made our way through the maze to get there, and.... CLOSED AGAIN for a private party.  We weren't the only ones disappointed; a few other people walked up angry it was closed.

So anyway, I have never been past the front door of this place.  It looks cool from the outside, but since they've never let me in they get only one star.

Here's what you can take from my review: call before trying to go to this place.  Apparently I am either coincidentally unlucky twice, or they close themselves off from the public fairly often.
author: Claire T.

description:
For all those negative reviewers out there, you need to:

a.) lighten up! 
b.) do a little background research and if you don't like the prices or the sound of it, don't go!

Otherwise, call this place tacky, call it silly, call it whatever you want, but you can't call it un-fun.  Exchange your snobbery at the door for the plastic lei and, for shit's sake, try to enjoy the spontaneous "thunder storms" and ridiculously delicious island cocktails.

This place is like a little secret (well-known) cove of surprises and wonderfully ludicrous props with some great food to boot.  I more than happily indulged in the Mai Tai and Pipeline cocktails as well as the Shitake Mushroom Eggrolls and an assortment of other things.

And on a final note, our server, Kenneth, was the shit - attentive and adorably sarcastic.
author: Christine M.

description:
There's a ton of history behind this 100-year-old hotel, and that alone makes it worth visiting. Many different people have walked through its corridors; social elite, a few different presidents, and performers ranging from the Rat Pack to James Brown. 

After wandering around the hotel for awhile, my girlfriend and I decided to grab a table and wait for some friends inside the Tonga Room. Normally, neither of us would have visited this place, but some of her out-of-towner friends were staying at the hotel & this was an easy spot for everyone to merge.

We nibbled on cocktail snacks, and sipped our Scorpion Bowl for two (or more like I sucked it down). The Polynesian cover band was actually pretty awesome, they played a mix of different songs for the mostly middle-aged to blue hair crowd--worth the $5 per person they charge for entertainment.

Her friends arrived, and we gathered around the bar people and watched for awhile. The best part about this place was the drunken uber creepy guy with pants that were 3 sizes too big who kept putting his hand down his pants on the dance floor, staring at women while slowly gyrating his hips and moving towards them... HOT STUFF! I heard he had a Black American Express card & almost wanted to solicit him for a few drinks--I couldn't get anyone else to do it.

This place is perfect if you're looking for a reasonable good albeit high-priced time at a place inside of a beautiful hotel. Awkwardly, when you enter the Tonga Room, it seems like you're on a 2nd rate cruise ship making your way to a hotel in Downtown Las Vegas. The rain from the ceiling & the mini-moving boat with the band on it was a nice, cheesy touch.

5-stars if they throw some video poker or slot machines around this joint.
author: matt m.

description: That it's located in the Fairmont should not mislead anyone into thinking this is an upscale spot, and those who expect it to be will be sorely disappointed. Think of it as the joint that time forgot, a tacky-in-a-fun-way throwback to the Fifties. Avoid any drink with an umbrella, keep in mind the pu-pu is caca, and just kick back and watch the tourists react as if they tumbled into Alice's Wonderland. I bring out-of-town guests here just to prove such a place still thrives in ultra-sophisticated San Francisco. It reminds me of the now-defunct midtown Manhattan spot, Hawaii Kai, where we went after the Senior Prom a lifetime ago. The entertainment it provides and the nostalgia it invokes earn it four stars. Just don't take it seriously.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
Viv said it perfectly...

"Now that I've been here once, I have no reason to ever come back."

You must come here once if you've never been.  Honeslty the cheese factor is THICK.  It's very much The Tiki Room from Disneyland.  Quite honestly they really should install those singing birds that come down from the ceiling.  

It's crazy cuz I LOVE cheesy shit...I do.  I dig that kind of stuff to no end.  Tonga Room though....I could've done without.  

It seemed like all the people there were my parents age.  Well besides our group, they probably were.  The bartenders had NO facial expressions, no acknowledgement of the customers and no personality.  

Don't get me started on the "Entertainment Charge".  Seriously...it was a cheesy band on a floating stage that were singing oldies.  Which was the most fun part for me since I adore oldies songs but not worth a $5 "Entertainment Charge" that is added if you have a table to sit at. 

Another SF standard that I can check of my list.  

Boo...this place blows.
author: Jay H.

description:
nice decor, good energy, service was fantastic. Make reservations.

The food is a bit expensive, you are paying for the full experience. I plan to do the happy hour next time. They have a buffet type set up and I think this maybe a more reasonable price plus experience  combo for me. 
 
I grew up on the islands and have a very specific expectation of island food, I expected more flavor from the food. I can make this food at home, have eaten it all my life and need it to be special if paying for it.
author: Camille B.

description:
Finally ate at the Tonga Room.  Been in SF for a while, heard it was closing, so wanted to try it out.
Meh.

I don't see the big deal about the place, the decor was tired and too dark.  The food was extremely bland and way overpriced.  When you order a main dish, and it comes out in 5 minutes, you have to wonder how fresh the food is.

The saving grace is the wait staff.  Very friendly and very helpful.

pass on it.
author: Andrew S.

description: I celebrated my 60th birthday at the Tonga room. The food was great, just to much. The drinks were a little strong. Loved the ambience of the place. Over a great time had by my party
author: Gloria O.

description:
I spent months fretting about this place. Would there be enough space for our group (they don't take reservations unless you have an enormous group), would the drinks be good and strong, would they appreciate a giggly group of bachelorette party-goers and would the band play things we wanted to hear and dance to? The answer to all those questions is yes, thank the lawd.

That said, there are a couple important strategies to ensure a good time:
1) Don't have dinner here. We just had some appetizers, and it was all very mall-food-court, except it's really, really expensive.
2) Drinks are also expensive, but they're very strong. This makes it perfect for, say, a bachelorette party, but not if you're just going out on a regular Friday night.

The good stuff:
Again, the drinks were tasty and strong. The old-school island kitsch of the place was perfect for my bride buddy, who is actually having an island-themed wedding. We got free volcano cakes because it was a big celebration. Free (fabric) leis for everyone. A dance floor that collectively struts its stuff to the band's renditions of "Sweet Caroline" and "Jesse's Girl," among others. It "rains" inside (into the center pool where the band is located) periodically.

And it's also in the Fairmont Hotel, the prettiest, but most expensive night's sleep you'll ever have. No, we didn't stay here, are you kidding?
author: Tara R.

description:
I would expect this kind of shit from some basement lounge on the Vegas strip, but not from arguably one of the nicest hotels in San Francisco.

However, anyone who knows me knows i have a complete weakness/borderline perverted sexual fetish for faux-polynesian kitsch.  

I mean, the fake rainshowers, light up tiki idols, plastic bamboo, neon blue drinks...do i need to spell the words "awesomely rad" out for you, or can you take it from here?

In my dreams, i sit here one night with John Waters, Divine and Rupaul drinking Mai-tais and dancing to the the off key rhythms of the top-40 cover band that floats out on that magical boat. 

Sigh - that hasnt happened yet for me, unfortch.

So i came here last year for my birthday and ended up crying because my boyfriend played a trick on me and somehow got me to believe he had gotten me some shitty sailboat off craigslist, when all i really wanted was a new ipod...so i cried and made a huge scene.  haha - i am such a royal bitch.

Wouldnt you know, i got the ipod anyway and i felt like a huge ass for making everyone stare so much.  I mean, they were totally staring.  I was almost hyperventilating i was so upset over the possibility of a beat down sailboat. 

Regardless, this night was awesome.

So the reason why i give the Tonga Room 3 stars is that it is crazy pricey...and the drinks are watered down like the jokes at a Ray Romano show.  

Also...

They serve you the coconut drinks in ceramic coconuts! 

Ceramic, kids.

Hold on, hold on, back the eff up here... you are gonna charge me half my retirement savings for one lousy sugary bevarage and then have the nerve to serve it up in some busted ass fake coconut?!  

Is nothing sacred anymore?
author: Kirsten S.

description:
What's prompting me to write this review is the article I read on Boing Boing last week (see Beau G's review), saying that the Tonga Room's days might be numbered... It kills me to think that they'd ditch the Tonga Room for some stupid ovepriced condos.  Let's hope the Fairmont  rethinks the plan!

This is hands down the best tiki bar I've ever been to.  Honestly, the term "tiki bar" is a total understatement.  As you walk through the door, they hand you a lei and lead you into an entirely different world, filled with wonderful things like pirate ships and indoor thunderstorms!  It's like Disney World, man.  I can't speak for the food, since I've never bothered with it -- I always go straight for the tiki drinks, which are strong and delicious.  

Losing this place would be awful.  :-(
author: Jane A.

description:
This place is kind of fun and hokey but not the place you want to go if you are looking for great food. The food is priced too high for the quality.

I ordered the ahi poke appetizer and the scallops entree. The ahi poke was bland. I have never had ahi poke that only had tuna and some sesame seeds. I'm used to ahi poke with soy sauce, ogo seaweed, green onions and sometimes other things that add flavor. The ahi poke at Tonga Room was just flavorless mush.

The scallops were even worse. They were undercooked and extremely under seasoned. Luckily they took the scallops back and didn't charge them to the bill.

It's mostly old people who were in the restaurant. I felt like I was at Disneyland in the pirates of the caribbean ride. This is definitely a tourist spot since they can't expect to bank on return customers with the low quality of the food and the overpriced menu. I can't imagine somebody eating at Tonga Room and deciding that they need to return unless they're old people who like cheesy atmosphere and mediocre food at top dollar prices.

Overall it wasn't the worst meal I've had. The ingredients in the food seemed to be of good quality but the poor preparation killed the flavor and texture. My champagne was good though.
author: g m.

description: Decided to try the Tonga Room since I was at a conference nearby and it seemed like a cool idea and it turned out to be cool experience. Service was great...food from appetizer to entrees to desert were tasty - fresh, full of flavor and good portions...environment was fun and inviting. Periodic rain and lightening storms add some excitement.
author: Darrin J.

description:
Went there for a prom night 40 years ago.  I was dying to revisit it and what I was going to pay was not the issue since I had visited the web site.  I was not disappointed. The Singapore Slings were good according to my lady who has had them before.
But the chef needs to go to the Napa Valley to learn how to fry Calamari...They had a lousy oil soaked batter on them.
The Chicken Salad was really one of the best salads I have ever eaten.
The Mongolian Beef had generous chunks of good meat as well as the oyster mushrooms.  It was different than what you would get in another type of place. It too had a lot of oil in it that had me belching oily soy fumes all night.  The coffee was very bad.
The service was good. The quartet really rocked.  We got up to dance several times during our meal.
It is what it is.....I will return.
author: Paul T.

description:
I am so sad to see so many bad reviews of this place. It has elicited so many laughs. Case in point.....

You have to laugh when; 

You take a friend from out of town here and the thunder and lightning start.....no matter how cheesy it is they ohh and ahh like they are getting laid on the 4th of July.

The all "Polynesian" band comes out on their "raft" and sings Madonna and Culture Club with all of the flair and talent of an Old Vegas lounge act.

The middle aged tourists try to dance to the aforementioned band, with a huge buzz and remnants of glazed ribs from the happy hour buffet wedged in their teeth, because this is, after all, vacation and the one time a year they "let loose". 

The bill comes, you're fairly sober and you realized you were totally duped, yet, strangely, you had a good time.
author: Drue C.

description: Very fun ambiance. Try to get a seat next to the pool if at all possible. Enjoy a band floating on a boat, a small dance floor, and periodic artificial rain showers. Nice for a fun or even romantic dinner for two.
author: Jonathan W.

description: Our evening at the Tonga room provided the most entertainment I've had in years.  We went on a Sunday night and there was some kind of aging hippie band (think Barry White and the Eagles), with plenty of randoms hitting the dance floor to bump and grind to the random repertoire.  The cocktails were yummy and tropical but overpriced (par for the course at that hotel).  I just loved how out of place Tonga Room is, right in the middle of in the classy, historic Fairmont.  Just hilarious.  Everyone was super nice and we had pretty decent service.  Best of all?  Immaculate restrooms (guests use the Fairmont conference restrooms).  Not sure I ever would have ventured here had we not been staying in the hotel, but you can better believe I'd come back next time I'm looking for some random tiki-themed hilarity.
author: Kristen W.

description:
Get lei'd

Get made

Get paid.

Kitsch factor:  high
Tourist factor:  even higher

Worth a visit at least once if you're a local or out-of-towner.  Be prepared to pay at least $10 a drink for the simple stuff; exotic stuff quite a bit more.  I'd imagine it goes to the "let's clean the tourist puke out of the pool in the middle of the room" fund.  Our server, though courteous, did have to look down at his name badge a couple times when we asked his name (it was too dark for us to read the small print).  Maybe they're running a witness protection program here.  I could see that.  

Food is tasty but not exceptional (think mass-produced) and portions are on the small side.  You do get to explore your creative persona with those tiny drink umbrellas while you lounge in tiki goodness, so I guess it's just the price you pay.  If you're in good company, all the better.  

Go ahead and let loose here.  Bust a move on the dance floor or sing along with the floating raft people in your best fake accent.  If you ever return, it's highly unlikely you'll ever run into those same tourists again.  

Make it rain.
author: Jeff H.

description:
* food sucks
* overpriced
* decor is gimmicky at best
* did i mention? the food really, really sucks.

tourist trap, if i've ever seen one.  i have no idea how a place like this can survive in the city.

you have been warned.
author: vuForce Fresh n.

description:
I agreed to be friends date for her firms party, but I wouldn't  have guessed I would end up in a parallel dimension.This easily takes the cake for the most surreal place I've been to in SF. 
I wasn't drinking, but I sampled a couple drinks and damn were they strong. With drinks called the "Scorpion" served with 2 foot straws (hoses), go here if you want to tie one on frat boy style.
The boat in the center with the singer is a interesting touch and the people dancing are hilarious to watch (50's cult time warp) but it all lost it's novelty quick. I was in the corner with plenty of empty seats around having a conversation, and the waitress kept coming over and asking for an "Entertainment charge" which was annoying.  There is a 2g tab at the bar and you want 5dollars??

This is the place to go if you're a 50plus real estate agent in town for a convention.
author: Debu M.

description:
Tonga Room. Tourist Magnet. Tourist Trap.

How do I know? When I was in college, we used to come up here from Southern California each year to either watch USC play Stanford or USC play Cal. Little did I know, I would eventually go to USC, UCLA, Stanford and Cal. So who do I root for now? All of them.

Anyway, we used to come to SF like I said, and we would always go to Tiki Bob's, the Saint Francis Hotel, Lefty O'Doul's and the Tonga Room.

And of all the places, I liked the Tonga Room the least because it just seemed so tacky. You would go inside, it would be all dark and the rainforest would be raining down all that mist. I got claustrophobic in there and to me it just wasn't that fun, good or romantic. And the drinks, at the time, seemed expensive.

I don't think that I have ever eaten here and after reading these yelp reviews, I am not sure that I ever will now. Kind of hit and miss it seems. 

For dates, proms and marriages I can see where this would be a fun place to come because it has so much going on. It does have some uniqueness as far as kitchyness and charm too. But for me, I would rather eat and talk at a place where the food/dining experience is more reliable.

Thanks yelp. You have, once again, steered me either towards or away from a good/bad restaurant.
author: Terry H.

description:
First of all, you really have to be down with the whole Tiki culture thing to get it. The Tonga Room is right up there with some of the best tiki bars in America and in my opinion is one of the best kept secrets in SF (thank God).  It's such a part of SF history - it's been there for something like 70 years! 

Yes, the waiters are rude. Have you never been to New York? All the cheesier IMO, so just get over it. BTW - on my last excursion there with my husband and 10 year old our waiter was just fine. 

It's nice and dark at all hours with some fantastic tiki paraphanelia. Round tables & dark leatherette chairs.  The little lake in the center could have been ripped out years ago to make way for more tables, but did they? No, and that 's what I like about this place. Anyway, if they did lose the lake there'd be no place for the floating barge that the band sits on.   If I had any negatives at all it would be that the music wasn't right. Throw some Les Baxter or Martin Denny in the mix and it would be perfect all around. 

Best time to go is absolutely happy hour. Tons of yummy, fried, greasy, delectable goodies including Chinese spare ribs, dumplings, greasy things, egg rolls, more greasy things all for around 7 bucks. Order the drink that's the size of your head. It comes with 2 ridiculously long straws that makes for a good photo op and then just wait -- a little longer --- a few more seconds and crash! Call me a simpleton, but a thunderstorm INSIDE a bar? Very sexy. Order another one of those bathtub drinks and the experience will become exponentially better.  I promise you.
author: Valerie M.

description:
Look at the boat! Its floating! And there is a band on it playing cover music! Wow! Look at the menu! Its got pictures of all the drinks! Oh my god! Look its raining over the pool with the boat in it! Oh my god! I'm so drunk! 

This is pretty much what its like to go to the Tonga Room for the first time. But beware the Tiki curse... Strong drinks made with cheap rum will cause you pain the following afternoon when you finally wake up.
author: Sean D.

description: One of my favorite places in San Francisco, and I am a native. I love the rain and the lake in the middle and the pina coladas and the scorpion bowls and the fried-food-fat-fest buffet at happy hour so much that I won't even deduct a point for being politely asked to leave a few weeks ago. Apparently I drank too much at a wedding across the street and a girlfriend and I mistook the Tonga Room for a dance floor. Apologies to the waitstaff trying to serve food around us. I still love you, Tonga Room, and there's not a thing you can do to make me love you less.
author: Autumn K.

description:
Now I'm not biased, nor am I "5-starring" this place because of their current situation, but I am gonna tell you the truth about Tonga Room.

It's a San Francisco Icon.

It's a great local escape from the stressful, the pretentious, the overdone-modern desiged-straight out of an Ikea catalog-boring joints that fill up San Francisco. 

The food is not "5 star"  but is worth the money if you tie in the ambience and the chill jazz acts on the floating stage.

The bar is "5 Star" in my book.  If you had to have the perfect Mai Tai once in your life, you'd get it here.

The service is good, not THE best, but more than sufficient enough for you to get what you want.

If you want to get rid this place, or agree that this place should be rid of, you:  a) must not be from around here, b) never got out much, c)are lame and pretentious, d) All of the above. 

I've celebrated many important occasions here-  
my parents' anniversary
my birthday
my dinner before my Senior Ball
Special Dinners with my now Ex girlfriend.

And, YES...I HAVE been here RECENTLY!

EVERY experience I've had here was memorable and beyond pleasant.

I signed the recent petition to save it...You should, too if you care about any of the REAL spots of San Francisco.

http://www.savetonga.com/
author: Gio G.

description:
So yesterday my friend and I decided to check out the tonga room because of it's great $7 appetizer buffet deal.  Unfortunately it's $7 worth of greasy (not the good kind!), lukewarm, less than mediocre food. Yuck! I opted to eat more of the fresh fruit since that's all that was truly edible.  

Originally, I was going to give this place two stars but then I remember that I wasn't satisfied with the Chi chi cocktail that I accidentally ordered and our cocktail waitress let me order something else to replace it.  The drinks are quite strong but pricey - so if you're looking to get smashed on tropical drinks in a cheesy fakey rainy atmosphere - check this place out.  

This is a place to take your out of towners for a coupla drinks and then biggety bounce.
author: Aim E.

description: A must for tiki fans, go during happy hour. If you miss happy hour, they may try and charge you a cover, either sit at the bar or tell them you are a hotel guest and you wont have to pay. Drink quality can vary, but apps are good. Totally worth the trip to see this classic bar.
author: Alex A.

description:
We went here on a Saturday night with a group of 5 to celebrate a birthday.  It was very surprising to walk through the lobby of such a classy, elegant hotel to find a totally tropical oasis downstairs.  The restaurant had a fun vibe with lots of kooky additions (a lake with a boat and band in the middle of the restaurant?) The band was actually pretty good, a little loud but good.  We ordered:
- fried rice (yummy)
- scallops (my fav dish of the night, the corn accompaniment was soo good)
- duck (I don't eat duck, but my bf said it was good)
- hamburger patty thing (not too bad, but strange to order a burger patty)
- pina colada and strawberry daquiri (both were wayyyy too sweet, sickeningly so)

The reason for only 3 stars is because even though the service was good and food was decent, I felt that everything we ate was horribly salty.  I'm sure it's a matter of preference because some in the party thought it was good.  I wouldn't mind coming back here again if only to get their mixed rice and the scallops.  There's also a fun dance floor that quite a few people were tearing up :)
author: Yvette T.

description:
The Tonga Room is the epitome of tiki-chic.  I have been here several times for special events and happy hour.  While it's a little on the pricey side I find the schtick of the place is almost worth the inflated drink prices.

Known fact: every time I go to the Tonga Room I wake up with a headache the next day from drinking way too many overpriced sugary foo-foo girlie drinks.

A lesser known fact: if you go to the Tonga Room for happy hour on a weeknight you can partake in a free appetizer buffet which off sets the price of drinks by making it possible for you to skip dinner.

A very little known fact: the floating band will call you "Mark" no matter what your name actually is when they sing the birthday song to you.

A fact that I do not know personally: *cough, cough* Two Tonga Room tiki tumblers and a pair of chopsticks fit conveniently into the average sized purse. *cough, cough*

But, like I said: I have no first hand knowledge of that.

*takes drink of water out of tiki tumbler*

This is not the kind of place that I want to hang out at on a regular basis; but, every once in a while it's kinda fun.
author: Kate R.

description: This is a great spot for group activities and celebrations! Our club coordinated with Food and Beverage Manager, Luke Skinner and special guest hostess, Lilly, for an incredible evening at the Tonga Room. We danced to the music from the band floating on an island in the room's lagoon. Buffet and drinks were excellent. Service was the best! We will do it again!
author: Chuck H.

description:
While I was here I had to ask myself, "Should a cocktail make me this angry?"  

Kitsch, yes, there was fake rain into a pool in the middle.  There was no live music tonight, it was dead.  In fact, there was no crowd... But that didn't stop the servers from being extremely slow and completely helpless.  

I came here with my fellow yelper, Sarunya, plus two.  We had to wait ten minutes for the server to take our drink order and even then she acted as though she was VERY very rushed... with the two tables that she was serving.  

We just wanted to do happy hour but service was so slow that by the time our drinks had arrived we were all starving.   While we were waiting for our drinks to arrive we wandered around and saw the manager (lady in all black) and a server arguing because apparently someone had called in sick and they couldn't deal.  

Asked to order dinner items after our drinks, but we were told we had to order from another server if we wanted food.  WTH???  We asked to move to the dinner section instead of the bar so we could eat dinner (and get a new server). 

My second cocktail, a melon daiquiri, was not blended very well and was completely overtaken by the amount of sweet and sour mix poured into it.  Can you imagine what a sweet and sour smoothie tastes like?  Just all sour and ice?  Yes, that's what they gave me.  

It was like a miserable miserable midori sour.  While I was jabbing at it to break apart the ice so I could drink it, I noticed that I was very angry at this cocktail... but I remembered that it wasn't the cocktail's fault.  It was the bartenders!

The food came out and it wasn't very good.  It was OK, and for the price, I could have received better food at the Cheesecake Factory.  THAT'S RIGHT!  The Cheesecake Factory.

In the end, I left cranky and hungry.  The drinks were not tasty and the food was mediocre.  If I wanted kitsch I can go to bubba gumps restaurant, and for better tasting drinks and appetizers, I can go somewhere else.  I would not recommend this place, even to "try."
author: Wilson K.

description:
Only the sheer tack of this place saves it from a less than 3 star rating. 

Came here last night with a fairly large group of people to sit in the bar area.  They accommodated nicely and then our waitress came around and took our order in two parts.  But not the standard drinks then food way, in the "I'll get the order of HALF THE PEOPLE first, get that shit out, then take the order of the other half of the people".  And after that I don't think we saw her again.  She clearly needs another line of work.  

Also the prices made me want to have a heart attack.  One thing was totally worth the crazy prices: this volcano dessert thing that my friend and I ordered was on FIRE.  Mind you it was supposed to be an ice cream cake.  That I am willing to pay $12 for.  But the rest of it? I mean I know it's the Fairmont but seriously? $4 for tea?  Isn't it just hot water & dried leaves?

But the saving grace of this place was that it is Pirates of the Caribbean come home to roost.  It is definitely an experience to have.  Raining inside on the hour with a live band on a boat that plays cheesy ass music to match the venue. There is a small yet decent dance floor too.  Granted if you sit down in the bar after the band goes on they put signs out that they will charge you a cover for the nautical lounge music.  $5 I believe.  Huh, I thought I was paying for that with the $4 tea.  Guess I'm paying for the rain and the beyond tacky and hilarious Polynesian decor.
author: Alexis B.

description: Great food. Not to thrilled about the added charges for entertainment and tip.
author: Jason A.

description: It seems like touristy fun, but the food is subpar and the service sketchy.
author: Cheryl P.

description: Romantic, lively & fun.  Great, killer drinks and the live band that floats on the pool playing island tunes makes this experience a San Francisco must!
author: Emily R.

description:
Tonight was our friend Tom's birthday and he picked the Tonga Room for his gathering. There were a dozen of us from the east bay meeting in Nob Hill for drinks.

We get there about 9:15. After looking for parking for a while, we settle for the $12 an hour lot. That seems crazy ... but that is our choice.

The line at the Tonga room is about 20 people. The fee to get in is $7 each ... and you get your lei on the way in. This is how they know you paid to get in.

The Tonga room is nice and cheesy at the same time.  It is kinda like Disney Land. 

The atmosphere is unique since a lot of bars and nightclubs in San Francisco do not have enough room to put on a show like this. The Fairmont dedicates a lot of floor space for this club. It is costly.

Once we settle into our table and we order drinks, the band was ready to light up the stage.

The band floated out in the middle of the water and they began to play Michael Jackson tunes. When I heard the music I thought we were at someone's wedding celebration. I was looking for Autie Ruth on the dance floor because she is the first to boogie every time.

I'll have a drink please. I really need a drink.

As you would expect ... the drinks are expensive and not very good. They look good though. My husband said for what they charge, they should give you better liquor. I agree. That would be the least they could do for all of the torture so far.

All of the cocktails in the tiki style glasses look very festive. All in all, it is a fun plac to go. Just keep an eye on the time and remember that the parking bill is at least $36 by now.

I hope no one pukes on the way home.That would be bad.

Happy Birthday Tom!
author: Lee R.

description:
Never Never eat here!!!   Came in there with my family and friends for a quick bite before a show and the Maitre'd told us "dinner is far better than the happy hour."   If that's the case than happy hour must be dog food.  

You would think that being in the Fairmont hotel this place would have 
to live up a standard.  I ordered the chicken curry which I think I could have made better at home. At $26 bucks I felt offended. The salads were small and overpriced as well. My Maitai was pretty legit but everything else Sucked.  There's no pretty way to say it. This place sucks.

Also the waiter dropped off our food and then didn't come back to the table until the meal was done.  Terrible service.
The happy hour was voted the best for 2006 but because the Maiter'd blatantly lied to us I will never step back in this place again.  Worst Meal I have ever had hands down.
author: Adam L.

description: I could have made better stir fry myself. The entertainment was very cheesy! Three guys singing on a boat in a pool in the middle of the restaurant, and they couldn't sing.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Crappiest cheesiest place ever !!!
Waste of money..... Food sucks... I'm so glad it's closing down... Wonder how much money they paid to get featured on travel channel... Or is travel channel running out of great places to feature..... Shame on travel channel to feature this place...makes me wanna stay away from Travel channel itself thinking that it might be biased in a lot of different ways.
No originality in the place. Food does not fit the theme they have.
author: Justyna R.

description:
Cheesy South Pacific decor?  Check.
Mast parts and rigging parts from an old ship that circumnavigated the globe?  Check.
Fruity rum drinks which taste great and pack an amazing whollop?  Check.
Indoor lagoon?  Check.
Barge full of lounge singers floating on indoor lagoon?  Check.
Occasionally rains indoors?  Check.
Complimentary wasabi-infused quasi-Asian snack mix?  Check.
Relatively easy to get seated in the bar?  Check.
Nob Hill institution?  Check.
One form of payment they don't take: check.

Sit in the bar and drink.  Don't eat dinner here, it combines the worst parts of overpriced and suckitude.  But do drink yourself into oblivion.  And buy me a drink if you see me there.  I always do.
author: Ben P.

description:
First impression, fun tiki decor.  I was not fooled, however.  I did still realize that I was still in San Francisco.  I don't care *how* many pirates were milling around.  The food was good, but the menu wasn't overly populated with choices, so there is that.  I think I would have expected a wider array of menu items.

The pool and periodic tropical storms in the middle of the room mitigate the lack of food choice...to a degree.

We had an attentive and accommodating server and the food was good, but not worth the trip in itself.  With dinner, I had a yummy strawberry Chi-chi.  Mmmmm...tropical booze.

Following dinner, we went over to the bar for a friend's 40th birthday celebration.  I had more Chi-chi's and then, feeling not at ALL intoxicated, noticed a startling difference in the bar menu from the dinner drink menu.  Nowhere on the bar menu is ANY SORT OF BOOZE listed as an ingredient in the Chi-Chi.  What the hell?

I am not a lush.  I rarely drink, but on the occasion that I am at a birthday party in a tiki inspired bar surrounded by a bunch of burners and a man dressed as Wonder Woman, NOT TO MENTION, Sara Silverman dressed in a gorilla suit and throwing ripe bananas at me, I WANT BOOZE IN MY CHI-CHI!  Seriously.  

Oh...and the bar servers were atrocious.  I'll just throw that out there.
author: Emily H.

description:
Bring some sturdy crackers, cuz this place puts the cheese on thick.  Enjoy the rain shower every 30 minutes.  Enjoy the 80's music coming from the band on the moving, floating island in the, errr, ocean.  And most of all enjoy the lava bowls with a few friends and some yard long straws.  This place does not know the meaning of the word subtle.  If you go there expecting all of that, it does not under-deliver.  

If you want a classy place, a cool place, or a hip scene, you will not like the Tonga room.  If you want good food, forget the tonga room too.  This is a bunch of out of towners and locals out cheese balling and getting ripped on tropical punches.  If you are there late enough and you want a random unabashed out-of-town hook-up with some hotel guest in their 40's or 50's, this place might be just what you are looking for too (any cougar hunters in the audience tonight?).  Oh, but watch out for evil prostitutes milking free drinks from unsuspecting guests who only wanted to buy them a drink before paying them for sex.  If you want to pay someone for sex, negotiate that first, then buy them a drink to take up to the room with you.

Most of all, have fun at the Tonga room, cuz that's what most people are doing there.  It is just a cheesy place to dance like no one is watching, and really, no one is . . . especially here.
author: Paul W.

description:
Sheesh.

1 Year anniversary at the Tonga Room:

They took our reservation for 8:30 PM,  but didn't have a table ready until after 9:00. When I complained, the snotty hostess told me "It should be just a moment". Half an Hour?! It's a reservation! That means you RESERVE it!!!  Like Seinfeld said, "Anyone can just TAKE 'em". If I wanted to wait, I wouldn't have called TWO WEEKS ahead! 

The manager told us that "good" restaurants don't EVER have tables available. Cripes! Let ME be the judge of what a good restaurant is! I'm the customer! You overbooked you stupid fuck!

Service was TERRIBLE, but I didn't stiff on the tip (because I'm a waiter too, and I know that some nights are just difficult), if I was a normal person, she'd be lucky to get 10 percent... I just wanted a glass of water! It took 15 minutes! She managed to turn an hour long meal into an hour and a half. It wouldn't bother me so much if I weren't a waiter too. I could do better any night, and I don't make no Tonga Room money.

The tab for two people: $125 (Yikes!)

$14 cover charge for the shitty pop band. They play on a little boat...that's cute. But it doesn't justify the cost when the tab is so high.

Food was good, but portions were small. Very small. If I hadn't ordered that $10 desert, I would have left hungry.

Lame.
author: Arthur W.

description:
Too loud. If I were to sit around alone, or be expecting a club/ bar like atmosphere, sure. As a restaurant, it doesn't work at all for me. I need to be able to actually talk and hear what someone else is saying in order to appreciate a restaurant.

In this case, the atmosphere was fairly loud to begin with but the main difficulty was the live music (I know, typically considered a plus, but not if I want to talk to someone).

If you like something quieter in the same spot, I would recommend the restaurant and/or bar in the Fairmont hotel - up the elevator from the Tonga Room.
author: Peter S.

description: The obvious good points about the Tong Room is that it is an icon of San Francisco. Even as a local I enjoy going once in a while to sample the scenery. Like walking the Golden Gate, Tonga Room is something you do about once a year or so just to say that you love being in San Francisco. That said, they need to work on the menu. It's a bit dated and generic. The best feature is the mixed drink list.
author: Brian J.

description: The Tonga Room was great. It felt like I was on vacation on a Tropical Island. The food was also great. However, I did not like the $7.00 charge per person for the entertainment that was added to our dining bill.  The band was good, but I'm not too sure if the bands change. There is also a small dance floor.  it reminded me of Hawaii or a filipino party.
author: Lyka C.

description:
I love it here.  Live band in the middle of the fake ocean - YES!  Fruity drinks in fun glasses - YES!  Fake rain storm - YES!  

Drinks are a little steep, but you can dance and the ambiance is great.  There might be some older folks hanging around as its an old establishment.  When I told my mom I was going there, she said "That used to be my favorite place!  It's was always special to go on a date there."  She's been married 30+ years.  Ok mom, just don't show up on Saturday night.
author: Brittney B.

description:
I should give the Tonga Room a bad review.  There's a lot to hate here, starting with the $7 cover on some nights because some god-awful cover band is playing, to the fact that the majority of the crowd seems to be older business travelers and bachelorette parties from Walnut Creek.  The tropical drink menu is surprisingly small for a tiki bar, and the drinks tend to taste syrupy.  It's obvious they're using cheap liquor and juice from concentrate.

And yet despite all that, I love this place.  Maybe it's because it's real kitsch, not some tarted-up hipster version of kitsch.  Maybe it's because it feels like Disneyland decided to make a bar.  Maybe it's the rainstorm!  Whatever the reason, I keep coming back here, especially in winter when I really need a faux-tropical getaway.  Bonus: The old menus lining the hallway outside are a trip.

Going early and on weekdays is the best way to avoid that pesky cover charge, by the way.
author: Sarah D.

description:
I judge this place on "hi, i'm drunk everytime I've been to the Tonga Room and have not had to pay for any of my drinks".....with that being said.....I like the cheesy ambiance and the drinks are poured strong.  Fun dance floor for the old timers, kids and lushes like me.  Great place to take out of towners.

****
i lost my groomsmaid dress at this establishment.  :(
author: Christina S.

description:
I went here to dance a little cha cha (1-2....cha cha cha) on a Friday night.

We arrived and the place was full, but we got a seat without a problem.  Kind of a touristy bunch, but I guess that is expected at a hotel bar.  

I give this place more than 1 star because the live band was fun and they play on in a gazebo in the middle of the tropical lake.

There were many problems with out night there:

1) They don't charge the $7 cover at the front, but it's built into your bill.  So that expensive $10 fruity cocktail is $17.  

2) The $10 fruity drinks are nasty.  I've spent some serious fruity-cocktail-time in South Florida.  Give me a rum runner with a 151 floater on the beach in Fort Lauderdale any day over whatever is in the drinks at the Tonga Room. 

3) The server was REALLY pushy about buying the drinks as soon as we sat down.  

4) When I checked my credit card statement the next day, I was double charged for our one transaction.  The Tonga Room apparently gave us a little something extra to remind us of our special night.
author: Tim W.

description: I'm obsessed with this place. I wish i lived in SF just so i can frequent this bar. I love tiki bars and 60's inspired decor so of course I loved the Tonga Room. Can't wait to go back
author: Kelly M.

description: This place has an amazing ambiance and great music for dancing. I have been there several times, both on week nights and on weekends and it's always full. You definitely need a reservation. The cocktails are a bit pricey but interesting. The Pina Colada is really good! The food is very expensive and OK but nothing special. Definitely worth it for the dancing, the music and the thunderstorms!
author: Dawn S.

description:
I hadn't visited the Tonga Room for over 15 years.  We checked it out Friday, after hearing the news about the possible closure.  It was crowded, with a wait for cocktails for over 20 minutes.  The wait was almost worthwhile, if we don't get back here.

$7/per person cover?  PLUS drinks and appetizers.  not an inexpensive night out.  I'm giving 4 stars because I don't want to see the place close.  Service was pretty mechanical.  Atmosphere was fun.
author: Collin W.

description:
Welcome to your mini-vacation!

The Tonga Room is all about the atmosphere, it's something to experience at least once.  If the food quality lived up to the lush surroundings, this place would be amazing. However, it's great fun to come here with friends visiting town. 

It is pricey, but it's all about the fun experience and the world famous scorpion bowl!
author: Valerie S.

description: How have I lived in SF and not been here until this week?! This place is a total gem with its Disneyland-esque rain storms, tiki decor galore, and seriously lethal lava bowls! I couldn't bring myself to order an entree here since it's ridiculously priced for asiany noodles and mushrooms but my friends and I did split an app platter and everything was decently tasty, especially the ribs! Also beware of the entertainment charge that you will have to pay if the band starts playing during your mini vaycay. It's $5 per person on off-nights and $7 per person prime time. Personally I'd rather apply that money toward another drink and just listen to Elvis' Blue Hawaii soundtrack on my iPod but the band does play some fun songs and it's cute to watch the father-daughter dances. Aloha!  Another round please!
author: Krystle S.

description:
Where else can you go and have fruity little drinks with umbrella's, live band, a ship deck dance floor  and indoor rain???
Yes....Tonga is cheesy beyond belief, but on a whatever night, it's fun to get all dolled up and go for happy hour.....I love dancing to the cover band, cheesy 80's music and drinking WAY too many scorpion bowls....really, this place is classic SF.....go here for the atmosphere and the drinks......the food is "eh"...
author: Bianca L.

description: We went here with a grp of friends for happy hour and had a very pleasant time. The drinks were excellent, quite strong. We also ordered the edamami, chicken satay, and egg rolls. The food was decent but over priced. But the venue was cool.
author: Mrs S.

description:
Since when does a plate of mongolian beef cost $30???!?!!!

2 stars for the atmosphere and drinks.  And the live band for an extra $5?  After I've already paid $30 for a plate of mongolian beef???  Yeah, it stops at 2 stars.
author: Liz C.

description: The service was horrible. Had a reservation, but was told that since our whole party was not there they reserved the right to take back our table if they got busy. Our waitress was unfriendly and had no "aloha spirit". Drinks were overpriced, but strong. Atmosphere was very tourist, but it was very cute inside. And the rain added a little extra to the experience.
author: Olivia M.

description:
The closest thing in San Francisco to feel like you're drinking at Disneyland. The Tonga Room.

Now, whenever I go to a tiki bar that isn't Trad'R Sams , I feel like I'm cheating on a loved one but, the Tonga Room so revels in its, um, "Tonga-ness" that you can't help but smile and appreciate Don Ho.

Inside the cave that is the Tonga Room, you'll find this rather large pond with a boat floating in it and every so often you'll notice that it rains indoors. Don't worry you won't get wet. 

Drinks are a bit pricey but you have to factor in the amusement level to the cost, in which case, they're practically a bargain. I've never eaten there but I admit, I'd like to try.

All in all, much like Disneyland (minus the lines), the place is so silly, you can't help but enjoy your time there.
author: Andy A.

description:
Tonga Room is tiki classic.  Mai tais?  Check.  Scorpion bowls?  Check.  Elaborate tiki carvings?  Check.  Band on a floating boat in the restaurant?  WTF?  Check!

Tonga Room even takes it up a notch with the frequent indoor rainstorms.  (No, it isn't just some fool setting off the sprinkler system!)  They have an all you can eat happy hour buffet for less than $10, which is a great deal.  Gary Danko it isn't but what do you expect for 10 bucks? 

The Lava something drink is insanely potent - just pure alcohol.  The scorpion bowl isn't sized for six but is plenty big and comes with straws long enough that people on the far side of the table can get in a few sips.

Stay classy San Francisco.
author: Aaron T.

description:
The first time I ever went to the Tonga Room was a long long time ago.  It's one of those memories that I have suppressed over the years.  If I had to, I could remember ... a very naive college student in a velvet gown... terrible but pricey chinese food... white girl moves danced to the theme of Hawaii 5-0.... lots of tack with extra cheese...  painful but in that aw you were so young and you didn't know any better way.

More updated memory (from last Friday night) - rude service, ovepriced drinks, entertainment fee with no entertainment and it was nearly empty on a Friday night (at 11pm).  The cheesiness reminded me of my recent cruise but at least the cruise had free entertainment and buffets.  

I don't think I'll go back 

except maybe for the buffet.
author: mia s.

description:
The Tonga Room is the completely unhip, Treasure-troll cousin of the San Francisco bar scene--it lives underground, it is neon-colored, it has strange plumage and it is absolutely a left over from another era.  Bring friends you can have a good time with because their company will absolutely be the best thing about the place.  

That said, it's pretty amazing that this has managed to survive (and will probably outlast!) the many incarnations and evolutions of SF hipsterdom.  Fake rain, cover band in a boat, and gigantic, expensive, syrupy cocktails--you have not experienced the finest that Tiki can offer until you've been to the Tonga Room.
author: vicarious c.

description: one of my favorite places to go. Great place for dates! nice bar, live music, dance floor, and great food!
author: Nicholas L.

description:
You gotta go for the cheese factor alone.  Seriously, the rain?  The floating band?  The fruity drinks served in redonkulous containers?  Sometimes on fire, even.

Actually, for post-work happy hour, it's not a bad spot.

Oh, and don't forget to bring a jacket or something to keep you warm if you get cold in the produce aisle of the supermarket when those misters go off.  Brrrr....
author: Anonymouse C.

description: Mixture of Tiki Room, the restaurant in Pirates and a Jungle "Booze" Cruise. The drinks are strong and happy hour buffet is less than $10 with a one drink minimum. The chicken is great, especially the sauce. Drink are around $7.50 but are worth it.
author: M S.

description:
I went to this restaurant for my friend's birthday -- and although it's supposed to be a fun environment with the whole boat-floating-in-water-indoors and person singing thing ... the food was extremely overpriced and not good ... just wannabe asian food served in nice little displays -- but Panda Express in the mall probably tastes 50 times better than anything they serve here. 

I got the expensive cool looking drink that comes in a pineapple, and it was like two sips -- and the rest was ice.

The entertainment was ok, but when the check comes and you see that they charged $3/person extra fee for it -- it's just gives you further confirmation that this place is just NOT worht it.  Not only do they charge you extra for entertainment, the charge you extra for rice, and there's barely any parking in the area.

I noticed a lot of tourist families enjoying the cheesy environment and music, so maybe it's a good place for people who like expensive bad tasting food and cheesy fun.....

As for me, "No thank you."  I would never go back to this place again.
author: Sandy C.

description:
The Tonga Room is somewhere you go to if you want to be surrounded in an atmophere that makes you feel like you're on vacation on some tropical island. The lighting is colorful but not too bright and when you walk in you automatically smile because you feel like you've walked into something that's been waiting for you to enjoy your entire life.

The glowing blue pool in the center of the restaurant is hard to miss and one of the first things noticed. Above, surrounding the pool, is a husk hut and every half-hour or so water flows down and the sound of lightening goes off, which is pretty cool. There's a stage in the middle of the pool that bands play on on certain nights of the week. There is a seperate area/room for people who want to have some cocktails and a few snacks, but not dine. 

On certain days (you have to check the website) they have a buffet specializing in asian-pacific fusion food. Dim sum, buns, a few meat dishes, but nothing fancy, nothing spectacular tasting, and a small selection. The buffet is cutely decorated and is about $7, but you are also required to order a drink when you eat at the buffet. This is where they get you. I chose coca-cola because I assumed soft drinks would be the cheapest (yeah ,yeah). When the bill came the soda was like $4! No WONDER the buffet was so cheap. Tisk-tisk. Sneaky little boogers they are.

Although the food quality was a bit mediocre and expensive, I would come back because I did have fun and I think the ambiance makes up for everything.
author: Jen Y.

description:
This is one example of a restaurant that has improved with age. Our first visit here was back in the early 80's and all I remember was having to tip the host so he wouldn't seat you next to the kitchen and  expensive, mediocre chinese food (chow mein, sweet and sour pork, etc.).
While it is still freakishly overpriced the food is now quite good. My husband and I were pleasantly surprised. Our first visit was in late June with our son visiting from grad school. We hung out in the bar and had an appetizer sampler plate and cocktails. We especially liked the ribs and the coconut shrimp and of course enjoyed listening to the cover band play songs from the 70's and 80's and watching all the inebriated couples dance. It was a hoot.
Our most recent visit was last night with  a party of 4 for dinner. We went with the family style dinner (Pangai Island) which proved to be WAY too much food. (Our server did try to warn us beforehand but we chose it anyway). We started with ribs, spring rolls and coconut prawns. Then came green papaya salad (good), then sweet and sour soup that wasn't typical of most in that it didn't have that vinegar overkill. I actually enjoyed it. Unfortunately, by the time the soup came I was pretty much full. Then they rolled out our serving cart of entrees, seafood hot pot, dragon chicken, lamb curry, forbidden rice, szechwan green beans. All the entrees were quite good but we ended up taking much of it home. Then dessert arrived, mango mousse which thankfully was light as air and a great end to the meal.
We had several cocktails, mai tai, scorpion, hurricane (you get to keep the glass) and the singapore sling. I think the hurricane was the best of the bunch. Oddly, we didn't care for the mai tai. Also, the singapore sling packed a punch! 
The same cover band was there as were the drunk people on the dance floor. It is obvious that the Tonga Room is one of those special occasion restaurants. We heard many Happy Birthday songs and large groups and families enjoying themselves. By the time we left around 10:00 the bar was completely packed and the place was buzzing.
Also, while we were dining a gentleman came by and offered to take our picture. He was using an old style black and white film camera. He took our photos and about 25 minutes later presented us with a pair of matchbooks with our photo on the cover and two 5 X 7 black and white photos. We had the option of choosing one or more but we splurged and got the entire package. It was a fun and kitschy way to remember our visit. 
This place is a landmark and I'm really happy that it is still here after all these years!
author: Alyssa N.

description: I was probably to most excited San franciscan when going to this place. I have been wanting to experience the Tonga Room since I moved here - 4 years ago and finally did it! The great thing was the place is phenominal. You can beat decor like this and the band was the perfect touch for a cheesy night to remember forever. The bad was the fodd and the service. I have never quite experienced anything like this. If you like S&M you will love the servers. If you don't know what that means - go to the Tonga Romm and you will find out very quickly :(.
author: Laura A.

description:
I'm so sad that the Tonga Room is closing. My father was a regular here when ballroom dancing was all the rage back in the early 60s, and we had our father daughter dance at my wedding reception, also at the Tonga Room in 2002.  

The Tonga Room is one of the few fun bars that you can bring a minor to in San Francisco.  I always bring my niece here when she comes to visit.  She gets a giant non-alcoholic drink out of a pineapple and I have a cocktail - it's perfect.

Minus one star because the drinks are SO EXPENSIVE and the wait staff can be weird about sitting at various tables on Friday and Saturday nights.  They are reserved for the tour buses that bring the tourists in.
author: Justice Cat ..

description:
The family came here last night while some are in town from Denver and Oregon.  

My mom and her sisters thought this place would be fun since they used to come here as a family years back. I hadn't been here in 18 years so I wasn't sure what to think. I don't really recall much from before.My four year old loved it. 

The band was great. I don't think they charge the cover if you eat dinner rather then hang in the bar. Our server (can't recall his name) was really on top of it. 

The food was well done and presentation was impressive. They even hunted down a small cup of ice cream for my son from the room service kitchen. The whole production kept my 4 year old busy body happy for over 3 hours... you earned the 4 stars just for that! 

On a plus size; the place was pretty busy and the dance floor was full at even 9pm. There was a handful of woman that I am sure should have been cut off a bit ago - but, hey they were fun to watch. 

I would say take a friend from out of town. I have had better food but, it is the overall effect that makes the prices worth it.
author: Amanda E.

description: I heard of this place after watching Anthony Bourdain and since I was in the city, I decided to make a stop here since I've been wanting to go for the longest time after watching the episode. Hidden within the Fairmont Hotel, this bar/lounge is cute! It reminded me of Pirates of the Caribbean at Disneyland. Dimly lit, this place is pretty chill and intimate with candlelit tables. My friend and I only ordered a drink each since we were semi bar hopping that night and their Happy Hour was pretty impressive! I'm not positive exactly how much was discounted but it SEEMED to be that the cocktails were half off or close to half off. The drinks came out strong and nicely presented with multiple garnishes and interesting glassware. Service was on par and i loved the center where it randomly "rains" and has a little boat for live music. If you're ever in the area, this is definitely a must go to place for drinks.
author: Marissa C.

description: So fun and so strange, but not as tacky as expected! They have live music some nights beginning at 8:15pm ($5 service charge) and a dance floor that people (all ages) were doing there thing on. Awesome rain storms and drinks, food was good but a bit oily. Good size portions though. Not a place I would go to on a regular basis, but so fun for drinks and dancing or to bring out of town visitors.
author: J E.

description:
drinks suck
i'll start off w/ that
dont expect tiki ti
however, the chicken wings at their happy hour buffett are to this day the best ive ever had
not greasy, lotsa meat, no fat, flavorful sweet
happy hour starts at 5,  and we arrived about 15 min before as i read how you 'll wait to be seated if you arrive after or  at exactly 5
and lo & behold there were 2 groups ahead of us
so at 5 they let in the swarm & i think there was 1 bartender & 3 servers so yup, our drinks took forever
AND, the bathrooms are far away like annoying far
so back to the drinks.
picture my 14 yr old neice mixing what she assumes a hawaiian cocktail is & there ya go:
but youre coming here for the history of the tonga room, for the love & obsession w/ tiki, the respect for the oldies, & cuz youre on vacay .. & on that note, yes, the clientele was like a midwest family reunion (family as in university of wisconsin class of 1970)
so arrive hungry 
the spread was off the chains
mac salad, those damn tasty wings, & fried rice & other goodies i cant remember
but yes, worth every penny
so we had 4 cocktails & 2 buffetts & it was about 60$ minus tip obviously & no, we didnt get tacked on that rumored entertainement charge 
all in all, if youre still weeping over bahooka, & this is your 1st time here, yes you'll fall in love
the boat on the water,
the fake rain, the decor, drinking out of a real pineapple, yes, you'll be happy
viva la tonga room
oh, and we walked to chinatown from 5th/market, & then took a bus about 3 blocks westbound cuz the streets heading here are STEEP trust
author: belinda n.

description: This place is awesome.  The drinks are ridiculously good and strong (albeit a little expensive) and the venue itself is just the most unique and cool in San Francisco.  If you've never been there you gotta go check it out.  My wife and I had our main wedding reception there and our 240 guests had only positive things to say about it.  The food was excellent, the ambiance was amazing, the band kicked a$$ (usually a cheesier band but fun none the less).  It's pretty historic to San Francisco as well as it used to be the pool for the Fairmont until they made it into the Tonga Room in the 40's.  Also the manager Ruth was awesome, very customer service oriented!  My wife and I even jumped in the pool at the end of the night (I don't think they usually allow that) and they had robes waiting for us when we got out.  Great times!
author: Prabal D.

description:
Kitch to the max, yet I wish we all got laid!! Hahaha... A gaggle of us went  on Friday after work, and I swear on my life I was there at 5:12 and all these out of towners were in line in front of me. 

WTF, I wanted to go get my tiki on w/o screaming kids, bridge and tunnel and people from Michigan there. Yes, there were screaming kids there!!! Are you kidding me?!! 

Hi parents, this is a little FYI from all of us going out to Friday Happy Hour after a long week at the office, DO NOT BRING YOUR SCREAMING BRATS TO A BAR!!! HAPPY HR IS ADULT TIME!!!

I know there is food there and this is a restaurant, but let's be honest, people are coming to stuff their face with fried food and umbrella drinks!!! 

We being good SF'ers we were doing our part to make sure that Tonga does not go Condo!!! And I will say we did have a really good time, and all left with tons of parasols in our hair. That was my goal, and goal accomplished. 

Now, beware of this. Once the tunes start on the boat at say 8ish, which was suppose to be 7, they slap a $7 entertainment fee on you and each person for the next round of drinks. We already had a fair size tab going and were not dying to see the act on the boat, hence we passed. Also note this, we wanted to split the bill 50/50 2 cards, no big. I gave them my card when I got there when we sat down so we could run a tab. Fine, no problem this is totally normal practice. 

When we ask to close, sorry the tab has already been run, and NO we can not split. I was not OK with that. If you can't split tabs, cool, then do not have your waiters tell people you can when we sit down. Irked on principal alone! Worth going once, but buyer beware.
author: Nicole F.

description:
My brother was a guest in the Fairmont hotel this weekend for his wife's 50th birthday.  He hosted the party for her in the Tonga Room, where he spent more than $4000 at this establishment.
         I had luggage with me and asked to have it checked in coat check.  They told me it would be "safer locked in the manager's office" and took my luggage.  When I went to retrieve it at the end of the night, I was informed that there had been a robbery, and my luggage as well as other people's belongings had been stolen.
        I was shocked at the attitude they took me with that night.  They said it casually, "Oh, well, sorry, but your luggage has been stolen.  Have a nice night."  They didn't offer to call anyone for me, or offer me any sympathy or advice on how to proceed.  When I burst into tears--the items in that bag were both costly and personal--they told me that the Fairmont would reimburse me for everything that was lost.
        This morning the Fairmont called me and it was a different story.  They would not be compensating me for one dime.  There would be a police investigation, and maybe the police would recover my items and if not, apparently, I was out of luck.
         I am utterly shocked that a luxury hotel such as yours would treat guests in this way, especially after the amount of money we spent in your establishment this weekend.  Nothing whatsoever was offered to me; even a free night in your hotel might have eased the pain, but your establishment offered me nothing, not even an apology.
         I spent the day trying to replace everything that was lost with money I do not have. I am outraged that the Fairmont takes no responsibility.
author: Cathy V.

description: If you are looking for an experience that's a cross between a tacky wedding reception and a luau, this place is it. There's a band that plays classic hits from a boat. There's also thunder and a (very) fake rainfall. I ordered a $12 drink of the menu that appeared to be in a coconut. I asked, "does this drink come in a coconut?" The waitress said yes. But it was a fake coconut glass. The drink wasn't bad. I went with my Swedish roommate; it's a local place at a very fancy hotel. We had no reservation so sat at the bar area, which wasn't much different from the restaurant but there was a $7 cover per person. We ate from the full menu, so this fee was a bit silly, especially when 15 minutes after being seated there were a whole bunch of seats in the main dining room that opened up. The food was mediocre Chinese; the orange chicken was similar to a dish you can get order at Best Wok in Manhasset, New York (for a totally random reference point). I wouldn't come back again, unless perhaps I took some LSD first. That would be a totally authentic San Fancisco experience.
author: Lauren H.

description:
Dear Tonga Room,

Wow. You really haven't changed a bit since I was 14.  Go figure - the "rain storms" still tickle me pink just as much as they did all those many years ago.  Thanks for all of the memories.  And the hangovers.

xoxo,
Me
author: Whitney H.

description:
I wasn't sure what to expect from the ol' Tonga Room.  My wife, Stella, really wanted to go and since we were staying at the Fairmount, I had an open invitation to drink to my heart's content, always a plus.

We had come from dinner and a walk and got into the Tonga Room about 8.  It was only moderately full and we easily found a table in the bar.  I ordered a Maker's Manhattan and Stella ordered a mai tai.  At $10 a drink, I didn't want to have to order too many drinks, but at the same time, it was a pretty good price for the not quite kitschy atmosphere and location.  

We got there just in time for the band to start their set.  The bar played their thunderstorm thing on the lagoon and the band floated out into the middle of the lagoon during the storm.  It was really kinda cool and well done which keeps the Tonga Room from crossing into kitsch.  We were lucky, the 3 piece band was really phenomenal and played songs we knew and loved.

I had one of their tropical drinks after I finished off my Manhattan.  It was pretty good but not good enough to get another.  I got another Manhattan.  We sat and enjoyed the band for quite a while.  I finally finished the Manhattan and Stella said I was going to have to finish her mai tai.  She had only drank about 3/4ths of the drink in the time it took me to drink my 3 drinks.  I finished it off, but I don't think I was better off for having done so.

In the time it took to pay the tab and make our way to the hotel room, I had lost the ability to actually shut a hotel room door.  Anyone passing by our room would have gotten quite the show if they bothered to look.  Luckily I woke up after about an hour and noticed that the door wasn't quite shut so no real damage done, I'm not that concerned about others seeing my twig and berries.

We had a great time at the Tonga Room, but be warned, the mai tais are straight rum and will make you drunk.  Maybe you'll get a story like mine or maybe you'll rob a liquor store on your way home, I think anything is possible after one of those mai tais.
author: Jeff H.

description:
The lack of vegetarian options at the happy hour cold be made up for by the drinks if the drinks arrived in a timely fashion.  They did not.

Perhaps the waitress who has been there 20 plus years should be given some respect but perhaps she could do her damn job. 20 years is too long to be waitressing especially in a dark establishment such as the Tonga Room but if you are going to do the job, do the job.  Paint on a smile and go gets the drinks.  I waited 25 minutes to get a drink and I watched the drink sit on the bar for 10 minutes.  Had there not been so many other staff in and out of the kitchen I would have gotten the drink myself.

I second the notion that the tropical rain was a downer when witnessing it in the rainiest month on record in SF.  Perhaps if theire had been live music or dancing this would have been fun. They did not and it was not. And I like Tiki's flavored atmospheres but in the future I won't be going here.
author: Sean S.

description:
11:45PM on a thursday night, we stroll in for a postprandial cocktail. The party is sizable - a dozen people. Other patrons are visible at the tables, so we ask to be seated. Instead we get the "Sorry, we're closing".

I understand that bars have times of operation. I also understand that if you're late, you're generally out of luck. But when a large party of well-dressed people in evening wear comes in AND you're a part of a hotel that stays open 24/7/365 - I think it is ridiculous to refuse them service. Especially since you're an overpriced establishment in the first place!

Won't be back.
author: Maxx L.

description: I had friends coming from out of town who were really excited to go to this place.  But what a shitty experience!  Mostly due to the horrendous service.  The drinks were quite delicious and they sure do have their schtick down to a science (yay for tiny umbrellas and tiki-guy mugs), but their prices were WAY too high and the waitress we had was absolutely wretched.  I don't think I've ever had an occasion to use the word "wretched" in my entire adult life, so you know this bitch made an impression on me!  First off, we had a party of 7 people, so she COULD have worked this tip gold-mine very well.  But no -- she took forever to come to our table, and then she took only HALF of our orders before turning around and walking off.  WTF!  She was standing nearby at the computer terminal and my husband tried to get her attention so the rest of us could place our orders, and what did she do?  She literally shushed him!!  She stuck her hand in his face and turned back around to the computer!!  Never in my life have I seen a server behave like this.  When she DID finally come back to the table, she gave us all a bunch of attitude (I asked a question about the margarita and she acted like I was a complete retard) and then took forever to bring us our drinks.  So yeah....I think I tipped her like a dollar or something.  And even that was more than she deserved.  Wish I'd thought to get her name.
author: Heather K.

description: The Tongan Room was My husband and I First Date ever! I Love it here. My fav place in San Francisco. Romantic Dinner with great music.
author: Alayna C.

description:
Fucking wonderful! Completely cheesy! Absolutely adorable! And unforgetable. Worth bringing people who have never been at least once. It's just a trip to hear the beginning of a indoor thunderstorm set off and a cover band float over a indoor pool. Yes, a pool...indoors! :)

The tiki totems are pretty sweet too! The Tonga Room is delightfull and I still think their is something wonderfull about a kitchy tiki bar at the bottom of the Fairmont Hotel which is known to be a very old and refined place. This place has a sense of humor, but it also knows how to serve up a mean Mai Tai. I definately reccomend grabbing one during happy hour. It's the only thing logical to do in order to wrap up a long week....Whew!

Some people don't like this place because it is decidely cheesey and when I say cheesy I mean....the oozing with embarassing kitch.
author: Laura G.

description:
I worked at the Fairmount as a shop girl for a few years. Tending the botique there at the Fairmount had its ups and downs. $10,000 sale days and $0 sale days dictated the mood of my life for way to long.
 Dealing with rich ass older women who have more time to waste shopping than anyone should ever have and squirling around in the front window of the botique dressing and redressing the display maniquins leaves a girl thirsty by the end of the day.

Being the avid drinker and socialite I was back then it didnt take me long to discover that a short flight of stairs down to the lower level of the fairmount housed its very own tiki bar. Complete with indoor monsoon rainshowers and tiki bar band floating in the middle of the dining area/pool.

The whole place is pirate ship themed. Complete with masts and decks, fake ship window holes and rope ladders. There is a american/hawaiian/chinese buffet tuesday-friday nights $7 all you can eat. Mind you it ends at 7 so get there early the place opens at 5pm. The happy hour drinks are $5 and were talking tropical vacation drinks. Blue Hawaiis, Mai Tais, Pina coladas, yeah the works...inclluding the big chunks of friut and paper umbrellas!

 Needless to say the bartenders like most everything else at the Fairmount are old as shit. Which means these guys know how to pour a drink, pour it fast, and laugh at you when your wasted fifteen minutes later. They once gave me an entire bag of happy paper umbrellas for a project with a smile while I was twirling around the bar in my Pina Colada induced bliss.

 Ive had dates here,anti dates, impress the date who makes you nervous dates,fun time happy friends dates, yeah you get the idea....great after work hang out and entertaining atmosphere you cant really find anywhere else these days. Cheers to the Fairmount for changing the hotel pool into a tiki bar. Who needs to swim anyway when you can drink and have indoor monsoons?

Love it.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Back when we were still in high school, and my fiancee' was still my "boyfriend," he took me here on a dinner date preceding prom night. I remembered being very impressed by the eloquent decor, exceptional service, and food. Ambiance is great, very romantic setting.

To take a walk down memory lane, I surprised him by taking him there for his birthday last month. Everything was exactly as I remembered it was. The food wasn't as good....., but the memory flashback that did it for us. Its a special place we'll always remember =).
author: Linda P.

description:
Came here last week on Sat. Great place to hangout with friends and awesome interior decor. 

However their drinks totally lack. Poor selection of Beers and their hawaiian drinks taste like shit.
author: John Z.

description:
LET'S TONGA!
Yeah!
I went to the Tonga Room with my husband on his b-day.
Very fun, cool, place to go to. Fun band playing lots of classics.
Enjoyed dancing on the dance floor!

It was very cool to sit by the banister and watch the boat full of musicians while I sipped the best Mai Tai I've ever had, and my husband drank his Pineapple Royal.

The food was good. I like the Chicken Huli Huli - the Kobe beef was not that good, a little too tough to be anything close to Kobe.

The appetizers were really good - I liked both the coconut shrimp and the Poke. 

The sticky rice was delish! (and I don't even like rice most of the time)

I've got to say, though, that the best thing was the Mai Tai - and I usually don't even like Mai Tai's!

Hat's off to this place - we had so much fun! Awesome atmosphere and very helpful staff.

FYI - Be sure to make reservations on the weekend.
author: guess w.

description: I will come back again here for dinner on my birthday. I liked the service , fast and waiter is so friendly. There's a live band, so we went dancing after dinner.  For sure , I will come back.
author: Connie D.

description: This place only gets 4stars because it's fun. There is a dance floor and a dj on a boat, very lively. The downfall, man oh man our waiter sucked. My girlfriend and I ordered  strawberry daiquiri's. She had a vrigin one I did not.  When they brought out my drink it tasted like traight up cheap liquor, so I kindly asked them to remake it. Each time it sucked more than the last. I finally gave up and just swapped with my friend. The food  was ok they had one dish that was nice it was a combo of a few appetizers. Nonetheless I was pretty annoyed with the drink matter so overall this place is great to go to 1 time, for a bucket list thing but thats it
author: Ja l.

description:
My 78 year old great aunt Sophie absolutely loved this place and said she felt like she was at some Hawaiian resort. Granted, Aunt Sophie has never actually been to Hawaii, or any other tropical island. After getting liquored up (she had one $10 mai tai), seeing a show (complete with faux rainstorm), and dancing with an elderly gentleman (he came with another woman!), Aunt Sophie proclaimed the night the most fun she had in 15 years.. and this coming from a woman who is queen of her retirement village in Boca Raton.

If you are looking for somewhere to take out a sprightly septuagenarian, I can recommend the Tonga Room. Also a good place to take out of town guests (they don't have to be elderly) or lovers of tiki bars.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Don't go here if you are expecting amazing food, trendy cocktails, and good music. The Tonga Room is the last of a dying breed and you should come here only if you appreciate a slice of old time San Francisco in a classic and classy atmosphere. 
Every time I've come here I feel transported to another era, with white-jacketed bartenders, cocktails served in actual pineapples, indoor rainstorms, and free entertainment. It would be even better if the band played standards from the 30s and 40s, rather than the bland Lionel Ritchie covers, but then again, they are a hotel band trying to please the generic masses from all over the world, so I guess they have to keep it recognizable. 
Maybe it's cheesy and a "tourist trap," but it would be sad to see the Tonga Room replaced by another generic hotel bar serving pomegranate appletinis to paper salesmen and women with outdated "Friends" haircuts.
