author: Delilah P.

description:
I went here with a party of 15 ppl . The party ate a set menu and I decided to prearrange that I would be ordering on my own off the menu. Upon entering ,  I was delighted to see how we seemingly walked into an episode of Gilligan's Island. Fully equiped with a live band, a lagoon in the middile of the restaurant  accompanied with rain every 20 minutes or so . There was a $7 entertainment fee added to each persons tab , including the gratuity.

When I sat down I explained to the waiter that I would be eating seperately from the group along with my GF and he insisted that we had to eat with the group. I then had to ask the person in charge of boooking to explain to the waiterwhat the deal was and to go speak to thte manager. The manager gave us the OK and so we ordered our food. 
I decided to order the mongolian beef and the catch of the day . When the waiter brought out the food I was dissappointed to have received food which didn't even compare to the quality of food that I cold have ordered in china town. Did I mention that the Mongolin beef plate was $30?! And I had to order rice on the side for another $8.WOW!. The fish was just OK. I however was able to look beyond the outrageous prices and the lack of quality food so that I could just enjoy myself. 

Next thing you know, the waiter comes out with a bill for $1300. They had forgotten to mention that even thought we were ordering seperately we would still be charged for eating from the set menu. We of course asked to speak to the manager , explaining to her (Ruth is her name) that that was never explained to us. She insisted that the waiter said that he explained that we would still be charged for he food that we would not be eating. NOW SERIOUSLY, who in their right mind would agree to that?!. I proceeded to explain how I ended up ordering something that was on the set menu without even knowing it and asked her to put herself in my shoes. IF I knew that they would charge us to eat the set menu, don't you think I would have just eaten that instead of making the person in charge of our party  have to pay for me, and would I so stupid to order something which we would already be receiving on the set menu . I explained to her that as a manager she should be more concerned with helping us out, rather than giving us such a hard time. When I said the waiter never told us anything about being charged ectra, she insisted he did, as if she was right there. Last time I check THE CUSTOMER IS ALWAYS RIGHT! ----End Result: She could not win against us and ended up accepting the fact that we would NOT pay extra for food we didn't even eat. She stated, JUST PAY AND LEAVE. I couldn't believe such an establishment would treat paying customers that way.So we paid our tab and proceeded to the elevator., security guard followed and kept coaxing us as if he wanted us to do something. The elevator door opens and he stand in our way, takes off his coat and pushes one of the guys in our group . Thankfully we are smarter than him and requested to speak to a manager. They called the police and we explained what happened. Ultimately ending with a hopefully fired security guard and an experience we will never forget. If anyone ever asks about the Tonga room. I have nothing but BAD things to say about this waste of money establishment. Check my other reviews. You can do MUCH MUCH BETTER! This place BLOWS!
author: Vincent R.

description:
I think people who don't like this place were never destined to like it. Their snarky, hipster attitudes won't let them. Put aside the "I'm too hip to be here" attitude, get some friends together, go and have a good time. YES it's cheesy, NO it doesn't take itself too seriously. It knows that it's cheesy and revels in it. 

Yes the drinks are sweet, just like the ones you loved when your parents let you sip their drinks on vacation. Yes, it rains. Yes, the boat leaves the dock when the band steps on board. Yes the song selection is cheesy-lounge to-the-max.. And it's great. And yes you're going to rub elbows with midwestern tourists, but you live in SF! Aren't you used to that by now?

I've lived in the city for 10 years and love this place. I've been going at least once or twice a year since I was 25. The best time to go is during Happy Hour when there's a free buffet. Sit down, take in the totally fake Polynesian atmosphere and a sweet drink or two. I don't know who got the weak drinks. I stumbled out of there the last time I visited. If you're up for it, stay for some of the performance when the band comes on.

Definitely recommended.
author: Mike W.

description:
Tonga!  Tonga! Tonga!

There are certain places you go ONLY when you have guests in from out-of-town.  Fisherman's Wharf, Chinatown, the Stinking Rose, the curvy part of Lombard and, of course, the Tonga Room.  

The Tonga.....ahhh the Tonga.  The drinks are insanely expensive, there is a ridiculously high cover charge on weekend nights to hear the house band play crappy soft-rock hits of the seventies and the servers seem to want to kill you most of the time.

So why take your guests from the Midwest there?  So why the three stars?  Well.....

The stupidly expensive drinks all come in totally festive Polynesian vessels with enough garnish to qualify it as an appetizer, the crappy cover band plays from a pontoon floating in the middle of a lagoon and the servers, although grumpy, are really efficient.  So yeah, kitsch goes a long way in my book.  I love the indoor thunder storms (an idea that was ripped off by Safeway's produce department) and the overall feeling that I'm having a drink in a giant Disney attraction.  Wheeeeee!

If you happen to get there at happy hour they have these really tasty teriyaki mini-rib things.  Oh yeah.

Tonga!
author: Mark G.

description:
Atmosphere:  Upscale Epcot Center Malaysian TIki Theme sans monorail.

Bartenders:  One speed:  Slow as hell. 

Music: Mildly entertaining.

Defining Moment:  Faux rain falls as band sings "Who'll Stop the Rain" by CCR.  

The final word:  Avoid at all costs.  I wish I could have those 2 hours of my life back, plus the $45 I spent on 2 beers and 2 glasses of Champagne.
author: Bryan S.

description:
Overpriced, overrated. As locals, we wanted to go check this place out. We had heard, like many others, this place was being possibly being closed down. After the experience, I can't say I'll ever go back.

Atmosphere: 5/5
What a beautiful place. You can feel the history and class oozing out of the walls. Rain falls, dance floor, floating stage. Very cool.

Food; 1/5
This was my biggest problem with the Tonga Room. The food is extremely over priced for what you get. The same food can be got for $5 at any asian restaurant and it probably tastes better. The Tonga Pot, $26, was nothing more than some broth, way too much bell pepper pieces, some underseasoned fish, and rubbery scallops. I, and everyone else at our table, was very unimpressed.

Wait Staff: 5/5
Extremely friendly, fast, and helpful staff.  Not only that but the treated us to 3 free deserts. Good people!

Drinks: 3/5
Again over priced and not that amazing. Go to any of the East Bay tiki bars (Forbidden Island, Conga Lounge, Kona Club) for much better drinks and a fun tiki bar atmosphere.

Entertainment: 3/5
Good generic band on Saturday night, but was a bit peeved to see on our bill we were charged $7 a piece for the band, which I wasn't told about.

Value: 2/5
Our party of 4's tab was $230 for 2 appetizers, 4 meals, and 7 drinks.
author: Vor H.

description: So, this is a longtime sf staple and we wanted to try it out for food and drinks on a birthday. After this experience, i highly recommend reservations only! The line for walk ups to just get into the bar goes through the hotel hallways and around the corner. Once you get in and get everyone situated the ambiance is fun old school tiki bar. Order your drinks in funky glasses and island tiki mugs. But that is where the goodness stops. Way overpriced drinks, and mediocre food (again, overpriced). I would say not worth the wait. It did seem like this place could get fun if you came with a mixed group and had reservations for dinner. The dance floor did get packed with island music and old school funk beats. i may try again if invited for a special event and hope to have a better experience.
author: Gerry D.

description:
minus one star for closing so early..

I love this place.. 

There is a pool in the middle of the room with a boat that holds a band & every half hour or so it rains..

how can you not love this..

its old & cheesy & tiki-tastic..


plus you get to drink a huge tropical drink out of a very long straw..
..I will be back very very soon tonga room don't you worry
author: bee h.

description: I was pretty surprised at the atmosphere of this place. My boss brought me here saying it was a big "tourist" spot, and when I entered I saw it immediately. The lighting, the decorations, the band playing on the little boat in the middle and the fake rain was pretty cool. There was a huge dance floor so it made me wonder what kind of dancing goes on during the week. It's too bad I went on a Wednesday and there wasn't dancing, but the band that played was kind of cool and played some cover tunes. It's a huge location that can easily fit a group of friends.
author: Jacob H.

description: This place is magical with enchanting decor out of The Tiki Room and an actual rainstorm every half hour.  Unfortunately, the entrees are way overpriced and mediocre. Your best bet is to come for the happy hour buffet which is $6 with a fancy Polynesian drink (another $6). The food isn't amazing (dim sum, spare ribs. fruit), but the fun decor goes a long way. It's definitely something everyone should experience once.
author: Kathleen M.

description: 3 stars only because of the great tacky ambience. 2 stars for food, is average at best. Curry was salty and chicken satay was bland. Drinks are mostly sugary fruit juice. Servers were attentive and courteous. BUT...where else can you see a live band float onto a pool and play? Where else can you have a tropical rainstorm indoors? The line out the door says it all. Its just something ya gotta see before you die. Order light and you won't be unhappy with the experience.
author: Anthony C.

description:
This place is so over hyped.  You can find a place that makes better Mai Tai's (and other drinks) in Chinatown for half the price.  

Since this place was feature on The Layover with Anthony Bourdain, there is going to be a ridiculous line to get in and there is no place to wait and have a drink it does not have a bar.  Also, after happy hour, there is a cover charge to go along with their over priced drinks.

At the end of the day, waiting for an hour in line just to get a $20 drink to see "rain" fall inside isn't worth it.
author: Matthew D.

description:
Tonga Room wears multiple hats for me. I had a total 5 star experience here at a company holiday party about 5 years back or so. It was the perfect place for a group or 60+ loud, fun loving, holiday work friends partying. The service was good, the food was very fun, great drinks, live music the band on the water although super cheesy was great! I was looking forward to coming back with friends after my first experience and avidly recommended them to others. 

My second visit was for happy birthday/happy hour drinks for a group of 10 of us. It was so-so. The service was lacking, but there were 10 of us so I can see how it'd be semi chaotic since it wasn't an 'organized' event. But, I was expecting more, like, shouldn't they be used to big groups? And is 10 really that big? Any how, we still had a few drinks, laughs and a good time despite waiting a lot longer between drinks and orders than we would have liked, but that was probably better for us in the long run, just bad for them.  

My third visit was my idea. Living around the corner from the Fairmont now, I had some girlfriends visiting from out of town and thought the Tonga room would hit the spot. We went for a few appetizers and their tropical drinks before a night out on the town. The service was AWFUL. The waiter was rude, rushed us from the time we sat down. Was annoyed if we'd ask questions or try to converse with him. Ewww, we got bitchy back after a few drinks and he then quit serving us and just brought our check. They didn't have music that night (or maybe we just missed it?). My friends left angry and I left embarrassed that I'd suggested an overpriced tacky tourist trap that from the evening proved to have no perks to it that I'd seen before. Overall I am over the Tonga Room. I have no plans to go back out of my own freewill. If it's an organized  party, then perhaps I will go as their planning for events is much better than their rude regular waiter service. But considering the 2 places I work now, I am the one that does the event management for all parties and organized celebrations I doubt I'll be back.
author: Audrey V.

description:
Came here on a whim - definitly not your everyday spot but we had a blast. I think if you're in the mood for something sill you should come here. I felt like I was on vacation in a Waikik at a cheesey touristy spot but with the right group of people you can have a lot of fun. 

I love that every once in a while you hear thunder and it starts raining in the middle "river" area (sort of like when you're in Safeway and it's time to wash the produce!). The sound of the rain is so relaxing. Order the totally cheesey drinks and you have it do it in the scorpion bowl things. After polishing off a lava bowl and scorpion bowl we order bud lights in the bowl!! Everything is more fun when you get to drink out of a really long straw out of a communal bowl! 

One thing I could live withought would be the cover charge - I mean the band is funny but I don't think it's worth paying for. Be prepared to witness some bad dancing a la cruise ship style, but go with a silly attitude and you'll have a fun night!
author: Lindsay A.

description:
NOt that the place is bad...but I was really hoping the tonga room would be serving polynesian type food and not some crappy, i could get anywhere else for cheaper "american-chinese" dish.

but i did enjoy touring the hotel itself and taking a look at all the history.

omg..and the bathrooms here are gorgeous....

anyways, there was a photographer there who made our night .... he took posed pictures of me and my gang, framed em and then took individual shots of us and had them made into matchcovers...so of course i bought a bunch of em...

it gets a 2 because i would never go there again, but im glad i did it once.
author: Malalini S.

description:
I'd realistically give this place 4.5 stars. But anyway, this place is fabulous! I came here for my cousin's birthday dinner and I'm glad that it was held here. 

You come here for the experience, maybe not so much the cuisine. (The food was pretty good though, especially the pineapple upside down cake & sorbet!) The room is like an old pool room converted to an attempt at tropical paradise with huts, tiki decor, and leis. 

We had a pretty large sized group and the staff did a very, very good job ensuring great service. The dancing was what did it for me! They played oldies! I couldn't stop dancing. Well until my feet hurt. 

I recommend going if you're into the dinner and dancing scene. Great for a date night!
author: Liane T.

description: Amazing ambiance - rain and thunder, live bad, nice music, dance floor, and great cocktails. The food at dinner was fine, but not exceptional, and a bit pricey.
author: Antonia T.

description: Fair warning: The Tonga volcano bowls pack quite the punch. I saw stars the whole evening, and that was even before the clouds broke!  What a dazzling dapper time.
author: Mal S.

description:
I had to go here because I once read a recommendation for it by Ben Gibbard. 

Me likey. But me also hatey, for a couple reasons I shall outline.  me likey because I agree with everyone and say it is real cheeky tiki, and you have totally scored if you are there for happy hour, when the drinks are half price.
 
But if you are there for happy hour, BE WARNED: your entire party has to be there to be seated (yes you have to be seated for happy hour). That doesn't sound so hard to do, but when you're a skip-through-the-city-drinkin-by-the-seat-of-your-pants kinda gal, it raises problems. Of course I was the Johnny Come Lately, and my other 4 friends who had patiently waited for me shot me vague death rays when I finally got there. And you have to pay for the entertainment! 5 bucks a person, to watch the cover band on the pool. Me hatey!
author: Shannon V.

description:
Don't even get me started on how much I love this place.

Cheesy cover tunes from a live band on a BOAT.  A RAINSTORM indoors! Fried appetizers. Lush, tropical decor. Huge, strong scorpion bowls that helped to drown my sorrows of turning 33 in October 2005. Best birthday bar ever! 

I seriously almost slugged our friend's girlfriend on my birthday at the Tonga Room. She was dissing the place left and right and making fun of the band. Don't mess with The Tonga, you'll have to answer to me! 

If you take yourself too seriously, you won't like it here. You've got to accept it (and love it) for what it is......the most awesome thing ever atop Snob Hill.
author: Abby W.

description:
Where else would you see Willie Brown shakin' his ass with some blonde big breasted MILF?  

This place makes me want to take my top off, grow my hair down to my waist and walk around in a hula skirt.
author: Daniela L.

description:
This review applies to "happy hour" only.

I'm not quite sure what people are expecting from the Tonga Room.  Each time I've gone, I've had a good time.  Sure, the food isn't the greatest, but it is edible and for $9.50 plus one drink, it's reasonably priced for San Francisco - especially when you consider the location and "ambiance," which is worth the price of admission itself.

Having traveled extensively in the Pacific, I've only found one place in all my travels that looked anything like this and that was in Pago Pago - and even they told me their decor was inspired by the Tonga Room in San Francisco.

Drinks were good, though everyone did mention that the Mai Tais packed a bit of a wallop.

We went on a Thursday with a group that eventually grew to 12 and found the service to be extremely friendly and accommodating.

This isn't the place you go for serious cuisine, but for drinks and pupus with a group of people, it's a surefire good time
author: Scott M.

description:
I am REALLY not surprised that this placed opened in '45. That's awesome.

Tonga Room its place to visit. It's silly & kitschy where the drinks are pretty damn strong and the atmosphere is playful. Everything was a little overpriced, but it was a relaxing lounge and everyone sitting around us would start conversations with the people near them. I am sold.
author: Rachel S.

description:
This place made an already depressing foggy Saturday in SF even more depressing.  I was looking forward to cutesy kitsch tiki but this place was so not what I was expecting.  

First of all, you're surrounded by a bunch of out-of-towners who think they're out on a fancy night on the town.  I haven't seen so much cheap rhinestone accessories since my eighth grade graduation dance.  I knew I had to leave when I spotted what I thought was a prostitute soliciting an older gentleman by grinding up against him on the dance floor during the band's heartfelt rendition of "She works hard for her money" -- only to learn it was a daughter and either her dad or uncle.  I had to call it a night after seeing that.
author: Helen C.

description:
super cool environment to pontificate on the state of the world as well as see a groovy rainstorm.!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  "Blue Hawaiian"................
anyway...................in the fairmont , and beyond cool. Very much encouraged.
author: Jerry M.

description:
Tonga Tonga Bo-Tonga Banana Nana Bo-Tonga

A great place to take friends visiting town, or for a funny kind of "get out of town" dinner party. It can also be a good date place if you want to make sure you do not run into certain people :-) 

The food is decent but not something that stands out for the foodies however after a few cocktails it can taste as good as the next  entertainment type restaurant. Speaking of entertainment, the band is cheesy however fun and after a few of their special fruity drinks you will be on the dance floor with the cougers or if your a women you will be dancing with the guys in their suits.

have fun!
author: Bobby B.

description:
Shhh. . .listen. Do you hear it? The winds are beginning to pick up. The sky hastily clouds over into thick, electric darkness.  The swaying trees start to frantically shake their limbs. And there it is! A cacophony of thunder and pounding rain! A spectacle of lightning! A menagerie of wild animals shrieking at the stormy skies!

Now that I have your attention, let's talk Tonga Room, one of my favorite places to take out of town guests or to visit during happy hour with friends. Located in the basement of Nob Hill's Fairmont Hotel, the Tonga Room is the tiki bar of all tiki bars. Upon entering, the sheer size of the place takes precedent over the interior's details, but once seated it all comes together. Palm trees litter the space and the countless tables and chairs appear straight out of the verandah of a 1970s tropical getaway. A "porch" exists to the right, raised up by a few steps and covered with a thatched roof. Lanterns are strewn about and--get this--a swimming pool, presumably worked to represent the ocean, sits smack dab in the middle of this cavernous room! Unreal! Totally glorious!

Happy hour offers a buffet that my carnivorous friends rarely decline, and I hear that the pork buns are actually rather tasty. Menus of tropical drinks sit atop every table and one can choose from a simple strawberry margarita to a giant bowl of alcohol to be shared between two. 

The drinks are inconsistent in terms of strength and sometimes the fruit tastes, um, a bit overripe, but this review still lavishes the T.R. with 5 stars. Why, you ask? Because the simulated rain storm that occurs every 30 minutes basically reconfirms all the reasons why I love my life so much. And I'm sure it'll do the same for you.
author: Chloe S.

description:
Tonga room is 4 stars in ambiance.  This is old school kitschy Tiki Bar style.  The food is mediocre especially for the price.  The drinks are pretty nasty, sweetened with fake stuff.  Better off with a beer.  The service is strange, not too friendly and a bit of a 'we might rip them off' vibe and trust me, my husband and I do not give that feeling off and never receive it.  After awhile the wait staff warmed up to us.

My feeling with the Tonga Room is that they know it is closing so no need to keep the customers coming.  Too bad with proper management, better food and drinks it could be a money maker, it is not just locals that like kitsch, many tourists love it too as they don't have it, it is a part of Americana.

If you want a great tiki bar experience you have to check out Foridden Island.  If you want good old fashioned (not modern) Tike-bar style food, Trader Vics in Emeryville.  If you want to say goodbye to a has been - Tonga Room!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
The atmosphere here was awesome! I love the way they did the decor. It looks like you're really dining in a tropical hut.

The food was ok, nothing special. I'm not sure I would go again, but I think it's definitely worth it to go there once, just to see what it looks like inside.

I think this place is even more fun if you go with a group of 5 or 6 people.
author: Rena K.

description:
I just turned 25! And I spent my birthday here. Well actually my friend surprised me by bringing me here. So this review is tainted by some rose-colored birthday glasses.

So I think the key to this place is the element of surprise. 
I was having a birthday dinner with my good friend and everything was wonderful. Then she suggested we go to a hotel that has a boat inside it with fake rain and thunderstorms. Whhhaaat?
I didn't know if I was dress ok and she said I looked fine - Fiiiinnnneee - but not dressy....so we proceed to Nob Hill.

I am giving it a five star rating because it was Disneyland in SF. The whole place threw me aback and I had a lot of fun ordering their tropical drinks that are pretty colors. Some of them were pretty strong.

We sat at the bar to avoid the entertainment fee and to get a better view of the entertainment - kind of ironic. My friend bought me a desert and they place a candle in it. 

The dance floor was as friendly as a Bar Mitvah's or Wedding - but there were a few really good dancing couples who waltzed and cha-cha 'd. And the cutest kids ever dancing with one another.

I liked the history of the place - Oh and the guy with the pony tail who sang - gave me a special Birthday hello! 

I am stoked. 

Not sure when I would go back. Probably to surprise someone in a very silly way. Its a relaxing atmosphere and the bartenders were nice.
author: Sari G.

description:
While staying at the Fairmont in the summer of 2007, I could not resist coming to the Tonga Room.  How convient for me to have a tiki bar in the hotel!

Well, the place is very neat, sort of like being in Disneyland.  The Mai Tai, well, not the best I had in San Francisco, Trader Vic's much better, but still good.  A little tart!

They have this neat buffett for like $8, it was nothing more than a bunch of snacks but they did have this guy that will make a vegetarian mongolian.  

On certain nights, they have a live band.  I thought they were awful, but who cares, I was there for the drinks.  The place can get quite crowded.
author: John O.

description:
My old moms used to live in San Francisco back in the 50s and when she heard I was staying at the Fairmont, she said, "Oh that was the place that had a bar with an orchestra playing on a raft while it rained on them, indoors!" 

I said, "I doubt that's open anymore, Ma."

SURPRISE.  It apparently was closed for a while but now it's re-opened, albeit with a lounge band playing Elton John and Lionel Ritchie tunes on the raft, instead of an orchestra.  So of course I had to check it out and report back to Mom.   

I moseyed down there about 8:30 pm on a Friday and apparently I hit it just the right moment as there was no line and although there was only one of me, I got seated for dinner at a table for four although I said, "I'm by myself, I'll gladly sit at the bar." (Huge table just for me? WTF? but whatever.)  By the time I left about an hour and  a half later there was a big ol' waiting line.   Plus, I no sooner got sitting down than they let loose with the fake rain-and-thunderstorm, which was pretty impressive.

Yes, this place is kitschy as all get-out, but somehow it's also way classier than similar theme joints in Las Vegas, Disney World, and malls here and there across America.  Part of it's the History Factor - the Tonga Room did it first.  Part of it's the attention to detail - the tropical drinks all have their own "theme" tiki glasses to match the drink.  For instance, the "Pipeline" cocktail has a surfer on the glass.  The servers all look like island folk.  And so on. 

The dance floor is done up to look like the deck of a ship and it was worth going just to see the different types of dancers.  Everything from Dads dancing with their preschool kids, to the older couple who clearly has had a ton of dance lessons proceeding very unsmilingly through some type of 70s disco dance to a Bee Gees tune. 

My drink was very sweet and good, and my prawns and hush puppies were huge, to match the huge price.  Yeah, it's expensive, but this is Nob Hill in San Francisco.  Deal.  Plus the fact that it costs a bit (and is located in the relatively pricey Fairmont) keeps out a lot of the more annoying tourist element, who probably troop on down the hill for a cheaper evening in Chinatown or on the Wharf.

You also don't need to dress up to go here. They recommend business casual, but I saw people at the bar looking like beach bums in faded old jeans and t-shirts, which did fit in with the decor. If you look too grungy you might get a fisheye from the frosty maitre d and doorman when you enter.   There is a discount on certain nights for hotel guests as well.

All in all I'd recommend it in all its slightly tacky glory.  The only reason I didn't give five stars is that the doorpeople were slightly intimidating and that I didn't get a free lei after I ate.  Sob sob.  I'll have to go back sometime and demand one...I WANT MY LEI!
author: M. M.

description:
I have to give it 5 stars for the Asian band that played the Bee Gee's hits floating in the middle of a fake lagoon.! Too flipping funny! 

My dearest 2 gal pals for over 30 years and I spent the weekend in SF at the Mark Hopkins doing SF. They are from podunk  Roseville and Colfax, so this was quite an adventure!

The food was not half bad, but the fun part was watching the people on the dance floor and listening to the"band". How surreal for an Asian guy to be singing a Tom Jones song. Is this a Fellini movie I stepped into?

Oh yeah, and I got a really HOT look from this 90 year old! 
Must have been my black patent leather 5 inch platforms..:S
author: Christine E.

description:
It's got the kitsch, yes, but not the goods to back up the fun.

I went there recently for the first time in ages (and only the second time in my life...and I'm a local), and, even if it wasn't closing I wuold never go there again. They were rude from the moment we walked in. 

The lounge was crowded for happy hour, so you think they would have been in a good mood. Not so much. Our group was large, so a few of us were standing, and as there was no waitress to be seen, we headed up to the bar. We were yelled at by the bartender that he would not serve us, only through the waitress.

Ok...10 minutes and lots of shoving around later, we were told to sit in a particular area. Not a prob...then we were told they couldn't seat us there. Still, no drink. Finally, after about 20 minutes, we went back to the bar, where again we were yelled at...this time we stood firm and got our damn drinks.

Later, one of my colleagues tried to pay for her own drink. The waiter told her it would sure be a lot of work for him to take her drink out of the table tab. He COULD do it, but it's a lot of work, so he wouldn't. This is what he said to us....thus turning off someone who had just been saying it would be cool to bring her kids there.

The charm of this place was completely lost on me. I get that everyone has bad days, but for the whole staff to be so foul to us (and, we were very nice at first, until we were shown that attitude) was just unacceptable.
author: Annie F.

description:
The Tonga Room is one of the best places I've ever been.

It rains inside.

They have a cover band on a floating barge in a fake ocean.

The food is mediocre, but the drinks are great.  

I wish I were there now.  NOW!
author: Sarah T.

description:
The Tonga Room is a classic San Francisco night spot. Located in one of the City's most elegant and landmark hotel's, the longstanding Tonga Room is a pleasant spot for after work or a night out on the town. 

For the younger crowds that like a more contemporary atmosphere the Tonga Room might not be the place. Yet if you like a relaxing and reasonably priced happy hour spot, the Tonga Room is worth the visit.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
The Tonga Room has been recently renovated, though you might not realize it as it pretty much looks the same!  But, why would you want the kitsch factor to change?  The thunder/rainstorms are the best, with a close second being the HI-larious little cover band that plays on the 'boat'; I swear they were playing one song all night (Sailing... by C Cross, not N Sync), but it worked. And they really seem to dig performing out their on their boat.

The food was good.  Solidly good, but not over the top outstanding.  Really high quality chinese style high end menu.  Good service.  Go for the tropical drinks. They really don't know how to make a good dirty martini, but that is not what they are known for, so go tropical!

They do have a great happy hour with good grazings!
author: Danielle R.

description:
The Tonga Room really *should* close--great kitschy interior, but stupid high prices, adversarial staff, and unpredictable crowds just don't make a good mix.

They attract tourists, which is what kills them.  Middle-aged folks in college sweatshirts and flip-flops are a major turn off.  And if I have to drink with tourists, I expect some discount, but no the beers (at happy hour) are $6.  In the bottle.  I have no idea what their regular prices are, but does it matter?

And the rules of the joint are built around the assumption that the customers are thieving assholes.  I'm sure most of us are, but that's because the drinks are expensive as hell and the crowd sucks and when you know you're never coming back, duh, you want to steal glassware.  Seriously, tho, a bar with a buffet should just make it free--otherwise your wait staff has to constantly police whether or not anyone is sneaking an egg roll off their friend's plate, and it makes the place feel like a fucking Sizzler.

The place is living on its laurels, and getting anorexic on that diet.  I wish I'd known it when it was worth visiting, but it sure as hell isn't now.

Everyone who gets on Yelp and bemoans its loss, I dare you to go there tonight and have a good time.  I double-dog dare you.
author: Martin W.

description:
What a find.

I was on a full day adventure with a few buddies when we stumbled into the Tonga room. I honestly thougth they were shining us on because we were not dressed for this place. Flip flops, shorts, baseball hats. Not what the suited hotel guests expected to walk through the door. When security came over to check us out and said "take the elevator down, then go to the back of the basement, " I was sure we were getting the boot.
Big surprise when I saw the tikis welcoming me to my new home in SF.

Since that fateful day, I've been back with my wife, her family, sent my friends, talked about it with long time locals, found history on the place........

You get the idea.

If you like tiki, this place is a must stop.

$7 all you can eat pupus, and band on a floating stage/boat in the old swimming pool in the evenings, and the occasional tropical storm.

The drinks are pricey, but good at happy hour, but you have to get the senior bartender to make your mai tai from scratch.
author: Eddie W.

description: The Tonga Room is a good place to go for the history and the ambiance either once or once in a while.  It is a neat place to hang out, with the vintage charm, floating band and fake rain.  The food is mediocre and not equal to the price.
author: Jessica G.

description:
I had reservation at 7pm on a Sunday, finding street parking was unsuccessful , parked in a garage at 750 bush street 2 blocks away( $6/30 min). Arrived at tonga room at 6.30, nobody was at the reservation counter, the line for walk-in were moving faster, so after waiting for 10 mins for someone to show up, we just went to the walk-in line.

SERVICE WAS HORRIBLE. After the initial order, we wanted to order some more stuff, our server was nowhere to be seen, we asked 2 other servers, the standard reply was "Let me get some server for you", but even after waiting 20 mins still nobody to take our order. After reminding one of the other servers our server finally showed up.

Cocktails: we ordered pina colada and 2 other drinks, drinks were good. 
Food : , we ordered shrimp rolls, tonga platter and singapore noodles. All the fried stuff was too oily, and when I say too oily I mean dripping oil. And the singapore noodles were not good. The final bill for above stuff was $110.  Thats $55 per person, thats too much for the bad food we were served.

Anthony Bourdain made it look like a very good place but in reality it is not worth your time and money. Most likely you will come out of Tonga room feeling that  your neighborhood restaurant is better than tonga room.
author: Animesh D.

description:
Occasion:  

What an exciting and unique dining experience!  Sweetie and I had dinner at the Tonga Room last Saturday as part of our San Francisco getaway experience.  We stayed at the Fairmont Hotel on a bed and breakfast package.  

Ambiance:  

I was not expecting to find a fun, festive party atmosphere at the Tonga Room.  We were both welcomed with "lei's" as soon as we entered the restaurant.  The place was dark, loud and full of laughter.  We were surprised to hear "thunder" then see the "rain" in the middle of the pool where the hut that also served as the stage was located.  

Social Scene:

It was fun to see multigenerational families celebrate together with fun drinks.  There were people who celebrated their birthdays that night, got engaged, etc. The dance floor was packed at 8PM. 

Salud!:   For me, Tonga Room was all about the drinks and the party atmosphere. The drinks were yummy.  Warning:  Order the Lava Ball Drink if you have the tolerance of an elephant.  If you are planning a long, intimate night, SKIP IT!!!! It was 151 proof! 

Taste:  Don't go there for the food. They were overpriced, common-placed Asian/Chinese food although our mongolian beef was very, very tender. It was ALMOST worth the $23.00 price.  The rest were so-so.  

Tab:  Our tab came up to $170.00 with tip  (one appetizer, 2 dishes, 2 rice, 2 drinks and 1 lava ball drink which 2 people has to share.   We were charged $7.00 a piece for music charge which was worth it.) 


Highly Recommended:


The good thing about dining/drinking at the Tonga Room and staying at the Fairmont was you can drink all you want.  After all the Lava drink, thank God we had a room upstairs because I yakked everything out after dancing.  I guess, heat, alcohol and dancing do not really mix especially if you are a lightweight. Sweetie got his groove on, though.  The dancer in him woke up.   Despite everything, we will definitely go back to eat, drink and dance at the Tonga Room. I will definitely avoid that Lava drink!!!!!
author: Leah E.

description:
The night before our wedding I brought the entire wedding party and all the out of town guests to the Tonga Room and they loved it.
Sure, its a little cheesy with the Tiki stuff, but that's the fun of it.
Big syrupy fruit juice drinks with variations of rum or vodka in funky glasses.
You'll get a headache from the combo of sugar rush, brain freeze and alcohol, but it's worth it.
author: Kev M.

description:
Wait--this is what all the fuss was about? This is the place I've longed for over the past...however many years it's been since that article came out in the Chronicle about how it was going to close, and Herb Caen (or someone) was spinning in his grave, or at least tilting a little, except the article and/or the rumor was really/probably just a ploy to get people out to the place, to reignite interest...this place? This I guess San Franciscan institution from a time when the city was not yet gay and still had a middle class--not that, btw, I'm coming even close to alleging that the inverse of the former is causative of the inverse of the latter--but this place? This purportedly magnificent (to the extent kitsch can be magnificent...which I guess, if pressed, I would have to admit that it can be)--but this place, this is the place I've tried to go to or at least *thought* about trying to go to for years? 

Meh. 

Beginning with the confoundingly long line in which we had to wait--despite a) our having reservations, b) there being literally dozens of chairs and handfuls of tables open--and continuing on through the--WHAT??!? [inaudible, inaudible] WHAT???!!?? [inaudible] I said, the [inaudible]--just abusively loud music, it was just an unpleasant postprandial cocktail all around. Sure, if you don't like loud music stay away--I get it--but, I mean, the whole point of tropical vacations and islands is to, ah, relax, no? To close your eyes and be lulled, to listen to the rain hit the water, to let your hand dandle over the edge of your chair.... Instead, I had to shout over a rendition of I Heard It Through the Grapevine that could be heard from across a vineyard. Yes I'm pleased with myself for that little turn of phrase, but still I wish I didn't have to make it.
author: T U.

description:
The very fact that this place exists is evidence of some kind of divine intervention.

Those were some damn good Pina Coladas. I felt like I was on a Pirate Ship, sailing the seven seas. Next time, if drunk enough, I will jump onto the Band's Raft and be a stow-away.
author: Elissa D.

description:
Sometimes I can't handle too much cheese in one sitting.  This place under any normal circumstances would probably be slipping right into that category.  It's depressing and also wildly obnoxious.  They would probably receive 2 stars from me had I just walked in alone.

I decided to give them 3 because I went here with a really good group of people.  If you go with a fun group who acknowledge the cheese factor and love it.  Maybe even flourish in it?  You'll have a good time trust me.  I did thanks to them.  Lots of gray haired tourists and snobby staff to watch out for, so beware!

We ordered a fatty/expensive ($25) tasty tropical drink we shared with straws while watching the little boat float out with a singer and her keyboard/band member entertain us.  

And boy did they ever.
author: Mary R.

description:
The Tonga Room sucks. I went here for drinks after work for Happy Hour with coworkers and that is the only reason I had fun. The food was ok. They called it an  "extensive buffet". There was only like 4 things to choose from. They have raised the price on their tiny buffet. Wen we went last year, it was only like $7

I do like the thunder and rain storm in there. 

The drinks are expensive and watered down. And this is coming from someone who doesn't drink that often.  

They have a parking garage under the Fairmont Hotel. I believe it's valet parking. They charge $4 for every 20 minutes. That is expensive! $20 and hour?!?!? After paying, the guy hands us our keys and points in the direction where our car was parked. That really helped....NOT!!! He so was not getting a tip. 

NEVER will I go to the Tonga Room nor will I suggest it to anyone. I really don't see what the appeal of this place is. Other than a tourist trap.

Got this off the website:

Tonga's Award Winning Happy Hour
Monday to Friday:              5:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m.

The Happy Hour includes an extensive buffet of Pacific Rim delicacies with items such as mini spring rolls with plum sauce, chicken wontons with chili sauce, vegetable chow mein, Kalua pork and cabbage, assorted cheese and crackers, sliced melons and tree ripened fruit, pineapple bowl and honey coconut dipping sauce, Szechwan guacamole dip with prawn crackers. The all-you-can-eat buffet is a 'steal' at only $9.50 per person with a one drink minimum. To complement this feast fit for kings and queens, the tropical restaurant and bar serves tantalizing cocktails at Happy Hour prices.

You owe yourself a scorpion bowl after walking up the hills to this place.

Yes it is going to have tourists as it is in a hotel (duh) and the hotel is by other hotels (duuuuh) so get over yourself and be glad that you live somewhere that tourists like to frequent. 

I really had a fabulous time splitting a few drinks with friends that are on their way out of town. The service was quick and professional and the drinks were mighty strong. I also really liked the rainstorm but to be fair I also get excited when the thunder noise goes off at Safeway before it "rains" on the produce.

Oh, and to the douche bags that cannot be trusted with matches...thanks a lot for ruining the flaming drinks. Yes, they used to have it until your dumbasses tried to burn down the bar. PBBBT on you.

It is what it is, don't come here with expectations through the roof or wanting to see a San Francisco original. I will look forward to another occasion to come back and in the meantime will drink as many beverages as I can from my newly acquired 3 foot straw.
author: Allegra F.

description:
Not many places in SF quite like Tonga Room. My new hubby & I were lucky enough to have our wedding reception at the Tonga Room and closed out the entire room. All of our guests said the service, the food, and the music was exceptionally fantastic! **disclaimer--our menu was a specially prepared menu from catering dept** 
anyways, we had the pleasure of meeting Fairmont's executive chef & the room managers..they're all wonderful people, very friendly and great customer service. and the band...thank you CJ & the island groove band for having us dancing & groovin' all nite long...we did a CONGA line!! or should i say 'TONGA' line..heh. and all our guests got 'lei'd'!!!

The service was top notch, servers were on top of everything..a table or two didnt have bread baskets but the servers brought it out ASAP. drinks were yummy & it was all in all a great time!

for those complaining about prices..this is the fairmont hotel after all..not some motel. come for drinks & the atmosphere. or host a party here...

i love the tonga room and everyone there!! see you soon...
author: Yolanda L.

description:
My first time here was back in 1966 for my 21st birthday, as a treat from my coworkers. I loved it, but never returned because I moved out of state shortly thereafter. 
Last week I was back in San Francisco after a long absence and returned to the Tonga Room with my daughter and son-in-law. 
We so enjoyed the atmosphere, the scorpion drinks with the two foot straws, the lightning, thunder, rain, and the band floating on a raft in the middle of a pool! Just as I had remembered! 
Our tall blond waiter was attentive, without being over so, and had a good sense of humor.
I may never get to the Tonga Room again, but I have now passed on the experience to others, who in turn, have created their own Tonga Room memories.
author: Bev M.

description:
If you're into over the top gimmicks, this place is for you. The Tonga room is a tiki bar complete with straw umbrellas, rain storms, and a live band playing in a lagoon. Drinks are served in tiki mugs, porcelain coconuts, and hollowed out pineapples and cost about $9-$10 for most with two person scorpion bowls at $18. 

Great fun if you like a good gimmick.
author: Andrew B.

description:
This is a souped up Rainforest Cafe.  I will admit that I had an amazing time!  I took away 1 star for being incredibly expensive for no good reason.  It was like being at Disney World and having to buy food and you have no choice but to buy a 20 dollar hamburger.  We had purchased the homerun which lowered the cost but the bill was still very high.  The drinks are super overpriced but very strong, and in a fun tropical fashion.   The bowl we had came with fruits and two super long straws.  I did feel like I was on vacation though, somewhere tropical and cheesy!  They had a live band floating in the pool and a dance area that everyone seemed to love (including me).  Minus one star for charging $7 per person for an "entertainment fee".  Those things should be included, it felt like I was on an airplane and they were charging me for EVERYTHING!  Lots of big groups, pretty packed for Saturday - definitely need a reservation.  I couldn't get over how expensive it was for what seemed like chinese take out.  The banana mousse dessert was pretty tasty, very different.  

I'd come back if someone else was paying because it really is a fun place!  Kinda like a novelty place, once in awhile or for special occasions.  Aloha!
author: Tiffany L.

description: Family came to visit and we wanted them to enjoy the ambience.  We ordered a Lava bowl.  None of us could taste any rum.  Waitress said "Maybe you're heavy drinkers." Asked for a refund & left.  We will NEVER go back.
author: Kathi S.

description: Fun atmosphere(a little on the touristy side though..), great decorations. Service is a little slow, but that's understandable as there is a lot of people and a big line waiting out the door. The food was decent. It could have passed for four stars if it wasn't for their house band... TERRIBLE!!!!! It was like a bad wedding band.. Or a batmitzvah band... Whatever it was, it was bad. Clearly someone in the band must be related to the manager in some way. We were debating staying longer for drinks at the bar but couldn't take the music anymore so we left shortly after our meal.
author: Maddy S.

description:
I was kinda disappointed by this place. OK, I may be embittered by the fact that I had just missed happy hour. But when it comes down to it, the mai tai is too syrupy and the service is spotty and the bartenders are pretty brusque.

I know it's supposed to be a classic but I can find better tiki drinks elsewhere. Here, everything is overpriced anyway. 

If you're looking for a killer cocktail, just walk on down to Cantina for a tasty five-spice margarita.
author: Caroline P.

description:
I haven't been to the Tonga in years. It's one of those places that I rarely go but I'm glad to know it's still there. I'm a native and accordingly I was brought here a few times when I was really young. I went again for someones Bar Mitzvah party, and several other times once I turned 21. 

Now by all means don't eat here. It's expensive and the food and service are rubbish. I like Chinese food a lot. But this isn't even Cantonese which is the blandest Chinese cooking there is. This is what Americans imagined Chinese food was back in the atomic age when swanky tiki bars and Hawaiian music on your Hi-Fi were all the rage. It's like going to a restaurant in Disneyland only you're not surrounded by the nightmare that is Los Angeles. 

I say bring a date that has a good sense of humor, order some crap Polynesian cocktails with way to much cheap rum and juice in them, and give her a snog when the indoor tropical storm gets switched 
on.
author: lazslo t.

description:
This place just plain sucks.    I went with a group 20 people for a bday dinner and they tacked on an additional $140 cover charge to our bill.

Who does that?

Secondly the food was really bad.  I mean not just untasty and bland, but really bad.   FIRE THE CHEF, I am serious.  Get rid of the chef and hire a new restaurant manager ASAP.

I had the beef dish for $30.  You'd figure, if you are going to shell out $30 for a meal, it should be decent quality meat, cooked, and at least luke warm.

The atmosphere is really cool, but it's just ruined by the service and the food.  Why spend 1M on redesigninga restaurant  if you are going to screw people out of their money?  Cause then people like me will spread the word and let people know that this place really sucks.

Bottom line, if you want to pay too much $$$ for really crappy food, get bad service, and drink watered down koolaid/ rum drinks  then you should eat here.

If you want similar tropical dinner experience, pay the same amount of money, but eat better qualiity food and have a really good time, then go to Le Colonial or Anamandara.
author: greg d.

description:
NEVER EVER COME TO TONGA !!! 
I went to this place for the happy hour buffet "all you can eat". The waitress (I forgot her name, she is Chinese, very short hair, slim) was so rude. First of all when we sat, the waitress asked for our credit card (she think we might run away without paying the food). After served the drink, she never came back to our table. Lots of dirty plates was not picked up. When my daughter started singing, she came to our table just to tell us to control our daughter (for the God sake, she is only 1 year old). I asked her if anyone complaint about it? She said "not yet"...and even the guests next to our table was smile to my daughter. So the waitress was so overreact or she might have personal problem with the baby? I do not know and I do not care?  Maybe Tonga should put the sign "Baby is not welcome"...

We left right away even we had not finish our food yet. And we will never back to this place again. I would never recommend this place to my friends. We went to so many restaurant, this the WORST EVER ...  

Since I have to choose the star, I put 1 star, but ..this place does not deserve star at all......
author: chris j.

description: I cant believe this place got bad reviews!! this place is awsome.. I love this place. It is pricey..
author: MiLLie M.

description: Swankier than most places I'd visit but it does get an extra star for it's Tiki Room/Vegas vibe.  I felt a little under dressed coming to some beautiful hotel to go to its restaurant/bar (by the way, if you go to the elevator and hit T, you'll get there).  We had mai-tai's in an appropriate coconut cup with an umbrella and pineapple.  It's pricey from what I remember.  A friend bought the drinks so I can't be certain.  The top of this place is stellar.  Beautiful view of the city...we snuck some red wine and finger foods that were left over from some event there.  Rather expensive...but definitely a cool place for the cheese factor.  The smoking patio/top of the hotel makes this place worth going back more than anything else.
author: Amy J.

description:
It's hard not to get excited about this place.  "Tonga!" I shouted.  "Tonga bonga rotongalo konga?" my girl responded.  "Kotonga rebonga!" I responded.

All due respect to Tongalese culture, this place is truly awful.  Weak and sugary overpriced drinks, tourists partying as if they had just come back from getting drunk somewhere else.  The highlight is the Korean party band running through one tropical hit after another, wearing sunglasses in the dark hitting all the high notes in their fake boat in the middle of the pond.
author: Rob R.

description:
Although this place is very tacky, with overpriced food. I must say that the live band is what provides this tiki bar its charm. The live band does its job by getting you to sing and dance easily... however, something about tiki bars attracts all kinds of people -- your older crowd, family crowd, young crowd, and it ends up being super random. I didn't know what to think of my whole experience there, but nonetheless had a decent time!

I would definitely get the mai tai. Strong and tasty.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Made a reservation a month in advance to have drinks with friends on my birthday. I've never been before and heard it could be lots of fun. Get there and there is quite a line, but since we had a res we go right to the host. Ignored for about five minutes along with a few other groups that had a reservation. Once they greet us, they confirm we are eating dinner and I respond we are here just for drinks. Guy tells me we can't sit because they don't take reservations for just drinks and the bar is first come first serve. Of course the bar was full. I try to talk with him about it, saying I made this reservation a long time ago, I didn't know this, etc. But he didn't care, saying I should of known, it's written everywhere on the site and Open Table, basically being a rude, non accommodating host. I went back through my steps to see if this is written anywhere when I made the reservation through Yelp and its not. Only if you actually make it through their site, not Yelp. We decide not to stay or ever go back because that sucks and the guy was extremely condescending about something that ended up not even being correct. Fix your shit Tonga Room and get a nicer staff. Thanks for ruining by bday plans and trying to make me feel like an idiot.
author: Brittany S.

description:
Where else in the city can you act like such an ass and not feel bad about it the next day?  The Tonga Room drips with cheese.  Artificial flowers, artificial rainfall, drink served in pineapples with little umbrellas. Later in the evening a band plays in a raft on the artificial lake and you can dance your invented version of Tonga with the tourists.  

I think my dad summed it up the best. "This place is kinda weird."  Me, "I know, isn't it awesome."
author: Alexis M.

description:
Tonga! Tonga! Tonga!




The Happy Hour's scintillating buffet of Pacific Rim delicacies really sets this place apart. Killer drinks--Mai Tai and what I get Planter's Punch--help quell your fears of the every approaching hurricane! 

Hotel is has some fine beds too.
author: D. R.

description:
The Basics:
Time: Monday Night Happy Hour
Food: 7$ gives you all you can eat "dim sum"
Drinks: $7.50 each

Reality:
"Time*
Think awkward Tiki beach party, where there are 6 dudes talking about Dungeons and Dragons after getting riled up at a computer convention and the only girls that showed up, saw them, and left. Don't go on a Monday.

*Food*
Miniature Veggie Egg Rolls tasted like their was one little retarded cabbage slice wrapped 17 times in dough, then deep fried for an hour too long. Friends noted the Ribs were "palatable". Definitely not Dim Sum considering dumplings were no were to be found. They probably saw the super twice baked double fried egg rolls and ran for their little pork filled lives off the banquet table.

*Drinks*
The Tonga Tart was tasty, just enough Rum to bite, but not overwhelming. The slice of pineapple and indigo umbrella was cute ... for about 12 seconds until it stabbed me right in the eye.
The strawberry daiquiri was laiquiri( is that a word?) well, it was lacking alcohol. Hello!! ... Tonga Tarted Tiki Tribe ... tip that bottle down a little longer when it comes to my drink.

*Music*
None
author: Chris S.

description:
It rains in here people! For that you have to give this place five stars. The Tonga Room is great for making new friends. How can you not be friends after sipping gallons of rum out of a communal bowl using a ridiculously long straw???  The last time I was there after only one giant drink I became BFF's with my boyfriend's sketchy friend whom I previously despised. We sat around, telling dirty jokes in Spanish, and watching the older folks cut a rug to the cover band on the boat.
The Tonga Room....bringing people together.
author: stephanie c.

description:
The disparity between the price and quality of the food is appalling.  Not only is the food overpriced, but as my main man Charles Barkley would say it's "turrrrrble."  I went there on a triple date, and nobody got food that they liked.  That's turrrrble considering there was a 1 in 6 chance that SOMETHING would be good.

Although the decor and theme is quite charming, I go to a restaurant to eat and expect good food ESPECIALLY if I'm paying close to $30 a plate.  I guess that's too much to ask for this place.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
I got rickrolled by the cover band at the Tonga Room for great justice.

They claim on the web site that the mai tai is the best in all San Francisco. So I ordered one and it was very sweet and very strong. It's the kind of sweet that leaves an aftertaste. I came in on a wednesday, which it was pretty calm and my group was the only one in there.

Waiters were so-so. The guy we had at the end was friendly and remembered what we ordered and got our bill right. There was another waitress that I had to keep repeating myself to, and did get confused. She seemed cold and inattentive. The camera guy though, he was nice and likable, with the old 1940s camera. We all loved him but didn't get our picture taken (and did it ourselves).

Even though the drinks are expensive, it didn't seem like you had to be very dressy to come inside. After all, this is inside a hotel lobby. I saw some scruffy guys in hoodies and bedhead walking in and out.
author: Daniel L.

description: Scorpion for Two! Mai Tai was good, over all this place is about the History and the ambiance I didn't think it was all about " great food".... I did have the pork ribs and they were ok, but again this is a great place to chill , listen to some live music and check our the Indoor Rain Storm over the indoor lagoon
author: Michael S.

description:
It's been over 13 years since I've been here the first time and for some reason the Tonga Room doesn't have that same charm as it did before. 

The first time I went here, my boyfriend at the time took me here before his Senior Boat Dance for dinner. I was 16 and even though i couldnt drink, i thought this place was the shit because they had the cool lagoon with the performers and it would "rain' inside the restaurant. Wouldn't you have thought it was the shit then?

Fast forward to now, the bf has never been here before and I heard that they have a pretty sweet happy hour with a free buffet. Well, the buffet wasn't free anymore ($8 with a minimum 1 drink purchase) but the drinks weren't too expensive and the buffet was actually worth its $8. 

The decor was ok, had that South Pacific feel but as for the rainfall, it just wasn't the same. No oooohs and aaaahhs here anymore. 

I think I read one time a couple of years ago in an InStyle magazine that this was the place that the celebs hang out at when they are in SF....hmmmm, I don't know about that!
author: Pippi L.

description:
C H E E S Y.

and over priced.  ...But where else can you hear thunder and fake rain and watch a 65+ Russian couple dance in evening gowns and black ties?
author: Today Y.

description:
Ultimate cheese. Seriously, the Tonga Room is on the same cheese level as Disneyland. In fact, I think that's why I kind of like it. The rainstorm is the greatest thing that I have seen in a bar - ever.

That being said, atmosphere is the only thing the Tonga Room has going for it. It's overpriced, the servers all seem to hate their lives, and they'll definitely stick you with an entertainment charge (even when you get there early enough to avoid it - check your bill carefully).

If you're feeling cheesy, this is the place for you!
author: Ava S.

description:
I don't really understand all the bad reviews...

A bunch of us went out for our friend's bday, and I must say, this place is SO hilarious! 

1 very BIG star for the DELICIOUS Mai Tai in the cute coconut shell with pinapple and umbrella!!

1 GINORMOUS star for the Disneyland meets Hawaiian vacation atmosphere (and I'm a SERIOUS Disneyland fanatic..SERIOUS)

1 star for the general feel of the place-EVERYONE was having a good time, EVERYONE was dancing, laughing, and just letting loose which is alot more than I can say for more than HALF the bars/clubs in the city.  (City mix is 1 part yuppie, 2 parts drama, dash of testosterone, shaken and hurled in your "it took me 2 hours to do my makeup and hair! OMG!" face)

(Hey-I'm allowed to put my two cents in about some of the people in SF-I was born and raised here, so get over it-you know you're not a native)

1 star for the entertaining rainstorm, and cute boat with the live band :o)

minus 1 star--there were kids there (???) On a Saturday night? I know it's a restaurant, but c'mon...it's a SATURDAY night...keep it adult after a certain hour.

It's nice to know you can *kind of* get away from the typical night scene every so often and just have some plain, good fun!
author: Michelle R.

description:
I always heard about the Tonga Room and wanted to go.  I had been to the Fairmont a few times growing up, but never went there....I don't know if it is a good thing when your grandma says that she used to party there like in the 1940's or 1950's and said it used to be the spot..!!..ha ha...Well, we still went for my birthday..

Ok, when you walk in it is very interesting.  You would not think that under this big beautiful hotel there was this moat thing at the bottom....The food was ok.  Too expensive though!  You can go to Panda Express and get the same thing for like $5!!!

The bar was cool.  I drank something red out of a big bowl-glass.  And I drank something orange out of a pineapple.  And than I drank something blue out of a coconut...And than I can't remember what else I drank!  The bartender was really funny.  Once he found out it was my birthday, he kept giving me free drinks..!

The band on the boat going around the moat - pond thing was.....interesting.  Did you ever see the Wedding Singer with Adam Sandler??  Ok, well the band is sort of like that...

I think the Tonga Room is a good experience.  And everyone should give it  a try once.  Andy maybe take grandma with you.  She might enjoy it...
author: J R.

description:
Because 1/2 of the maternal side of my family lives in New Zealand, I am going to feel legitimate saying, this is the BEST TIKI BAR this side of the hemisphere. I know.

The decor is detailed and clean and FUN. In the way that Vegas feels like an old Western facade portending to be something it is not, the Tonga Room and Hurricane Bar is most definitely something, and that something is sizzling HOT. 

The 1950's era coordinating coconut and hula girl drink glasses are picture worthy, the dance floor or deck of the ship is smooth and the inside rainstorm with the band in the center bobbing and floating makes very cell in your body radiate with 'I don't want to leave for hours'.

I went in late Feb 2009 bc I read on Laughing Squid that this bar may be doomed with the condo expansion dreams of the Fairmont. I seriously can't imagine it coming down. The only reasonable option would be to reconstruct it as an exact replica somewhere else. See other reviews for links to saving it in situ.

Happy Hour starts at 6pm. Don't be late.
author: Miel H.

description: Great atmosphere.  Feels like you're in the tropics. There was a live band but also a cover charge for it. Food was good but not spectacular. Spent $100 for the two of us. But was able to stay and enjoy the music and atmosphere afterwards.
author: Tony Y.

description: The concierge told us that this was the most popular happy hour 5-7pm with famous Mai tai's and that it would be packed so we should make a reservation. We decided to wing it and just show up at 6pm. There were 2 tables with people at it in the entire place and obviously tourists. We are from south Florida so we were expecting a happening place. They have cheap Chinese food and the Mai tai was disgusting. I had to ask for more pineapple juice to cover some of the flavor of the cheap liquor. The decor is Polynesian in a pirate ship. Like the pirates of the Caribbean ride at Disney world. Super super cheesy! U might enjoy this if you are completely wasted prior to arrival or you are ten year old child amused by water coming from ceiling like pretend rain. I can't imagine any local ever coming to this place. It's definitely a tourist trap and we fell for it. Worst hotel bar and btw it's at the fairmont hotel which makes no sense at all. But this fairmont was probably the worst one in the world anyways so maybe it all makes sense now.
author: Shehnaz H.

description:
This place reminded me of a Hawaiian themed elderly cruise- but the drinks were yummy and once you get past the cheesy-ness of it all it's pretty fun to have a drink and watch the people dance. Drinks are pricey, but if you are not satisfied the bartender will make you another.

Our waitress was not friendly at all. My boyfriend said she's been working there for years and has never been nice- I'm surprised she still has a job there.
author: Melinda Q.

description:
Jimmy Buffet meets Pirates of the Caribbean meets Scrooge McDuck.

That is to say, this place has a slightly annoying atmosphere, strange and gawdy decor, and really high prices.

That is not to say it wasn't completely enjoyable.  It's just ridiculous enough to be fun.  There is a big pool of water in the middle of the restaurant with a boat where the band plays at night. I didn't catch the band, but I'm sure it adds to the enjoyment.

Every few minutes, "rain" pours down from the ceiling into the pool (not over your table, no worries).

One would think this place would stink of stagnant water (like Pirates of the Caribbean), but it conveniently does not.

The food was pretty good, just not good enough to merit prices that high. Plus, the waiter was much like a drug pusher. He somehow got our table to order a massive amount of food and a myriad of fruity, tropical drinks. 

 I had the Innocent Passion because I liked saying the name in a provocative way. However, it was really sweet and a little like drinking pixie sticks.
author: Ellie S.

description:
First Impression:
- Hidden from the lobby of this beautiful hotel.  On the bottom floor across from the gym -kinda hard to find.  The restaurant was large and dark.  Loved the pool in the middle.

Menu:
- The menus were in a hard cover binder WITH dividers as if it were used for school.  There was a $24 cocktail - a Cosmo 2K.  I didn't try it.  The cocktail menu wasn't as large as Trader Vic's.  The Mai Tai was also strong but served in a porcelain coconut.  The pineapple that was served as a garnish was still frozen.
- The dinner menu wasn't very impressive.  Nothing really called out to me.  They had price fixed dinners to choose from that  I believe started in the $40 range. 

Service:
- The hostess wasn't so friendly.  Didn't ask us how we were and didn't smile.  We were sat at a table in the bar because they weren't sitting people for dinner quite yet.  The server/bartender was friendly at first but rushed us when he took our order and rudely snatched the drink menu out of my boyfriend's hand.  We were going to leave but we already ordered a Sampler Platter.  After that, the server/bartender was friendly.  Not sure what the snatching was all about.  

Food:  
- The food was OK.  We only based it on the Sampler Platter.  It came with fried prawns, ribs, chicken satay with a peanut sauce, veggie egg rolls and pot stickers.  They weren't really tasty.  Edible,  yes, but nothing that enticed me to stay for dinner.  So we didn't stay.

Price: 
- $9.50 for a Crown and Coke
- $9.00 for a Mai Tai
- $21.00 for the Sampler Platter

Entertainment:
- $5 entertainment fee for everyone staying after 8 PM
- The room was the old pool.  A pool of water is still set in the middle of the room with a platform in the middle of it for the music/band.
- Probably every half an hour, sounds of lightning and thunder are heard over the speakers and flashes of lightning are seen above the huts.  Rain falls from the ceiling and falls into the pool.  Very cool. 

Dcor:
- The room is dark.  Tall, wooden tiki gods are found everywhere.  You walk into the lobby and find the bar to your right with one LCD television, stools surrounding the bar and low cocktail tables.  Outrigger boat hangs from the ceiling to the left and lit glass buoys hang from the right.  The platform of a ship stretches the entire width of the room after the bar.
author: Bernadette M.

description: I always have fun bringing people to the Tonga Room at Happy Hour. Was it better 20 years ago? Absolutely! The buffet was unbelievable...however, even now, the drinks are fun with their Polynesian flair, there's a tropical storm every 10 minutes, with thunder & lightning & rain that falls into the pool at the center of the room. The snacks, for the nominal charge, are still pretty good, and the least healthy ones in town. So, get there early, seating from 5-7pm M-F gets really crowded with tourists & business travelers alike, and take advantage so you can have all the greasy fried food you can handle!
author: Alyssa P.

description: Fun, but diminished by overpriced drinks, drink minimums, long waits and rude service.
author: Raina M.

description:
Bad food and backwash?!  Count me in!

Tonga Room happy hour is all about the kitsch and it's well worth at least one visit!  This was not my first visit and I can confidently say that it will not be my last.  I like to introduce Tonga Room to out-of-towners or locals who have never taken the time to check it out.  It's all about tiki torch madness with a cheap buffet to keep you grounded from drinking over-sized scorpion bowls that you share with your friends using long-ass backwash-inevitable straws!

And there's a pool in the middle of the room!  What are you waiting for?  Check it out!
author: Nicole N.

description:
ATMOSPHERE: the tonga room is the definition of kitschy, but the tropical rain + lightening + thunder was kinda cool

DRINKS: hit or miss in regards to level of strength... the scorpian bowl was my favorite of the night (the looong straws are fun)... better tasting than the lava bowl. the mai tai was NOT the best i've ever had, not even close. and the banana daq was bland and water'd down and too icy. ALSO, way too expensive. i mean, cmon, $6.50 for a coors light?! that's awful! 

FOOD: overcooked, greasy, fried, bland, limp, mushy, spent too much time under the heat lamps hawaiian fare that doesn't include sides or rice... 

COVER CHARGE: really? really! you know who was on the dance floor? old, retired, rich people who could (A) afford staying at the fairmont and (B) were wearing hawaiian shirts and totally having the time of their life. we danced some too and it was fun because nobody took themselves too seriously. good place for a group off-site, but I wouldn't pay a cover charge to hang out here.
author: Christine N.

description:
I'm all about indoor water displays. If I ever strike it rich, there will be waterfalls, fountains, and lagoons in every room of my house. Instead of toilets, there will be babbling brooks in which you can take a leak. It will be classy and beautiful. 

So, I was all amped to fall in love with the Tonga Room and their fake thunderstorm/lagoon business. But, the TR takes itself way too seriously. Cover charge?!  $9 cocktails? I can't enjoy myself when I feel as though I'm being taken for a sucker. 

Also, any restaurant in SF that doesn't offer at least ONE vegetarian entree is on my permanent crap list.
author: D e v a n.

description:
Johnny Depp, where were you?

This cheesy place is hilariously Pirates of the Caribbean/Disneyland.  I took my best friend here as a joke.  Anyone San Franciscan will frown on this place.  She's not from here and even she frowned on this place.  It's too touristy, Bridge and Tunnel, old Caucasian businessman taking a young Asian girl from out of town on a date, throw up in your mouth, pre-party before your high school prom type place.  

The drinks are overpriced, the all you can eat happy hour fare is decent.  Don't come here expecting to fill up on food because the tea saucers they call plates forces you to keep coming back while everyone stares at you like you're sinning for coming back and getting more food.  And I didn't want to keep continuously getting embarassed because I looked greedy each time I came back.  Or maybe I was just embarassed anyone I knew would see me there.  Well, t hey should be embarassed I saw them there too!

2 stars for the rain in the middle and the cheesy live 80's band.  But ONLY 2 stars since they charge you a cover to stay and watch the band.
author: Nezza F.

description:
Great place to have someone meet you from out of town if you live in Nob Hill, since you know they will never find parking in your neighborhood and they will be able to justify paying for it in a garage since you are meeting at a public place. 

But be warned - the food is terrible and overpriced! There is however,  a decent happy hour during the week . The whole tikki, rain show, live band thing is a bit entertaining, as well.
author: Gina G.

description:
One of the primary problems I find with Yelp reviews is that many folks fail to correctly identify the function of what it is they're reviewing. The reviews I'm reading here on the Tonga Room are a perfect example. Let me clarify the role of the Tonga Room...

WHAT THE TONGA ROOM IS - one of the last authentic Polynesian Pop Tiki bars, a place to start the evening with nostalgic cheesiness that combines 60s Disney jungle rides with Don Ho and booze. It would be accurate to say that the Tonga Room is a symbol of a bygone tackiness that never ceases to amuse. There is food, but you are not there for the food. You are there for the tropical rainstorm every 15 minutes or so. You're there to drink fruity rum drinks next to a pool and listen to a band on a KonTiki raft play bad lounge music. You are there to occasionally dance badly to this music. Most importantly, you are there to put on a pleasant buzz with strong fruity drinks and laugh yourself silly. 

WHAT THE TONGA IS NOT - A place for a great meal. A place for hipsters to drink Fernet, do coke in the bathroom and converse in inadvertently ironic sarcasm speak. A place to listen to the latest music. And, last but not least, a place to be bitterly cynical. 

I hope this clears up any confusion for you.
author: Jay N.

description: Cheesy? Yes. Pricey? Yes. Shocking? No! The drinks were great, the atmosphere was awesome, our staff was friendly and attentive, the food was OK. This place is what it is - a cheesy tiki bar with over priced drinks. But, sit back and enjoy the show, and have a great time!
author: Thomas C.

description: San Francisco kitsch and history.  Dont dare miss it!!
author: Christin A.

description:
Greatest Bar Ever.  Ever.
There is a little band on a boat.  Indoors.  And it rains. Indoors.

This isn't going to be anyone's neighborhood bar.  It is in a hotel, after all.  But it is an awesome place to take people who are visiting from out of town. (the fact that none of my friends are wealthy enough to actually stay in the Fairmont Hotel has never stopped us)  This is a good place to go every once in awhile for an awesome night out.

One of the best parts of it is that the bar attracts a good mix of people.  The other people there were a good mix of ages and there was a nice collection of people dressed up for a night out and some people dressed more casually.
author: Clay H.

description:
Normally I head to Forbidden Island in Alameda to satisfy my tiki fix, but last night a friend and I found ourselves in the neighborhood, so we decided to stop in to the Tonga Room for a drink before heading home.

The bad: the drinks could have been a little better, the appys could have been a little cheaper (although they were mighty yummy) and the $5 music cover was actually about $5 more than I wanted to spend. 

The good: no problems with the staff, the hostess and waiter were friendly, and a busboy gathered our empty plates the second we finished. The atmosphere was nice (I'm a sucker for fake thunderstorms) but I did find myself wishing they could figure out a way to disguise the "rain" pipes a little. 

What really sold me were the other patrons, some of them looked like they'd been coming there since long before I was born. The band, on their little floating island, started playing "Fly me to the moon" and soon several couples appeared on the dance floor, among them a pair that had to be in their 80's. Those two were just about the sweetest thing I've seen all year. (Yup, I'm sappy. Is that so wrong?)

I would definitely revisit for a special occasion, or try to catch the happy hour when it's a bit more affordable.
author: Jess S.

description: Go during happy hour and get one of the fruit daiquiris.  I got the pineapple and it was awesome.  They had a buffet for $9-something but I didn't try it.  Nice place for a drink.  If you live here you gotta check it out sooner or later.  Thumbs up!  Classy joint.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
I love this place, because it has a fun tropical atmosphere, fun band, fake rainstorms, yummy cocktails, and the simple joys of being able to watch uber drunk people dance in the most creative ways.
