I learned a new dance move that night called "the lawnmower"? Didn't realize how cool it  was until we saw one of these drunkards rockin' it. 
The food was really good too, especially the spicy baby broccoli. I can almost say this side dish was more flavorful than our lemongrass curry seafood hotpot. The food seems a bit overpriced for what you are getting, but the atmosphere makes it worth it. I really like the idea of putting cocktails in coconut shells, but alas I didn't order one of these because it was $16? 
The hotel it is in is also incredibly nice and the valet drivers are even nicer. Even though there weren't anymore parking spots, they parked our cars anyways where they weren't supposed to. We totally got hooked up!
All in all, I would totally come back here because it's like a mini tropical vacation in SF.
author: Sonya D.

description:
Because this is one of the oldest tiki bars in our nation I think everyone should check it out as least once. Be prepared to pay $10 for a buffet that isn't anything amazing to write home about and be prepared to pay $13 for tropical drinks. You would think this little treasure doesn't constitute five stars, but it's historic, and that makes it a must experience. The buffet consisted of Kahlua pig lettuce wraps, egg rolls, fried rice, fruit and seaweed salad. My step dad was in heaven while my mom and I were taking in the ambiance and not so much the food :-) 

Service was good and the rain forest storms that came about once every thirty minutes was a nice touch. There is also a band on a boat that comes out onto the water to play. I missed that but hear it's pretty awesome.
author: Jen B.

description: That floating barge of mediocrity they call entertainment doesn't make up for the pupu-esqe buffet and overpriced drinks served in what I can only describe as footed cereal bowls.    Neither does the contrived thunderstorm that almost makes me wish for the real thing...though the impromptu showers may water down the cocktails even more.
author: Joc V.

description: Kitschy fun, great band and atmosphere, friendly staff and clientele, very expensive.  Too expensive, but hey--it's something you gotta do. If you've spent any money down at Fisherman's Wharf then you've already been bent over. What's another $100?  Go have fun.
author: Ken S.

description:
I just had dinner there tonight with a group of my friends for a birthday. After experiencing it myself, I thought for sure I was going to find people on yelp saying the same stuff but boy was I wrong. Apparently, San Franciscans love the cheesy theme and rate this place with 4 and 5 stars for that rather than the food.
Anyways, I'm going to get my two cents in. The menu at a glance looked really good. "family style" and  "large plates".. okay. Sounds good for a big group. NO. complete UTTER lies. Their large plates which average $25 per entree are NOT AT ALL large. Maybe it's large for a family of rats but really... please don't call it large when it's not. We thought ordering 5 dishes was going to be enough to share among 9 people but boy we ended up ordering 9 large plates and none of us really ate that much. That's the biggest thing that got on my nerves tonight. 
Let's get to the food. "Fire Cracker Prawns", "Dragon Fire Chicken". WOW sounds amazing. Too bad the food doesn't have what it takes to back any of those fancy words up. All the dishes lack real taste, the seafood still tasted fishy. Since we ordered 9 "large" plates, that's pretty much every dish on their "large" plates menu and in all honesty, I will not eat any of them even if they were $5 instead of the $25. 
Service... not bad. Except the waiter gave me an alcoholic drink when I ordered pineapple juice and one of the chopsticks was broken at the tip which could've led to a bloody mouth.
Lastly, the environment. Overall, it's not bad. Except the damn thunderstorm that happens almost every 15 mins. I'll admit it, it was cool the first time it happened but when it started doing it every 15 minutes, it just got annoying and disruptive. 
Bottomline, take your money somewhere else where they serve food that's actually tasty.
author: Steven L.

description:
Here's the thing about Tonga Room. This place is over-the-top tiki torch, Hawaiian shirt, crazy fruit all up in my drink madness. Kinda like your first trip to Hawaii when you go to to a luau and everyone stares in awe at the grass skirt dancers because they really believe that the experience is traditional. And that's kind of what Tonga room is. You get the mix of people who really think the fake rain and the show boat performance is the real tropical deal and the the other half of the crowd who just go to go. 
This was definitely a hard place to rate, especially when you're a local and there's way cooler things in the city then rocking my Friday night at the Tonga Room. But based on my experience, I had a friggin blast. I had my fair share of Mocolocco Martinis (not sure if those are real, but they should be), and attempted to dance brilliantly on the dance floor with my friends. This was an EPIC moment just because everyone thought I was actually a good dancer and cheered me on. We took pictures with random strangers, crashed a birthday and accidently dropped someone on their head (yikes), which not everyone can say, can they?
Sure this was just my night, but what I'm saying is that you should just go and rock it out, too. It's something different, and whether you take it seriously or not, Tonga Room is "an experience to remember."
author: Alex H.

description:
I was lured by the happy hour all-you-can-eat special; but they have these tiny plates; and they guilt trip you if you try to have enough, and also guilt trip you into buying a drink; so you really don't save that much; and the food isn't anything special.

Ambience is pretty cool though.
author: Mark A.

description:
This joint exists with a kind of oblivious self-abandon that is frankly indifferent to the current directions of the "hipster massive". The super-sweet drinks, the fake rain, the island, the thunder & lightning! I though folks were pulling my leg about all those!!

The singer projects from the "island boat" in the middle of the pool/fake-lagoon and she covered a startling range of top40 songs! She was like a "live" Lite 96.5 KOIT! Particularly surprising, she sang a recent-y "hit" by the Pussycat Dolls - "Don't you wish your girlfriend was hot like me"!! Her rendition was a little flat and the rhythm was a bit off, but was it was funny and endearing to see all the folks from all ages/walks of life, flooding the dancefloor to do the cha-cha, swing, random-ballroom dancing to it!! Just getting close and romantical! awww!

In a nutshell, if you go here, don't take it too seriously, 'cos this ain't the cutting edge, but can be fun!! 4 Stars!!
author: I. O.

description:
My low rating is due to the service (not including the bartender).  We went to the Tonga Room to start off the 'after-party' for a friend's wedding.  We were going to meet up there and get some drinks before heading up to the guest suite for the 'real' party.

At the time, dinner service was still going on.  The live band was already playing on the floating stage.  People were dancing.  The bar area was full.  Full meaning, there were no available tables, but plenty of standing room.  

Our initial group had about 8 people, and we were getting a hard time from the hostess who for some reason, didn't want us standing by the bar.  When more people from our party showed up at the door, she was giving them trouble coming in.  I don't know what the deal was.  I guess she wanted us to get  table - but there weren't any!  And they charge you for sitting at those tables, did you know that?  So, not only are the drinks expensive, you have to pay for the privilege of sitting.  Where are we, Vegas? 

I was able to order a yummy strawberry daiquiri from a very nice bartender, so both stars go to him.  No stars for the way we were treated.  

When a group of people come into a bar, you should let them in.  They're there to spend money on alcohol.  Not smart.  A couple of us who were there early had drinks in hand already, so we all just went up to the suite.

To be fair, the atmosphere of the place is very cool.  The floating stage thing is kind of tacky, but hey, it adds to the charm of the place.  How about that indoor rain storm?  I like the tropical theme.  I didn't try the food, but it looked good from what I could see at the tables.  And the restaurant was completely full - so I guess that tells you something.
author: Denise M.

description: Ahh the Tonga room, a mix of pure cheese and funk. A large group of us came here for a celebration and it was so much fun. Dancing and fake rain + Mai Tai's and friends= really funny pictures to post on social networks. Expensive as far as drinks go but that is expected. Get a room at the fairmont for after to make it an evening and it's like a mini hawaiian/vegas vacation.
author: sophie p.

description:
For eating environment this place is great! It is literally The Fairmont hotel doing its own version of the Rainforest Cafe. A couple stunning parts of the interior architecture: a ship's bow as the dance floor and a moving boat stage that slides its way over to the center of a pool when there is a performance! And the lady who was singing made eye contact with me because I was singing right back. You may enjoy all her renditions of pop songs, but check out her singing in French! You are expected to pay $5.00 per person for the mandatory performance fee. 

Secondly, the food is not that great. I had the appetizer platter for two for myself and it was filling but it just did not taste special. Also, if you are in a group of four try the infamous LAVA BOWL! Crazy alcohol and sugar. With four people I don't think you would even finish it! But it is all part of the experience. -Matt
author: Matthew C.

description: Kitschy, but fun kind of kitsch. Great place which would be so easy to miss for visitors to San Fran like me. A friend I know in town suggested we meet here. Drinks are made strong, so while they are pricey, you're not going to be drinking too many. Loved the live band on a barge in the 'lagoon'.
author: Joe T.

description:
I've been to the Tonga Room a couple of times for happy hour. It's an ok place to hang out with your crew for a little bit, that is until the happy hour buffet ends. As for the  Hawaiian theme, no this place is not. The food is the same you'd see at any of the mediocre Lee's delis around downtown.  I would have rather skipped it. The food's sole purpose is to draw you in and to act as a buffer against all the alcohol you'll be drinking. 

Save your money for a real Polynesian restaurant and then take yourself to Bamboo Hut or somewhere for the Hawaiian shirts and leis.
author: Jen A.

description:
Good God.  It's like the pirates of the carribean threw up in here.  But without the fun wenches.  Besides super slow and angry service, the drinks are pretty good.  And strong.  

There appeared to be some sort of buffet thing.  I think I'm allergic to even the idea of a buffet.  I am not sure what it is, but mass grazing just really sounds gross.

oh, and there is this thunderstorm thing.  You know, like when you're in the produce section and you hear that thunder and then they start to spray the wilty lettuce??  Yep, they do that at the Tonga Room.  They have been doing it for 20 years.  Do you know what water recycled for 20 years smells like?  You can go there and find out. You and the rest of the other 50+ year old tourists who found it in their guidebooks.

Kitschy, dark, but come on, anything served in a plastic coconut has to be good...
author: Alison R.

description:
Being that I live in San Francisco, and have seen this bar on the travel channel, I decided I needed to check it out...

My best friend and I went on Sunday evening about 10:45pm. (mind you they close at 11:45pm on Sundays)

There is a sign outside saying 'Please wait to be seated' 
Ok great, no problem, I work in a restaurant, I can wait. 


Waiting......

Waiting.... 

10 minutes later! Some guy in a suit comes out, barely looks at us and starts doing something on the computer! 

I smile and say "2 for the bar please"

He looks at his watch and looks at us and says "Well you better get in there, we're almost closed" (!!!?!!!)

Stunned I looked at him and said "excuse me? what time is last call?" and he said "about 20 minutes" 

I was pissed. If I hadn't been waiting politely for 10 minutes to encounter your rude self, we wouldn't be in this position now, would we? 

So we go in, seat ourselves at a (dirty) table in the bar and wait another 5 minutes at least to be greeted. The waiter was very polite and courteous, thank goodness. So we ordered a drink, took in the scenery and thunderstorm action, which was pretty cool by the way. Oh yea, the drinks were also good. 

If it weren't for the rude manager guy and the wait to even be acknowledged, this place would have gotten four stars. But let me tell you, if I talked to my customers the way this guy did, I would not have a job, or any customers!

Overall, cool experience, LOUSY customer service.... You can do without this place.
author: Heather C.

description:
One of the nation's first Tiki Bars, it's in the historic Fairmont Hotel around the building's former indoor pool.  It was built in 1947 to give WWII soldiers a taste of the South Pacific that they were so nostalgic for after they came home from the war.  And those same worldly men of The Greatest Generation are still drinking and dancing there today.  

An amazing place that's equal parts history, kitsch, and senior center.  Like Disney's Tiki Room, but with strong umbrella drinks.  Oh, and geezers gettin' down to groovy tunes played by a coverband on the deck of a "ship" in the middle of the pool as it rains.  Fantaaaaaaastic.
author: Skye R.

description:
OLD SKOOL SAN FRAN

You gotta check this place out at least once for the following reasons:

TIKI... not good tiki but tiki
Umbrella Drinks...see below
Scorpions... Oh Yeah
Happy Hour Food... Its free
It fucking RAINS in here with thunder and lightning
Bands on a float in the "lagoon"
Cool bartenders and ridiculously dickhead waiters... order at the bar and watch the waiters squirm and hate you

If thats not enough...Its THE FAIRMONT, when your grandpa brought your granny here it probably added branches to your family tree, there's a rooftop garden, did I say it rains here

If you cant have a good time here you couldnt have fun with a stolen credit card!
author: Scotty B.

description: while the food was just OK, the atmosphere was pretty cool.  The indoor rain made it a unique experience but the overall atmosphere didn't really make it stand out from the crowd.  i wish i could give this place more stars but it didn't really impress me...
author: d h.

description:
I came here on Valentine's day on their preset 3 course meal.

It's like asian-infused gourmet food. The appetizers were good but the hot pot was not so good. Being an asian person and eating asian food all the time it wasn't good. But to non-asians food eaters, I think they might think it's good.

But the drinks here are good.

and the Band and atmosphere is fabulous. So their is this little pool fountain with a tiny boat with a live band that plays on it. VERY COOL! (it was a former swimming pool) It would have a thunder/rain effect once in a while. 

Great atmosphere and beautiful place. Dance floor too.
author: Tam T.

description: Cheesy, overpriced, but still addictive and oh so much fun (think of colored  ceramic glasses with sweet drinks overflowing with pineapple).
author: David A.

description:
I read your reviews and yesterday my husband and I ended our date night early and decided we wanted to stay out for drinks.

Headed to Top of the Mark but decided we didn't want to pay $20 for a cover charge for only one drink each - so I looked at the Tonga sign that I look at every other day while walking around Nob Hill and decided - I'm dressed up and in heels, I'm not ready to go home... we are going in!

What a wonderfully, cheesy yet exciting experience!

First of all, you have to walk down the hall in the hotel on like the ground floor to get to it which is quite the experience!!!!

Then  you walk in and are completely overwhelmed by the decor and ambiance as well as the interesting mix of people in the bar.

There was a $3 entertainment charge per person after 8, so we figured at least there will be music (3 is way cheaper than 10)

We sat down and I had a Tonga Itch and my husband a beer, and our adorably and helpful waiter brought them to us with no problem. He informed us that the band was on a break - so we waited patiently and took in the AMBIANCE (it certainly calls for CAPS)

I honestly think that everyone MUST GO HERE - at least once in their life. It's Pirates of the Caribbean with Hawaiian undertones and there is a freaking thunderstorm, complete with rain and lightening.

Intrigued - just go. The food looked overpriced and not very yummy, the drinks were tasy but pricey, but we fully enjoyed the band and watching the people who bravely danced on the dance floor.

As cheesy as it was it was terribly romantic and hip. 

Maybe I'm still too much of a tourist - but I'm glad we went there. It's like being in a themed cruise ship bar only without the sea sickness.

Have fun and enjoy it - that's what I think:)
author: Annie M.

description:
Thursday Happy Hour 1 - Fairmont Hotel, Tonga Room 
Disappointing...

Tonga room looks very nice in the picture. The introduction also looks nice with $9.50 All-you-can-eat buffet for Happy Hour special. However, there is a huge gap between what is on the paper and what is in reality. 

Environment: The place may be under construction. The roof looks like half way done warehouse. If you don't look up, the place is actually very interesting with its tropical island theme. 

Drink: The price for cocktail is pretty good, somewhere around $7.50. But the wine seems a little pricey. The drink itself is OK, nothing special, I had Mai Tai. 

Buffet: Such a disappointment. All they had were spring rolls, deep fried won-ton, stir fry noodles, cabbage with pork, and some cheese and fruit. First of all, I truly felt the food was not worth of $9.50; second, the quality of the food is not great; third, the taste of the food is just average. Thinking of Tonga Room in Fairmont Hotel, Gosh, it is even worse any Chinese buffet in China town you can get for $6.50/person. 

Service: Oh-my-god!!! We must own her money in the previous life, no smile on her face, harsh tone in her voice, very slow service, over charged bill... one word, 'horrible'. And then, she forced 20% gratuity. 

Conclusion: Never again. 

P.s. if you want to be treated like shit and get ripped off, you have to check out Tonga Room in Fairmont Hotel.
author: Lydia L.

description:
Last night, after reading a few reviews of the Tonga Room, I took my girlfriend there for dinner.  The place itself is nice enough with a band on a floating barge in the middle of the restaurant.

The food was also pretty decent with entrees in the $30 range.  The service is also satisfactory but not superb.  Overall, the experience was pretty good.

BUT 

when the bill came, they charged $7 each for what they called an Entertainment Fee.  Now, this is what makes me hot.  The food they served was typical asian/pacific island fare that would typically cost $10-$12 a plate anywere else.  All entrees came a la carte so any sides like basic rice were extra ($7) so since I've already paid for the experience, why the heck would they charge me an additional $7 per person to be entertained by the floating band??  The food wasn't worth it and now to be gouged an additional amount of money for no reason made me swear never to return.

Be warned if you go in there, because paying that much more for average food and ambience is NOT worth it at the Tonga Room.
author: Max C.

description:
I mean, you have to be in the right mood for this.

Tonga Room for happy hour is a serious "bring your own party" location, whether that means a party of 10 coworkers ready to get shmammered on daquiris or some sketchy tryst that will take place in the darker corners. You are not coming here to scope out a super-sexy-cool crowd.

But as a blank canvas to work from, I am a huge fan of the Tonga Room. Weird non-denominationally Asian food, strong and ridiculous drinks, insanely cheesy in-restaurant theatrics that are outdated circa 1965...all of this stuff make great set pieces -- you just have to bring the players.
author: Sophie S.

description:
2 for food
2 for wait staff
5 for ambiance
= 3 stars

Went here for our 6th year anniversary.  Went online to opentable.com and reserved a table from my cell phone.  
Walking in, nothing beats the island, lively feel, with the lake and island in the middle of the joint.  Very romantic.
But the service is so-so, with the guys needing some people skills workshops - they are very business-like and have no island warmth whatsoever.  And the food is blah, especially for the prices.

But how can you beat the live soft-rock, swing, and cha-cha.  Get on the dancefloor and it's the perfect speed for us 30-somethings that know that it's not the new 20-something.
author: Andrew P.

description:
So, before going to the Tonga Room, I read through the reviews, so I felt I knew what to expect.  I just came back from taking my mom there for Mother's Day, because she has heard all about the Tonga Room, has never been, and really wanted to go before it closed for good.  

Boy, were we sorry we went.  
Overall, we thought the set-up was really cute - the host lai'd us as we entered, the dimmed lighting, and the decor was fun, and just what you want out of a tiki-bar, no big problems there.  

But the food... wow, I think this was the worst meal I've had in a long time.  And its not cheap either - the tonga appetizer for two set us back $25, and each of the dinner entrees was roughly $25.  The menu features island style dishes... and you are surprised when the waiters arrive with chinese-style dishes (but worse than any chinese food i've ever had), with "island" aka sweet sauces.  On top of that, some of the dishes we ordered had many "extra" ingredients added in, and we couldn't really recognize them from the menu (we almost sent one back because we thought we got the wrong thing).  If you are planning on serving something - give an accurate description of it on the menu.

Very disappointing.  Only good if you are looking for the atmosphere, and maybe just checking out the bar.  At first I was sad when I heard it was closing, but now I'm actually glad - because no one else should be sucked in to paying as much for a crappy dinner as we had.
author: Kelly B.

description: I'm a native of SF and was excited to try the famous Tonga Room. I finally went there about two weeks ago; and to put it out there I was on codine so I did not try any of the alcoholic beverages. There were 5 of us. I got a non alcoholic ale which tasted disgusting, my boyfriend got their pina colada and he said there was too much coconut juice and too little of rum, his friend got a beer, and his other friend and gf shared a drink. They also got one plate of appetizer which we all shared; nothing too thrilling. With that said, the bill came out to be a little over $60! Are you @4#$% kidding me? What a waste of $60! Ugh... not to mention the service (for a 5 star hotel) was crap!!! I'm disappointed that it did not live up to what I thought it would be... but I'm even more disappointed that we paid $60 for crappy service, food, and drinks!
author: selina n.

description: I've lived in San Francisco for 10 years and have been to the Tonga Room a few times and to be honest there is nothing to write home about here but it is so kitchy that you kind of have to enjoy it.  I took some clients here earlier this week as they wanted to go to a tourist trap.  The Happy Hour isn't too great but the food and drinks afterwards are much better.  The drinks have a ton of sugar in them so you can't stay here all night but with the rain and thunder there is no other place like this in the city.
author: Blake B.

description: Food was meh, and expensive. Server was nice though, and it was cool to see a live filipino reggae band there.
author: Emy s.

description:
Doesn't everyone need cheesy fun once in awhile?  

This is your cheesy fun spot!  80's music played by a band that floats out into the pond thing in the middle of the restaurant.  Yummy, fruity  strong slightly overpriced drinks that you need straws for, all the staff dressed in Hawaiian gear,  a fake thunderstorm when you least expect it, and couples your parents age dancing together on the dance floor next to you and your drunken friends.

Love it.  Great place for girls night out, or to take out of towners that are slightly older than you, or for friends that just want some cheesy old fashioned fun.  

I haven't had the food or happy hour, so I don't know how those go. 

My one gripe is that there is a cover to go inside on certain nights?  Really, is that necessary for a hotel bar?
author: Denise B.

description:
I couldn't be more thrilled to have gone here before the inevitable gears of capitalism turn this San Francisco legend into condo's.  

The food and drinks are expensive, and honestly the food (while tasty) isn't all that great and no where nears the quality that you can get down the street...

but.....

The place is just plain badass.... where else are you going to see a jazz band perform on a boat in the middle of a pool in a restaurant in the basement of one of the ritzy-est hotels in SF? (screw you,,, I'll run on sentence if I want to.) You really should go here.. I went for a good friends bachelor party and we were loud, obnoxious, drunk..... loud.   We sang something at the top of our lungs at one point.... it may have been "more than a feeling" I'm not sure.  And while I'm sure they were happy to see us leave, I will be sad to see them go.


Damn The Man... Save The Tonga!
author: John S.

description:
I hated the $7 cover for live music... which was good... but not $7 worth.  The waitress for our table had a chip on her shoulder, and took forever to come around for refills.  She only smiled after dropping the check - expected a large tip... but oh wait... she already added the gratuity!!!  That is all you get gurl, thanks anyway!
It is definitely VERY kitschy, with rain showers and tiki torches.  If you have friend from outa town, it might be fun, but I rather save the $7 for a long island ice-t at Badlands!
author: Grant S.

description:
I have been here for drinks on a few occasions now, and every time I've really enjoyed myself. It's a great place to take visitors; they always think it's very fun.

It's kitschy, I know, but that's why people appreciate it. Go. Laugh. Have fun.

Drinks are decent. Very juicy/tropical. But they're all served in fun glasses. I've had one shaped like a tiki statue, a (fake) coconut, and a giant elevated punch bowl (the Lava Bowl).

A friend and I shared the Lava Bowl, which is intended for four, and it got us on our way, if you know what I mean. Long, embarrassing straws are included. This definitely isn't the place for people that need to look "cool" while drinking.

If you order the Hurricane, you get to take the glass home as a souvenir. I have two... so far.

A band plays on a real, floating boat in the middle of a pool. I think it's pretty great.

I've only been on week nights and it is never very full, so it's very easy to grab a table and enjoy a couple drinks while listening to the band. There's a dance floor where people tend to gather after sipping one too many juicy Tonga concoctions. Don't they know that sweet drinks make for bad hangovers?

Anyways, last time I was there two lesbians were tearing up the dance floor. It was a pleasure to watch. Even my mom thought so.
author: Adam P.

description:
Do you have cousins from Mississippi coming to town? Well, now you can show them a real San Francisco tropical storm... in a bar!
The Tonga room offers RAIN, yes, real rain, at no extra charge. 
Do you want your out-of-town guests to "ooh" and "ahh" as they suck down on their semi-expensive, extra fruity, practically non alcoholic drinks? Do you want to catch a LIVE cover band (usually on weekend-nights)? Or perhaps you want to take photos of your family in a tropical oasis? Whatever your goal is, make sure to bring more tourists to the Tonga room!
author: Rada I.

description:
when you think tiki lounge you think
scorpion bowl= lots of yummy alcohol and should be stumbling after
when you think of tonga room= yumm that juice as really good im very full lets go hit up a liquor store!

two of us got the bowl for 4 people and nobody had a buzz....shame on you for selling pineapple juice and ice for $32. 

the food was on point tho. hella bomb. got the appetizer sampler and some rice. tummy was very very pleased. bc it was late on a saturday night they had a live band which was kinda dope. there was a $7 cover so no biggie. its a very mature crowd so its nice to know that your parents have a fun place to get down at. 

probably wouldnt go here again expecting to have a fun night of drinking but a nice pre going out mini dinner would be nice here
author: Ashley H.

description: I saw this bar on the Travel channel and had to come here unfortunately my experience was not at all what I had expected. I came here twice, once as a group of 3 right when they opened and the experience was alright. I came back with a group of 7 during a pretty busy Saturday night and the service was terrible. Only 3 of us wanted drinks and there was only two other groups of 2-3 people ordering drinks. It took more than 20 minutes to get our drinks, when the bar tender finally took our order he completely ignored one of the men in my group and would only speak with a female I came with, when he spoke to her he was completely rude, and he didn't actually make the drinks it was premixed. When my friends finally got their drinks they said they tasted horrible and wouldn't finish them. I got the attention of the bar manager, complained to him and he said oh okay and walked away. I will never go here again. The only reason we were in this part of town that night was to go to this bar and it was horrible. If you are only going here for the bar don't waste your time. The atmosphere is interesting but not worth the rudeness of the staff.
author: Sarah W.

description:
I've only tried the dinner buffet at the Tonga Room and the food was very mediocre, both in taste and variety.  They had about 6-7 selections and most of them taste like something you can get at Panda Express.  The price was cheap, but so was the food quality. 

The tropical rain forest theme is pretty cool though.
author: Tom S.

description: So cool! Felt like I travelled back in time to the set of Gilligan's Island! The food was amazing! We shared beef and broccoli, huli huli chicken, and few other items. It was delicious! There was also a live band that played some favorite classics!
author: Skyler B.

description: Hokey but fun. The food is OK and the ambience is wonderful. The music is quite good.  Great place to bring out of towners.
author: Jeanette C.

description:
I came here for a romantic dinner with my gf who was visiting me in S.F. A friend recommended it to me and warned be about the cost, which is about $40 a person for dinner. 

The food is good, but not worth the price. Most of your money is going toward the restaurant atmosphere, which I admit is very sweet. However, the restaurant does charge an extra fee of $7 per person on weekend nights to pay for the musicians. This is the first place I have ever been to that charges for live music, which is pretty ridiculous. 

I would have given it more stars if the prices were lower and there was no outstanding music cover charge.

I read that this place has an all you can eat buffet for $9.50 with the fine print that you have to purchase a drink at the bar. This seems reasonable and will have to check this out in the near future.

They do have a dance floor and like I mentioned before has a really nice atmosphere and would be very good to take a date to. 

*Dress up a little nice (business casual) for this place or you will look out of place.
author: Shahram S.

description:
Promise you won't judge me?

I LOVE this place. It's FUN.

The drinks are stiff, decor kitschy (but in a good way), great cover bands, space for "getting jiggy with it."

You can really let loose here without anyone judging you. Everyone else is acting a fool anyway.

Don't think there should be a cover charge--the inflated prices should cover it, but eh, I had a good time.
author: Ava C.

description:
I swore that I'd have my first martini in an Art Deco bar on a cruise ship (okay, so what if it was the Queen Mary docked in Long Beach).  It was an experience I wanted and enjoyed.  I like kitsch, tiki-kitsch is a good thing.  I've lived in the Bay Area most of my life (except 7 years an ex-pat on the east coast) and had never been to the legendary Tonga.  The threat of demise and some friends visiting from down under prompted a must visit to the Tonga Room.

A+ tiki kitsch = *************
Mai-Tai = ****
Food = *

The drink was strong, whether or not it was perfect I leave to my Aussie friends, who declared it far better than any they'd enjoyed in their recent stop in Hawaii.  It was plenty strong for me.

The food, well, I've had better happy hour buffet food from bars far less swanky than the Tonga.  I found it very "white bread" and some downright strange combos.  Take a look at the dinner menu, it's weird.

Well worth a visit for the experience.  I do lament the possible demise of yet another old SF landmark, but I can't whine so much about it since it took me so long to go in the first place.
author: Donna H.

description:
Great romantic date location. Hear me out, here. 

Great food, fun music, dancing, but still slightly cheesy so there's none of that "uber-romantic restaurant pressure" making you nervous. You know that feeling... Candlelight so dim you can't find your plate (let alone your date), more silverware than you know what to do with, music so soft you feel like you're disturbing the next table if you speak above a whisper. Even worse, the knowledge that this experience is costing you as much as a year of college and that you don't think you even like this person very much. You won't find that here.

My boyfriend took me here on our third date. The menu had great choices for both of us (he's a picky eater), and the simulated thunderstorm made us both laugh and relax into the evening. To top the evening off, ride the cable car down to FIsherman's Wharf - it is almost a stright downhill trip. Stand on the back deck, lean your back against the window and let your date lean on you and look straight out, at the stars that are now directly in front of you.
author: Erica B.

description:
I give it three stars for nostalgia. Years ago, a high school friend of mine decided we'd take our girlfriends out for a night on the town. And if you're a couple of suburban teenagers in 1989, the Tonga Room sounds like a pretty swanky place. We had dinner, watched the rain storm, I think we even danced with our girls as the cheesy band played.

Fast forward to now, when a friend from college invited me to their Happy Hour on a Friday. The place still looked as it did, but I guess its charms are just lost on me now. Tiki drinks and bad Polynesian-style food just aren't enough now.

I do wish someone would have told me 15+ years ago that they didn't card. That could have been helpful.
author: Timothy O.

description:
What do you get when you mix man-made thunderstorms, four mighty hurricane drinks, 15 out-of-towners dancing and two coolkidz dressed up as a sexy cop and mr. too nerdy for halloween? F***loads of fun! 

This explosive cocktail set the stage for my Halloween '06 festivities. Everyone at the Fairmont Hotel was awesome, goofy and played along with our costumes treating us like celebs. The husband and wife band floated back and forth on their artificial pond inducing throngs of cheating businessmen and cougar dance partners to whup it up on the dance floor. The bartender even gave us some Hurricane glasses to remember this magic night.
author: Brady K.

description:
Fruity drinks with maraschino cherries and umbrellas.  That's what I like about the Tonga Room.  I've never eaten a meal there because I'd much rather spend my dining dollar elsewhere.  

Love the thunder and lightening and rain falling every however many minutes on the hour.  

On weekend nights they have a band floating around the lagoon.  I requested the band play "Down Under" from Men At Work, since my visiting friend is Australian.  I told my friend I had requested a song for her.  Much to surprise, the singer announced the dedication and started singing Kylie Minogue's "Love At First Sight".  I  love my friend, but not like that.  She was still thought it was funny, but I'm pretty sure I heard her lock the door to her room later that night.

Tonga Room is definately a sentimental favorite,  and a place to take visitors.  It has an interesting history and I hope it's around for a good long time (although I hear it might not).
author: Kate A.

description:
Yes it's cheesy but any place that has fake rain, a lounge act that gets the older crowds dancing gets total points with me. i think most of the people working there was in their fifties. Plus, the pina coladas were good too. Scored with my date. That's definite plus.

update - 3 years later...
I really didn't appreciate the campiness/cheesiness of this place until visiting it again with my gal pals. The stage is a pirate ship; the people (when were were there) seemed like from the set of Napolean Dynamite; and once again, there were good times all around. Bonus, found out that the entertainment was my friends stepdad and bro-in-law. Nice!
author: Vanessa J.

description:
The atmosphere and experience deserve a solid five star rating. Dock one star for the employees. 

My roommate called to make a reservation for 9:30 on a Saturday, and the man she spoke to told her to simply show up. So we arrived at 9:20, and the hostess told us that they were booked for the evening. She was also very rude about asking what we were there for - dinner or drinks. Blah. My roommate told another hostess what had happened and we were seated about 5 minutes later, no problem. There were a ton of empty tables in there! I don't know WHY the original hostess said that they were booked for the evening. 

Also, my roommate found a tiny black hair in the marshmallow-chocolate volcano thing she was given because it was her birthday. When we informed the waiter of this. he said, "i don't see any hair" and shoved it deep into the marshmallow-chocolate mess so that it couldn't be found! GROSS!

The crowd is a little awkward, by the end of the night everyone is making out/groping on the dance floor. But the cover band is awesome! The drummer is amazing!

If I ever come back to the Tonga room before it closes, I'd probably only come for drinks. Because who doesn't love a good passion fruit pina colada in a fancy cup with an umbrella?!
author: Samantha M.

description:
Las Vegas?
Yes, this is the place for families to drink themselves silly while kids run around destroying things.
author: Daniella B.

description:
THIS PLACE SUCKS.

two stars because everyone needs to go at least once, order a fruity drink with an umbrella, be entertained for about three and a half minutes, wonder why youre still there, and then get the F* out and go to a real bar.
author: N. B. K.

description:
Inexpensiveness of the bar buffet was offset by the high cost of pepto bismol to wash it down.

Happy Hour?  not very...
author: Brian M.

description:
This place is the best tiki bar in the world.  Ultra-fab decor, great drinks, the best happy hour in the city.  If you've never been, you need to go.

The owners are planning on demolishing the Tonga Room to make way to condos.  See this thread here:
http://www.tikiroom.com/tikicentral/bb/viewtopic.php?topic=30385&forum=1&start=45&73&PHPSESSID=13cebf5b0a0641c3f45bbe3e7a12715e
author: Jen H.

description:
I'm all about the food, drink, and Ambience. TONGA HAS IT ALL! 
Great Entertainment, Awesome Food, and Damn Good Drinks.
Not to mention, it's located in the fabulously gorgeous Fairmont Hotel.
Bring someone special, (hell, bring anyone) Guaranteed you'll have a great time! Try the Prawns, they are messy, but delicious! The BEST on the menu. You will not be disappointed. I don't get the review that say this place is "ridiculous" If you are used to meat market night clubs, playing boring ass rap/hip-hop music all night, this place is not for you.
The thunder and rain adds an element of surprise to those who have never been. (SPOILER!) 

Grab a drink, Grab a friend, and dance the night away! Very friendly staff, and fantastic atmosphere!

Need I say more? :)
author: Carlie D.

description:
Such a fun place- makes me sad that it might be done for! The tropical decorations, elaborate drinks, and band floating in the middle of a pool are one of a kind in SF. Though it is a bit over the top, I think that's part of its charm. 

Definitely a good place to start on a Friday or Saturday night- grab a few drinks, people watch (there will inevitably be a birthday party, family reunion, or wedding party happing in some corner), steal some leis, and then move on. Save the tonga room!
author: L B.

description:
I was excited to go to the Tonga Room for happy hour because I celebrated my sixteenth birthday here years (and years) ago. I have nice memories of the live band and the stage rain. 

Happy hour has a buffet from 5-7 for $9.50. I read the Yelp reviews before I got there and the two plate tip was a really good one! In our group you could tell which people had read the same review. There were fried stuffed wontons and eggrolls, some kind of sausage dip, fruit, garlic noodles and fried rice. The wontons and eggrolls were good as well as the sausage dip and fruit. I thought the noodles were a bit soggy and didn't taste like much. They also had wakame salad which is pretty expensive at asian supermarkets. I thought I'd be clever and fill up on that to get my money's worth. I probably ate 1000% of my sodium intake for the day in one sitting...stupid. All in all, I thought the buffet was just okay. I do not think I would get the buffet again.

The atmosphere is pretty laid back with the Hawaiian music in the background and the occasional indoor monsoon. It's a nice place to relax after work, but given my experience with the buffet, I don't know if I would try the restaurant now.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
one of the coolest places ever . i wish i was shipwrecked at the fairmont hotel for the rest of my friggin life. I saw air checking in to the hotel while i was there.so rad bc air is the bomb diggy thought you knew


anyhoo

tonga room happy hour is genius. you get grup ass drinks plus all you can consume yummy yum yums buffet of finger foods .nice staff. the rain every half hour is so dope.

i love you tonga room ,i love you like a fat kid loves cake

holler
author: Lauren V.

description:
I love the Tonga Room!

Great decore, love the rain forest, floating cover band, strong Mai Tais and great food.
This is where I go to indulge and pretend to be rich. :)
author: Larry J.

description:
Oh, great Tiki spirits! Hear my prayer.

I summon you to preserve and protect the Tonga Room. Let the flood of tasty Mai-Tais continue unabated by skeptical fashionistas who know not the value of authentic Polynesian kitsch. Cast your mighty shadows over the simulated tropical rainstorm! Reward hoteliers who dare to convert their indoor pools into a temple for happy hour frolics. 

Oh, omnipotent Tiki gods, show the Tonga room chefs the way to making food as sumptuous as the cocktails. Spare not the spices for making it slightly less bland!

Great Tiki spirits, we few San Franciscans with a whimsical sense of humor and need for exotic drinks salute you!
author: Christian R.

description:
Tonga is a novelty of sorts meant for tourist, out of town business folks who think the Tender-Nob is too shady of an area to drink in and locals who are feeling a bit rich on a given night.

The place gets insanely busy and you're better off getting a table with a hostess rather than waiting at the bar long enough that the previous drink already wore off while surrounded by national sales reps from Omaha in bad suits. Get ready though, each drink will cost you at least $10 and will come in a container reminiscent of the Disneyland Tiki Tiki Room.

Meanwhile the dcor hasn't really changed much over the past few decades, they still have a stage the "floats" out to the middle of a pool where a live cover band performs and the dance floor is made to look like the deck of a ship, meanwhile there is pseudo bamboo and thatch all over the place, the whole package gives you the feel of being in some setting for a classic Rat pack flick.

The big upside of the place is their "happy hour" yeah it sounds cheesy but they lay out a spread that sort of helps compensate for the $10 drink you'll be sucking down... well so would simply sticking that tiki mug into your back-pack/messenger bag/purse but that would be illegal
author: Keith A.

description: This is a great restaurant, the decor is amazing, food is average, drinks pack a wallop! Overall a very good tiki restaurant. If you are a tiki enthusiast, then you must go.
author: JB B.

description:
Crackle, crackle... "Is that thunder?" I say.  Sure enough, this kitchy bar is complete with piped thunder and rain falling from the ceiling above the lagoon.  This, along with the floating live music and a mai tai in a cocconut, made for a great mood.

One warning: the $5 "entertainment charge" after 8 pm when the live music comes on.  The drinks are already expensive, this hardly seems necessary.
author: Adam W.

description:
The Tonga Room is a national treasure. Sadly, it is usually populated only with tourists and guests of the Fairmont, but I highly encourage  locals to get in on the action. 

The Tonga Room is like Disneyland for adults. Get a big fruity drink with an umbrella, enjoy the intermittent tropical storm, and get down to the rockin' cover band floating on a barge in the middle of the lagoon. To boot, their drinks are no more expensive than your typical bar/club in SF (which is a pleasant surprise for the Fairmont).

They also have a fantastic selection of fruity mocktails for pregnant and dry people, so you don't have to look like Debbie Downer with your  Sprite while everyone else is slurping down a Lava Bowl.
author: rachel m.

description:
See Tonga Room Fairmont Hotel
http://www.yelp.com/biz/8EqKyEVK5y1PAVOGx4gHjw
author: Deb N.

description:
I recommend  going here for happy hour from 5-7pm where you can indulge yourself in the happy hour buffett for $8 and induylge yourself in 
Fruity little drinks which can also make you feel sick if you drink to many.

It was either those fruity drinks or the 2 bottles of patron  I finished with my friend ,well technically  1 small one which probably equals a pint and then we started on another after 4am. How come you always come up with these supposed great Ideas when your already drunk.

1 happy hour + 2 bottles of patron = sick for 3 days ..Damn sure not as  as young as I used to be LOL

But I still will go back just not right away and I think I will leave the patron out of the equation
author: Kim R.

description: LOOOVE the Tonga Room!  My friend took me for a surprise birthday dinner here and we had a fabulous time.  It's like a classier version of Disney's Tiki Tiki Room.  If you're looking for a trendy, upbeat spot, this may not be for you.  But if you want to go somewhere different for dinner and a few drinks, then you should definitely give the Tonga Room a try.
author: Ashley B.

description: Okay it's super cheesy, but that's part of this place's charm. The live band on the boat in the middle of the pool, the waterfalls, and rain. It's all so over the top but that's the best part of this place. The drinks are pricy but good. Sometimes there's a cover, which isn't worth it. Come on the off days if you have a hankering for some kind of tropical drink and you're feelin' the  tiki kitsch vibe. I haven't had the food here at all but if I had to make a guess I would guess overpriced...
author: Kimi W.

description:
If I'd been sober it would have been even less stars, but I'm beginning to think that I should pound a few scorpions and hit up the Tiki Room at Disneyland for just as much fun.

Seriously, what is this place?  Why would they have such an extravagantly bizarre bar inside such a plush hotel?  When the band began playing, I felt like they were traveling closer and closer to me across the pool in the middle of the room, and people, it wasn't the booze talking.  The stage moves out into the middle of the pool during the show.

If you like tropical drinks, this is the place for you.  But just ask Jay H, your hurricane tastes better in your mouth than on your crotch.

Just like Disneyland, once you grow up (or sober up in my case) the appeal wears off.  So sad...
author: Tempe M.

description: Fun and quirky; casual dress although the fairmont hotel is quite formal..be sure to take a stroll through the hotel before or after.  A cool bar for a quick drink; so many other places to eat in SF, so I'd recommend just drinks here.
author: M W.

description:
This place is so tacky and over priced. 

First you pay $10 if you come on a Fri or Sat night. 
Then you order a drink for $18 and you finish it in two gulps. You stare into the glass and wonder what happened to my drink? There is nothing left because the drink was mainly shaved ice.What a bummer it was when I saw my glass empty.

While realizing my drink was gone I was soon got distracted by a man in a floating on a boat in the middle of a rain storm. Where could I be? In the jungle of a tropical island? No, in the Fairmont hotel. OK? That's why I used the word tacky.

Hope I didn't offend anyone who actually liked the floating  mysterious band. Lol
author: Kelli H.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco over thirty years now and I have visited the Tonga Room several times during those years.  It's always been a fun
place, usually chosen for a work get together, farewell party, or celebration of some kind.  It's always been amusing to enter the "other world" atmosphere of the rain forest, don leis, and be transported to 
the South Pacific, far from the clang of cable cars on California Street.

It mattered not that the food and drinks were a little pricey, we were always there for a party and the occasional splurge was fine.  We were worth it.  We left full and happy and usually danced a bit, and that, after all, is what the Tonga Room is about.

I was surprised last night when my son's girlfriend chose the Tonga Room as the place for his 24th birthday celebration.  Except for me, 64-years-old, the other seven guests were under 28 ( nice of them to include the gal who endured labor to deliver the 9 pound eight ounce boy!! ).  We had a great time.  They shared the Scorpion for four, I had a Zombie - fun drinks, the kind you see in Hawaii and they were pretty tasty, no more expensive than what you find anywhere in San Francisco at a hotel bar.  The food was definitely a bit pricey but it was pretty good.  I thought my Kahlua pork kau kau was the tastiest with slow braised pork, onions, shiitake mushrooms, baby spinach and rich broth ( $28 ).  The Mongolion beef tenderloin at $26 was like any you'd get at a decent Chinese restaurant.  Granted, most of the dishes would have easily served two diners..as they forewarned in the front of the menu.  There was plenty left over to take home.

The appetizer platter for two at $25 was nice with an assortment that included Tonga's Aloha pork ribs, shiitake egg rolls, pot stickers, flatbread with macadamia nut spread and jumbo coconut prawns.  

Only the birthday boy opted for dessert since it was complimentary - a Tonga Volcano - passion fruit mousse wrapped in meringue with a molten raspberry center, served flaming.  It was $10 on the menu and I almost rethought the whole dessert thing.  I am a passion fruit addict.  Thankfully, he did share with his mother and it was superb.

The band was decent and the dance floor was jumping.  They played a whole litany of songs that were multigenerational so that, even I, was dancing in my seat.  

OK, so maybe, the thunder and lightning and rainfall are a little hokey, but it was great fun.  Nice to do something like that once in awhile.  We get far too jaded in this life!!!
author: Carmen H.

description:
I'm a fan of all things tiki, so I absolutely loved the decor. I've wanted to got here for a few years, and we finally moved to the area so went for an anniversary.

We had a reservation, and were seated promptly. The hostess said happy anniversary. Our waiter seemed a little frazzled though. It was a Wednesday at 8:30 and I think more people showed up late for dinner than they were expecting. He took our drink order and then disappeared for quite a while. When he showed up again he took someone's order who arrived 10 minutes after us. A busser saw me put my arm up like "what the hell" so he tried to take our order. So basically, our waiter sucked and was inattentive, but the busser was super friendly and kept stopping by to make sure that we were happy. He made up for the waiter.

We ordered 4 appetizers instead of full meals. The green papaya salad was basically a $16 plate of cole slaw, so not stoked on that. The poke was good, but small. Mushroom eggrolls were good, as was the vegetable tempura. Overall, if I was just rating food, this would probably get a 2.5. I would only go back for the drinks, which while pricey, definitely had a good amount of liquor in them, so you get what you pay for.

I also agree with everyone else that adding a cover charge for music to your bill when you already spent almost $100 on dinner and drinks should be waived. The band was really talented though, so I see why they charge a cover for at least people in the bar. It would be cool if they had a steel drum band instead of a cover band playing Enrique Iglesias, but they were still good.

Also nice, they brought out a flaming volcano thing for dessert since it was our anniversary. Nice touch.

I give them 4 stars for drinks and ambiance. I would definitely go back, just not to eat.
author: Amber K.

description: This touristy/Disney-esque restaurant hidden in The Fairmont Hotel was just that, touristy and Disney-esque. Our server barely spoke English and therefore didn't understand our order. Drinks, dinner, and dessert were all disappointing, the food was really bad. It was fun to explore the hotel a bit and the decor was unique with a kitchy band on a boat but seriously, this is San Francisco and the food was not up to par.
author: Eliz M.

description:
First things first:  DO NOT VISIT THE TONGA ROOM ANY OTHER TIME THAN HAPPY HOUR!

Unless of course you're independently wealthy and enjoy overpriced crap-ass food and service in a room that could have been used as a set on Gilligan's Island.

But Happy Hour (5-7pm) is worth it.  The usually outrageously priced drinks are somewhat affordable ($7.50 for a Bora Bora Horror, $13 for the Lava Bowl for 2).  There is an all-you-can-eat "Polynesian buffet" (i.e. greasy Chinese food you could buy by the frozen bag at Costco) for $8 a person.  And it rains...every 30 minutes like clockwork.  

I usually avoid the buffet unless I've had one too many mai tais and need to soak up the alcohol.  I concentrate, instead, on the fruity rum drinks that are always served with the requisite pineapple wedge and little paper parasol, sometimes in a festive glass or bowl for 2.  And did I mention the rain?  It's the star attraction.

Don't stay for dinner unless you want almost unbelieveably overpriced food and a $5 per person "entertainment charge" for the floating band.  Do soak up the island atmosphere at happy hour while downing a Tonga Tart or two and enjoying an evening rainstorm with some out of town guests.
author: Jon B.

description:
Where's the kanoe?  Wow.  It rains in here too!

This place makes you feel like you're in a sing-along from the Jungle Book.  It's great after you have a little bit of punch and you start singing along with the hired entertainment to their rendition of Gloria Estefan's "The Rhythm is Gonna Getcha."

There was a wedding reception or something going on in the back part and a few painfully pregnant women were making me feel uncomfortable...but their kids were cute as they tore up the dance floor.

Be ready for a Disney-esque experience.
author: Susan C.

description:
To have a bar like this located in the bowls of the posh Fairont Hotel atop Nob Hill is a brilliant twist of irony. The clientele is straight from the airport, sprinkiled with a few locals there simply for the amusing eye candy. The drinks are totally overpriced, but then again, never put a price tag on fun. 

A floating band announced by a thundering rainstorm? Lighten up, this is a classic.
author: Tim F.

description:
Consider filing it under so bad that it's just bad.  Come on, an indoor "thunderstorm," in front of the "buffet" during happy hour with scary looking egg rolls.   I was expecting the waitstaff to break into song - tunes from South Pacific.

And it's just so weird if you stay in the Fairmont, which is an elegant hotel.  Also, I think shared drinks in bowls with straws and fans are kind of yucky, but I respect that you might think otherwise.
author: EE S.

description:
If this was the Tonga Room of the '80s I would be rating it higher. Or maybe then I just didn't know any better.

PROS:
- Pretty cool decor.
- They finally took the big TV out of the bar and put in some banquet seating.

CONS:
- The decor was much cooler before the recent "renovation." I really don't want to see the pipes the rain falls from. Why the hell did they take out all the faux foliage that used to hide them? And what is that fabric they put on the walls? It looks like a southwestern print! Definitely not polynesian.
- The drinks are disgusting blends of low-quality spirits and probably canned fruit juices.
- The prices (except during happy hour) are ridiculous for the quality (or lack thereof)
- The service. I've been to the Tonga Room at least a dozen times in my life and can't remember one time when the service has been quick and friendly. The waitresses are surly, slow, and often screw up the order. They also conveniently let you sit with an empty glass for 30 minutes and show up just moments after happy hour has expired to ask what else you'd like.
- The band is cheesy and the song choices are completely inappropriate for a "tiki" bar. 
- The food is overpriced and bland.

I'm giving the Tonga Room three stars for the fact that it has survived this long and still makes a nice place to take visitors just for the rain storm and happy hour. But seriously, I can't give more than that for a place where the food, drinks, prices, and service are so bad!
author: Jennifer E.

description: Dreadful chemical-tasting cocktails, horrendous food and live music that takes itself waaaaay too seriously considering the surroundings. Avoid.
author: Doug B.

description:
A bit high priced for the taste and service. 

I went to the Tonga Room on a Thurs. night.  First impressions was "cool atmosphere" there is a pool of water right in the middle of the restaurant.  On that pool of water was a boat holding the band members who played cover music throughout the evening.  The band sounded great and sang well.  Every once in a while they would take a break, the boat would retract from the center of the pool and it would rain.  The rain was awesome! 

On to the service and food.  The service was ok nothing too special.  

The food was not worth the price.  I ordered some type of seafood curry with a Mai Tai drink.  The seafood dish looked and tasted like seafood chow-mein something I would not have ordered.  The drink was strong and delightful.  

When we received our check the Tonga Room charged us each a  $5.00 cover charge.  This was a bit surprising as we weren't expecting it.  With the food, 1 drink, cover charge, tax and tip my meal totaled $60.00 - much more than I believe it was worth.  The band was great, but I went there for the food.
author: Hope D.

description:
Went during the $9.50 happy hour buffet.   No wonder its so cheap, food kinda sucks. 

Its not really cheap when you think about it since you already have to pay at least $12 for drinks in addition to the price for sucky appetizer food.  

Appetizers: shrimp chips, fried wontons (not sure what the filling was - maybe chicken, maybe shrimp), veggie egg rolls, veggie sticky rice, veggie chow mein, and fruit salad (strawberries, cantaloupe, honey dew, and grapes). 

I know it shouldn't necessarily hold it against them. It wasn't like it was unedible.  It was okay, but you get hella sick of the food. 

I just would've expected something more from the Fairmont. 

The cocktails drinks are okay. Most of them consisted of rum, which I hate so I guess I'm biased and can't rate appropriately in that area. 

Service is good. Not amazing, but not bad. 

Based on the happy hour, I wouldn't go here again. Also, I bet the regular dinner is wayyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy out of my price range. Their liquor shots are $15. WTF!
author: Dorothy N.

description:
A magical experience for Tiki-lovers, I enjoy the fake rainstorm and special effects with full knowledge that I'm drinking the most pricey liquids in town, I just don't care.

I've loved Tiki bars since I was a kid and been to a ton of them.

This is the only one I've ever been to that almost transcends Tiki into a high class experience and dare I say even a good place to take a date?

Not the best restaurant in town, but I was pleasantly surprised by the food.
author: Victoria B.

description:
Hil. Ar. I. Ous.

How could anyone not love this place? Take any dive bar you've ever been to and toss a ton of money at it and give it an island theme. That's the Tonga room. It's Trad'R Sam's with money and on crack. The dance floor is a ship (awesome), the band floats on a pool (sweet), there is thunder, lightning, and rain (money), and the crowd is such an odd mix that the fun never ends.

Seriously. I could spend all night here and be totally happy. There are plenty of options for people watching (seriously, from lonely travelers, to the oddest of couples). I came to grab a drink at the bar with a friend and sadly there were no seats (yes, there were that many people there on a Wednesday night at 9pm. so I'm an alky, shut it.) It didn't even matter that I had to stand. On top of the special effects, the decor, and the people, the band plays cheesy music as if it were an awful wedding or every Bar Mitzvah you've ever been to.

No, this is not the most glamorous bar. Yes, some of the people there are a little sad. But how can you not love a bar that wholeheartedly embraces it's kitschy cheesy nature and goes balls out? Seriously, if you don't like this place, who beat you as a child?

If you're ever in the area check it out. You'll never be happier to not take yourself so seriously.
author: Mitchell L.

description: It is sad that I have to give them 2 stars, I have been coming here for a long time, and I love this place, by far the best Tiki bar out there, the atmosphere is fantastic, and up until a month ago I would have given them 5 stars, however they have made some bad changes to several of there menu items that have cheapened the experience and literally left a bad taste in my mouth...first the Salmon... it used to me so delicious with a miso glaze...and wasabi mashed potato's, not it served with very dry rice and the salmon was flat with little flavor. The biggest disappointment is the Lava bowls, they used to be wonderfully presented and made such a great first impression when brought to the table with fresh fruit such as pineapple and cherries, and the flavor was sweet, fresh and delicious, they have now went cheap with a light rum, and ginger beer with a few slices of lime floating in it, the taste is bitter, and incredibly acidic...so so sad...
author: Steven D.

description: A must-love for it's quirky novelty! The experience is about the place itself, not the quality of music or even the food. Order a drink and soak in the origional "tiki room!"
author: Robynne W.

description:
Upon hearing that this place would potentially be closing, my girlfriend and I went here last night. It was great! We went at about 6 for Happy Hour and the buffet. 
     The drinks were good (my girlfriend's Mai Tai was rather strong) and my Lava Flow was delicious (I ordered it even though it wasn't one of the Happy Hour drinks - well worth it!). We then moved on to a couple of piña coladas which were delicious and, what's more, were served promptly.
And the food? Well we were a tad reluctant to go after reading the reviews on here that told of sub-par food and poor service. I'm sorry but they're wrong. The food is rather good, especially at the buffet prices. I shall go here in the future and see what the full-priced fare is like. I am sure it will be pretty good.
     The reason this is my first review is because I though it was of the utmost importance to convey to other yelp! users that this place is AWESOME. Who wouldn't like thunder, lighting, and torrential downpours every 20-30 minutes? Who wouldn't like tacky island music being played by a band on a floating stage in a 'lagoon'? I know I do and I also know that I know how to have a good time. Please be your own judge and check it out for yourself. Go there and have a great time. It's great.
author: Luke H.

description:
We had heard so much about how busy the Tonga room would be, we made plans to be there early on a Sunday to beat the crowds.  Maybe the crowds got lost; maybe we beat them to death; all I know is the Tonga room was dead.  I'll be fair, we got there right when they opened and it was a Sunday but we were there about 2 hours and we were the only people in the place the whole time.  

The decor was... wow!  A boat in the middle of the pool where a band plays... not that we saw it.  Yes, it rained indoors and it was fun.  The partial pirate ship inside was also cool.  

The thing is, for it being utterly dead, did we really have to get seated at the end nearest the door.   There were seats in huts and on the ship, there was plenty to look at and enjoy but we were seated so far away from it all it was hard to see any of it.  No music to speak of, I'm sure there was but that tells you just how meh it was.  

The drinks were good, so that's a plus, I was definitely a little too happy on my way home but that's as much the fault of the limited food options - read no options for veggies.  

I'm giving three stars; this is a place you have to see because it is a classic, but maybe try to be there when other people are around for a more pleasurable experience.  Enjoy your drinks, they're well made even though they're slow.  I hate to say it but based on what I saw, I'm not that surprised there's talk of closing it.  It's not that I don't think it used to be great or could be great again, but what I saw sure could use some improvement.
author: siouxzi r.

description: Went here with a group for my 24th birthday, what a blast! This is my kind of place. First of all, it's located inside the super elegant Fairmont Hotel. Second, it's a tiki-bar inspired atmosphere! The food was pretty good, island style things, and I got to drink mai-tai's out of a coconut! And the best part was they have a floating band playing in a river in the middle of the restaurant and they sang happy birthday to me! So cool.
author: Lianna S.

description: I like the Tonga room...I wouldn't eat there, but it has an interesting atmosphere for a cocktail and definitely is not your average neighborhood bar.
author: Amanda S.

description:
This is a good place to have a drink after a dinner or before you are going on a drinking roll as this will be your first and warm-up stop. The crowd seems to be on the somewhat business casual as well as family sides. Not a party crowd that's for sure. And it starts to get busy around 10pm.

Music is the oldies (60s and 70s) and I just don't understand why all Hawaiian restaurants (including Roy's) and everywhere in Hawaii always play "Somewhere Over the Rainbow/What a Wonderful World"? No matter how much I love this song it gets old when you hear it all the time...

Drinks are okay. I had the Hurricane and they put lots of rum in it! :) Good buzz!
author: T L.

description: Taking this place for what it is - a tiki bar - you will love it! It's funky and fun. The floating band was GREAT. The drinks was delicious and the atmosphere was playful. There were many couples dancing on the dance floor and the crowd was a good mix of young adults and more mature. There was a $7 cover charge the night we went (because of the band I presume) but it was worth it!
author: Karen C.

description: Such a fun atmosphere! Went there for the first time over the weekend and I had a blast jammin to the great band and eating a different yet yummy dinner :) ... The lava flow drink was pretty and great for two people but it was a tad bit strong, not complaining though because it was worth the money !!!!
author: Mary B.

description: Such a neat, random experience, but a bit overpriced.  My favorite thing is to take someone where without telling them anything about the place in advance.  My friend started cracking up when it randomly started raining fifteen minutes into our meal.
author: Mike G.

description:
I like their happy hour where you can get like a drink and pay for just $7.00 or so for an endless buffet of appetizers. I like also how you feel like you are in a jungle and the rainforesty sounds surge every so often with a fine mist spray. 

If you want to get away from the city but can't, this place is a nice quaint get away for the evening...
author: Mashimaro M.

description:
I had been to the Venetian Room, but had never heard of the Tonga Room until Deb N. organized a West Coast Swing dance trip to this delightful step back in time (aside from the overpriced drinks). 

I've read some other reviews about this place, and they seem to have a whiff of disdain for people honestly enjoying themselves. I definitely DO NOT roll this way, and like to see people having a good time without endangering themselves or annoying others.

I revel in the tiki landscape, the periodic rainfall, the band on the boat, the netting and rattan decor. Aside from the nightmare of parking in the vicinity, I enjoyed myself very much here, and would love to go back! The only drawback I noticed is that there's a trek to the restroom.
author: Marja M.

description:
The king of all tiki bars!

I have a friend who is OBSESSED with Mai Tai's. So of course when he came to SF for a visit, we HAD to stop here--by his orders! I'm not a huge fan of hotel bars but this one definitely gets style points.

I've never seen a theme bar be SO HARDCORE. There are coconut looking glasses, straw huts, ship masts, and even a floating stage for the band that moves and looks like a boat! There's even fake rain that occurs (only over the water area) every now and then!

This bar would be such a great place for a Yelp event--albeit an insanely hungover-from-drinking-so-many-sweet-drinks event.

Downsides: It's way out there! Totally bus-able/cab-able but out there, in the Fairmont Hotel. Also, since it's a hotel bar, most of the patrons are hotel patrons or people who just got out of a wedding in the hotel. Okay so now imagine the wedding crowd again, that's sort of how the music is like too. Entertaining but in a PG-mom-would-approve sort of way. It's a bummer because the space is huge and it's really wonderful ambiance (in a cheeeeesy way).

Also, not a downside but there is a $5 entertainment charge per person at night IF you sit at a table. Understandable since there is a live band. Save yourself the money if you stand/sit at the bar.
author: Cindy P.

description:
I've celebrated two birthdays here. I'm a big fan of tiki culture, and walking into this place doesn't disappoint. The first visit, we sat in the bar area and had cocktails, which are big and come in pineapple shells and decorated in fruit. Delicious.
The second year we decided to have dinner and cocktails. The menu is pretty boring and nothing to go there for, except the coconut broth, which I loved.
This place looks great and the drinks are good. Everything is overpriced and it's just petty to charge a fee for a band that plays Bee Gees covers.  It's a tiki lounge, where's the Don Ho?
author: Jennifer M.

description: Kitschy is not the word!  A spoof of a polynesian tiki bar (don't miss the periodic thunder, flashing lights and manufactured rain showers).  Service was slow and the food was OK (I had the Thai basil curry with prawns) with good portions.  I expected more from the Fairmount . . .
author: Stephen M.

description:
The Tonga Room and Hurricane Bar is a fun interesting setting, complete with its own  lake (where an ok cover band plays on a boat), and off and on (man made) thunder and rain showers.
It's an attractive spot, that sits up a steep hill in the heart of SF, inside of the Fairmont Hotel.
This was my second visit there in a year....But it was not overly pleasant.
They force you to start a tab, which means you have to give a credit card, even if you want to pay cash.
There is a $7 per person cover added to your bill if you are not staying at the hotel.
I can live with all of that, but what I can't live with is waiting 30 minutes for my second bottle of beer.
There was one elderly waitress in the vicinity, and she disappeared for long periods of time.
About 20 minutes after I ordered a second beer for my husband, I stopped her and reminded her about the missing order.
Her answer?...."It's on the way!"
Ten minutes later, it showed up.
I like the Tonga Room in general, but I'll think twice about going there if I want more than one beer.
author: chinesegirlinLA c.

description:
Ok, I have to admit, I'm only talking about the Happy Hour. I never actually ate here when it was not Happy Hour. So, I can't say anything about the price of the food, though I can assume it's a bit pricey. 
Anyway, the Happy Hour is awesome!! From 5-7pm Monday - Friday. You can have all-you-can-eat buffet for less than 10 dollars, when drinking at least 1 drink. The food is a bit greasy, but tasty. 
First time I went here was with a group of about 15 people, with no reservation, and the staff was happy to have us in. It was pretty full, but they did not complain about a big group without reservation. Cocktails are great and cheap (10 dollars regular price, 7 dollars Happy Hour price), and they are big. Staff is funny and friendly. 

The rainstorms are cool : ) Especially when you go there with a friend who's already drunk and had never been there (so doesn't know what's going on). 

I love this place, it might not be the first restaurant/bar to think of going, since it's in a hotel and most hotel bars just don't work. But this one is really worth the steep hill you have to climb before getting there, besides that, if you climb that hill, you burn calories that you can later on gain again by drinking the delicious cocktails (win-win situation).
author: Helen D.

description:
Ok, you caught me.  I like some kitchy stuff here and there.

This place is the ultimate in 'complely rediculous.'  They have a cool happy hour buffet that is something like $13 a person (I think).  There is also a 'scorpion bowl' that comes with four straws and tastes like sweet turpentine. (sp?)
author: Thadd L.

description:
CHEESE! but you have to be ready for it.  I read through the reviews and I had been warned but I HAD to go check it out!

Decor was definitely fake polynesian/tiki/straw and wood "chic".  The thunder lightning with "rain" was a little amusing. So, that's their gimmick! Oh well... 

As for the food.... hhhmmmmm.... what can I say?  They served Cheese (literally) haha.  The eggrolls were not bad (at least they were not soggy), the crab rangoon was underwhelming, the short ribs were okay (meaning they were not dry as a bone and had a ltitle meat on them).  the stir fry was a regular stir fry. 

So, would I go back?  Unlikely.  Was it worth it?  Probably not.
author: H. Q.

description:
Quite possibly one of the worst dining experiences I've ever had in San Francisco. Terrible. I would give it zero stars but I can't, so I'll award 1 star for the ridiculous tropical rainstorm in the middle of the dining area.

The decor and feel of this place makes you feel like you're eating at the restaurant inside the Pirates of the Carribean ride at Disneyland...except you're not. You're at the Fairmont Hotel at the peak of Nob Hill. You should expect and probably deserve more than this if you're hanging out around here in time for dinner.

I went with a group of 12 people, the majority of which were - not surprisingly - tourists (they were family friends). The menu consisted of a lot of americanized chinese food, which was so unoriginal in both selection and so bland in taste, it puts PF Changs or maybe even Panda Express to shame. For two or three times the price!

The service was slow, the waiter didn't understand English and could not for the life him understand that his own restaurant offered more than one kind of tea. He ended up going into the back room and bringing out the cardboard wholesale box of all the varieties and yelled "pick one, pick one, pick one" until we picked one.

I'm not one for writing bad reviews, especially when on Yelp, but in this case I just had to. Extremely dissapointing.
author: Tolga E.

description:
It's like a tropical Disneyland in here, complete with floating boats and what not.  Nice time out.  But boy was I looking forward to drinking the b-double o-z-e from a bowl.  Unfortunately all of the rum drinks I ordered tasted pooey!  I heart rum too!  What up with that?

P.S. Pay that one price to get all the apps you can eat.  Love those little pork sticky bun thingys!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
It's $9.50 for the happy hour buffet.  Yesterday, the options were:

*Shrimp chips with sauce
*Fresh fruit (pineapple, grapes, cantaloupe, honeydew) with pina colada sauce
*Fried won tons with two sauces
*Kahlua pork pupusas
*Butter noodles with Kahlua pork
*Rice

Not bad.  Sorta unhealthy, sloppy happy hour fare.  They give you tiny, tiny plates, so just grab and fill up like four of 'em before you sit yourself back down to sip your mai tai.  

But it's cheap, there's lotsa room for big groups, and that pool with the boat and the thunderstorm effect has been amusing me forever.
author: Kimberly Q.

description: Cool-looking place, but the drinks weren't that good (the pina colada I had was awful) and outrageously expensive
author: Mollie T.

description: The Tonga Room far exceeded my expectations. I only went there because I was staying at the Fairmont and I had heard there was a Tiki bar/restaurant there, and I'm a sucker for kitsch. Well, this place is kitsch done right!
