A Tiki bar can easily go awry and just come off as old and dank, but the Tonga Room is big and airy, the food was great (especially the soba noodle salad and the winter squash curry!), the drinks were strong, and the band was lounge-a-licious (and they played on a floating raft stage in the middle of a pool!). I had so much fun there I'll go back the next time I'm in San Francisco even if I'm not staying at the Fairmont, but I'll probably break down and pay the $5 to take the trolly up that hill!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Great ambiance, but it didn't make up for the overpriced food, rude staff and dirty tableware...

We made reservations. When we arrived and gave our info, the maitre'd was rude, telling us to move aside while hotel guests who arrived AFTER us (with no reservation) were ushered ahead (and told they didn't have to pay the cover). We were required to sit and wait for several minutes before a server finally led us to our table, even though it wasn't very busy at the time (our dinner reservations were for 9pm) We asked to be moved to an empty table beside the water, and the server left to check if that was ok, but never came back. Some people that walked in several minutes later were seated there.

Our waiter was very personable and prompt, but we found red lipstick marks on the 'clean' water glasses. There was a $7 pp cover charge, which was a little ridiculous as we were there for dinner, (and spending more than just drinks in the bar) and couldn't even see the band from our little table in the rear of the restaurant. The cover applies if you're there after the band starts at 8pm, regardless of what time you arrive. The prices seemed so high, we ended up ordering only light appetizers and two large lava bowl drinks to share between the 4 of us,  and the bill still came to $160 before tip. AND we left hungry.
While the lava drinks were great, the food we got was nothing to write home about, certainly not worth the money ($27 for an Tonga appetizer platter for two..two prawns, two mini spring rolls, two ribs, 2 or 3 bits of tempura, 2 small chicken satay sticks...$15 for a small plate of calamari)

Overall, the experience was very disappointing. The food is ridiculously overpriced. I wouldn't recommend it. Many better places to eat..ie. Leopolds in Russian Hill. Wish we'd just stopped by for a drink. Oh well, at least I can say I've been to a tiki bar, I guess...
author: M C.

description:
Imagine Al Czervik (Rodney Dangerfield from Caddyshack) owned a tiki bar.  THIS is exactly what it would be.  Exactly.  

It can be fun -- if you suspend a lot of disbelief.

And, yes, they do serve Scorpion bowls, which will jumpstart said suspension...
author: Tim G.

description: The drinks are expensive but you have to pay for those damn paper umbrellas somehow.  Was here with a friend for the rainshow when we somehow got singled out in their happy birthday dedication to Doris.  We were like the youngest people in the joint and they thought one of us was named Doris?!?!?  It was pretty funny.  Take your parents or out of towners here and enjoy a great laugh.
author: Anna L.

description:
It's really a two-and-a-half, but I settled for two to try and discourage people from going there. Both stars are for the decor - even though it's too old and shaggy and needs renovation. I like the original idea that was put into it, but nowadays...the food is WAY overpriced and you find nicer quality at Panda Express. The servers are rude and impatient...ours couldn't speak English...

If you'd still like to visit the place, go late at night  - it's more fun to just go there for drinks.
author: Kate P.

description:
Came here after my Bday dinner to have drinks and take in the kitchie atmosphere.  You need to cut thru the Fairmont lobby to get here.  There was a $5 cover after 8pm and a one drink minimum per person.  The drinks were in the $9 range.  
The kareoke quality band plays in the center of the water pond on a boat and there is water rain effects every time they float in or out.
The crowd was touristy and abit on the older side as well.  Casual dress.
author: Julie G.

description:
A really fun place to bring your family or a group of friends from out of town. The crowd, anytime I've ever been, is pretty non-existant, a few people from the Farimont Hotel it is located within, but usually not much more. Despite the mediocre crowd factor, the place is fun. 

Though I'm not really wowed by the Tonga Room, and it's sort of laughable with its camp-factor,  I like to bring people from out of town here.

If you go later in the evening, you can sit by the giant pool they have in the middle of the room upon which it rains every 10 minutes or so. And a band floats in a little tiki hut in the center of the pool...like I said, a fun place! Cheezy, but fun.
author: Sophie D.

description:
Quite honestly one of the most hilarious times I have ever had out. Hawaiian-shirt-wearing waiters, bamboo everywhere, faux monsoons, a canal (in the Fairmont?!), a band on a boat...what's not to love? The kitsch factor was intense. 

Word to the 20-somethings. You will be the youngest ones there. You will be so young that you will potentially feel strange. Do not fear! Embrace the awkwardness and you'll (literally) be the life of the party. 

Caveat: Drinks stop being served at midnight. Why? I have no idea.
author: Madeline N.

description:
I've been here many times over the years and it's always fun! I've taken friends from Australia to London here, everyone likes it!
Great vintage tiki atmosphere, which is really rare these days. Especially over seas. It always takes Europeans to appreciate what we take for granted.  
The drinks are always pretty consistently great!! And the service not bad. If your nice to them you'll get it back. 
For everyone complaining about the food/ happy hour. You're going to a BAR. You're ordering food, do you expect it to be a gourmet meal??
This is a place to go drink and have fun!
author: O. S.

description:
After being in this place for about an hour I thought I was in Vegas.  It could of been a number of things, but here are a few;

-The fake rain
-The floating barge
-The karoke band who were all in their 50's
-The dance floor that was a ship

I was bummed to walk out and find myself not on the strip and back to reality.

The food was okay, nothing to spectacular.  One of my co-workers told me she had her high school prom there.  When she said that, it all made sense.
author: Nacho C.

description:
This could be THE cutest place EVER!  I had a large party resie, $79 pre-fixed menu, everything shared family style.  Was it worth $79...eh' not really, but you do get tons of food, no ones gonna' leave hungry guaranteed, maybe a little more broke...(shrugging shoulders)..trade offs. The food was nothing to write home about, not even the lobster which i was disappointed with, I did like the beef filet tho'.  Our server David was very accommodating and sweet, he made sure I got everything I needed on my birthday especially my very own dessert with my name written in chocolate sauce surrounding a marshmallow volcano filled with cakey tarty goodness!  

So....the Fairmont Bucks, parking $5 every 20 minutes, no happy ending, it's extra.  We ended up  parking up the street at the Masonic Garage for $15.  It took us 15 minutes to exit the garage because no one wanted to pay $50 everywhere else and who can blame them.  After 8pm if your still in the Tonga Room an $8 charge per person is added on to your bill because that's when the band comes out performing on a floating stage on water.  Couples get up to dance while it intermittently rains.  Its tons of fun but you pay for the ambiance.  I recommend it if you have money to blow and you just want to experience something different or just go for drinks and dancing.  I had fun, but I'm corny like that...; )
author: Gily J.

description:
As a resident of Hawaii I wasn't expecting much if anything from this place... It's suposto be Tiki theme and it delivers on all fronts. 
1. The decor 2. The rain every 30mins 3. The drinks

Now here's where it starts to suck...
The drinks: $10+ per a drink is standard operating procedure in SF so that's not what bothers me... it's the damed TASTE. I ordered a "zombie" and boy did it make me feel like one. It tasted like straight jet fuel. I had to order a coke on the side just do mix it.
The buffet:  $7 (or something). Cheap and it tasted that way too... all 5 choices of things.
The service: Non existent. We had a party of 15+ people with our own section on one of the boat things and that was cool but the waiter only came around about once every hour. He would drop off our drinks, then run away, not waiting to take more orders. I once tried to grab my own drinks at the bar and was STOPED by the host person saying I MUST order from our waiter. (because of the "contract"... I $hit you not)

*This is a good place to go if your a tourist in town for a convention or some other work related event where you try to escape your daily misery. Other than that..................
The cover band was really good (2 stars).
author: Brennan M.

description: The cocktails were great and the ambiance was fun! Just a bit of advice, if you sit by the pool be prepared to shout in order to have a conversation due to the floating band. 4 stars for a fun and lively place!
author: Juliet G.

description:
I thought I wandered into a bad episode of Fantasy Island the other night when attending a party at the Tonga Room.  Trust me if tattoo was actually there I would have given this place 2 stars.

Speaking of stars, I think I saw a few more when the bartender handed me my tab.  Seriously, the last time I paid that much for a drink it was in the form of my kidney when I was left for dead in the lobby of the clift hotel.

The kicker in this awful process is that you are accessed a $7 cover fee for a 2nd rate Don Ho cover band.

look boss dee plane, dee plane....!
author: Solbiato S.

description: delightfully cheesy. a classic joint. definitely worth popping in for a tropical libation.
author: Timo R.

description: Fun place to hang out with at this Hawaiian inspire restaurant. The band place in the rain inside the restaurant. Good place for yummy margaritas.
author: Bonnie D.

description:
The Tonga Room is some place all Bay Area people should visit once.  But maybe only once.  

The drinks are over-priced and so are the mediocre appetizers.  The fun kitsch factor was destroyed by the ghetto execution of the tiki flavor.  I'm sure the design was cutting edge 30 or 40 years ago, but serious upkeep is needed as everything seems kind of worn out.  And the "lagoon" where the fake river boat floats out with the washed-up cover band singing horrible  versions of already horrible music punctuated by mock monsoons every so often, is a glorified gym pool.  This sounds way more fabulous than it is.

The crowd is mostly a random mix of hotel wedding guests and tourists working the dance floor after a scorpion or two or three.   

But I am glad I went.  And with friends, a fancy hotel on Nob Hill and a lot of material to poke fun at, how can you not have a good time.
author: Sharon R.

description:
A great tourist place to visit when in SF. The Tonga Room is located in the Fairmont and is a tropical themed restaurant and bar.

We only hung at the bar and had a fun time watching people dance to the live band that played '70s music. The service was great, but the cocktail selection was a bit limited to well drinks or tropical themed drinks.

Overall - a fun place to visit and bring friends from out of town.
author: Sharon C.

description:
We went here for a late dinner once then for happy hour when we stayed at the Fairmont. Food was ok, this is more of a fun athmosphere than a foodie place. It is kind of hokie (sp?) but in a good way, definately where I would take out of towners.

Second time was for happy hour, it was 8 bucks for the buffet plus one drink min. Not bad, lots of food, my fave was only the eggrolls and spareribs which I thought was meaty. The crab rangoon is not good at all, did not try the stir fry and the fruits are ...fruitty
author: Alissa T.

description:
It has been close to a decade since I have been here, but remember it like it was yesterday. I remember being surprised on how portions the size of my finger nails could put me into a food coma. The food was not the greatest....just filling.

If you can, get seated next to the lake, because you get some tropical feelings from it when the fake rain hits and the floating pagoda has the band on it. Very cheesy in the third person, but romantic in the moment.
author: Ray H.

description:
We're drunk off numerous cocktails and wine at dinner, looking for a great place to party and have fun. E Todd hears of a place that has  "pirate theme" with a "band that floats in a plays in a LAGOON!!!". This, of course, is right up our alley, so away we go to the magic land of Tonga. We were not disappointed (at first). The scene was everything we had imagined and more- tiki torches, the lagoon with the band, dancefloor with people getting crazy, loud, fun music....and....NO BOOZE. We practically ran up to the bar to get our drinks and get our party on, and were quickly denied because..."The bar is closed".  "But sir", I impore the bartender, "it's only MIDNIGHT?!". "NO MORE DRINK" he shoots back. Crestfallen and dejected, we leave the oasis, which was just that- an illusion.

Break it down:

-4 stars for existing.

-5 stars for the fact that it's a ridiculously kitschy theme and there's a band that plays on a floating stage in the middle of an indoor lagoon.

-MINUS 4 stars because they stop serving alcohol at MIDNIGHT. That's right, you heard it here, folks. ON A SATURDAY NIGHT. 
WTF!?!?!?

-MINUS 4 stars because the lame-duck manager at the front could offer me no explanation of why they stopped serving drinks at midnight on Sautrday night other than "we don't have the proper license". ARE YOU KIDDING!?!?!? That place could be a gold mine- why don't you go out and get one already!

And that's all I have to say about that.
author: Kara G.

description: Good food, really quite good.  A bit odd decor, feels like back in time.  Island tiki feel in basement of Fairmont Hotel.  Also a bit of a theme going with a pond in the middle with a boat that carries a band.  Maybe good for a group that wants something different and doesn't mind some kitsch a la Trader Vics back in the day.
author: Stevie B.

description:
I don't even drink alcohol and I LOVE The Tonga Room!!! I am a Tiki culture aficionado and The Tonga Room is one of the best, most authentic Tiki Bars in the world. The timed indoor rain shower, the epic wooden tikis, and the bamboo enclaves make this a notable San Francisco landmark.This place should be preserved and maintained at all costs!!
That aside, the food is fantastic! The appetizers are glorious and the virgin mai tais are delicious. Obviously, I'm not a specific food reviewer, but I can say that the food here is as good as Trader Vics, which is quite a compliment!
author: Philip R.

description: The drinks are great but a little pricey. But the happy hour buffet is awsome and more than made up for it.
author: Ben P.

description:
I hate to do this.

I went to the Tonga room last night and was totally disappointed! 

The food and the service have gone down hill.  It took forever to get our first round of drinks.  Then we had another person join us and it took even longer for her to get a drink.  We Here is how it breaks down. We asked for the check and she must have walked by us 3 or 4 times before finally bring it.

The food is even worse then the service (only commenting on happy hour buffet never had a meal here) .  The buffet lame.  Only 4 hot choice and 3 cold.  For hot you had: soggy egg rolls, chewy noodles, sticky rice (not sticky in a good way), mushy chicken wontons.  The wontons had no meat in them.  The egg rolls were fulled with limp over cooked vegetables.  The noodle and rice were both flavorless & very odd texture.  Cold you had orza rice, Shrimp chips and fruit salad.  The Shrimp chips were OK unless you remember that they are suppose to taste like shrimp.

Drinks are fun and fruit and actually ok prices considering that you are in the Fairmount.

Atmosphere is tiki and then some.  Grass huts indoor lake with Rain and lighting. 

Here is how I'd break it down:
Drinks 5
Atmosphere 4
Service 1
Food 0
author: Kevin C.

description:
I guess when I get old and have a higher tolerance for salt and my tastebuds don't work then I might enjoy their food.
I am not a fan even with the drinks and fanfare about the decor. 
Likely a good wholesome place for your corporate party!
author: Clementine O.

description: The most fun bar in San Francisco! It has a great atmosphere and some potent cocktails. The service can be hit and miss, but the staff are all very friendly. Great for visitors to San Francisco as well as locals. You can't beat drinks during an indoor thunderstorm!
author: Jeff G.

description:
This was the first bar I ever went to in San Francisco, and while it must be experienced at least once it is way too expensive for what you get.  The happy hour prices were high enough, I'd hate to see what they're charging for a rum drink otherwise.  The bar used to be the hotel swimming pool (notice the proximity to the gym) hence the pool in the middle.  Still, gotta give em props for being the first bar I've seen that had a thunderstorm simulated every 15 minutes or so.
Still, delicious Scorpions, Zombies, Mai Thais, and any other fruity drink you can think of.
author: matthew w.

description:
Make sure you make it to the Tonga Room's Happy Hour before the big gong strikes and everyone turns into pumpkins! I strongly suggest this....otherwise you will see the snappy suit-clad execs and hangers-on devolve right before your very eyes, into the worst dressed tourists you can imagine, dancing badly to sad FM (as Bridget would say).

If you stay within the confines of the 5p-7p crowd you will not be disappointed. The drinks are amazing looking!  I am such a sucker for fruit-laden heavily accessorized drinks topped off with a gaudy umbrellas. 

But the best part was watching two very tipsy top-heavy tourists attempting to dance and making themselves ridiculous as one, actually bent over and tossed her hair around (ala Flashdance) in the faux rain shower! We laughed so hard, that we ended up crying. I have never laughed as hard as last night. Kudos to the floor show! 

All in all, the Tonga Room was a blast sans the tourists. If you follow the rules and don't stay past 7pm and hang out exclusively at the bar, you will be guaranteed a good time.
author: Nickee M.

description:
The Fairmont is special to hubby and me because we got married there two years ago. So for our second anniversary dinner we had dinner at the Tonga Room. Food wasn't the best but the place had a fun ambiance and the consistent service the hotel provides is almost unsurpassed.

Hubby had the huli chicken, which was very tender. I had the mongolian beef, which was really tasty. A bit on the sweet side but with really tender meat. A lot of it too.  Cocktails were yummy too although the cherry that came with my virgin strawberry daiquiri tasted a bit old. Loved the little umbrellas. Seriously, where else can you get those in the city??

As a congratulutory gesture, the restaurant gave us free desert. I gotta say those two were yummier than the entrees. The first one is called, I think, the Pearl (rich chocolate cake inside a white chocolate sea shell). Decadent and has to be eaten until nothing's left.  The other one was some sort of volcano, i.e. something flan like with raspberry sauce and bread crumbs. God...I polished that one off too...
author: Hadley K.

description: Great drinks and a good place to have a night out. Only complaint is the waiter would not split a check for a table of three. If Applebee's can split a table of 10 people, I don't see what the hard part is with how expensive this place is. Make reservations. The faces on all of the people we skipped were priceless.
author: Scott M.

description:
what's this?  good service?  came in again with my out-of-town friend for a late night drink for two, and had a great time.  we got to sit where we wanted, a nice wasabi-style peanut snack bowl was set down with the drink without asking, and a cool lounge singer crooned beautiful music aboard the band float.

at first the drink was not cold enough and too strong (rare for SF drinks).  our nice server guy noticed and brought over juice and ice to tone the rum down.  how thoughtful!  even the former snippy waitress from last time was accommodating and helpful.  aces all around :)  i guess the moral of the story is to come late at night for the music and atmosphere and to stay away from happy hour.
author: Holly B.

description: What a pc of crap!!!!!!! I can't believe people are giving this place good reviews!  The food is by far the worst asian food I've had.  To top it off we spent $100 per person for microwavable food.  I would never recommend this place to anyone. Not even my enemies.   Only thing good was the music.  It's been over a month and til this day we still dread this place.
author: Jino l.

description: This is a San Francisco Classic and it's still fun.  Yes, it's over priced ($12 drinks) but they do pack a 'punch'.   It rains on the hour, yes it's corny but it's fun.  We didn't order food so I can't comment on that, it was fun for a drink before dinner.
author: William K.

description: Took the kids here as part of a  Christmas weekend outing, and they loved it.  That together with the wonderfully kitschy decor result in the two stars.   Food was terrible and over priced, drinks were passable and over priced, and service was fine.
author: Doug O.

description: I was just there last weekend and thought it was great location, OK food and service. I can see this place being a "cute" selection for a first date; let's hope you enjoy loud cheesy music? I have to admit that it is funny to see all the drunk people dancing around, definitely a plus. What I liked the most was my banana mousse dessert.
author: K O.

description:
Amazing lamb curry, great atmosphere and decor.
A bit fancy and pricey, but excellent for a special occasion.
author: Mike W.

description:
Very Ordinary Chinese food and the drinks are over priced even during happy hour. 
The storm is cool.
author: Marcus R.

description:
The Tonga Room isn't so much a tourist trap as a very well-preserved example of 50's kitchiness- a real throwback to a mid-century themed bar. The middle of the room features a large pool (used to be part of the Fairmont's original swimming pool) and a floating tiki island a band plays on. Every 15 minutes, thunder crashes, and it rains over the pool. But what's awesome is that it's not "ironic", it's just left over from when tiki torches were really glamorous. The dance floor looks like the bow of a ship, and you can sit in little tiki huts.

Yeah, the drinks are overpriced, and ordering actual meals is pointless. Go during the happy hour for slightly cheaper drinks, and an all-you-can-eat $8 buffet of  faux Chinese food (pot stickers, spare ribs, won tons, chow mein, etc), which is good in a bad way.  Sure, you'll spend a lot of money, but it's not an everyday type of place. The tropical drinks are very sweet and strong enough; the Bloody Marys are bad; the regular mixed drinks are strong too. 

And yes, it would be better if the band played something other than "I Just Called To Say I Love You", but then that would mean that the Tonga Room got wise to its extreme campiness, and that would probably be less fun overall.

In conclusion, of you like things campy and retro, the Tonga Room is a good time. It would be nice if the quality of the drinks and food were better, but I personally don't mind paying once in awhile for the wonderfully eclectic ambiance (plus it's nice and darkish in there.) And the fact that it's full of Midwestern tourists and not trendy drunk hipsters is, at times, as refreshing as tropical rainstorm that arrives every quarter of an hour. It's pretty glamorous as long as you appreciate that sort of thing, and you don't get to experience it all the time. But if sleek modernity is more your speed, then you may be better off somewhere else.
author: aunt t.

description:
fantastic decor, awful drinks, very expensive.  Beware if you go on a night when they have live music - $7 per person for wedding quality covers of 70s music.  We had been warned not to expect much about the food, but the appetizers were pretty good. The drinks had nothing to recommend them except their size - this is based on the 11 drinks our 6 person group ordered. The drinks in the lobby bar upstairs are much better tasting. Service was too slow to send anything back - we ordered one champagne cocktail that was totally flat - yesterday's champagne.

Parking on nob hill is a real challenge, it can actually be cheaper to take the cable car ($5 each way) than a garage. The Fairmont Hotel is spectacular, but the Tonga room isn't worth more than a visual inspection.

The decor is incredible.
author: George S.

description:
Fairmont Hotel off of Mason..zzzzzz..My friends and I drove around for a good 30 minutes looking for parking!  Still we wanted to give this place a try after hearing much about it.. 

Incredibly overpriced food/drinks..so called Tongan food was much like Panda Express food on a fancy plate!  Maybe I'm just not that familiar with the Tongan culture, but are coconut shrimp and dumplings really Tongan food??  Definitely not worth $25!  For the 7 of us, the bill & tip reached nearly $300..The center stage performances were tacky/cheesey and definitely not the same feeling you get from a Luau dinner in Hawaii..or something to that effect.  The lady seating us was really REALLY rude, probably because we were all in our twenties?  We looked around to see a bunch of older folks..possibly in their 50s and 60s..and obvious tourists!  Also, we waited nearly 20 minutes to get seated with no one else ahead of us..AND!!! we had reservations!  

Regardless, my friends and I had a ball that night.  (we hit up a club afterwards in hopes of regaining our youth)  But I will never forget the Tonga Room.  Places like this never fails to remind me that it's always the people that you're with, not the places that you go, that creates a fun-filled evening!
author: Rosa K.

description: Horrible food in a lovely room.  Shameful that the Fairmont Hotel puts its name on flavorless, uninspired food.  Let Panda Express handle the kitchen, it would be a 1000% improvement.
author: Marthe J.

description: The Tonga Room is such a fun evening.  We ALWAYS make sure to save at least one night to have some great drinks, dancing, and fun at The Tonga Room when we are in San Francisco.  You have to try their large drinks like The Lava Bowl and Scorpion--They are delicious.  The staff has always been so friendly too.  The band plays a great variety of music from the 60's and 70's mainly, and you just have to cut loose and have some fun on the dance floor.  The atmosphere great!
author: Tiffi G.

description: I personally didn't enjoy the drinks too much but my friends seemed to like them. Be prepared for them to add a $7 cover charge (per person) to your bill. But if it's because of the live band then it's worth it. They were great and there is a dance floor for you and your posse to get down and boogie. The band plays on a stage in the middle of the pool with simulated rain/thunder storms that come on every now and then. I hear the drummer is the owner. Also, ladies, if you are lucky enough to get seated by Khalid, he is quite the charmer and has the most adorable English accent. The customers seemed to be more of the older crowd, ie 50s and up. If you are going out for your 21st bday, I wouldn't recommend this place. If you get a little rowdy there are guys in there dressed up like secret service and they might just haul you out... Lol
author: M. T.

description: Last night was the first time I had dinner at the Tonga room in years!  I have had the buffet many time, but not dinner. Last night it was great! a NEAR PERFECT experience.  All the staff was friendly, the drink I had (Zombie) was really good and the Dragon Fire Chicken, the Mongolian (and stuff) beef and the meat free fried rice were great and updates on standard chinese fare. The recent renovations looked great and added seating to the bar area (and removed the big TV--YAY!). The place looked great.  I just hope the plans to tear it  down with the rest of that section of the Hotel don't come to be.  Save the Tonga Room!
author: BRUCE S.

description: Where to begin? I sent back the first drink of my life which was followed by the only bad dessert I think I've ever had. Then the band, which we paid a mandatory cover to hear while we sat, stopped playing for twenty minutes so it could rain in the pond in the middle of the bar. Definitely don't waste your time unless you're a tourist or just really bored.
author: Jenny W.

description: Have you been in the Tonga room with the new remodeling at the Hurricane bar area. its looks great with the chairs
author: Jun Z.

description:
SO GOOD!

If you want something to do in San Francisco that is good, and fun (cheesey...but fun) GO!

Great for groups (easy to get in on a friday night)

Great Drinks

and GREAT DECOR!!!

It's like the  "tiki room" in Disneyland (sans singing birds) and I felt like I was in a place where the Rat Pack would have hung out in San Francisco...and when you walk in, you get a lei!

AMAZING...the house band was playing classics too! I highly recommend coming here for your next event
author: Candace H.

description: The ambiance is not worth the terrible food.  I'm a local, was looking for something different, and I am usually somewhat amused by touristy spots.  My expectations were not high going in.  Result: I've been to themed restaurants in malls that had better "South Pacific" ambiance and better food.  The chicken we had was really terrible; I was afraid to eat it because it tasted like it had been cooked several days before and sat around for awhile.  The "firecracker" shrimp had no flavor, let alone spice.  They seem very concerned about serving folks who don't like spicy food.  If you REALLY want the ambiance, go for a drink.  Though, if you've actually been to the south pacific, you probably won't even enjoy your watered down drink.
author: S R.

description:
2 1/2 stars

I have never seen a place with more incompetent bartenders than at 
Tonga Room. Not only did they blatantly ignore several patrons (accidentally, which only further proves their incompetence), they were exceedingly slow in pouring/preparing drinks, gathering payment, providing change, etc.

That completely soured my experience, but the decor of this place was very cool including an area for a band in the middle of a pool. Great for hosting a party in terms of space/venue, but guys step your game up with your bartenders.
author: Scott L.

description: Really disappointed.  I heard about this place a long time ago (my parents even went here for dates way back in the day).  But it's gone downhill, I guess.  No more flaming scorpion bowl cocktails, lounge singers, or fake tropical rain storms.  All good things must pass.  Booooo.
author: Jim M.

description:
you come here for the atmosphere.  the food is pretty good, but it comes with a hefty price tag that doesn't necessarily reflect the quantity.  

my first tonga room experience was for a friend's birthday.  complimentary leis at the table added to the festivities.  and our waiter seemed really friendly, until we realized he was only friendly when trying to convince everyone to order lots of drinks and appetizers, and when we kept declining, he suddenly became much less interested in our table and didn't really bother to check on us for any other reason.  Oh and then they tried to charge us the $5 entertainment cover charge even though we arrived and began eating before the cover charge time began.  Thank goodness the manager came out and took off the charges.  My second time here it was a weeknight dinner and our waiter (a different fellow) was much better.  very attentive, very friendly, the way a waiter should be.  so i guess it's luck of the draw.  

in terms of the food, you'll get very tasty meat and seafood dishes, i just think the price is higher than you'd pay for comparable dishes at other restaurants, and the quality isn't necessarily improved.  so if you don't mind paying for the atmosphere, then by all means, eat, drink, and be merry.  

now in terms of the atmosphere, a band singing margaritaville on a boat in the middle of the river isn't for everyone.  yes, it's the perfect ambiance for this place, and you can even dance on the pirate ship dance floor while the thunderstorm sends rain down every hour.  ok, i can dig the gimmick, but i wouldn't make this place a regular venue, and seeing as i prefer different genres and styles of dinner entertainment, i'd probably hit up a jazz club instead if i was feeling music with my food.  

but it's always good to say you've gone to the tonga room at least once, seeing as it may not be with us for much longer.
author: Anne Marie B.

description: Even if you're a scrooge, you have to enjoy the Tonga Room. It's totally kitschy, but in a great way. The thunder and lightening storm are not dramatic, but it happens every 30 minutes and it is festive! The staff is always accommodating, their cocktails are delicious, and the floating band makes you want to dance! Very cute spot, and an old-standing SF bar...so you love supporting it!
author: Anne A.

description: Great fun! Totally hokey but I love it! Feel like I am in Disneyland drinking a mai tai! Check it out!
author: Nancy M.

description: Drinks are okay, and the atmosphere is way fun. THE classic tiki bar ambiance in the bay area. The band on a barge and the artificial rain provide an experience not easily duplicated elsewhere. For a tiki/water view mix, there's always Tiki Tom's and Trader Vic's. For superb quality in classic tiki drinks, there's Forbidden Island and Smuggler's Cove. But for recreating the tiki atmosphere and spirit, the Tonga Roon is sui generis. Prices are a tad high but for the occasional treat or for out of town guests, uniqueness has value.
author: alamedabrian m.

description:
I was feeling low - in Chicago we had a great Trader Vic's in the basement of the Palmer House Hilton and it closed. My last trip to San Francisco my spirits were lifted when I saw you had a Trader Vic's too - but it sucked. Total bummer. 

And then I remembered reading about the Tonga Room. We went on a weekend so the entertainment was floating away in the pool, singing my favorite soft rock hits. The drinks were fruity and strong, the prices were a bit high, but boy does the atmosphere make up for it. 

I'm not one to indulge in little-girl wedding fantasies, but boy would I like to float out and get married in the middle of the 'sea' surrounded by my family and friends who are back on 'land'. It's sick! Would a rainstorm after we've been pronounced husband and wife be badly prophetic or awesome? I'm not sure. I just know no future trips to San Francisco will be complete without a stop at the Tonga Room.
author: Kelly N.

description:
If I could live inside the Tonga Room I would!

The aesthetic is amazing. The drinks are great, the food not so much. But if you want to do something unique this is a great place to go. 

Dress up folks, it's a tikki bar/restaurant with a dance floor on a pirate ship. A band plays on a boat that floats in the water and it thunders and rains...

I took my niece and she just had to take home a tikki mug.

Bring money...they don't tell you when you make reservations, but there is  a $7 charge per adult for the entertainment and if you just go to drink there is a $2-3 sitting fee if you choose to sit at a table rather than at the bar.

Closed rather early and call ahead to make sure there isn't a special event. 

Take the cable car down to the Embarcadero after, the hill is fun!
author: Zeph C.

description:
I have sort of mixed feeling about this place:

(+ side): Really cool lounge in the Fairmont Hotel. Has a lot of cool history behind this place. Really nice 'tiki" bar atmosphere to it. Has what use to be the old swimming pool there where some sort of boat/barge floats around with the house band on it. Interesting drinks. A little dance floor (nice after about 4 or 5 drinks). A little area by the bar to sit at.

(- side): Drinks are a little pricey. Has some sort of 'entertainment/sitting' fee (about $6/person, might be more).

They do have some dinner/food/buffet but I didn't eat there and you can probably find some info. here on yelp. Oh ya, the part where we were escorted out by security was pretty classy. Luckily, my friend decided to use the "Chewbacca" defense and we avoided any further altercation.
author: Rob H.

description:
so i read today the tonga room might close soon.

to this i say 

NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO


where the hell am i supposed to get my conga on at the tonga if the tonga doesn't exist????  you can't conga anywhere else.  i mean, really.  just don't.  

i mean- seriously.  if it comes down to it, move that thing somewhere where they can have a better floating island for a band in the middle of an old hotel swimming pool.  and you best have a better pirate ship dance floor.

but condos?  really?  aren't there enough of those damn things everywhere?  there's only one tiki pirate rainstorm filled floating island kitschy slice of happiness.  and it's here.

the end.
author: Kimberly K.

description: Been a Neighbor of the Fairmont 20 yrs..Chose to celebrate a special birthday there This Friday night with Family coming in from Napa area..At 7PM tonight found out Tonga Room was bought out for a special party..My birthday reservation was taken & booked with a phone number..NO ONE LET ME KNOW.. Sorry I did not have the $$$$$to buy out the Tonga Room...But I should not have been treated in this manner..MY BIRTHDAY HAS BEEN RUINED..
author: judith s.

description: As a girl, the Tonga Room was a favorite place for my friend.  We were attending a conference in SF and she wanted to see it one more time.  I am so glad that we went.  We ordered hurricanes for the souvenir glass and had to work hard to finish the drink.  Then they gave us a clean and nicely wrapped new glass.  The people watching on a Saturday summer's eve was worth the cover charge.  A wedding party, honeymooners and herds of singles all getting funky with the live band.
author: Diane M.

description: I must start out by saying I am a HUGE Tony Bourdain fan.  After trying out the Peppermill  during our last Vegas trip (per his recommendation) the BF and I have decided his word is gold!  So when we saw him stop by The Tonga Room in one of his episodes of The Layover it was promptly added to our "To-Do" list for our trip to San Fran.  Let me tell you Tony Bourdain you did it again.  We had a blast at the Tonga Room!!  We got there about 8pm and there was a line to get a seat at the bar which luckily for us only took about 20 mins to get through.  The ambiance of the place is wonderful.  Polynesian themed with dim lighting, bright lamp shades and a pool that sudden, unexpected rain showers poured down on.  We were hoping to make it in time for happy hour (as I hear it's great) but alas we didn't.  However after the couple of drinks we had - me the Chi-Chi and the BF a Mai Tai - we didn't even notice the lack of food in our bellies.  The drinks were strong and tasty and the waitstaff oh so friendly.  The only gripe I would have about this place is the host at the front desk.  He was pretty unhelpful with people's questions and considering there was a line and no indication on why everyone was waiting in said line while other groups walked straight up to the host and were seated promptly there definitely were questions!  Also, they have live bands certain days of the week which even as a bar patron you are going to pay to see $5 per person I believe.  We finished our drinks before the show begin so I can't comment on if it's worth the price or not.  All in all a very fun place even for a somewhat large group - a must see if you are ever in the area.
author: Nicole M.

description: I would give this place 4.5 stars if possible. The atmosphere here is really fun! The food was decent, i had the vegetable tempura and thought it was delicious. The only complaint was that the place was pretty dead! I guess this isn't the place to be on a weekday? The band was fairly decent but I was a little irritated we had to pay a 5 dollar cover especially since we had dinner and drinks. This place has such a fun ambiance though so I got over it fairly quickly. The thunderstorm and rain made it cool too. The drinks are pretty good and I wouldn't mind coming back just for that and hanging at the bar. I just wish at least someone was dancing! I would come back here on the weekend. Overall, a fun place to come for a celebration or just for some drinks and live music!
author: Gianna D.

description: It is the place to go...  Great atmosphere .. Great music, the maitai's sneak up on you for sure.. And great music!!!!!!  If you are visiting and are looking for time this is the spot!!!
author: Josh T.

description: I've been coming to the Tonga Room for about 20 years now, and its atmosphere never disappoints. If you're even remotely fond of the Tiki scene and Polynesian Pop, this is the place for you. To be clear, I'd give the Tonga Room a 5 for the atmosphere alone. The drinks, I'm happy to say, have improved over time (they seem to be using better rum and overall they taste fresher). So why am I giving it just 3 stars? I ate dinner there last night, and the dinner was truly lousy. I get the impression all the ingredients are frozen (that tinny taste to the vegetables and flavorless chicken lead me to this conclusion), and they are very heavy-handed with overly sweet sauces; the food is drowning in them. So, come for cocktails and atmosphere--and maybe some hors d'oeuvres, catch the band and a faux storm or two, but skip dinner!
author: Jess R.

description: I think I am becoming a tiki bar regular these days.  I was told by numerous people that I HAD to go to this place!  I had fond memories of going to the Fairmont Hotel as a kid, so I was excited to visit again and relive those days.  We didn't have a reservation on a Sunday night, however, they were able to seat us right away.  We sat two tables over from the water, which was nice and had a very cool table set-up.  Our waiter was beyond hilarious and REALLY encouraged us to keep drinking...heh.  We decided to order a bunch of small plates and/or appetizers to share.  I was very happy with all of the food that we chose...it was all very yummy.  Our drinks were amazing and strong enough to get you pretty tipsy even after just one.  The only downfall I would say is that it can get pretty pricey.  You are paying more for the experience and atmosphere than anything.  We stayed just long enough to see the cover band play on their floating boat for a couple of songs.  I was amazed at how nice of a dance floor they had and that multiple couples took to the floor immediately.  Overall, my experience was just lovely.
author: T T.

description: I love tiki bars and totally found this place by accident when I was in town to watch my sister run the Nike Woman's Marathon. The Tonga Room will always be on my list of places to go when I'm in town.
author: Matt F.

description: This place is good for if you like to listen to live music and grab some dinner good place to go on a date the food is OK i am not very into Asian food but the drinks and dancing the decor makes it a special place to go
author: SAMAY A.

description: Fun spot, definitely worth trying once. Go in expecting it to be expensive, and then you won't be annoyed when the bill comes. Yes there is a 'cover charge' for the band. Highly recommend the shrimp dumplings!! The chow chow noodles were good too. And the lava bowl with the long straws :) Make a reservation.
author: Caitlin B.

description: I remember well in the 90's when the happy hour buffet was free and the drinks were 5 bucks, so nowadays it seems overpriced, although the atmosphere and decor remain very uniqe.
author: Charles S.

description: Just had a happy hour after work out with my gurl Lillith. We meet some friends here and had some fruity drinks and lots of fried foods. It was fun..
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
What a    h u g e   dissappointment!! Last Saturday me and my giant wedding party of 40 thought we would endulge in a little post wedding cheese (by cheese I mean the whole Tonga decor and selection of music), only to have all our expectations tossed out into the gutter. 

First, as we all arrived at different times from differend cabs etc., the peps at the door let some people in, but turned at least half of our people away. Nobody could get a good explanation as to why. The room  was mosly empty, though the bar was fairly happening, the dance floor also empty. The bar wasn't to close for another hour. So why turn business away?

Once inside, they made us sit at a long table, wouldn't let us enjoy the bar area. Long table not good for post wedding socializing, especially over lould cheesy 80s tunes. 

The drinks- average. But the service quick considering the size of the order. 

The best (or worst part) of the 30 minute experience, was when the waiter handed the bride (me), fully dressed in wedding garb, the bill for 20 people. You could imagine my surprise at the realization that no employee of this bar bestowed once single ounce of tact. 

Luckily for us, we planned ahead and continued our party in our suite, thus not a complete failure at the Fairmont. AND ,thank goodness for me I have good sense of humor.
author: Miranda B.

description: Who doesn't love drinking obscene amounts of liquor from ornate bowls? I just wish I didn't have to spend the evening with schmucks from the suburbs and listen to shitty bands cover Jimmy Buffett (not to mention, PAY to listen to shitty bands cover Jimmy Buffett).
author: Brittany L.

description: First of all, we had a BLAST at Tonga!  It's located in the Fairmont Hotel on Nob Hill, so you know it's going to be expensive.  Do not come here expecting deals or 5 star food..it's just not that kind of place.  We ended up having their famous rum drinks  ($10 a drink, but tasty and strong) and ordering 3 appetizers and 1 entree for 4 people.  More than enough food.  The fun part is sitting by the pool and watching it rain...pretending you're back in Hawaii.  I heard they might close this place down, so try & head out soon if you can.  Order the scorpion!
author: Autumn C.

description: Way overrated. The lava bowl for two is the same amount of drink for 1 person- and mediocre food (the buffet tastes the same as eating at a fastfood hawaiian bbq place) SF has so much to offer why settle.. and what is with this random rain shower that happens- its so lame!! Luckily I didnt have to wait the 2 hr wait to get in because my friend was already inside-i would have been heated!
author: Marie o.

description: Duck was way undercooked.  Atmosphere seemed hokie and was trying too hard.  Maybe it was the THREE birthdays that were going on at several tables for 16-20 somethings?  I try not to hate, but it is confusing going to a "Tiki" place and having mostly Asian on the menu.  Plus the bill was $40+ each for standard shiz.
author: Phillip M.

description: Neat atmosphere but that's about it. Service very slow and inattentive. Buffet was terrible- limited selection, overcooked, tasteless. 2 drink minimum- drinks watered down and weird tasting. You'd think that being in a nice hotel it would be better- it's not, it's pretty bad.
author: Rice C.

description: Super cheesy but fun if you're in the right mood - right mood being wanting to dance to wedding music next to Aunt Sally and Cousin Jeffrey, people you're comfortable with and not looking to impress.  Cover was $7 but I don't remember paying it, maybe because our group didn't stay long because we had reservations for dinner elsewhere.  The drinks are no joke; one will knock you off your a$$ for the rest of the night.  So even though they're spendy, it has good buzz value.  Not sure why but I found the band on the floating barge hilarious.  They would release them in the lagoon for sets and then reel them in for breaks - reminded me of catching and releasing fish.  From what I could tell, everyone there was having a good time and not taking him or herself too seriously.  Bonus, the cable car is steps from the Fairmont.
author: HW R.

description: I do love a cool tiki bar, and this wasn't what I had envisioned, though it had its highlights. The pool in the middle of the room is unique, and the "thunder" and "rain" over the pool was amusing. And my waiter was pretty attentive and friendly--I had made a reservation and he referred to me by name throughout my  meal, which was a nice touch. The drinks were well done too. Blue Hawaiian was delicious, and the mai-tai was good and was served in a ceramic fake coconut cup--so the bar really said "tiki." But after that, things turned fairly average. The food was decent but overpriced. Had the hana pork that really needed to be served over rice, which was an extra charge. It was good, but the menu was definitely  more Chinese than Polynesian, which was a big disappointment. There was an automatic cover charge for everyone who entered, $5 on weekdays, and $7 on weekends. I didn't think that was cool for those who came for dinner--people are dropping $40 or more per person, and you need to charge more for the band? I was there on a Wednesday, and the band was good but not what I expected. They played jazzy soft rock and classics, again a bit of a disappointment since I'm in a Hawaiian-themed restaurant. Mix in some Henry Kapono, Izzy, and even some Don Ho--or someone should be playing a slack-key guitar. Maybe the weekend show is more Hawaiian-flavored, I don't know. The band does play on a covered "boat" that floats out toward the middle of the pool--gives a bit of an extra zip to the show and puts them nearer the center of the room for all to see. The decor looks to have stayed the same since the 1940s or so, which is OK as it's not run down, and it's darker in tone, not vibrant like a more modern take on tiki. Overall, if you're travelling to SF, it's a landmark and something worth going to. A caution to single diners: make a reservation for one if you want to do anything other than sit at the bar. They were hesitant about seating me at a regular table at first, but after I mentioned I had a reservation they were happy to oblige with no further discussion.
author: Rick B.

description:
okay, first things first: if you drink at all you will not get out of here without a severe headache the next day.  it doesn't matter what you order: the drinks are all made of 10% pineapple juice 20% alcohol and like 200%  high fructose corn syrup, topped with a pink umbrella and five maraschino cherries.  Just how momma likes it.

ladies and gentlemen, if you have not been here, it is worth the headache.  There is nowhere like this on earth (but probably there is in heaven i don't know i haven't been there).  i can only think that this bar was dreamed up in an alcoholic black out after pounding singapore slings and pork buns for 48 hours straight.  i give it four stars for the atmosphere (three of those stars are for the indoor monsoons. they are maybe the best idea a human being has ever had ever.)  the last star is because of the two fantasies this bar has inspired in me.  Don't worry, I will share.

THE FIRST DREAM:
Finally, I scare up the nerve to do what my friends and I have been threatening to do for a long time, and stow away on the band ship.  I stay hidden (behind the speakers? underwater with a straw from the bar? I haven't figured out that part yet) until we're in the middle of the lagoon and there's NO ESCAPE.  Then, with catlike agility, I pop up, chloroform the singer, and take the mic.  I start out with a song i know will get them.  I sing: Cocomo.  Now in normal life, i have an unbridled hatred for the beach boys but for some reason, tonight, cocomo just seems right.  at first the band is stunned and suspicious and i have to sing a cappella.  then the keyboard player in the turquoise blazer starts nodding--he gets it.  He starts to jam along.  pretty soon I've even won over the cynical alcoholic drummer who should have quit years ago.  when that song is over, without speaking, together on the same transcendental plane of groove, we all simultaniously launch into a thirty minute long cover of chic's LE FREAK.   by the second time i tell the crowd that le freak c'est chic the entire bar is FREAKING OUT.  They are all both FEELING THE RHYTHM and also CHECKING THE RIDE. I BRING THE MFING HOUSE DOWN.  i leave, to return only in the legend told in whispers late at night.  

FANTASY NUMBER TWO: 
it's the last song before closing.
Surrounded by elderly tourists and conventioneers, i'm holding my special someone and doing the 8th grade slow dance two step while the chick on the boat sings "tiny dancer".  the bartender is wiping down the bar, the waiters are finishing their side work, the singer's voice is tired and gravelly, and i'm just swaying back and forth with the old people and silently weeping with the beauty of it all.
author: joy m.

description:
the good kingdom of tonga would declare a war on san francisco if they ever walked into the tonga room...

...however, as a peasant, i like the tonga room for all its over-the-top decoration. ok, over-the-top is too generous for the tonga room. it's more like...

tacky, ticky. tacky, ticky. tacky, ticky...

seriously, tacky and ticky are the only words that comes to my mind in describing the tonga room decoration and its infamous thunder and rainstorm show. god, please gag me! it's the kind of stuff even vegas would not touch.......well, maybe except for the thunder and rainstorm. i vaguely recall one of the vegas hotels had something similar. cheeeeesy!

however, despite all this madness, i truly enjoy the tonga room.......and especially, their happy hour! thus, more often than not, you can find me in the tonga room, abusing their drink specials (about $4 - 7, i think. i can't remember exactly, but if i can afford it, you can certainly afford it.) and all you can eat "asian inspired" buffet ($8). ahhhhh, only the king of tonga eats and drinks better.

.
i don't think i would make a good ambassador to the good kingdom of tonga...
author: frisco j.

description: The happy hour is worth checking out - $7 for all-you-can-eat Chinese appetizers with one drink minimum. Make sure you get there at around 6pm because they take the food away at 7 sharp. The decor is like a semi-ritzier version of Rainforest Cafe. The waitresses are mean and cranky though. I think they used to push the dim sum carts at Gold Mountain.
author: Connie C.

description: I was served RAW chicken...and then the waiter mistakenly thought I was a tourist and told me that was normal in SF asian restaurants.  The manager was very apologetic...but honestly nothing can make up for the waiter's condescending attitude or the possibility of salmonella poisoning.
author: Kerri L.

description: Here's the deal....following a panel that I co-organized at the anthropology meetings, held that year in the city, a group of us went out to the Tonga Room. Our panel was on theming, so we, of course, loved this place. The theming--dead on and amazing. The boat with the singers on it that moved into the center of the small pond--timeless. The problem is: bad and overpriced food and drinks that are the same (as well as not that strong). Theming uber alles!
author: S L.

description:
A friend decided to have his birthday party here. I had heard about the place for many years. The Tiki atmosphere was fun to look at for about 10 minutes. The tropical rain and band on a boat were cute for a minute until the band started to play then the place started to feel creepy.
The food was possibly the worst I have had in 20 years of living in San Francisco. It was super over price and really utter garbage. My advice is to go there have one drink and and get out.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Frankly I was a bit nervous after reading several reviews but my curiosity got the best of me and I am so glad it did!  We made 7:30pm dinner reservations.  First we were seated poolside or should I say bamboo plant screen-side but an adjacent table was very loud after a couple hours of the strong drinks. We were graciously moved to a different table along the side wall and a perfect location for enjoying the whole ambiance of the room.  
Instead of the fruity drinks we had a bottle of wine which was a perfect match for our dinner. We started with the steamed scallop shrimp dumpling.  Dinner was the butterfish asparagus and the tonga hot pot of shrimp, scallops, and opah fish in a red curry coconut broth with brown rice to soak up the delicious flavors.  Dessert we shared peppercorn ice cream.  The portions were large.
We listened to two sets of music.  It reminded me of my favorite satellite radio station.  The band was good but not great. I think their mics need a check.  The wait staff was very professional. 
All in all I am very glad to have had the experience.  I would go back again if the right opportunity presented itself.
author: Mary H.

description: I'm sorry but this place is just not what it used to be... at least for me. The set (can't really call it decor) looks dated and old, the water effects aren't really all that cool, it's way too dark inside and the happy hour buffet isn't anything to Yelp about. Much of the seating is reserved for diners, so get there early if you're going in a group. Still, all in all, it's an amusing, different place to grab a few drinks if you're in the Nob Hill area. Personally, I think Rainforest Cafe owns this place when it comes to drinking in a Disneyland-like set with periodic rain showers and is way better for impromptu groups.
author: Kristina A.

description: I visited the Tonga Room on Saturday, 2/25 with a small group of friends. It was the first visit for all of us. We made reservations since we had a group, and good thing because there was a huge line out the door and around the corner. My first impression was that the atmosphere was awesome. We knew in advance that we would have to pay $7 per person because there was a band playing that night. Unfortunately, the band didn't come on until an hour after we sat down and only played for half of the time that we were there. The service was extremely slow and English definitely wasn't the waiter's first language, making it difficult to communicate. One of my friends asked if they had a gluten-free menu. The waiter told her no but that they could make anything on the menu gluten-free. Obviously, that is not true, but that could potentially be dangerous if someone has a serious allergy to a certain type of food. In addition, the waiter was very pushy, trying to up-sell us on ordering more food and pricier drinks throughout the night. When our food finally arrived, it was all delicious, so no complaints there. Then came time to pay the bill.... Three couples paid with cash and two paid with credit card. We gave the waiter the two cards and $370 in cash. He left with it only to come back a minute later without the cash, saying that we were $65 short. He swore that his co-worker double counted the cash, but the supposed co-worker never came out to confirm and we never saw the cash again. One of my friends paid the extra $65 just so we could leave but a few of us didn't feel that was fair and asked to speak to the manager. After quite some time, the manager refunded the extra $65 paid. Overall, the atmosphere was cool, the food was good (although nothing spectacular), but the prices were high and the service was beyond shitty. Therefore, I definitely do not intend to return.
author: Catherine C.

description: White trash extravaganza. Horrible food, lousy music, loud and obnoxious. Fisherman's Wharf rejects. Tear this dump down and build some retail and condos already.
author: Steven G.

description: This is quite possibly the worst, cheesiest bar in SF. It's supposed to be campy and fun, but they take themselves way too seriously. The drinks are weak and $10. The crowd is generally 50 year old tourists from Omaha. Not cute enough to make up for the lameness!
author: Roseanne W.

description: Now that the closure has been announced I guess the staff and management think it's OK to behave in a surly manner and water down the drinks.  SKIP IT.  Don't waste your money here.  Come in, look around, enjoy the kitsch but head down the hill - anywhere else - for your drinking.  Did I mention the part where the perma-frown cocktail waitress threw - no kidding! - the bar menus on our table when we asked for a food menu?  The Fairmont chain has become exactly that: a chain.
author: J. Santiago S.

description:
i love the pina colada's here - felt almost like i was back in hawaii.  :-)

not so crazy about the $5 entertainment fee.

Or the $24 plate of beef chow mein!  how ironic that if we just walked two blocks towards chinatown, that same dish would have cost $2.40.
author: Josie M.

description:
Tonga room has an awsome, unique atmosphere which is highly appealing.  Theres a stage in the middle where bands can perform and a waterfall which surrounds them.  
However, I came here early in the mid-evening for their happy hour and was very disapointed. As you walk in, you get the leisure to find your own seat, but being that its so dark inside, it took the staff about 20 minutes to locate us.  Water isnt free like most places, its 5 friggggn dollars!! wow...The buffet was heart attack central, all greasy foods which I thought was prepared by a Jack n the Box.  I've been told coming here for dinner is a different experience, so perhaps try that out and avoid their crappy happy hour.  
My advice for Tonga room, hire more curteous staff, change your buffet items and purchase a heater bc its so damm cold inside
author: Ray M.

description: A horrible throw-back to old-school hokey Vegas.  You arrive looking around for your server; you leave wondering what time Wayne Newton was scheduled to start his first set.  OMG:  call the police.
author: Patrick B.

description: A perfect (cocktail) refueling station when you have out-of-town guests, this deliberately tacky lounge is frozen in time when exotic bars were all the range in the 1950s. Well, almost frozen in time -- the terrible-in-a-good-way Asian cover band that floats on a barge stage in the swimming pool, ushered in and out by faux rain-forest storm effects (think Safeway's produce watering device on a much larger scale), as well as ridiculously over-priced drinks are reminders that we are indeed living in the 21st century, and that they're having to cough up rent in one of Nob Hill's grandest old-school hotel$. Still, the fun factor wins. And I would like to personally shake hands with whomever came up with the names of their house drinks -- hilarious!
author: Gregor G.

description: The Tonga Room is a lot of fun.  The band that plays on the weekends is great.  It's essentially a wedding band.  They play all the quintessential wedding songs.  If you don't like rum drinks stay away from the drink menu.  A great place to go if you like to dance at weddings and have drinks in bowls rather than glasses.
author: Josh V.

description:
I was up here for a friend's grad celebration.   I entered the Fairmont hotel from the California st. entrance and turned right to make my way around the corner to a unique dining area.  I slid past the dance floor to where my party tables as I began to feel like I was on a pier in Hawaii- minus the humidity.  I began socializing in the dim tropical ambiance when all of a sudden it started getting wet!  Leaky roof?!?!? Nah, welcome to the Tonga room's indoor typhoon- rain, thunder, and strobe lights.  It was slightly distracting during conversation, but at times it was a welcome break in monotony. 
The band plays on a floating straw hut in the middle of a huge pond which I like to call the "indoor pacific ocean."  They played some classic cover songs and when I say classic I mean golden oldies.  They played so clean that sometimes I thought I was listening to the actual record being played; so I had to look at the lead vocalist from time to time just to remind myself that they were actually performing live. 
The room is filled with suspended canoes and tropical warrior weapons screwed into the wall- adding to the island fantasy. I was just waiting for the hula girls to appear but they never came.  After a cold Sierra Nevada, the food made its way to the table.  I'll be honest I didn't know what to expect since my friend ordered everything.  I was thinking island food probably, but I was wrong.  It was actually Chinese food.  The egg soup was delicious but spicy. How Spicy? Make you sweat-like- a-pig in front of everybody spicy.  So if you're one of those that tends to get hot under the collar- have the napkin in hand while eating the soup.  The main course was pretty good- coconut shrimp , really really tender beef and broccoli, plain white rice (nothing spectacular), and some mango ice cream for dessert.  Ah, reminiscing about it is making me salivate.  I have no complaints and I would so go again.  Maybe next time I'll bring a surf board and jump in to the indoor pacific.
author: JONATHAN A.

description:
A restaurant in a hotel with a lagoon. What's not to like about this place?

The drinks were good but pricey. 
The food was really good. We order a tonga platter and a steak.

Both were delicious. I forgot what we got for desert but it was good too. (There was a small wait though.)

Service was excellent.
author: Brian W.

description: Food was good. I wish they had more to choose from on the menu. The band playing on a raft in the pool was fun to listen to as they played during dinner. The Tiki theme made you feel like you weren't in SF. Definately a place to check out at least once.
author: Eddy Z.

description: What a pathetic dump. This place is Like a nightmarish Disneyland version of Trader Vic's, minus the numbing drinks,  edible food and entertainment value. I recommend eating your own arm rather than letting someone drag you here.
author: David K.

description:
you know why, i love the tonga room? cause when i walk in, i feel like i just stepped in to a WW2 movie in hawaii. 

the drinks are wonderful, and the music is divine. the stage on water floating back and forth, how can you beat that uhh.

one day if i get enough people i wanna host a WW2 theme party there. where the men dress up as GI's and Sailors, and the women as nurses and just "dames." that would be sweet.
author: nick P.

description:
Generally I stay away from bars due to the fact that I'm a crazy drunk but some of my fellow jungle mates were very excited about this place's Happy hour. So I ordered a pina colada and for no reason I can figure out I switched to banana daiquiris. I've never been to Tonga nor anywhere in the south Pacific but I did see the movie once so I know a great deal about the culture. Just like the movie there was singing but the Tonga Room does it from a raft in a pool. I was quick to attempt to grab the microphone after my 5th daiquiris by swinging from the thicket roof but a rain storm dissuaded me.
I am no longer allowed in the Tong Room
author: Daisy S.

description:
Went to the Tonga Room with a dozen friends on a Friday night for happy hour.  We arrived early (4:45 p.m.) and we were the second people in line.  The line did grow quite a bit by 5 p.m. but the host accomodated us well with seating next to the bar.

The $9.50 appetizer buffet is worth it I think, even though it's mostly fried foods.  The service was good and the mai tais were even better.  Prices on the drinks aren't cheap but they aren't ridiculous either.  Lot's of choices.  

I hope the Tonga Room stays and doesn't get booted by the new condo development!
author: K V.

description:
Perhaps my expectations were low since I was expecting this to be just an expensive hokey tourist trap.  However having lived in the Bay Area my whole life I figured I had to go to the Tonga Room at least once in my life.  We had dinner reservations for 6:45 but got there 2 hours earlier in order to experience the bar and appetizer buffet ($10 per person with a 1 drink per person minimum).  Not great but good.

After the drinks and apps at the bar we relocated to our table in the dining area next to the "lagoon" - formerly the hotel's swimming pool.  Yes, it was hokey but also very cool.  The dinner prices weren't even as high as I had expected.  The service was excellent.  Our waiter was very attentive and friendly.

We had made our reservation on line through YELP.   Very professionally we received a reminder/confirmation phone call a couple of days before.  I'm glad they did call because one of the things the lady told us was that everyone still in the restaurant or bar after 8 gets an automatic $7 cover charge added to their bill for the "entertainment" that starts at 8 PM.  Since our reservation was for 6:45 we were concerned about being stuck for an additional $14 cover charge when we had little control over how fast the service might be or in the event we found the entertainment to be really aweful.  We were also worried that if our dinner ran only 15 or 20 minutes past the 8:00 curfew and had incurred the charge, we'd then be given the "bum's rush" to hurry up and vacate the table once we were finished eating.  Our waiter assuaged our concerns on both accounts by telling us that at his station we could stay without being charged the extra cover until 8:30 PM and that once we were finished eating and if we wanted to sit at the table and stay longer we could stay as long as we wanted.  While I'm sure he would have been true to his word about being able to stay a little longer without the extra charge and even though, because of the great service, we were pretty much finished by 8:00 anyway,  we decided take him up on his offer and stay a bit longer in order to get the whole Tonga Room experience and check out the music.  While it wasn't what we expected (we assumed it might be Polynesian style music) the light rock the small combo played on the "barge" in the middle of the "lagoon" was O.K.  They even got us up on the dance floor a couple of times.  We ended up staying till almost 10.

Over all I think the Tonga Room is a really good "must do" San Francisco experience for both the locals as well as tourists.  It is an historic exprience from another era.   It evokes the feelings and atmosphere from another time.  It is a little kitchy but it is also sort of romantic.
author: Duane S.

description: All I can say is that the Tonga Room is FUN!
author: V J.

description: Despite the super-cheesy decor, the Tonga room is pretty fun, and the food is decent. I was particularly pleased with seafood pad thai which featured 4 jumbo prawns and 4 ginormous scallops...good thing I was sharing! The price reflected the abundance of seafood, however. No deals here. Tasty food and rainstorms though.
author: Jessa B.

description:
I'm taking away stars because I, uh, 'refunded' my meal. But let's be fair and hear the whole story....Went there with the boy to take advantage of their famous happy hour. We had knocked around the idea for the last 2 years and finally felt like actually going. The price for the appetizer buffet is $9.50 with a one drink minumum (done and done!). The drinks are at special happy hour prices which is $1.50 off of the regular prices. So the Mai Tai is $7.50 instead of the usual $9.00. I think my tender tummy was a little too empty for the super strong Mai Tai and the buffet was filled with fried foods. The food isn't gourmet or anything, but grubbin nonetheless. Kalua Pork with Cabbage-grubbin. Chow Mein-grubbin. Fruit Plate-grubbin. Pork filled fried Won Tons-grubbin. Egg Rolls-grubbin. Sorry for the overuse of the made up word, 'grubbin' as the choice adjective for tasty. I never even use that word. Ever. Somehow it looks less douchebag chode in print, ya know? Anyway, the food was the yum-yum quality of some cool snacks your friend heats up at their house to go with your alcohol munchies.  I really went to town, too, so I can see how there was a little trauma to the system. 

Important tip: If you want to partake in the Tonga Room happy hour, you MUST get there right when it starts at 5:00 PM. 5:30 might be acceptable but not after that. I didn't once see anyone refill the table so first come, first served, baby.
author: Magi C.

description:
I'm very torn writing this review, hence the ambiguous 3 star rating. Majority of my experience at the Tonga was killer. Drinks were good, band was cheesy as all hell, the waiter was friendly, and we had a blast on the dance floor. We encountered a few problems though. I tried the lava bowl and scorpion bowl (shared, of course) and maybe my taste buds are whack but they tasted identical. No worries though because they were STRONG. Other people's drinks, however, weren't so strong and quite disappointing (e.g. daiquiris and coladas).  Next complaint is service. While our waiter was friendly and patient with our drunk asses, dinner took almost 3 hours! It was a 3-course prix fixe family style meal so the plates should have been flying out of the kitchen. Last complaint was the astronomical bill at the end. Dinner was set at $50/person, which was incredibly overpriced for mediocre salty asian food. Somehow the price was more than doubled by the end with drinks at $10/each and "entertainment" fee. 

I'm sure I'll be back for some event or birthday party but at least I'll be ready with my bowl o' booze and wad of cash.
author: Susan L.

description: we had a group of friends go to the tonga room and they had one check for the table and said we can pay anyway we wish at the end of our stay and not have to charge it on the credit card they required at the beginning of our meal. We all gave cash and paid the waiter without any problem. A few days later, I find out from the bank they also charge the same amount exactly including tip on the credit card. Watch out for this place!!
author: Henry L.

description: I'm trying to understand what all the hub-bub is about. The food was "meh" at best and we were brought the wrong spring rolls, wrong chicken satay, wrong drinks. It was a total cluster and if we hadn't had so much to drink (before and during), probably would have been pissed, plus service was super sloooooooooooow. With that being said, when the live music started (which was a combination Micheal Buble/60's/70's favorites), everyone perked up and we really started having a corny good time. It was super sweet to see little kids dancing with their parents too. We were slightly shell-shocked when we got our bill - 3 alcoholic drinks, 1 iced tea, 2 appetizers and 3 entrees = $174 + a $5 per person entertainment charge, not including tip. Ouch. We'll probably go again, but next time we'll stick to the bar and eat elsewhere. Oh - LOVE the thunder, lightning and rain over the pool that appears every 30 minutes; a really neat touch. A serious tourist place, but everyone should go once if only for the Tonga Room's history.
author: Sheila R.

description:
I had been dying to check out the Tonga room and finally went for drinks with a group of friends last night.  The service was so miserably awful that we actually said at the table, "I am going to Yelp the sh*t out of this place." Hence the review.
Anyway we were "greeted" at the door by an incredibly angry middle aged woman, apparently the matre d' if you could call her that.  I can honestly say, I have never been treated with such hostility before by someone at a restaurant.  We were not a bad crowd either - 6 attractive, completely sober 25-30 year olds, with a reservation mind you, and dressed to the nines. We asked about the cover as it was our 1st time there and we had reservations, and she couldn't be bothered to explain anything and just stared at us with an angry face. So we all start taking money out to give to her, since it appeared that she wasn't letting us in. She looked at us like we were idiots and told us it goes on our bill. Fine. We didn't care. Then she sat us down at a table that was a seat short, and when my boyfriend went to one of the 5 empty tables around us to take a chair (which easily fit in) for himself, she told him no, he could not do that and we would have to move. Odd? We didn't really get it and she walked away with us standing there confused, so we took the chair and carried on.  
Eventually a waiter handed out menus and we ordered up some drinks.  Let me also mention that while we were ordering the waiter was pressed up against me and leaning down so he was smacking me in the head over and over and over again with his notepad and it was uncomfortable to say the least. Then he took all the menus while we were requesting to keep one. Drinks came.  Some were better than others but really cute and fun and that's what we were looking for so it was fine. The bill came but we weren't even 1/4 done with our drinks. The waiter kept coming back for the bill but it had only been a few minutes and my scorpion bowl was full! Another friend wanted to order another drink, but it was way too complicated for him to manage a single mojito and he was very perturbed by the whole idea.  He was making such a big deal out of it that she finally lost it and cancelled it and we wanted to get the heck out of there. $150 for one drink a piece and being treated like garbage. 
I will say the band was great, the kitschy environment and really uniquely done tiki theme was really fun, and spirits were high. It's actually a fun place that I normally could have had a great time at. But the service is so awful that I would NEVER bring out of towners there again. It would just be embarassing.
author: Christine S.

description: Closing soon....so you must visit at least once!  Sure its cheeky and corny...and the Filipino cover band plays Backstreet Boys...and the drinks and food are insanely overpriced.....BUT it is worth the experience.  Has a bevy of alcoholic libations and tasty Polynesian fare, but also has an ample dance floor in shape of a pirate ship!  And it rains inside the club!
author: Loren H.

description: Had the Pineapple Royal..Ah-Mazing!!!  and the ambience was awesome!
author: Tania N.

description: Poorly trained staff, sub par food, mistakes with drink orders, overcharged on bill, horrible service. Even the tables around us were complaining about the awful food and service. Skip this place...the atmosphere isn't that great. I'd rather eat a Subway sandwich than spend money here.
author: Bobby D.

description: Not an every day kind of place but it is definitely one of those "must see" place if you're visiting San Francisco. They have a good selection of classic Exotic Drinks and though they're pricy they are strong enough that you don't need more than two.
