I will admit that I was a little disappointed with the rum selection compared to other spirits. They could stand a few more varieties of rum even if it meant they had to cut back on the other spirits they purchase, I haven't had the food and from what I hear it's less than impressive but come on, they hand you the drink menus first for a reason. If you aren't going to drink then why would you go?
author: Nicholas J.

description: Went here b/c the Top of the Mark was full...not sure if I would ever go again but the shots we had came in these cute little buddah glasses that we got to take home.  I keep mine in the kitchen and rub it for good luck!
author: Kristine Y.

description: Tacky room with a dirty pool in the middle of it.  Bad drinks and rude staff.  A waste of time.  Felt like I was sitting in an awful theme park restaurant.  Had heard about it for years...what a disappointment.  What an ugly room!!
author: Dee K.

description:
People either think this place is cheesy or awesome....I am among those that think it is awesome, but then again, maybe I like cheesy things.  You walk in and it's a huge dark restaurant with a massive pool in the middle with a floating stage.  Throughout the night, it thunders and rains.  On weekends they have a band performing on the floating stage.  Who wouldn't want to experience that at least once?  This is truly a unique place.  As far as the food goes, I think it is pretty tasty.  It is sort of Hawaiian/Asian infusion types of food.  I think it is beneficial to split dishes here.  Drinks are yummy.  They have one called The Lava Bowl (I think) and it is for two.  This thing is huge.  I suggest getting one for yourself if you want to get tanked.  They also have a pretty good Mai Tai.  I've gotten dessert here once for a birthday.  We got the brownie with ice cream.  It was gigantic and delicious.  Overall, this is a good place to go every now and then or to take an out of towner because it has such a unique atmosphere and the food is decent too.  They also have a buffet style dinner during the week for a set price.  I've never done this, but have always wanted to check it out.

Update 8/27/2007:

I came to check out the buffet one night.  It's a deal for sure.  Like $8 plus one drink and it's all you can eat.  Really great idea if you are on a low budget.  And the food is pretty tasty too.
author: Vanessa Z.

description:
(insert musical notes here) 
if you like piiiiiina colaaaadaaaas, and getting caught in the raaaain! 
(end cheesy song)
**** then this is your place!!! luckily i LOVE both and will be back.  but i'm definitly coming w/ one of my rich friends, as it can be a $15 pina colada you're drinking while it rains.
author: Shanti G.

description:
Here's some advice for the Tonga Room during happy hour (5-7pm):

1) Plan to be seated by 5:15; otherwise the place is crowded by 5:30 and there are no tables left in the lounge or at the bar
2) Order the Tonga Itch (as weird as it sounds --- it was definitely worth the HH price and gave me a cool buzz)
3) Don't order the Strawberry Daiquiri or anything strawberry (it tasted like they just dropped a whole bottle of Robitussin cough medicine in there and called it a Strawberry Daiquiri!......I've had better!)
4) Don't turn around and gaze at the tropical rainstrom every time it happens! That is so touristy.....
5) Don't take pictures of the decor or the scenery! You don't want to be seen as the annoying tourist.
6) Try the decent appetizer buffett. It's $8 with a one drink minimum and you'll be stuffed after 2 plates or so. Definitely have the crab ragoons and asian spareribs!
7) Lastly, leave by 7:30....or else you'll be charged $3 for the entertainment that begins at 8!
8) Last one (I promise!) and you'll thank me for this one: Don't park in the Fairmont Parking Garage.....it's $4 per 20 minutes and if you count correctly, our 2 hours and 30 minutes of fun cost us an additional $32!!!!! 

Looking forward to another HH at the Tonga Room.
author: La C.

description:
This place is awesome.

My buddies took off their clothes, jumped in the pool and swam a lap. That was more awesome.
author: Pfeif E.

description: Fun touristy spot. My drink was so strong. But, the macadamia nut spread with coconut on flatbread was really good. I also liked the rainstorms.
author: Anu Y.

description: Worked very hard to get here with my boyfriend - as tourists, we were navigating the transportation system and rearranged our whole day to make our reservation on time. When we got to the restaurant, almost nobody was in there. Yet, the hostess/manager was somewhat rude to us when we asked to be seated near the water, and she had a temper tantrum-like attitude just because we asked. However, the Tonga Room is expensive, and if we couldn't have a seat by the water, then my request would be that she at least treat us more respectfully. We saw one family leave because they were baffled they couldn't be seated with almost no one in the restaurant, and one other couple take issue with the table she had given them in a dark corner. However, the food was fantastic and the waiter was pleasant. I have a slightly bad taste in my mouth from my experience here, and I probably won't go again (although maybe for drinks at the bar.)
author: Kelly D.

description: I was so upset and pissed off. I ordered a vodka guava drink that should come with a real coconut shell (at least from the pic) but instead a ceramic bowl...so I took the decorative umbralla home for souvenir.
author: Michael K.

description: even though our waitress was a female dog and it took over a half hour to close our tab this place is amazing. the drinks were delicious and strong. i will definately go back and cross my fingers i don't get the same server.
author: Tommy G.

description:
Funky, interesting and WTF!

Tonga Room is located in the swank Fairmont in the even swankier Nob Hill. This place comes from the land of lost bars. I guess it reminds me of some old, tropical themed place with lots of cheesy-ness. But in a delightful way. 

Everyone has to come here at least once to experience, the nicely named drinks with mandatory fruit wedges and little umbrellas crammed into them. And then check out the decor, lava rock, flowers and even a fake lake (pool) where a band plays? There was even simulated rainshowers, like when you are shopping in the produce section of Safeway and it scares the crap out of me everytime.

Go for happy hour and indulge yourself in the $8 buffet of decent food. And then throw back a few "tikki torch something or others".

5 stars for one interesting place!
author: David B.

description: The drinks are expensive, the music is cheesy, the staff is uptight, and the food is just terrible - I love the Tonga Room!  Try to go when the band is playing and do some drunken dancing on the ship deck dance-floor. Eat $10's worth of fresh fruit at the happy hour buffet, but stay away from the chow-mein. Jump in the lagoon and get kicked out!
author: J. R.

description:
i was sooo hoping to give the tonga room 5 stars but they just didn't cut it. my husband and i decided to have dinner here for our 2nd anniversary. we honeymooned in maui so we thought this place would be perfect. before making our reservation i read through the many reviews on yelp and was prepared to have less than spectacular cuisine BUT i didn't expect it to be this disappointing. 

we originally planned to start off with happy hour and then go into our 7pm dinner. as usual, i took longer than planned to get ready so we didn't make happy hour but we did make it to dinner on time. i started off with the famous mai tai which was too strong for my taste and i struggled to finish it throughout dinner. my husband loves asian pears so we started with the kula greens salad. omg, this was SOOOOO salty. it's supposed to be a sesame soy dressing but it tasted like straight soy sauce and unfortunately the pears were soaked in it. thankfully we weren't charged for this salad disaster. we shared the tonga platter for two which tasted okay but is overpriced. the tonga ahi poke was good. the dragon fire chicken was bland and salty at the same time (didn't think that was possible) and the shaka rice was just okay. 

thinking there was no way they could mess up dessert, i decided to try the tonga volcano. ugh, even this was disappointing! 

though dinner was disappointing i really did LOVE the atmosphere and decor. the "rain" and "lightning" reminded me of our honeymoon because it rained almost the entire time we were there. felt like we were in maui again. the live music was also a plus. ooh and the keepsake photo shoot was a nice touch. we left feeling like we had a mini vacay.

if you really want to check this place out i recommend doing the happy hour buffet and drinks thing. you get the experience and a way cheaper bill. ooh, and make sure to walk around the hotel. cool old stuff to look at and the roof top garden is neat, ha!
author: Angela W.

description: The food was absolutely horrendous. We had 2 dishes that we just couldn't eat because the meat quality was so poor. Our kids enjoyed the atmosphere, but the mediocre service, outrageous prices and terrible food were not worth it. The Fairmont should not have such an awful restaurant in it's premises.
author: Gabrielle O.

description: Great Happy Hour.  Grab some steamed buns, vegie sticks and an Island Cooler then jam the night away on the dance floor.  If Gidget was in the city filming, the Tonga Room would make the perfect set.
author: Shiho F.

description: I am giving this restaurant 3 stars only because of the fun drinks and fun kitsch atmosphere. The food is simply awful. It tastes like it came from an institutional cafeteria. I think they just take the same food they serve to their huge conferences and sprinkle some chopped green onions on top hoping it passes for fine dining. It doesn't. We came here 13 years ago for our first date and just went back for the first time and the drinks and silly rainforest atmosphere were fantastic (as remembered) but the food was a complete waste of money. They must rely on people who don't repeat their visits, being a hotel.. But I would expect better food at motel 6 let alone the fairmont.
author: Anna E.

description: The food is definitely subpar, but i didn't come here for the fine cuisine.  The service was prompt, the ambience catchy and fun, and the drinks tasty.  I went on a Sunday night and a band was playing on a floating barge in the water.  What a riot.  Definitely a fun time.
author: Alexis H.

description: I had read some reviews that said this place was kind of cheesy... but when people compared it to the Tiki room at Disneyland I knew I would love it! My husband and I went there for dinner on a Saturday night because we were staying at the Fairmont and we were not disappointed. The atmosphere was so fun if you're looking for a place that is upbeat and doesn't take itself too seriously. On certain nights they have a band that plays music on a boat in the middle of a pool and we thought that was really fun! But be prepared to pay a $7 cover charge per person on those nights, even if you're eating dinner there. We tried four different appetizer type dishes... the calamari, coconut shrimp, chicken satay and the vegatable spring rolls; they were all pretty good. The drinks are amazing and they do not skimp on the alcohol! At a minimum of $12 per drink I actually felt like I was getting my money's worth. We tried the Chi Chi and the Bora Bora and they were both delicious and very tropical. I had read that the service wasn't that great but we had no problems at all. They were friendly enough and the service was pretty quick. We will definitely go back to the Tonga Room the next time we're in San Francisco, it was such a fun place! If you're looking for a quiet, uptight restaurant this is not the place for you. Reservations highly recommended.
author: Michele M.

description: Tonga, I would just like you to know that I am STILL pissed off at you for charging me an outrageous "entertainment fee" for sitting at a crappy table waiting for my $$$$ Blue Hawaiian to arrive.
author: leslie j.

description: I was very excited to check this place out based on the fun reviews. It was a huge waste of my time. When we got there they said we could not sit down because we did not have a reservation, but we could sit at the bar and wait until 8:30 (45 minutes).  We thought about it and agreed to go to the bar area and have a scorpian bowl. As we sat in the bar area overlooking a sea of empty tables for over ten minutes, I knew what was going on. They wanted us to spend money at the bar, then seat us - the oldest trick in the book. Note to Tonga Room - that trick only works if it is semi busy and you can pretend the seats are actually about to fill up with reservations!  When the waiter finally came and took our order he was not friendly at all. When the scorpian bowl came, it was really just a small mug full of juice with a splash or rum. $17 for that little cup of juice! After sitting there for over a half hour, looking at the empty tables, we decided to leave rather than spend $29 on an entree of crappy Chinese food. It took forever to get the check and for him to bring back the credit card. By that point it was past 8:30, all the tables were still empty, and they didn't offer to seat us. We left and went to Chinatown for authentic Chinese food.  Oh, yeah, and the decor, sure it's kitschy but the rainshow looks more like a firesprinkler went off. There was no band playing.
author: Mark S.

description:
I first started coming here in elementary or junior high. My parents always took me to Happy Hour. Tons of food for me, and cheap drinks for the adults.

As an adult, I still enjoy coming here. I love the live band that comes out on the boat. Sure, it's just a pool with fake rain and a cheesy band, but it never ceases to amaze me.

The food is delicious. It's a bit pricey, but as I don't come here often, well worth it. My favorite is the coconut shrimp. No other place compares!

Their drinks are delicious... and I love the waiters/waitresses. So friendly.
author: Eina L.

description: Really cool place. We made reservations and I would suggest that to anyone because when we left the line was 20 people deep.  Food was exceptional and the drinks were fun and tasty. Service was great, our waiter was friendly and attentive.
author: Brian K.

description: Frankly I'm really amazed places like this exist in SF.  Food was mediocre, atmosphere was super tacky and reminded me of a really bad wedding you get stuck at, and at the end of the day we got charged $7 per person "cover charge" so we could watch the live music.  I'm surprised about the location too, because the Fairmont is one of the classiest hotels around. This restaurant somewhat cheapens the Fairmont brand for me.  Never again.
author: Wayne S.

description: I went during happy hour with a friend, and it was a pretty cool experience, though I don't think I'd ever become a regular. The atmosphere is pretty unique and fun, with the pool in the center, the simulated rainstorms and the tropical feel, and the specialty drinks which match the theme. I liked that there was a happy hour buffet but the food was a little too deep-fried for my taste. The drinks were expensive, but that could be expected.
author: Cyrelle D.

description: This is a perfect place to go when you want to forget it all.  The interior made me think of the tiki room at disneyland but without singing birds.  I came for their famous happy hour between 5-7 and I loved it.  The eight dollar all you can eat buffet is a must even if you hate buffets. There is a chef who can make you a custom veggie stir fry, fruits, cheeses, egg rolls, crab rangoons and short ribs. Certain drinks can also be had for cool happy hour discount prices.
author: Amber L.

description: I stop by for one thing here.  The Laua Flow (it is a fish bowl size drink -- it comes with two straws.  They said its for two, but I don't share.  It almost guarantees a great night ahead).  Cheers!
author: Sherman H.

description:
So i came to this place out of a random suggestion and at first i was impressed...you walk in and instantly feel like your on a pirate ship and all the crazy fruity drinks giv es the illusion your on this crazy pirate island getaway...
HOWEVER! The wait staff and prices ruined everything.
We first walk in and go to the bar area, we order a "lava bol" and sit down at a table that had no sign on it that said that we couldn't sit there or that we would be charged 5 bucks to sit there!
Then, this incredibly rude waitress barges in starts setting up the table and i tell her that we ordered a drink at the bar and she yells "I KNOW" then storms off.
Then, I see our drink at the bar so i get up to go get it since she was no where to be found and it was right there!
So i grab the drink and she magically appears and says "what?? are you in a hurry??" um...ya bitch. i got drunken priorities tonight.
Then she says "I need a credit card to keep the tab open" and i tell her we just wanted the one drink so we'll pay cash. Then she grunts again, storms off, comes back with the bill with the god damn 5 bucks on it and proceeds to STAND there as if we're supposed to pay her immediately. as awkward as that was we paid and she took off.
Look, I realize i look young but my money is as good as anyone elses and how DARE you treat me so rudely as if u think my age tells if i'm gonna "dine and ditch" or not.
So then we meet up with friends, dance a little bit and the vibe starts to get better...the band in the middle of the water on a boat was a pretty cool little set up.
Then we go back to the bar to get another drink and the SAME bartender we ordered from before says "I need ids" which he didn't even consider asking when we FIRST got there...whatever. so i go get my id, then he looks at it...takes it away and proceeds to stare at it for 5 fucking minutes trying to do math in his head to realize i turned 21 LAST JUNE then he keeps looking around as if i'm trying to fuck with him, compares my id with my friends, then i guess a little spark went off in his pathetic little brain and he gave it back.
We ordered a soco shot clean with lime juice....and it comes back in a glass, no juice and with a lime....hm. no!
Then he fixes it and 3 shots and 2 beers ends up being 50 fucking dollars.
I;m sorry...this would have been a really cool little escape but i've never left a bar so pissed and disrespected in my entire life.
author: Stacy L.

description: Why do people like this place?? Seriously. What is the appeal? Is it the fanny packs, the 3 year olds whose parents can't keep track of their 34 shopping bags, the weak expensive drinks, the questionable "buffet", or the sad silent lonely business trip guys drinking their 4th Hurricane? This place feels like a sad Disneyland ride.
author: Wendy C.

description: This place has a really nice scenery for special events--birthdays, etc. It was packed on a Saturday night, we had to wait in line for 45 minutes. But in the end, it's worth it. There was a band performing in the center of a pool! Definitely less like a club, rather more like a place for having chats with some soothing tropical drinks!
author: Janet L.

description: came here for the happy hour with the girls, it was cool..atmosphere wise. the drinks were pretty good, had the tonga tart with vodka, it was prettty good! the food for happy hour buffet, was ok, bu ti guess thats what you get for paying 9.99, right? the macademia fried rice was my favorite, the garlic noodles weren't too bad either. wasn't too big of a fan of the fried chicken wontons or the eggrolls, felt like it needed more filling. other than that, it was an okay experience!
author: Stella J.

description:
Before you read ahead, please realize we never ended up going in...

I had made reservations for me, my boyfriend and his dad who was in town for the weekend. We showed up about 10 minutes early for an 8pm reservation on Friday night, and were very excited for the cheesy atmosphere and "girly" drinks to come. 

First off, there were two lines at the door - one for hotel guests and one for those with reservations. No one was in either line, but I felt like we were entering a club and those with "table service" get priority. The sign said "$7 cover after 8pm" so we asked if we still had to pay it since A) it was still before 8pm, if only by a few minutes, and B) we had a reservation for dinner (and would already be guaranteed to spend $$ inside) .They told us yes. No explanation. No apology. I was baffled. Yes, I had read that sometimes there is a cover here, but nowhere when I made the reservation did it mention this, on the restaurant's site or opentable or anywhere else. We were extremely disapointed and ended up walking away, not because we can't afford $7/person, but because $21 automatically added onto our tab makes an expensive dinner even more ridiculously expensive. And no one had told us beforehand. They weren't even nice about it. Does that mean I could have made the reservations for 7:30? Clearly I should have booked elsewhere. ANNOYING!
author: Natalie H.

description: Went here with another couple looking for a fun environment. This definitely was cheesy, quirky and fun and right up our alley. The staff was friendly and greeted us promptly. The band played which was nice and our drinks were really good. The biggest problem here is the food.  I was ready to pay for good food, but it was super disappointing. I even tried two other people's entrees to get a sample taste, and theirs was just as disappointing with barely any flavor. The mongolian beef tasted the best of all four dishes. I would recommend this restaurant for the environment, and i'll stick to happy hours, but I won't take out of town guests here again because of the food.
author: Jen S.

description: I went to this place a while ago when a friend from out of town was visiting. Okay the inside of the place is kind of corny, but I thought it was cool. Rainstorms...Live Band...Good stuff. Other than that I wasn't really impressed. The food wasn't horrible, but it wasn't memorable either. It is way overpriced and we had to get quite a few dishes to feed the six of us. The drinks are AWFUL! We shared a few Scorpion Bowls and they were hard to swallow. So we ordered Mai Tai's--and they were pretty much liquid heartburn. Burned so bad. We're a group of boozers and I don't think any of us finished a drink. Sure it's a cool place. Do I think it was worth 70 bucks a person? Absolutely not.
author: Shaun V.

description: I'll admit I only wanted to go here because of Anthony Bourdain's recommendation, and I'm glad I did.  There are very few places you walk into where you immediately feel calm and relaxed.  This is one of them.  A great band playing soothing melodies in a boat in the middle of an old pool.  An upscale tiki bar atmophere, where gentle rains cool the air every so often.  Drinks in awesome glasses that pack a punch.  I hear the food is OK, but I only went to get my tropical drink on.  The service is slow, but that kind of fits the atmophere... I'm not in a rush when I'm at the Tonga Room, and you shouldn't be either.
author: Andy F.

description:
Last time I was at the Tonga Room for happy hour, the all-you-can-eat buffet was free with drink purchase.  Now it's $8 + purchase of a drink?  WTF happened?  Free was a somewhat fair price for the food, which they swipe off the banquet tables as soon as the clock strikes 7pm, whereas eight bucks seems like about nine bucks too much.

But a visit to the Tonga Room isn't about the food.  It's about the atmosphere.  It's about the experience.  It's about the indoor thunderstorms, and the live band playing on a floating raft.  It's about little paper umbrellas in your Mai Tai.  It's about waving Hello to the people at ClubOne when you make the long trek to the Fairmont bathroom.  It's about going once a blue moon, but never more.
author: Hannah J.

description:
This place is a hoot.  Definitely strikes me as a tourist trap.  The place is a cross between a tropical island and the Pirates of the Caribbean ride at Disney.  

Met my family members there and was immediately struck by the thunderstorm raining in the middle of the restaurant.  This was the intro for the cover band, which floated out on a boat to the middle of the rainstorm swimming pool.  Funky band, too.  Did everything from Bobby Darren to Queen.  Lead singer looked like a young Chinese-American guy, other members of the band also seemed Asian, fitting in with the Tongan theme, sorta.  They totally made you want to get up and boogie.  My 10-year-old niece just loved them.

The food was remarkably good given the level of cheese in the decor.  I had a duck breast which was tender and moist.  The mongolian beef tasted really good as well.  

Prices were on the higher side for what you got, but that's to be expected at a place like this, where it's all about the decor.  Worth trying at happy hour, I think.

I would have given this 4 stars except for the fact that parking there is a NIGHTMARE.  I had to actually park in the Fairmont Hotel parking garage, which charges $5 per every 20 minutes!  Maxes at $50!!!  I ended up paying more for parking than for dinner.  Note to self:  park a few blocks away for much less and walk or take the cable car up.
author: Julie T.

description:
Look. If you know the first thing about the Tonga Room, you know the point isn't the food. It's the kitsch: tiki torches, wooden tribal carvings, indoor thunderstorms, smarmy bands sailing their barge on the tempestuous sea while crooning "Sail-ing... Takes me awaaaaaaaaaaaaay, to where I'm going...." And the point is also, of course, the drinks -- the giant, colorful, umbrella'ed, bucket size drinks for two (or in some cases, even four). So you could eat, and you probably should, because otherwise the hangover from those frothy libations would be wicked.  And you could do worse, but (does it need saying?), you could do better too. 

Tonga bills its fare as Pacific Rim comfort food, or some such improbable description. On my recent visit, I got Mongolian Beef stir fry with crispy noodles, which arrived in a thick soupy brown sauce that no way ever touched a wok, some weird mushrooms and a smattering of crinkle cut carrots (I think). My description sounds bad, but it was actually pretty good, in the way that pizza-when-you're-drunk is. Maybe their seafood dishes are better and more refined, but this stuff was basically fast food with an elevated price tag -- all main dishes looked to be in the high-20s to 30 dollar range. 

So again, I'm telling you, visit, but not for the food. And if you are in the area, do it quick: I have read that the Fairmont wants to turn this place into another bland grey soulless hotel restaurant, which (no matter how little Tonga's food has to recommend it) would be a great loss of one of the time-honored charming oddities that makes SF so unique.
author: Jenny B.

description:
OMG!  I can't believe I got suckered into going to Tonga.  And on a Saturday night!  Argh.  First, the theme is tiki....nuff said.  Second, the service is horrible.  Lastly, me thinks this is the place where old guys pick up old chicks (I looked totally out of place!).  

Oh - and the food sucks too.  

Sorry for all those who wrote great reviews.  This was not my cup of tea....
author: James B.

description: If you like the taste of a lobster's poo, served by an alien with a spiked hairdo... don't go to the Tonga room. But if you like a thatched roof Tonga Village built around an old swimming pool with lots of plastic tropical foliage, retro kitsch, and an appearance that appeals to the most undiscriminating of tastes, then "pig out" at the Tonga Room. Because in spite of the tawdry ambiance, the food is very good, and the drinks, though pricey, are potent. And if you like to listen to elevator music, the band (which is dragged out into the pool on a barge) will play it loud enough for you to dance to it.. Be prepared to spend some bucks, however, or just leave when your finished by going to the bathroom which is located in another part of the hotel.
author: richard w.

description:
I'm not entirely sure whether to give this place 2 or three stars...debating three due to the prior review regarding the history, etc....but i think ill have to stick with 2 due to the quasi tackiness and shitty service we had.
Obviously yeah, similar to rainforest but more polynesian, and this place was a more in your face tacky i'd say (the chair i wanted to sit in had very creepy stains too...)
we came here after top of the mark, and were asked if we wanted food or happy hour..we said happy hour, then our waitress rudely told us that no, happy hour was over, when we inquired as to what the specials were...ok, well perhaps the hostess shouldnt have offered it--and the waitress was fairly rude in general the entire time...along with being very MIA..she made it pretty clear she was miserable, which tips are involved, i'd disguise if i were she...
my 'chichi' was good, but not blended and mostly ice...and once the clock hits 8, they want $5 entertainment fee from everyone for what i can tell is god awful music and old creepers dancing...my friend had been there before and said the entertainment was pretty awful, which is fine, but if its not busy and we're already paying full price for drinks, must we really pay $5 for painful performances?? (we didnt, we left)
also, the ambiance of the hallway en route to the tonga room left much to be desired..its fine its in the basement, but at least make the hallways there less depressing!
author: Danielle J.

description: They do have a worthwhile happy hour.  A buffet of well-made dim sum type foods along with fruits and veggies, and an alcoholic drink for about $13 isn't bad, and of course, you get peace and tranquility of the rainforest.
author: ellyk E.

description:
I will give them the fact that the decor is AWESOME and I would undoubtedly live in that bar and wear a pirate hat every day and be very happy if only...their service didn't BLOW. I mean really.

We sat at a table int he bar area for my friend's 21st Bday. The guys went to get drinks and got scolded by the bartender for not ordering from a waitress.  But they did in fact get their drink. I elected to wait for this mystery waitress. Nothing. So I went to the bar where I was told to return to my table and order from the waitress. The wait continues. Long story short, over the next 20 minutes my friend went to the bar two more times (still no waitress although we tried to flag her over every fucking time she passed by) until they finally agreed to make my drink.

Vodka cranberry. Poured in the exact opposite order?!?!?!?! The bartender poured in juice, then vodka, then shoveled in ice. Ok....um sure, I guess it's all going into the same place? Of course there wasn't nearly enough ice in the drink and just in case I didn't get the "we suck at our job" message he also did not give me a straw and ran off so I had to flag him down for a straw. All that for $11.50. 

So yes, the place looks really cool, and maybe it was just the day of the shitty staff so I will give it another try but the experience last  night was complete crap. 

My friends liked their gigantic volcano-looking rum beverage thing which I will agree looked really cool.
author: Tatyana D.

description: The closest thing I've seen that mimics the Kahiki. The food looked to be the typical asian/polynesian fried goodness. The drinks, however, are the highlight of the menu in terms of presentation. The actual taste though leaves a lot to be desired (Mai Tai). The band was surprisingly good which got people in the mood to dance, which might be the saving grace of this cheesy establishment...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Hmm. Mixed emotions about this place. Better to rate it as a 2.5.
I went here for the first time on Saturday night for a friend's birthday gathering. Got there kinda late, so I was not asked for a cover or entertainment charge (I guess that is tacked onto the host's bill?). Walking into the lobby of The Fairmont is pretty impressive and I loved the tiki theme/thunderstorm gimmick at the Tonga Room, but the cover band and the clientele started to bum me out after about an hour. I witnessed all the characteristics of bad club dancing (excessive finger pointing, side-to-side marching/stepping, light kicking/leaping into the air) to the listener-friendly cover tunes of '70-'80's rock and soul. It was like being at a bad wedding or at club night on a cruise ship. On the other hand, the aforementioned clientele seemed to genuinely have a great time, so who am I to judge? Maybe I just needed to have some more drinks to make it enjoyable. (but if you HAVE to drink to make it enjoyable, is it worthwhile? again...the mixed emotions thing)
Drinks are expensive so you may as well make the most of it and get a themed drink instead of your old boring rum and Coke.
In closing: Not a bad choice if you are looking to entertain a wide variety of ages for maybe 2 hours. Even grandma would be comfortable. Music volume is acceptable. Otherwise, try to avoid.
author: Barbara K.

description:
DO NOT GO FOR THE FOOD!!!  REPEAT...DO NOT GO FOR THE FOOD!!  Go for the laughs!  This is the cheesiest place I've been in SF.  When I first went I was pissed off that they insulted my culture and misused my namesake but then all of the sudden lights went on and this funky boat came floating out in the center of the restaurant and the funniest, cheesiest, wacky 80's/90's cover band started singing...ON THE FLOAT BOAT!! hahahaha.  There were middle aged white people trying their hardest to stay on beat while they jittered and jumped around or what they think is dancing...lol.  The food was so gross so we tossed that aside and started ordering these big huge drinks that were so good.  We had a blast cracking up.  So now when we are in the area we pop in after we're a little buzzed to show up the rhythmless dance floor and die laughing at the float boat with a terrible live band before moving on to an actual establishment....hahahahahaaha.

3 stars for pure CHEESE!
author: Alicia K.

description: I can't understand the bad reviews? What the heck? This place is magical, majestic, and marvelous! A step back to a wonderful time that I doubt we will see again. This place is part of America's national heritage, even if it hasn't been recognized yet. I have been going here for 12 years now and still love it! Celebrating friends birthdays and other events is always uber fabulous here. It should be a historic landmark.I guess it is not closing now? Wonder why does San Francisco keep allowing the city to let its uniqueness disappear for luxury condos that no one is buying? My friends and I swear we can sense the ghosts of the many now-deceased movie stars that frequented there. The lagoon was originally a swimming pool called the Terrace Plunge, opened in 1929 and christened with a dive by actress Helen Hayes. In 1945, Metro Goldwyn Mayer's leading set director, Mel Melvin, made it to what is is today. The Tonga Room. Along with the Polynesian décor and fabulous thunder,lighting, and rainstorm effects, it's got an exceptional dance floor, built from the remains of the SS Forester, a four-masted lumber schooner that sailed regularly between The City and the South Sea Islands in the early 1900s. The best I have ever danced on... better than the Waldorf-Astoria or Maxim's because it is a whole lot funner!
author: T J.

description: Local strongly suggested this place for a unique TIKI drink, but on Monday night it was just a cycle of rain shower, funky drinks and even funkier faux Chinese food. Hummm... guess you had to be there to be funk-y-fried.
author: miriam b.

description: What happened to Tonga Room? Not only they increased their happy hour buffet prices ($13 i believe, with purchase of drinks), they also took away the bbq ribs!! WTH!  It was the only reason why i come here often. NOT anymore.  Now their buffet is crap.  They serve fried rice, noodles, and tiny little wontons, veggie egg rolls, and fruits.  How disappointing!!
author: Jessica N.

description: Here's the deal on the the Tonga Room. Go for the drinks and the atmosphere. There's a pool, indoor thunderstorms, live band on a floating raft, dance floor on the deck of a pirate ship, all in the basement of a luxury hotel. You have to appreciate that this place really hasn't changed in fifty years and the experience is as authentic as an inauthentic Tiki bar from the post-war era can get. So keep in mind that back then, Polynesian couldn't be separated from Chinese, and that the food is an "Americanized" version of Chinese that was an exotic departure from the typical June Cleaver meatloaf or Alice's pork chops and applesauce. The food scks. I'll be honest. But throw back a few zombies and you'll be dancing the Cha-Cha in no time.
author: Coren D.

description: Great Experience!  Wonderful music.  Dance floor.  Bar.  Of course it's a theme restaurant - so don't be surprised.  Visit if you want a taste of Hawaii - not totally authentic, but fun.  Cute drinks and cool rainstorms.  Don't forget to get the longer straws!  Food is pricy, but service was excellent.  And if you come for dinner, they have a photographer that takes pictures of their guests as a momentum.  Would go again.
author: shirley h.

description: I loved the interior and the fake rain storms. The design of the place really made me feel as through I was back in Hawaii.  The food was solid and the drinks were too.
author: John G.

description: I'd rate this place a 3, but the fake tropical storm pushes it up a notch.  How is that not cool, right?  Otherwise, this is the place to go if you want toys in your overpriced drinks.
author: Kyla B.

description: Service with a snarl at this toilet of a restaurant in the bowels of the Fairmont.  Weak, overpriced drinks, bad food, and a poorly executed theme make this a typical tourist trap.  Avoid at all costs.
author: Aaron A.

description:
Ok, so I came here for my birthday with about 6 friends.

The atmosphere was FANTASTIC, loved the music and loved the feel of the place. 

The drinks were great too :) Mi gusta!

The dinner was pretty pricey. We got an appetizer and I was not impressed with the temp. of the food.  The taste was good, but when it came out at room temp, I was not a fan.

Also, a little disappointed that they did not specify when we made reservations that there was a 7$ cover charge per person for the evening, we found out on our bill, the waiter did not even share that info with us, so that was a little upsetting.

I really enjoyed this place, I would have given it 4 starts if the waiter were a little nicer, the food was hotter and the cover charge was told to us before the bill.
author: Dom M.

description: You've got to give this place 5 stars for the audacity.  I love it!  The $8 all-you-can-eat happy hour is the best deal in town, and perfect for a pre-Sutter Street theater snack.  You can get as full as you want on that 8 bucks.  They have recently added a real live chef at the stir fry, so everything is just that much fresher than before.  And the thunder storms?  Who are these grinches who are complaining???  It is amazing this architectural wonder escaped the ravages of the redecorators all these years.  A San Francisco must see.
author: Robert M.

description: Yes, this place is cheezy, but unique.  Everything is a little over-priced.  You pay more for the ambiance than the food.  DON'T get dessert here, it is horrible, but this place is nice to come for drinks or cocktails.
author: H. A.

description:
funky fabulous fun ! I don't mind paying 10 bucks for a good drink and I don't mind the decor they've kept since the 70's -- campy good tiki style. you almost feel like you're on vacation somewhere in Polynesia.

do be careful maneuvering the Hills of Nob after a night of tiki lounging -- you don't want to end up at the bottom of California St. sprawled on your arse
author: Prima D.

description: I really like this place. It's very entertaining. Drinks are super awesome, but they are a little overpriced. Look forward to going back.
author: Brenda F.

description: Too touristy and very expensive. Cost us $70 for a dish and a drink. they also have a per person charge for entertainment. Not going there again. Food and drinks are below average
author: Mona s.

description:
a couple of friends and i came here on a Thursday night. when we arrived i couldn't help but laugh! this place wasn't what i expected. AT ALL. the crowd was a bunch of old smug people and families. We ordered some drinks and talk about a rip off! there's like an inch worth of alcohol and the rest is ice. we were not even half way through with our drinks and the waiter hands us the bill...exsquezze me?! what if we wanted to order another?? why not WAIT until we're finished and ASK us if we want another and if we decline THEN give us the bill. when i looked at the check there was a $7 entry fee, the total amount of our drinks and then TA DA!!!! a $7 entertainment fee. Call me cheap, but $14 just to SIT in the Tonga room?!?!  COME ON! Ive been to other bars that have given me better service/drinks than this for HALF the price! 

if you like being ripped off, by all means, spend your money on a worthless environment that doesn't deliver what they charge.
author: Tedi O.

description: Over priced sugary drinks. 3 stars because the decor is worth checking out at least once.
author: Gary Y.

description:
Y'all. This place is so bomb. Ok. Granted I went with my boyfriend's family sans my actual boyfriend at like 10 pm just in time for last call and the last songs of the delightful adrift band, but it totally blew my mind. The comparisons to disneyworld are, to my mind, incredibly apt. It's so nice looking... and yet so unbelievably tacky.
Also, I am kind of a connoisseur of the ridiculous, and I adore any place that is not trendy (the kitschiness of this place is like the anti-matter of trendy) but it is still worth a stop for anyone who values the absurd.
Long live "rainstorms" over "lakes"!!
author: Jessi C.

description: I went to the Tonga room and I must say people must be easily amused and entertained because everyone was clapping and taking pictures of water falling from the ceiling into a pool in the middle of the restaurant that I guess is supposed to simulate rain (it sounds more interesting than it is). There is a floating stage where bands perform which is kind of cool but that's it. The food was just ok I had a $24 Singapore Noodles which was just ok, I've had better Singapore noodles or chow mei fun I think it's called for less than $5 at a take out Chinese restaurant. Service was mixed, I walked in, didn't make reservations but did get seated right away but at the lounge which has smaller tables which was fine but then the hostess who seated me with my party of three others gave us one menu without any explanation and still I was fine with that. Our waitress was nice and friendly, older Asian woman, I ordered a drink a scotch neat Macallan for anyone who cares and it arrived in a glass that looked opaque but only in certain spots, I rubbed my finger on the inside of the glass only to smear some kind of greasy substance and I found that absolutely repulsive. I walked up to the bar and kindly asked for another drink because my glass was dirty and the bartender referred me to the waitress so I unhappily went to my waitress and showed her the glass to which she was very apologetic and replaced the drink with me looking on of course. Through all of this I didn't make a fuss or complaint because I was just too tired and just wanted to go home. Needless to say I would never return, it's overpriced, mediocre food and entertainment for those who are easily amused, and I had some of those people with me.
author: J B.

description:
Five stars for drunken debauchery and 1 star for karate kick to the neck/babymaker type hangover. Woof. Talk about really putting the tiki in your Riki Tiki Tavi! This place serves some strong shots into unassuming umbrella drinks. BEWARE! Its like a college bar that serves hunch punch...you girls know what I am talking about. That sickeningly sweet punch that knocks you on your butt and makes beer goggles look like 3-D Fantasy glasses. Yeah....its that great. 
Pound a scorpion bowl, mai tai, and half a Hawaiian sunset and you are bound to put on your dancing shoes and join the conga line during an embarrassing rendition of Shaina Twain's "Man I Feel Like a Woman" to the horror and delight of your coworkers. Don't let anyone bust out their iPhone...you will surely regret it. 
If you come here...you will by all measures get lei'd. The bartender Shin guarantees it. Just don't constantly scream his name and wave wildly to get his attention and order 5 drinks at a time because he doesn't like it. Trust me.
author: Stacy T.

description: Ok, people, yes, its overpriced. But it rains inside, complete with thunder. That's worth at least $2. The band, while floating, will take requests. But, as a long time visitor to this place, have the photographer whose been there since I was 4 take your picture. It seriously is the most flattering, gorgeous photo you will ever have. Its ridiculous how beautiful you will look.
author: Noelle Q.

description:
the volcano bowl was definitely one of those things i wanted to do just to say i've done it. i make better jungle juice at home. not to brag, but my Pink Panty Dropper is making quite a name for itself!

the tonga room is dark and tacky, and doesn't quite seem to fit the fairmont hotel. regardless, i feel drawn to it - could it be the mystical power of the islands? perhaps the rumbling thunderstorms? probably it's the close proximity to my apartment, but who's keeping track!? tonga, baby!
author: Valerie N.

description: This review is for dinner....Just not my thing for the price.  However, there was great service.  It is kind of "vegasy" in decor with a hefty price (ie. $22 for veggie chow mein).  If you have out of town guests and they really want to go, let them go without you.
author: Jen W.

description:
I am sure you have heard that the tonga room's days are numbered.
the old man and i came here for puu puus and drinks last night.  i was happy to see that that it was pretty busy for a wednesday evening.  
I was also surprised and happy to see kids there with their families, dancing and taking pictures of the band.  everyone was definitely having a good ole time.
the crowd was supportive of my uncoordinated husband when we stepped out to dance.  
despite how busy the place was, our server, the photographer and barbacks were super helpful and old school in their style of service.  
i imagined all of the generations of beautifully coifed and styled san franciscans waltzing and lindy hopping and swimming laps and synchronized swimming while wearing swimming caps with vinyl flowers... hot sailors and officers on weekend leave dancing like fred astaire with saucy red heads in flirty skirts while their garter held panty hose peeked out as they twirled.  it was fun to think that i get to be a part of that history.
any whoosit.. GO!  make it a special night and have fun.
thanks for reading.
author: yayoi s.

description: This place is lame for a Happy Hour!  Okay so the buffet is $9 and all you can eat with the purchase of one of their drinks but the service cancels that out.  If you go, look to wait at least 30 mins for someone to come by and ask for your order and don't even think about going up to the bar cause they won't let you.  The novelty wears off in about 10 minutes.  The buffet leaves little to be desired so the chances of you going for seconds or thirds probably won't happen.  There are just so many more places in the city to go for a Happy Hour.  Maybe next time if a polynesian theme tickles my fancy, I'll give Trader Vic's a try.
author: Kirsten M.

description: I would say its a place u need to go to once, and after that your good. Its a touristy spot, they charge a cover on top of realllllyyyy expensive beers and cocktails. The decorations are cool, and its a spacious place. Its hard to fight the urge to rip your shirt off and dive in the pool after a few of their lava bowls however, so be warned, because drinking and swimming do not mix!
author: Chris P.

description: Drinks were ok, however service was ATROCIOUS. Waitress was very rude and at the end of the night our bill was added up incorrectly, she was very unaccommodating and refused to fix the mistake. Needless to say, will not be returning and will not recommend to others...
author: A.R. H.

description:
i love the indoor storm here, and they have quite a tiki decor. but for the same price you can have much better drinks and food at trader vic's. also the last time i was there about a month ago, there was a mouse on the bar! i didn't imagine this because the bartender tried to catch it, with the help of a couple of patrons. the bartenders looked rather embarassed, and rightfully so.

i know the building is over a hundred years old, and stuff but i still want to see their health inspection report!

oh, and the mouse got away...
author: Will L.

description: It's official, Tonga Room is the worst restaurant, with the worst service!!!
author: B R.

description: This bar was a great place to hang for a few hours. The atmosphere is outstanding- the best designers really make it feel as though you are on the beach. It rains every 30 minutes and it's surreal. Through yelp each person in your party gets a free drink too- so make sure to show your server the coupon on your phone through the yelp app. Food is a bit overpriced, but the ambiance certainly makes up for it! Dishes are large and can be split easily between two people. The band starts at 8pm. Parking at the fairmont is outrageous, so park across the street at intercontinental- it's half the price.
author: Carly K.

description: This place is alright I guess. I mean it is a total tourist trap. If you like rain forest cafe then you will like this place. It's all about the atmosphere here. If you want to go out for a night with some friends this is prolly not the place for you. There will be children from 2 to teens and a larger older crowd. Definitely not for the 20 somethings. Their appetizers were good, but pricey.... same thing with the drinks, but what do you expect from a place like this?
author: Tyler D.

description:
Can't say enough good about this place.I haven't been here since the 70's with my parents and it has only gotten better!!!  What prompted me to go was a coupon on Facebook.  I went with 4 other girlfriends for a "girls night out" 2 weeks before Christmas.  As were were parking one of the women read the "Fine print" on the coupon and it had expired 2 weeks ago!  When we got to the hostess stand, the hostess honored them no questions asked.  Further One of us need a special diet and she said" I will speak to the Chef , but we want you to be happy"  I LOVE THAT ATTITUDE!!!  We had a waterfront table as we sipped Mai Tais and ate dinner with the thunder and rainstorms as well as the band.  Dancing was fun and there were lots of other people of all sorts who joined in.  Many company Christmas parties were going on and yet the service was very attentive. To top the night off, a photographer came by and took a B&W pic of us and sold it to us 1/2 hr later in a  matt with the Fairmount on the cover.  Also individual matchbooks wit heath of our pics.  Very old school and fun. 

 The food could have been stepped up a notch, but I must admit I would come back ten if it stayed the same.  TONS 'O FUN!!! Great decor and ambience
author: Allison L.

description: I have been here twice now and be fore was atleast 8 yrs ago. I really enjoyed the food. TASTY. I thought the price reasonable for a nice dinner and atmosphere. The live music was a blast.  We had the noodles, beef and seafood. The rolls, yum. The Tonga Room is a themed restaurant, I really liked it and will go again.
author: Diana H.

description: My cousin had their graduation dinner here. I've heard about this place on the Food Network, so I was curious to see how good/bad it was. I passed up on the alcohol and opted for their Innocent Passion instead. I forgot what was in it, but it was good stuff. For dinner, my aunt and I split on a Tonga platter and an order of Huli Huli chicken. The best of the two was definitely the platter. I actually ate more of that than the chicken. I had to cut off a star when it was time for dessert. The Flaming Volcano wasn't as spectacular as I thought it would be. I could taste the alcohol that provided the "flame" while eating it. I knew I should have ordered the sticky rice instead! But despite my disappointment, the place isn't too bad. The live band played good music and had people on the dance floor in a matter of minutes. I keep hearing about renovations being due here, which isn't a bad idea seeing that it's pretty dated. Whatever the replacement is, it definitely needs to top this. It would be nice if the prices weren't so high too. But then again, it's the Fairmont. What more do you expect?
author: Rhia R.

description: I can't believe it took LaughingSquid talking of their demise to help me discover this place. This place makes a mean MaiTai and Pina Colada. The food was pretty good too.
author: Keith P.

description: I had dinner before Junior Prom here. Being able to come back to cheesey tiki and reminisce over that night over twenty years ago (!!) is worth five stars alone. I love the little dance floor, the periodic thundershowers and the strongish drinks.
author: Lise L.

description: I went with a coworker for the first time last week and we are going again today...can't wait for the tropical feel.  Just shared ribs last time...COMIN BACK FOR MORE, delicious. Services was good too.
author: Christina G.

description: I have to say I love this place. Not because the drinks are incredibly strong or the food blows me away... its the pure kitche value! Where else can you dance to a cheesy cover band singing ABBA floating in a pool?? Gotta take the guests here or anyone turning 21.
author: Erica B.

description: Went here for "dinner" for Sr ball a few years ago expecting to eat dinner. However chow mein for $14!? Instead we indulged ourselves in the happy hour where we had to buy a minimum of 1 drink per person (virgin daiquris for everyone! since we were all only 18 at the time). We also got the eat in the buffet which consisted of potstickers, noodles, etc. The food was okay, I think the scenery was really nice. There were bamboo huts, exotic looking plants, a floating boat in the middle for music!, we didnt end up staying for the live music but I think it would've been cool. I'd defintely go here again for happy hour but I may go elsewhere for an actual meal. Cool place though!
author: Miss H K.

description: I loved the Tonga room. I rains, they have tons of fruit drinks...let me warn you that those fruity drinks tend to lack tastiness...but it was still a good time with good friends. It's large and quite empty so a great place to take over with your own party!
author: Cassy R.

description: This is a great place to visit.  I am not sure if I will go there again with my local friends but I do know that when I have visitors we will be going.  The happy hour buffet is $7 you can't beat that!  I think I loaded up 3 plates with nothing but spare ribs.  The drinks were so-so and a little on the sweet side, next time I will stick to beer, if you must have a tropical drink go for the tonga itch.  It's a good place to people watch, and watch the fake rain storm.
author: Erica N.

description: For complicated and sentimental reasons having to do with a Mac World party he threw in late 90's (complete with imported band from Seattle and friend diving in pool),  and his real affinity for tiki (not tacky), my visiting friend from Seattle insisted on the Tonga Room post his girlfriend's mom's 60th birthday..   Last time I went, it was reasonably empty.  Last night?   Packed.  Liked the tiki, didn't even mind the band that shifted smoothly from Gwen Stefani to Earth Wind & Fire.  Drinks a bit sweet for my taste, and a big old crowd, but it was fun enough.
author: Laurel B.

description: The original tiki bar. Nuff said....
author: Clifford S.

description: I have to say the band is AWESOME! The themed drinks remind me of some corny hut in Hawaii, even though I've never been, but they're cute nonetheless! We went for my dad's bday and had top notch service. This was a little over a year ago, but lets just say I still remember having a good time here... Even though it may be empty at times, this place is a San Francisco LANDMARK!
author: Eric A.

description: There's photographic evidence that I was at the Tonga Room after Beerfest. My great uncle that was a Navy Admiral took my great aunt here in the 50's when stationed in SF. That makes the Tonga that much cooler. It does feel strange to walk through the Fairmont after a few too many Bowls of tropical drink (whatever it may be), but it's pretty fun for those that don't take themselves too seriously.
author: Chris B.

description: Tacky and cheesy.  What's not to love?  If you don't take the place too seriously, you'll love it.  Go there with a couple of friends, grab a couple of scorpion bowls, watch and listen to the fake rain and have fun.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
the rain falls in parallel lines 
in the tonga room
author: Zachary S.

description: LOVED IT! Went for a 21 year old Birthday Bash and had so much. The best atmosphere, fun drinks and great music. The decor is the best and a SF landmark. The best well hidden secret and the best place for a party!
author: Katrena M.

description:
if i lived in san francisco i'd have every birthday party here.

i was a bit skeptical at first.  there's a fine line between awesome tiki and well not so awesome tiki.  but after mentioning we might go to a few people their reaction pretty much meant we had to go.

it was love at first sight.

dance floor on a ship?  check
thatched roofs?  check
tiki glasses? check
asian trail mix? check
rain storm?  check
a band that floats out on a raft to the middle of pool?  double check!
leis?  che...oh wait we didn't get one cause we didn't eat.  boooo!

the drinks were good, the paper umbrellas plentiful, and the waitress was super nice.

we looked at the menu ahead of time so we knew it was too pricey for us, but i would go back any time for the drinks.
author: jess e.

description: Holy crap, there's a pool in here. And even better, the band is perched right on top of a floating stage, complete with hydraulics. If you stay long enough, you'll find yourself dancing with the rest of the tacky people who find their way down here. This place is great for two reasons: 1. it's in the basement of the beautiful, pretigious Fairmont Hotel, and 2. it serves drinks out of a fishbowl with numerous straws. Out-of-towners are immediate targets for this, usually at the end of a crawl (we don't want to scare them right away). make sure to bring your camera, and be careful of the much older men.
author: Amanda C.

description: Yikes!   Touristy.   Terrible Food.   Cheesy and ugly.   And after we ate a big dinner complete with fruity drinks, they charged us a "cover charge" since we were there after 8 and the floating band in the middle of the swamp started playing.  NEVER go here.
author: laura a.

description: I got really and pleasantly drunk here by ingesting a few concoctions that came in a hollowed out pineapple. Then the Tonga Room closed and we ran around the Fairmont Hotel. By that time, things got blurry and we took a car service home and when I woke up, I had to have a very hungover lunch with my future in-laws just one day before I made an honest woman out of my hot hot girlfriend.
author: Ross G.

description: It's very 1960s tiki. That's a good thing, the drinks are more expensive here but I think that has a lot to do with the location.
author: Sharon M.

description:
have you ever been in the mood to go to a wedding but noone is getting married?
the tonga room is the dance party that is a wedding dance party minus all the speeches. a live band plays in the middle of a pool with simulated rain storms every half hour or so. the band plays all the classics and they're actually scarily similar to the original tracks.
the scorpion bowls are sort of gross in a sugar high way but are perfect for having a dumb night with friends.
so cheesy, yet so so awesome. food is really gross.
author: EM F.

description: The atmosphere here does make you feel like you are in the Polynesian islands. the happy hour here is good here for drinks and a small buffet. their selection of food were small but i did enjoy one of their dishes, the pineapple macadamia fried rice. i was hooked on that. i did order the strawberry daiquiri but i have to say i was disappointed. it tasted really bland with hints of rum in the background. i would have preferred to have more of a strawberry taste with the rum.  for happy hour you don't have to make a reservation unless you want to order from their dinner menu. the happy hour buffet is 9.99 per person and you have to have one drink minimum. it's definitely a tourist trap but if you haven't been there before as a San Franciscan just go and experience it.
author: Lynn P.

description: An unlikely location for such a kitschy place.  It's hard to drag locals in there, but visitors always get a kick out of it.  It was one of the first places I went to when I first visited SF, and I still enjoy it.
author: Bridget T.

description: I went here a few months back and oh boy is this place cheesy.  However I can see the appeal.  The drinks were mediocre and the menu was limited.   The only that I liked was the rainstorms that went off once in a while.
author: Kim N.

description: A nice looking place, looks like Disneyland without the fun, a bit on the fancy side, service can be a bit aggressive at times... All goes well until you get a bit drunk (their coktails are HUGE), and jump in that-big-pond-that-looks-like-pool with your friends, and you get kicked out of the place. Ok that thing reaaaaally looked like a pool, ok !
author: Steph S.

description: The huge 2 and 4-person drinks were a lot of fun. I also enjoyed the fake rain and the decor in general. One star off an otherwise 4-star place because the buffet was pretty bland. Overall a great time!
author: Stu M.

description: This place is terrible! The decor is uber cheesy (complete with a "thunder storm" that is actually a garden hose with holes in it that runs around the "lagoon", which is actually a dirty pool), the food greasy and disgusting and the service mediocre. For what you pay for the meal (about $350 for four of us - we did the pre-fixe) it's definitely not worth it. Maybe cocktails here for happy hour wouldn't be so bad but I'd never come back here for dinner. It will be interesting to see what becomes of this iconic SF landmark but anything would be better than the Tonga Room!
author: Sadia J.

description:
Waste of time and money. The "Island Groove Band" is one of those bad wedding bands that plays sleazy lounge lizard music that was terrible when it was new back in the seventies and the volume was way way way too loud. 
Do not come here if you want to talk. Do not excpect to see locals - it's full of tourists from the mid-west.
The food was ok ... except for deep fried lobster! Sacrilege! The drinks were ok .. but $10 a go!
The only good thing about the place was the pakistani waiter.

Oh, and upstairs in the looby they had pleasant Jazz but don't order the chocolate cake. They claim it's a speciality of the house but it was dry, stale and tastelesss, although the drinks were excellent!

Overall it was quite disappointing. If I could give it 1/2 a star I would!
author: norman w.

description:
I came to Tonga Room for its buffet happy hour, and I was slightly disappointed. The buffet is only $9.50, but the food selection is limited and not very good. Available items included:

Fried shrimp chips
Seaweed salad
Spring rolls
Macadamia Pineapple Fried Rice
Garlic Noodles
Fruit Salad 

The quality was just below average overall. 

We tried both drinks meant to be shared between two people for $13 each. The first was barely mixed and all the alcohol seemed to be on one side of the bowl. The 2nd one was ridiculously strong (a plus I guess). 

Can't say anything bad about the ambiance; the restaurant is very nicely done. If you're looking for a fun place to hang out, I'd come back later at night when the bar fills up. However, there are plenty of cheaper happy hour places, and I wouldn't recommend the buffet again.
author: Jeffrey T.

description: I was not excited to hit this place up, but I LOVED it.  Especially the live Barry Manilow cover band playing on a Wed. night.  Rainforest Cafe?  My ass.  This place was 'Elvis in Hawaii' cool.  The only problem is that it closed too early for my taste, so we had to crash a hotel ballroom party within the Fairmont.  Not too shabby.
author: Shannon M.

description: I went to the Tonga Room for my birthday in April. Pros of the tonga room are the fabulous and unique decor, the dancefloor! (which was really the reason for my choice), the yummy Huli Huli Chicken, and the yummier banana mouse dessert. The Tonga Room has a pool in the middle of the restaurant and a thunderstorm over the pool every hour; personally I would've preferred if the thunderstorm would've sprinkled over the restaurant patrons as well but what can you do. They have a live band after 8 which plays on a boat that goes back and forth across the pool and a dancefloor which shakes slightly with the thunderstorm. The tonga room is covered with hawaiian/pirate decor which comes together very nicely. The cons are the food and the price; except for the items mentioned above it's really not very good, especially the Mongolian Beef. Another con is the music as in my opinion it was far too loud and I had trouble talking to my guests. The set-up of the Tonga Room isn't the best if you're in a large group. The band and the pool are in the middle of the restaurant and take up a lot of space and the tables are to the side of the pool which would have been fine for a regular occasion but for my birthday I would've preferred an environment that was more intimate and secluded. As already suggest I would also recommend coming here for drinks or for a small meal with a small group but certainly do come.
author: Alla B.

description: Some of the best Chinese food I've ever had, and the atmosphere is fun! They have dancing on the weekend nights, and every so often it thunders and lightnings and the sound of rain fills the room (think Tiki Room at Disneyland.) This is a Polynesian themed place. Everyone should experience it at least once. Kids will love it, and it's a great place for a first date!
author: D. T.

description:
We went last Friday at 6 PM to the restaurant. My wife, son (5) and my Mother-in-Law had a great time. Unlike the reviews below, our service was quick (in and out in under an hour with MULTIPLE small bite plates coming out), and the food was way above average. The fried rice with sausage and shrimp was some of the best fried rice we ever had. The drinks were good. The price is high for everything, but you also pay for the ambiance, and anyplace that can keep my son entertained for an hour with rain and thunder so that the family can relax is great.

DON'T TEAR IT DOWN!
author: Renascence C.

description: If you're too cool for overpriced drinks with umbrellas and zombie cups, don't go.
author: Amy E.

description: Over-hyped and way overpriced.  The food is poor and the entertainment is not what you'd expect.  The cheezy lounge music they play is too loud and not fun to dance to unless you're over 65.  You also have to deal with the guy who will want to take a group photo and sell you the pictures -- the whole place is a racket.  I say they turn the Tongo room back into the Fairmont pool.
author: Blake B.

description:
dear tonga room,

you are just an abandoned hotel pool.

i'm so sorry.
author: steve m.

description: I had to give it at LEAST four stars just for the atmosphere.  But, if I were rating the waitress we had recently, it would be in the negative star range.  I feel sorry for someone who is that rude...they need to go home and pull out the stick out of their hole, but they're too busy being rude while working.  Tough times to have a job in this economy!  Anyways, we tried to ignore the rudeness and just have a good tiki time out on the town.  After trying a couple of the non-happy hour appetizers from our rude waitress (who tried to explain away her rudeness by suggesting it was someone else's fault), I would suggest sticking with the drinks only.  Save your cash.  Some of the drinks were great, but one of them had a distinct Vicks 44 aftertaste.  Whatever...get out there and support your local tiki bar...don't let this tiki wonderland close on our watch!!!
author: Julie T.

description:
With all the fuss to save the Tonga Room (The Fairmont wants to close it in favor of luxury condos) I really wanted to check it out before this treasure was lost.
I love the history of the place and how many people have wonderful stories about it (going there as a child, parents meeting there, etc.) but I went there for happy hour on Thursday and their much touted buffet was horrible.  Granted it did cost only $9.95 but gee, I would expect any food a nice hotel like The Fairmont would serve would be good.  It was so carb laden, rices, pastas, really awful egg rolls and some fried dumpling chicken thing (glad they labeled it, I never would have guessed it was chicken), all tasteless.  Why not charge $19.95 and serve something decent?
Later when the music started, a few people danced but the most touching thing was when two father - young daughter couples danced together.  In fact, there were a couple of large, multigenerational groups who were having a great time.  So, something special was going on there and do appreciate that.  
I understand that the hotel is thinking about relocating The Tonga.  I say let them, but make the experience more upscale, something to match the rest of the hotel.
If you go, go just for drinks.  They were fun and fruity to match the theme/decor and the service was quite good.
One final note, I don't think it's worth staying for the music.  We decided to - for the full effect you know.  A couple of the musicians looked like they might actually be Polynesian, so I wondered if we might hear some Hawaiian type music.  Nope, the first song was More Than a Woman.  Very 70's and campy.  Then again if you are in the mood for that...  :)
author: Kara H.

description: After a long girls day in San Fran we decided to grab some food at the Tonga Room. I've been to a lot of nice places and definitely do not mind paying a large check as long as the food and atmosphere are good. Needless to say the food was nothing special and pretty tasteless. The atmosphere was all right I guess, but nothing like some of these reviews talk it up to be. Would I go back? Absolutely not.
author: Alison R.

description: The Tonga Room is such a trip. I've never seen so many people just unabashedly dancing their asses off to bad 70s music. Go on a weekend night when they have a band playing and get a table near the dance floor for some great people watching. Sure, the drinks are over-priced, but all the fruit juices cover up the fact that they get the job done. You have to take this place, for what it's worth - a fun place to take your parents when they're visiting or for a kitschy birthday party.
author: Lindsey S.

description: This place is great for entertaining your friends. They got happy hour from 4-7pm, so for under $10, you have help yourself to a great buffet. I know it sound bad, yeah, who eats buffet, but not bad if you're in the neighboorhood for a quick bite and drink. During normal hours, they got live music and pretty good food. Just watch out, there's a cover for the music. Now, that's a rip-off...
author: Stanley K.

description: This place is so cheesy but that was part of it's charm.  I went here for the first time Saturday night.  Wasn't expecting a place like this inside the Fairmont hotel.  My friend said this was supposed to be a Polynesian restaurant.  The decor was cool...canoes, paddles, water moat in the middle of the restaurant and a live band on top of a floating island which gave the place a tropical, island feel.   The floating island would move back and fourth every hour with rain as an additional effect  (cheesy but entertaining LOL).  We all took kamikaze shots which is a double shot and you get to keep the to-tum shot glass as a souvenir.  Cool change of scene and good place for a large group/family oriented outing.  Food was okay but overpriced and they charged an extra $5 surcharge for the live entertainment.  Try it once definitely for a birthday...go back.  ummmm...I'll pass.
author: Diana L.

description: As a kid I was in love with the rainfall that goes off every so often and I still love it for its romantic and fun vibe it adds to the Tonga Room. The Tonga Room wouldn't be the Tonga Room without this feature. Take a seat, get a drink, and order a poo-poo platter.
author: Jen J.

description: I think we got lost and ended up at the Tonga Room in some sort of Polynessian meets American Porno decored cave.  There's a boat with a live band, interesting drinks (try the itch) and a small dance floor.  It rains inside the place which is fun but the band is either ON or OFF (they did a beyonce cover that made me want to scream).  A GREAT place to be wasted with friends for a guaranteed good time.
author: Jared F.

description: We went here on a random triple date with the bf's.  Wow, very interesting place but yet cheezy I must say.  It was a Saturday night, and the crowd was mostly old folks...i mean OLD...like 50's and 60's old, getting down on the dance floor with Lionel Richie old.  They had a live band but all the songs they was singing was sooooo outdated! Seems like my parents would have a great time here!! As for us, we made the best of it! We ordered the appetizers for two, and the portions were tiny! The food was ok, nothing special.  As for the drinks, they were soooo tiny!! The bf and I had the tropical drink for two, umm...was more like for one person...well at least the drinks were super strong!! All in all, including the appetizers, we had about 4 drinks each, and spent about $70 a person.  We had fun, but not our type of crowd, maybe it was just that night, but I don't know if I'll be coming back to Tonga Room anytime soon.
author: Lissie B.

description: The food and drinks are just so-so. The price tag is kind of high given that the food is nothing fantastic. But the ambiance is fun and I'd recommend coming here at least once.
author: Kat T.

description: This is one of my favorite spots in the world. It's kitchy. It's over priced. Four ways to approach this place to have fun: 1) You need to make a dinner reservation way in advance 2) get there early or 3) stand in a long line for happy hour 4) come late for an after dinner scorpion bowl with a gang of people to drink out of many long straws and have dessert. But it's a blast! The ambiance is great. There's thunder and lightening. The band starts at 8 and plays music you can dance latin to, like the cha-cha, rhumba, mambo and even a fox trot and swing. I like to get there when the band starts and leave around 9-9:30 when the band starts playing some other kind of music.  Don't come expecting a gourmet experience. This place is unlike anyplace else outside of 1960s Las Vegas. It's a little trip to Hawaii just down the block.  The food can be the best. The forbidden rice is lovely.  Get one of the fixed menus and take all the stress out of choosing your food tonight.
author: Figaro S.

description: I love it when a bar serves drinks with things you can accessorize yourself with.  The little origami umbrella that sits on top of cocktails makes an adorable tool to dress up your hair with.  Just be careful not to stab yourself with it, wouldn't be a good look anywhere.
author: Wendy H.

description: This is a funny place. What used to be a hotel pool is a funky dark restaurant with a pirate-tropical vibe. It's upscale cheesy. Definitely a funky place if you're in the mood for a different kind of vibe.
author: Sara W.

description: Interesting place, I must say.  I haven't been here in years, but the last time I was there, we had a great time.  Coming from Hawaii, I feel this place is pretty cheesy, but still fun.  I think it probably changes from night to night; sometimes fun sometimes not.  Come here with a bunch of friends when you're in a celebratory mood, and have high tolerance for the cheese factor.
author: Sarah F.

description:
ultra-corny-retro-neo-ironic-era-splicing good times, 
it rains blah blah, 
if you go more than once a year when the coolness of your own life needs to be put in a greater sociological perspective you have a sincere need for a reboot/vision quest/and/or mescaline addled trip into the center of the earth
author: saru s.

description:
4.5 stars for atmosphere, music, and delicious drinks! But only 2 stars due to the ridiculously high prices, rude and unfriendly staff, and the fact that the crowd is a combination of all ages, including small children and the elderly. Not the best place for a crowd in their 20's to really enjoy themselves.

If you're looking for a Hawaiian, or Tiki theme, check out Trader Sam's out on Geary and 26th! That place is awesome!
author: Alex M.

description: I HAVE to Yelp about the experience I had a the Tonga Room this past Saturday Night. It was my brother's 21st birthday Sunday, so at midnight we headed to the Tonga Room since we had rooms at the Fairmont for his first, celebratory legal cocktail. We headed in around 11:50, explained to the bartender it was his 21st. The bartender was extremely unfriendly. We said we knew we had to wait until 12:00 but we all wanted a round of the Mai Thai's they are supposedly famous for. He then told my  brother who was all smiles and excited for his 21st birthday cocktail, to get away from the bar and that he had to wait until 12:01. 12:01??? Talk about insulting! He then brought all of us "legals" our drinks and made my brother wait empty handed, away from the bar. It was humiliating and this was going to be his first legal drink, in a big irish family this is a pretty big moment for us. When he finally served my brother, the mai thai's were awful, and music was terrible as well. We didn't even finish the drinks and got out of there as quickly as possible. AND, since our bartender was so dilligent as to follow the most extreme laws in serving my 21 year old brother, it's pretty funny that he never checked my 18 year olds cousin's ID and readily handed her a big alcoholic mai thai. What an idiot. I'm sure the Tonga Room is festive and fun for some, but with all the incredible restsaurants in SF, I will certainly never go back. Steer clear of the bar for a special occassion, the Tonga Room will ruin it!
author: Tessa G.

description: Many years ago I had fun drinking at the Tonga Room.
