More recently, I wanted to bring my husband there just for the decor experience, but twice we showed up and each time it was closed for a party (which is damn annoying).  Eventually, we ate there and I have to say that the food was mediocre at best.  Every dish tastes the same, as if everything is fried in the same crusty oil.
author: Lulu B.

description: I have a friend who has raved about Tonga for a long time. Huge tropical drinks enjoyed in the presence of a floating pirate ship in the rain that is home to a band that sounds like the Beach Boys? Too good to be true? I decided to come here with some friends on town when it seemed like a ridiculously touristy event was OK to check off my list of things to explore in San Francisco. Everything I was told was true and it was just that ridiculous in person. A couple of issues - the bar was DEAD and closing very early, granted it was the middle of the week. The drinks were terrible - sugar in a bowl and enough to make anyone feel ridiculously sick. I still say it was worth the visit - I want to meet the people who came up with this business plan. I bet my life they were high as a kite.
author: Alicia J.

description: The Tonga is certainly a SF landmark (my dad went boozing there back in the 50's), and the decor is basically porn for tiki lounge nerds. There are a few cool touches like the indoor, Disneyland-style hurricane show and the famous lagoon. This place also has a great selection of old-school tiki mugs. That said, I was rather disappointed in the cocktails. my Mai Tai was over-sweet and would make Trader Vic roll in his grave. I avoided the food due to its double-digit prices that would've set me back a few Andrew Jacksons. Overall, the Tonga is more of a historical place to admire than to drink at. Visit the joint before developers take it away.
author: Cameron M.

description: Three stars for the drinks and all things tiki, but the fouth star...ah, the fourth star that is for the all-you-can-eat happy hour buffet.  I can eat my weight in terriyaki shortribs.
author: L W.

description: Loved the food, the weak sauce drinks with little umbrellas and the rain storms.  Dancing while waiting for your main meal is a must as is trying to crash the parties in the conference rooms of the Fairmont.  PS don't order the scorpion bowl if one of you has strep
author: Allison K.

description: Definitely kitschy, but one of a kind and not to be missed, especially if you like tiki drinks.  I recommend the Bora Bora Horror.
author: Asteridae A.

description: OMG weak day specials here are awesome 5-7pm. For $10 you can eat all the bar food buffet. Ribs rolls and other things plus discount on the drinks " little pricy " plus they have an indoor waterfalls.
author: Kp K.

description: If your friends are cool enough to have some serious fun at somewhere not too serious, this is the place. Get smashed and start a conga line, it's going to get crazy.
author: Philip M.

description:
from everything that i had read about this place and how cheesy it was, i somehow expected it to be really run down. i pictured it to be like a old battered reno casino, with grumpy frumpy old waitresses, a falling apart stage, and dirty floors. but i forgot to take into account that it's in the Fairmont. so, we walk inside (all 20 of us) and realize that this place is actually a bit fancy, and we're a bit under-dressed. hrm. this place is definitely kind of kitchy, but kitchy in an extravagant kind of way. it turns out that we have to pay if we want to sit at a table, so we just opt to drink at the bar. or at least try to drink at the bar. after 30 minutes of waiting, we still havent been able to order. finally, we give up... it just isn't worth it. yeah, yeah, we never got to see the band float out or the fake rainstorms, but i somehow think that i'll get over missing that stuff.

(my resolution this year is to visit 50 new bars in SF.  read about it at: http://fiftybars.thisisvlad.com)
author: vlad k.

description: Think Disneyland's Tiki Room,  minus the anamatronic birds, but with a rainstorm and alcohol!  awesomely campy - great place for happy hour or to take friends from our of town (it is in the beautiful Fairmont hotel).  The happy hour is good- $6 + one drink and you have an all-you-can eat appetizer buffet of mostly Asian fare.  Try the drink in the frozen pineapple!  Just don't stay past 8:00, as they'll add an automatic $5 per person "entertainment charge," every night of the week. Campy cover bands on a barge on a fake lake are never worth $5 per person, unless you have MANY frozen pineapple drinks and, since the drinks are overpriced, you won't.  Make this spot a pre-party or afterwork 1-2 drink stop.
author: Jenni D.

description: How can you not love this place?! Sooo cheesy in a good way. Come here for the cheesiness and you won't be dissappointed. They have a happy hr special with some food, and every hour the "pirates of the caribbean" show comes on. Come for the happy hour, but don't stick around. Downfall, inconvenient to get to.
author: Sarah G.

description: I was staying in the Fairmont Hotel so I had to roll on down to the Tonga Room. I gotta give this place extra stars just for it's uniqueness. What other bar in a four star hotel boasts a cheesy band floating in the middle of a lake with "rain" and "thunder" and "lightning" randomly interrupting your night. The libations were quite tasty although a tad overpriced ($9 for a Mai Tai!) You also get charged a $5 dollar entertainment fee. It's a fun little place to dance to some cheesy tunes and make fun of drunk tourists.
author: Cathy T.

description: Came here last Saturday after our office party that was nearby and we had sooooooo much fun dancing and singing!! I love the tacky decor and the huge drinks you can share...they're pretty strong though, so watch out!
author: Suzy Q.

description: I was eating a nice quiet dinner with my mother when the clearly inferior roofing gave way and it began to storm inside the restaurant. Yeah that's right, it rained down into the place on top of our half assed prawn salads.  And if that wasn't bad enough, a small boat of Asian pirates stormed the joint and attacked us with an unintelligible Tom Jones medley.  We ducked under the table to avoid another Somali ransom fiasco and stayed there until the pirates sailed off after having dragged a round of obligatory groans from the unsuspecting patrons at musket point. ( I assume since I wasn't watching) We were happy to pay the steep bill for underachieved Asian fusion in return for our lives and freedom from tacky kitsch themes. I have heard good things about their happy hour and may return with a band of ruffians in tow, but not until I am certain that the ship of karaoke raiders has vacated the waters.
author: Dru P.

description: I came on a weeknight for happy hour.  Great place to enjoy when it's not so crowded.  They have a thunderstorm/rainstorm every 20mins or so.  The buffet was all you can eat for $7 w/a one drink minimum.  Drinks are around $7.  You get, a cocktail, fried won ton, vegi chow mein, bbq pork ribs, pot stickers, egg rolls, fruit.  Hmmm, great place for first date during happy hour.  Volume of music is reasonable to have a great conversation with someone. They do have a dance night, where the deck turns into the dance floor and a band plays music on the boat out on the water.
author: Christi S.

description:
ok, so I finally went to the tonga room. 
yes, it is overpriced but it does have a charmingly cheesy interior, and it rains. The damage for the drinks will run you 6.50 for a beer, 9 for a mixed drink and anywhere from 15-26 for a share with your friends drink bowl type of drink. 
Go once if you have never been (mostly for the experiance and to say you have been there), but I doubt I would make this a regular hang out - it isn't nearly that cool of a joint.
author: Russ C.

description: Frankly, Im surprised this place is still around. I thought it was cheesy years ago. I think its cheesy now.
author: Alden H.

description:
One of my very favorite tiki bars in the country.
the drinks are super strong, the atmosphere is amazing, and it freaking rains over the pool.
I am giving it 5 stars for the drinks and for the atmosphere-
the food would get maybe a 1 or 2...
if you get hungry after a couple of drinks-you would totally be better off catching a cab outside and going to a different neighborhood for something good- otherwise you'll drop like a zillion dollars on some not so tasty, just kinda ok, would rule if it were like $3 type food (chicken wings, spring rolls, etc...)
 and there are much better places for food at either end of your budget within a 5 or 6 dollar cab ride. 
but even if you do fall for the $5,000.00 spring rolls, you will be so happy from your delicious tiki drink to even care, and then in the morning when find the crumpled up receipt in your purse, you will laugh and rationalize it by how much fun you had.
author: Maxine M.

description: Bizarre, surreal, kitsch, cheese, gaudy... What the hell is this place doing in the opulent Fairmount? It's like Pirates Of The Caribbean at Disneyland, with a covers band on a floating stage and fake rain. I'm still weirded out by this place, couldn't believe I was still in San Francisco. Our group probably had the only locals in the whole place, not counting the workers. Definitely worth checking out at least once, overpriced lame food and theme cocktails.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Went here for a Birthday party awhile back and I swear I would never come back again. Overpriced greasy Chinese food that you could get anywhere. The worst part is the service! They throw your plate down to the table and rush off before you could even ask for another drink.  Two stars b/c their drinks aren't too bad and the entertainment was nice while we waited over an hour for our food (but the $5 entertainment  fee is automatically added to your check). Never again!
author: Kim D.

description: Leave your pretensions at the door.  Go have fun.  I've lived in the Bay Area most of my life and I never made it to the Tonga Room until last night.  It's a Fairmont hotel, it's popular, it's a night spot, and it's unique.  Therefore it's going to be expensive.  The food is fair.  The drinks are fine.  The band was fantastic.  You can dance.  I read reviews about poor service but overall the staff was friendly and our waiter was attentive and always had a smile.  If you make a reservation you have to have dinner.  Upside is you don't have to wait in line and you can take your time drinking, dining and taking breaks to dance.  If you don't want dinner then you have to stand in line.  It appears around 11 they fill the dining area with those waiting to get in so if you want to drop in sometime around then you won't have to wait for a table.  As for dinner we just ordered a few appetizers and two entrees for the three of us.  Yes, you'll get better this and that at other restaurants for less money but you don't come to the Tonga Room for the food.  Have fun and smile.
author: Dave H.

description: What a disappointment!  There is no denying the beauty and grace of this grand hotel and the iconic value of the great Tonga Room.  As a stand alone review the Hotel and the Tonga Room are must a must see while in San Francisco.  To understand and appreciate the history of the Tonga Room makes the trip worth while, not to mention the delight in seeing this wonderful Tiki Lounge...it is nothing short of plain and simple fun.  We loved it and the drinks were fantastic.  This is where you should stop!  Have a drink and get out!  DO NOT EAT HERE!  the meals we had were simply awful.  Each dish had chicken in the ingredients and my wife and I found the chicken to be inedible...horrible is too kind!.  We sent our meals back and settled for a side of broccoli.  What was also very troubling, is the fact that our server seemed to be expecting our response suggesting he had sen this scene play out many times before.  We had seen other posts 'warning' not to eat the food.  We had hoped those 'warnings' were exaggerated so took a chance, because we really wanted to take in the entire experience of the Tonga Room.  We certainly wish we had listened to those that dined before us...please listen now to me...do not eat the food.  It is a true shame, because you would image a Hotel with the history, legacy and reputation for quality and service would not allow so many negative reviews about the food in the Tonga Room go unchecked.  Review after review have bad things to say about the food. In fact, I would not eat at this property period, because our food experience in the Tonga Room reflects very poorly on the quality being presented throughout the hotel s I wouldn't take the chance and waste the time and money to eat at the Fairmont Hotel.  As stated, with so many poor reviews surrounding the food in the Tonga Room, I wonder if management simply doesn't care...Management...you need to listen, oh and maybe try the food coming out of the kitchen (Especially with chicken)..I bet that will make you take some action.
author: Michael M.

description: When your grandparents come into town, and the Zeitgeist ain't gonna cut it, you can take them here. Make sure they're paying as the drinks are completely overpriced. On the bright side, the drinks are also completely watered down so you won't get drunk and say something you might regret.  There is a floating pontoon with a "wedding singer-esqe" lounge act that sings musak versions of oldies but goodies....enjoy!
author: Jennifer S.

description: So cheesy, but I love it all the same. My sister insists on going every time she's in town. I just like taking my ladies out on the bridge/dance floor.
author: Angela K.

description: A popular after-work venue AND the biggest tourist gyp experience ever. I'm not sure why tourists flock to see the stupid "rain and thunder" combo inside this restaurant when the happy hour drinks are watered down and the buffet menu, lame.
author: Miles G.

description: This is a very fun place to take out of town visitors. I hadn't been in about 8 years. I was racking my brain trying to think of something that would be fun for visiting family. Ding, ding, ding......Tonga Room. They loved it. The drinks, the rain, the appetizers ( I personally didn't find them very appealing but the rest of the group liked them ) and the staff. After the Tonga Room visit, we wandered through the lobby of the hotel and lounged on the fancy sofa's and plush chairs. It was fun, even for someone who lives here!
author: Cindy J.

description: We just celebrated my mom's 60th birthday party here, and it was a total success. Everything from the food to the service was excellent. This place just screams "Good Times" with the music, the exotic drinks, and the indoor "thunderstorm." We chose the Ohana banquet menu, and everything was good and plentiful (we took home so much food it lasted us another four days!). The reasons for 4 instead of 5 stars is because we had the waiter remarked matter-of-factly that my youngest son was cuter than my oldest, and then we had a server give me attitude when I asked to have confirmation that my children weren't being charged for their food since it was so expensive and they don't eat much. Overall, my mom was so happy with her party (and she loved her birthday cake) in the place she first visited 30 years ago.
author: Kiki C.

description: The place is fun and cool. The waiters at the bar are rude and cold.  The drinks are really expensive, but it is a happy crowd and an interesting atmosphere.
author: Car H.

description: You really should expect a lot of cheeseyness when you go to a bar called the tonga room, but it's actually a lot of fun.  Go with a bunch of friends for the happy hour (and buffet), sit back in some chairs and drink down some excellent tropical drinks.  It's fun to get scorpion bowls for those long straws.   Enjoy the thrill of a tropical thunderstorm in the comfort of the fairmont.  It's definately totally lame, but that's what's so great about it!  I mean come on, a floating lounge band?  I'm not saying you should hit this place up every weekend, but every san franciscan should give this classic a try at least once!
author: Mr. G.

description:
If you're even the slightest big into the whole Tiki-Tacky thing, this place is a must-see.   Decor straight outta the 70's.  Great happy hour spread. They charge a couple bucks for it, but it's pretty good Polynesian inspired finger foods, with usually some fried rice and a cheese and veggie tray.  Great tropical drinks, on par with Trader Vic's. The band should fit more with the theme, though.  I don't really need to hear pop songs here.  Jimmy Buffett says he was inspired to write the song ALTERED BOY on his FAR SIDE OF THE WORLD cd after a visit to this bar.  
Most fun part of the place? A couple times an hour it actually "rains" in here...the band plays on a boat actually floating in a lagoon in the center of the room.  if you have a few too many, the hotel is very nice, great views of the city by the bay.
author: Joe S.

description: I think this is one of the most fun places for a happy hour cocktail with co-workers. Plus after the hike up the hill from the FiDi, you'll have earned it (cable cars are for sissies). Yes its cheesy, but do we have to be at serious bars all the time?  And yes the employees seem to hate their jobs, but who doesn't? Yes its expensive, but hotel bars often are.  Bring people you like and have a good time.
author: Beth W.

description: The drinks are outrageously priced (like $11 for a gin and tonic that came confusingly in a wine glass). But, honestly, such a fun night out. It kind of feels like a mid-western wedding with the folks out on the town dressed up in their sparkly finest.  The silly tropical drinks are the best option- the cheezy band playing on the boat is so much fun to dance to. The decor is so over the top I feel like I'm at Disneyland. What's not to love?
author: Dana K.

description: Based on pure cheesiness alone this place gets 4 stars!! Where else can you go where there is a gigantic swimming pool in the middle of the room,  a boat that the band plays on , and at random times throughout the night fake thunder and lightening begin and rain starts pouring from the ceiling over the pool??? Come on people - this is awesome especially after a few scorpions - which according to the Tonga Room if you have one to many they can "sting" HA HA.   We went with a group of friends before dinner, and a bar crawl,  and it was a great place to start - so many fruity drinks to choose from you'll be in umbrella and Tikki glass heaven!!  We didn't try the food - but I want to go back just to try happy hour again. We had fun - and might I suggest taking cheesy pictures (no flash) by the red wall in the bar area! :)
author: J S.

description: WOW..what took me so long to get here?  If you love tiki bars (who doesn't) you need to check out the Tonga Room.  We came on a week night so skipped most of th' tourist crowd.  Some folks complain about drink prices but when you realize most of these cocktails are pretty much booze-flavored booze it make sense.  Def get a table as th' bar is kinda far from th' action (action=cheesy band floating on 'lake' with rain and lightning storms, more fun than it sounds!).  Food is ok-Amberjack tuna overcooked, pork very flavorful, but that's all secondary.  Love love LOVE the Tonga Room!
author: STEVE L.

description: A nice throw back to the 50's tiki theme.... the happy hour buffet (9.95 plus one drink) is a good value in such a hotel (the Fairmount)...Service was what I would have expected.... the rain and thunder was a nice change from the rain forest cafe, no animal sounds or bad mechanical leppards in the trees.  I'd go back once in a while....
author: Blake J.

description: I don't care what anyone says, I love this place. It makes you feel like you are walking into a polynesian vacation the second you step through the door. It transports me back to every tropical vacation I've been on so really, it's not so expensive when you compare it to a plane ticket and hotel bill.
author: Ellen T.

description: this is the second time i.ve been here now. the last time i went was back in '98. my wife, girlfriend back then took me there on a date. we went there for dinner and i had a good time. I liked how the band was playing on there stage which was a raft on water and it would go back and forth in a little pool. We also danced that nite too. b This time we went for happy hour. the drinks are good and they have a little buffet for $9.50. It's not a big selection, They  had garlic noodles which was like chow mein, spring rolls, macaroni salad, shrimp chips, terriyaki wings, and seaweed salad. the food was good and drinks were $6.00. Not bad cosidering that we were in the fairmont hotel. the happy hour is only on wed, thur, and fri from 5 to 7.
author: Matt D.

description:
Stopped in here for a drink with friends a few months ago. Our drinks were fine/strong and the decor was amusing/cheesy. Way overpriced.

However, after we left the lounge in search of a restroom, we were literally accosted by hotel staff and followed into the restroom. Long story short, there was some sort of protest in front of the hotel and they thought we were protesters (although we were dressed in business attire and had just come from work??). I complained to the male individual who harassed us on my way out of the hotel and he refused to apologize. The next day, I wrote in a complaint on the website and, to the hotel's credit, they did did respond to me immediately. However, I was never offered any sort of apology or compensation as would be the case with a normal reputable establishment. 

So, Fairmont Hotel and Tonga Room...I'm still waiting for an apology! Until then, there are plenty of other overpriced bars and hotels in San Francisco (with better decor) where I'll spend my money instead.
author: J L.

description: Just went last night.They  lost our reservation for 6people, but did cram us into a table meant for 4. The food was terrible. If you are an out-of-towner and you have to see this place, do not eat here. Please.  San Francisco has GREAT dining places, some of the best in America. Do not waste you money at The Tonga Room. If you have to order something the steamed rice was ok.
author: S C.

description: I LOVE this place - drinks are amazing and strong the way they should be and kitchy atmosphere is terrific, love the boat and live music! We come here at least 3 times a year from out of town and stay at the wonderful Fairmont. Can't be beat anywhere, an SF historic institution! Let's hope this place is here to stay instead of being ruined by another stupid developer!
author: Habsfan B.

description: Living history. A must see just to see how Tiki was done back in the day. Don't feel like you have to drink or eat here, however, as it's pretty pricey and the food is also available much cheaper at any one of the hundred or so cheapass dim sum places in the city.
author: Andrew L.

description: I give the food 3 stars, the gave an extra star because the scene was pretty nice. I like the fake rain and  the little lake they had in the middle were the band was playing, that was pretty cool. We started if with an appetizer called Tonga Island Platter For Two which included Shiitake Spring Rolls, Sesame-Barbecue Pork Short Ribs, Chicken Drummettes, Pot Stickers and Sesame Prawns. Served with a Trio of Dipping Sauces. The portions were pretty small but hey it's an appetizer. For our main course we both had the Imperial Lobster  served with seasonal vegetables and oyster sauce. I always prefer to dip my lobster in butter, but this was an ok alternative. Oh yeah they make there drinks really strong, so prepare to get wasted after dinner.
author: Carlos D.

description: Went there once with a bunch of friends for cocktails, that place was packed.  God, this place was sooooo 80s.  Decor was so outdated and they had this, what?? rainstorm??? every 30 minutes?  WTH, I thought I was in Disneyland.  We waited about 30 minutes then they let us in.  Staffs were unfriendly, service was SLOW, drinks were weak but pricey.  They have a dance floor but nobody really danced.  Music sucked BIG time.  Those who went there are in their 40s or 50s, so, if you want to meet some young people and some modern and chic atmosphere, don't go, this is not for you.
author: Josie K W.

description:
this is a place to impress people. the history withstanding, it's just crazy here. the drinks are great and loaded with alcohol, but you can hardly tell. if you don't leave sloshed and broke, you've done something wrong. the food sux, but iam a vegan so Polynesian food is too meat centric for my taste. expensive but worth it for the right occasion. don't take the place too seriously as it can be a little too absurd for some. i love the TONGA!!

oh! and don't forget the Rooftop Garden on the way out. not to be missed.
author: Daniel N.

description: Heard so much about this place, both good and bad, i decided to try it out on my own. Overall the place is very well decorated it almost feels like you are no longer in sf but rather a remote island somewhere. I was expecting this place to be alot more crowded, but maybe wednesday had alot to do with it. The drinks overall were actually pretty good compared to some that i have had at other places. The cosmo and the martinis surely were done right. All and all not a bad place to frequent during happy hour. Oh and yes i had to take one star of that place simply because parking around that neighborhood just seems impossible. Definitely, will refer this place to all my friends.
author: Raj K.

description: You gotta love a Polynesian themed restaurant. I love the rain forest! It's cool and you really do feel like you are somewhat in a tropical paradise! Kind of... I think the ambiance and good STRONG tiki drinks...ok..maybe some of the cover bands are the only reason to come to the Tonga Room. It's definitely not for the food! The food is way over priced and over cooked or not warm!! I've had only appetizers here...that's enough. Definitely eat before hand and just order a mai tai or blue Hawaiian, that's all you need...
author: Suzette R.

description:
Normally I'd say a tourist restaurant is not very good, but the Tonga room surprised me.  I had rice, chicken, beef and it was all good quality food.  It was way expensive, but I expected that.  

Good place to take guests from out of town.
author: Richard C.

description: I was here over two years ago celebrating my graduation from my master's program. I had a nice group of people including some of my closest family and friends. Even my friend from San Diego made it to the ceremony so it was awesome. I was pretty happy this night considering all the great drinks people bought me. I was surprised by the dim tropical ambience as my friend put it so nicely. I definitely enjoyed the indoor typhoon- rain, thunder, and strobe lights and the band on the floating straw hut in the "pool" of water in middle of the restaurant. The songs were great because it was timeless. Friends and family, young and old, got up to dance to the classic & golden oldies. The lead vocalist should have been on American Idol :) I'm sure he could have been a finalist. I will forever remember this evening with my friends and family at the Tonga room. Great food, great family, great friends, great music, and all thanks to my brother who paid for the bill at the end.
author: Kaye J.

description:
Well, its a very kitch tiki bar. It's something of an institution. My wife had her 8th birthday party here, and I know quite a few people from the bay area with similar experiences. We heard it might be closing, so we trekked up the Peninsula so I could check it out.

The drinks were what I expected. Not the best tropical drinks, but very serviceable. The decor is awesome, assuming you're not the kind of person that takes themselves too seriously. I found the wait staff very attentive, maybe a little too attentive, but friendly and helpful enough. We did not feel rushed or anything like that.

I was pleasantly surprised by the food. It was much better than I was expecting. I had the Hot Pot, and it was very tasty, with very fresh ingredients. The fried rice was good, and my wifes diver scallops were also very fresh and nicely cooked. Pretty good pan-asian flavors. 

All in all, given the ambiance, rain, decor and silly drinks, the over-the-top atmosphere made for a fun night out. Would go again.
author: Sean A.

description:
Management needs to be replaced.

What a waste of a cheesy, fun decor and great location.  This place has SO MUCH potential, it's a shame that inept management and terrible service are killing a potential goldmine for the owners.

We went here December 30 with a fun, big-spending. big-tipping group. The manager could not have been ruder nor could the bartenders have been slower or less eager to please.  After waiting at the bar for 30 minutes for a drink, the manager calls "last call" at 11:00pm! This is on the night before New Year's eve in a packed place! There were close to 200 people there.  He easily turned away $5,000-$10,000 in business IN THIS ECONOMY?!?  He then proceeds to throw a hissy fit, yelling at all the customers to "get out."

Hey, anyone can have a bad night, but i get the feeling that this wasn't a first time thing for this guy. He was too high strung. And, the bartenders just had a whole "I don't care" attitude about them. If i owned the place, I'd be FURIOUS! You can't treat customers the way we were all treated and expect to survive in a city like San Francisco. There are just too many other places to buy overpriced drinks.

What a waste!
author: Spicey G.

description:
I've been going to this place for years. Sure I'm a local, but it's a really fun place to bring any SF visitors.

The atmosphere is great in there. I really love the whole design of it. I mean, you can't deny the awesome-ness of a restaurant with a pool that a band floats on from inside a tiki hut. Did I mention that every few minutes, it "rains" over the pool? Yep, pretty awesome.

It's just one of those SF dining experiences you should do at least once while you're here. Great place.
author: Nicole R.

description: Awesomely cheesy. Expensive, I wouldn't even attempt to have food here, but the atmosphere and yummy drinks make it worth $10+ per drink. It really feels like you're not in SF anymore, what with all the tourists having a good unpretentious time, amazingly bad loungey music--is a cover of Rock with You ever disappointing?--a laid back gleeful kinda vibe, and just generally normal folks.
author: P R.

description: if you ever have the urge to crash someone's wedding or bar mitzvah, make your way over here. same feeling except you gotta pay your way. line dancing. 13 year olds dancing awkwardly in tight dresses. weird drinks. that band playing those songs your parents listened to. random people you may or may not be related to. and the rain!! YES. have you ever seen the rain? creedence? oh yeah. but i was kinda sad that they don't have any pyro cocktails. :(
author: Adrienne Y.

description: Unusual and fairly limited menu.  The atmosphere isn't what is advertised.  Part Disneyland, part convention hall.  The live band was great.  Staff wasn't very friendly.  We decided to eat appetizers as the main meal at the bar.  We tried 5 different plates.  The most tasty being the flatbread and carpaccio.  The least was the fried rice (black?).  This with 3 drinks each was $150.
author: Nikola T.

description: The Tonga Room is a fun place to take a trip to. It reminded me of the tiki room in Disneyland and that was fine with me. I like to have fun when I go out to eat now and then. We decided to try it out for our anniversary and we weren't dissapointed. We made reservations and were promptly seated. Our waiter was very friendly and fast and attentive. There are many choices and you can expect to overpay for the ambience :) but the food was good. We had the coconut shrimp to start with and then I had a chicken dish (cant remember the name) and my husband had a steak dish. We also shared a Lava Bowl drink which was yummy. I loved the Tonga Room. The only reason I took a star off was because the music was just so-so. Maybe it's because the place is older, but the sound quality wasn't so great so it took away from the entertainment. Overall though it was a great time, great food and totally worth a trip :)
author: Kimberly R.

description:
ok, here it goes - after months of browsing, my first Yelp review. 

i felt compelled to write because of the HORRIBLE service we received last night at the Tonga Room. we waited about 15 minutes from the time we were seated until our waiter came over.  after we were served, we waited (i kid you not) 45 minutes before the waiter bothered to come over again, and that was only after we managed to flag down a bus boy to ask him for our check.  a 10-top next to us was seated, served and paid in between visits from our waiter.  this is *completely* unacceptable for a $200 dinner.  

positives;
- food was decent
- love the floating bar and the band :-)
- great for out of town guests - my teenage cousin and her friend had "the best night of their lives" so i'll give the Tonga Room credit for that.
author: gracie m.

description: Try the happy hour. Not bad at all. A touristy kind of place but the price was quite fair and OK,
author: jacqueline c.

description: fun to take out of towners to for 1 drink...love the lava flow bowl thingy...
author: lindsay f.

description:
I love the atmosphere of this place (the cheesy decor and band that floats on water.)  One star for that.  The band floats on water, which is also cool.  One more star.

The food is cheap (but definitely not inexpensive) chinese food.  I've had better stuff in the ghetto for $5 a plate.

The drinks are good.

The service is probably some of the worst I've experienced.  The waiters can't speak or understand English very well at all.  When you ask them for something sometimes they hear you and not what you say, but don't respond at all.  Then once you've repeated yourself several times, they get around to saying "yeah I heard you".  Subsequently they'll take forever to get you what you ordered.  You pay an arm and a leg to hang at this place, you think with that money they could hire a better quality staff.

The band is a bit loud for conversation, but I guess it gets the floor moving which can be good sometimes.

We had a party here and one of the waiters spilled several bottles of our wine on the floor and on someones jacket.  They didn't tell anyone about it and I'm sure nobody found out.  I'm positive we still got charged the $25 cork fee for the spilled bottles because no one admitted spilling anything, and whoevers coat that was probably never got reimbursed.
author: sean o.

description: Poor service.  It has been here forever.  Time to make a change.  The rain and thunder was great for the kids.  Nothing but old people and young tourist that have no idea that they are in the wrong place.
author: Allen B.

description: Even though I would have given it 5 stars for the unintentional comedy the food was actually very good.
author: Jake B.

description:
this place is cougar central.

but where else can you pretend you're on a cheezy cruiseship version of disneylands' "pirates of the carribean" ride circa 1989? love it!

the $18 cocktail that is served in a whole pineapple is cute, but not as good as you want it to be. 

and the fairmont hotel is a classic- a great place to take outoftowners for a pre-dinner cocktail old-school style.
author: StephanieLauren B.

description: Well, it looks like a really cool place inside. But it seems like they don't care too much what anyone thinks of them or their service. We were turned away on Friday at happy hour, told that a "private party" was taking place. I complained but didn't get anywhere with that. Maybe they have this attitude since they're rumored to close eventually when the hotel is remodeled. Oh well.
author: Bob M.

description: this place is disneyland on polynesian crack and i love every tacky ass second of it!  furthermore, it fucking rains INDOORS at the tonga room.  and the awesome band in a boat covers top 40 from 1998.  this is seriously the absolute best place in all of san francisco.  don't go on monday or tuesday though because no live band in a boat!  NOT COOL!  i only wish i could give it 6 stars because damn i love this place.
author: Laura B.

description: It was the worst meal I've ever had! The Scallops were sour in the Tonga Hot Pot. Everything had no flavor. We had to go somewhere else for dinner afterwards.
author: S G.

description: The cover charge is high, the drinks are pricey, but this place is the holy grail of tiki bars, it is the real deal.  However, I would like to see them bring the Hawaiian band back, last time I was there they had a top 40 cover band instead...ya need the Hawaii band to complete the picture
author: Ron B.

description: the food is more expensive than chez panisse and tastes worse than panda express, but the surroundings make you forget all that. the tonga room is a little bit of paradise in san francisco. the service is attentive and the cocktails are perfect. i will return, but not for the food.
author: taggylee b.

description: It's in the Fairmont so drinks are kind of pricey ($10-12) but the atmosphere is so fun!  Live band playing great music, tacky but entertaining decorations (it 'rains' every half hour or so).  Three of us shared a 'lava bowl' which was hilarious though not that strong.  But delicious!
author: Caitlin G.

description: This isn't the kind of place I'd normally rate so high. Like the hotel it's situated in, I love the history and learning about it through old articles framed up around the hallways. The food is like any other asian fusion restaurant, but the service is definitely better. Our waiter was very attentive and accommodating. They didn't skimp on the alcohol on their cocktails. We ordered the Tonga Platter which had the ribs, chicken satay, coconut prawns and fried spring rolls, and also got rice and szechan green beans. The ribs were extra sweet, but I didn't mind that. The prawns were pretty big and the chicken satay was devoured by my husband. The spring rolls were nothing to write home about. We really loved the green beans! They were cooked just right and the sauce was so good over our rice. We'd eat here again if we were staying at the hotel. The water show and the ambiance of the place made me feel like I was in the Tiki Room at Disneyland.
author: Yelp O.

description: Two Shots of Patron Silver: $32 Mandatory "Entertainment" charge: $5/person Meager, soggy, and cold Pu-Pu platter: $18 watered-down Scorpion Bowl: $34.50 surly waitstaff: free  an evening at the Tonga Room:   worthless   Don't anger the Tonga Gods, lest they smite you.  The tiki fun of the former Fairmont Plunge has perhaps finally slipped over the edge, tumbled down the cliff, and dashed itself across the rocks of tourist trapdom below.  What once once was a fun lark has unfortunately become a charm-less exercise in extracting every last dollar from their drunk tourist patrons.  The drinks have become absurdly expensive, and the waitstaff, who are about as friendly and accommodating as Hessian mercenaries, demand a credit card imprint even before you've ordered.  Maybe it's just that I've grown old and jaded, but if you're going to be spending $16 per drink, it should at least come with a view.  Step next door to the Top of the Mark.
author: Gabriel S.

description: everyone else already worded it so perfectly... this popular hotel bar is tacky tiki FUN! order a tropical drink and pretend you're on holiday with friends while enjoying the show around you.
author: Michelle I.

description: I guess your feelings about this room will really be a reflection of how you feel about retro-Tiki culture--specifically when it's done "straight," without any knowing wink on the side to say that it's all in the name of good, campy fun.  3 stars does it for me.  The Tonga Room is Tiki to the max, complete with an impressive litany of effects and accessories: mood lighting, giant fake palm trees, big Tiki/"Easter Island head" statues, bamboo and wicker everywhere you look, a fake thunderstorm every half-hour or so, and a rectangular moat-like lagoon surrounding the island where the lounge/wedding-style band plays at 8.  It would be one thing to take it all in with a snide snicker at one of our more tacky and un-PC pop-cultural moments, but it's hard to feel OK and non-snobby about that when the aging touristas all around are so clearly enjoying themselves without the aid of irony--and that's a pretty thin source of entertainment anyway.  Not to carp further on what's basically a harmless, doofy experience, but I was a little irked that they automatically charge everyone the 5 or 6 clam cover for the band even if you got there before 8 and happened to stay until they started--a word to the wise.  I also was underwhelmed by the zombie I had here.  Oh, it was strong alright, but really hard to drink on account of what I assume was cheap well rum.  I'm not a huge rum fan to begin with, but I've had drinkable rum & cokes made with good stuff, and this was shudder-inducing.  Take it for what it is--if it's your thing, then you won't find a better faux-Polynesian experience around.  It's not really my scene, though it was fun to go once.
author: Michael T.

description: I Don't understand how this restaurant has a 3 and a half stars.  While the atmosphere is nice (reminded me of an island restaurant or one you would see in disney land)The food was horrible for the price.  I guess I shouldn't have expected much when I saw one of the ingredients on the rice dish was  spam.  The shrimp on the noodle dish was the small canned  shrimp.  I asked the waiter about the menu (which is very limited) and he didnt even know what I was asking about and had to review the menu before he could answer.  I felt very rushed in the beginning. My last complaint would have to be that even if you go to would have to be the $7 cover charge whether you eat there or not.  I can understand the cover charge if you are just going to drink but when you are eating and paying the over priced food bill for the quality of the food you are getting the least they could do is throw in the entertainment.
author: Michele Z.

description: the tonga room is one of those places that, if you plan on spending any amount of time living in san francisco, you must visit at least once. after you witness the indoor lake and thundershowers, see the boat-themed and thatched hut decor and order a fruity drink that comes in a bowl (the scorpion sting for two, $12 or for four $22), you may leave and never come back, because you can now say that you have been to the tonga room, and there are cheaper bars to visit nearby.
author: Tom H.

description: If you are a worthwhile person, you will enjoy going to the Tonga room. This hotel bar is a tropical paradise of clueless yuppies, tourists, and desperate, sleazy women in their forties, all drinking overpriced, sugary drinks in novelty glasses, and dancing (if they're lucky) or wistfully watching the dance floor. The most fun part of going to the Tonga room is deciding what to wear, which, in this writer's opinion, should always involve at least one item that is either gold or sequined. Bejewelled, we'll say. Okay, the best part is actually the Tonga Room players, who, as previously described, FLOAT out on a bamboo island and play covers ranging from Beyonce to James Taylor. The Tonga Room players are supposedly the "longest running gig" in San Francisco, which is suspect since the lead singer looks like she's about 30... But they are truly fantastic. My dream is that one night at the Tonga room, I'll meet a stock broker with slicked back hair and we'll start a family together.
author: Caitlin P.

description: Today's mystery: How can you run/work in a TIKI bar and not have a sense of humor? I mean, it RAINS every half hour, but the servers act like they're employed by the freaking Four Seasons. The Tonga Room *should* be the height of kitschy goodness, and if the atmosphere lived up to the decor, I'd be willing to forgive its faults-- say, the ridiculous prices, the sub par food, and the fact that a bar serving mostly blended drinks really should avail itself of a decent blender. But the whole affair is marred by the staff's snooty 'tudes. I came here during happy hour for a friend's birthday. The condescension started right at the door with a patronizing host, but soon enough we were a big table of happy twenty-somethings looking to down as many daiquiris (meaning $$$$, at these prices) as the Tonga Room could throw our way. Getting round one took long enough, but after that we were totally ignored. The servers catered to the 60+ crowd and never looked our way again. The other patrons did, though--every time anyone at our table seemed to be having the slightest bit of fun. I mean, come on people. You are not at the yacht club. You are at a tiki bar. It is RAINING. There is a FAKE THUNDERSTORM. You are drinking an electric blue drink with an UMBRELLA in it. This is an absurd situation--you should be allowed to giggle!
author: Sarah D.

description: Just about the lamest bar I can imagine. Unfriendly waitstaff. Expensive drinks. Mai Tai, the famed drink of the bar, smells like puke from someone who drank too much sweet, sweet liquor. Tastes kinda good though. I am no hipster, but seriously, a fat and very un-hip crowd. Was it all tourists? I do not know. Complaints aside though, that moving band boat is fucking AWESOME. If I could ride the band boat 5 stars would be given. If I could swim in the pool, four stars would be given. If I could climb the ropes around the dance floor, two stars would be given. Alas, I cannot do any of these things.
author: YUP K.

description:
Not impressed.  
I showed up at around 6pm on a Wednesday night in a party of 8.  We were told that only those wishing to order dinner could be seated, because the front half of the Tonga Room was already full.  So we waited.  And waited.  For 40 minutes, with quite a number of other groups.  After being told that they could not give us an approximate time until we would be seated, we were about to leave.  At this point, they seated us in a rather small space.  Luckily, the group of 3 next to us left, and we commandeered their table.  By this point, happy hour was just about over, so we quickly ordered some items.  The drinks were AWFUL.  Mine was bad quality sour mix with a scoop of crushed ice.  No fresh fruit juice or alcohol to be tasted at all.  In fact, only 1 of us could taste any alcohol at all, and unfortunately for him, his drink tasted only of low quality booze.  The food was solidy mediocre, but very expensive.
It's really a shame because the ultra cheezy decor and ambiance is completely fun.  Considering there are tiki bars in the bay area with excellent drinks and atmosphere, I won't be back here.
author: Melissa K.

description: I like atmosphere of that place. Ok to have several cocktails, but no a diner)))
author: Oleksiy M.

description: Kitsch and cheesiness galore, right down to the fake polynesian wood carvings, tropical umbrellas in your mai-tais and wait - drumroll please - the unparallelled pseudo tropical storm complete with the ever so realistic thunder, lightning, and pouring down rain special effects.  However, the highlight of the evening was when the barge carrying the band (imported directly from somewhere in the Orient, or at least Hawaii, I suspect)  floated into the middle of the man made "lagoon"  around which the diners could satiate their appetites with even more authentic and mediocre interpretations of "Polynesian" fare. When the band struck up their rendition of famed Barry Manilow tunes, the older folk start spinning their heels on the dance floor.  A once in a lifetime experience, not to be repeated any time soon. And yes, sadly we paid the cover charge because we were simply riveted by the whole spectacle. We just couldn't leave our seats, yet.
author: Suepattra M.

description: I never met a drink I couldn't put down until last night.  The mixed drinks are undrinkable not to mention overpriced. After 8 p.m., they charge you $3 to sit in their lounge  under the name of an "entertainment fee". What entertainment? Listening to their crappy house lounge band play? They should have paid me to listen to them.
author: Sierra d.

description: My boyfriend said he felt like we were in the Safeway produce section at the grocery store, because you would hear thunder and suddenly there was rainfall over the pool in the center of the restaurant.  If you've ever been to Rainforest Cafe at Pier 39, it was very similar.  This place definitely caters to tourists.    We ordered the Mai Tai, Blue Hawaii, and the Lava bowl to share, the drinks were strong, and sweet, which I guess they are supposed to be, considering they are tropical drinks, but I think maybe they added alittle too much simple syrup or something cause the drinks left a sweet coating in my mouth.  We had the happy hour buffet for $9  Not worth it!!  Fried Wontons with a tiny bit of meat in the center, veggie eggrolls were ok, bread and a few different dips that were too sweet, there was fruit, greasy noodles, and fried rice.  We didn't stay for the entertainment, we were tempted, thinking it would sway our opinion for the better but, we didn't give it a chance.  So maybe we missed out, or not.  I have to be honest though, I wasn't expecting much when I planned on going here, but it was actually worse than I expected.
author: Charla M.

description: I had the worst experience here on a thursday night.  Now I know i didnt have a reservation and excepted the fact that we had to wait in line, but when 3 couples that came after us where taken and seated i got a little annoyed. It was my birthday and i just wanted to have a nice dinner with my FAMILY so i did not expect to be seated in the bar area with my 4 year old.  Unlike everyone around us we were not given food menu's only the drink menu that was already on our table.  While on a bathroom trip with my daughter i came back to my table now missing a chair and the table next to us had been expanded to seat 4 instead of 2 and the people next to us looking disgusted that they where seated next to us, This also left very little walking room between the tables. The customer service was horrendous while I seen about 3 other tables celebrating birthday and being brought sparkling birthday cakes we where not even acknowledged. I know for sure I will not be going back and would not recommend to anyone. Thank you Tonga room for one of the worst Birthday services ever. Sad to say the best experience was with the valet staff in the parking garage. They were nice as can be.
author: Tiffany F.

description: My husband and I saw this on the travel channel and decided to go there. We have to say, we were very disappointed. The food was expensive and okay, large plates, were small plates. The drinks were expensive and very weak, the atmosphere was okay, music was okay. This is a place we would not visit again. Very disappointed.
author: Lisa S.

description: You must go here. I don't know why it took me so long, but last Friday we ended up here after an art show and we ordered a four person lava bowl (hey, there were three of us). One person had to leave rather abruptly, as it was her eighth drink of the night, but the two of us remained, enjoyed two more lava bowls and subsequently did eighties style dance solos on the lakeside dance floor (because the lake is IN the Tonga Room) with rain coming down behind us. It was the most fun I've had in months. I could talk more about the photographer who took a picture of us and three minutes later handed me a picture of the SO on a matchbox (awesome) or the band that somehow made their cover songs even better than the original, but instead I will implore you, once again, GO HERE. Supposedly it's closing, and if it goes without you having this experience you will be filled with regret. I went again last night, took advantage of the YELP DISCOUNT and had some of the best service ever. Go here.
author: Katie T.

description: the drinks were really good!! but the food is NOT Hawaiian at all!!! it's more like over priced Chinese Food!!! I would not recommend dinner for anyone, unless you like to pay $30 for a plate of sweet and sour Chicken!!!
author: Lillian K.

description: Love it!! Its hysterical and fun to take out of town guests!!
author: Bronwyn B.

description: This place is so wrong but for some reason, it just feels so right.  I'm Pacific Islander, and normally, really hate places that whore out island culture, but I went there last night, and I don't know, maybe there was magic in the air, (more likley it was the $32 hurricanes), but I watched people from all walks of life--tourists, hipsters, Marina yuppies, cougars, queers (actually, I think we sealed the market on that one...no no no, there was these two Irish guys--however, my friend picked picked up on them later and we ended up taking them to Badlands, so technically, they count as part of our group) business men, bridge and tunnel bachelorettes complete with too tight Miss Sixty Jeans and muffin tops--unite as one on the dance floor.  We sang together to Journey's "When the Lights go Down in the City", and I swear, I almost teared up when when we formed the Soul Train Line for KC and the Sunshine Band.   What can I say, the Tonga Room won me over.
author: Nic B.

description: I went last night on a date. Terrible place to try to get to know someone. I the music is incredibly loud. Points because they band plays in a boat in the middle of a pool/ river, and when it is break time the boat floats back to the dock with a cool rain storm show. Fav part of the night. Very touristy. Terrible service. Repeat... terrible service. Richard waited on us, in the middle of taking an order (which he later got wrong) just up and walked away to pre-bus another table. Finally after we finished eating it took him a good 20 minutes to bring our check, after he was asked. The food was good. I had the dragon fire chicken, great sauce, and my date had the mongolian beef which was also good. The bill was 100$ for two people, Which is not bad I was just not impressed. I am usually very hard to displease, being in the industry I give a lot of slack.  For the same price you can go to King fish or Ruth's and have good food with great service. I give this place two stars, one for decent food, the other for creative decor.
author: Amanda T.

description: As a tradition I take my family to stay at the Fairmont Hotel in San Francisco every holiday season.  We always look forward to our stay in the city. We always make a point to visit the Tonga Room.  The Tonga Room is a special place and we always have a great time.  This year, our host, Khalid made our experience that much better.  His gracious nature made us feel welcome and special.  Great Job Fairmont for employing people like Khalid and keeping the tradition of the Tonga Room alive!
author: Fran M.

description: The Tonga room is a great place if you want to visit the a historic San Francisco Landmark.,    It was my first time, which was nice and all.   Just wanted to let any future visiters, that the tonga room prices are high for drinks, small pates etc.   I went during happy hour.  Now if drinks on the happy menu are pricey, how about during regular business hours.   No appetizers are on the happy hour menu.   Be prepared to spend.
author: JERRY B.

description: Had a great time at the Bar here - shared a Hurricane and some short ribs. Everything was great. I really appreciated the dance floor and live band. My wife and I had the chance to practice our Waltz - a rare treat. Afterwards we wandered upstairs to the hotel's roof garden for a great view of the city. I hope this place lasts for ever.
author: Mark R.

description:
Last night my family and I were anxiously looking forward to an exotic, Polynesian atmosphere at the Tonga Room Restaurant in the Fairmont Hotel.  It had been years since we had last been there, and with the relatively new renovation, we we're pumped to sample an old San Francisco tradition once again!
Visually, the Tonga Room is like being on the set of an old Elvis Presley film, which immediately transported us to a Tiki-like, Coco Palms feel; we were swept away by the  Aloha...but that's pretty much where the magic ended.
We began by ordering a mixed pupu platter and Mai Tai's. The drinks were served in ceramic totem Tiki glasses, which looked festive with their pineapple wedges and umbrellas, but there was little hint of any rum.  On our first sip, through straws, the bottom layer was warm, not iced..not shaken or stirred...WARM.  The pupu platter looked fun, but the coconut shrimp was stale tasting like old fishy frying oil.  The skewered Satay Chicken was pretty good, the spare ribs were actually very good, probably the best thing on the menu, but the egg roll was again disappointing as it too had a rancid old oil quality to it..not fresh at all and had no other real flavors to speak of.  Even the dipping sauce didn't help.
My husband and I chose the Mongolian Beef, and it smelled and looked delicious when it arrived, but there wasn't one piece of meat that wasn't RAW.  I love rare meat, but if this was WOK seared, the wok was barely waved over a flame, totally raw!  The same thing held true for my sister's Lamb Curry...raw.  I don't think any one of the 6 of us had anything we'd ever want to order again.  No one was raving, and our exuberant gaiety present at the start was lost into attempting to get through the meal.
We tried two other drinks hoping to get one properly mixed and with some rum, but were sadly disappointed, by the same plastic-y consistency.
Highlights of course were the intermittent rain storms and little combo band on the water.  they were as we remembered, very entertaining and there were loads of people on the dance floor having a great time.
So, bottom line....if you're not fussy about what you eat or drink...you'll get a kick out of it.  To me, though, it's a crying shame not to have at least B+ chefs in the kitchen...AND someone who really knows how to make drinks....I was expecting better, but I'll have to give it a "C+" overall..("A-" for Atmosphere, a "D" for food and libation).  Had heard for years that the food was below par, but this was worse than any of us expected.
I love that the Tonga Room is still swinging and looks so wonderfully tropical in a Walt Disney-esque (Pirates of the Caribbean) kind of way, but PLEASE...it could do with some new cooks and maybe a refreshed, more up to date menu!!!  Order carefully.
author: Kathryn B. H.

description: Happy hour drinks were very good but pricey. Most importantly, the buffet food was terrible. Must not have been prepared well because I got sick from food poisoning right away. I would never go back again.
author: Sharon C.

description: Located in the basement of the prestigious Fairmont Hotel on the top of Nob Hill.  Go here for the thunderstorms.  Yes, that's right it rains inside!  Complete with lightning.  The house band floats out of a hole in the wall and anchors in the dock near the dance floor.  I love it!  Think Disneyland (wait we are in one of SF's most elegant hotels right??).  The band takes requests, but sticks to 80's and 90's standards.  The bar is always busy.  This place is a restaurant, but I only ate dinner once.  Everyone goes for the lake.  I took away a star cause the food was not spectacular.  I have taken a variety of peeps here and we always have a good laugh and get buzzed on the hurricane cocktails.  Everyone I have taken here opts to keep the Tonga glass home as a souvenir of this ultra cheesy, yet enjoyable spot. Its also kinda cool to wander around this beautiful hotel late at night.  Its all lit up from the outside and when the fog rolls in it looks even better.
author: Denise G.

description: overpriced underwhelming drinks + cover + tip = really expensive experience (and not very enjoyable experience)
author: Tom L.

description:
picture a really bad 80s wedding that is still going on 20 years later.  oh yeah, and add a ridiculously expensive (and rude) cash bar.

BUT, i was recently taken here on a first date and as much as i abhor cheesiness,if you don't take yourself too seriously, it can be really fun.  we were amused by the older couples shaking a leg and just kicked back and enjoyed the campiness of it all.  the best part was that i later learned my dad took my mom here over 30 years ago on one of their first dates.
author: M D.

description: I ate here for an company party. The food was great, and the music was cheesy, but I loved it. I wish there were more old Asian couples dancing on the dance floor when I was there. I got a huge steak, and fried shrimp, but I think the appetizers there gave me a stomach ache. I love how it rains inside the place. It's cool, but I don't think I would go back their unless I was really drunk. Then it would have been just super.
author: Mike h.

description: i don't mind the forced hawaiian-tiki atmosphere. i came here with my girlfriends for happy hour and it was all in good fun. i kind of think it's really cute with the intermittent storms. anyway, the drinks are okay - they're not that expensive and the appetizer buffet is a good idea if you're going to be there for a while. it's cheap! what a deal for $8. you should probably get it, because you'll need to it. in fact, you should probably eat a whole bunch before you order their mai-tai. that is ONE strong drink.
author: Mel L.

description: For a San Francisco institution this place could be so much better. The thing to go there for is the classic tiki interior: the pool in the middle, the thunderstorms, the floating stage, and the beautiful Polynesian artifacts, these are what make the place. Unfortunately, the drinks are weak and unimaginative. The food is seriously mediocre and the prices are way too high. They must rely mostly on tourists, because SF residents expect more if they're going to pay an arm and a leg. If they would bring up the quality of the food and drinks, this place would be a destination I would look forward to going. As it is, when someone suggests it, I am not enthusiastic. My suggestions would be for the management to improve the quality of the drinks, not bother with dinner and only serve really great appetizers, and get better lounge bands that have more of a tropical retro flavor. If you want a great tiki experience, I would recommend going to Forbidden Island in Alameda.
author: jenn a.

description: When you walk in, you feel like you are in Hawaii or some tropical place.  Very nice drinks, too.  Cheesy entertainment makes you forget that you are in a hotel bar....  Hey! There it goes rain shower!
author: Su Kyeong K.

description: Call me Ishmael.  Ok, don't but call me a checkered cab when I walk out of Tonga.  Can't you just imagine hot dames and sharp suited men in this place 50 years ago!   The cocktails, the decor, the staff.  I dunno.  Another good kitsch joint.
author: Misti L.

description: this was my second time at the tonga room, and i just love it so.  maybe it's because i love places/things from a bygone era, but it's just such a cool spot.  the band plays on this floating thing in the middle of the water where rain pours down every half hour!  anyway, i was there last thursday night (unfortunately missing happy hour by a half hour), and sat at the bar.  i had 2 drinks whose names i can't remember, both of which i disliked, but the margaritas my companion had were incredibly tasty and wish i had ordered one of those instead (shin is the name of the bartender btw).  it was still a good time, and i got tipsy enough that i went upstairs to the hotel lobby just to see how much their cheapest rooms are ($250 in case you were wondering).  maybe next time...
author: erika w.

description: Really great authentic Tiki bar & restaurant in the lower ground floor of the Fairmont Hotel, best to get the trolley to the top of the hill and walk down to the place, I got off too early and had to trek up a very steep incline- but that did give me a good appetite. It's so great, If you love tiki/kitsch! Big witco tikis,bamboo everywhere, koa wood kayaks, paddles, glass fishing ball floats with nets, tiki torches, an indoor lake with boat, the tables are covered by their own tiki hut, every hour there's a simulated monsoon with goes over the tiki huts and into the lake, the boat is where the house band plays. They do have happy hour, but we were too late eating. The meals are quite expensive in comparison to china town, but you do get good portions, and what a venue!. But the main reason people come, is for tiki cocktails in the ceramic glasses, I had a zombie- I finished half and was plastered, I asked the waiter to fill it up with more juice, and it came back even strongerblew my mind! But I loved it! Definately a dining experience!
author: Skintight_Chorltonite

description: so much fun!  I hate paying the entertainment fee they always try to charge me.  and the service is very slow.  otherwise, I recommend this for a good time with friends.
author: olivia s.

description: What could possibly say "Let's have a great night of drinks!" more than mind numbingly immersive Polynesian tiki kitsch decor, overpriced, ornately decorated frou-frou drinks served in miniature hollowed-out Easter Island statutettes along with a lounge band covering one-hit wonders from the 80s 90s and today in the middle of a frigging artificial lake? . . . "um . . . uh . . . nothing . . . ? " say all you over achievers in the front row of the accelerated class . . . well you would be exactly right!!!
author: Matt B.

description: Yuk.  My teeth still hurt from the sugary nastiness.  Who are these people here?  I'm giving it two stars instead of one because it was bizarre to see so many people enjoying themselves in an unironic way.
author: Greg S.

description: My wife and I wanted to go out for a night of dancing when someone mentioned the Tonga Room.  First off, the place is all about the kitchy Island vibe that starts the minute you enter when the doorman presents you with a colorful cloth lei.  The place is layed out like a tropical rain forest lined with grass tiki huts and after some thunder, lightning, and rain, a boat carrying the band fulls up to present the music. Patrons dance on the deck of an old schooner.  The drinks are strong, yet expensive as I had a couple of potent Mai Thai's which loosened me up to joing in the festivities on the dance floor.  The band was rocking and very good. All and all a very good evening and recommeneded to locals and tourist alike - at least once.  The $7 door charge is added to yor bill and the sticker shock wears off long before the memory of a rocking evening in San Francisco does.
author: Nick C.

description: When the niece and nephew came to town from the east coast and requested a night out at the Rainforest Cafe for their joint birthday celebration, I thought "Oh god, no."  I hoped the alternative option of the Tonga Room was a stroke of genius on my part...similar theme, cooler rain storms and non-gut buster food for the adults.  Sadly, we were disappointed.  The rain went down well with the kids and the leis even better.  I'd pre-arranged (discretely) for birthday desserts for the two kids and could hardly wait for the excited surprise in their eyes when the desserts arrived.  Unfortunately, the waiter announced that he would be bringing birthday dessert.  Though the 6 year old was distracted by the tiki surroundings, the 9 year old didn't miss a beat so the surprise was ruined.  In case this oblivious waiter hadn't ruined the moment enough, he proceeded to bring one dessert and sing happy birthday to only the 6 year old.  When we pointed out the mistake, he took over 20 minutes to bring the second dessert to the, by now, pouting 9 year old.  Sigh....what's an auntie to do?  Gut-buster or not, I guess it's all about the kids at the Rainforest Cafe.  Thus, I don't recommend the Tonga Room for special occasions.
author: K S.

description: So we went here on a Friday early evening to squeeze ourselves into the all-you-can-eat buffet, $9.50 per person with a paid drink.  Sounded simple enough.  Well, turns out, other people do the same thing on Friday nights, and so we had to wait more than half an hour in line....wait...maybe even 45 minutes!  At least they served us some fruity drinks during our wait, and I happened to be dying of thirst, so that gesture brought up my spirits despite the long wait.  When we were finally seated, we walked over to the buffet area....I don't know what I was expecting, but whatever it was, it did not meet me there.  There was so little food choices available, and all the choices were more like mini appetizers, except for the noodles...I liked the noodles, but they were kinda cold....but that's to be expected in a buffet, I suppose.  To match with the ambiance, it was really dark in there, and I could hardly make out what I was getting at first, which probably was a good thing that we couldn't see how little there was to choose from.  I mean, the place itself is really cool...we're talking, indoor pool/water show type of cool....but, dark.  I don't like dark ambiance, personally.  The drinks were expensive, but that was expected, and overall, I would say, this was sooooo NOT worth it.  When I walked out to the bathroom, I saw this HUGE line and thought to myself....man, they're just wasting their time...so not worth it...food-wise.
author: W W.

description: After a busy day of walking in the city, my aunt, uncle, mother, and I decided to try the Tonga Room which I had never tried before.  I was looking forward to great fooed and the rain storm that they do and I was not disappointed.  The mai tai, there signiture drink, was sweet with orange and pineapple juice and a lot of liquor (not enough to tone it down or make me stay away,) but definitely strong for anyone who is used to light drinks.  After pondering the menu, we decided to get the Tonga sampler with chicken satay that was tender, flavorfly marinaded and grilled to perfection with a spicy, zingy, tongue tingling peanuty peanut sauce.  The shataki mushroom spring rolls are crispy and greasless filled with flavorful shataki mushrooms and served with a well balanced sweet and sour sauce that is not too sweet or too sour.  The coconut shrimp are huge, crispy, and greasless with a coconut coated badder with a wonderful tart and sweet mango sauce.  The macadamia nut, almond, and scallion flat bread is soft and chewy, but not soggy or hard with the nuts, honey, and scallions making for a plethora of nutty, sweet, and zesty.  The pork ribs are tender with a wonderful honey and five spices marinade and tangy hoi sim sauce.  Our waitress was very nice and attentive, leaving nothing to chance; always checking back not too often to bother us, but not forgetting about us.  The atmosphere is plain happening with young couples to older people staying in town or comming from work to let their hair down.  I llove the traditional bamboo furniture with the nice tables.  The rain storm makes you feel like you are in Hawaii or the Pacific Islands.  So, for excellent, traditional food and cocktails in a fun, casual, festive, traditional atmosphere at a little more than a moderately priced restaurant with a mock rain storm to match, the Tonga Room cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.

description: After a month of hype from SF friends sayinghow fantastic the Tonga room is, I finally went with a bunch of friends for a birthday.  After sitting down, we waited almost 30 minutes for a server to come and take our drink orders (which by the way, were very strong, but tasted nothing like how a mai tai should taste, despite the cute, kitschy mug).  20 minutes later we get our drinks, and are also told that we are about to be charged a $7 cover charge for the band that i couldn't see or hear from where we were sitting.  We stayed anyway, and continued to pay a fortune for incredibly bad service and expensive drinks.  Because we had a bunch of people, we were separated at different tables near by, and when one table decided to leave, they got hit with a bill for the entire group!  (three tables, being served separately). This was about the worst service Ive ever received in SF and I cant imagine how people put up with this. Fun kitschy place to walk in, take a look around, and then leave.
author: Anne R.
